description: Morning

title: Slayer Gets 30 More Years in Jersey
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 30  A house painter serving a life term for the murder of a 22yearold Bergen County woman was sentenced today to 30 years more for the slaying of a 26yearold nurse.

title: Dance: Lucinda Childs and Company
description: Dance, which continues at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through tomorrow afternoon, is a collaborative work by three of the most interesting avantgarde artists of the day  Lucinda Childs, Philip Glass and Sol LeWitt To this taste. the work is a failure.

title: Giants to Let Actions Speak in Cowboy Rematch Holding Back
description: When asked if he knew what might be wrong with the slumping Dallas Cowboys, the Giants coach, Ray Perkins, said, Yep.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Canada in the Doldrums
description: Americans suffering from political malaise might glance northward. The Ayatollah aside, Canada contends with afflictions that are familiar here  plus the torment of Quebec. The minority regime of Joe Clark has dwindled to caretaker status. The opposition Liberal Party will be leaderless until it elects a successor to Pierre Trudeau in March. And the United States shares in Canada's troubles, since the two economies are closely bound by trade and investment.

title: In France, a Better Break For Large Families An Increase in Maternity Leave
description: PARIS, Nov. 30  Two businessmen dash into the Gare St. Lazare here to catch their train to the suburbs, pausing only to buy their monthly tickets. Both men live in the same town but one pays only half as much. Why? Because he has more children. In this case, four as opposed to two for his friend. He need only show his card saying Famille Nombreuse  large family  to get big discounts on trains, buses, and subways throughout France. And he doesn't have to have the children with him.

title: High Winds Believed to Be Cause Of the DC10 Crash in Antarctica Similar Case in U.S. Part of Tail Section Intact
description: Catastrophic Antarctic wind currents swirling about volcanic Mount Erebus were viewed by safety experts yesterday as the most likely cause of the crash of the Air New Zealand DC10 into the moun tainside Wednesday with 257 people aboard.

title: Davidson Finally a Winner
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 30 (AP)  John Davidson, the New Haven goalie, collected three minor penalties tonight as the the Nighthawks scored a 64 American Hockey League victory over the Nova Scotia Voyageurs. The victory was the first in four games with the Nighthawks for Davidson, who had been a New York Ranger regular.

title: 3 Democrats Vie for Key Jersey Senate Job Merlino Backing Carter
description: TRENTON, Nov. 30  Three veteran Democratic state legislators are vying for a twoyearterm as President of the New Jersey Senate. It is an especially coveted position this time because could include an unusual political bonus

Begins Bias Inquiry At Ohio's Public Colleges 3 in.Georgia Family Slain, Apparently by Acquaintance Suit Challenges Mormons On Trial of Rights Advocate

description: AntiAmerican demonstrations appar ently linked to the Iranian crisis were re ported yesterday in Kuwait and the Philippines, where Moslems were pre vented from marching on United States embassies; and in Thailand, where, two bombs exploded in the embassy com pound.

title: Ozawa and 4 Musicians Will Perform in Peking
description: Seiji Ozawa, music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and four of the symphony's members will go to Peking for the Christmas holidays to take part in two and possibly more performances of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. Mr. Ozawa will conduct the Peking Central Philharmonic Orchestra, a local chorus and soloists. The final movement will be sung in Chinese, which may be the first time this has happened.

title: Pratt & Whitney Sets $1 Billion For a FuelEfficient Jet Engine Intend to Remain Competitive
description: The Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, announced yesterday that it would spend $1 billion to develop a fuelefficient let engine.

title: Frances O'Brien, 70, Playwright And College Journalism Teacher
description: Frances B. O'Brien, a playwright and teacher, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Iran Seen Immune To a US. Food Ban
description: By H.J. MAIDENBERG

title: Leading Indicators Down 0.9% Slower Growth Signaled 15Prime Spreads
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  The Government's index of leading indicators fell ninetenths of 1 percent in October, the steepest drop since a 2.4 percent decline in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Market Down 9.39 Energy Issues Rise
description: Stock prices fell yesterday amid renewed tensions in the Iranian crisis. Goldmining issues, apparently benefiting from these tensions, ranked as the market's strongest group and selected energy stocks also moved higher

description: Deatha

title: Champion and Lady; Sports of The Times What He Had to Do A Feeling of Life
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 30 Sugar Ray Leonard and Juanita Wilkinson plan to marry next June 28. The pride of Palmer Park. Md., and darling of television's millions revealed the wedding date before punching Wilfred Benitez loose from his piece of the world welterweight championship tonight in the windupof a threetitle, twocity TV spectacular.

title: Godunov's Appearance In Washington Canceled Report of an Interview
description: Aleksandr Godunov will not dance tomorrow at the John F. Kennedy Cen ter for the Performing Arts in Washing ton as scheduled. Reports also circu lated that the former Bolshoi Ballet star, who defected in August and has not danced in public since, might re turn to the Soviet Union.

title: Britain and Rhodesia Rebels Moving Closer to Accord Meeting With Carrington
description: LONDON, Nov. 30  Britain and the Zimbabwe Rhodesian guerrilla leaders moved closer tonight to agreement on the terms of a ceasefire in the sevenyearold civil war.

title: More Prisons For New York?
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  New York State is on the brink of making one of the most serious criminological and economic mistakes of this decade. It is about to expand its prison system to contain 9,000 more inmates in the hope  vain beyond belief  that this will control crime, and at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars. Admittedly, New York State has far too much crime, and every effort must be made to reduce it. But is prison expansion the answer? It is not, in the opinion of many researchers and criminologists. The best data available suggest that there is no relationship between the rate at which a state imprisons people and its crime rate.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CASTLEWALK As perhaps befits a prominent 19thcentury Shakespearean actor, Edwin Forrest built his house on a hill in Riverdale overlooking the Hudson. It was not just a house. It was a castle  Fonthill Castle  reportedly inspired by Fonthill Abbey, the country house of William Beckford in England. The actor's Fonthill is a finely constructed Gothic castle with six turrets of various heights, pointed arched windows, battlements and octagonal towers.

title: Wilkinson Will Miss Coaching in Pros Joys of Living
description: Bud Wilkinson's secretary put the phone call on hold, and taped music filled the brief waiting time.

title: Sadat Affirms That Shah Is Welcome to Live in Egypt Egypt's Offer the Only One
description: CAIRO, Nov. 30  President Anwar elSadat emphasized today that he was still prepared to offer Shah Mohammed Riza Pahievi a home in Egypt.

title: Algeria, Myth and Reality
description: With military parades and other displays of power, Algeria recently celebrated the 25th anniversary of the start of its revolution against France. Since independence in 1962, it has registered impressive gains, espe daily in heavy industry, military modernization and political institution building. The relatively peaceful transfer of power last February after President Houari Boumediene's death attests to the system's growing political maturity, and there is even some hinting about incipient democracy.

title: St. John's Triumphs Spartans Win, 6046
description: By PARTON KEESE

title: Plan to Cut Yosemite Congestion Is Called Lax by Conservationists Criticism by Conservationists Destruction of Buildings
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP)  The National Park Service has announced a $100 million plan to clear a large part of Yosemite National Park's congested valley of commercial enterprises, but conservation groups say it does not go far enough.

title: Bahrain Shiites Stirred by Iran To New Fervor Khomeini Stirred Emotions
description: BAHRAIN, Nov. 30  It has been going on for many nights now  chanting, breastbeating, mourning processions and bloodletting.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, The Times misstated in some editions yesterday the explanation of yes votes in the rollcall in which the House of Representatives rejected a temporary ban on the construction of new nuclear reactors. A yes vote favored such a ban.

title: Ballet: Bournonville Festival's. Hilarity
description: COPHENRAGEN, Nov. 30  A delighted international audience at the Royal Theater here gave the Royal Danish Ballet an exuberant footstamping, flowerthrowing ovation yesterday and Wednesday when the company presented August Bournonville's hilarious ballets Kermesse in Bruges and A Folk Tale.

title: Soviet Nuclear Device Tested
description: HAGFORS, Sweden, Nov. 30 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union exploded an underground nuclear device today at its testing grounds near Semipalatinsk in western Siberia, a spokesman for the Swedish National Defense Institute observatory said. The signals measured 4.9 on the Richter scale and corresponded to those of a weak explosion, the spokesman said.

title: PRESIDENTDECREES. CURB 0N PAPERWORK In an Executive Order, Carter Puts AgenciesFiurry of Forms in Control of Budget Office What the Carter Order Does
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Tucked away in a corner of the Federal bureaucracy is a bureau designed.. to cut down on the Federal bureaucracy. Its 24 bureaucrats have calculated that it took Americans 913 million hours to fill out 4,900 types of Government reporting forms last year.

title: COMMODITIES Rally in Silver Futures Continues for 6th Day
description: By The Associated Press

title: French Abortion Law Made Final
description: PARIS, Nov. 30  The abortion law passed provisionally five years ago was made permanent today by the French National Assembly. In spite of efforts on one side to liberalize the measure and on the other to rescind it, it was approved by a vote of 271 to 201.

title: Obituary 6 No Title
description: Deaths

title: Wyoming Jury Frees Law Official in Killing Knight of Old West Presented
description: PINEDALE, Wyo., Nov. 30  Ed Cantrell, the former Public Safety Director in Rock Springs, Wyo., who shot his own undercover agent between the eyes in front of two, other policemen, was found not guilty of firstdegree murder today.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 47.

title: Mobil Denies Report of Improper Link
description: The Mobil Corporation, in a blunt and bitter rebuttal, took sharp issue yesterday with a published report that its president had improperly set up his son in a shipping venture that benefited handsomely from its relationship with Mobil.

title: Garden Dies, but Flowers Will Live On; Uprooted Gaillardia Blooms Still Promised to Go Quietly
description: The flowers, the shrubs, the trees and the wellnurtured topsoil of a triangular garden that was an oasis in Greenwich Village are being removed to make a storage area for debris.

title: Mortgage Rate Increase Is Urged
description: A committee appointed by Governor Carey to study housing and lending practices in New York State yesterday recommended an increase of 2 to 2.5 percentage points in the state's mortgage interest rate and a variety of other measures intended to increase the availability of mortgage money in the state.

title: Parking Dispute Snarls Gift Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Thousands of Federal employees, angry over their loss of free parking at Government facilities here, have retaliated by refusing to make charity contributions to the Combined Federal Campaign for the National Capital Area.

title: Sugar Pact Is Ratified By Senate Little Effect Seen On Cost to Users
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  The Senate ratified the 1977 International Sugar Agreement today, an accord designed to stabilize the price of sugar on the world market.

title: Suspect Wins Main Case In Attack on Police Decoy; Released Without Bail 'Entirely Appropriate'
description: A 30yearold Brooklyn man accused of slashing the throat of a decoy police officer posing as a vagrant was found not guilty of attempted murder last night by a State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan.

title: Johnson Wins Title On Knockout in  11th Johnson Stops Galindez
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 (AP) Marvin Johnson nailed Victor Galindez with a looping left to the head to score an 11th round knockout and win the World Boxing Association lightheavyweight championship tonight.

title: Pontiff and Orthodox Leader Pledge Accord Exaltation of Temptation
description: IZMIR, Turkey, Nov. 30  Pope John Paul II and Dimitrios I, the Orthodox Ecumenical Patriarch, pledged today in a joint declaration in Istanbul to hasten the day of full communion between the Catholic Church and the Orthodox Church.

title: The Modern Family: A Deluge of Fears And Complaints Secretary Expresses Hope
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The American family was pictured as an endangered species by hundreds of citizens who voiced concern here today about issues ranging from inflation to the rising influence of cults.

title: Carl W. Andrews, 58, Served as Headmaster For Collegiate School Led a Consulting Concern
description: Carl W. Andrews Jr., former headmaster of the Collegiate School in Manhattan, the oldest private day school in the country, died Thursday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 58 years old and lived in Eastham, Mass., on Cape Cod.

title: News Summary; International National Metropolitan
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1979

title: Mallory Hathaway Bride of Patrice Gravire
description: Mallory Hathaway and Patrice Gravire were married at noon yesterday in the Towson (Md.) Court Building by a deputy clerk of the Baltimore County Circuit Court.

title: Antuofermo Retains His Crown In Disputed Draw With Hagler Hagler Says He Won Antuofermo Keeps Title On a Draw A Slugging Match
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 30  Vito Antuofermo, to the surprise of 10 Italian countrymen and others, retained the world's only middleweight boxing championship tonight by fighting draw with Marvin Hagler. At least, that was the way the fight was scored.

title: Notes on People The Collector, the Cabby and $33,000 in Lost Rare Coins
description: After attending a coin auction Thursday at the St. Moritz Hotel, Tom Morley, a collector from Cocoa, Fla., took taxicab for Kennedy Airport and flight home. But when he stepped out, he absentmindedly left his prize purchase  $33,000 worth of large, 18thcentury United States pennies  on the back seat in a small brown box.

title: Nuclear Power Concern Terms Fine Unjustified
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  The Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., has told, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that a proposed $450,000 fine against the company for safety violations at its Palsades nuclear power plant is unjustified and should not be levied.

title: Rein Gets 4Year Contract To Coach L.S.U. Football
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 30 (AP)  Bo Rein, a disciple of the Woody Hayes brand of ballcontrol football, was given a fouryear contract today to coach Louisiana State University.

title: Obituary 5 No Title
description: FORDESNicholas (Fotiades), on Nov. 29, 1979, beloved husband of Dite loving father of William and George, dear brother of William. Reposing at the Litres Funeral Home (Dahill Chapels), 2525 65 St. corner of Avenue P, Brooklyn, until 10:15 AM, Monday. Funeral service at St. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 11 AM. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. Chapel hours Saturday and Sunday, 59 PM.

title: U.N. Council to Sit Without Iran
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 The Security Council agreed today to go ahead with its planned meeting tomorrow night despite the refusal of the new Iranian Foreign Minister, Sadegh Ghotbzadeh. to attend the session.

title: OBSERVER Changing The Light Bulb
description: A bunch of the boys were sitting around telling lightbulb jokes when the light bulb blew out. Everybody sat chuckling about the irony of it for a while, but finally a voice said, Are we going to sit here in the dark chuckling about irony, or are we going to change the light bulb?

title: Profit Dip in Japan Seen
description: TOKYO, Nov. 30 (Reuters)  A survey by the economic newspaper Nihon Keizai showed that Japanese corporations expect their aftertax profits in the fiscal halfyear ending next March31 to fall an average of 25.2 percent from the preceding six months, when they climbed by 15.6 percent. The survey covered 849 companies listed on the nation's eight stock exchanges. The predicted sharp decline was attributed to the sharp increase in the price of oil and a rise in the cost of imported raw materials.

description: A CHRISTMAS CAROL, adapted and directed by Charles Ludlam; starring Mr. Ludlam, at 1 Sherldan Square, 7.

title: Saudi Says Some Rebels Still Hold Out in Mosque
description: BAHRAIN, Nov. 30 (Reuters)  Some of the armed Motlerns who stormed the Grand Mosque in Mecca 11 days ago are still holding out in tunnels under the building, the Interior Minister, Prince Nayef. said today.

title: Laura Gilpin, 88, Studied Navajos In Her Photographs for 40 Years
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Nov. 30 (AP) Laura Gilpin, the photographer whose studies of Navajos spanned 40 years, died today at St. Vincent Hospital. She was 88 years old.

title: Shutters On the World
description: The emphasis at Windows on the World has shifted from the view outside to the view inside, as sharpeyed doormen, hostesses and waiters appraise the attire of diners.

title: Koch Seeks Funds to Monitor City Drug Programs
description: New York City, the home of three of every 10 narcotics addicts in the United States, needs more money to fight drug abuse and in particular to monitor existing drug programs, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Iranian Warns Europe On Ties to Oil Nations
description: PARIS, Nov. 30  The head of a dele gation from Iran's Revolutionary Council said here today that relations between the West and the East, partic ularly between the petroleumproducing Islamic nations and the West, will depend on the position of the Western nation with regard to the American in tervention in the affairs of our coun try.

description: By RICHARD F. SHEPARD

title: An End to the Chicano Roundups
description: Until Attorney General Civiletti this week put a stop to arresting undocumented aliens in their residences, MexicanAmericans in Los Angeles and elsewhere must have wondered what had become of the Bill of Rights.

title: Medical Malpractice Units Cut Trials, but Not Awards Verdicts Not Binding Concept Not So Bad Medical Malpractice Panels Reduce Trials but Not Awards, a Study Finds Continued From Page 23
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 30  Medical malpractice panels, created by New York State in 1974, have achieved one of their goals  reducing the flood of malpractice trials. But they have failed in their second major objective  cutting the size of awards.

description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 30  Late one Friday afternoon not long ago, messenger gave his employer, Howe, Barnes & Johnson, a small Chicago brokerage firm, two hours notice. He had just been offered $100 a month more than his $10,000 a year to join another brokerage firm.

title: Secretary of Education Is Confirmed by 81 to 2
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) Judge Shirley M. Hutsteiler of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit today was confirmed by the Senate as the nation's first Secretarv of Education.

title: House to Probe Fighter's Death
description: A subcommittee of the House of Representatives is set to join the growing list of Government bodies investigating the death of Willie Classen, the boxer.

title: BeltedBias Tires Made After Oct. 1 Now Graded for Quality by U.S. Treadwear Median Established
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  In the second phase of a threephase operation, all beltedbias tires made after Oct. I have come under the Department of Transportation's system for grading the quality of tires.

title: Urban Institute Names Califano
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. I (AP)  Joseph A. Califano Jr., former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has been named to the board of trustees of the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research organlaption that focuses on the problem of thenation's cities.

title: COMPANY NEWS Xerox to Lift Prices An Average of 6.5%
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (Reuters)  Levi Strauss, & Company said today that its directors had declared a 2for1 stock split, payable Jan. 2 to shareholders of record on Dec. 10.

title: BRITAIN'S AID PLEA TO COMMON MARKET SPURNED AT MEETING SETBACK FOR MRS. THATCHER She Still Wants a $2.2 Billion Cut in Contribution, but Leaves Hope of a Compromise Not Overly Optimistic British Political Opinion United Thatcher Tactics Criticized Common Market Spurns A British Plea for Aid
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 30  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher failed today to persuade Britain's partners in the European Economic Community to approve a huge reduction  $2.2 billion  in the British net contribution to the community in 198081. It appeared to be her biggest setback since she took office in May.

title: New Aide Says Iran Will Not Attend U.N. Session New Aide Says Iran Will Not Attend U.N. Session Reiterates Khomeini's Position The New York Times/Jack Manning
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 30  Iran will not attend the meeting of the United Nations Security Council, the new Foreign Minister, Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, announced today.

title: Old Long Island Mansions Are Her Haunts Nearly 600 Manor Houses
description: She was about 12, she says, when she became obsessed. And while all she can now remember of the house are the arched porticos and soaring ceilings, sne will never forget the feeling of being alone in that vast ruin. After school, Monica Randall would lean her bicycle outside the great iron gate, trot down a long driveway overcome with weeds, crawl through a broken window and become a princess.

title: Mexico Reported to Fear Reprisals By Moslems if Shah Is Readmitted
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30  The Mexican Government decided against allowing the Shah of Iran to return here after signs that it might also become the target of terrorist or diplothatic pressure to send the deposed ruler back to Teheran for trial official sources said today.

title: The U.N. Today
APPEAL COURT BACKS CARTER ON TAIWAN Upholds His Abrogation of Treaty Without Consent of Congress U.S. Appeal Court Upholds Ending Pact With Taiwan Senate Rebuke to Carter Continued From Page 1
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia upheld today President Carter's abrogation, without consent of Congress, of the mutual defense treaty between the United States and the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan.

title: The Region Jersey Is Enforcing Gas Purchase Rules
description: TRENTON  Steppedup enforcement of New Jersey's rules on minimum gasoline purchases went into effect yesterday. The State Energy Commissioner, Joel R. Jacobson, said the $5 minimum purchase for fourcylinder cars and $7 minimum for other vehicles had been in effect since June 21, but had not been strictly observed.

title: Holiday Fatalities on Toll Roads
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)  All but two of 48 toll roads surveyed nationwide recorded no fatalities over the 102hour Thanksgiving holiday weekend, the Inter national Bridge, Tunnel and Turnpike As sociation said. It reported that the single fatalities occurred in accidents on the New York State Thruway and the Penn sylvania Turnpike.

title: Charles Bergerson Dead Voice of America Officer
description: Charles Bergerson, European specialist for the Voice of America, died Thursday at Memorial Hospital in Manhattan. He was 56 years old and a resident of New York City.

title: Joyce Grenfell, 69, British Actress
description: Joyce Grenfell, the British actress whose sketches and impersonations on stage and screen of a variety of wellintentioned but slightly daffy British upperclass ladies delighted viewers on both sides of the Atlantic, died yesterday in London She was 69 years old.

title: World Court Will Hear U.S.Iran Case Dec. 10
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 30  The International Court of Justice has informed the United States and Iran that it will hold a hearing Dec. 10 on the American request that it order Iranian Moslem militants to release the 50 Americans beine held at the embassy in Teheran.

title: Fewer Regulations Urged
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who has sometimes been accused of favoring big government, called today for a reduction in Federal laws and regulations and for speedier justice in the nation's courts.

title: Most Major Banks Cut Prime to 15%
description: Most of the nation's major banks, led by Citibank, lowered their prime lending rates by a quarter of a percentage point yesterday to 15 percent. They failed, however, to match the 15 percent level announced earlier in the week by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Dollar Off Sharply In Europe CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Declines Steeply Against Mark and Franc Termed a Supportive Move Continued From Page 27
description: BONN, Nov. 30  The dollar dropped to its lowest level in more than a year against the West German mark and French franc in European currency trading today.

title: Air Travelers Feel Jammed As Planes Install More Seats An Extra Seat Per Row Air Travelers Feel Jammed In as Planes Add Seats to Increase capacity Reports Loss of 7 Seats Continued From Page 1
description: What happened to legroom? Thomas Hart demanded recently in a Tray0Gram to the Airline Passengers Association. The California sales executive complained that aboard a Western Airlines flight from Phoenix to San Diego I had less than one inch from my knees to seat in front of me. In the event of any sudden stop on the runway, he wrote, I would have bussed the seat in front of me at about nose level.

title: Connally, Stumping Middle West, Intensifies His Attacks on Reagan 11th Commandment Cited
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 30  John B. Connally, who this week is making his first concerted swing through the Middle West in his quest for the Republican Presidential nomination, has sharply stepped up his attacks on Ronald Reagan, whose strength puts him in the lead of the Republican contenders in the opinion polls.

title: Zeppo Marx Dies on Coast at 78 Last Survivor of Comedy Team
description: Zeppo Marx, the surviving member of the Marx Brothers comedy team who left the quartet in 1934 for other businesses, died yesterday at Eisenhower Medical Center in Palm Springs, Calif. The youngest of the brothers, he was 78 years old and had lived in Palm Springs.

title: SovietChina Talk to Go to Peking
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 30  The Soviet Union and China ended two.months of preliminary talks on normalization of relations today without result but agreed to resume negotiations later in Peking, according to Chinese officials.

title: Obituary 7 No Title
description: PUCCIARELLIWilliam. The cers and Members of the Amalgamated Clothing & Textile Workers Union note with deep sorrow sudden passing our colleague friend, William Pucciarelli, a valued staff member of the for more than 40 years. He served with integrity and devotion in a riety of important posts, most cently as Associate Director of Industrial Department. After duating from Fordham Univerity, Bill began his union career as an ganizer in 1938. He worked for years with Laundry Drivers 324 as organizer and business before becoming Education for of the Amalgamated Laundry Workers Joint Board in 1964, also served as Plan Administrator for Local 324's Insurance Fund 1959 to 1973. Having gained a tation as a coordinator of extraordinary skill, Bill Pucciarelli named in 1969 as Office Manager the Amalgamated with responsibility for the smooth running efficiency of the union's international quarters, a function he performed superbly until assuming his recent post. Unfailingly cheerful and untiring as he was In his daytoday duties, Bill was perhaps known to all of us in ACTWU for friendly demeanor and the meticulous attention to detail with he arranged and coordinated the tricate plans for the union ?? conventions. He will be sorely missed by all who were fortunate enough to know him. To his Alice, his brother Anthony, and er members of the family, we

title: On the Hunt for Russian Submarines in the Atlantic Electronic Sensors
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 30  The American submarine hunters call him Crazy Ivan;

title: `WindfallOil Profits Tax Still Stymied in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) The assistant Senate minority leader, Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said today that no agreement had been worked out yet on the windfall oil profits tax bill, which has been stymied in the Senate for two days, and that a filibuster was possible.

title: Bridge: Opening Bid in Rivals'suit Can Sow Seed of Confusion Club Nine Is Led
description: Most kinds of theft  felonious or Ilterary, for example  are entirely deliberate. But theft at the bridge table can be entirely accidental.

title: Japanese Gap in Trade Widens
description: TOKYO, Nov. 30 (AP)  Japan's currentaccount balance of payments, covering trade in goods and services, showed a deficit of $1.13 billion in October, compared with a $792 million deficit in September and a surplus of $364 million in October 1978, the Japanese Finance Ministry announced today.

title: The West Side Plan and the Squatters
description: New York's West Side Urban Renewal Area is unique in the annals of city revitalization because it has successfully mixed people of widely varying income and social condition. To speed the development of the last few sites in the area, the Board of Estimate has now approved a fifth amendment to its plan, to reduce future crowding between 87th and 97th Streets and between Central Park West and Amsterdam Avenue. But the amendment was a mistake. It confuses economic and development problems with a human problem: How to handle 100 squatter families who moved into the area without permission after buildings scheduled for demolition had been emptied.

title: Giving Old Sol His Due
description: BRUNSWICK, Me.  During the millions of years that life has existed on this earth, the sun has seldom been seen solely in its current modes: as a fusion Phenomena to be duplicated. or an energy source to be captured and exploited. It has, instead, been viewed through a third dimension a dimension of wonder, of reverence, of mysticism, magic, worship, gratitude, artistic inspiration, and an awareness of essential mystery. These are the qualities so vividly absent from today's perceptions. Yes, we have astronomers, we have physicists, we have more knowledge of the facts of the sun than ever before. But in a paradox of history, as that physical knowledge has increased, the sun's metaphysical significance has decreased until the personna of our star is eclipsed by the data of its vital statistics.

title: Hostages to What?
description: If the United States and Iran are destined to find a sane resolution of their present conflict, a turning point should be at hand. With the adoption today of a new Islamic constitution and the end of the fervent celebration of holy Shiite martyrs, there may finally emerge in Teheran a government willing and able to return the 50 Americans who have been bound and abused in their embassy. Their release would not compromise Iran's bitter claims on the Shah and his fortune, no matter where he next resides. But it would halt a dangerous slide toward other acts of war.

One sunny Saturday several weeks ago, 3,000 people packed a civic auditorium hear eight authors of current best sellers discuss their literary philosophies, then lined up to have the visiting celebrities autograph copies of their books. Later, several of the guests, veterans of many a bookpromotion tour, were heard to say that this was the most exciting encounter with readers they'd ever experienced. That pleased, but hardly surprised their hosts. This was the fourth annual authorreader encounter they'd held, and writers (Mending the preceding ones had said the same thing. It took place in the heart of the eighth largest book market in the United States, a market that is, per capita, one of the richest.

title: The Public Milked Again
description: As the commercials put it, Milk is a natural. But the price of milk is unnaturally high. A maze of quotas and tariffs, as well as health standards, protect American dairy farmers from lowcost foreign milk products. Federal price supports insulate those same farmers from the sometimes painful effects of domestic competition. And now, in spite of his tough talk about fighting inflation, President Carter has signed a bill that will send dairy prices ever higher.

title: Stage: Five After Eight The Cast
description: How can you write a song about Manhattan when they've all been written before? laments the chorus in Five After Eight, the musical comedy that opened Tuesday night at the Cubiculo, the minuscule theater of the Experimental Arts Club; and the burden of this rather hectic show is to prove that it can indeed be done. Yet the librettist Michael Bitterman has managed to borrow every musical clich known to Broadway. Subtitled A Musical Entertainment, Five After Eight assembles a cast of spirited young actors and puts them through their paces in a chaotic pastiche of West Side Story, Stephen Sondheim and television specials. More a succession of random cabaret sketches than a play, the script by Richard Morton is hopelessly adolescent; the libretto features a succession of indefatigably upbeat numbers with refrains on the order of Look out world, I'm coming through; and the actors are diminished by the roles they have to play.

title: Iran Drafting Plan to Reshape Economy; Imports Are Key Target

title: Gardening Choosing  and Caring for Holiday Greenery
description: THE winter holiday season will soon be upon us, and with it the decoration of our homes, houses of worship and places of business for festive occasions. For centuries, evergreen trees and boughs have been the traditional decorations for these holidays. The ancients considered the living greenery an omen of the eventual return of spring, and much religious significance has been attributed to their use.

description: HARTFORD, Dec. 1 (AP)  State Senator Richard C. Bozzuto formally opened his campaign for the 1980 Republican nomination for United States Senator today, saying that America could regain its No. 1 rank among nations by taking the fetters of government off our people.

title: How the World Bank Manages Its Money; It Generates Yearly Profits Of $40 Million
description: WASHINGTON  Seated at a round table below clocks that give the time around the world, Araceli Gonzaga, shortterm money trader, is trying to squeeze out the best return possible on $110 million she has to invest for 32 days  until a scheduled payment for bond sinking fund falls due. As she places the money at 13 percent in New York, her colleague, Philip R. Spray, is busy getting interestrate quotes from German banks, and Hugo J.H. Shielke, their boss, is on the phone trying to sell some twoyear Treasury notes that he believes will soon go down in value.

title: Rule on Payments by Medicare For Noncovered Service Clarified
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)  Medicare beneficiaries must pay for noncovered services only if their doctors gave them written notice in advance that the Government would not pay for the procedure, an agency of the Health, Education and Welfare Department says.

title: Color Studied for Dollar Coin
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI)  The Susan B. Anthony dollar coin, which has been largely rejected by the public because it is easily confused with a quarter, might catch on better in a different color, the United States Mint says. Cory Gillillana of tne Mint said yesterday tnat further tests were under way on the feasibility of changing the coin's silver color to something like bronze or brass. More than 650 million of the coins have been minted, but only a small number have been accepted by the public.

title: Court to Rule On the Legality Of Set Asides For Minorities; FactBound Analysis Is Likely
description: WASHINGTON  When the United States Supreme Court heard the Bakke and Weber cases, spectators had lined up before dawn to be sure of getting in. The crowds were absent last week for the arguments in Fullilove v. .ICreps, the empty seats surprising even the Supreme Court police who watch the courtroom. Where's everybody? one officer wondered aloud. I thought this was supposed to be another Bakke.

title: Revelations of Womanhood
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR THERE are artists who become inalterably obsessed with one subject. It might be a piece of fruit, the face of a clown or tree, and no matter how nondescript the subject might be to someone else, the artist incessantly goes back to it, rediscovering new aspects about it each time he sees it. The subject and the artist's personality become one, each other's complement.

title: 34 Saudis Moving to Third College In Wisconsin After Student Fights Argument Over Driving

title: Proxmire Gives PrizeFor Air Force Spending

So they bought, among other things, 30 color television sets for $20,000 and resurfaced the base tennis courts for $32.000.

title: Headliners; Pie in Their Eye

So far, it hasn't happened, and last week Albert Meath, who joined the White House as pastry chef in February, said he was leaving Washington in January. Mr. Kumin, who became celebrated in New York as master of desserts for the Four Seasons and Windows on the World, will return to the staff of the Culinary Institute of America, in Hyde Park, N.Y. Among the reasons Mr. Kumin gave for his departure were the cost of living in Washington and the absence of modern machinery and =pasteurized cream in the White House kitchen.

title: Concert: Mahler's Third From the Baltimoreans The Program Satchmo! Tribute on Dec. 8
description: There was only one work on the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra's program Friday night in Carnegie Hall, but nobody complained. The work, conducted by Sergiu Comissiona, was the Mahler Third Symphony, which runs well over an hour and a half without intermission. It is not often played; it demands huge forces, including mezzosoprano solo and chorus, and it is not one of Mahler's more accessible works. Dimitri Mitropoulos loved to conduct it, and of course there was Leonard Bernstein in the days when he was putting Mahler on the map. More recently, in 1976, Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic took it on.

Its somewhat oppressive air of French provincialism is relieved by pleasant scenery and some splendid restaurants. It is the very heart of the French Pacific  and the center of fastbrewing trouble.

title: Earl Jones: Preparing for His Vocation; Jones: Preparing for His Career
description: MOUNT HOPE, W.VA. EACH morning last spring in this Appalachian mining town, Margaret Jones watched the front door of Mount Hope High School from her post as assistant cook in the cafeteria, checking to see if her son Earl had arrived for class. With basketball season over, the 6foot11inch youngster  one of the finest high school players in the country and the most renowned in West Virginia since Jerry West  had stopped making the short walk to school, down a rutted road, past the ramshackle houses beside the railroad tracks. For 63 days of the second semester of Jones's junior year, his mother watched the door while the youngest of her eight children stayed at home in bed.

title: Cleveland Strike Talks Resume
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 (AP)  Efforts to end a 95dayold teachers strike resumed today between the city's school board and representatives of the 5,000member Cleveland Teachers Union. Negotiators met for nearly three hours this morning before recessing so board of education members could meet privately.

title: Fresh Weathers
description: American Indians left their mark not just on place names and tomatoes and tobacco and other fruits of the New World. They also left it, indirectly, on the weather, as in Indian Summer. That was the time, said the Indians, when after the first frost of autumn, the air would suddenly turn warm. The sky would go bright and hazy, or smoky, as the Indians put it, because some faroff god had lit his pipe. After that, chilly autumn would return in earnest.

title: Docking Delinquents
description: You want another reason to hate inflation? Here's one. Starting with the current tax year, it will cost you twice as much money for interest on delinquent and late tax payments, and the size of the increase is directly related to the rising cost of money.

Today. our laughter has an odd, dark undertone. Harry has just returned from his. 40th high school reunion. I've just attended my 25th. The experience has shaken both of us, although neither of us seems willing to admit it.

title: The Case for Thomas Wolfe; Wolfe
description: AMID the many reminiscences devoted to the 50th anniversary of the Depression, a literary event that shares the same date has gone unnoticed: the publication of Look Homeward, Angel. There was a sense of dread and ominous foreboding in the air, Thomas Wolfe recalled in You Can't Go Home Again. Millions of people in the faroff hamlets, towns, and cities did not know what to make of it; and it was into this atmosphere of false calm and desperate anxiety that his first novel was launched in the autumn of 1929.

title: A Second Time, France Passes A Law Making Abortion Legal
description: PARIS  One side of the rue de i'Universite was lined with the blue buses of the tough riot police. Across the way, under the walls of the National Assembly, small groups of people, mostly women and mostly middleaged, huddled fingering rosaries and whispering prayers. Inside, after four days of debate, the Assembly voted 271 to 201 last week for a new, permanent French law permitting abortions in the first 10 weeks of pregnancy. Senate approval is expected.

His election must be approved by a majority of the active Episcopal bishops and standing committees of all dioceses. Bishop Belden died Nov. 4 in Denver.

But now, even the staunchest critics are pleased with a new plan that encompasses only one intersection  all, that is, except one group that may become the most formidable adversary yet 17 Polish nuns.

title: GARDENING Choosing and Caring for Holiday Greenery
description: THE winter holiday season will soon be upon us, and with it the decoration of our homes, houses of worship and places of business for festive occasions. For centuries, evergreen trees and boughs have been the traditional decorations for these holidays. The ancients considered the living greenery an omen of the eventual return of spring, and much religious significance has been attributed to their use.

title: U.S.South African Discussion on Shah Is Hinted; South Africa Expected to Agree
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 1  South African and American officials offered guarded comments today on the possibility that the United States had asked South Africa to provide sanctuary for the deposed Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Editors' Choice
description: DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Golding. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A magic fable that explores the darkness of human nature through the fortunes of Matty, brushed by fire as a boy during a World War II blitz, and of numerous people he later encounters in Britain and Australia.

title: Books on the Wing; Birds
description: Every December, Audubon Society chapters across the country participate in the Christmas Bird Count, fanning out over field and fen to conduct a census of every bird they see. Since bird watching has burgeoned as an American pastime, the need has arisen for another kind of tally: a Christmas Bird Book Count. For, just as dependably as whistling swans arrive every fall in Chesapeake Bay, there appears every autumn a flock of new books vying for a place on the Christmas lists and cocktail tables of the more than 10 million Americans who are avid birders.

title: The Pickles Were Made at Home; Sheraton
description: FROM MY MOTHER'S KITCHEN

description: THE winter holiday season will soon be upon us, and with it the decoration of our homes, houses of worship and places of business for festive occasions. For centuries, evergreen trees and boughs have been the traditional decorations for these holidays. The ancients considered the living greenery an omen of the eventual return of spring, and much religious significance has been attributed to their use.

title: CALENDARS; Motor Sports Horse Shows Dog Shows
description: Today  Wing and Bonnet Sports Car Club 60mile T.S.D. rally; start at Steinbath's in Manalapan Mall, Route 9, Freehold, N.J. Registration: 11 A.M.; first car off 12:01 P.M.

title: MiddleClass Bellmore Getting U.S. Aid; Bellmore Getting Federal Funds
description: BELLMORE MERCHANTS in downtown Bellmore are hoping that the infusion of $250,000 in Federal funds will reverse a trend of deterioration that has plagued the area for more than a decade. Many storekeepers blame the deterioration on the increasing popularity of large, enclosed shopping malls such as Roosevelt Field, which they say have siphoned away many customers.

title: Claire Ambler Wed To Gary L. Russell
description: Claire Wistar Ambler, daughter of Wistar Ambler of New York, and Mrs. Edward Byrd McGeorge Jr. of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Gary Lloyd Russell, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Russell of Buffalo, were married yesterday. The Rev. Herbert

title: World's Postal Services Receive Permission to Raise Letter Rates
description: BERN, Nov. 29 (AP)  Postal services throughout the world have received approval to raise international letter rates by as much as 100 percent, following the Universal Postal Union conference last month.

title: Obituary 7 No Title
description: Deaths

title: WASHINGTON AGENDA DISRUPTED BY CRISIS; Meetings, Decisions, Official Trips and Appointments Are Stalled by Attention to Teheran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  Zbigniew Brzezinski had to pass up a scheduled trip to Europe, Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti was forced to cancel eight speeches within two weeks, and the White House advance team made the arrangements for four Presidential trips, all of which were scratched.

title: SPEARING PERSONALLY Hail; New Atlantic, Home
description: MOVING 200 miles to my new home in Englewood has been complicated by the intangible confusion of adjusting to life in a national joke.

title: Water Report Called Suspect State Water Report Is Called Suspect
description: TRENTON AREPORT by the state's Department of Environmental Protection that says the quality of water in New Jersey has been improving has been called suspect by a member of the Governor's Committee on Hazardous Wastes.

title: Portuguese Right Expected to Triumph in Vote Today; New Life for Government
description: LISBON, Dec. 1  The Portuguese will vote tomorrow for a Parliament that, soundings of opinion suggest, could mark a sharp shift to the right, a break with the fading leftist legacy of the 1974 revolution of the flowers.

title: WHAT THEY ARE SAYING
description: Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback, on what told Matt Bahr before the rookie kicked a 37yard field goal with nine seconds left in overtime to beat the Cleveland Browns: We try not put any pressure on him. We just said, Miss it and you're cut.

title: ANTIPOLLUTANT GEAR IN CARS IS CRITICIZEDFires, After Vehicles Were Parked, Attributed to Heat Generated by Catalytic Converters
description: WASHINGTON (AP), Dec. 1 driver parked his 1977 Cadillac over a pile of leaves on a suburban street here. A few minutes later, the leaves burst into flame and set fire to the car and a Chrysler parked nearby.

title: Nofthwest's BoomTown Lights Impede Study of Aurora Borealis Move to Switch Lamps
description: RATTLESNAKE MOUNTAIN, Wash., Dec. 1 (UPI)The starry night sky isn't what it used to be in fastgrowing southeast Washington, and that is bad news for astronomers at the Rattlesnake Mountain Observatory. Booming towns in the area are glowing brighter at night, interfering with the observatory's studies of the aurora borealis, or northern lights.

title: PARKWAYS ASSIGNED TO STATE TROOPERS They Get Job in New York on Jan. 1 on General Traffic Routes-- Police Transfers Planned Parks Responsibility Continued
description: ALBANY, Nov. 28  The familiar blue and gold cars of the New York State police will start patrolling parkways on Long Island, the Palisades Interstate Parkway and several upstate parkways Jan. 1.

title: Illegal Tenants Fought; Illegal Tenants Are Drawing Lawsuits
description: Denise and Michael, a young unmarried couple sharing an Upper East Side apartment, were recently threatened with eviction by their landlord even though they had never missed a rent payment, caused any property damage or disturbed the peace. The problem was that only Denise's signature appeared on the lease.

title: Major News; In Summary Religious Fervor Stiffens Teheran's Refusal to Bargain
description: There may yet be, Inshallah, a bloodless resolution to the Iranian crisis but last week was clearly not ripe for it. Clashing notions of law and morality permitted no compromise. While lawyers and diplomats at the State Department and United Nations followed international legal procedures to seek freedom for 50 American hostages, the followers of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini were fervently reenacting a Shiite Moslem morality play in which the United States had been assigned the Devil's role.

title: Music Notes: The Saxophone; From Suburbia
description: When Adolphe Sax invented the saxophone in the 1840's, he assumed it would take its place among the classical instruments in existence. It has done that to a certain extent, but today it is best known for its use in the field of jazz. One man who is out to restore the saxophone to its original status is Harvey Pittel, who will give a recital on the instrument in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

title: IN THE NATION The Allies And Iran
description: WASHINGTON  It may seem only a sidelight to the Iranian crisis that the West German Government has criticized an American bank that took legal action to attach a 25 percent Iranian investment in Krupp, the German steelmaker.

title: The Feisty Sheik of Alberta
description: Alberta's production of light and medium crude is declining rapidly  it will be gone in under 10 years  so we are just not prepared to sell substantially under commodity value for any extended period . . . If we don't get such an arrangement, Alberta will have to reassess this winter its continued sale of light and medium crude.

title: Katharine Anne Keresey Bride
description: The marriage of Katharine Anne Keresey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Keresey of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of Mill Neck, L.I., to Andrew Mitchell Ault took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of BethesdabytheSea in Palm Beach. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Burchenal Ault of Santa Fe, N.M., formerly of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Maureen Gentzkow, Teacher, Is Married to John B. Bryson
description: Maureen N. Gentzkow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Nolan of Valley Stream, L.I., was married yesterday to John B. Bryson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel L. Bryson of New Dorp, Staten

title: Madison Borough Retains Title
description: Madison Borough and South River, two of New Jersey's most potent high school football teams, each collected a third straight state championship yesterday.

title: Time Limit Rejected In Alimony Ruling
description: A DIVORCED law student who is seeking to have her former husband pay alimony until she qualifies to practice despite the stipulation in their divorce decree that the payments shall terminate after three years, won an important legal victory last week in the state's highest court.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: SIDESHOW, by William Shawcross. (Pocket, $2.95.) An account af United States diplomatic policy and military iperations in Cambodia after 1969 that charges Henry A. Kissinger and Richard M. Nixon with responsibility for its eventual takeover by the Khmer Rouge. Although It was published in hardcover just last April, it has been rushed into paperback because it counters the story Mr. Kissinger tells in White House Years. In writing it, William Shawcross, a British journalist, drew upon interviews with hundreds of participants as well as Government documents, some of them classified Top Secret.

title: ANTIQUES Historic Setting for Norwalk Show; CALENDAR
description: NORWALK TOYS that first delighted youngsters more than a century ago, scrimshaw carved by sailors in the 1840's, gleaming silver and crystal as well as furniture and other accessories of the 18th and 19th centuries will be featured in the antiques show to be held at the LockwoodMathews mansion here next Saturday and Sunday.

title: Jessy Lilly Wolfe Bride Of Raymond L. Dirks Jr.
description: Jessy Lilly Wolfe, daughter of Mrs. Frederick J. Wolfe of New Orleans and the late Dr. Wolfe, was married yesterday to Raymond Louis Dirks Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dirks of Needham, Mass. The Rev. F. Forrester

title: 3 Years for Blind Man Who Shot 7YearOld
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 (UPI)  A 60yearold blind man who shot a 7yearold boy in the head as the youngster tried to retrieve a ball from his yard was sentenced to three years in prison for being a former convict in possession of a gun.

title: Useful Skepticism; Author's Query
description: THE CLAL I OF REASON

title: Queens Museum Preparing Exhibition on World's Fair Nostalgic Paraphernalia
description: Plasterers were spackling new dry walls, painters were painting and cleaners were vacuuming the Queens Museum's 22,000 square feet of new gallery space to prepare for its opening next June when one of the building engineers made a discovery.

description: EMPTY WORDS

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE; HARTMAN'S NEW HOME PORTRAITS AT YALE THE SANTA EXPRESS CHRISTMAS CHAMBER SONGS MIDDLEEASTERN DIALOGUE COMMONER IN WESTPORT A FOLKART FESTIVAL
description: The Hartman Theater Company's blacktie opening of Georges Feydeau's farce, The Ribadier System, is scheduled for 8 P.M. Wednesday at the company's new location, the Stamford Theater.

title: The First Lady of Cartier
description: PARISEvery day of the work week, at about 12:30 Nathalie Hocq begins to disrobe in her office on the swanky Rue de la Paix. Off comes the designer dress, the bangles on her wrist, gold chains around her neck, tank watch and gold ear clips, dotted with diamond chips. On go the sweatsuit, socks and sneakers. After a skip and a jump down the street, Miss Hocq, her long brown hair pinned up, whips once around the formal Tuileries Gardens before she returns to the staid establishment just minutes away.

title: U.S. Aide Visiting Cairo for Talks About Arms and Egypt's Forces
description: CAIRO, Dec. 1 (Reuters)  The United States and Egypt discussed the research, development and manufacture of arms as well as use of American expertise in organization and training, the Egyptian Defense Minister, Gen. Kamal Hassan Ali. said today.

title: Architecture Firm's Fortune Rises on Conversion Tide; Fortunes Rise With the Conversion Movement
description: Stephen B. Jacobs has become accustomed to carving unusual, complex apartments by necessity out of former bakeries, convents, factories, hospitals, printing houses, warehouses and the like. But today much of the complexity of his current projects is by design, not necessity.

title: And There's Even a Diet Pasta Dish; **Da Marcello
description: ADD Da Marcello in Manorhaven to your list fine Italian restaurants. It has been open only a couple of months in the premises formerly occupied by the Aqua Manor restaurant.

title: HalfMile Blaze in Ditch Laid to Children at Play; Allegations on Dumping
description: MARRERO, La., Dec. 1(UPI)Children playing with matches yesterday turned a drainage ditch into a halfmile stream of flames that destroyed four buildings. Parish officials said that they might take legal action against a company that had dumped a gasoline product into the ditch.

title: Christmas Areas Brace For Rush on Postmarks
description: BETHLEHEM, Ga., Dec. 1 (UPI) Several small towns across the United States, like this one, are already starting to receive the annual deluge of letters and postcards for Christmasseason postmarks.

description: Margaret Tillman Gibson, who is with the Department of State in Washington, and Henry Alexander Thompson, governmental and laborrelations officer with the HBH Company, builder of naval bases and trainer of navy personnel in Jubail, Saudl Arabia, will be married in Washington on Dec. 29.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Events Today
description: Christmas at Richmondtown: Restored American village decorated for Christmas; tours and crafts demonstrations; 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Richmondtown Restoration, Staten island. (Call 3519414 for information.)

title: All Power to the Ayatollah, Proclaims New Iran Charter; No Deviations Allowed
description: TEHERAN, Iran  The Constitution drawn up for the new Iran, to be voted on in a referendum today and tomorrow, outlines a remarkable way to run a country.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING Neighbor, Spare That Tree
description: I WENT to a planning and zoning meeting in my town a few weeks ago. I went to save a tree. As fond as any homeowner of the trees in the immediate neighborhood, I was there to protect a giant oak that had soared majestically over the edge of my property for well over 100 years. Now it was in imminent danger of death by regulation and even possibly execution by municipal saw.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS; Steve Shagan
description: Steve Shagan, who calls himself es sentially a screenwriter, insists there was no thought of a movie deal in his head when he closeted himself in his Beverly Hills office two years ago and began to write his third novel, The Formula. I just wanted to have fun and not be burdened by deals. I didn't even have a contract. I hadn't written a novel in about two years and needed to get out of the straitjacket restrictions of the screenplay.

title: BOOK ENDS; Sumptuous Diet
description: Wondering what a phenomenally bestselling commercial book means to a modestsized publishing house  not so much in financial terms as in unworn to take on other books that may not have a cashregister ring to them  we asked Rawson, Wade about the shape of things after The Complete Scarsdale Medical Diet. The book is heading toward one year on the Best Seller List, with nearly threequarters of a million copies in print. That's the kind of diet book that keeps publishers plump.

title: Dole Wants to Revive LincolnDouglas Style
description: DES MOINES, Dec. 1 (AP)  Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, said today that the the Republican Party should return to the Abraham LincolnStephen Douglas style of debating, and urged that Presidential candidates hold such headtohead confrontations.

title: Anthony Newman Has A New, Mellower Image; The Mellower Anthony Newman
description: Just a few years ago, Anthony Newman was the wild man of music. Well, maybe not exactly wild, but at least strange and abrasive and extreme.

title: Northford Woman Finds Fashions; of the Past More Petite Than Today's
description: NORTHFORD SEVENTH Avenue may be taking its inspiration from the last few decades, but Sarah Smith wears the real thing from generations before the Retro look. Preferring the lacy feminine clothes of the turn of the century, she has been collecting and wearing them for several years.

description: By Anthony Hecht. 91 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $10. Paper, $4.95.

title: 33 Bighorns Treated As Rescue Drive Ends
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Dec. 1 (AP) Federal and state wildlife officials have ended one of the most dramatic wildlife rescue operations in the nation's history after capturing and treating 33 Desert Bighorn sheep for a rare scabies epidemic.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE State Bar Association's Client Security Fund, created in 1961 to reimburse those duped by dishonest lawyers, has paid out $2.5 million, according to a report by trustees of the fund.

title: Giants Sign Zachary Dixon
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 1 (AP)  The Giants today signed Zachary Dixon, a running back from Temple. The 6foot, 204pound Dixon was picked by the Denver Broncos on the 11th round of this year's National Football League draft. He played six games with Denver before being cut.

title: Project Shakes Up Neighborhood
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 1 (UPI) A moneysaving construction method being used to erect a school over a former landfill literally shook up an Indianapolis neighborhood Monday.

title: Leader of Mine Union Seeking Power to Fill Vice President's Post Special Election Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The newly elevated head of the United Mine Workers of America, Sam Church Jr., is moving quickly to consolidate his control over the 250,000member union, which was racked by internal disputes under the recently resigned president, Arnold R. Miller.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Stifel Plans To Be Wed May 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Stifel of Short Hills, N.J., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Snead Stifel, to George Christian Hansen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton D. Hansen of Moline,Ill

title: Fishermen Find Profit Is the One That Got Away; Fishermen Find Profit Elusive
description: MONTAUK IN the black of night, Scott Bennett grabs his pipe and jeans, throws the teakettle on the stove and calls the boys. By 4 A.M., the 41yearold captain and his crew are cruising out of Montauk Harbor aboard the 52foot trawler Seafarer in search of a day's catch. For the last 30 years he has been following a similar routine.

title: New Jersey/ This Week; THEATER
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Death of a Salesman, In an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Dec. 15). $3.5045.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50; group rates. (201) 4297682. Westminster Theater.

title: What's Doing in the ALGARVE
description: WINTER SUNSHINE  Even in the dead of Europe's winter, the weather in the Algarve, the southernmost province of Portugal, remains mild. The air temperature is usually in the 60's and the sea rarely falls below 59 degrees. This climate may not be perfect for the beach and bathing, but it is pleasant enough for outofseason vacationing when the hordes of summer tourists are absent.

title: Sarah Harper Plans To Be Wed in June.
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. Harper of New York and Locust, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Harper, to Robert M. Dorer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Dorer of Wilmington, Del.

description: ALTHOUGH the thermostat is the central operating control for the home's heating system  it tells the furnace or boiler when to send up heat and when to shut it off  this instrument gets little or no attention from most homeowners.

description: Fund to Aid the Neediest Nearing Its 68th Season

title: Virtuosos of the Woodwinds and Horn; European Woodwind Virtuosos
description: Now that James Galway and JeanPierre Rampal have proved that a flutist can achieve superstar status, is there any hope for those musicians who play the oboe, clarinet, bassoon and horn? So far there have been no comparable celebrities among musicians who perform on the lowerpitched instruments of the wind quintet family, but talent runs high here and eventually a performer may succeed in capturing the public's imagination on an international scale. Some, in fact, seem to be trembling on the verge of doing just that.

title: A Young Senior Runs Up the Score; SPORTS
description: BRIGHTWATERS ONE of these days somebody is going to beat King Van Nostrand in a tournament tennis match, but until it happens the wiry, redhaired 6footer will remain the No. 1 senior player in the Island, the East and perhaps in the country.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR; The Proficiency Test And Its Role in Education
description: An opinion piece by David Ifkovic in the Nov. 11 Connecticut Weekly (Academic Proficiency Tests: They Are Not the Answer] raised many interesting and challenging questions, but failed to include information which, if omitted, can create misleading and incorrect information.

title: Marlboro Tightens; Monitoring of Food
description: MARLBORO AT THE state psychiatric hospital here, where five people died in October from what is believed to have been food poisoning, state sanitarians, according to the hospital administrator, found no major breaches in food handling.

description: WASHINGTON BETWEEN now and next April, 9,000 to 10,000 men and women will be mobilized in New Jersey to take and tabulate the 1980 census, and many will be picked by the timehonored practice of first winnine the approval of politicians.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING RentStabilization Expansion Asked
description: ANGERED by large rent increases in the last few months, Westchester apartment dwellers have begun to talk of tenant power, to organize and to demand that rent stabilization be expanded to new communities.

description: AMITYVILLE  Abstract landscapes by Richard Vaux; noon to 6 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays; through Dec. 23; Amityville Art Gallery, 127 Merrick Rd.

title: Anderson, Presidential Prospect, Gets $5,000 From Abortion Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1A Republican Presidential candidate, Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois, today accepted a $5,000 contribution from the National Abortion Rights Action League's political action committee.

title: Weather Brightens HeatingOil Outlook; Weather Brightens HeatingOil Outlook
description: THE prolonged Indian summer that has warmed the Island and much of the Northeast with unseasonably high temperatures in recent weeks is expected to help homeowners use less fuel this winter heating season.

title: Ebony Spleen Wort and a Carrot Force Up Price of Sewer System
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Dec. 1 (AP)Protecting a small endangered fern, the ebony spleen wort, and a species of wild carrot is doubling the cost of a proposed sewer system for the village of Augusta.

title: U.S. Black Hebrews Ostracized by Israelis; Barred From Public Schools
description: DIMONA, Israel  Thirtyseven black children in long blue robes were wedged uncomfortably onto benches and chairs in the tiny basement room of an apartment house in this desert town. Despite the cramped conditions, their attention to their teacher was unwavering. There was no teasing, no talking out of turn. When called on, each stood politely to recite.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MAYORELECT Alan M. Parente of the City of Glen Cove says his first objective when he takes office in the new year will be to get some development going in the downtown renewal area.

title: MARRIAGES INCREASE FOR IRANIANS IN U.S.; Crisis Prompts Some Students to Wed Americans  Tempers on Campuses Are Cooler
description: Before Iranian students seized the United States Embassy in Teheran four weeks ago, the usual rate for IranianAmerican marriages in Houston was about one a month. Last week, 20 Iranians seeking to marry Americans showed up at the Harris County Courthouse and applied for marriage licenses.

title: Regina B. Wiedenski Engaged to Wed Brian P. Backner

title: New Publisher in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1 (UPI)  Ashton Phelps Jr., 34 years old, today took over the job held by his father and once held by his greatgrandfather  president, chief executive officer and publisher of The TimesPicayune Publishing Company, which publishes both of this city's daily newspapers.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE; OLYMPIC POSTER SALE
description: The raccoon, which can extract the contents of a padlocked garbage pail in minutes, is the 1980 Winter Olympics mascot. His face can be seen on Tshirts, bumper stickers and official posters, some of the latter to be personalized by Donald Moss, the designer, from 1 to 4 P.M. Saturday at the Portfolio Gallery in Cross River. The posters are priced at $10.

title: Morris County Salutes Washington
description: MORRISTOWN ASCORE of Morris County organizations began a series of events yesterday to commemorate the bicentennial of the Continental Army's second winter encampment here in 17791780. The programs will run through May.

title: Heinz Calls lithe Hernia Pack
description: Insiders at H.J. Heinz call it the hernia pack: quite simply the largest bottle of ketchup designed by man. Eight years ago Heinz introduced its 32ounce Keg of Ketchup, which soon became the company's bestselling bottle. Perceiving an even greater hunger for the condiment, Heinz last year brought out a fourpound bottle  22 ounces of glass, 44 ounces of ketchup. The phenomenal success of this experiment encouraged grander fantasies at the Heinz marketing division. The bottle now in the works will be 30 to 40 percent larger than the 44ounce size.

title: Bullets Overtake Nets, 104100; Key Players Missing
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 1 The New Jersey Nets came here tonight riding the crest of a threegame winning streak and looking forward to their fourth victory before a threeday layoff. Instead, they left with yet another loss in the final minute, 104100, to the Washington Bullets.

title: Miss Ridder Plans Bridal

description: The crucial piece in the puzzle at a robbery trial in Queens was whether an undercover police officer had actually been in a position to observe the face of the driver of the getaway car.

title: Historical Societies Widening Aims
description: LONG before the current resurgence of interest in preserving historic places, almost 200 volunteeroriented historical societies in the state were rescuing, preserving and restoring such sites and serving as the public's reminder of local heritage.

title: Oil Expert Says Israelis Should Develop APower
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 1 (Reuters)  An Israeli expert on oil exploration said today that Israel should develop atomic energy and stop wasting money on speculative drilling for oil.

title: Other World Events; Antarctic Tragedy
description: A DC10 airliner on a sightseeing trip crashed into the side of an Antarctic volcano last week, killing all 257 people on board. It was the fourth most deadly plane crash in history. Three of the disasters involved DC10's, but this time experts suggested that violent Antarctic wind gusts were fault. In 40 years of operations, the carrier, Air New Zealand, had never before had a fatal accident. Recovery teams searched for evidence and bodies around the wreckage 2,500 feet up the 12,400foothigh, snowcovered slope of Mount Erebus. But their efforts were hampered by winds of up to knots, with higher gusts. Because of the crash, a flight celebrate the 50th anniversary on Thursday of Adm. Richard E. Byrd's aerial exploration of the South Pole was postponed.

title: POINT OF VIEW Oil: Why There Were Those Profits
description: Big oil companies with access to foreign crude were charged last week with having diverted supplies to the spot market to increase their profits. The charge was contained in a study prepared by Terence L. O'Rourke, special counsel on energy to Alfred E. Kahn, the President's adviser on inflation. The following is an abridged version of Mr. O'Rourke's report.

title: Assessing Fairfield County's Housing Bind; 147 Housing Solutions Proposed
description: A state commission that has been studying what it describes as the housing crisis in Fairfield County has published a preliminary list of recommendations, among them the possibility that corporations be required to subsidize the construction of housing for their middle and lowerlevel employees.

title: N.F.L. Turnaround: Pass Setting Up Run; Change in the Pro Passing Game
description: During the CBS radio broadcast of last Thursday night's MiamiNew England game, Hank Strain, the analyst and a former National Football League coach, said more than once that the best and almost only way for the Patriots to attack the Miami defense was by passing, not running. Although the Patriots lost through malfeasance.

title: the Great Chateaus
description: Cinderella before or after the ball. But it came as a disappointment to her when she, found that this twostar restaurant had no onion soup and that the available cold lobster soup could not be heated up. She made short work of the filet mignon, the biggest she had ever tackled, however, and was happy with the fresh strawberries  although she refused the little wild fraises de bois. (Dinner without wine came to $35 a person.) As we went to bed that night at 10  an hour and a half after Fiona's normal bedtime  we wished her mother could have shared in our pleasures.

title: Anthony DavisExplorer in Jazz Piano; Anthony Davis Explorer in Jazz
description: When the pianist Anthony Davis settled in New York City in 1977, he already had an impressive reputation. He'd attracted some initial attention while still attending classes at Yale, and his first recording (as a sideman with the composer and trumpeter Leo Smith) and early appearances as a group leader in New York prompted several critics to praise him extravagantly. The city's jazz musicians gave him their own seal of approval: Leroy Jenkins, Oliver Lake and a number of other group leaders hired him to play in their bands or on their albums. To each of these assignments, Mr. Davis brought a multitude of gifts. He was sensitive to the most involved structural demands; he had an extraordinary ear for nuances of texture and coloring; he ranged easily from abstract idioms to solemn mainstream swinging, and he edited himself as he went along, so that both his solos and accompaniments were concise, gracefully deliberate, and packed with provocative, intelligently ordered ideas.

title: Screen: 'Robert et Robert,' Claude Lelouch Comedy:The Cast
description: Wearing the expression of a dog who expects to be kicked at any minute, Robert Villiers (Jacques Villeret) looks as unhappy as he actually is most of the time. He is overweight, forever second-guessed by a pushy mother, and so unsure of himself that he apologizes for the noise when he turns the page of a magazine in a waiting room. You know that he'd never go out of the house if his shoes squeaked.Robert is a student policeman but the chances are slim that he'll ever make the grade as a Paris gendarme. His way of dealing with a traffic accident is not that of the gendarmerie. Instead of officiating at the scene with the proper biliousness, Robert flees, often close to tears.Robert Goldman (Charles Denner) is no better adjusted, though he attempts to mask his unworthiness by being impossibly arrogant. This Robert is a taxi driver, as was his late father, much to his mother's long-lived disappointment. But Robert Goldman takes taxi-driving seriously. He prides himself on his knowledge of Paris and on giving his passengers service de luxe, including their choice of tea or coffee during the journey.Neither Robert is obvious marriage material, so it's probably natural that they should meet in the waiting room of a matrimonial agency, one that guarantees its customers satisfaction with the aid of a computer that is able to match a man who likes hot chocolate with a woman who likes hot chocolate. When Robert Goldman objects that he doesn't want a woman who's exactly like him, the head of the agency, Mr. Millet (Jean-Claude Brialy), says sagely, "Remember, your wife would be your best friend if she were a man," which stumps Robert for a moment.Claude Lelouch's "Robert et Robert," which opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse, is the diverting, very funny tale of the growing friendship of Robert Villiers and Robert Goldman, two of the world's least predatory misfits, and of how they break through to social success in ways they could never have expected. Like all Lelouch comedies, "Robert et Robert" is infinitely generous, both in spirit and to its characters, but, unlike many earlier Lelouch films, it is not more generous than we in the audience want it to be."Robert et Robert" has the great good fortune to have two exceptionally fine actors in the title roles. Mr. Denner, who has been a star in French films for years ("Landru," "The Bride Wore Black," "The Two of Us," "The Man Who Loved Women," etc.), is an old friend, and the sham hauteur he displays here is not too different from the self-satisfaction he exhibited as the obsessed rat-catcher in Franois Truffaut's "Such a Gorgeous Kid Like Me."Mr. Villeret will be a discovery for American audiences, though he has had small roles in such earlier Lelouch films as "And Now My Love" and "Another Man, Another Chance." For reasons I don't quite understand, he reminds me of a very young, portly Peter Lorre, perhaps because behind that facade of quiet desperation there are hints of the existence of an intellect that is far from passive and innocent. However Mr. Villeret works on the consciousness, his performance is exceedingly comic and appealing without ever slopping over into the sort of lazy sentimentality that sometimes mars Mr. Lelouch's films.The excellent supporting cast is headed by Mr. Brialy, who's in the process of making a most graceful transition from star roles to character parts, and Regine, the singer and nightclub hostess, who plays Mr. Villeret's acid-tongued mother, a woman who finds sexual satisfaction through the same agency that fails her son."Robert et Robert" is not entirely free of Mr. Lelouch's tendency to hoke up things that would be more effective if played-straight. There's also no reason at all that both of the leading characters should be named Robert, except that someone thought it would be a cute title. Yet these sugary affectations and sunny mannerisms, which have often made Mr. Lelouch's films look like commercials in search of name-brand products, never succeed in distorting the comic, no-nonsense decency of Robert and Robert. They are good company.

title: Pilot Swerves DC9 Off Runway To Avoid a Collision on Landing

title: East Germans And the Hunt: A Serious Pair Only Members Can Shoot
