description: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 1  At daybreak a bugle sounded on a gray, wet Saturday, and 90 members of the Nassenheide Hunting Society set out for a day of shooting hare near the East German town of Kremmen in the low, wooded countryside north of Berlin.

title: Jazz: Max Roach Quartet
description: The quartet that Max Roach led at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue near 17th Street, through last night is more a collection of individual virtuosos than an ensemble. Mr. Roach puts strong ernphasis not just on solos, which are common hallmark of jazz groups, but also on unaccompanied or minimally accompanied solos.

title: Kenyan in Appeal on Iran Crisis
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec.1 (AP)  President Daniel arap Moi called on all churches and religious bodies in Kenya today to remember the United States Embassy hostages in Teheran in their services tomorrow so that God may relieve them and their relatives from mental anguish and torture.

title: Egyptian Cancer Clinic Offering to Treat Shah
description: CAIRO, Dec. 1 (UPI)  If the deposed Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi comes to Egypt, he could get treatment at the Cancer Institute of Cairo, its director said today.

title: Music: Debuts in Review Paul Capaccio, Pianist With a Hard Sound
description: Paul Capaccio, who performed last Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a young Jullliardtrained pianist who lives in Clifton, N.J. For the most part, Mr. Capaccio produces a hard, chiseled sound, and more often plays loud than soft. His fingerwork is accurate, clean and muscular. There is nothing suave about such playing, but, in the right kind of music, it has its merits.

title: Words of Our Fathers; Words
description: HOW WE LIVED

title: Style/Christmas Gifts(2)
description: Socks and a globe for him, lingerie and slippers for herwhile the requests on your list may sound common, the things you find to fill them with can be uncommonly inspired.

title: Innovative Program Prepares Minority Pupils for Prep School; 300 Recommended, 37 Chosen
description: The delegates to the Constitutional Convention of 1787 were debating carefully such questions as whether the importation of slaves ought to be permitted.

title: Crisis Alters Attitude in U.S.; May Have Reached Turning Point; Iran Crisis Helping U.S. Shed Fear of Intervention Abroad;Relation to Oil Supplies; Collision With Commitment; Looks at Every Beehive; QuickStrike Force Authorized; Slow Reversal of Trends
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The Iranian crisis has brought about an important shift of attitudes here that, many believe, will have a significant longterm impact on the willingness of the United States to project its power in the third world and to develop greater military capabilities for protecting its interests there.

title: E.P.A. to Investigate Herbicide Over Concern on Birth Defects
description: MUSKEGON, Mich., Dec. 1 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency next week will undertake an investigation of the herbicide Oryzalin because of charges that it could cause birth defects.

title: Role of Magistrates; Widening in District
description: WASHINGTON THEY are a rare breed in the Federal court system, usually little noticed but about to assume added responsibility to help clear dockets.

title: IN THAW, EGYPTIANS NAME SOVIET ENVOY; Ambassador Assigned to Moscow as LongCool Relations start to Take a Turn for Better
description: CAIRO, Dec. 1  Egypt's relations with the Soviet Union, which deteriorated over recent years nearly to the point of rupture, have subtly improved after apparent efforts on both sides to smooth over differences.

title: Letters; Regulating Discos
description: To the Editor:

title: Bicyclists Find Progress in PedalingTheir Cause; Some Interesting Advances
description: Although some bicycle enthusiasts pun about pedaling their cause since the invention of the wheel, Congress has mounted the twowheeled bandwagon only in the last two years. Earlier this month it appropriated $4 million toward the improvement of bicycling.

title: Children's Concerts Return to Carnegie
description: Children's concerts will return to Carnegie Hall after a lapse of almost a decade, when the American Symphony Orchestra, led by Paul Dunkel, plays a series of six free daytime events there Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. The concerts will be heard by 15,000 school children.

title: Letter  TO THE EDITOR; The Pen Is Mightier ...
description: Those who read Paul Heath Hoeffel's and Juan Montalvo's disturbing Missing or Dead in Argentina (Oct. 21) will, think, be interested to learn that the pseudonym Juan Montalvo alludes to the famous 19thcentury Ecuadorian essayist of the same name.

title: Shelley A. Morrison Is Married in Jersey
description: Shelley Ann Morrison, daughter of Mrs. John Fraticis Morrison of Convent Station, N.J., and the late Mr. Morrison, was married there yesterday morning to Edmund Robert Kowkabany of Hackensack, N.J., son of Mrs. Gilbert W. Cullen of Ridgewood,

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Problems of ecumenical holidays.

title: Shipping/Mails Outgoing
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Prosecutor in Jordan Inquiry Seeks New York Office and Early start; Duration of Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  Arthur H. Christy, the independent special prosecutor appointed this week to investigate allegations that Hamilton Jordan used cocaine, plans to work from an office in New York City, will hire a small staff of lawyers ana secretanes ana may use me Federal Bureau of Investigation or the Drug Enforcement Administration to assist him.

title: Miss Goodyear, Lawyer, Fiance Of Dr. B.G. Wolff
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harold Goodyear of Columbus, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Beth Goodyear, to Dr. Bruce Giles Wolff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Luther Horn Wolff, also of Columbus.

title: Girl Whose Pajamas Caught Fire May Get $4 Million in Settlement
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 1 (AP)  A 9yearold girl who was seriously burned when her pajamas caught fire four years ago may receive $4.3 million from the companies that made and sold the garment.

title: Future Events; Skating or Disco?
description: Dec. 4  The Foreign Friends of New York, a new group eager to show its love for the city, is making its debut at a cocktail gala with dancing from 6 to 9 P.M. at Regine's. The event, to benefit the Public Schools Athletic League, is the first by the nonprofit group. Among the founding members of the fledgling organization are diplomatic representatives from Spain, Italy, Brazil, West Germany and Kuwait, as well as many prominent Americans. To accommodate the group's frivolous evening, Mrs. Roger Choukroun, known as Regine, is donating her New York disco. Tickets are $75.688.0516.

title: Sporting Gear
description: More boatmen are realizing that constructing a custom craft, using a commercially sold kit, is almost as satisfying as using the finished product. Among the choices offered by Country Ways are six models sailboats (from $445 to $2,165), an iceboat ($725), six kayaks (from $170 to $235), two canoes ($245-$260) and a dinghy ($260). The kits include all necessary materials, a tested pattern and instructions. The steps that require machines or specialized technical skills have already been completed by the manufacturer. The kits are available at outdoor and marine stores, or can be ordered from Country Ways, 3500 Highway 101 South, Minnetonka, Minn. 55343, (612) 4734334.

title: British Airline Halts Iran Flights
description: LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP)  British Airways announced today that it had suspended flights to Iran indefinitely because of the political situation there. The line is advising passengers to contact Iranair, now the only airline flying between London and Teheran.

title: Tension Unified the Jets
description: IN the beginning, there were boos at Shea Stadium yesterday. Boos when Walt Michaels was introduced as the Jets coach. Boos when Richard Todd trotted onto the field as the quarterback. Boos when Dave Jacobs, the new placekicker, not only missed a 34yard fieldgoal attempt but also missed the ball  he scuffed the ground with his kicking shoe before making contact with the ball. Chilidipped it, golfers would say. But then Jacobs made field goals of 28, 27 and 42 yards. Deadly Dave, flashed the message board on the auxiliary scoreboard. Richard Todd completed 12 of 26 passes for 215 yards and one touchdown despite the cold, swirling winds that always swoop off Flushing Bay late in the season. The defense recovered three Baltimore Colt fumbles. Joe Klecko blocked a punt that positioned another touchdown. And when Walt Michaels strode off the field after the 3017 victory, no boos were heard. Only cheers.

title: Establishmentarian
description: As everyone has heard by now, there is an American Establishment. Depending on one's prejudice, its denizens, graduates of elite schools, have an appetite for power or public service. But what is now supposedly common knowledge was originally a spoofing thesis propounded by Richard Rovere, the political journalist who died last week at the age of 64. Rarely has a Joke so rabidly become part of nonular wisdom.

title: Woman Survives Fall At the Empire State
description: A 29yearold woman apparently jumped from the 86thfloor observation deck of the Empire State Building last night, but survived when she landed on a threefoot ledge about 20 feet below, the police said. She was admitted to Bellevue Hospital with a fractured pelvis.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The closeknit international banking community hasbeen badly rent by the actions taken by large Amkricari banks to seize Iranian assets and declare their loans to that nation in default. European bankers chargb the Ainerican actions arepoliticalfy motivated, in an industry that stresses its a political nature, [Page D1.]

title: Music: Miss Amacher
description: UNLESS you find yourself in an acoustical chamber, there is always something to hear. In other words, no matter how silent a space supposedly is, the sharpeared listener can perceive something. And if that listener is esthetically oriented, he can make an artistic experience out of his perception.

title: Marguerite Yourcenar's Tranquil Literary Life on Maine Coast
description: NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me.  She is MOW, simply, Madame. When one inhabitant of this pretty village, on Mount Desert Island off the morthern coast of Maine, asks another, How is Madame? everyone knows who is meant.

title: Eagles, Steelers Get Playoff Berths
description: With only two weeks left in the National Football League regular season, not one of the six division titles has been clinched. Of the five teams that had an opportunity to nail down playoff berths yesterday, two were up to the challenge.

title: South African Blacks Dispute at Ford Motor Reaches to the Heart of EqualRights Struggle
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Nov. 29 The church hall in the dusty township was packed, a thousand or more men crowding in to hear their leaders denounce the Ford Motor Company for dismissing 700 workers, practically the entire black labor force, from an assembly plant in this town on the Indian Ocean.

title: Connecticut Ambulance Boycott Threatened Over Welfare Rates
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 2 (AP)  Commercial ambulance companies in Connecticut are threatening a limited boycott it the State Health Department does not increase its payments for transportation. services for welfare patients.

title: Commodities
description: WHETHER the price of a cornmodity futures contract moves up or down, one thing is certain: Most of the nonprofessional traders in that market will lose money. Experienced brokers estimate that between 85 and 90 percent of the small traders come out losers.

title: Cleveland School Board Will Ask Judge to End Teachers Walkout
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 (AP)  The strikebound Cleveland school system will ask a judge tomorrow to order teachers to end their 96dayold walkout, the school board president, John E. Gallagher Jr., says.

title: Rebellious Mennonite Faces New Test
description: PLAINFIELD, Pa., Dec. 2  For the last seven years, Robert L. Bear, a 50yearold Reformed. Mennonite who farms outside this small central Pennsylvania town, has been shunned for questioning the purity of the Reformed Mennonite religion. Former friends and fellow church members have reviled him, some calling him crazy or evil, and have refused to have any contact with him.

title: Omega Watch To Mel Richman
description: Mel Richman Inc., a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., company specializing in advertising and sales promotion, has been making time with Omega Watch. This has resulted in the agency's landing the account, which will be raising its budget substantially in 1980.

title: Wings Stage Rally And Tie Flyers, 44
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) Dan Labmaten scored with 3 minutes 7 seconds remaining in the game to cap a threegoal Detroit rally that earned the Red Wings a 44 tie with the Philadelnhia Flyers tonight.

title: Bankruptcies: Read All About It
description: EDGEMONT, Pa., Dec. 2  Bankruptcy, in general, is not thought of as profitable venture. But to Leonard E.B. Andrews, president of Andrews Publications, corporate failures represent future business.

title: March by  AntiAmerican Students Broken Up by the Pakistani Police
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 2 (Reuters)  Pakistani students demanding compensation for the family of a student killed in the attack on the American Embassy in Islamabad last month clashed with the police today in Rawalpindi.

title: Security MixUp Delays Shah's Motorcade to La Guardia
description: Evading television crews and photographers staked out at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahievi was taken by F.B.I. agents and his own security guards from his 17thfloor suite shortly after 4 A.M. yesterday to the hospital's subbasement and through a tunnel that led to a garage in a building two blocks away at East 71st Street.

title: Westinghouse Nuclear Center
description: PITTSBURGH Dec. 2  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation plans to apply the lessons of Three Mile Island in a new nuclear training program.

title: No One Was Running, But Town Picks Mayor
description: MORRISON, Tenn., Dec. 2 (A P)  A small group of dedicated people have just voted in Morrison, even though no one was running for anything.

title: Iranian Assails Asset Freeze
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The head of Iran's central bank has accused the United States of trying to strangle the Iranian economy.

title: Heisman Riddle Answered Today
description: Victories by Alabama, Houston and Texas A and M Saturday solved the problem of who was going to fill the five remaining bowl assignments. This left two important questions to be ancumnsel who is the outstanding player in major college football this year?

title: Sports Today
description: Saints vs. Oakland Raiders, at New Orleans Superdome. (Television  Channel 9 P.M. Radio  WCBS 9 P.M.)

title: ABROAD AT HOME Patience And Fortitude
description: BOSTON, Dec. 2  It is a month since the mob seized the American Embassy in Teheran. We can see now that there has been a desigh in the tactics used by Ayatollah Khomeini and the students over that time. The an has been to provoke the American public and Government  to goad us into rash action that would damage our interests.

title: Mystery Is Presented by Jellyfish In Water of Virginia Stone Quarry
description: ROCKFISH, Va., Dec. 2 (UPI)  Jellyfish have been found flourishing in a granite quarry in the shadow of the Bluel Ridge Mountains near here, and how they arrived is something of a mystery.

title: Music: Chopin Is Played By JeanneMarie Darr
description: FOR some pianists, performing can nearly seem a lifeordeath ordeal, demanding the most strenuous concentration and exhausting emotional commitment.

title: Mustering in Colonial Style
description: As their livenant waited with military patience, mernbers of the Staten Islimd Militia Bil/Ops Corps tugged and pulled and squirmed and twikted to attention yesterday during maneuvers at the RishmondtOwn restoration. The Militia came out along with appropriately costumed townsfolk for a recreation of a Colonial Christmas in Richfnoncitown; sponsored by members/ of the women's auxiliary of the Staten Island Historical Society.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Ernie Duplechin had been coach of the defensive backs at McNeese State University in Lake Charles, La., for 14 years when he was suddenly elevated to head coach in the middle of a football practice on Aug. 15. He replaced Jack Doland who had just received a promotion of his own when he became president of the school.

title: When Putting In a Good W4O1R1D2 Is What Counts
description: In the room the people come and go, talking of words like imbroglio.

title: Chess:
description: A recurring theme in mating combinations is the importance of the fianchettoed bishop in defense. If it can be eliminatedeven at the cost of a small sacrifice if necessary  the defender may be hopelessly compromised.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 1, 14, 28, 27, 25 and 19. The supplementary number was 38.

title: Flight Recorders Are Recovered In Search at Antarctic Crash Site
description: SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Dec. 2 (Reuters) Recovery teams today found both the flight recorder and flightdeck voice recorder of an Air New Zealand DC10 that crashed in Antarctica on Wednesday, killing all 257 people aboard.

title: Nurses Strike at 2 Hospitals
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 2 (AP) Nurses and maintenance and support workers at Women and Infants Hospital went on strike today after allnight negotiations failed to produce agreement on a new contract. Thomas J. Parris Jr., executive vice president of the hospital, said 100 supervisory personnel and 50 volunteers were providing care to the 180 patients. Meanwhile, there was no end in sight to an unrelated strike by 180 registered nurses at St. Joseph's Hospital that began Nov. 24.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter provided a refuge for the Shah in an Air Force hospital in San Antonio. A White House statement said the Shah was moved from the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center to Texas so that he could have a secure place to recuperate pending further travel plans. But the President, responding to a reporter's question, seemed to leave open the possibility of permanent asylum for the Shah in the United States if he cannot find a haven abroad. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: New Work's Talc Miners: A Dual Fight for Survival
description: GOUVERNEUR, N.Y.  At stake have been the lungs of the workers who mine and mill talc, and the economic health of this mineralrich but dirtpoor region.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: A California jury has assessed the Standard Oil Company of California $12.6 million in damages for oppressively or maliciously breaching a supply contract with Seaman's Direct Buying Service of Eureka, Calif., a small fuel supplier.

title: The Region
description: A complaint by an employee of New Jersey's Health Department has led to a determination that a chemical capable of causing cancer was in the air of department laboratory in Trenton. Certified letters suggesting a physical checkup at state expense were sent Saturday to 10 current enployees and to 47 others, some of whom had left the agency as long as five years ago.

title: When Giant Industries Falter
description: U.S. Steel is closing 16 plants in eight states, laying off 13,000 workers. Chrysler is certain to close plants to save itself. Economic giants seem to be falling before our eyes. And since little people get hurt when giants fall, there is a natural public instinct to rush to the rescue.

title: Frequent Failures of Seat Belts Are Found by a Consumer Group
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  Seat belts frequently fail in automobile crashes, allowing hundreds of deaths and injuries each year, a consumer group said today.

title: Croquis, $36.80, Victor at Big A
description: Croquis, competing for the first time since last September at Belmont, won the $43,700 Busher Handicap yesterday before 18,647 fans on a fast track at Aaueduct.

title: Nordiques 3, Canucks 1
description: QUEBEC, Dec. 2 (AP)  Real Cloutier scored a goal and set up two other scores tonight, enabling the Quebec Nordiques to snap a sevengame victoryless streak with a 31 triumph over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Bowl Lineups
description: Garden State Bowl  Dec. 15, East Rutherford, N.J.: Temple (92) vs. California (65).

title: Europeans In Rift With U.S. Banks
description: BONN, Dec. 2  The closely knit fabric of the international banking community is showing increasing signs of unraveling because of repercussions from the Iranian crisis.

title: Stage: Bent, Starring Richard Gere
description: WHETHER or not author Martin Sherman can carry us all the way to the blistering climax of Bent, he's got.a powerful sense of theater going for twothirds of his bizarre, bloody journey. Along the way be may be willing to use the tricky surprises of suspense melodrama to make sure we're startled to attention, but he never uses them Cheaply.

title: Snow oredesters. Crestfallen
description: If the question was where were the /snows of yesterday?  as predicted by at least two professional sources the simple answer was Two positives made a negative. And last night, acording to the National Weather Service, there was still no snow in sight for the New York metropolitan area.

title: Bears 14, Buccaneers 0
description: AT TAMPA, Fla.  For the second week in a row, the Buccaneers failed to clinch their first division title. The Bears (8.6) climbed to within one game of Tampa Bay's firstplace perch in the N.F.C. Central Division. Defensive alertness led to both Chicago touchdowns. Bruce Herron blocked a punt and two plays later Walter Payton scored on a 1yard plunge. Then Gary Fencik intercepted a pass, one of four thefts of Doug Williams's tosses, and returned it to the Chicago 46. After a couple of penalties against Tampa Bay, Mike Phipps passed to Dave Williams who completed a 13yard scoring play with a sprint into the end zone. Ricky Bell led the Buc offense with 24 rushes for 80 yards. Payton, who gained 77 yards on 22 carries, set a Chicago record with his 60th career touchdown, breaking the previous mark of 59 he had shared with Rick Casares.

title: Deaths
description: AHEARNJack. Friends may gether at Walter B. Cooke Inc., 1504 Third Avenue, N.Y.C, Monday, December 3rd, 68:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Official of Store Beaten to Death At Riding Stable
description: A 36yearold Alexander's departtnent store exicutive and onetime Stars Senate candidate who became the focus of a political controversy in Westchester county last year was found bludgeoned to death saturday afternoon in a wooded area near a riding stable in Eastcheatert, N.Y.

title: Conferees Hear a Controversial View of Incest
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  Afterward they used terms like provocative and thoughtprovoking to describe the speech, but as Prof. LeRoy G. Schultz delivered his address last week at the first national conference on the sexual abuse of children, the phrases bandied about by the audience were male chauvinist and oh, my God.

title: Wall Street Challenge: Volatility
description: The real challenge facing Wall Street in the coming years is neither capital nor diversification nor markets, but management. Where once brokers could count on relatively steady markets for relatively generous earnings, News Analysis now tney must leant to thrive on volatility, to profit by helping their customers adjust to rapidly changing economic and financial conditions.

title: U.S. GRANTS SHAH SANCTUARY IN MILITARY HOSPITAL IN TEXAS; ASYLUM QUESTION IS LEFT OPEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  President Carter gave Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the deposed Shah of Iran, temporary sanctuary today at art Air Force hospital in San Antonio and left open the possibility of permanent asylum if another suitable haven for him was not found abroad.

title: Aspin Says All Navy's New Ships In Four Years Were Delivered Late
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)  Not a single one of the 47 new ships received by the Navy in the last four years has been delivered on time, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Stephanie A. Hale, Architect, Married
description: In Temple Rodeph Sholom yesterday afternoon, Stephanie Andrea Hale, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Aaron Hale of New York and Rensselaerville, N.Y., became the bride of Dr. Howard Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Weiss of New York. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony.

title: An L.I. State Hospital Will House Youths Accused of Violent Crimes
description: Because state laws enacted last year require that juveniles who commit violent crimes be jailed separately, an unused wing of the Pilgrim State Mental Hospital in Brentwood, L.I., is being converted into a prison for such youths. The first 15 prisoners at the facility, to be operated by the New York State Division for Youth, are scheduled to arrive in midJanuary.

title: Television
description: 5:50(5)New Zoo Revue

title: United Press International
description: MRS. WALLACE TAKES A SENTIMENTAL JOURNEY: Cornelia Wallace, former wife of George C. Wallace, former Governor of Alabama, performing as a guest with the Cypress Gardens Water Ski Review Saturday In Winter Haven, Fla. Mrs. Wallace had starred at the recreational complex in 1961.

title: De Gustibus Portulaca Uses
description: There was recently a vigorous increase in the correspondence to reach this desk following a discussion of purslane and portulaca. Someone had inquired about the uses of portulaca or purslane in salads. I admitted ignorance as to the uses of the purslane herb, which was referred to as portulaca.

title: Carter Aide Sees Impact Of Aliens on Joblessness
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (AP)  The unemployment rate in the United States could be reduced to less than 4 percent if it were not for the presence of undocumented aliens, according to Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall.

title: Developing Gasohol
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J.  A relatively new word in our vocabulary is gasohol. Gasohol is a blend of 90 percent gasoline and 10 percent ethanol (ethyl alcohol). Gasohol costs a little more, but it gives a little better gas mileage to justify the price. Gasohol is going to be a big thing. The Department of Energy has estimated that the production of ethanol for fuel use will climb to 600 million gallons per year by 1985, up from 100 million this year. Major financial incentives are available to ethanol producers. Congress has been debating legislation with more incentives.

title: Notes on People
description: A Christmas party for youngsters with cerebral palsy was just getting started at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in the South Bronx Saturday afternoon. John Saunders of the Bronx was pushing 19yearold Marcus Pagan in a wheelchair from group home on East 149th Street when, suddenly, a car careering out of control came straight at them.

title: Sabres 2, Capitals 0
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 2 (UPI)  Rick Martin got his 12th and 13th goals of the season 1:53 apart in the final period tonight to give the Buffalo Sabres a 20 victory over the Washington Capitals. Bob Sauve stopped 20 shots to earn his third shutout of the season.

title: Education of Richardson
description: When Red Holzman played for City College in the 1940's and later for the Rochester Royals and the Milwaukee Hawks in the National Basketball Association, he was called a playmaking guard. The same term was later used to describe Bob Cousy, Oscar Robertson and Walt Frazier. Now, although playmaking remains the same, the name has been changed  to point guard.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: COVADONGA (Spanish Line Kerr Steamship). Santander Dec.12, Bilbao 13, Lisbon 14 and Cadiz 15; sails from Port Newark, N.J.

title: Dance: Ailey Homage to Joyce Trisler
description: THE New York dance world lost one of its steadiest presences with the death in October of Joyce Trisler, the moderndance choreographer and teacher. A coiieague since 1951, when the two met while, dancing with Lester Horton in Los Angeles, Alvin Ailey has dedicated the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's winter season at the City Center55th Street Theater to Miss Trisler. On Thursday, the company performed Mr. Ailey's new Memoria, a work dedicated to the joy, the beauty, the creativity and the wild spirit of my friend Joyce Trisler, as Mr. Ailey's prdgram notes put it.

title: Jazz Dexter Gordon's Annual Concert
description: FOR his third annual concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening, Dexter Gordon, the tenor saxophonist, supplemented his regular quartet not only with Woody Shaw, the trumpeter and fluegelhornist, who has appeared there. with Mr. Gordon before, but also with the Barry Harris strings (an 11piece ensemble), the Barry Harris Singers (17 voices), two dancers, Tina Pratt and Scobey Stroman, and Mr. Harris himself, who alternated on the piano with Kirk Lightsey, Mr. Gordon's pianist.

title: Pakistan Getting Tide of Refugees Frorri Afghan Civil War
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 28  The rising number of Afghan refugees arriving here and the worsening physical condition of many of the newcomers attest to a harsh civil war in Afghanistan made harsher by winter snows.

title: Mondale Filling In for Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)  Vice President Mondale will substitute for President Carter at campaign fundraising events in New York, Chicago and Atlanta this week. Mr. Carter, who plans to formally announce his candidacy Tuesday, cancelled the fourday campaign swing to keep close watch over events in Iran. Mr. Mondale is scheduled to appear in New York City on Wednesday, Chicago on Thursday and Atlanta on Friday.

title: Building Off 9% in October
description: A moratorium on nuclear power plant projects was the major cause of a 9 percent drop in new construction in October to $14.2 billion, the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Inc. said yesterday. It was the fourth consecutive decline reported by Dodge, which is a leading statistician of the construction industry.

title: World Gymnastics Spur Hopes of U. S.
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The 20th World Gymnastics championships opened today, marking the first time the event has been held outside Europe.

title: Book Calls High Court's Actions Affected by Justices Private Rifts
description: Supreme Court Justices, like other public figures, have on occasion allowed political posturing and personal antagonism to affect their work, according to new book on the Supreme Court that was quoted extensively yesterday by Newsweek magazine.

title: Letters
description: Americans often seem bewildered when foreigners, especially thirdworld peoples, reveal deepseated hostility toward them  despite all that we have done for them. Sometimes this hostility derives from the manner in which U.S. aid is given, which often breeds widespread cynicism about what America's real motives are.

title: Expelled Boys to Return To School Under Order
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Dec. 2 (AP) Two students who were expelled because their mothers did not sell enough tickets to a school fundraising event are to return to class tomorrow under court order.

title: U.N. Council Debates Iran Crisis as Diplomats Caucus
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 2  The United Nations Security Council held second session of its emergency debate on Iran tonight, as diplomats struggled behind the scenes to find some way to resolve the crisis.

title: Reed in Hospital
description: Willis Reed was admitted to New York Infirmary Hospital Friday. The former Knick star and coach was stricken while hunting in upstate New York. He is reportedly being treated for an intestinal blockage.

title: 3 Key TaxExempt Sales
description: The taxexempt bond market will face three important sales of state issues this week that should provide this sector of the credit markets with its most significant test of interestrate levels in three weeks. TripleA yields are likely to run from 7 to 7 percent for the first time.

title: 2 Churches in Kansas City Merge In a Racial and Financial Accord
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 2  It is a modern sanctuary, with lots of glass and blond wood choir stalls, but until a few weeks ago there was no choir. Many Sundays, the people worshiped with no music at all because there was no one to play the organ or the piano.

title: Getting Mortgage Money Moving
description: Governor Carey is right in urging a special session of the legislature to deal with the disappearance of mortgage money from New York. The reason is simple: New York's present usury law limits lenders to receiving 10 percent interest on their mortgage loans.

title: Vietnam Says Cambodia Denies It Is Hindering Aid
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec: 2 (Reuters)  The Vietnamesebacked Government in Cambodia denied it was hindering Western aid shipments, The Vietnam News Agency said today.

title: St. John's Victory Gratifies Coach
description: Coach Lou Carnesecca and his St. John's team did some celebrating Saturday night after beating Michigan State, the defending National Collegiate basketball champion, 8873, in the final of Joe Lapchick Memorial Tournamnent. But yesterday was Just another day.

title: Helene Verin Wed in Illinois To Rodney Ripps, an Artist
description: The marriage of Helene Verin to Rodney Ripps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Michael Ripps of Douglaston, Queens, took place yesterday in Highland Park, Ill., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Verin. Rabbi Robert Marx performed the ceremony.

title: Icelanders Voting for Parliament
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 2 (UPI) Icelanders began voting today amid high winds, sleet and rain to elect a new government whose main task will be to deal with soaring inflation and ties to NATO.

title: Shah Is Flown. Out of New York, Gets Tight Security in San Antonio
description: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 2  Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi flew here today from New York and continued his hospital convalescence behind a United States Air Force security screen at. Wilford Hall, the major Air Force Medical facility.

title: U.S. Triumphs In Soccer, 30
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 2  The United States Olympic soccer team, with a starting eleven comprised of 10 players under contract to professional teams and one 18yearold collegian, defeated Bermuda, 30, today in a qualifying game.

title: India and Bangladesh Trade Fire in Border Dispute
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 2  For more than a month India and Bangladesh have been engaged in a shooting match at the border town of BeIonia in northeastern India, but life goes on as usual for both the Governments and the people.

title: Asset Freeze Alarms The Arab Oil Exporters
description: KUWAIT The Finance Minister of this wealthy Persian Gulf sheikdom held a banquet the other day for his United States counterpart, G. William Miller, but spent most of it personally selecting food for an American reporter on his right.

title: Chiefs 37, Seahawks 21
description: AT KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Chiefs held the Seahawks to only 18 yards rushing and 81 yards passing as they took a 377 lead early in the fourth quarter. Seattle started without three regulars who had been injured, and lost six more regulars during the game. Ted McKnight got two touchdowns and Jan Stenerud kicked three field goals for Kansas City.

title: Concert: Handel's L'Allegro
description: HANDEL'S L'Allegro, IL Penseroso ed it Moderato (1740) consists of two parts in which verses of Milton's poems L'Allegro and Il Penseroso alternate, followed by a third section of text by the man who made the arrangement of the Milton, Charles Jennens.

title: CARIBBEAN LEADERS EXPLAIN VIEW ON U.S.
description: MIAMI, Nov. 30  The small and populous nations of the Caribbean are still eager for United States trade, investment and technology, but they are vulnerable to promises of paradise, Caribbean leaders warned here this week.

title: Sports Briefs
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2  The topwinning whippet in America and the recordholder for the breed was named best in show at the Boardwalk Kennel Club dog show, the largest oneday indoor show in the East thus far this year.

title: Music: For the Love of It
description: FOR the Love of Music. is the name of a series of chambermusic performances that enlists a shifting assortment of musicians not necessarily associated regularly with the chambermusic repertory. This season the series has moved to the Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodman House, and it offered its first performance there yesterday afternoon.

title: Bankruptcy Warning On Itel Loss
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2  The Itel Corporation reported a thirdquarter loss of $176.1 million and warned might have to seek protection in bankruptcy proceedings if creditors enforced in full the terms under which received $1.1 billion in loans.

title: Cardinals 13, 49ers 10
description: AT ST. LOUIS  Ottis Anderson scored the deciding touchdown on a 6yard run with 2:53 remaining, and became the first rookie in N.F.L. history to gain more than 100 yards in each of eight games. He picked up 129 yards on 26 carries and was only 24 yards away from the rookie rushing record of 1,450 set by Earl Campbell last year.

title: Two Are Killed as Van Overturns And Bursts Into Flames Upstate
description: BREWSTER, N.Y., Dec. 2 (AP)  Two Connecticut men were killed today when a van overturned and burst into flames on an exit ramp from Interstate 84 here, the state police said.

title: U.S. Facility in Bangkok Warned of More Attacks
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 2. (AP) An anonymous telephone caller today threatened another bombing attack against the United States Embassy here and the Thai police further tightened security at the diplomatic compound, an embassy spokesman said.

title: Government Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The Federal Government spent $128 million on advertising last year and was the 25th largest advertiser in the nation, Advertising Age reported. Most of the advertising budget, up 10 percent from 1977, went toward armed forces recruiting efforts, the trade magazine said. The recruiting ads cost more than $96 million.

title: The City
description: The bodies of two young women whose heads and hands had been cut off were found yesterday on burning beds in a West 42d Street motel room by two firemen.

title: Islanders Conquer Jets, 40
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 2 (AP)  Bob Bourne set up goals by Anders Kallur and Bob Nystrom tonight and Billy Smith recorded the team's first shutout of the National Hockey League season to pace the New York Islanders to a 40 triumph over the Winnipeg Jets, ending the Islanders sixgame streak without a victory.

title: A History Park For the City
description: If you exclude art museums, which not everyone enjoys, New York City boasts surprisingly few tourist attractions fora city that accommodates 17 million visitors a year. It is particularly bereft of historic landmarks because many buildings that today would have been regarded as such have fallen victim to headlong developMent.

title: Iranian Charter Is Greeted With Fervor and Misgiving
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 2  The polling place was in the inner courtyard of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini Mosque near the Teheran bazaar, and to reach it All Akhbar Bayat had to ease past a huge tree whose trunk was splashed with slogans urging Iranians to support a new Islamic constitution.

title: Kennedy Center Honors Five For Life Achievements in Arts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  When lustrous stars from the world of the perforMing arts mingle with powerful stars from the world of politics as they did this evening at the second annual Kennedy Center Honors gala, an intangible electric quality permeates the air. For the stars from these two diverse worlds have a longstanding fascination for each other This year, five artists were honored for lifetime achievement in the per, forming arts: Aaron Copland, Henry Fonda, Martha Graham, Tennessee Williams and Ella Fitzgerald.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Dec. 2 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II said today that Roman Catholicism and the Eastern Orthodox churches had common spiritual heritage and were working together to end their 1,000year schism.

title: Head of Blunt Spy Ring Named by London Paper
description: LONDON, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The spymaster who controlled one of the most effective Soviet espionage rings in Britain probably operated in the United States too. The Observer said today.

title: Bridge:
description: Free trips to Fresno, Calif., for the Spring Nationals next March were at stake Saturday in the district finals of the Grand National Pairs played at Ade1phi University, Garden City, L.I.

title: Christopher Street's Merchants Join in Its Revival
description: I love this block. This is like Europe. This could be Amsterdam or Copenhagen.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SMALL WORLD Choral singing and puppet performances are coming up soon in the holiday festivities at the World Trade Center. Meanwhile, starting this morning, a puppet village complete with inhabitants goes on display in the lobbies of the two buildings, before midmonth shows.

title: Chippewas Seek Funds to Hire A Medicine Man for Alcoholics
description: BARAGA, Mich., Dec. 2 (UPI) Along the shores of Lake Superior, group of Chippewa Indians wants to convince officials that Federal money should be spent to hire a $28,000ayear medicine man for their alcoholism treatment program.

title: Interception Mark for Krause
description: Nolan Cromwell helped the Los Angeles Rams spoil Paul Krause's setting of the National Football League career interception record yesterday by scoring the winning touchdown in overtime in a 2721 Ram victory in Los Angeles.

title: China Publishes Taiwan Writers
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 2 (Reuters) China has published a new collection of 22 novels and short stories by 16 Taiwanese writers for nationwide sale, the New China News Agency reported today. It was the first time in 30 years that works of fiction from Taiwan had been issued in China, the agency said.

title: Market Place
description: SHARES of Allergan Pharmaceuticals, the last independent among major opthalmic companies, surged last week as rumors of a takeover coursed through Wall Street.

title: Soviet Paper Says U.S. Is Using Iran Crisis as Pretext to Interfere
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2 (UPI)  The Soviet Army newspaper, Krasnaya Zvezda, said today that the United States was using the crisis in Iran as a pretext for moving in forces to interfere with other countries in the region.

title: Russian Likens Seizure To U.S. Airport Affair
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 2 (AP)  The Soviet Union's Ambassador to Canada says the takeover of the American Embassy in Teheran is similar to the detainment of a Soviet airliner by United States authorities at Kennedy International Airport in New York in August.

title: A New Shake at Sambo's
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2  The management team that helped build Motel 6 Inc. into the nation's largest budget motel chain has been installed intact at Sambo's Restaurants in an effort to repair the sagging fortunes of the 1,090unit restaurant group.

title: Advertising
description: DESPITE the fact that he had been editor in chief of The Pioneer at Maine Township High School, Park Ridge, Ill., and a columnist for, The Williams Record at Williams College, when it came time to choose between the editorial or publishing training programs at Time Inc., Robert Krefting chose publishing.

title: Louise Stanton Is Bride of Lawrence Sichel
description: Louise Collier Stanton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Stanton Jr. of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Lawrence Drucker Sichel, son of Mr, and Mrs. Howard A. Sichel of Elkins Park, Pa. Zen Master Seung Sahn performed the ceremony at the Providence Zen Center in Cumberland. R.I.

title: Issue and Debate A Voice for the Consumer on Utility Rates
description: Who speaks for the telephone customer? For the electricity ratepayer? For the gas user? When the utilities marshal volumes of figures in support of yet another hundredmilliondollar rate increase, who champions the consumer's side in opposition?

title: South Texas Resort Seeking to Woo Tourists Driven Away by Spill
description: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex., Dec. 2 (AP)  Sandpipers and tiny crabs have returned to the water's edge and the sticky cloak of oil that blackened miles of Texas shoreline four months ago is gone.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low clouds extend from New England to the lake region, and across southern Texas. Frontal clouds stretch from the Pacific Northwest to the northern Rockies. A strip of snow is visible from the upper Ohio Valley to the Northern Plains States. Clear skies are apparent elsewhere.

title: Hawaii's Striking Public Workers Due Back Today
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 2  Most state and county bluecollar workers are to return to their jobs tomorrow as a result of their ratification last week of a new twoyear contract that will cost $33 million more than is budgeted for the current fiscal biennium. The results were announced Yesterday.

title: Hostage, on Tape, Calls On U.S. to Return Shah
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (AP)  A tape recording reported to be by one of the Americans held hostage at the United States Embassy in Teheran calls for the United States to surrender the deposed Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, so the hostages can be freed.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Two months have passed since the Federal Reserve surprised the fixedincome markets on Oct. 6 with its move to restrain the expansion of credit. Interest rates soared to record highs and then descended to less lofty levels; now they seem likely to behave in a more controlled way for a while As bond traders see the outlook, the credit markets have moved into a trading range, and they are likely to stay within it until some new pressures build up to force interest rates and bond prices to move more definitely one way or the other. Slackening loan demands and a weakening economy are pulling rates down, while the crisis in Iran, weakness in the dollar and inflation are pushing rates up. At the moment, these opposing market forces are in approximate balance.

title: In Iowa and Elsewhere, the Kennedy Campaign Is Getting Into Shape for Battle
description: DES MOINES, Dec. 2  The Kennedy campaign, both candidate and organization, appears to have found its footing for a political challenge that is neither as easy as the national polls suggest nor as implausible asPresident Carter's supporters say.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON THE TREASURY is getting a barrage of complaints from American exporters who sold goods to Iran before the freeze on its assets and cannot collect, even though the money is on deposit in the United States.

title: JUDICIAL NOMINATION DIVIDES ARKANSANS
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 30  For the last several months this has been a political war zone as the Carter Administration and Arkansas United States Senators battle over the appointment of Federal judges.

title: Suburban Incidents Portend More Racial Tension
description: The cross burnings, street violence and other racial incidents that took place in the areas surrounding New York City this year portend a somber beginning for the 1980's, a decade that is likely to see a continuing move of minorities into the largely white suburbs and the possibility of increased strife.

title: Broncos 19, Bills 16
description: AT BUFFALOThe Bills outgained Denver, 398 yards to 226, but suffered seven turnovers and lost in the final three seconds on a 32yard field goal by Jim Turner. Craig Morton took the Broncos 40 yards in 15seconds to set up the winning kick. Buffalo (77) ended its threegame winning streak and dropped out of contention for a playoff berth. The Broncos (104) remained tied for first with San Diego in the A.F.C. Western race. Morton completed passes of 21 yards to Steve Watson and 19 to Haven Moses after Denver had gained possession on its 44yard line with 18 seconds to play. Earlier he had passed 46 yards to Moses for a touchdown that put Denver ahead, 1610. But Buffalo rallied to tie on field goals of 32 and 34 yards by Nick MikeMayer, the second with less than two minutes remaining.

title: Jersey Titles Decided In Playoffs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 2  Bergen Catholic and Toms River North both gained New Jersey State football championships today in Giants Stadium. Bergen Catholic defeated DePaul, 146, for the parochial A North title. Toms River North defeated Brick, 1514, for the South Jersey, Grouo 4 crown.

title: Women Disrupt Film Showing
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP)  A dozen women, chanting and carrying placards, forced their way into a theater at the University of California last night and halted the showing of a pornographic film, Misty Beethoven, at the law school's Booth Auditorium. David Leiwant, chairman of the law school's Film Society, said the protesters were making a misguided attempt at censorship.

title: Music: Diana Kacso, Piano
description: DIANA KACSO is a young Brazilian pianist whose recent success on the competition circuit is reflected by a first prize in the 1978 North American Tchaikovsky Competition and a second prize in the 1978 Leeds Competition. Any art1st with such credentials is bound to be a polished, agile executant, and in this regard Miss Kacso did not disappoint Saturday night at the 92d Street Y. In particular, she dispatched the Liszt 8minor Sonata with thorough digital facility, negotiating even the briskest, thorniest passages without muddying the sound or retarding the musical flow:

title: Borg Defeats Connors Again
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Dec. 2 (AP)  Bjorn Borg survived a shaky second set and went on to win the $233,000 Frankfurt Cup against Jimmy Connors, 63, 46, 63, 64, today.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Ponchleill's La Gioconda, 8.

title: Cowboys Top Giants By 287
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 2  They were all in this together, Coach Ray Perkins told the Giants today be. fore sending the entire 45man squad onto the field for the coin toss.

title: Music: Collegiate Chorale
description: The Collegiate Chorale had a new condlictor Saturday night in Carnegie Hall  Robert Bass, who for the last few seasons has been the group's assistant conductor. Mr. Bass chose two sacred works, neither of which turns up in concerts frequently enough, C.P.E. Bach's Magnificat and Poulenc's Gloria.

title: Iran's Constitutional Vote Overshadows Nevs of Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 2  A referendum beginning here today on the new Islamic constitution overshadowed the news of the deposed Shah's flight from New York to a military hospital in Texas.

title: Dennis Karr Weds Gail Brown
description: Gail P. Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Brown of Merrick, L.I., was, married yesterday in the Park Avenue Synagogue to Dennis M. Karr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlyle Karr of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony. The bride is on the advertising sales staff of Gerald Magit Associates in New York. Her husband is president of Gronich & Karr Inc. a New York realestate concern.

title: Redskins 38, Packers 21
description: AT WASHINGTON  The Redskins (95) stayed one game behind Philadelphia, the National Conference's Eastern Divison leader, and kept alive hopes for a wildcard playoff spot, as Joe Theismann threw four touchdown passes. Theismann, who matched his* career high of 21 completions in gaining 256 yards, connected on scoring tosses to Ricky Thompson (20 yards), Danny Buggs (8), John McDaniel (39) and John Riggins (12). His passing helped Washington rally from a 217 halftime deficit. Lynn Dickey of the Packers (410) started at quarterback for the first time since breaking a leg two years ago and threw scoring aerials of 52 yards to Walter Tullis and 43 to Aundra Thompson. Riggins carried 17 times for 88 yards and caught seven passes for 34.

title: Columbia Reaches Soccer Semifinals
description: KINGSTON, R.I., Dec. 2  Kazbek Iambi, a freshman forward, scored two goals and assisted on two others as he led Columbia University to a 51 victory over Rhode Island today in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate soccer tournament at Keaney Field. Columbia advanced to the semifinals in Tampa. Fla., next weekend.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Dec. 2 (UPI) Residents turned out by the thousands in a weekend demonstration against presence in this beachfront community of the Church of Scientology.

title: Israel Assails U.N. Move Rejecting Peace Treaty
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 2 (Reuters)  Israel said today that the United Nations General Assembly's rejection of the. EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty reflected serious deterioration within the international organization.

title: Brother of ExSenator Montoya Is Found Dead in His Apartment
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 2 (UPI)  State Senator Theodore R. Montoya, the last surviving brother of Joseph M. Montoya, the late United States Senator, was found dead of an apparent heart attack in the bathroom of his apartment today, the police said. He was 44 years old.

title: Prof. Bryan Patterson Dies at 70
description: Bryan Patterson, a retired Haivard professor of vertebrate paleontology and explorer who was an authority on the evolution of mammals, died Saturday at New Engliild Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 70 years old.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Jerry Plotkin, the only businessman being held with 49 State Department employees in the United States Embassy In Teheran, arrived in Iran just few days before the embassy was stormed by Iranian students on Nov. 4. According to his lawyer, Mr. Plotkin's trip to the Middle East was his first outside the United States.

title: Premier Asserts Mrs. Gandhi Fostered Corruption
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 2 (Reuters) Prime Minister Charan Singh blamed former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today for increased poverty and corruption in India.

title: Piano Katsurako Mikami Returns After 2 Years
description: KAATSURAKO MIKAMI, young pianist from Japan, gave a favorably received New Yorkliebut recital two years ago, and late Saturday afternoon she returned to Carnegie Recital Hall to reaffirm that good impression. Although Miss Mikami offered a program of thricefamiliar standards, her performances proved to be thoroughly fresh and invigorating.

title: A New Boom Boom Deals With Old Pressures in Montreal
description: MONTREAL THE Boomer's wife, Marlene Morenz Geoffrion, the daughter of Howie Morenz, whose portrait hangs in the main lobby of the Forum with Jean Beliveau's and Maurice Richard's and Toe Blake's. His daughter, Linda Geoffrion Monahan, is married to Hartland Monahan, who plays for the St. Louis Blues. His youngest son, Danny, plays right wing, the same position for the same team that his father played with for 14 seasons.

title: Soccer Strike Voted
description: ATHENS, Dec. 2 (AP)  Players from Second Division clubs of the Greek Soccer League voted to strike today in protest of the Government's refusal to give them more money. The 40 teams in the Second Division, which are split into two groups of 20, are supported financially by the state, and the players are demanding larger grants.

title: Harvard's Drive for $250 Million Aims at Maintaining Standards
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  In late October, when Harvard University announced the start of a fiveyear drive to raise $250 million, a shoal of especially prosperous and influential alumni was netted for the occasion.

title: Drawings of David Smith Being Shown at Whitney
description: The first major retrospective of drawings by David Smith, the sculptor, will be presented at the Whitney Museum of American Art from tomorrow through Feb. 10.

title: A Needless 1,500Mile Ditch
description: Last year, Congress asked the President to decide which, if any, proposed pipeline should be built to bring Alaskan oil east. Mr. Carter is now being lobbied to approve the Northern Tier Pipeline, a 1,500mile, billiondollar project that would link the state of Washington to Minnesota. We doubt the need for any pipeline. But if one is built, there are better proposals and routes.

title: Cable TV for Sports Junkies
description: BRISTOL, CONN. STARTING at 6 P.M. last Friday, it went like this without interruption: a halfhour of sports news, then halfhour preview of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball season, followed by the Joe Lapchick Memorial Basketball, Tournament with St. John's vs. Oral Roberts and Michigan State playing Princeton. Another halfhour of sports news precedes a midnight showing of Soviet women basketball players at the University of Tennessee. Division II football playoffs in the N.C.A.A. go on at 2 A.M. and at 5 the Lapchick tournament games are repeated. Then come sports news, a table tennis tournament, an N.C.A.A. football preview, Division II soccer in the N.C.A.A., Valparaiso vs. Notre Dame in basketball, more soccer, more sports news, Michigan State vs. Michigan hockey, the Lapchick tournament final, sports news, Yale Connecticut in basketball, N.C.A.A. football, N.C.A.A. soccer, sports news, more college football, the Soviet women basketball players against the United States AllStars, Boston University's hockey team against New Hampshire, the Soviet women at University of California at Los Angeles, sports news, more college football, sports news, the N.C.A.A. soccer final, more football, more news and at 4:30 A.M. today, the Lapchick final repeated.

title: EGYPT RENEWS OFFER OF ASYLUM FOR SHAH
description: CAIRO, Dec. 2 (AP)  The deposed Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, probably will remain in the United States for several more weeks, but he is welcome to come to Egypt when he is well enough to travel, an Egyptian official said today after learning the Shah had been flown from New York to a hospital in Texas.

title: ExCity Aide Said to Be A Control Board Choice
description: Lee P. Oberst, a former director of the city's Office of Operations, is expected to be named by Governor Carey this week to fill a vacancy on the State Financial Control Board, according to sources close to the Governor and to City Hall.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sonata for Flute and Harpsichord No. 5, C.P.E. Bach; Serenade for Strings, Warlock; Trumpet Concerto in D, ToreIli; Tales of Hoffmann, highlights, Offenbach.

title: Poetry in Films at Millennium Workshop
description: Vladimir Nabokov and Robert Creeley will be shown on Dec. 11 at 8 P.M. as part of the Poetry in FilMs at Millennium series on Ttiesdays at the Millennium Film Workshop, 66 East Fourth Street. Shot in Montreux, Switzerland in 1966, and directed by Robert Hughes and Terence McCarthy, Vladimir Nabokov was the author's first filmed interview.

title: WNYC Gets $1 Million Improvement Grant
description: New York City'p voice on the air, WNYCAM and FM, has been awarded a fiveyear stationimprovement grant totaling as much as $1.1 million, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting announced yesterday in Washington.

title: EMBASSY OF THE U.S. IN LIBYA IS STORMED BY A CROWD OF 2,000
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  About 2,000 demonstrators, some of them shouting slogans in support of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khon,reini's antiAmerican policies, stormed the United States Embassy in Libya today.

title: Todd's Running and Passing Spark Jets 3017 Triumph
description: A few Jet players complained about what they termed Coach Walt Michaels's obsession with football purity  no mistakes allowed - after their disastrous flop last Monday night against Seattle. They complained about Chuck Ramsey's having been singled out for causing the loss.

title: Saudi Arabia to Build Causeway to Bahrain
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, Dec. 2  In a move of enormous implications for the Gulf region, Saudi Arabia has decided to build a SI billion causeway to this island state that will attach Bahrain to the Arab mainland.

title: TV: Seekers, More ofjakes's Family Chronicle
description: THE considerable audiences that were attracted by The Bastard last year and The Rebels this yearcittay find something of interest in The Seekers, the third and probably the last installment of the early American family chronicle adapted from the novels of John Jakes. It will be presented from 8 to 10 o'clock tonight and tomorrow night on WPIXTV, Channel 11.

title: $24.3 Million in Grants Awarded To Improve Education of Indians
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  The United State Office of Education announced today 170 grants totaling $24.3 million to improve education for Indian children and adults.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Allies Foresee Wartime Peril In Cuban Base
description: Officers in navies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization say that they are becoming concerned over the possible wartime potential of Soviet naval construction at Cienfuegos on the south coast of Cuba. They say that the uproar over reported Soviet combat unit in Cuba diverted attention from what the officers view as the graver threat of the naval base at Cienfuegos.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If a pitch bounces before it crosses home plate, and the batter manages to drive it for a hit, is that legal?

title: Associated Press
description: SAVING GRACE: Gilles Gilbert of Bruins sweeping away shot in game with Rockies last night at Boston. Rockies won, 53.

title: New England to Get First Black Mayor
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 2  Leo E. Jackson, a quiet, 53yearold welding instructor at the submarine shipyard here, is about to become Mayor. He will be the first black mayor in New England and one of only seven in the Northeast.

title: Mormon Feminist Awaiting Verdict of Her Church Trial
description: OAKTON, Va., Dec. 2  Mormon church authorities said today that charges of spreading false doctrine against Sonia Johnson, an outspoken supporter of the proposed equal rights amendment, were being carefully and prayerfully considered after a closed church trial here last night that attracted about 100 demonstrators.

title: Audiences for TV Newscasts in Dramatic Increase
description: More people have been watching the television networks evening newscasts this year than ever, according to an analysis of the weekly Nielsen audiencepopularity reports for the first 11 months. Although gains have been scored by all three networks. ABCTV has been getting the greatest share.

title: Inspectors General Draw Praise From Earlier Foes
description: New York, City's inspentort general program; began last year amid charget that it was amayoral snooping unit and aninsuit to munnlcipal Workers, hat gained the respect of some of its initial opponents for its efforts aginst employee misconduct and iinefficient management.

title: Auction of GasGuzzlers Nets $7,400 for Museum
description: BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  The Museum of Transportation auctioned 15 gasguzzling cars today, raising $7,400 and giving a tax deduction to the owners who had donated their fuelhungry cars for the event.

title: TV: Friendships, Secrets and Lies
description: HE gimmick mills are apparently inexhaustible. Tonight on NBCTV at 9 o'clock, Friendships, Secrets and  Lies is being billed as the first television movie with an allfemale cast and creative staff. But what some nervous males might subtitle The Ultimate Revenge of Gloria Steinem promises that no.males are seen or heard in the milestone film.

title: ESSAY Sala In our Alley
description: WASHINGTON  While the Carter Administration's atteptiOn is riveted on Iran, the Soviet Moil has been moving to threaten Saudi Arabia. Anarchy in Iran affects our national prestige, but control of Saudi oil affects Western survival.

title: Books of The Tirnes
description: IT used to be simple around here to put the new children's picture books to the acid test. But the acid test has now outgrown them, and the ultimate measure is interested only in the moon. Still, I've tried to be objective in picking out the best of this year's hundreds, which are listed below in no particular order.

title: Browns Thwart Oilers, 147
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 2  The Browns who play on defense for Cleveland had made no claims to being the best in the National Football League after giving up to 10 points in 14 previous games, an average of three touchdowns a game.

title: Ballet School Benefit Dec. 22
description: The School of American Ballet, an affiliate of the New York City Ballet, will sponsor its annual scholarship program benefit at the company's Dec. 22 matinee of The Nutcracker, at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center. After the 2 P.M. performance, patrons will be invited to a holiday party on the theater's promenade, which will feature entertainment by the children's chorus of the New York Grand Opera, a visit in costume by members of the ballet cast and refreshments by Famous Amos. Tickets for the benefit are available at $35 for orchestra seats (which includes a taxdeductible contribution of $18) and $40 for the First Ring (including a taxdeductible contribution of $20). Reservations and information: 8777635.

title: Earth Music Ewart and Drake
description: DOUGLAS EWART has been heard in New York City primarily as a reedman and percussionist with various jazz ensembles. Hank Drake is a Chicagobased musician who's been more heard of than heard here; last spring the writer heard him playing drums in Chicago in a style heavily influenced by African and Caribbean percussion patterns. On Saturday evening, Mr. Ewart and Mr. Drake were at the Alternative Center for International Arts making a different sort of music  the concert was called Music for the Whole Earth.

title: Battered Grandparents A LittleNoted Problem
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 (AP)  While child abuse and wife beating have drawn considerable attention, another serious family problem, battered grandparents, has gone mostly unnoticed, according to a researcher.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in The Times last Saturday incorrectly reported the date of memorial service for Carl W. Andrews. The service will be held Saturday at 2 P.M. at the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue at 77th Street in Manhattan.

title: Art: venetian Masters Shown on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES ONCE upon a time there was a city in which the new buildings were by Andrea Palladio and Jacopo Sansovino, the new, music was by Claudio Monteverdi, the new books were printed by Aldus Manutius and the new. paintings were by Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese. Power and prosperity were the marks of this city, and it had an unparalleled hold upon the imagination of its time.

title: Democratic Alliance Scores Victory Over Socialists in Portugal's Voting
description: LISBON, Monday, Dec. 3  The rightwing Democratic Alliance scored a major victory in yesterday's parliamentary elections and appeared to be close to attaining an absolute majority of seats in Portugal's National Assembly, according to returns early today.

title: The U.N. Today
Grenade Kills Monk in His Room In Monastery on the West Bank
description: TELAVIV, Dec. 2 (AP)  A Greek Orthodox monk was found dead in his monastery room over the weekend, the victim of a hand grenade apparently set by Palestinian terrorists.

title: Steelers 37, Bengals 17
description: AT PITISURGH  The Steelers clinched a playoff berth for the eighth straight season, tying the league record held by the Dallas Cowboys (196673). In the process of handing the Bengals (311) their 10th straight defeat at Three Rivers Stadium, the Steelers also took sole possession of first place in the American Conference's Central Division. Pittsburgh (113) leads Houston by one game with two left for each team, including a meeting between them next Monday night in Houston. The Steelers set several offensive records. Terry Bradshaw completed 17 of 29 passes for 339 yards (including two touchdown passes to Lynn Swann), giving him 3,278 yards for the season. That total broke the Steeler record of 2,982 setby Ed Brown in 1963. Franco Harris rushed for 92 yards in 20 carries (including a 1yard touchdown run) to raise his season total to 1,027 yards. He thus tied Jim Brown of Cleveland in gaining 1,000 or more yards for each of seven seasons. Harris also passed Joe Perry of San Francisco as he became the league's fourth leading career rusher, with 8,404 yards. He trails only Brown, O.J. Simspon and Jim Taylor.

title: Falcons 28, Chargers 26
description: AT SAN DIEGO  The Chargers missed an opportunity to clinch their first playoff spot in 19 years and fell into a tie with Denver for first place in the A.F.C. West, each at 104. Atlanta (59), out of playoff consideration, marched 51 yards in nine plays ror the winning touchdown with 21 seconds left. It came on a 6yard pass from Steve Bartkowski to Wallace Francis. Bartkowski connected on all five passes he threw in the final drive, as the Falcons broke a threegame losing streak and ended San Diego's string of consecutive triumphs at four. Dan Fouts again passed splendidly for San Diego, completing 28 of 38 aerials for 339 yards. His season's total of 3,599 yards is the fourth highest in N.F.L. history. He gained more than 300 in a game for the sixth time, tying the record set by Joe Namath in 1967.

title: Schools in Ohio Town Planning To Segregate the Troublemakers
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2 (AP)  Putting aside the paddle and other traditional means of punishment, school officials in nearby Groveport plan to begin isolating habitual troublemakers in restrictive classrooms.

title: Triumphant Return for Cherry
description: BOSTON, Dec. 2 (UPI)  Don Cherry, a favorite of Boston fans while coaching the Bruins to four Adams Division titles, returned here with his new team, the Colorado Rockies, tonight and left with a 53 National Hockey Leaeue victory.

title: Street of Fear in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 The old man who ran the sandwich counter in the corner of the grocery store has retired, she said. So she made the sandwich with its inchthick stack of fresh sliced turkey, poured the coffee and pushed the cream jar forward.

title: Outdoors: Hunting Deer on a Preserve in the Catskills
description: HORTON, N.Y. DEEP in the Catskills there is a large, wellrun hunting preserve where one may pursue woodsmen.

title: Creating Jobs: Think Small
description: CAMBRIDGE, Masi. the threat of largescale unemployment after World War If prompted a Congressional declaration that all Americans able to Work and seeking work have the right to useful, renu-, merative, regular; and fulltime employment It Is clear that we have taken that right to heart. We now employ a greater share of our adult population in the work force than ever before in history and have about doubled the size of our job base since 1945 to do it.

title: British Oil Output Drops
description: LONDON, Dec. 2 (Reuters)  Britain's energy department has reported that the country's oil production in October, mostly from the North Sea, dropped to 1.61 million barrels a day from 1.67 million in September, with the reduction primarily the result of bad weather.

title: Morgan Stanley To Get Record Fee
description: The $3.65 billion takeover of the Be!ridge Oil Company by the Shell Oil Company calls for Belridge to pay Morgan Stanley & Company a record fee of $14.6 million for arranging the deal, according to documents sent to shareholders.

title: OBSERVER The Duds Doldrums
description: Men, have you ever felt the lust for shirtings? I mean, have you ever ducked into one of those hightoned haberdasheries to get out of the rain and noticed a discreet sign over in the corner  probably in Old English lettering that says Men's Shirtings, and felt your mouth water?

title: Beating of Dissidents Seized in Seoul for Protest Meeting Is Reported
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 3  South Korean army investigators, looking into who was behind a large antiGovernment meeting held here nine days ago, were reported today to have resorted to heavy beating of some of those interrogated.

title: Bakke's Lawyers Seek Triple Fees From State
description: WOODLAND, Calif., Dec. 3 (AP) Allan P. Bakke's lawyers, asserting that they were representing the public interest when they won a historic reverse discrimination decision, are seeking $437,280 in legal fees from the University of California.

title: Shah Moves to Suite on Air Base And Is Said to Be in Good Spirits
description: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 3  The deposed Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, and his entourage were moved today from Wilford Hall, the medical center at Lackland Air Force Base here, to a suite of apartments in the base's quarters reserved for visiting officers.

title: Terrorists in Puerto Rico Ambush Navy Bus, Killing 2 and Injuring 10
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 3  A band of men armed with automatic rifles leaped from a van parked on a lonely road outside San Juan early today and ambushed a busload of United States Navy men and women as they headed for work. Two sailors were killed and 10 were injured, two of them critically.

title: Pakistan Embassy Attack Victim Is Buried Near Home in Carolina
description: SWANSBORO, N.C., Dec. 3 (AP)  Funeral services were held today for Chief Warrant Officer Bryan Lee Ellis of the Army, one of two American servicemen killed Nov. 21 when a mob attacked the United States Embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan.

title: Does Betrayal Reveal a New Pinter?
description: RAUL JULIA and Blythe Danner, seated at opposite ends of a small table, regarded each other. They ignored a spectacular view of the city through the rehearsal room's picture window, high above Broadway and 44th Street. They were trying to become Jerry and Emma, in a scruffy English pub, the first scene in Harold Pinter's Betrayal, due to open Jan. 5 at the Trafalgar Theater, on Broadway.

title: White of U.S.C. Wins Heisman Trophy
description: Charles White, the latest in a long line of excellent running backs at the University of Southern California, was overwhelmingly selected yesterday as the 45th winner of the Heisman Trophy, the prestigious award that is presented each year by the Downtown Athletic Club to college football's outstanding player.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: NEWMANKlaus. The Officers and Directors record with profound sorrow the passing, of Klaus Newman the only son of John H. Newman, the Founder and Chairman of the Board of Bunzi Pulp and Paper Sales Incorporated New York.

title: Japanese Dancers to Give ShimazakiIto Program
description: Satoru Shimazaki and Dancers will be seen in a program of dances by Mr. Shimazaki and Michio Ito, the moderndance pioneer, on Dec. 12 at Japan House, 333 East 47th Street. The company WIII perform mr. Ito s Clair de Lune, Ladybug and Tango. The program also includes four new works by Mr. Shimazaki: Jimbo's Lullaby, The Snow Is Dancing and The Little Shepherd, all part of the ShimazakiDebussy Children's Corner Suite, and an untitled solo for Junko Kikuchi.

title: Canadian Banks Heading South
description: TORONTO, Dec. 3  The Toronto Dominion Bank, in a move reflecting the greatly increased interest of Canadian banks in the United States market, announced today that it was establishing an American divisional headquarters on Wall Street.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Steel Output Off in Week
description: Steel production fell to 2.3 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, decrease of threetenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.277 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute renorted yesterday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A news release from Revlon yesterday wasted few words: Revlon Inc. today announced that M.C. Bergerac, chairman and chief executive officer of Revlon Inc., has entered into new employment agreement, approved by the board of directors, which provides for his continued services as chief executive officer of the company through 1992.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Wednesday reported incorrectly that there was a nationwide limit of $250 on heatingaid grants for households that receive Supplemental Security Income. There is no limit.

title: Mortgages Bought at Lower Rate
description: Interest rates on home mortgages sold to the Government yesterday continued to decline yesterday from the peak they reached a month ago.

title: Express Train Derailment Kills 25 In Southern India and Injures 12
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 3 (Reuters)  At least 25 people were killed and more than a dozen injured today when an express train ran off the rails in India's southern state of Karnataka, the Press Trust ofIndia reported.

title: Kennedy Chided By the Leaders Of Both Parties
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Senator Edward M. Kennedy set off a political furor today with his comments about the Shah of Iran, which were promptly denounced as inappropriate and potentially harmful by a wide range of Republican and Democratic leaders as well as the State Department.

title: IRAN CHARTER GETS EXPECTED LANDSLIDE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 3  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's new Islamic constitution was rolling up its expected landslide ratification as the polls closed tonight after two days of ballotine.

title: Gas Linked to Halt In Toronto Market
description: TORONTO, Dec. 3 (AP)  At least seven traders were carried unconscious from the floor of the Toronto Stock Exchange today, possibly the victims of carbon monoxide blowing through the airconditioning systemm officials said.

title: Science Watch
description: American and Italian experts are applying some of the most sophisticated techniques known to science in an effort to find a long lost fresco by Leonardo da Vinci.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Dec. 5 ROTTERDAM (Holland America). Lett San Juan Dec.1; due 10:30 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Older Enlistees Find the Navy Less Appealing
description: NORFOLK, Va, Nov. 30  Herbert F. Wilt, a sonar specialist aboard the aircraft carrier Eisenhower; Gregory A. McCann, an electronics technician on the destroyer Radford, and Robert L. Stefan, a machinist's mate on the attack submarine Memphis, are all trained, skilled and experienced  and they are all planning to leave the Navy soon.

title: A Diversity of Independence
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Once past the Park Street subway station, outbound toward Harvard Square, the proportion of thin, intenselooking passengers seems to grow. If one or two are fat, their flesh is not so much carried as expounded. It is not a mere excess, but a statement, an attitude, a world view. Thin or fat, they wear crowded expressions and a nurtured air.

title: Found Out From My Girl Friend
description: On the dark wooden walls of the Heisman Room at the Downtown Athletic Club, framed oil paintings of the trophy's previous winners created a tribute to the running back.
