title: High Court to Hear Water Rights and TV Safety Suits
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  After 12 years in the lower courts, a battle over water rights in Californias lush Imperial Valley finally arrived at the Supreme Court today.

title: Travel Business: Bumpy Road
description: WASHINGTON  After a close examination of their present and future, most representatives of the travel and hospitality industries agreed that they did not like what they saw.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on the Middle East Political and Security Committee10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Scypion s Trauma Is Abating
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 3  Each day, Wilford Scypion says, the memory intrudes a little less.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Publisher and a Novelist Lose $75,000 Libel Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Supreme Court refused today to review a $75,000 libel award against a novelist and her publisher, won in a suit brought by the selfdescribed reallife model for one of the novel's fictional characters.

title: Rhodesia Governor Approved
description: LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP)  The Cabinet issued an orderincouncil tonight authorizing appointment of a governor to rule Zimbabwe Rhodesia with full legislative and executive powers.

title: Classen Is Buried In Bronx
description: When the hearse pulled up to the church in the Bronx yesterday, two small boys dressed against the bitter wind stopped throwing stones at a sparrow to watch the cortege That's for the boxer they killed, one explained to the other as the limousines full of weeping relatives stopped in a line. He died, man. They messed him up and he died.

title: Paper Quotes Daughter As Saying Kosygin Is Ill
description: OSLO, Dec. 3 (AP)  Prime Minister Aleksel N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union is seriously ill, a Norwegian newspaper has quoted his daughter as saying.

title: Women Seek to Oust Mormon Judge in Rights Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI)  The National Organization for Women today filed a court appeal seeking to disqualify a Federal judge who is a leader of the Mormon Church from hearing a case involving the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: Times Dividend
description: The New York Times Company has declared a regular quarterly dividend of 22 cents a share on its Class A and Class B common stock, payable Dec. 26 to stockholders of record Dec. 12. This final dividend of 1979 brings the total for the year to 85 cents a share. The quarterly rate was increased to 22 cents a share from 20 cents a share in September.

title: Court Dance Company To Appear at EmanuE1 Y
description: The Court Dance Company of New York will present a program of social and theater dance of the 16th and early 17th centuries, performed in period costumes, on Saturday at the Performing Arts Center of the EmanuEl Midtown Y.M.Y.W.H.A., 344 East 14th Street.

title: Radicals Say Attack on Bus Is Retaliation for 3 Deaths
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. Dec. 3  Three radical organizations taking responsibility for today's attack on a Navy bus that left two sailors dead and 10 injured said that the act was in retaliation for the deaths of three advocates of Puerto Rican independence.

title: JOSEPH KAHN DEAD; SEATRAIN CHAIRMAN
description: Joseph Kahn, chairman of Seatrain Lines, the ocean transport and shipbuilding complex, and an advocate of a strong, independent United States flag merchant fleet, died at University Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CapitalGains Tax Cut to Nowhere
description: Remember all the clamor for a cut in the capital gains tax last year? Its sponsors insisted a reduction would send investors rushing to risk their money on new business plant and equipment, stimulate the stock market and promote economic recovery. Despite widespread skepticism, their logic prevailed and the tax on capital gains  the profit from longterm investment  was reduced from 50 to 40 percent.

title: Refugees: A Priority
description: WASHINGTON  Confirmation of the wanton destruction of a people is paraded before our eyes with a constancy that dulls our senses. We receive photographic evidence daily that Cambodians by the thousands are dying of malnutrition, disease and warinflicted wounds. Washington and other interested power centers had earlywarning signals of the impending disaster in March, but President Carter energized himself on the Cambodian crisis only when it threatened to become a major domestic issue in midOctober.

title: Nostalgia Blooms in Russia for Discipline of the Stalin Era
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 3  As the 100th anniversary of the birth of Stalin nears, his hand still weighs heavily on the country he did so much to shape.

title: Notre Dame Triumphs Over Iowa State, 8777
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 3 (AP) Tracy Jackson scored 20 points tonight, including 6 in a secondhalf surge that carried Notre Dame to an 8777 college basketball victory over Iowa State.

title: Tiny Chip Helps Hunt For Moons Of Saturn
description: CATALINA STATION, ARIZ. NIGHTFALL. It is cold, dry and clear atop the Catalina Mountains. A good night, as astronomers say, for seeing. Stars appear and fill the sky, crisp points of light and smears of cosmic dust, an intimation of infinity.

title: Around the Nation
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 (AP)  Public schools reopened today in Cincinnati after a threeweek shutdown that was ordered by the Board of Education when the district ran out of money in midNovember.

title: Interracial Unit Honors Helen Hayes
description: Helen Hayes was honored last night for her efforts to combat bigotry and said she must have been chosen merely as an example. There are an awful lot of people in America who live quiet lives of good grace, Miss Hayes said. It isn't possible to applaud every one of these so I suppose it is a good custom to choose a symbol of them.

title: Kuhn Sees Free Agent Time Bomb
description: TORONTO, Dec. 3  Bowie Kuhn opened baseballs annual business convention today by warning that a a time bomb is ticking away in the snort's freeanent system.

title: Catholic Unit Plays Role in SelfHelp Drives
description: It looks and feels like just another vacant lot in the South Bronx  fragments of old brick still crunch underfoot  but the people of Hoe Avenue say it will be a park in a few months.

title: Bolivian Peasants Block Roads To Protest Economic Measures
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 3 (Reuters) Bolivian peasants blocked roads around the capital today to protest tough economic measures adopted by the Government last week.

title: Staff of Museum Declares a Strike In Wage Dispute
description: Employees of the NewYork Historical Society went on strike yesterday in the first such action in the 175year history of the museum, noted for its collection of materials tracing the growth of the city and some of its leading citizens.

title: Seoul's Mood: Rising Strains
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 3  In the last 10 days, martial law authorities here have arrested close to 200 religious leaders, students and other dissidents, and many South Koreans wonder whether the honeymoon between the authorities and dissidents that followed the assassination of President Park Chung Hee is over.

title: Raiders, Down 287, Defeat Saints, 4235
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 (AP)  Ken Stabler hit Cliff Branch with two fourthquarter touchdown passesone a 66yarder - to rally the Oakland Raiders to a 4235 victory over the New Orleans Saints in a National Football League game tonight.

title: Iran Considers Oil Output Cut
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 3 (Reuters) - Iran's Finance Minister, Abolhassan BaniSadr, said today that Iran was considering a further cut in its oil production.

title: U.N. COUNCIL DRAFTS NEW APPEAL TO IRAN TO FREE AMERICANS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 3 The Security Council reached tentative agreement today on another appeal, its third, for prompt release of the American captives in Teheran.

title: State Department Help for Evacuated Families
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3They spend a lot of time at the State Department; you can spot them in the halls. Dressed in summer clothes as conspicuous as their anxious faces, they walk the long corridors, children in tow, tentatively asking directions as they go. They wear no name tags, but they bear their evacuee status like I.D.'s.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1979

title: 30 Cases of Illegal Fraternization With Female Army Recruits Cited
description: Disciplinary action has been taken in 30 cases of illegal fraternization involving female recruits at Fort Dix, N.J., since the base began training women there in October 1978, according to an Army spokesman.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Gilbert Maxwell, a poet and novelist, died Thursday in South Miami (Fla.) Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: New Air Pollution Policy to Give Industry Flexibility on U.S. Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Environmental Protection Agency put a new air pollution policy into effect today that is designed to lower costs and increase efficiency.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Carey Supports Mortgage Interest Rate Rise
description: Governor Carey and the state's legisla tive leaders, trying to encourage new mortgage loans, agreed last night to look for an acceptable way to increase the interest rate on home mortgages and pump state money into the banking system.

title: New Studies Explain Protective Benefits Of Mother's Milk
description: AS IF rediscovering the wheel, scientists studying the chemistry of breast milk are finding that it is uniquely constituted to foster the health and growth of the human infant. The new findings help to explain the considerable circumstantial evidence that breastfed babies are healthier than those raised on bottled formulas.

title: Knicks Monroe Is Reactivated
description: The New York Knicks announced yesterday that they had reactivated Earl Monroe. The 35yearold veteran, who had beenon the injuredreserve list all season, is expected to see some action against the Phoenix Suns in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Monroe suffered a hip, pointer injury in a preseason game against the Boston Celtics.

title: Radio Session Called Success
description: GENEVA, Dec. 3  The World Radio Conference, called to plan international cooperation on the use of the airwaves over the next 20 years, has been a success despite a shaky start, Glen O. Robinson, leader of the United States deleeation. said today.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Lemuel Bannister, senior partner of the law firm of Bannister, Stitt, Holloway & Krause at 342 Madison Avenue, died Sunday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 92 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J., and on Squirrel Island, Me.

title: Marshall Islands a Disaster Area
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 3 (UPI) The Marshall Islands of the Trust Territories, ravaged by heavy seas and flooding for the last week, have been declared a major disaster area by President Carter. Cecil D. Andrus, the Secretary of the Interior, made the announcement in Honolulu Saturday. The designation permits the use of Federal funds for relief and recovery efforts.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Rates on Treasury bills, after declining sharply from their lateOctober records, moved markedly higher yesterday in the Government's weekly auction of these shortterm securities, a financing that raised $600 million of additional cash to help finance the Federal budget deficit.

title: Buying Time for 1980
description: President Carter's fiveminute television appearance tonight to kick off his reelection campaign is the result of a temporary pause in a bitter battle over access to the airwaves. All three networks refused to sell the President half an hour on any night this week, saying it was too early to yield prime time (at reduced rates) to the 1980 candidates. The Federal Communicadons Commission found this refusal unreasonable and ordered that time be made available; a court stayed that order. Then came Iran, making the Carter forces think that a 30minute documentary at this stage would be inappropriate anyway. But the test of principle and power will continue as the courts review the F.C.C. ruling.

title: Carter Promises to Stop Sanctions After Rhodesia Political Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  President Carter promised Congress today that he would end sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia within a month after a British governor had arrived in Salisbury to guide that African country to free elecflails and legal independence.

title: Shifts on Reagan Staff Strengthen Role of Campaign Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Highlevel changes in the Ronald Reagan Presidential campaign have strengthened the authority of John Sears, the campaign chairman, at the expense of some of the former Governor's longtime California political aides.

title: OPEC Strategy Meeting Ends
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 3 (AP) - The strategic committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reportedly ended its longterm policy talks today in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, without reaching a consensus on pricing recommendations.

title: President of Bally Agrees to Sever Ties as Company Seeks Casino Permit
description: The president and chairman of the board of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation has agreed to sever relations with the company, at least temporarily, as a condition for his company's obtaining a temporary casino.permit in Atlantic City.

title: 11 Killed and 8 Badly Hurt in Crush Before Rock Concert in Cincinnati
description: Eleven persons were killed and at least eight others were severely injured last night when thousands of young people waiting to attend a rock concert suddenly rushed the doors of the Riverfront Coliseum in Cincinnati.

title: Byrne Rebuffed in Effort to Revise NoFault System in Auto Insurance
description: TRENTON, Dec. 3  Chances of enacting a longpromised overhaul of New Jersey's automobile insurance system were virtually eliminated today when a Senate committee shelved, on a 5to0 vote, a bill that would revise the state's nofault law.

title: Science Library
description: TO many of its practitioners, science is the supreme adventure and the most fascinating of all games. Why shouldn't the adventure begin early in life? For some children it can, and good books help.

title: Thais Cut Aid to Cambodian Group
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 3 (AP) The Thai Government said today that it had cut off food and water to an enclave of 300,000 Cambodians on the Thai border because the antiCommunist guerrillas in charge there are reportedly diverting civiltan supplies to their own use.

title: October Construction Activity Slow, Reflecting Fed Measures on Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  Total construction spending rose by sixtenths of 1 percent to $236 billion in October, although spending on private construction was virtually unchanged, the Commerce Department reported today. After discounting for inflation, however, both total construction and private construction slowed for the month, the department said.

title: Veeck Has Surgery
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP)  Bill Veeck, owner of the Chicago White Sox baseball team, is recuperating from surgery on his kneecap and should be up and around in six weeks, according todoctors. Veeck, who has an artificial leg, broke his kneecap Friday, when he slipped on a wet floor at a South Side high school after he spoke at an alumni reunion. His wife, Mary Frances, said two pins were inserted into the bone in Veeck's knee in an effort to reconstruct the shattered lower part of his kneecap.

title: Energy Program Lags in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  No major segment of the energy program that President Carter sent to Congress last summer with a highpriority designation seems likely to become law until next year.

title: World News Briefs
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 3 (Reuters)  Two policemen have been sentenced for the sadistic interrogation of an Arab prisoner from Hebron in the death of a relative of his.

title: 42 Food Establishments Are Cited for Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 42 food establishments that it said had violated the health code.

title: GovernmentAppointed Doctors Report Flood Is Fit to Stand Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI)  A Federal prosecutor said today that Governmentappointed doctors had found that Representative Daniel J. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania, was competent to face a bribery retrial although Mr. Flood's personal physicians have said that he is addicted to drugs, depressed and incoherent.

title: Jazz Seek Deal For Maravich
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 4 (UPI) - Tom Nissalke, coach of the Utah Jazz, said tonight after his club's loss to the Milwaukee Bucks that he was trying to negotiate a trade for Pete Maravich, who has not played in the team's last five games.

title: Radio
description: MUSIC

title: Style-
description: _ Style_

title: Ruth Lewinson, 84, an ExOfficial For County Lawyers Association
description: Ruth Lewinson, a former official of the New York County Lawyers Association and former special referee of the New York State Supreme Court, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old. In recent years she had been active in Surrogate Court cases.

title: Church of Scientology Implicated In Additional Plots, U.S. Asserts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI)  Federal prosecutors said today that the Church of Scientology's campaign against those it regarded as enemies inchided implicating the Mayor of Clearwater, Fla., in a fake traffic accident and infiltrating law firms and newspapers, including The Washington Post.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: For many years to come, a continuous supply of Mideast oil will be vital to us and to the entire Western alliance, including Japan. Our strategic policy should insure that that supply will not be cut off or severely curtailed. After the crisis in Iran has been resolved and a grand inquest held by Congress and the press to discover how we blundered into that morass, it should be remembered that for decades we have failed, despite many warnings, to take any measures whatever to safeguard that supply.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif., Dec 3 (Reuters)  MCA Inc. announced plans today to double its stake in Cedar Point Inc. to 20 percent and said it was interested in a merger. Cedar Point reacted coolly to both proposals.

title: Heating Oil Costs Rise in New York
description: The first effects of a new price increase in Venezuelan oil began to be felt in New York City yesterday as the prices of some No. 6 heating oil used by apartment buildings went up as much as 12 percent.

title: Nuclear Panel Concedes Lag in Emergency Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission conceded today that its members did not realize the importance of planning for nuclear emergencies before the Three Mile Island accident last March.

title: Fraser: Possibility Of New Auto Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Dec 3 (Reuters) - United Auto Workers President Douglas Fraser said today that he could not dismiss the possibility that his union might have to negotiate a new wage contract with the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Theater: Ludlam Stars In A Christmas Carol
description: APPROACHING classics, Charles Ludlam is a borrower and a blender, but what we tend to forget is that even at his most extreme he has a curious fidelity to his source. His Bluebeard was lunatic ana lascivious  just like the original. Though hairychested, his Camille was rhapsodically romantic. His assault on Wagner turned the Ring cycle topsyturvy but remained a grand Valkyrian ride.

title: Taxes
description: As Christmas approaches, many parents go on buying sprees for their children, but often overlook the tax advantages of making gifts of lumpsum payments of $3,000 or less. combines gift and estate taxes. To the extent that taxpayers use the credit to reduce tax on gifts made during their lifetime, the amount of the credit that can be used against Federal estate taxes due at death is lessened. You can't have it both ways, Mrs. Nitsch notes.

title: MEXICO DENIES U.S. URGED SHAH'S ENTRY
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3  President Jose Lopez Portillo strongly denied today that Mexico had been pressed by the United States to receive the Shah of Iran. He said that, to avoid embroiling the country in a conflict which is not ours, the deposed ruler's Mexican visa would not be renewed.

title: The City
description: The Church of Scientology reported yesterday that it would release today an analysis of Government papers indicating that the Army and the Central Intelligence Agency had held bacteriological and chemical tests in New York City streets and tunnels in 1956.

title: School Board Property May Solve Chicago Fiscal Crisis
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 3  The Chicago Board of Education owns nearly 100 parcels of commercial property, worth millions, that it may have to use as collateral for the estimated $500 million that the school system needs to avoid bankruptcy.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: ADELSONSamuel. Beloved husband of Gussie. Devoted father of Gloria and Jerry. Adored grandfather of Mark, Susan, David and Amy. Services Boulevard. Park West, 115 W. 79 St. Wednesday 11:30am.

title: India's Christian Tribes Are Angered by Influx of Bengalis
description: SHILLONG, India  Life in the towns of northeast India seems to end at sundown these days. When the curfew comes into force, only dogs and policemen are free to roam the streets.

title: News Summary
description: Rhodesia to free elections and legal independence, President Carter pledged Congress. The promise was reported to Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, who has introduced legislation to force the President to lift sanctions unconditionally. [A20:12.]

title: Projecting Hospital Revenue Is Tricky, Koch Learns
description: Mayor Koch called an unusual special meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday to discuss the fiscal problems of the Health and Hospitals Corporation. He wound up getting a lesson on the complexities of projections about revenues and expenditures.

title: Polaroid Unveils Faster Film
description: The Polaroid Corporation introduced a new instant color film yesterday that it said develops twice as quickly as its current SX70 film while offering better color.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: United Press International
description: WORSHIPERS RETURN TO SHRINE IN MECCA: As guards stood by, pilgrims at the Grand Mosque in Mecca last Friday kissed the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine. The Saudis have repaired damage by insurgents who took over mosque on Nov. 21. Yesterday, proIranian demonstrations were reported in oilproducing areas. Page A16.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Avis Rent A Car System Inc. has appointed Kerry B. Alberti to the new position of vice presidentstrategic management.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Breath

title: IRAN ISSUE DETRACTS FROM ARMS TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  After weeks of predictions that there was ample time to begin debating the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union this year, the Senate's majority leader said today that the Iranian crisis made the environment unsuitable for the debate.

title: Market Place
description: EVER since the bear market of the 70's, institutions have looked for ways to avoid a repetition of the ruinous losses they experienced then almost without exception. They wanted to smooth out the valleys of investment experience without chopping off too many of the peaks. One of the techniques that developed is broader diversification through investment in equity markets around the world.

title: U.S. Reports No Success in Finding Haven Abroad for Shah
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The United States reported no success today in its continuing efforts to find a permanent haven abroad for the deposed Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who was flown yesterday to Texas as a temporary measure.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: HALPERINFannie. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Center records with sorrow the passing of the mother of Its member, Betty LerowItz, and extends Its heartfelt awnpathy to the bereaved family.

title: Old Met Site Is Marked By Plaques
description: In the days when it was known as the yellow brewery, the Metropolitan Opera House stood on Broadway between 39th and 40th Streets. Its existence there, from the time it was erected until the company moved to its present home at Lincoln Center, was commemorated late yesterday afternoon with the unveiling of plaques at the Chemical Bank branch now on that site. The event also served as a celebration of the bank's 10th anniversary there.

title: OddEven Gas Sales on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (AP)  The 43 California counties that had previously imposed no restrictions on gasoline purchases today joined 15 others in putting into effect oddeven restrictions on the sales of gasoline. Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. ordered the restrictions statewide. Earlier this year, the most populous counties in California adopted such restrictions as gas supplies temporarily became scarce.

title: EDUCATION
description: BERKELEY, CALIF. AFTER leading a legal revolution that helped change the economic foundation on which much of American public education was built, what do you do for an encore? John E. Coons and Stephen D. Sugarman faced this question and decided to try to change the structure on too of the foundation.

title: Moynihan Offers Measure Revising Medicaid Reimbursement Formula
description: A bill revising the formula for Medicaid financing, which would require the Federal Government to increase the amount it pays 41 states by $2.1 billion a  year, was introduced yesterday by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: EARNINGS J.P. Stevens Results Up By 34.8%
description: J.P. Stevens & Company, the diversified textile producer, yesterday reported profit increases of 34.8 percent for the fourth fisal quarter ended Nov. 3 and 31 percent for the full fiscal year.

title: Kennedy, After Criticizing Shah, Supports Carter's Efforts on Iran
description: RENO, Dec. 3  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, finding that sharp criticism he had made of the Shah of Iran was stirring the first major controversy of the Presidential campaign, said today that he continued to support fully President Carter's efforts to free the American hostages held in Teheran.

title: New York in the Cold Is a Down Town
description: Stephanie Baum of Greenwich Village was just leaving home for her secretarial job yesterday morning, dressed in her idea of an eminently fashionable, eminently sensible winter coat, when the man she lives with called out, Hey, you forgot to take off your sleeping bag

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Acting under pressure from the State Department and the Canadian Government, the Justice Department rejected a recommendation of its own investigators last year that Gulf Oil and eight other companies be indicted. The indictment would have charged the nine with involvement in a worldwide uranium cartel. [Page Al.]

title: Money
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1979

title: Pop: Stevie Wonder
description: STEVIE WONDER'S concert at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday night had all the trappings of an event, and indeed Mr. Wonder was accorded standing ovation at the end. But earlier, the audience seemed oddly apathetic, and this writer found the occasion sad.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In what ways do girls mature  faster than boys?

title: U.S. Investigating Olympic Contractor
description: A corporation that was awarded a $250,000 food management contract by the Lake Placid Olympic Organizing Committee is under Federal investigation for possible currency and customs violations. Law enforcement officials also say the company, ARA Services Inc., was suspected as recently as 1976 of having been infiltrated by organized crime figures.

title: About Education
description: THIS is  for me  a book about activists, not Mark Ruddtype activists, nor Ralph Nader types, but people who wanted to do something and, though not without discomfort, did it. Are still doing it.

title: Amid Hapsburg Splendor, a Gala at the Met
description: Around 9 o'clock last night Halston came up the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art with Martha Graham on his arm and a bevy of beautiful girls in his wake.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: FOXJ. LEWIS beloved husband of Ruth, devoted father of Janet Sidle, David and.Jeffrey, dear brother of Lillian Saxe, loving grandfather of Adam and Jason Sidle, Matthew and Justin. Services today 1:30 PM, Boulevard Park West, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: $3 Million Awarded in Air Suit
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 3 (AP)  A Superior Court jury today awarded $3 million to the widow and six children of a San Diego real estate developer who was one of 144 victims of an aircraft collision over this city. The family of Lee H. Johnson had sought $24 million in the lawsuit against Pacific Southwest Airlines. A Pacific Southwest jet collided with a small plane over San Diego on Sept. 25, 1978. It was the second verdict in a trial over deaths resulting from the incident. In the first, survivors were awarded $300,000.

title: India's Stance Cautious In Issue of U.S. Hostages
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 3  By slow stages, the Government of India has moved toward condemning the seizure of United States hostages in Iran.

title: The Region
description: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and the 17 unions representing its employees met yesterday with officials of the National Mediation Board in Washington as efforts to settle contract differences intensified.

title: Farming 89th Street
description: My friend John the Farmer is a retired postoffice worker. A bachelor. John farms a vacant lot on 89th Street . and Columbus Avenue. It's rather disreputable looking, strewn with rusty beer cans, empty wine bottles, dog droppings, mildewed mattresses and abandoned cars. But the soil is extremely fertile.

title: Iranian Assets Attached By Starrett Housing
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation, which built the Citicorp Center, housing on Roosevelt Island and Starrett City in Brooklyn and then invested heavily in Iran, said yesterday that had obtained a court order of attachment for $38.3 million against the Government of Iran and two Iranian banks.

title: Cup Skiing Opening at Val D'Isere
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 3 The World Cup skiing season  the white circus, as the organizers like to call it  opens here this week with 150 skiers from 19 countries and barely enough snow to go around.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at t P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WATCH ON THE BAY Some New Yorkers prefer to visit the South Street Seaport Museum during autumn, with the salt air of Fulton Street heightened by the brisk chill, and the oldtime ships sturdily riding the wind alongside the piers. On a leisurely morning or afternoon you can warm up by stepping inside the museum's Seaport Gallery, 215 Water Street, which has a new exhibition through Feb. 24  a showing of 68 prints by the turnofthecentury photographer, Alice Austen (18661952).

title: Advertising
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3  Board members of newsgathering corporations  both print and broadcast  should supervise the editorial as well as the business side, the dean of the Harvard Business School suggested here today.

title: Bridge:
description: The world's biggest bridge event, one considers only those in which the field is eventually reduced by stages to produce a winner, is certainly the Grand National Pairs. An official estimate of the number of players competing this year is 75,000. The great majority of these have already been eliminated at club and unit level. and a few district winners have won expensepaid trips to the national finals in Fresno, Calif., next March.

title: U.S. Aides Say Soviet Will Start a Pullback In East Germany Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Soviet Union is expected to begin withdrawing about 10,000 troops from East Germany later this week, a move that Carter Administration aides said today was meant to reduce Allied political support for modernizing American nuclear forces in Western Europe.

title: A Flight From Newark to Cuba Shifted After Threat Is Reported
description: NEWARK, Dec. 3  The first regular charter service between Havana and the New York metropolitan area began today, but only after an apparent terrorist threat had forced Cubana de Aviacifin to shift the departure of its Russianbuilt airliner to Kennedy International AirDort.

title: Rangers, on Esposito Goal, Gain Tie With Canadiens
description: The young hockey season has never seen the Rangers in anything but a slump, but slowly, painfully, that is beginning to change. In a 33 tie with the Montreal Canadiens last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers showed that while they are not yet diamonds, they are no longer rust.

title: Trial of Park's Accused Assassin  Suspended Soon After It Opens
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 4 (AP)  The trial of Kim Jae Kyu, the accused assassin of President Park Chung Hee, opened today but was suspended until the Supreme Court can rule on where Mr. Kim should be tried.

title: Federal Grand Jury Considering Bus Shelter Franchise
description: A Federal grand jury has begun hearing evidence to determine whether any criminal acts were committed in the awarding of a lucrative bus shelter franchise in New York City, according to officials familiar with the investigation.

title: Music: Xarhakos Leads Mitropoulos Fund Benefit
description: ABENEFIT concert for the scholarship fund in memory of Dimitri Mitropoulos was held Sunday night in Avery Fisher Hall. The fund was recently established at the Juilliard School, and the first award will be made to a talented young composer or conductor of any nationality next year, the 20th anniversary of the Greekborn conductor's death. The benefit concert was led by Stavros Xarhakos, a native of Greece, who made his New York debut with the New York Symphony Orchestra, an ensemble comprised mainly of Juilliard students.

title: Books of The Times
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, books for young readers aren't exclusively about death, drugs, divorce and disability. Sometimes they deal with childbeating, molestation. insanity. runaways and acne. While such subjects do seem to make up the vast bulk of icebergs beneath the sea in children's literature, there are still the tips of the bergs towering majestically over all and hinting of awesome power. Here then, are some slivers and chunks of those tips that came floating past this year.

title: Brown Invited to Attend Election Forum in Iowa
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 3 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California was invited today to participate in a Jan. 7 debate with President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Topics Insult, Injury
description: Lane Kirkland, the new A.F.L.C.I.O. president, is in trouble in Hoboken, N.J., for saying about the labor movement that everything not A.F.L.C.I.O. is Hoboken. A long list could be made of places whose names have become synonymous with nowhere. But that list should include an appendix of consolations.

title: Two Former Antipoverty Agency Officials Indicted
description: Two former officials of a Manhattan antipoverty agency with an annual budget of $2 million were indicted yesterday in the theft of $24,000 from the agency. City officials called the indictments the first against antipoverty officials to result from a twoyearold inspector general nrogram.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Phoenix Suns, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Manhattan Cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio- WNEW, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Dollar Falls To a Low In Germany
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 3  The dollar plunged to a higtoric low against the West German mark in hectic European currency trading today as the rapidly rising tension in the Middle East fueled heavy dollar sales.

title: Kurds in Iran Shun Referendum, Stressing SelfRule Aim
description: MEHABAD, Iran, Dec. 3  There are few posters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini here in Kurdistan.

title: Bomb Blast Damages Morgan Guaranty Branch in Frankfurt
description: Associated Press

title: Court Lets Stand Telex Fee Award
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  The Supreme Court refused today to disturb a $1 million fee the Telex Corporation must pay a San Francisco law firm for preparation of a Supreme Court appeal that was never acted upon.

title: Computers Become a Major Design Tool
description: ITHACA, N.Y. ON a computer display terminal, a picture of a house appears, grows in height and whirls around to display itself from every angle. The operator asks the computer for the noon sun to come out, and the house suddenly casts shadows on the ground and an adjacent structure casts shadows on the house. Commands to the computer to exhibit the movement of shadows as the day progresses are obeyed as well.

title: Shift Seen On Title IX Fund Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  In major policy shift, the Government has decided that, except for scholarships, colleges do not have to spend the same for each female athlete as for each male to conform with Federal laws banning sex discrimination.

title: 3,000 Dentists Strike in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 3 (UPI)Sweden's 3,000 dentists in private practice went on strike today in the first of a twoday action to protest a plan to impose strict limits on their work. State health authorities want to restrict private dentists in an effort to expand the public's use of services provided by the 4,500 dentists who work in the staterun public health system.

title: Metals and Oil Issues Gain, but Overall Market Sags
description: Precious metal, copper and selected oil issues showed gains yesterday, but heightened concerns about the Middle East caused the general market to move slightly lower. Wall Street analysts said these concerns were directly linked to higher prices for gold and silver bullion.

title: IN THE NATION A New Economic Wind
description: WASHINGTON  Largely unnoticed in last week's Senate debate on the windfall tax bill was an 81to14 vote that suggests which way the economic wind is blowing on Capitol Hill.

title: Events Today
description: KOKO, A TALKING GORILLA, a documentary directed by Barbet Schroeder, at the Public Theater.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: POLICE CHIEF WHO REPLACES HOSTAGES IS SLAIN: Thomas Buntrock, left, Police Chief of Mequon, Wis., was shot dead by Anthony Johnson after he traded places with two hostages held by his slayer. Mr. Johnson, who had robbed a fuel station, seized the two hostages at nearby home but agreed to release them in exchange for Chief Buntrock. He slew the officer but was himself shot dead by other policemen. Above, Mr. Johnson's body is removed from a stolen car at a roadblock.

title: OvertheCounter Sale Urged for Hydrocortisone
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel says consumers should be allowed to buy hydrocortisone without a prescription to treat poison ivy and other skin irritations.

title: Notes on People
description: The day before Thanksgiving, Mayor Jane M. Byrne of Chicago paid a quiet visit to a Chicago hospital and underwent facial cosmetic surgery. It was an outpatient procedure, a spokesman said yesterday, and she stayed close to home for several days.

title: Buffalo Gets the Blues: In the Sky and From the Snow
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 3  We're seeing daylight now, James Lindner, Commissioner of Streets Sanitation, said today as cleanup crews, working under a cloudless sky, struggled with mounds of snow dumped by Friday and Saturday's storm.

title: Homosexual Who Ran Third Backs San Francisco Mayor in Election
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- In a move emblematic of the steadily growing political power of homosexuals in this city, Mayor Dianne Feinstein today called news conference at which the homosexual who has become the most soughtafter power broker in a closely contested mayoral race endorsed the Mayor for reelection.

title: Hyperactive Children Often Suffer As Adults
description: WHAT do you call a oncehyperactive child who's old enough to drink and vote? He's not really a hyperactive adult because the constant fidgeting and pacing that plagued his childhood let up during adolescence. But he's not exhyperactive either, since his behavior may still be volatile enough to keep him from making friends and get him into frequent accidents on the road.

title: Rightists in Portugal Seem Assured of a Narrow Parliamentary Majority
description: LISBON, Dec. 3  In a shift toward the right after five years of leftist and minority Governments, Portugal's voters appear to have given the rightist Democratic Alliance a narrow majority in the 250seat National Assembly.

title: Southern Pacific Granted Use of Rock Island Lines
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Interstate Commerce Commission granted permission today to the Southern Pacific Transportation Company to operate over the lines of the bankrupt Rock Island Railroad, providing relief for Western farmers with products ready for market.

title: Ballet: Sylphide Ends Danish Festival
description: COPENHAGEN, Nov. 30  Therese Muller, August Bournonville's 86yearold greatgreatgranddaughter, was in the audience when the Royal Danish Ballet brought its weeklong Bournonville Centenary Festival to a close here, and she was thus on hand for a spectacular finish.

title: Supreme Court Asked to Review Ruling on Ending of Taiwan Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Senator Barry Goldwater asked the United States Supreme Court today to review the Court of Appeals decision last Friday that President Carter acted legally in ending a mutual defense treaty with Taiwan without the approval of Congress.

title: For Teheran's Zero Class, Constitution Is Secondary
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 3  Except that electricity was installed a couple of months ago, not much has changed in HalabiAbad, Teheran's City of Tin, since Sayed ZabiOllah Mousavi moved into a tin and mud shack there seven years ago.

title: Spain Extends Antiterrorism Law After a Year of Political Violence
description: MADRID, Dec. 3, (Reuters)  The Spanish Government extended a tough antiterrorism law today after a year of political violence in which 124 people were killed.

title: Data Show U.S. Rejected Uranium Cartel Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Justice Department, facing objections from the State Department and Canada, rejected staff recommendation last year to indict the Gulf Oil Corporation and eight other companies, mostly foreign, on felony antitrust charges because of their involvement in a foreign uranium cartel, Government documents show.

title: A New Remedy for Ailing Hospitals
description: The Federal plan to pump money into three Brooklyn hospitals that serve the poor may turn out to be more than a political handout after all. The main motive is unquestionably political. Federal health officials originally wanted no part of the scheme, designed primarily to save the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital from bankruptcy. They feared it would prompt a wave of similar requests from financially pressed hospitals around the country. But pressure from New York politicians forced the Carter Administration to reverse itself and support the rescue plan that Vice President Mondale proudly unveiled on a campaign trip to the city last week.

title: Asarco and Other Suppliers Lift Spot Copper Prices
description: Asarco Inc., a major copper producer, raised its domestic spot price of electrolytic copper yesterday by 12 cents a pound, to $1.12, effective immediately.

title: Iran Buys Ads For Debt Message
description: In advertising scheduled in American publications, Iranian financial officials are asserting that their country will honor all of its legitimate debts.

title: Car of Westchester Murder Victim Is Found as Police Seek 2 Suspects
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3  The Westchester County police, seeking the killer of Sharon Enea, a political activist, said tonight that they had found her missing car in a parking garage at the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers, eight miles from the Eastchester bridle path where she was found bludgeoned to death on Saturday.

title: London's Covent Garden Warns of Fiscal Disaster
description: LONDON (Reuters)  The Covent Garden Opera House has warned that without inflationmatching grants cannot survive as a major international opera and ballet center.

title: SCM Meeting Set
description: The SCM Corporation said that its annual meeting, which already has been adjourned twice since Oct. 25, will take place at 4 P.M. tomorrow to receive a report of the inspectors of election in a proxy contest for control of the company's board. SCM already has said that a preliminary count of the proxies cast showed that management had won the contest. However, a certified report of the results will not be available until tomorrow.

title: Conquering Hero of Portugal's Right
description: LISBON, Dec. 3  Save Portugall Save Portugall screamed several ecstatic women, reaching into the back window of the slowly moving Peugeot to touch the small, trim man with wavy black hair and green eyes. Francisco Sa Carneiro flashed a tight smile at his middleaged wellwishers and then relaxed. Well, he said, these are the last hours.

title: Music: Fairfield Chorale Maccabaeus
description: THERE are two historically plausible ways to present Handel's oratorios nowadays. One way, based on a tradition that dates from long after Handel's death, is to marshal as many musicians and singers as can be crammed on a stage and let them go at it. Until a generation or so ago, this was the only kind of Handel you were likely to encounter in the major concert halls. The other, historically more legitimate, procedure is to present the music with 25 or 30 singers and an orchestra of at least the same number.

title: About New York
description: If Karen Hubert and Len Allison had not needed a new camera for the documentary they were making, they would probably never have opened a restaurant. The restaurant, named Hubert's. at 148 Hoyt Street, Brooklyn, has achieved popularity in its centuryold quarters, formerly a bar, in the Boerum Hill district. But rather than pass gastronomic judgments on its menu here, this story tells how New Yorkers find careers in a peculiarly New York way.

title: Spokesman Denies Shah Gave German Interview
description: The deposed Shah of Iran denied yesterday through a spokesman in New York that he had granted an interview to a West German newspaper that quoted him as having derided the Western nations for their total readiness to give up.

title: Music: Work by Oliveros
description: IT seemed a terribly bright idea cuuple of decades ago: that a composer need not actually write a piece of music but might merely offer a few guidelines or signposts and let the performers and listeners do the creative work. In recent years, we have seen less of this practice, but memories of it were revived at Alice Tully Hall last night when the American Composers Orchestra presented the first New York performance of Pauline Oliveros's For Valerie Solanas and Marilyn Monroe in Recognition of Their Desperation.

title: Jones Is Permitted to Play Pending Decision by Court
description: Earl Jones, a 6foot11inch transfer student from West Virginia who was declared ineligible for a semester's competition at Spingarn High School in Washington. yesterday was granted permission to play bas- ketball While a District of Columbia court determines whether the he was denied his right of due process and misled by school officials.

title: 2 Killed by Floods in Sumatra
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 3 (UPI) Rivers swollen by two weeks of heavy rains flooded eastern Sumatra over the weekend, drowning two young children and forcing more than 20,000 people to flee their homes, the newspaper Kompas reported today.

title: Martin M. Goldman, an Attorney; Was Counsel to Former Speaker
description: Martin M. Goldman, an attorney active in Democratic Party politics, died in his Manhattan home last night after a long illness. He was in his 70's.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Moscow Dissidents Urge Soviet To Support U.S. Firmly on Iran
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 3  An open letter signed by dissidents and circulating here asks the Soviet Government to demand the immediate release of the American hostages being held by the Iranians.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's Book Are to Be Distributed by Peking
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 3 (AP)  Excerpts. from Henry A. Kissinger's memoirs, White House Years, have been translated into Chinese and will be distributed throughout China this month, according to a Peking newspaper.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Silver prices soared to record levels yesterday as all markets in precious metals reflected rising tensions in the Middle East and the fears about the future health of the dollar. But most other commodities appeared to spin in theirown market orchits

title: Iran Curbed On French Atom Plant
description: PARIS, Dec. 3  A French court has froEen Iran's stake in a big international company manufacturing nuclear reactor fuels and suspended repayment of a $1 billion loan Iran made to help finance the project, sources close to the transaction disclosed today.

title: A Tax Break Plan for the Elderly Leaves Many of Them Confused
description: A program designed to help elderly people with low incomes cope with high property taxes is so complicated to apply for that many older New Yorkers who are eligible will never receive its benefits, state officials said yesterday.

title: Film: 'Koko,' Tale of a Talking Gorilla:Fascinating Insights
description: WE'VE all heard tell of that special, indefinable quality that makes a movie star, that makes one face more captivating to the camera than a thousand others might be. Well, Koko the gorilla has one of those fabulous faces. Koko is the subject of a feature-length documentary by Barbet Schroeder, handsomely photographed by Nestor Almendros, but she didn't earn her star's status on glamour alone. Only 7 years old, and with a life expectancy of 50 years, she has already mastered 300 words of the sign language used by the deaf. She can also eat hamburgers, identify vegetables, ask to be tickled and clean up her room.Mr. Schroeder's "Koko, A Talking Gorilla," which has its American debut today at the Public Theater, concentrates on the relationship between Koko and Penny Patterson, the developmental-psychology student who is either Koko's trainer or her mother, depending on your point of view. They have spent five years together, years in which Miss Patterson has not taken vacations. And they are so close that Miss Patterson, who lives in a house, must be sure to be around Koko, who lives in her own trailer, at Koko's bed-time and when she wakes up in the morning.The film watches them quarrel, and study, and just plain horse around, letting Koko's remarkable talents reveal themselves during the course of many different episodes. At the beginning of the film it may seem strange so see Koko sitting beside Penny in a car, in traffic, in a suburb near Stanford University. By the end, you may wonder why Koko isn't driving.Mr. Schroeder makes a point of approaching both his subjects, Penny and Koko, as a foreigner. So a good deal of time is devoted to the very American habits of pretty, blond Penny, and her manner of passing them on to the gorilla. Peanut butter and the aformentioned hamburgers have become staples of Koko's diet, a narrator remarks, and an astonishing sequence shows Penny trying to teach Koko to put on mascara. (At this, Koko puts one of her four feet down.) Koko reads from standard storybooks, and prefers her red sweater to her yellow one. She has already been taught such words as "good," "bad," "polite" and "steal." As the narrator inquires, "Will Koko become the first White American Protestant gorilla?"Miss Patterson herself raises the question of whether Koko ought to have the legal rights of an American child  her I.Q., after all, is only slightly below normal for a human being of the same age. The film also discusses, in its concluding section, the question of whether humans have exclusive rights to the status of persons, and how much more reluctant they might be to despoil nature if they considered themselves at one with their environment rather than superior to it. "Koko raises all the important questions about man," the narrator maintains.Whether or not that is so, Koko does present some fascinating insights into matters of behavior and education. And Mr. Schroeder has assembled this funny, provocative documentary with gratifying intelligence and care.

title: Trade Aide Is Named
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  Robert D. Hormats of Maryland was confirmed by the Senate today to be deputy special representative for trade negotiations. Also approved by voice vote and without debate were the nominations of John M. Deutch of Massachusetts as United States representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency, and of Gerard C. Smith and Roger Kirk of Washington as alternates.

title: Unbeaten Columbia Defeats Manhattan
description: Columbia is not yet ready to lobby for inclusion into college basketball's top 20 teams, but the Lions are still among the undefeated after their third straight victory, a 7156 triumph last night over Manhattan College in Draddy Gymnasium.

title: Bomb Laid to Croats Damages Queens Travel Agency
description: A powerful explosion shattered Queens travel agency yesterday afternoon, the apparent work of selfstyled Croatian freedom fighters who threatened to detonate two other bombs last night if their political demands were not publicized immediately.

title: The High Jumper's Sin
description: Greater love hath no organization than the Amateur Athletic Union, which will sacrifice its virtue for a high jumper. The jumper is Dwight Stones, former holder of the world record, whom the A.A.U. cast into outer darkness a year or so ago for soiling his hands with money won on a television show. Branded a professional and forced to stand in the pillory with a scarlet P embroidered on his shirtfront, Stones no longer was eligible for underthetable payments from promoters of track meets.

title: Political Wisecracks: Some FrontRunners
description: FOR comics, there is always President to kick around. But never does the national penchant for poking fun at politicians reach such a peak as it does every four years when the ring is full of hats, the air full of Presidential campaign rhetoric and the occasional political mouth full of feet.

title: Morgan Gains 2d Attachment
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Dec. 4 (AP) The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the American bank that startled the German financial community by obtaining a court order attaching Iran's 25 percent share in Krupp Industries last week, obtained a second attachment order from a court in Essen, a Krupp spokesman said today.

title: Baby Found in Manger At a Scene of Nativity
description: LONGVIEW, Tex., Dec. 4 (AP) The Rev. Charles Holland walked by the Nativity scene in front of his church and heard the sound of a baby's cries coming from the manger.

title: Norfolk Hospital Gets Preliminary Approval For Fertilization Lab
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 4 (UPI)  Plans by Norfolk General Hospital to open the nation's first socalled testtube baby clinic got firstround approval today from the Eastern Virginia Health Systems Agency.

title: Carter, Without Fanfare, Declares He Is Candidate for a Second Term
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  President Carter, still grappling with the Iranian crisis, today officially declared his candidacy for a second term in a subdued, nineminute ceremony shorn of the usual political fanfare.

title: GASOLINE USE DROPS SHARPLY IN CITY AREA
description: Public awareness of the need for conservation, along with high prices and shorter supplies, has resulted in sharp decreases in the use of gasoline in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, officials of the three states said yesterday.

title: Gasohol in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 4 (AP)  Texaco Inc. plans to start selling gasohol soon in the Hartford metropolitan area and in Fairfield County, in the first widescale marketing of the fuel in the Northeast by a major oil company, spokesman said today. A state official, who asked not to be identified, said Texaco had most of the required permits for selling gasohol and had planned to begin sales Dec. 1 but encountered delays.

title: Radio
description: 910;30 A.M., WQXR: Breakfast Symphony. Serenade in D minor, Dvorak.

title: Chang Kuotao Dies in Toronto
description: TORONTO, Dec. 4  Chang Kuotao, the last surviving founder of the Chinese Communist Party, died in his sleep yesterday in a suburban nursing home. He was 82 years old.

title: Chrysler's Plans in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 4 (AP)  Chrysler Canada Ltd. will invest between $1 billion and $1.2 billion (in Canadian funds) in Canada over the next five to 10 years, depending on governmental financial aid from Canada and the United States, Economic Development Minister Robert de Cotret said today after meeting with Chrysler officials.

title: Christmas Food Gifts: From 80 Cents to $110
description: ALL of the shops included in this roundup can be relied upon to tell you which foods are deliverable and which you should take yourself. Obviously, the fresher the food the more perishable it is. Cut and ripening cheeses, game, foie gras, truffles, smoked fish and cured meats should all have warnings on their outer wrappings, so recipients will not leave them out of refrigeration longer than necessary. Because most shops are keeping special holiday hours it is a good idea to telephone in advance before going.

title: Boeing Reports Sale of Six 727's
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 4  The Boeing Commercial Airplane Company today announced the sale of eight aircraft for more than $100 million to Mexicana Airlines and Frontier Airlines.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Von Hayek And Lima's Vendors
description: LIMA, Peru  Prof. Friedrich A. Von Hayek, the 1974 Nobel Prize winner in economics, came to Lima in November, still as strong as an ox at 80, to discuss democracy and the market economy. And, well, he certainly met the market headon as he stepped out of his hotel.

title: Icelandic Voting Leaves Fight on Inflation Unresolved
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 4  After an election campaign fought on the issue of the 55 percent rate of inflation, Iceland was no closer to a solution today, and its political future seemed as cloudy as its gray December sky.

title: A Novel's Heroine Buoys the Spirits of Canada's Acadians
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 4  A new Canadian heroine, PelagielaCharrette, has emerged as a symbol and champion of the Frenchspeaking minority's determination to survive on an Englishspeaking continent.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: When I came in this morning I expected the market to get pounded, but it doesn't want to go down, one municipal bond dealer said yesterday afternoon after he assessed the unexpected action of the credit markets. On Monday, the dollar plunged on the international currency markets, but it recovered yesterday amid reports that central banks were actively intervening to prevent the further decline of the currency.

title: Chamber: Eastman Trio
description: ALTHOUGH it may not figure on anyone's list of the world's bestknown chamber groups, the Eastman Trio, judging from Sunday night's concert at Alice Tully Hall, is an ensemble of worldclass attainments. The violinist is Zvi Zeitlin, the cellist is Robert Sylvester and the pianist is Barry Snyder. Each is a strong instrumentalist with something to say, and as a team their work is vital, fluent and exceptionally refined.

title: And Something for Sipping
description: THE ultimate gift for an oenophile should not be stuffed in a Christmas stocking hanging from a mantel, nor should it be placed under a Christmas tree or even opened on Christmas morning. It is very rare and special bottle of wine that will need careful handling, a refined palate and an enormous budget a Chateau LafiteRothschild 1803 that will be sold at auction next Wednesday at Sotheby Parke Bernet in London.

title: Bridge:
description: Attempts to use the world of tournament bridge as a backdrop for a novel have usually been failures. The latest one, however, is a success, combining literary and bridge skills in pleasing proportions.

title: Koch to Alter Hospital Agency Control
description: Mayor Koch is planning to change the leadership structure of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation in an apparent effort to reduce the power of the corporation's president, Joseph C. Hoffman. city officials said last night.

title: They Love New York  in Any Language
description: THERE are a lot of things the city needs and another charity benefit doesn't head the list. But the men and women involved in such things are an ingenious lot and there's no keeping them down. Just when everyone is ready to yawn with boredom at the very idea of yet another worthy cause, darned if the fertile imaginations don't come up with a new twist sufficiently tempting to move fingers where they really count on check books.

title: Investment Stimulus Urged
description: A New York Stock Exchange study of economic growth in the 1980's urges national consensus to redirect a portion of the nation's output from consumption to larger and more productive investment.

title: Equity Moves to Save 3 Theaters
description: Actors Equity Association asked Mayor Koch and the Board of Estimate yesterday to reevaluate a city official's proposal to make room for a new $170 million, 54story, 2,020room hotel in Times Square by tearing down three major Broadway theaters.

title: Friedrich Ebert, Served As Mayor of East Berlin
description: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 4 (AP)  Friedrich Ebert, a founding member of East Germany's ruling Politburo and the first postwar Mayor of East Berlin, died today. He was 85 years old.

title: Cincinnati Officials Order Inquiry Into Concert Crush That Killed 11
description: This river city was shocked and saddened by the deaths of the young rock fans and the injuries to at least eight others caught in the frenzied stampede to get firstcome, firstserved general admission seats at the concert by the Who.

title: Rep. Vanik Warns Airbus
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Charles A. Vanik, chairman of the House trade subcommittee, today accused a European aircraft consortium of engaging in predatory exportfinancing practices in trying to win a big order from Trans World Airlines and warned that Congress might have to legislate relief if such practices continued.

title: Credit Exports Rise in Japan
description: TOKYO, Dec. 4  Japanese exports based on letters of credit continued to rise in November because of the depreciation in the value of the yen, according to a report released jointly today by the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan.

title: Hospitals and State Settle Suits on Medicaid Rates
description: ALBANY, Dec.4  After three years of litigation and the expenditure of more than $2 million in legal fees, a state agency and a trade group representing 251 hospitals settled several suits today relating to Medicaid reimbursement rates.

title: Egyptian Opposes Asylum for Shah
description: CAIRO, Dec. 4  The leader of Egypt's principal opposition party today criticized President Anwar elSadat's offer to grant asylum to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi.

title: Hearings Open in Marine's Vietnam Desertion Case
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., Dec. 4  Pfc. Robert Russell Garwood today heard Marine Corps prosecutors read the charges, including desertion and collaborating with the enemy, that could lead to his courtmartial and execution.

title: Brooks Brothers Net
description: Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., which operates a nationwide chain of 199 department and specialty stores, reported yesterday that in the third quarter ended Nov. net income totaled $3.7 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $3.8 million, or 81 cents a share, on fewer shares. Sales rose 8.9 percent to $105.7 million.

title: Administration Maps EnergySaving Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Carter Administration officials are scheduled to make public later this week a program to force the states to conserve energy, as well as a proposal for a standby rationing program for gasoline.

title: Court Under TwoFisted Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP)  A man who identified himself as Donald Stolz of Reno today punched out with his fists four glass panels of an interior front door of the Supreme Court Building. He was arrested by Court police officers and held for the District of Columbia police on charge of destroying Government property. He gave no explanation, said the police officer who had apprehended him without force. He just started punching.

title: Sears Said to Consider A Major Reorganization
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the country's largest retailer, is seriously considering a major corporate restructuring in which it would become a holding company with three principal divisions embracing all of its current operations, authoritative financial sources said yesterday.

title: New Drive to Revise Courts Is Begun
description: For the sixth time in as many years, group of judges, lawyers and representatives of good government groups began campaign yesterday to change New York's court structure.

title: Kathleen Crofton, 76, a Dancer, ExDirector of Maryland Ballet
description: BALTIMORE, Dec: 4 (AP)  Kathleen Crofton, former artistic director of the Maryland Ballet, died of a heart attack last Friday in her office in Rochester. She was 76 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Doc. 5 ROTTERDAM (Holland America). Left San Juan Dec. 1; due 10:30 A.M. of W.55th Street.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Mr. Jones had been vice president of the Reid Ice Cream Company in Brooklyn, which he joined in 1919, and became vice president of Borden when Reid merged with the company in 1928. He retired from Borden in 1946, but remained director until 1960. He is survived by daughter, Marion Hocks of Rochester; five grandchildren, and three greatgrandchildren.

title: Soviet and Iranian Planes Watch U.S. Navy Moves in Arabian Sea
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Defense De1 partment officials said today that Soviet) reconnaisance planes, a Soviet warship, and an Iranian Navy plane had been watching the American fleet in the Arabian Sea south of Iran.

title: Too Much Guardian
description: The powers given by the new Iranian constitution to the nation's leader are nothing short of astonishing. Assuming that Ayatollah Khomeini is declared Faghi (trustee or guardian) of the Islamic Republic, he will be empowered to declare war, dismiss an elected president, appoint jurists who may veto the laws of an elected parliament, and more. The constitution is evi dently a far less democratic document than many Iranians had in mind. Indeed, it became more theocratic and authoritarian as it was being written, and it could bend again under unforeseeable political winds. But what must fascinate readers of constitutions is the historical resonance of this Faghi  that, and the faith needed to believe that such an institution could possibly function from generation to generation.

title: Rock Group Dedicates Concert to Dead Fans
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 4  The rock group The Who dedicated its concert here tonight to 11 fans who were killed yesterday in Cincinnati.

title: Copter Rescues 5 Fishermen
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Dec. 4 (AP) - A Coast Guard helicopter rescued five fishermen today from a vessel sinking in the Atlantic about 47 miles off the coast. The men were lifted safely off the deck of the Mary and Vince, a 75foot vessel based in Boston. The Coast Guard was not sure why the boat encountered trouble off Cape Cod this morning.

title: New Haven and State Seek to Save U.S. Steel Plant
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4  Dismayed by U.S. Steel's decision to close its mill here on Dec. 31, with the loss of 400 jobs, city and state officials and union representatives are trying to persuade the company to reverse its decision.

title: Advertising
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 Wherever advertising people gather these days, the talk sooner or later gets around to the controversy over syndicated magazine audience research. And today, on the second day of the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Breakers Hotel, Paul H. Chook, who has been looking at media numbers for about 30 years, gave his informed opinion:

title: Mrs. Harris Strengthens Title IX Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that colleges must give the same proportion of athletic scholarship aid to women athletes as they give to men. But she added that they did not necessarily have to spend the same amount of the total athletic budget on each woman that they spent on each man.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: ADELSONSamuel. Beloved husband of Gunn. Devoted father of Gloria and Jerry. Adored grandfather of Mark, Susan, David and Amy. Services Boulevard Park West, 115 W. 79 St. Wednesday 11:3:14m.

title: G.M. Plans to Cut Output at 7 Plants
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce production at seven auto and truck assembly plants in the United States to cut inventories of slowselling models, effective Jan. 2.

title: Search for Nationalist Terrorists Pressed in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 4  The Federal and local authorities appeared to have few solid leads today and slim prospects of early arrests as they pressed their search for the nationalist terrorists who ambushed a busload of sailors.

title: BurnupGardiner Link
description: Burnup & Sims Inc., a leading telecommunications and cable television service company, said yesterday that it had acquired the Gardiner Communications Corporation, a leader in the marketing of satellite receiving stations. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: News Summary
description: Release at once of American hostages in Teheran was demanded unanimously and urgently in a resolution approved by the 15 members of the United Nations Security Council. The demand reflected extraordinary support for an American position. Donald F. McHenry, the American delegate, said that the family of nations speaks with one voice. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N ) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Russell W. Layland, an advertising executive in the United States and Europe, died Monday after a long illness. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan and Quogue, L.I.

title: A Dazzling Show By Nadia Comaneci
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 4 (AP) Rumania's Nadia Comaneci, no longer the ponytailed sprite who captured the hearts of millions at the 1976 Olympics, coasted through four women's compulsory events today in the 20th World Gymnastics championships.

title: New York Cultural Units Called Lax in Grant Bids
description: Many of New York City's cultural institutions lack aggressiveness in seeking out available Federal grants, a study by the City Comptroller's office has found. Most of the city's museums, botanical gardens and zoos, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said, make virtually no attempt to obtain Federal grant funds because they lack the ability to cope with application procedures.

title: A Tribute to W C Handy
description: A billsigning session at City Hall was unexpectedly set to music yesterday when a trumpeter rose to play a few bars of the St. Louis Blues as Mayor Koch authorized street name change to honor the song's composer, W. C. Handy Jr.

title: Cabinet Quits at Request Of the Nicaraguan Junta
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 4 (UPI) - The entire Cabinet of Nicaragua's revolutionary Government resigned today to allow the nation's fivemember ruling junta to act freely, officials said.

title: Dance: Modern Variety From 2 Experimenters
description: MEL WONG and Sara Rudner are experimental choreographers for whom movement itself provides the motivation for a dance. But the kinds of movement that spilled out onto the Camera Mart /Stage One performing space, where the Sara Rudner Performance Ensemble and Mel Wong Dance Company performed on Sunday under the auspices of the Dance Umbrella festival, were evidence of the variety of modern dance today.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Senate voted to increase the revenues from the proposed tax on windfall oil company profits as a weeklong stalemate ended. Proponents of a lower tax ended their filibuster threat in return for assurances that their amendments would be considered. [Page Al.]

title: Carter's Second Chance: Political Benefits in Iranian Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Three months ago, in the aftermath. of President Carter's puzzling retreat to Camp David and his dramatic Cabinet shakeup, Democratic politicians around the country were giving him no more than 100 days to save his Presidency or be written 9ff for renomination, let alone reelection.

title: SENATORS BACK RISE IN PROPOSED OIL TAX AS STALEMATE ENDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  The legislative logjam holding up President Carter's plan to tax windfall oil profits broke today and the Senate promptly began strengthening the measure along lines suggested by the White House.

title: Violence at Rock Concerts: Cause and Effect
description: mere was nothing about the concert at Cincinnati Monday night that could have led one to predict an incident such as the one that occurred. There was the Who, one of rock's oldest and most popular bands. There was an experienced promoter, and the sort of facility in which many largescale rock concerts take place these days.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: RIRELY have function and beauty so perfecty married as they have in the copper mixing bowl. The copper bowl, gorgeously gleaming bit of symmetry, is, in the opinion of most accomplished cooks, virtually essential for beating egg whites. It is true that egg whites can be beaten in a stainless steel bowl, too, but not with any hope of gaining the volume and the lightness that emerges from a copper bowl. And that airiness is central to, say, the success of souffl.

title: Physician For Classen Under Ban
description: The State Athletic Commission doctor who examined Willie Classen three days before the boxer's fatal bout at the Felt Forum on Nov. 23 is under a year's suspension by another state agency, the Workmen's Compensation Board, for alleged fraudulent practices.

title: Judiciary Committee Sends the Senate a Bill Revising Crime Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  The Senate Judiciary Committee, by a vote of 14 to 1, approved today and sent to the full Senate a 395page bill that would thoroughly revise Federal criminal laws.

title: Common Market Sets Oil Sharing
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 4 (AP)  The nine nations of the European Common Market agreed today on sharing the 472 million tons of oil to which they will limit their overall imports next year, but they showed little solidarity apart from that.

title: President Negotiating To Give Vesco Inquiry Answers by Videotape
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  President Carter is negotiating an agreement to answer questions by videotape for a Federal grand jury investigating allegations that Robert L. Vesco attempted to have his legal problems fixed in the Carter Administration.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: EVERYBODY knows that the Wright Brothers were the first to fly a heavierthanair machine, but how many truly understand what Wilbur and Orville accomplished on Kill Devil Hill at Kitty Hawk, N.C., on Dec. 17, 1903? Not very many, argues Harry Combs, longtime pilot, president since 1971 of Gates Learjet and the author, with Martin Caiden, of Kill Devil Hill: Discovering the Secret of the Wright Brothers. The clich persists, says Mr. Combs, that the brothers were some sort of tinkerers who stumbled onto the secret of flight, or at best that they were skilled bicycle mechanics who took a body of previously developed theory and gave it practical application.

title: Cheese Company Studied For Organized Crime Tie
description: ALBANY, Dec. 4  An application by Canadian company to manufacture mozzarella cheese has plunged the New York State government into a complicated web of investigations and legal proceedings involving alleged control by organized crime of large segments of the Italian cheese industry in the United States.

title: Soviet, Backing U.S. in Crisis, Is. Said to Improve Own Ties With Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  American officials said today that the Soviet Union had responded to the Iranian crisis by giving lowkey support to United States efforts to gain the release of the hostages while shoring up ties with Teheran.

title: Niagara Falls Is Considered As Defendant in Waste Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  The Justice Department has added the Olin Corporation and the City of Niagara Falls, N.Y., to a suit it has prepared against the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation involving the dumping of toxic wastes in that city.

title: Central Bank Reports Dollar Support
description: The Federal Reserve and the Treasury actively supported the dollar during the AugustOctober quarter, the central bank disclosed yesterday in its regular auarterlv report on its dealings in the foreignexchange markets. All the support, however, came before Oct. 6 when the Federal Reserve announced its moneytightening program that drove interest rates sharply higher.

title: TeenAgers in Poll Back Traditional Home Values
description: A poll of top high school students indicates a swing back toward traditional values regarding home and marriage. Only 8 percent of those surveyed said they favored couples living together before marriage while 47 percent of those polled in 1971 said they favored cohabitation before marriage.

title: OHIRA LEAVES TODAY FOR VISIT TO PEKING
description: TOKYO, Dec. 4  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira will lead a Japanese delegation to Peking tomorrow on a fiveday trip with profound and complex implications for the course of Asian affairs.

title: State Bonds Fall By Half a Grade In Latest Rating
