But there are companies that stock obsolete window hardware or will fabricate replacement parts if a sample is available to copy. They also stock parts for vintage bifold and sliding closet doors and patio or terrace doors. New hardware for steel and aluminum windows and doors is also available through these dealers.

title: Air Force Flying Relief Supplies To WavePounded Atoll in Pacific
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 5 (AP)  Air Force planes are flying relief missions to provide basic necessities for residents of Majuro Atoll, which is being pounded by 15to20foot waves for the second time in a week.

title: 4 Plead Guilty in Election Fraud
description: OPELOUSAS, La., Dec. 5 (AP)  Four men pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today to charges of buying 120 votes at $5 each in order to win a seat on the St. Landry Parish School Board. United States Attorney Ransdell Keene of Shreveport said it was the first time the Federal Government had prosecuted election fraud involving a state election.

title: Council Vacancy Rule Advances
description: The Rules Committee of the New York City Council yesterday approved a requirement that any vacancy in a Council committee chairmanship be filled within 90 days and in committee memberships within 00 days. The rule is expected to win approval of the full Council next week.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Nets Win As Natt Gets 27
description: PISCATAWAY, NJ., Dec. 5  If any of the 5,162 fans gathered tonight at the Rutgers Athletic Center had any lingering doubts about the Nets trade of Bernard King, last season's leading scorer, to make room for Calvin Natt, a rookie, they must have been dispelled after New Jersey's 115100 victory over the Phoenix Suns.

title: Christmas Dilemma: The Holiday Tip
description: IF you don't tip the superintendent this Christmas, will your pipes explode one day, ruining your parquet floors and flooding the apartment below, thus destroying the Aubusson carpets of the vacationing downstairs neighbors, who will then enmesh you in a $500.000 lawsuit?

title: Oil Companies Check Security
description: Some of the American oil companies operating in Libya said yesterday that they had taken steps to safeguard their personnel in Libya. The companies emphasized that operations were normal.

title: At Your Service: Buying New Windows
description: REPLACING old, ugly windows is one of the most rewarding home improvements because new doubleglazed, tightfitting windows will ultimately pay for themselves in fuel savings. The immediate rewards, which really sell these expensive windows, are good looks, comfort and convenience (the windows tilt indoors for easy cleaning and most never need painting).

title: Market Place
description: IS one of the more profitable tax shelters losing appeal, along with the companies that are structured to provide that shelter? That's one interpretation of last week's announcement that National

title: Four Potential Refuges Are Ruled Out by Shah
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 5  A spokesman for the deposed Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, today ruled out the Bahamas and Panama as refuges.

title: Advertising
description: Adapting To Use New Media

title: Kennedy Shifts Criticisms on Iran, Urging a Public Debate on Asylum
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, trying to deflect the political fallout from his criticism of the deposed Shah of Iran, said today that any decision to grant the Shah permanent asylum in this country should be the subject of full public debate.

title: Deaths
description: BRENNERJoseph. Beloved and devoted husband of Florence, deer brother of Aaron and David Brenner, and Frances Flaum. Loving uncle. Services Thursday December 6, 1979 1 P.M. The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Today Is Friml's Broadway Day
description: The Mayor's Office of Special Events has proclaimed today Rudolf Friml's Broadway Day to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth.

title: Some in Cincinnati Seek Ban on Rock After Deaths
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 5  At the office of Mayor John Kenneth Blackwell, the phone rings and rings. Many of the callers are angrily demanding a ban on rock music in Cincinnati. At the Globe record shop, one of the big record retailers here, management is concerned about a tapering off in sales. And at several of the city's rock music stations, there is some worry about declines, if only temporary, in listeners and advertising.

title: MOVE TO OUST MAYOR;REVERSED BY ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 5  Israel reversed its decision today to deport the Palestinian Mayor of Nablus, Bassam alShaka, and released him from prison. He returned in triumph to his hometown on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan, where hundreds of supporters gathered In festive rallies, cheering him, carrying him on . their shoulders and shouting Palestinian nationalist slogans.

title: Keeping Family Ties;Over Long Distance
description: THE last time my immediate family gathered together in the same room was at my wedding, nearly four years ago. This has to do, mostly, with geography. My two older brothers have abandoned their native land of No Parking and potholes for the suburbs of Philadelphia and Florida. My parents spend 10 months year in Florida. Which leaves me here in New York City, loyal but without family. Sometimes just keeping track of one another's whereabouts is a job in itself.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) The Nuclear Regulatory Commission tentatively approved new rules today that would require nuclear power plants to have federally approved state and local emergency plans or face possible closing.

title: EARNINGS
description: Gulf and Western Industries reported yesterday that earnings gained 12.7 percent for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31. Although they were the highest for any quarter in the company's 21year history, the increase was less than the Sales rise of 21.7 Percent.

title: THAIS AGAIN CUT AID TO CAMBODIAN CAMP
description: SISOPHON DISTRICT, Cambodia, Dec. 5 For the third day, no food was delivered today to an encampment of nearly 300,000 Cambodians who have turned an area of fallow ricefields hard on the Thai border into Cambodia's most densely populated center.

title: Moscow Backs Iran on Hostages While Conceding Breach of Rules
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5  The Soviet Union made it clear in an authoritative cornmentary today that it was backing Iran in the crisis over the American hostages while recognizing that they were being held in violation of international law.

title: About Nassau Hispanic Residents Have An Official Champion
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 2 The wave of Hispanic culture that washed over the Americas starting almost 500 years ago is finally lapping at Nassau County, where the Hispanic population has increased in eight years from 90,000 to a total now estimated at 100,000.

title: Estimates on Gulf Spill By Mexico Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Oil from a blown well in the Bay of Campeche, already the biggest spill in history, is continuing to pour into the Gulf of Mexico at a rapid rate despite assertions by the Mexican Government that spillage has been sharply reduced, witnesses testified at a Senate hearing today.

title: Ukrainian Archbishop Installed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (UPI) Myroslav J. Lubachivsky has been installed as Ukrainian Archbishop of Philadelphia, becoming, in effect, spiritual leader of the nation's 1.5 million Ukrainian Roman Catholics. Archbishop Lubachivsky, named by Pope John Paul II to the post last, month, received the gold staff of office yesterday . from the Most Rev. Jean Jadot, the Apostolic Delegate.

title: Home Beat
description: A Potter's Stackable Ceramics

title: Yule Cards for Hostages Urged
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (UPI)  Radio station KMPC urged its listeners today to send Christmas cards to its news correspondent in Iran for possible delivery to the 50 hostages held in the United States Embassy in Teheran. It said the cards should be addressed to: Fellow Americans, c/o Alex Paen, KMPC, Hotel Intercontinental, P.O. Box 121517, Iran Novin, Teheran, Iran.

title: Area RollCall on King Holiday Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP)  Following are votes cast by representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut today on the question of commemorating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. s birthday on the third Sunday in January rather than the third Monday in January. A yes vote was a vote in favor of the change and a no vote was a vote against it; xxx means not voting.

title: Airbus Gains In Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 5 (AP)  The Australian Government has approved the purchase by Trans Australian Airlines of four Airbus A300B4 aircraft, the Transport Minister, Peter Nixon. announced today.

title: Pledge on Chrysler Stock
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (Reuters) ChryslerPlymouth dealers in southern California will purchase $5.8 million of the Chrysler Corporation's new preferred stock over a threeyear period.

title: Calendar of Events
description: American Crafts Holiday Festival, New York University, 586 La Guardia Place, Washington Square Park.

title: Design Notebook
description: Celebrating the endurance and stability of wood.

title: Auction Tomorrow to Defy 1773 Law
description: Until yesterday, auctions held at night in New York City could sell paintings, sculptures, works of art and horses  but not chairs, lamps and vases.

title: U.S. Is Irritated by Article
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The United States was irritated today by the article in Pravda, the Soviet party daily, which also said that, instead of showing restraint in the current crisis, certain circles in the United States are putting their bets more and more on force.

title: Santa's Strategy for 1979
description: The Christmas season has swept into New York's stores on the wings of anaels or so it seems.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. Steel Seeks Help From Japan
description: David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that the company would turn to a major Japanese steelmaker to help it solve severe production problems at its pipe mill in Baytown, Tex.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Plants of Summer Find Winter Homes
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.

title: For Street Peddlers, Police Seizure Of Wares Means It's Not Their Day
description: Eddie Lopez looked furtively up and down Fifth Avenue from the corner of 52d Street, where he was selling stickpins for $2 and $3. He was one of the few peddlers who ventured out yesterday, the day a new regulation went into force allowing the police to seize, on the spot, any wares being offered by peddlers on major shopping streets.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Dec. 5.1919

title: Stage Folk Give $192,841 For Cambodian Relief
description: Liv Ullmann, on behalf of New York area theaters, presented a check for $192,841 for Cambodian relief yesterday to Leo Cherne, chairman of the International Rescue Committee. She said the goal was $200,000 by Saturday. Money was collected from actors, actresses and theater audiences by the Theater Committee for Cambodian Relief.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Questions of life and death are being raised ever more frequently on college campuses these days and the inquiries are taking place in administrative offices, not lust in philosophy classes.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Modern Dance: David Gordon's Matter
description: THE Matter (plus and minus) is the name of the twohour work being presented by David Gordon, an experimental choreographer and veteran of the Judson Dance Theater of the 1980's, at the Dance Umbrella, 54th Street and 10th Avenue.

title: Recital: The Bach of Rosalyn Tureck
description: AT this late date, arguments about the scholarly correctness or personal idiosyncracy of Rosalyn Tureck's Bach style, or indeed about her very favoring of the piano over the harpsichord for his secular keyboard music, seem a little stale. Either one likes her or not, and accepts her predilections or rejects them. This writer, on the basis of her Carnegie Hall recital Tuesday night, accepts them and likes her.

title: An Ayatollah's Boycott of Vote Assailed
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 5  Angered by his objections to Iran's Islamic Constitu tion, a crowd Shouting insults tonight marched on the home of Ayatollah Kazem ShariatMadari, one of the coun try's revered religious figures, and, ac cording to his office, at least one person was killed and nine were injured.

title: Russians Capture Gymnastics
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 5 (AP)  The Soviet Union, with no competitor scoring under a 9.5, stormed to the men's team championship of the world gymnastics tournament tonight for the first time in nearly two decades, with the United States third, the best finish it had ever made.

title: Screen: Found Footage at the Forum
description: THAT men behave like beasts is the none too suprising point of FioreIla Mariani's Homo Sapiens, a dogged, 55minute documentary made up entirely of ItalIan and French newsreel clips dating from 1925 through 1958. The film is the longest and most ambitious of the five shorts comprising the Film Forum's new show, Homo Sapiens: Found Footage Film Making, which explores the possibilities of films composed entirely of other people's work.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: G.E. Lifts TV Prices
description: The General Electric Company yesterday announced a 3 percent price increase on Its color television sets, effective Jan. 1, that will have the effect of raising retail prices by $10 to $20 a set. The company also announced a 2.5 percent price increase on its blackandwhite television sets.

title: I.M.F. Gold Sale Averages $426.37
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) Gold sold for an average $426.37 an ounce at the International Mono. tary Fund's monthly auction today, the agency said. The average price at the preceding I.M.F. sale, held Nov. 7. was $393.55 an ounce.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Sol Kittay, who built the B.V.D. Compny into one of the most diversified companies in the apparel industry before selling it to the Glen Alden Corporation 13 years ago, is about to acquire control of King's Department Stores, a major operator of discount stores, King's announced. The agreement to buy 11.8 percent of King's for $17 a share was made by Mr. Kittay's privately owned concern, Cornwall Equities Ltd.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Dense overcast clouds cover New England and frontal clouds extend from the western lake region through the Central Plains States to northern Texas. Layered clouds stretch from the central Rockies to the Pacific Northwest and high level clouds cover the Southern Pacific States.

title: Carey and Koch Bid School Board Formally Approve Budget Controls
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Koch said yesterday that they would ask the Board of Education to give formal approval to new controls on spending by the New York City school system.

title: Catholic Church Rejects Request To Assure Aliens on 1980 Census
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The Roman Catholic church today rebuffed Government requests that it lend its name and credibility to the 1980 census to persuade illegal aliens to register.

title: Sharon Shashanovich At 78th St. Theater Lab
description: Sharon Shashanovah by Alexander Francis Horn has started performances at the 78th Street Theater Lab, 236 West 78th Street. Featuring Sharon Gans in the title role, the play is directed by Mr. Horn, with music by Judy CasteIli, lights by Jeff Davis, sets by Michael Aitchison and Puppets by Nicholas Cortes.

title: Chicago Mayor Accuses Schools of Hiding Fiscal Woes
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 5  Mayor Jane M. Byrne asserted today that the Chicago Board of Education's financial dilemma was a result of a 10year coverup by school and business officials who sought to portray the school system as financially strong in a period when it was in deen trouble.

title: The Kid Is Quite A Captain
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 5  In his tailored gray tweed suit, white turtleneck and expensive black shoes, Steve Cauthen resembled a 19yearold millionaire from the English countryside, not the Kentucky countryside. And when he got up to speak today as the American team captain promoting Saturday night's Meadowlands International Jockey Challenge championship, he described the five European riders as quite good gentlemen ana gooa friends.

title: Thousands Wear Arm Bands in Iran Crisis
description: Radio station WMCA has been deluged with hundreds of thousands of requests for white arm bands that signify support for the American hostages in Iran. The idea was proposed by one of the New York station's talkshow hosts during a broadcast last week.

title: Dawkins Shatters 2d Backboard
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) Darryl Dawkins shattered a backboard for the second time this season with a powerful dunk shot tonight, as the Philadelphia 76ers beat the San Antonio Spurs, 132120, for their seventh straight National Basketball Association victor.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Continued at Philipsburg Manor, one of the Sleepy Hollow Restorations, in Tarrytown, N.Y., Saturday and Sunday as part of an 18thcenturystyle observance of the DutchAmerican feast of St. Nicholas. The good saint traveled far to bring gifts to deserving children, it was said, so food was left for his horse. Candle light tours of the manor from 5 to 9 P.M. will be led by guides in period cos tume. Daily admission of $3 ($2 for chil dren and the elderly; those younger than 6 free) includes the tours. Infor mation: (914) 6318200. At Snug Harbor on Staten Island  an 80acre former seamen's home now an arts center  a free 19thcentury Christmas weekend is planned, including children's enter tainment Saturday 1 to 6 P.M. and, Sun day 1 to 6 P.M., horse and buggy rides and a show of train sets, handmade toys and tree decorations. Informa tion: 4482500.

title: Carter's Increase in Poll Linked to Iranian Crisis
description: President Carter's handling of the Iranian crisis has led to a sixpoint increase in his popularity among votingage adults, according to figures released today by the Gallup Poll of Princeton.

title: Chinese Buy Foreign Song Book
description: PEKING, Dec. 5 (Reuters) All 50,000 copies of a book of foreign songs with lyrics in English and Chinese were sold out on the day of publication in Shanghai, the New China News Agency said today. It said that the Shanghai publishing house was preparing another 50,000 copies of the book, which contains songs from the United States, Australia, Britain and Canada.

title: World Gold
British Miners Reject Strike
description: LONDON, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  Britain's coal miners narrowly voted today against taking strike action and pulled back from a headon confrontation with the Conservative Government.

title: The Soares Legacy in Portugal
description: Portuguese democracy has taken some new turns with the apparent electoral victory of Francisco Si Carneiro's rightist coalition. Despite gains by hardline Communists, conservatives are likely to predominate in the Government for the first time since soldiers toppled the Caetano dictatorship in 1974. And for the first time since parliamentary democracy began in 1976, a Prime Minister should emerge with an absolute majority.

title: Stars Spin In to Open Roxy Roller Disco
description: WHEELS whirled uptown and downtown last night, with an invitationonly premiere party at the Roxy roller palace on West 18th Street and a skating party for Broadway stars at the High Roller rink on West 57th Street.

title: Trustees at U. of Massachusetts Decide to Honor Andrew Young
description: BOSTON, Dec. 5  The trustees of the University of Massachusetts voted today to offer an honorary degree to Andrew Young, whose resignation last August as chief United States delegate to the United Nations prompted disputes among leaders of some black and Jewish groups.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Television and Communications Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Time Inc., has elected John F. Gault president of Manhattan Cable, succeeding Thayer Bigelow Jr., who has been elected a vice president for TimeLife Films.

title: Controversy Clouding Cable TV in City
description: The New York City Bureau of Franchises and its longtime director, Morris Tarshis, have become the focus of a growing controversy over cable television rights. At issue are new franchises that will be awarded in the four boroughs and also the enforcement of two existing franchise agreements in Manhattan.

title: Eurodollars For Thrifts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI)  In another effort to assist the slumping housing industry, Government regulators voted today to allow some thrift institutions to issue Eurodollarbacked certificates of deposit to foreign investors.

title: 3 Homes Carved From One Space
description: MANY couples who design and build a place to live discover the tensions involved in renovating. By the time the project is finished, they may find that their relationship has come apart while their home was coming together. But Laura Bohn and Richard Fiore, close friends who had often worked topether were wiser_

title: Sound Hans Fantel
description: OUR Christmas audiobuying guide  begun last week with a survey of budgetpriced components  now moves into the medium price range. There is nothing middling about midpriced components. As a group, they satisfy the sonic demands of even the most richly orchestrated score and of musically discerning ears. A system assembled from the components mentioned here will provide frequency response encompassing the whole musical gamut, very quiet background and power enough to render rousing crescendos without reaching the point of distortion.

title: JAMES B. AMBERSON, MEDICAL PROFESSOR
description: Dr. James Burns Amberson, professor emeritus of medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and a former president of the New York Lung Association, died Monday at his home in Hillsdale, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: 90 Bodies Are Found in Antarctic At New Zealand DC10 Wreckage
description: SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  A New Zealand spokesman said today that 90 bodies had been recovered from the mountainside where an Air New Zealand DC10 crashed last week, killing all 257 aboard. The bodies were flown to New Zealand.

title: The Region
description: About 250,000 Long Island Lighting Company customers in Suffolk County lost electrical service for an hour Tuesday night after vandals broke into a Holbrook substation and opened circuit breakers and pulled switches, June Bruce, a Lilco spokesman said.

title: GARDENING
description: NOTHING could make a serious gardener merrier this holiday season than good, workable gifts. Forget the cute gadgets and fun tools that scarcely last through the giving season. More to the point are nuts and bolts items: the wellmade quality tool that will stay on the job in the years ahead; innovative aids to growing more plants, or splendid reference books that can inspire a gardener to grow wonderful things.

title: Referee Tells Why He Let Classen Go On
description: Lew Eskin, the referee in the Felt Forum bout on Nov. 23 that resulted in the death of the boxer Willie Classen, told a state investigating committee yesterday that at no point had he considered stopping the fight before Classen was knocked out 13 seconds into the 10th round.

title: HydroQuebec Weighs Link
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  A spokesman for HydroQuebec said today that the utility had nearly reached a decision to spend $200 million to link for the first time its transmission lines directly with those in New York State.

title: Jewett T. Flagg, Leader In the Apparel Industry
description: Jewett T. Flagg, a textile and apparel manufacturing executive for half a century and one of the pioneers in the industry's move from the Northeast to the South, died of a heart ailment last Sunday at his home, Blackwater Farms, Jasper, Ala. He was 78 years old.

title: Caesars World's License Extended
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 5 (AP) The New Jersey Casino Control Commission voted unanimously today to extend for three months the temporary permit of the Caesars Boardwalk Regency Casino Hotel.

title: Deaths
description: LUDWIGLouis. The Greater New York Committee for Israel Bonds notes with profound sorrow The passing of its Mahopac Chairman, who for the past 25 years devoted his life to the cause of Israel's eco nomic development. Our heartfelt sympathy to the family.

title: Senate Bars Consideration of Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The Senate voted narrowly tonight to block consideration of a Republican proposal to limit overall Government tax revenue and produce an annual tax cut of $39 billion to $55 billion during the next four years.

title: Pilot Program Will try to Get 90,000 Dropouts to Return to High School
description: A $2 million pilot program to find ways of getting 90,000 hardcore truants and dropouts to return to high school will begin in February in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, public school officials said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Orders Rules Review
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The Securities and Exchange Commission directed its staff today to begin a broad, fivetosevenyear review of the agency's corporate disclosure rules and requirements.

title: Myron W Watkins, 85, Worked in Justice Dept.
description: Dr. Myron W. Watkins, an economist, died Tuesday in the Shady Knoll Nursing Home in Seymour, Conn. He was 85 years old and had lived in Stamford for more than 40 years.

title: New State Bonds, at 6.71%, Sell Slowly
description: New York State sold $81 million of bonds yesterday that were priced to give investors taxfree yields ranging from 8.20 percent on those maturing in 1980 to 7.10 percent on those coming due . in 2004. The bonds sold relatively slowly although their rates were substantially higher than rates on the state's bonds marketed in February.

title: TV Weekend
description: ADDING substantially to television's holidayseason preoccupation with material designed to be heartwarming is Valentine, a twohour movie on WABC, Channel 7, tonight at 9. Pete Ferguson and Gracie Schwartz are madly in love and run off together on a freewheeling vacation. The catch is that Pete and Gracie are in their 70's.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sinfonta No. 12, Benda; Organ Sonata No. 4 (K.144), Mozart; Minuet, Haydn; Excerpt from La Vierge, Massenet.

title: Texas Concern Cited by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the founder of a Texas computer company and two business associates with fraud in a civil suit filed today in connection with a plan to rescue the company from bankruptcy.

title: Loan for Philippines
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  The World Bank today approved a $27 million loan to the Philippines at 7.95 percent interest to develop roads and ports on the island of Samar.

title: Hard Times for the Tiffin Wallahs
description: The meals, packed in aluminum cylinders with four compartments called tiffins, are cooked by the wives or mothers of the customers. Picked up at homes mostly in the suburbs, they are routed to the rightful owners by a railandfoot delivery system that is a marvel of labourintensive organization. The deliverers, the heart of the system, are called tiffin wallahs and they exist only in Bombay.

title: Mondale Extols
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 6  Vice President Mondale stumped the length of Illinois today, raising funds among Democrats in this pivotal state and hammering at points that are emerging as the central themes of the campaign to reelect President Carter.

title: Followers of Another Ayatollah Stage a Protest Against Khomeini
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6  In a gesture previously unheard of in revolutionary Iran, hundreds of angry Islamic demonstrators marched on the headquarters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini this morning in the holy city of Qum.

title: Art: A Buffet of English Portraits at Yale
description: ENGLISH Portrait Drawings and Miniatures at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven may not sound like the fun show of the year, but in point of fact it is as entertaining as it is instructive. Where else can we rub noses with John Locke the philosopher, Joan Keats the poet, Sir Hans Sloane, founder of the British Museum, Moses Kean the onelegged impersonator, and Lady Diana Cooper, perhaps the most beautiful Englishwoman of our century? They are all there in the Yale Center for British Art, along with many another person well worth looking at, and they will be on view through Feb. 17.

title: Stocks Move Ahead For 3d Day in a Row
description: The stock market moved moderately higher for the third session in a row yesterday as energy, airline, computer and gambling issues pointed the way.

title: Brazil Suspends Currency Trading
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 6 (AP)  Brazil's central bank ordered all foreignexchange operations suspended at the close of the banking day today until further notice.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Overcast extends from the Atlantic Coast to the Mississippi Valley, except over portions of New England. Bright thunderstorm clouds arm, the northern Gulf Coast. Layered clouds extend across the Northern Plains States, with high and thin clouds streaked across the northern Plateau Region and the central Rockies.

title: Texas International In Merger Talks
description: The Texas International Company said that UNC Resources Inc., the uranium producer, had initiated preliminary discussions with it concerning the possible acquisition of Texas International by UNC.

title: TaxExempt Authority Bonds
description: FTraded Flat

title: Conferees Agree on Military Funds $1 Billion Below Carter's Request
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  A HouseSenate conference agreed tonight on a military appropriation bill of about $131 billion, about $1.3 billion less than that requested by President Carter last January for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.

title: Appointment to U.N. Delegation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)  President Carter announced today that State Senator H. Carl McCall of New York had been appointed alternate representative for special political affairs in the delegation to the United Nations. He replaces Richard Petree, who has been made deputy representative of the United States in the Security Council.

title: Estimate Board Balks on Study of Franchises Bureau
description: The Board of Estimate postponed action yesterday on authorizing a study of Its Bureau of Franchises by an outside rsongultinsE firm.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Style
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Although he has been on the campaign trail for a month, Senator Edward M. Kennedy is still casting about for a style that is comfortable for him.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: The Washington Post/Matthew Lewis

title: No Cuts in Use of Gasoline Sought In New U.S. Conservation Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Carter Administration made public today a new gasoline conservation plan that, rather than demanding sacrifices of every driver, as had been predicted, merely calls for holding consumption steady.

title: Money
The 10 Best Sellers
description: Ten of the bestselling electronic toys and their list prices, as reported by several Manhattan stores and a major distributor, are:

title: State Employees Approve Pact
description: Members of the Public Employees Federation, representing 47,000 professional, scientific and technical employees of New York State, have voted overwhelmingly for ratification of a new contract, a spokesman for the group announced last night. The mail ballot vote, tallied by the American Arbitration Association, was 14,299 in favor and 5,807 against.

title: Philharmonic: Harrell Plays Dvorak
description: IT was Dvorak last night at the New York Philharmonic concert, with James Levine leading a program that consisted of the Cello Concerto, with Lynn Harrell as soloist, and the Symphony No. 7 in D minor. Mr. Harrell is one of the bigwattage lights among American cellits, and has been for some years. As for Mr. Levine, he is all over the world in opera and symphony. It was pleasant to see two such talented young men making music with such expertise and dedication.

title: 14 Killed and 60 Injured In Train Crash in Spain
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  A crewless train ran into a stationary passenger train at high speed near here today, killing at least 14 people and injuring 60, railroad officials said.

title: Grease Breaks a Record on Broadway
description: When the curtain drops to the rockandroll beat of We Go Together, at tomorrow's matinee of Grease at the Royale Theater, the show will have played its 3,243d performance and displaced Fiddler on the Roof as the longestrunning show in the annals of Broadway.

title: Rep. Johnson Bars Fifth Term
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) — Representative James P. Johnson, Republican of Colorado, announced today that he would not seek a fifth term in 1980. He said that he and his family would return to their home in Fort Collins, Colo., at the end of his fourth term a year from now.

title: Different Kind of Fiddler Plays at Fisher Hall
description: It is no secret that the age of the hillbilly is dead. Grand Ole Opry comediennes are society matrons in real life, bluegrass soloists are really heart surgeons, songwriters are journalism majors and live on yachts in Marina del Rey.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Art People
description: ONE of the better ways to see the world is to be director of the Metropolitan Museum. Philippe de Montebello, the present incumbent, was in Rome yesterday. Today he is in Moscow. Tomor row  well, as to tomorrow he isn't saying, but when he called from Rome there was a note of elation in his voice that got through even to an answering service.

title: Peking Closes Democracy Wall, Banishes Posters to Remote Park
description: PEKING, Dec. 6  A thin gray line of free expression called Democracy Wall was abolished today by the authorities after a year in which it was plastered with wall posters by dissidents and petitioners criticizing China's leaders, demanding more democratic freedoms and complaining about bureaucratic injustices.

title: Death

Services today 1PM at Gutter man's 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to The Heart Fund.

Hufstedier, former Judge of the United States Court of Appeals, being congratulated by President Carter yesterday after a White House ceremony. title: FakeArt Seller In Chrysler Case Accused Again; Gallery Trying to Recover $1 Million for 23 Works

The dealer says that neither then nor now has he guaranteed the authenticity of any of the works he sold.

description: BET HANINA, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Dec. 6  While Bassam alShaka settled back in his Mayor's chair at Nablus today, greeting streams of wellwishers congratulating him on his release from an Israeli Drison. his col leagues among the Palestinian leadership in the occupied areas were congratulating themselves for a skillful political performance.

description: ROSARIO, Argentina, Dec. 6 (UPI) Fire swept through a nightclub here shortly before dawn today and killed 16 young people who sought refuge in restrooms from smoke and fire and suffocated. At least 10 people were hurt.

description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 6 (AP)  West Germany's balanceofpayments surplus narrowed in October to about $205.7 million from September's surplus of about $5.45 billion.

title: The Era of Black Vaudeville Travels From New Orleans to the Village Gate
description: VERNEL BAGNERIS, who created, directed and plays a leading role in One Mo Time, the evening of 1920's black vaudeville that is enjoying a successful run at the Village Gate there will be five performances this weekend  remembers the show's genesis as a basic impulse. I was tourinp with the Everyman Players, doing classical acting, he says in his mellifluous New Orleans accent, and it was just too rigid; I wanted to get down. Ma Rainey, Butterbeans and Suzy, the stars of 20's black vaudeville, that was a way of getting back to the roots for me.

title: Dr. Arthur C. Upton Quits as Head Of Cancer Institute to Join N.Y.U.
description: The Government's top cancer official, Dr. Arthur C. Upton, is resigning as director of the National Cancer Institute to head the environmental medicine department at the New York University Medical School, officials of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced in Washington yesterday.

title: Christmas Tree at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)  The White House Christmas tree, an 18foot Douglas fir, arrived at the White House today from West Virginia. President Carter's wife, Rosalynn, accepted the tree.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The price of gold rose in Europe today and closed at a record high of $434.25 an ounce in London before falling back in New York. The dollar slipped in Europe and then recovered In late New York trading.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Panama has accused the United States of a material breath of the Panama Canal Treaty because the Administration has not yet filled its five positions on the board of directors of the Panama Canal Commission.

description: He once referred to himself as Just a ham at heart, so when he announced his resignation yesterday he invited top city officials, stars in the world of New York economists and many of the city's most powerful business and labor leaders to bid him farewell.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Producer Price Index, which anticipates inflation trends, rose 1.3 percent in November, partly because of an unexpected surge in food prices, the Labor Department reported today.

description: THE large exhibition of drawings by David Smith that opened this week at the Whitney Museum of American Art Is, without doubt, one of the best shows to be seen in this museum for many years. Organized by Paul Cummings.

title: Congress Erred On CETA
description: CLIFTON, N.J.  Flaws in the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, the Government's manpower program, led Congress in 1978 to enact legislation to eliminate mismanagement in what Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall called the new CETA. Tne congressional view was summed up by Senator Thomas Eagleton, who declared: Unless this thing is tightened up, the whole CETA program is in considerable jeopardy.

The driver's name was familiar: Ottis Jerome Anderson, who just happened to be, in the opinion of the Cowboys, the secondhighestrated player available in the professional football draft.

title: Everything's Torrid but the Weather in Troubled Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 6  John Cox's grin and J.K. Ramey's gun tell a lot about goingson here these days. What with the crime wave, the marathon feuds at City Hall and the tribulations of Senator Herman E. Talmadge, things are in just the. kind of political stew that Atlantans savor.

title: U.S. AIDES IN SOVIET ANGERED OVER IRAN

They feel that the United States has not pressed the Russians hard enough to help in the situation.

title: Associated Press

The rock group the Who returned to Ohio last night for a concert in Cleveland. Page A22.

title: Black Watch Marches Into Garden
description: Madison Square Garden will reverberate to Scotland the Brave, The Ale Is Dear and Mrs. McLeod O'Rassaay on Sunday afternoon, when the massed precisionmarching bands, bagpipers and drummers of the Black Watch, Royal Highland Regiment, fill the Garden with the skirl and colors of Scotland. On hand, too, will be practitioners of an art that is as honorable and at least as old: the highland dance.

title: Economic Scene
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Movie Tunesmith Is Rediscovered at 85
description: LOS ANGELES  The Chickering piano is 40 years old; the man playing Is nearly N. The unpublished tune beneath his fingers  a lament for lost lovers and lost loves  is his own. He has written 300 or 400 songs; he lost track of the exact number 30 years ago.

title: Correcting the Medicaid Tilt
description: In 1978, the Federal Government paid 78 percent of Mississippi's Medicaid costs  but only 50 percent of New York's. There was once a good explanation. Disproportionate numbers of poor, sick people lived in states like Mississippi  where local governments were too impoverished to offer much help. But over the years, a humane disbursement has become a cruel one. Cities, like New York, have become the nation's poorhouses  in two senses. They now contain a disproportionate number of the poor, and they are virtually broke. If there was once a case to be made for giving more help to the Mississippis of the country, that case must be made for the New Yorks. That is exactly the case Senator Moynihan has now laid clearly before the Congress.

title: Gang Wars Still Rage in Chinatown
description: Be is Chinese, but he is known as Bradley Joe. Fraillooking, wispywhiskered and just 5 feet 7 Inches tall, he seemed to shiver slightly under his green Army fatigue jacket on a recent chilly afternoon. He had paused briefly along Mott Street in Chinatown to talk with a plainclothesman he knew.

title: The Rights Noose
description: WASHINGTON  The collapse of Western collective security before World War II sealed the fate of European Jews and led to genocide in Nazi Germany. The collapse of collective security after the United States abandoned Southeast Asia to the Soviet and Chinese struggle for spheres of influence has produced the genocide campaign against the Cambodian people.

title: Painting: Ludwig Sander's Passion for Color
description: IN generation and in spirit, Ludwig Sander, who died in 1975 at the age of 69, was a charter member of the New York School, though his canvases never served as the grandscale gestural theater that they did for more noted members of the Abstract Expressionist group. He had a passion for color, which he expressed in his work via large, saturated chromatic fields separated by gently drawn black lines in the simplest of rectangular compositions, the better to focus on the subtle relationships of tone to tone. The works have a calm, even meditative presence, but beneath their meticulously brushed surfaces lurks a joyous lyricism, held back by a fastidious control. Indeed, the excitement of looking at these pictures comes from the tension between this lyricism and the austere means by which it is conveyed.

title: Mozambique Sentences 5 to Die
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Mozambique's Revolutionary Military Tribunal has sentenced 5 persons to death and 12 to jail terms of 2 to 30 years for crimes against the security of the people and state, the Maputo radio, monitored here, reported today.

title: Miss Nadig Wins Again; Leads World Cup Skiing
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 6 MarieTherese Nadig of Switzerland won the women's giant slalom today and moved far ahead in the overall World Cup standing after only two events.

description: Dr. Marvin Allen Stevens, an orthopedic surgeon in New Haven and New York City who was better known to sports followers as Mal Stevens, the former football coach at Yale and New York University, died in a Bronx nursing home yesterday after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Muscovites Are Sweltering
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Muscovites were sweltering behind sealed double windows today as newspapers reported temperatures up to 44 degrees, the highest for early December since records began 100 years ago. At the first sign of

description: Avery Rockefeller Jr., an executive of Grolier Inc., a publishing company in Danbury, Conn., was killed Tuesday in an automobile accident near his home in Greenwich. Conn. He was 55 years old.

Rose Associates, one of the city's largest residential and commercial builders, first fell in with the drift in 1939, when David Rose built the Westmore apartments a few doors from the Henry Hudson Hotel on the north side of the block between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

title: Article 111758645 -- No Title
November 28, 4579
description: Circuit Judge Richard Samuels of Markham, Ill., imposed a sentence last week that risks making him look either like the harshest Judge alive or the silliest. What looks harsh is sentencing a convicted murderer a maximum of 2,600 years in prison. In theory, the prisoner might have to serve until Nov. 28, 4579, a date more appropriate to the log of the Starship Enterprise. What looks silly, or sillier, is that the defendant will be eligible for oarole in 11 years and 3 months.

title: Canada to Let U.S. Buy Extra $15 Billion in Gas
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 6  In its largest gas export award to date, the Canadian Government has approved the sale to the United States of 3.75 trillion cubic feet of natural gas worth about $15 billion from 1980 to 1987. The total is based on current order prices of $3.40 per thousand cubic feet of gas.

P.L.O. Leader Is Called to Beirut Over Acceptance of Rights Prize
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 6 (Reuters) The Palestine Liberation Organization has summoned its representative in Europe, Dr. Issam Sartawi, to Beirut to answer questions about why he accepted a human rights prize jointly with an Israeli. Palestinian sources said today.

title: The Pop Life
description: WHOEVER it was  Paul Jabara, the composer, apparently  who brought Barbra Streisand and Donna Summer together was not dumb. Not dumb, commercially, be cause the resultant song, No more Tears (Enough Is Enough), is at or near the top of the singles charts these days.

title: Talks to Increase Mortgage Rate in New York Collapse
description: Negotiations to raise New York State's interest rate on home mortgages collapsed yesterday because of new disputes over how to control future increases and the refusal by Republicans to accept a program to help low to middleincome people get mortgages.

title: Screen: 'Aces High' and Berri's 'Papa':Airborne 'Journey's End'
description: "ACES HIGH" and "Le Cinema de Papa," two films that make up the latest bill in the Thalia's series of previously unreleased features, would otherwise inhabit the movie equivalent of never-never-land. Neither is lively enough to have won the attention of general audiences. On the other hand, neither is polished or audacious or exotic enough to have enjoyed an art-house run. It's easy to see why neither film warranted an American engagement before now.And yet the Thalia's series, by highlighting works such as these, makes an unexpected virtue of their mediocrity. By presenting movies that lack the wherewithal for either critical or commercial success, the series becomes an occasion for thinking about qualities most movie audiences take for granted. There's nothing particularly wrong with either "Aces High" or "Le Cinema de Papa"  but there's nothing really right with them either. Unlike some of the better unreleased features the Thalia has shown, such as last week's "Dirty Money," these aren't films of eccentric energy. They're formula efforts in which the formula never quite gets off the ground, and it can be instructive to wonder what's missing."Aces High," directed by Jack Gold, is a 1976 version of the World War I play "Journey's End" that has been given an all-star cast and an airborne setting. The characters are now pilots, and their biplane battles are perhaps the film's most ambitious feature. But the real action is on the ground, or at least it ought to be, as the young British officers of the drama try to steel themselves for war. Drinking and smoking and womanizing and barroom songs about heroism are all part of the process by which they ready themselves.Although "Journey's End" comes to a notoriously weepy ending, this movie version courts disaster by making it impossible to shed a tear. The final moments are so perfunctory that the film feels truncated. And for all its good actors and interesting performances  the cast includes Simon Ward, Malcolm McDowell, Peter Firth, along with Christopher Plummer, Ray Milland and John Gielgud  the film has a subdued feeling and no central thread.The aging boyishness of the three tow-headed principals sets an eerie mood at times; those scenes involving Mr. McDowell, Mr. Ward and Mr. Firth together are the movie's best, although Mr. Plummer also does a fine Job. But there are no real changes in the characters except for those brought on by attrition, and after a while the combat footage becomes the movie's only source of momentum. Still, "Aces High" is nothing worse than a well-cast, well-mounted war movie without any particular spark. At its worst, it is merely listless; "Le Cinema De Papa," on the other hand, is actively disagreeable much of the time.Claude Berri, who wrote and directed this 1970 autobiographical film, clearly subscribes to the Gallic maxim that one's own boyhood, faithfully recreated on the screen, can be a source of infinite charm. However, Mr. Berri has come up with a singularly charmless variation on this formula, although he has been more successful with other autobiographical efforts ("The Two of Us," "Marry Me, Marry Me"). This time, concentrating on his relationship with his late father and the early stages of his own movie career, Mr. Berri fills the movie with self-serving anecdotes about his own triumphs, and plays himself with an unappetizing mixture of complacency and false navet. The actor who plays Mr. Berri as a 16-year-old is just as grating, only smaller.

title: 5 More Players at New Mexico Ruled Ineligible for Basketball
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 6 (AP)  Five more University of New Mexico basketball players, including three starters, were declared ineligible today after school officials learned the students had received credit for a course they never took.

title: Party Gives Schmidt a Strong Lift
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 6  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt won significant personal and political success at the Social Democratic Party convention here, emerging with a clear mandate for his policy of keeping West Germany firmly at the side of the United States and the NATO alliance in seeking a balance of power with the Soviet Union.

title: Rhodesians Wary Over Truce Accord
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Dec. 6  After 14 years of isolation and half as long at war, blacks and whites in this disputed land reacted in wary fashion today to the British Government's announcement last night that it had reached a basic accord with the Patriotic Front guerrillas on a ceasefire.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP)  A grand jury today accused Police Chief Charles Gain and other unnamed city officials Of acting irresponsibly in their handling of a riot that followed a verdict of Manslaughter against former Supervisor Dan White.

title: Jersey Assembly Votes to Continue Job Preference System for Veterans
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6  Under heavy pressure from veterans organizations, the New Jersey Assembly voted 48 to 12 tonight to keep a Civil Service system that gives veterans of the wartime armed forces first chance at government jobs in the state.

title: Rumanian Gymnasts Win Gold
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 6 (AP)  Despite only a token performance by an injured Nadia Comaneci, Rumania captured its first gymnastics team gold medal in the country's history tonight at the world championships.

description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: DAVIDSONDr. Israel The BMP family circle deeply regret the Passing of Dr. Davidson, the father of our member Dr. James Davidson  on December 3, 1979. We offer our sincere condolences to the family.  Norma P. Siegel, President BMP Family Circle

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination has been reshaped, primarily by the crisis in Iran and Jimmy Carter's handling of it, but also by Senator Edward Kennedy's slow and uncertain start.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Queens Waterside Restaurant Planned
description: Plans for a $1.4 million restaurant and public promenade on the East River in Long Island City, Queens, were announced yesterday by the Commissioner of Ports and Terminals.

title: Courtly Arts From Korea At Carnegie Hall Tonight
description: The opening number in a program of Korean court music and dance that will be given one time only at Carnegie Hall this evening is a fanfare of traditional military music. It is the music that once charted the progress through their realm of Korean kings  among them. royalty of the Yi dynasty,which lasted 500 years and began exactly a century before the discovery of America. The music will be played on instruments equally ancient in origin: onetone trumpets, oboes, conch shells, drums, gongs and cymbals.

title: The Force of Diplomacy on Rhodesia
description: While America remains baffled by an isolated Iran, Britain has seemingly sliced a far more intractable knot. The major obstacles to a ceasefire in Zimbabwe Rhodesia have finally been removed after 13 weeks of nonstop negotiations in London. On what manna did the British feed? The answer is instructive. It took not supernatural diplomacy but years of pain and failure before all concerned could be persuaded to rise to the level of a ruthless selfinterest.

title: U.S. Wins Bowling Title
description: MANILA, Dec. 6 (AP)  The United States women posted a record twoday, sixgame total of 5,667 and won the title today at the ninth world bowling championships. West Germany finished second with 5,577, and Australia was third with 5,487. Annese Kelly of New York led the Americans with 1,189.

title: At the Movies
description: Malle explores Atlantic City in latest effort.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  In the 20 years since the beginning of the 60's, one American President (John F. Kennedy) has been murdered, his successor (Lyndon Johnson) retired under fire, the third (Richard Nixon) was run out of Washington, the fourth (Gerald Ford) was rejected in the election of 1976, and the fifth, Jimmy Carter, is now under severe attack by the press and by his opponents in both parties.

title: Colgate, Entrepreneur Differ on Rubinstein Bid
description: Helena Rubinstein Inc., the beleaguered cosmetics division of the ColgatePalmolive Company and the object of at least three abortive acquisition attempts in the last year, appears to be involved in still another corporate ball game with the announcement yesterday that a cosmetics entrepreneur is interested in buying it.

title: Senate Defeats Tax Indexing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  The Senate narrowly defeated a Republican plan today to prevent inflation from nudging taxpayers into higher tax brackets each time they get a costof. living raise.

title: Some in Iran Are Said to Favor Talks to End Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Intermediaries in contact with the Iranian authorities have informed the United States that several members of the ruling Revolutionary Council want to resolve the crisis over the American hostages and that the next few weeks may provide an opportunity for a negotiated settlement.

title: Restaurants
description: IF the polite and gentle personnel at the Sheba Restaurant in TriBeCa have their way, New York can begin to learn a whole new food vocabulary, one that will include words like berebere, doze wott, ldtfo, alitcha and injera. They are au Offered on the menu of a fivemonth old establishment that describes itself as New York's first Ethiopian restaurant. Situated almost at the entrance to the Holland Tunnel, this simple, storefront restaurant is clean, modern and bright, decorated with an attractive striped wall fabric, some Ethiopian pictures and a handsome brass filigree Coptic Cross.

title: A How Not To of Refunds
description: The author of four booklets on how to evade the law was charged yesterday with filing 47 fraudulent New York State income tax returns this year and collecting $148,000 in tax refunds.

title: GEORGE T. C. FRY
description: George Thomas Clark Fry, advertising director for the Evyan Perfume Company, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 67 years old and a resident of Upper Montclair and New York City.

title: Jazz: Hyman at Michael's
description: DICK HYMAN describes the selections his Perfect Jazz Repertory Quintet is playing at Michael's Pub, in its annual December tribute to the work of George Gershwin, as from Gershwin film scores. This is true, but it is slightly misleading because most of the pieces the quintet plays started somewhere else, primarily on Broadway, and eventually turned up in films. Woody Allen's Manhattan, with its soundtrack a treasure trove of Gershwin material, in itself gives Mr. Hyman plenty of leeway to choices material.

title: Seoul Opposition Asks Free Elections Next August
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 6  The opposition New Democratic Party greeted the proclamation of Choi Kyu Hah as South Korea's fourth President today with a demand that he agree to the free election of a successor by popular vote by next August.

title: Building Trades Study Terms Union Workers Superior to Nonunion
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Union construction workers are substantially more productive than their nonunion counterparts, a unionsponsored study reported today. The validity of the study and its conclusions were immediately challenged by contractors groups.

title: Japan Reports Radioactive Leak At Nuclear Power Plant Reactor
description: SAGA, Japan, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  A small amount of coolant water containing radioactive elements has leaked in a nuclear reactor at a power plant near here, the Kyushu Electric Power Company said today.

title: IRAN SAYS U. S. AIDE HAD FALSE PASSPORT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6  As evidence of what they charge is American spying, the students holding the United States Embassy here released documents to night indicating that an embassy official carried a false Belgian passport.

title: Byrd Sees No Arms Debate in 79
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)  Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, said today that there was no chance the Senate would begin debate on the strategic arms treaty this year.

title: 50 Tax on Gasoline Urged; Stricter UtilityFuel Plan Due
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  President Carter's top economic advisers are urging him to propose an additional gasoline tax of 50 cents a gallon, with the proceeds to be rebated to consumers, Administratiion officials said today.

description: ILFORD, England, Dec. 6 (UPI)  Ronald Marks was found innocent yesterday on a charge of shoplifting but was arrested as he left the courtroom on a charge of stealing a juror's coat.

title: L.I. Union Agent Ousts Son Over Atom Plant Testimony
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 6  A shop steward for a carpenters union was dismissed from his job today by the union's business agent  his father  because he testified at a trial here that he believes there are safety defects in the Shoreham nuclear plant that the union has been helping to build.

title: Talks on Wages Pressed to Avert L.I.R.R. Strike
description: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and the line's 17 unions stepped up their efforts yesterday to reach agreement on a new contract that would avert a possible strike this weekend.

title: The City
description: Two youths were arrested yesterday and charged with robbing Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan and a companion, Brenda King, at imifepoint in Central Park on Nov. 28.

title: Iran Moving Troops Against Kurds To Curb Unrest Over New Charter
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6  The Revolutionary Government began moving troops into Kurdistan today as ethnic unrest over the new Islamic Constitution mounted.
