description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Music: Saxophonia
description: IF the saxophone needs a Segovia, someone with the ability to make concert audiences take an overlooked instrument seriously, Harvey Pittel could be the man. Mr. Pittel presented a program at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night that not only glorified Adolphe Sax's 139yearold invention but also generally brought glory to the music that was played on it.

title: Grievances Aired On Kennedy Center
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Privately, and apparently passionately, some pillars of the Broadway theater complained to three Senators today that Roger L. Stevens and the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here discriminated against independent producers, ignoriid black playiand favored a conservative, proBritish taste. The Senators who heard the complaints in a hearing room of the Senate Office Building  Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming  were sympathetic, but, for the moment at least, without immediate succor for the visitors from Broadway.

title: Bergland's Plea to Farmers
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Dec. 6 When, Mr. Secretary, are you going to make it rain around here, asked a lanky Texan in a dark blue, threepiece suit.

title: Once the Panic Was Over
description: When 11 young people die in a crush trying to get into a concert by the British rock group, the Who, some questions are as obvious as they are insistent. Why weren't ticketholders given reserved seats instead of having to fight for them? Why weren't they allowed to file in gradually instead of just before the show? Why weren't more doors opened? Why didn't anybody announce to the crowd already seated inside that 11 people had been killed? (Part of the reason, we note gloomily, is that the authorities feared more violence.)

title: U.S. Planning $3 Billion for Egypt In LongTerm Military Assistance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Carter Administration, in a policy departure, is preparing to grant Egypt roughly 63 billion in credits for the purchase of advanced American arms, Government officials said today.

title: 2 Inmates Killed and 17 Injured In Rioting at the Soledad Prison
description: SOLEDAD, Calif., Dec. 6 (AP)  Two inmates were killed and 17 were injured as 80 prisoners battled today at Soledad Prison.

title: Book Fair on West 10th St
description: An allday book fair to benefit the Village Community School's scholarship fund will be held today at the school,. 272 West 10th Street, between Greenwich and Washington Streets. Children's paperbacks will be a particular feature, along with holiday cards and posters. Refreshments will be served.

title: Dividends
Auctions
description: ORIENTAL rugs will be up for sale next week in at least three houses, and they include everything from nomadic mats to palace prizes. In a twopart sale at John C. Edelman!! Galleries, 123 East 77th Street. next Tuesday at 6 P.M. and next Saturday at 11 A.M., the focus will first be on rugs and next on tapestries, Orientalrug books and Persian textiles. The top lots in the sale are a Saruq and a Qashgai prayer rug, each of which may bring up to $20,000. The lots with the lowest estimates are Kurdistan and Qashgai bagfaces that may go for $350 and $200 respectively.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Companies, a national propertyliability insurance group, has elected to its board Virginia Dwyer, vice president and treasurer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Questions on Dealings Of Commerce Nominee
description: Some unusual financial transactions in the United States and Israel by Philip M. Klutznick, the wealthy Chicago realestate developer, are stirring controversy as Mr. Klutznick awaits Senate confirmation hearings later this month on his nomination as Secretary of Commerce.

title: 9 Killed in Mexican Hotel Fire
description: CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Dec. 6 (UPI) Fire swept through a hotel in the mountain town of San Juanitio, killing at least nine people, Chihuahua state officials said. Earlier the police said 24 people were killed in the fire. The names of the victims were not immediately available.

title: U.S. Urged to Lift Alaska Oil Output
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Alaska could produce up to five million barrels of oil a day and nearly halve the American dependence on foreign oil, according to a study written by Alaskan businessmen that was released today.

title: Books: Poets on Poetry
description: IAM ravished by passions I repudiate, writes Fernando Pessoa. A book is a cubic piece of burning, smoking, conscience  and nothing else, ob. serves Boris Pasternak. I write to

title: Tis the Season For Give and Take
description: It could be worse, but not much. Christmas shoppers are already wall to wall, and your gift list hasn't been ticked off. A hundred tsks and an equal number of pshaws, none of which will help matters, but now that that's out of the way, down to business.

title: If There's a Knack To Computerized Games, It's Finding Them
description: Stopping thieves on Fifth Avenue may be a cinch compared to finding Stop Thief I or one of the other heavily promoted electronic games this Christmas shopping season. Though millions of the flashing, beeping and sometimes talking toys were produced this year, demand for the popular ones far outstrips supply.

title: EARNINGS Deere Net Declines 11.8%
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment and an important producer of industrial machinery, reported a 11.8 percent decline in profits for its fourth fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 because of the threeweek shutdown, which began Oct. 1, of its 10 domestic farm and industrial equipment factories.

title: Bothwell Is Sent To New Haven
description: Tim Bothwell had not moved out of his hotel in Westchester County near the Rye rink where the New York Rangers practice. I don't know how long I'm here for, so I haven't looked for an apartment, he had said.

title: World Gold
Notes on People
description: I was tempted to take it home and play with it in my bath, but I held myself in check, Robert Forbes said yesterday, but of course he was joking about the toy battleship he paid a record $21,000 for in an auction Wednesday at PB84, the uptown annex of Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Dutch Parliament Rejects Missile Program
description: THE HAGUE, Friday, Dec. 7  The Dutch Parliament voted a resolution late last night calling on the Government to reject the production and deployment of new intermediaterange nuclear weapons at next week's NATO Council meeting.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The SmithKline Corporation, the Philadelphia pharmaceuticals concern, and Allergan Pharmaceuticals announced jointly yesterday an agreement in principle for SmithKline to acclaim Allerven for About S259 million.

title: Goldschmidt Is Warned On Political Slush Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)  A Senate committee today told the Secretary of Transportation, Neil E. Goldschmidt, that it would not tolerate his turning Federal transit grants into a political slush fund for President Carter's reelection.

title: Ownership Issue Snags Cable Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Because of a violation of the Federal Communications Commission's cross.ownership rules, the regulatory agency today vetoed a $175 million deal between the American Express Company and Warner CommunicatIont Inc. that would have allowed the financial cotnnany to buy half of Warner's stock.

title: Free Dental Bill for Bird
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (UPI) Using the same pink acrylic that dentures are made from, a San Francisco dentist has built a new lower beak for a blackcrested night heron and implanted it in a sixhour operation

title: Deaths
description: STEVENSDr. Mervin Alien. Age 79 on December 61h, 1979 in New York City. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Survived by two daUghtars, Jeane and Marcy; one son, Marvin Allen, Jr. and many loving relatives and friends. Services will be held at 10AM in the Congregational Church Madison, Conn. Monday, Dec. 10th. Flowers to Swan Funeral Home, Madison, Conn. Hours 24PM Sunday, 9th.

title: Banks May Reconsider Iran Default
description: LONDON, Dec. 6  The syndicate that declared a $500 million Iranian loan in default may be reconsidering its decision. A source within the syndicate said that Chase Manhattan, the lead bank, had called a meeting for tomorrow at which the matter was likely to come up.

title: St. Nicholas Joins Daniel Tradition
description: TWENTYONE winters ago, the late Noah Greenberg and his New York Pro Musica exhumed a 12thcentury music drama called The Play of Daniel and staged it amid the frescoes, stone walls and Romanesque vaulting of the Cloisters. With its Latin text, formal processionals and spare, chantlike musical idiom. Daniel must have seemed an esoteric undertaking at the time  most likely, nothing comparable had been seen for centuries. But there was nothing esoteric about its appeal. As Brooks Atkinson observed in The New York Times, the story of Daniel and Belsha77sar seemed not charmingly quaint, but outside time altogether, like fine poetry, and probably as stirring . . . as when the score was sung originally by men and boys in the Cathedral of Beauvais.

title: Black Group Is Awarded License for Television Station in Mississippi
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Federal Communications Commission has settled a 15year struggle over control of an NBC television affiliate in Jackson, Miss., by approving the award of the license to a blackcontrolled group.

title: Mideast Envoy Departs On Trip to Egypt, Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)  Sol Linowitz, the Middle East negotiator, left today on his first trip to Egypt and Israel for talks with their leaders.

title: Computer Ranking
description: The University of Alabama has retamed first place in The New York Times's final regularseason computer ranking of majorcollege football teams. Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant's undefeated Crimson Tide rallied in the fourth quarter to beat Auburn, 2518, last Saturday and earn a spot in the Sugar Bowl, against Arkansas on Jan. 1.

title: Videotape Film Shows
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., Dec. 6 (UPI) The first look inside the crippled nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island since the accident there on March 28 showed conclusively that there was no structural damage inside the containment building, the owner of the nuclear plant said today.

title: State Auditor Asserts City Hospitals Deficit May Be Understated
description: The special deputy state comptroller asserted yesterday that New York City might have underestimated the budget gaps for its Health and Hospitals Corporation by more than $100 million.

title: Court Says Respirator Of Marianist in Coma May Be Disconnected
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 6  Asserting that an individual has the right to control his own person, a State Supreme Court justice ruled today that the life supporting respirator keeping a comatose 83yearold member of the Marianist order alive could be disconnected by his courtappointed guardian.

title: CAMBODIAN FOOD AID REPORTED SNAGGED
description: SISOPHON DISTRICT, Cambodia, Dec. 5  An international relief official who asked not to be identified said today that he believed 80 to 90 percent of the supplies delivered to the VietnameseCambodian Government were in warehouses in Phnom Penh, the capital, and in ICompong Som, the seaport. He attributed the situation to a lack of equipment and manpower.

title: Broadway
description: TOMMY TUNE will direct and choreograph A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine. Mr. Tune directed The Club Off Broadway and was codirector of The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas on Broadway, but until now, he has never had a Broadway show all to himself. In Hollywood/Ukraine he will be doing a show whose first act is about Hollywood in the 1930's and whose second is a film of Chekhov's The Bear as done by the Marx Brothers. In other words, it is an entertainment, which Alexander H. Cohen will produce as another in his Nine O'Clock series. In a Nine O'Clock production, the curtain rises at 9, although Good Evening, with Peter Cook and Dudley Moore, was also a Nine O'Clock production, and the curtain rose at 8. Nine O'Clock is a way of describing what kind of show it is, Mr. Cohen says, explaining why Hollywood/Ukraine is a Nine O'Clock show. He has another explanation, too: All my Nine O'Clock shows have been hits.

title: Marina Menshikov, 51; Soviet Specialist on U.S.
description: Marina Menshikov, one of the first Soviet scholars to study American agriculture, died Nov. 6 in Moscow, her family said. She was 51 years old.

title: Carlos Garcia Camacho, 54, Dies; Guam's Last Appointed Governor
description: AGANA, Guam, Dec. 6 (UPI)  Carlos Garcia Camacho, the last appointed Governor of Guam, died early today at Guam Memorial Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: Boat Basin's Operator Blocks a City Attempt To Cancel Concession
description: The operator of the 79th Street Boat Basin, described by Park Commissioner Gordon J. Davis as a slumlord, has obtained a preliminary injunction in State Supreme Court blocking the city's effort to cancel its operating concession and award the lease to an association of boat owners.

title: ARGENTINE POLICIES PLEASE U.S. BUSINESS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6  As in Iran under the Shah, American business generally supports the authoritarian military regime in Argentina, which has violently repressed leftist terrorism and welcomed foreism investors.

title: Pitt Given Lambert Trophy
description: Jackie Sherrill, the head football coach at the University of Pittsburgh, yesterday praised his team's archrival, Penn State, for setting the high standard of excellence in Eastern football that is a goal for us all as he accented the 44th Lambert Troohv on behalf of the Pitt team.

title: Controller Is Blamed for Near Collision of Airliners
description: A Government board ruled yesterday that a controller's failure to keep track of an Air Florida twinengine jet was the direct cause of the near collision of two airliners over North Carolina last month.

title: SUDAN REAPPRAISING CLOSE TIES TO EGYPT
description: CAIRO, Dec. 8  The Sudan, pressed by economic difficulties, is showing signs of reevaluating its traditionally close relationship with Egypt in the face of continuing Arab hostility to the Egyptian peace treaty with Israel.

title: Drug Testers Stiffen Olympic Procedures
description: Fooling the drug testers at the Winter Olympics will be harder than winning a medal, the chemists in charge of the detection system predicted yesterday.

title: 2 on Dole's Campaign Staff Quit,
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)  Two officials of Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign staff and eight of his workem in New Hampshire have resigned, his headquarters said today. But Mr. Dole said the departures did not signal any problem with his campaign and most of those who left were volunteers or lowlevel workers.

title: Jesuits Chief, at Pope's Request, Orders a Curb on Shortcomings
description: Pope John Paul II has asked the Father General of the Jesuits to monitor his priests around the world and the Father General has responded with a letter, received this week by all the major superiors of the order, telling them to remedy their regrettable shortcomings.

title: Bridge:
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 6  The tide turned here today in the International Team playoff semifinal, and a big lead established by the Chicago team last night became a small loss.

title: Signs of Slowdown Spur Broad Rally
description: The credit markets, disregarding oaring wholesale prices, advanced strongly yesterday, pushing fixedincome securities prices to their highest levels since the Federal Reserve Boards two months earlier announced Its program to improve its control over the expansion of money and credit.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Namibia.

title: Chrysler Joins Union In Opposing Pay Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Chrysler Corporation joined the United Automobile Workers union today in denouncing a proposed Senate bffi that would require Chrysler workers to accept a threeyear wage freeze in order for the company to qualify for Federal assistance.

title: 8 in House Seek Mormon Judge's Ouster in Rights Amendment Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Eight members of the House of Representatives urged the Justice Department today to persist in efforts to disqualify a Federal judge on the ground that, as a Mormon Church official, he could not rule impartially on a legal challenge to the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: Screen: Human Prey Menaced in 'Killer Fish':The Plastic Skeleton
description: How can I describe "Killer Fish," the new Carlo PontiFilmar do Brasil production from I.T.C. Entertainment, released by Associated Film Distribution, and presented by Sir Lew Grade? As a celebration of cinema? No. As a celebration of civilized ideas? Not really. Is it a film that demonstrates the brutality and tenderness of words? Quite possibly, though the only line I'm sure I remember accurately is when the beautiful Margaux Hemingway, in her first (and possibly last) film role since her memorable performance in "Lipstick," points to a vehicle in the sky and, putting herself right on the line, announces, "It's an airplane."You might not realize it but this is a triumphant moment. Thinking does not come easily to Miss Hemingway, the actress. Nor, for that matter, does closing her mouthher full, sensual upper lip has a way of getting hung up, like a theater curtain, on her upper front teeth."Killer Fish" might be most accurately described as a searing melodrama. It strips away the flesh of man to reveal, not the soul, but the plastic skeleton. I hesitate to tell you the movie's plot for fear you might think it's silly, but duty requires it.The film opens with a long sequence in which Karen Black, Lee Majors and three other men, all dressed in what appear to be wet suits, blow up a huge power plant that turns out to be in Brazil. But It's not really a power plant, per se. It's the power plant for an emerald mine, and the people dressed in wet suits blow up the plant to divert the attention of the guards responsible for a safe containing a veritable fortune in gems.The robbers make a successful getaway and bury the gems in a waterproof box at the bottom of a reservoir stocked with man-eating piranha fish, though they don't know that at the time. Later we meet James Franciscus, who plays the gang's mastermind and the fellow who stocked the reservoir with the piranha. Almost immediately we also meet Miss Hemingway, who plays a beautiful model; Marissa Berenson, who plays her boss; Roy Brocksmith, her photographer, and the other members of a group that's come to Brazil to shoot a fashion layout.Before Miss Hemingway can say, "It's an airplane," the members of the movie's cast meet one another at the fashionable resort hotel where they're staying, and they pair off in various ways while we wait for people to have their skeletons bared when they fall into the reservoir, which happens with some frequency."Killer Fish," which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, also has one hurricane, one tornado, one dam collapse, one plane crash, one boat going aground and one life raft that sinks. Even so, it looks less like a conventional movie than like the photographic record of a movie company's trip to Brazil.It may not be a good movie  it's really ineptbut it's friendly, like Mr. Majors's quizzical squint, which is, I'm told by people who watch more televison than I do, what Mr. Majors does best. Everyone, in fact, carries on gamely, as people do at a picnic when it rains. Miss Berenson, who looks more and more like Ann Dvorak with very thin eyebrows, maintains a kind of resolute availability, always ready to talk to someone who feels low or lonely. Miss Black makes the mistake of attempting to act, and thus comes across as the party-bore, the person who attempts to steer conversation to important topics when everyone else is interested in gossip."Killer Fish" was directed by Anthony M. Dawson, an Italian film maker whose real name is Antonio Margheriti."Killer Fish" which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains many scenes in which people are attacked by piranha fish that look like angry guppies.

title: Debate on Nuclear Pact Is Called Unlikely in 79
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)  Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, said today that there was no chance the Senate would begin debate on the strategic arms treaty this year.

title: Indian Protesters Demand Honor for Untouchable
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 8  Disturbances broke out in several parts of Maharashtra State today as thousands of protesters converged on Aurangabad to press their demands that the university there be renamed in honor of Dr. B. IL Ambedkar, a leader of the untouchables, who died in 1958.

title: For Those Caught in the Crush, Cincinnati's Nightmare Goes On
description: CINCINNATI, Dec.6  For David Hack, the nightmare isn't over.

title: Baseball Clubs Map An Effort to Change Compensation Rule
description: TORONTO, Dec. 6  Baseball's club owners, intent on correcting what they feel is an imbalance, want to change the compensation awarded a team that loses a free agent. Now the compensation is an amateur draft choice; the owners want to make that compensation a player on the team's roster.

title: Would Have Stopped Fight, Says Doctor
description: Dr. Edwin A. Campbell, the medical director of the State Athletic Commission, told an investigating committee yesterday that he would have stopped Willie Classen's fatal bout at the Felt Forum last month before the boxer was knocked out in the 10th round.

title: Deaths
description: GALINHerman. December 5, 1979. The Board of Directors and EmPloyees of GAG Shops mourn the Passing of its Founder and father of our President, Jay Galin. We are deeply saddened by his loss.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Roger Klein, executive director of the Public Securities Association since it was founded almost three years ago, has resigned to establish his own moneymanagement concern.

title: Pincay Finishes Second, Nears $8 Million Record
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec.  Laffit Pincay drew within $28,740 of becoming the first jockey to ride horses earning $8 million in one year when he finished second to Bold Ruckus tonight In the $53,700 Chief Pennelceck Handicap at the Meadowlands.

title: Eagles Near End of 19Year Title Drought
description: With the majorcollege football season completed, apart from the bowl games, pro football now takes over on Saturday afternoons. Tomorrow there will be two contests, one of special note, on national television.

title: Over the Hurdles and Down the Hill
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 6  I'm 36 years old, Willie Davenport said, and I earn $25,000 a year. When I'm 40 I'm going to be a millionaire.

title: Head of Bally Will Step Down for Now
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6  The Casino Control Commission granted the Bailey Manufacturing Corporation's New Jersey subsidary a temporary casino permit today after Bally's president said he would sever all relations with the company pending completion of an investigation into alleged associations with organized crime. The commission's vote was unanimous.

title: Avoid New York's G.O.P. Primary, Presidential Contenders Are Told
description: ALBANY, Dec. 6 (AP)  New York State's Republican organization today warned G.O.P. contenders for President to stay out of the state's March 25 primary election.

title: Publishing: 2d Volume Of Houseman Memoirs
description: AS John Houseman turned into the lobby of the St. Regis to keep an appointment with a reporter, a man stared at him for a moment, pointed a finger and asked, Say, aren't you the man who . . . ?"

title: Britain Breaks Relations With Regime of Pol Pot
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Britain has withdrawn its recognition of the old Chinesesupported Cambodian Government of Prime Minister Pol Pot, Junior Foreign Minister Ian Gilmour told Parliament today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The Chiang Ching Dance Company, which blends traditional Chinese and modern Western dance, has won critical praise. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M., the group will perform at the Henry Street Settlement's Arts for Living Center, 466 Grand Street. Included will be Soliloquy of a Bhilcstmi, choreographed for the company by the late Joyce Trisler, and based on part of a 16thcentury Chinese drama. Tickets are $4 ($2.50 for the elderly). Information: 7669334 or 4316234.

title: Leadership of Kennedy Campaign in New York State Changed Again
description: For the third time in a month, the leadership of the Kennedy campaign in New York State changed yesterday. Richard K. Donahue, a Massachusetts lawyer and former patronage assistant to President John F. Kennedy, was named head of the New York operation, which has been in disarray since it began.

title: Film Interns Honored at Astoria
description: They stopped making movies at the Astoria Studios yesterday just long enough to honor everfinte connected with the studio's filmmaking internship project, which has put eight young moviemaking aspirants into spots where they can learn the craft.

title: U.S. Soccer Squad Routs Bermuda, 50
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 6  Ricky Davis, with help from Larry Hulcer, one of his three new teammates on the Cosmos, scored two goals tonight to lead the United States Olympic team to a 5.0 victory over Bermuda in the second game of their series.

title: Events and Openings
description: STAR TREK: THE MOTION PICTURE, directed by Robert Wise; starringilliam Shaw and Leonard Nava, at Loewe State I; Loewe Orpheum, 34th Street East, Paramount, Laws State 2 (only through Dec. 18) and other theaters.

title: Dance: Alley's Noces
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater tried something different Wednesday night at the City Center in its first performance of Lar Lubovitch's version of Stravinsky's Les Noces.

title: Angels Get Cowens In Deal With Royals
description: TORONTO, Dec. 6  As the slowest trading market in recent baseball history headed toward a close, the Kansas City Royals sent Al Cowens to the California Angels today for Willie Mays Aikens in a fiveplayer deal that was primarily an exchange of the two hitters.

title: For Children
description: ANNUAL CHRISTMAS TREE AND EAROQUE CRECHE DISPLAY, with a 20foot blue spruce, decorated with 11/Wis and cherubs, and underneath an assortment of colorful Neapolitan craft figures, an view through Feb. 3, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Medieval Sculpture Hall, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street. Call 8795930.

title: Deaths
description: KASHDANSol on November 22, 1979. Devoted beloved brother of Sylvia Garber. Dear brother of Max. Brother Inlaw of Louis. Loving uncle of Stanley Hyams, Elaine Wexler, Carrie Ubasci, Renee and Linda Kashdan. Greatundo of Julie, Richard, Cindy, Brett, Jon end Rand. Funeral was at Mantellore Cemetery.

title: U.S. WILL AID AIRLIFT OF RHODESIAN FORCE
description: LONDON, Dec. 6  The United States has agreed to help transport a British military contingent to Zimbabwe Rhodesia, where it will form part of a Commonwealth monitoring force for elections expected there in February or March.

title: Islanders Triumph Over Bruins, 4 to 3
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 6  The Islanders came to life tonight and won game at home. Their victims were the Boston Bruins, and the score was 43, with Bryan Trottier picking up two goals for the victors, including the decisive fourth score.

title: 5 Scientologists Get Jail Terms In Plot on Files
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)  Five leaders of the Church of Scientology were sentenced to jail today for directing a conspiracy to steal Government documents about the church.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday ordered the State Department of Agriculture and Markets to hold a hearing and either grant or deny a milk dealer's license within four months to Utica Cheese Inc., which proposes to operate a large mozzarella cheese manufacturing plant in Oriskany, near Utica.

title: Uranium Discovered in Greece
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 7 (Reuters) Greece has discovered considerable uraniun reserves of still unknown size, it was disclosed today at the annual conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: Players Want Easier Route To Gain FreeAgent Status
description: TORONTO, Dec. 7  While baseball's club owners would like to make it more difficult for players to become free agents, the players, not surprisingly. want to make it easier.

title: An Unusual Deal Is Set By China
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 7 China has concluded an unusual agreement to produce an as yet unproven multifuel engine developed in the United States by a group whose principal stockholder was involved in a disoute with the Se. curities and Exchange Commission over securities sales tied to another experimental engine.

title: LaidOff Workers At Chrysler Get AidImports' Harm Cited by U.S.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 7  Some 50,000 workers in the. Detroit area who have been laid off by the Chrysler Corporation will he eligible for special Federal grants, which could total $17 million, available to workers made jobless by imports.

title: Steel Strike Set in Britain
description: LONDON, Dec. 7 (Reuters)  Leaders of Britain's biggest steel unions called tonight for a national strike next month in protest over the British Steel Corporation's 2 percent pay offer, Britain's domestic news agency, the Press Association reported.

title: The Region
description: Klan Leader Begins Drive in Northeast

title: SHAH SAYS THAT U.S.AIDED IN OVERTHROWMemoirs Say an American General Helped to Neutralize the Army Commanders in Teheran
description: LONDON, Dec. 7  The deposed Shah of Iran was quoted today as having charged that the United States helped overthrow him by working behind the scenes to make sure that the Iranian Army would do nothing to save him.

title: Focusing on Iranian Crisis From Iowa
description: AMES, Iowa, Dec. 5  Sooner or later everyone may feel compelled to assert patriotism in the Iranian crisis. Here in the middle of America there is a state legislator and former Fulbright scholar who has proposed cancelling all student aid for Iranians at the state campus, regardless of visas or political opinions.

title: Concorde and Air Force Fighters Came Within 10 Feet Near Jersey
description: An Air France supersonic Concorde jet recently came within 10 feet of colliding with Air Force F15 fighters flying in a loose formation off the Atlantic Coast southeast of New Jersey. The pilots reported the near collision five weeks ago, but it was not until yesterday that the Government, in response to inquiries, disclosed just how close the planes had come.

title: A Christmas Mystery
description: It was five o'clock on the Friday before Christmas and he was standing in Grand Central Station at the bottom of the escalators that cascaded a slowmotion cargo of jaded executives down and out of the Pan Am building. He'd been there all week and I'd seen him every night. He faced the descending throng and, catching any eye that would look, he would softly intone Merry Christmas or Hello. Only that. He wasn't soliciting or proselytizing or selling records. Just saying Hello or Merry Christmas.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HIMALAYAN ECHOES Today, tomorrow and next Saturday, the small but enterprising Tibetan group of New York, 35 people, is holding its annual bazaar of Tibetan art, antiques, crafts, clothing that includes the decorative Tibetani boots, carpets, jewelry and other objects. There are also more samplings of those exotic homemade native foods. The place is the Tibet Center, 114 East 28th Street, and admission is 50 cents. The bazaar is open 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: BUSINESS DigestSATURDAY. DECEMBER 8, 1979
description: Energy

title: Indonesia to Get U.S. Uranium
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 7 (Reuters) The United States will supply nearly 40 pounds of enriched uranium to Indonesia under an agreement signed here today at the annual conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency. The uranium will be used in the Trigs research reactor at Bandung.

title: Hitler Movie Coming Jan. 13 To Fisher Hall
description: Our Hitler: A Film From Germany, the sevenhour movie written, directed and produced by HansJrgen Syberberg, will be shown at Avery Fisher Hall Jan. 13 in a program spon sored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Francis Coppola is distributing the film in the United States through his firm, American Zoetrope.

title: Severe Depression: Families Suffer, Too
description: From 6 million to 8 million Ameri. cans suffer from severe depression, ac. cording to the latest estimates by the National Institute of Mental Health. But it is not only they who suffer. De. pression has repercussions for their husbands, wives, children, friends and colleagues.

title: Dole Says Resignations From Staff Are Sign of Progress in Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Senator Robert Dole said today that recent departures from his Presidential campaign staff were a sign of progress and not evidence that his pursuit of the Republican nomination had flagged.

title: Cabbies and Others Hold Protests on the Hostages
description: A yellow medallion cab with its headlights blazing pulled up at a stoplight Just after noon yesterday at 45th Street and the United Nations Plaza. The driver jumped out, pointed to the front of the hood of the taxi alongside and said sternly: Put your lights on.

title: 4 Women in Life Rafts Missing as Boat Sinks
description: Rescue aircraft from the Coast Guard Air station at Cape Cod, Mass., will resume a search at dawn today for four women who reportedly boarded life rafts after their 50foot sailboat, the Shadow, lost its mast and foundered in heavy seas about 360 miles east southeast of the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge early yesterday.

title: Letter: On TwoParty Rent Checks
description: What Subsidized Landlords Owe the City

title: Austrian Wins Cup Downhill
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 7 Peter Wirnsberger of Austria surprised only himself today by winning the downhill, the first men's race of the World Cup skiing season.

title: Shipping/MailsOutgoing
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Education Between the Boards
description: New York City's Board of Education has agreed with Mayor Koch on a way to cover its pending deficit of more than $75 million. It will cut spending by about $24 million without cutting teachers. Then it will count on special or previously unexpected contributions from the city, Albany and Washington to make up this year's balance. But that will leave the board at least $50 million short in every future year. The Financial Control Board should accept the arrangement only if it can find a way to prevent deficits from recurring.

title: Walter Haas Sr., 90; ExChairman Joined Levi Strauss in 1919
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  Walter A. Haas Sr., former chairman of the board of Levi Strauss & Company, died in his sleep early today. He was 90 years old.

title: M. Fred Cartoun Dead; Retired Longines Head
description: M. Fred Cartoun, former chairman of the LonginesWittnauer Watch Company and a leading figure in the Swiss watch industry in the United States, died yesterday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Dr. Cecelia PayneGaposhkin, 79
description: Dr. Cecelia PayneGaposhkin, for several decades one of the foremost women in astronomy, died Thursday at Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. She was 79 years old.

title: Sidney B. Hoenig, 72, Historian and Expert On Dead Sea Scrolls
description: Dr. Sidney B. Hoenig, an authority on the Dead Sea Scrolls who was associated with Yeshiva University for more than 40 years, died yesterday at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn after a brief illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: French Deny Shift on Oil
description: PARIS, Dec. 7 (Reuters)  Andre Glraud, French Industry. Minister, denied today, in reply to a parliamentary question, that French companies had been authorized to buy oil on the spot market.

title: Britain Eases Iranian Freeze
description: The Chemical Bank said a British court had modified its earlier order this week restraining the Iranian Government and Bank Markazi, the Iranian central bank, from removing any assets in the jurisdiction of British courts.

title: Passaic Officials Hail an Employee Accused of Concealing Tie to Nazis
description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 7 Passaic County and city officials here praised the county's chief purchasing inspector today and expressed surprise at Justice Department charges that he had concealed membership in a Nazi Waffen SS unit in Germany during World War II.

title: Your Money
description: Risk in Making Own Mortgage

title: Utility Paying $100,000 in Suit
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Dec. 8 (UPI) The Southern California Edison Company agreed Monday to pay $100,000 to the parcnts of a scuba diver who was sucked into the ocean intake pipe at a Redondo Beach power plant. The parents of Barry Peterson, 21years old, who was killed Oct. 16, 1975, had sued for $500,000, contending that Edison was remiss in not covering the pipe with a screen or grating to prevent such accidents.

title: DividendsFRIDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1979
description: gpayable in Conadan hunk

title: United Press international
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 7  Charles J. Haughey, a 54yearold symbol of Irish unification who nine years ago stood trial on charges of running guns to the Irish Republican Army, will take office next week as Prime Minister of the Irish Republic.

title: Carter Says He Plans a Trade Ban Against Iran if Hostages Are Tried
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  President Carter said today that the United States would initiate steps to stop international trade with Iran if any of the Americans being held hostage in Teheran is put on trial.

title: Bomb at Cuba Mission Injures Two Policemen
description: A bomb exploded outside the side entrance of the Cuban Mission to the United Nations on 38th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues last night, slightly injuring two policemen on guard duty and shattering windows.

title: Police Chief Accidentally Killed By Own Men in Wisconsin Battle
description: MEQUON, Wis., Dec. 7 (UPI)  Police Chief Thomas Buntrock was shot and killed Sunday by one of his own men who mistook him for a robbery suspect, officials said today.

title: Foundation in San Francisco Has a Problem: How to Spend $250 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  After 30 years of quietly managing a slowly growing endowment, the San Francisco Foundation will soon come into $250 million that will make it the bestfinanced community foundation in the nation and give it an unusual problem.

title: U.S. May Agree to Cut Missiles Planned for Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  The Carter Administration is prepared to cut back on the number of mediumrange nuclear missiles it plans to station in Western Europe if the Soviet Union agrees to future reductions in its own nuclear arsenal, a senior Government official said today.

title: Growing Dissident Voice in IranKazem ShariatMadari
description: Ayatollah Kazem ShariatMadari, whose opposition to Iran's new constitution has raised political divisions in that nation, has been regarded by many as the leading religious figure and scholar in his countryeven more than Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Cronyn and Tandy's Gin Game Delights Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 7 Russians may not play gin, and relations with the United States may be a mess, but all of Moscow is trying to see The Gin Game, the Pulitzer Prizewinning Broadway play that opened here with Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy last night.

title: Deaths
description: MILLERDavid, of Boca Raton, Florida. Devoted father of Robert. Loving brother of Sally Agranovitch, Florence Lewis and Manuel Miller. Services were held at Gutterman  Musicant  Kreitzman, Hackensack, N.J. on Friday, December 7, 1979.

title: Maryland Official Is Acquitted
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 7 (AP)  After deliberating for more than 20 hours, Federal District Court iurv acquitted State's Attorney William Swisher today of 21 counts of mail fraud and extortion. The Government had accused Mr. Swisher, a Democrat who was reelected last year as the city's chief prosecutor, sold out the powers of his office in return for political help from the late James Pollack, who headed the Democratic Party in Baltimore.

title: Stewards Irk Waltrip
description: Darrell Waltrip, sounding more like a disgruntled loser than a winner, criticized yesterday the performance of stewards in stockcar racing, a world he dominates with Richard Petty.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yestarday's Weather of 1 P.M. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Notes on People
description: American Academy Elects Distinguished Threesome

title: HostageTaking as a World Crime
description: The American Embassy in Iran was seized as final touches were being applied to an international convention against the taking of hostages. The preamble of the draft treaty, now before a United Nations committee, is unexpectedly topical. It speaks of the urgent need to develop international cooperation between States in devising and adopting effective measures for the prevention, prosecution and punishment of all acts of hostagetaking as a manifestation of international terrorism.

title: New Haven AT A GLANCE
description: Geography

title: LeFlore, Rodriguez Swapped by Tigers
description: TORONTO, Dec. 7  The Detroit Tigers, who shun free agents, jumped into the lagging trade market today by sending Ron LeFiore to the Montreal Expos and Aurelio Rodriguez to the San Diego Padres.

title: Thousands of Azerbaijanis Parade in Tabriz to Support Their Ayatollah
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 7  Thousands of people paraded through the streets here today to proclaim their devotion to Ayatollah Kazem ShariatMadari and to mourn the killing of a 24yearold guard at the Islamic leader's home in Qum during a demonstration against him two days ago.

title: Mime: Pulse, Other Works By Hakoshima
description: Yass Hakoshima, seen in his Kinetic Illusions program of 11 mime pieces at Japan House on Thursday, is a man of parts. A pupil of Decroux, Marceau and Erick Hawkins. Mr. Hakoshima has performed throughout the world since his debut in 1958 with the Western Pantomime Group in Tokyo. He displays an at times impressive physical facility, plucking thoughts from the air in Thinking, tugging on that old, familiar rope in Puller and pressing against those equally familiar invisible walls in Spell so that each exists for that moment with an eerie, almost surreai tangibility. At other moments,0 more literary conceits come alive, like a gossipy typist in .Pulse.

title: Three U.S. Soldiers Hurt By Blast in Korean DMZ
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 7 (AP) Three American soldiers walking through the Korean demilitarized zone in a heavy fog today were injured by an explosion, and officials speculated that they had triggered a land mine. One of the injured men apparently staggered away and was being sought.

title: Braths
description: GOTTLIEBEddie. The Officers and Membership of The US Committee Sports for Israel morn the Passing of Eddie Gottlieb. our devoted supporter and a long time friend of sports and young People In Israel. This month he was elected to the Jewish Sports Hall of Fame, his memory will be an inspiration to our Youth.

title: Today Could Be Pincay Day
description: Laffit Pincay won two races at Aqueduct yesterday and moved within $11,580 of becoming the first jockey to win $8 million in purses in a year. Track officials are so certain that Pincay will reach his goal today that they have scheduled a ceremony in his honor between the seventh and eighth races.

title: Baker's Campaign and Memories of Birch Bayh in '76
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Dec. 5 Flying over western Iowa in his singleengine Cessna 421 campaign plane after a long day of politicking, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. leaned forward in the early evening dusk to make a point rather sharply.

title: COMPANY NEWSSignal Set to Buy Shares of Unitrode
description: Signal Companies Inc. announced yesterday that it had entered into a contract to purchase from Schlurnberger Ltd. all 496,425 shares of common stock of the Unitrode Corporation owned by Schlumberger at $32.75 a share. The transaction is subject to the approval of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Retail Sales Lagging in New YorkWarm Weather Cited by Stores
description: Because of unseasonably warm weather and a general reduction in consumer buying, sales of New York City's largest retailers slipped in November from the strong trend of earlier months.

title: State Offers Rescue PlanFor the Chicago Schools
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 7  The state again came to the aid of the insolvent Chicago Board of Education today, advancing $37.2 million in payments that allowed the school board to pay its 50,000 employees and tentatively agreeing to buy about $200 million in school obligation notes to be sold in a complex bailout arrangement.

title: About New York
description: The search for the Christmas spirit in New York is often a pursuit of the intangible. Below the tinsel and the commercially induced jollity is the Christmas spirit rooted in the birth of Jesus and the Christian belief in what that birth means to mankind.

title: Trading Headaches Increase
description: TORONTO, Dec. 7 The moment of purest truth in baseball's, era of new economics probably arrived this afternoon, when the Detroit Tigers traded Aurelio Rodriguez to the San Diego Padres.

title: Remedies Elude Ailing City Hospitals
description: Few city agencies have endured more criticism than the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, which was established 10 years ago to operate the municipal hospital system.

title: Market Climb Led By. Takeover Issues
description: Takeover situations moved back onto the center stage of Wall Street yesterday and . Allergan Pharmaceuticals was the star performer. Popular averages. showed slight declines, but advancing stocks managed to run comfortably ahead of declining issues for the general market. Trading volume was heavy.

title: Panel to Recommend Crowd Control Policy Named in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 7 City officials today named a ninemember panel to make recommendations on public safety and crowd control at large public gatherings.

title: There's a Spirit of Hope in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 7  From the corset factory where middleaged women come to work in their aprons to the courts of the new downtown racquetball club, there is an optimism here these days that not even a gloomy labor picture can dim.

title: Reform Rabbi Declares Fathers, Too, Should Transmit Jewishness
description: In response to an increase in marriages of Jewish men and nonJewish women, Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, president of Reform Judaism's association of American congregations, proposed yes. terday that the religion recognize the transmission of Jewishness through the father as well as the mother.

title: Violin: Bach And Brahms; By Szeryng
description: Except for the human voice, perhaps no instrument more immediately reveals the performer's temperament and sensibilities than the violin. There is so little machinery standing between the artist and the receiving ear that the listener sometimes comes to feel that the music is leaping directly from one mind to another, like a spark across a gap. This sort of intimacy, in a poor performance, can be embarrassing, because the musician's bad taste, boredom or even poverty of spirit are all too apparent. More than most instruments, the violin is a confessional device.

title: A Restaurant Inspection Fraud
description: Restaurant owners in New York City were warned yesterday about a bogus inspector who has taken fees of between $35 and $50 for new health department permits from 25 restaurants during the last two months in Manhattan and Queens.

title: The Screen: 'Star Trek,' Based on TV:The Cast
description: "Star Trek," the popular television series that died 10 years ago but would not be forgotten, has, like Lazarus, come back to haunt the skeptical and reassure all those who have kept the faith. It's called "Star Trek  the Motion Picture," rather superfluously, I think, because I doubt anyone who sees it could possibly confuse this film with those shards of an earlier, simpler, cheaper television era.Watching "Star Trek  the Motion Picture," which opens today at Loews Orpheum and other theaters, is like attending your high-school class's 10th reunion at Caesar's Palace. Most of the faces are familiar, but the dcor has little relationship to anything you've ever seen before. Among the friends are good old Captain Kirk (William Shatner), commanding officer of the Starship Enterprise; pointy-eared Mr. Spock (Leonard Nimoy), whose humanity disqualifies him from attaining "kolinahr," the state of grace on his native planet Vulcan; Dr. McCoy (DeForest Kelley), the spaceship's general practitioner, nicknamed "Bones," just as he might have been on H.M.S. Bounty, and such other reliables as Scotty (James Doohan), the engineering officer, and Sulu (George Takei), the ship's helmsman.The newcomers are Stephen Collins, who plays Commander Decker, the Enterprise's stalwart young executive officer, and Perris Khambatta, an actress from India who plays Ilia, a shockingly beautiful young woman whose head has been shaved as clean as a whistle in the fashion of her home-planet, Delta Four.This time out the mission of the Enterprise is to intercept a mysterious cloud, which is apparently light years in diameter and is heading toward earth for reasons that not even Mr. Spock can divine. It's not revealing a secret to tell you that the cloud contains what is usually referred to under such circumstances as "a superior intelligence," though just what that intelligence is must remain one of the film's few witty surprises.I suspect that wit is not what "Star Trek" fans are looking for. Instead they want to see favorite characters who are as ageless and multidimensional as characters in a comic strip, and not at all ashamed of those origins. The dialogue  at least what dialogue one can hear over Jerry Goldsmith's music and the sounds of rockets being fired  is of a banality that soothes the weary mind, like Magic Fingers that work on a tired brain. Unlike "Star Wars," which was full of conscious associations to other literature, "Star Trek" refers only to itself, with the possible exception of the climactic sequence that borrows freely from Christian myth.The film's vision of the future, which is a bit tacky at the beginning, becomes increasingly hypnotic as the movie goes on, or maybe it just seems that way as one falls under the spell of so many abstract patterns of light and color, designed to simulate the experiences of the members of the Enterprise crew as they pass through various dimensions of time and space."Star Trek" is yet another film that owes more to Douglas Trumbull and John Dykstra, who did the special photographic effects, and to Harold Michelson, the production designer, than it does to the director, the writers or even the producer, Gene Roddenberry, who also created and produced the television series.The formidable Robert Wise, who once directed a good, pacifist sci-fi film, "The Day the Earth Stood Still" (1951), a film with very few special effects, directed "Star Trek," but I can't imagine what there was for him to do after telling the actors where to stand. Because most of the drama in such a movie is created in the laboratories, the actors are limited to the exchanging of meaningful glances or staring intently at television monitors, usually in disbelief.

title: Columbia's Success in Soccer Is RagstoRiches Story
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 7  In a ragstoriches story that has two chapters to go, a dedicated group of young soccer players and a 34yearold Marine veteran have taken the Columbia University team to the National Collegiate semifinal round for the first time in the school's history.

title: Drop in Jobless Ends Bond Rally
description: The surprising decline in unemployment in November that was announced yesterday gave bond traders second thoughts about the recession. The unanticipatea figure snuffed out Thursday afternoon's strong bond market rally and pushed fixedincome prices down sharply.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 21.

title: Enforcer For Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 7 The New York Islanders, in an effort to strengthen their hack line, today acquired Gord Lane, a defenseman who has a reputation as a brawler.

title: SEOUL LIFTS DECREE OUTLAWING DISSENTThe New Regime Also Releases 68 Prisoners Who Were Detained for Violation of the Order
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Dec.8  South Korea's Presidential Emergency Decree No. 9, which outlawed dissent against the regime of the late President Park Chung Hee, was lifted at midnight last night. Hours later the Government released 68 political prisoners who had been held for violating the decree.

title: Swede Is Jailed as Soviet Spy
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 7 (Reuters)  A former Swedish security officer was jailed for life today for selling defense secrets to the Soviet Union. Stig Bergling, 42 years old, was found guilty of selling documents about the secret police, with which he served, and about Sweden's defense staff and coastal defenses between 1973 and 1977.

title: Bonn Lists Sanctions On IranBut Moves Have Had Little Effect
description: BONN, Dec. 7  The West German Government, in the first public announcement of sanctions against Iran by an ally of the United States, said today that it had stopped guaranteeing new credits to Iran and would refuse permission for the export of weapons or parts to that country.

title: Excerpts From Statement by President
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Following are excerpts from President Carter's statement on the Three Mile Island incident and its implications for Administration nuclear power policy, as released by the White House press office.

title: Iraq Asserts Iran Attacks Envoys And Warns of a Possible Pullout
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 7 (Reuters) Iraq denounced Iran again today, accusing the leadership of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of responsibility for assaults against and harassment of Iraqi diplomats.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Dec. 7.1979

title: American Revamps Korea Port
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Nov. 30  A barrelchested American engineer, Aleck F. MacDonald  born in Brooklyn, raised in Florida is making a personal contribution to the South Korean export drive, advising the Koreans how to broaden, deepen and open up to container traffic the largest port In this country.

title: Prime Rate Cut to 153% By Banks Across Nation
description: In an industrywide move yesterday, banks around the country followed the lead of the Chase Manhattan Bank in dropping the prime lending rate to 15 percent from 15 percent.
