description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: News Summary SATURDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1979
description: International

title: Civiletti Says He Is Withdrawing From Role in Vesco Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)  Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti said today that be had removed himself from any role in the Government's investigation into allegations of White House influencebuying in behalf of Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

title: OBSERVERShopping;BlockHow to see things through the seasonal giftbuying rush when spark plugs and black snakes just won't do.
description: It is not the gift that counts in this season of the mercantile hallelujah; it is the thought. How well I remember hearing those words and how sweetly they fell on the ear when I was a dimpled stripling scarcely bigger than ,a stippled pimpling , Alas, alas. There was, there is, as there always is, a catch.

title: A Chinese Dissident Says He Has Seen the Light
description: PEKING, Dec. 7 Last spring Yang Guang, a 24yearold physics student, was earnestly helping to edit an underground magazine named Exploration, which called for Westernstyle democracy in China. The magazine was sold at Democracy Wall here.

title: Dance: Danny Grossman Troupe
description: Danny Grossman was once a leading dancer in the Paul Taylor Dance, Company and there was something, if not much, of Mr. Taylor's fondness for the freakish in Thursday night's opening of the Danny Grossman Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Torontobased troupe will perform there through tomorrow afternoon.

title: Around the NationHusband of Woman Killed In Mine Will Get Benefits
description: CLEARFIELD, Pa., Dec. 7 (AP) The Rushton Coal Company has agreed to pay survivors benefits to the husband and son of a woman miner killed on the job, according to an attorney for the family.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: UNEMPLOYMENT OFF T0 5.8% FOR MONTH IN SPITE OF LAYOFFSBut Many Job Cuts Aren't Counted  New York City Joblessness Climbs to 8.2% From 8%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Unemployment edged down slightly and employment rose last month in the face of layoffs in the automobile and steel industries and other signs of sluggishness in the economy, the Labor Department reported today.

title: New Play at Jewish Repertory
description: Benya the King, a new play by Richard Schotter based on Isaac Babel's Tales of Odessa, will open next Thursday at the Jewish Repertory Theater, 344 East 14th Street. Directed by Roger Hendricks Simon, the show features music by Ken Collins and design by John Schaeffer. Performances will be at 8 P.M. on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, and at 2 P.M. on Sundays. Previews began last Wednesday. Theater Development Fund vouchers will be accepted. For information and reservations, call 6747200.

title: 4Day Week Sought in Bay Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (UPI)  The Regional Transit Association has appealed to Bay area employers to adopt a fourday work week as a step toward sayMg gasoline and easing freeway congestion.

title: Braths
description: AMBERSONJ. Burns; Jr. M.D. on December 3rd, 1979 of Hillsdale, New Jersey. The obituary In the New York Times of December 6th did not note that Dr. Amberson is also survived by his daughter, Priscilla Adsit of Hillsdale, New Jersey, as well as his son J. Burns Amber. son, Ill, M.D. of Amherst, Massachusetts.

title: Jobless Rate Rises Slightly in City
description: New York City's unemployment rate rose last month to 8.2 percent, up from 8.0 percent in October, although it was well below the 8.6 percent rate of November 1978.

title: Swindler Sentenced to 4 Years
description: A 36yearold pharmaceutical salesman of Bayside, Queens, was sentenced to four years yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn for swindling friends and business contacts of as much as $10 million during a sixyear period, The Associated Press reported. None of the money has been recovered. The salesman, Larry Hecker, pleaded guilty last Oct. 10 to two counts of using the mails to defraud while bilking investors through a generic drug scheme.

title: Jets Anxious to Avenge Huge Losses to Patriots
description: Football teams are not supposed to score so many points: 27, 24, 55, 19, 56. But those are the numbers produced by the New England Patriots against the Jets since Walt Michaels took over as the New Yorkers coach in 1977.

title: Thomas Is 2d to Ditiatin
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 7  Kurt Thomas became the first American gymnast ever to win an allround medal in a world gymnastics championship tonight, interrupting two deCades of soviet ana Japanese men's domination with the effortless grace that has become Thomas's trademark.

title: Goldwater Greeted in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Dec. 7 (Reuters)  Senator Barry Goldwater arrived in Taiwan last night on a fiveday private visit and was greeted by President Chiang Chingkuo today. The Arizona Republican will receive an honorary doctorate of laws tomorrow from Fujen University.

title: Consumer Borrowing Slackens
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)  The Federal Reserve Board reported today that total consumer debt increased by Just $2.19 billion, or seventenths of 1 percent, in October less than half the record September increase of $4.45 billion and the smallest monthly increase since January. 1977

title: Hostages Relatives Relieved After Briefing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  One hundred relatives of the American hostages being held in Iran showed up for a State Department briefing today, and they seemed to feel better after talks by President Carter and State Department officials.

title: Britain Names Lord Soames as Governor of Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Dec. 7  Lord Soames, an experienced politician and diplomat, was appointed today by Queen Elizabeth as Governor of Zimbabwe Rhodesia. He will leave for Salisbury next week.

title: Carter Defeats Kennedy 84 to 14% in Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 8 (UPI)  President Carter, hailed for his handling of the Iranian crisis, won an overwhelming victory last night in a Presidential straw poll of Tennessee Democrats attending fundraising dinners in 10 cities.

title: Oil Lease Bidding Approved Despite Peril to Whale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 A Federal judge ruled here today that environmentalists and Eskimos seeking to postpone the leasing of oildrilling rights in the Beaufort Sea off the North Slope of Alaska had made a substantial showing that such drilling would threaten the existence of an endangered species' of whale.

title: Ford Aides Subpoena Quashed
description: DETROIT, Dec. 7 (UPI)  A Wayne County judge, Richard D. Dunn, today rejected a bid by Michael Cosentino, an Indiana prosecutor, to force 30 executives of the Ford Motor Company to testify personally at a criminal trial in which the automobile maker Is charged with reckless omicide. The company was indicted for recklessly designing and manufacturing Pintos.

title: Irving Neustein, 78, DiesLawyer And ExTammany District Leader
description: Irving Daniel Neustein, a Tammany Hall district leader from 1928 to 1942, died yesterday at the Jewish Home for the Aged in Manhattan. He was 78 years old.

title: Brazil Announces A 30% Devaluation
description: BRASILIA, Dec. 7 (UPI) Brazil announced a 30 percent devaluation of the cruzeiro today as part of a program to fight inflation, now at an annual rate of 65 percent.

title: Performance of Antitrust Official Sharply Questioned by Senators
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  The performance of the Justice Department official in charge of enforcing the nation's antitrust laws for the last two years was sharply questioned today by members of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: EichelbergerBreer Lead Mixed Golf Tournament
description: LARGO, Fla. Dec. 7 (AP)  Dave Eichelberger and Murle Breer picked up 10 strokes today to catch the leaders in the second round of the $400,000 Mixed Teams Golf Tournament.

title: Violin Recital: Miss Halprin
description: Because Diana Halprin got quite a .bit of publicity when she made her debut with the Philadelphia Orchestra, she can hardly be called an unknown violinist. But, of course, that was 28 years ago, and she was only 7 at the time. Since then, besides playing the violin (including a stint with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and concerts In Europe), she has studied conducting, organized and led a chambermusic ensemble known as the New York Kammermusiker and performed with another group she helped organize  the J. S. Blue countryblues band. In short, Miss Halprin seems almost to have tried to make people forget her auspicious beginnings as a virtuoso.

title: PRESIDENT DISMISSES NUCLEAR UNIT CHIEF IN MOVES ON SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  President Carter today dismissed Joseph M. Hendrie as chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and announced several other changes that, he said, would improve the safety of nuclear energy in response to the accident last March at the Three Mile Island reactor in Pennsylvania.

title: Miller Faults Senate's Chrysler Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)Secretary G. William Miller said today that the Senate Banking Committee's version of the Chrysler aid bill was unworkable, partly because the auto maker might lose many of its best workers.

title: Italy Suspends Chief of E.N.I.
description: ROME, Dec. 7 (AP)  Prime Minister Francesco Cosslga today announced the suspension of Giorgio Mazzanti, chairman of the state energy group, E.N.I., pending the outcome of a Government investigation into allegations that the company paid millions of dollars to middlemen to secure a Saudi Arabian oil contract.

title: Davis Turns Pro and Signs 2Year Pact With Cosmos
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 7  Ricky Davis, who scored two goals for the United States Olympic team in its 50 triumph over Bermuda last night, signed a twoyear professional contract with the Cosmos today. Details of the contract were not disclosed.

title: Indian Scholar's Views on Equality of Sexes
description: Kapila Vatsyayan insisted that her notes were a mess. She had just delivered a 90minute lecture about goddesses in ancient Hindu mythology, and now a young New Yorker wanted to copy the names of the characters she had been talking about  names as meaningful on the subcontinent as Zeus and Apollo are in the West.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in Business Day yesterday on a Federal Communications Commission veto of an acquisition by the American Express Company incorrectly identified the other company involved. American Express is seeking to buy 50 percent of the Warner Cable Corporation, a subsidiary. of Warner Communications Inc.

title: Nephew of the Shah Is Slain in Paris
description: PARIS, Dec. 7  A nephew of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi was shot to death in the street here today. The police said that 34yearold Mustapha Chafik, the son of the Shah's twin sister, Princess Ashraf, was shot twice In the head at close range as he walked in the rue de la Villa Dupont, a quiet treelined culdesac in the fashionable 16th District.

title: LOUISIANA'S VOTERS TO SELECT GOVERNORRepublican, an Apparent Favorite, Asserts Election Today May Be Stolen at the Polls
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7 Louisiana voters choose a governor tomorrow after a $20 million campaign marked by defections from the dominant Democratic Party and open warnings by the apparent frontrunner, a Republican, that the runoff election may be stolen from him.

title: Letters
description: If OPEC Had to Face a Sole U.S. Buyer

title: World News BriefsState of Emergency Called After St. Vincent Rebellion
description: KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, Dec. 7 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Milton Cato declared a state of emergency tonight and ordered a curfew in St. Vincent and its dependent islands in the Caribbean following a rebellion on one of the islands.

title: DISSIDENT AYATOLLAH APPEARS TO SUPPORT PROVINCIAL UPRISINGSEES AIDES OF IRANIAN REGIMEShariatMadari, Pledging Study of Disturbances, Backs Demand for Azerbaijan Autonomy
description: QUM, Iran, Dec. 7  Ayatollah Kazem ShariatMadari, symbol of the insurgent Azerbaijani minority, appeared today to be resisting pressure from the revolutionary authorities to order his followers to give up the Government buildings and broadcasting station in Tabriz that they took over to protest the new Islamic Constitution.

title: They Add a Little Tinsel To the Christmas Crowds
description: Ali MacGraw on 57th Street

title: Car Dealers Fight for SurvivalCrisis in Iran Hurting SalesTreasury Secretary G. William Miller criticized the Senate version of aid for Chrysler, saying the proposed threeyear wage freeze would disproportionately burden the company's workers. Page 31.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 7 Business in Porterfield Wilson's Pontiac showroom here has not been too exciting lately. In fact, nearly every dealer who sells new cars made in the United States is finding business slow.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 24.

title: Answering Volcker
description: The following remarks by Senator Ted Stevens, Alaska Republican, are excerpted from The Congressional Record. Mr. Stevens Was commenting on remarks by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that if inflation is to be reduced the standard of living of the average American has to decline. I don't think that you can escape that.

title: Ford Aides Subpoena Quashed
description: DETROIT, Dec. 7 (UPI) A Wayne County judge, Richard D. Dunn, today rejected a bid by Michael Cosentino, an Indiana prosecutor, to force 30 executives of the Ford Motor Company, including the retired board chairman, Henry Ford 2d, to testify personally at a criminal trial In which the automobile maker is charged with reckless homicide. The company was indicted for recklessly designing and manufacturing Pintos and failing to recall those suspected of being likely to have the gas tank explode when struck in the rear.

title: Rangers Rally to Defeat the Whalers, 7 to 4
description: SPRINGFIELD,Mass., Dec. 7 For. Ulf Nilsson it was an ordinary nighttwo assists, a few near goals and a lot of hooking and spedring by the opposing team, all of. it ignored by the referee. He talked about the harsh treatment afterWard in the dressing room, with a big purple bruise on his right bicep and slash marks across his stomach. He. looked. hurt, but he was smiling. He Was Smiling because it had not been normal night for the rest of the New York Rangers.

title: Mobil Suffers Major Setback in Effort To Halt Shell's Acquisition of Belridge
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7  A Federal court judge today all but ended the Mobil Corporation's efforts to prevent the Shell Oil Company from acquiring the Belridge Oil Company, in what would be the largest corporate merger on record. Shell has offered $3.65 billion for Belridge, a closely held company with huge oil reserves in California.

title: Shelley G. Silk Is Bride;Of Charles A. Wehrly 3d
description: Shelley Gray Silk and Charles Albert Wehrly 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wehrly 2d of Farmington, Conn., were married yesterday evening in Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., by the Rev. William Ray Shifley Jr.

title: An OffDuty Policeman Kills Man In a Robbery Attempt in Bowery
description: An offduty police officer killed a man early this morninig in the Bowery when he and two others attempted to rob the officer as he fixed his car. the nolice said.

title: Japan and China Announce a Wide Range of Accords
description: PEKING, Dec. 7 China and Japan today announced a broad range of new economic, technical, and cultural agreements under which Japan said it would begin to treat China as a developing nation  a move that could substantially Increase trade between the nations.

title: The City
description: $2 Million Awarded In Malpractice Suit

title: For City Antipoverty Effort, a New Era
description: A major step toward the achievement of one of the Koch administration's top priorities, the restructuring of New York City's sprawling, scandalridden antipoverty programs, was taken this week with the election of local policy boards in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. The boards will make decisions on funds for specific poverty programs for years to come, without actually handling money.

title: Social Security Tax Cut and Shift in Medicare Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  An advisory board of business, labor, academic and political representatives recommended today that the Social Security payroll tax be reduced and that Medicare hospital insurance by financed by individual and corporate income taxes instead of the payroll tax.

title: Banks Are Firm On Iran Default
description: LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP)  Banks involved in a $500 million syndicated loan to the Iranian Government have not changed their view that the loan is in default, the Chase Manhattan Bank said today.

title: Is D.J. of WKRP Bound for Cultdom?
description: No, he does not look like Erik Estrada or any of the other usual American male television idols. His blond hair is thinning, his forehead is heavily lined, and underneath the sunglasses he almost always wears deep pouches ring his eyes. He does, in fact, look slightly dissipated.

title: Seducing the Judiciary
description: Benjamin R. Civiletti has persuaded President Carter to nomlnate Judge Charles B. Renfrew, of the, United States District Court in San Francisco as Deputy Attorney General, the position Mr. Civilettl vacated when he succeeded Griffin B. Bell as Attorney General. Eariler, he had proposed Judge Frederick B. Lacey of the Federal District Court in Newark, who later asked that his name be withdrawn because of reaction in some quarters to his decisions.

title: Standby Gas Ration Plan Offered1 Gallons a Day. For Each Private Vehicle Is BasisStandby Rationing Plan For Gasoline Is Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7A new proposal for standby gasoline rationing that presumes the availability of about one and a half gallons a day for each of the nation's 135 million private vehicles was put forward today by the Carter Administration.

title: 1,000 Crib Toys to Be Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today that it was recalling 1,000 infant crib exerciser toys that it saia could pose a strangulation hazard. The recall is being conducted by the F.A.O. Schwarz Company of New York, which sold the toys from July 1976 though last January. The toy consists of a red elastic cord strung with colored wooden beads and rings.

title: N.B.A. Rules To Protect Backboards
description: Darryl Dawkins, the Philadelphia 76ers 6foot11inch, 252pound center, who has shattered two backboards with violent slam dunks in less than a month, learned today that similar incidents in the future may cost him more than just his safety.

title: L.I.R.R. Halted As Its Trainmen Declare a Strike
description: The United Transportation Union went on strike against the Long Island Rail Road at 12:01 A.M. today after negotiations in Washington failed to resolve their contract dispute.

title: A GeologicalSocial Essay on BulgariaEugem Mtlhaesco
description: In Sofia, the bookstores cluster on a single street and open at 10. With an hour to wait, I stepped into the Museum of Natural History. Its echoing halls contain the nation's geological. zoological, entomological and botanical collections. From the first glass box on the ground floor I was bored. Before me, with explanatory cards in Cyrillic, were the rocks of Bulgaria, some glimmering in the weak light but most sitting dully grayblack, undifferentiated from their neighbors. Four commodious rooms of them spread before me.

title: Syracuse Conquers LeMoyne by 10761
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 7 (UPI),  Louis Orr and Roosevelt Boule, the Syracuse cocaptains, scored 14 points each tonight to lead six teammates in double figures as the Orangemen beat LeMoyne, 10761, in the first round of the Carrier Classic basketball tournament.

title: Patents
description: Heat Gauge In Cancer Treatment

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Firefighter Rally Assails Practices Of Medical Unit
description: Two thousand New York City firefighters, alleging inhumane practices and policies in the Fire Department's medical division, rallied outside the division's offices yesterday. They then took their grievances to City Hall, where union representatives met with officials of the department and the Koch administration.

title: Bridge:Southern Team Victorious In Semifinal of Team Trials
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 7 Six tired experts from several Southern states, after surviving a desperately close semifinal battle this afternoon, began play tonight against a highly.experienced Aces team. At stake is me right to represent the United States in the 1980 world team championships.

title: A Scholar Identifies Legal Papers As the Oldest Found in Palestine
description: LEXINGTON, Mass.  A Harvard University scholar, after 15 years of reconstructing and deciphering fragments of wormeaten papyrus rolls found in a cave eight miles north of Jericho, has Identified what he calls the oldest legal documents known to have originated in ancient Palestine.

title: $750 Million More Is Requested For Northeast Rail Renovations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  The Department of Transportation, for the second time this year, has raised its cost estimates for the Northeast Corridor railroad improvement project and extended the estimated time for completing it.

title: Freddie Fitzsimmons, a Pitcher In National League for 19 Years
description: Freddie Fitzsimmons, a knuckleball pitcher with the New York Giants and Brooklyn Dodgers and a former major league manager, died of a heart attack at his home in Yucca Valley, Calif., on Nov. 18. He was 78 years old.

title: EDDIE GOTTLIEB DIES; A PIONEER OF N.B.APro Basketball's 'Hall of Famer, 81, Coached and Owned Warriors As Team Won First TitleAssociated Press
description: Eddie Gottlieb, one of the founders of the National Basketball Association and a member of basketball's hall of fame, died in his sleep yesterday at Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 81 years old.

title: The Judge, the Mayor  and the Jury
description: When Judge Bruce Wright released Jerome Singleton without bail last April after he was charged with attempting to murder a policeman, Mayor Koch and the police sizzled in anger. Now Mr. Singleton has been acquitted of the murder charge, while on the lesser charges of assault, the jury deadlocked, 11 to 1 for acquittal. He will be retried for assault, but several important conclusions are already clear.

title: Patricia Ann Keane Married  To David King, a Hotel Aide
description: Patricia Ann Keane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney H. Keane of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to David Crawford King, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. King Jr. of Waterville and Long Lake, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony in the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: African Church Defies Apartheid
description: GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  Archbishop Bill Burnett of Cape Town, the head of the Anglican Church in southern Africa, has declared he will support church defiance of apartheid even if it leads to the breakup of the church. The Synod of the South African Anglican Church in Grahamstown unanimously approved a resolution yesterday calling on dioceses not to apply for permits required under South African law for multiracial church functions.

title: Alison Coleman Married to John L. Forbis
description: The Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Alison Scofield Coleman, daughter of Mrs. Coleman Hormel of New York and the late Lieut. Col. Wilson Dudley Coleman, U.S.A., to John Linn Forbis. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson Linville Forbis of Dallas. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read.

title: I.R.S. Criticized in L.I. Estate Suit
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 8 (UPI) A State Supreme Court justice accused the Internal Revenue Service this week of a heavyhanded economic assault on a woman whose late husband's estate was taxed for damages never collected.

title: Della Oliver Plans Wedding on Feb. 2
description: The engagement of Della J. Oliver and John H. Leathers has been announced by Miss Oliver's parents, Ernest L. Oliver of Essex, Conn., and Jean C. Oliver of Deep River, Conn. Mr. Leathers is a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Hudson Leathers of Orange, N.J.

title: A Maine Schooner In the Caribbean; Under Sail in the Caribbean If You Go...
description: It is February and I am lying on a sailing deck, enveloped in stars. The night sky is not black at all, but a vast twinkling dome of massed lights. Soft Caribbean air caresses my face and an army blanket keeps the rest of me warm. The only sound is the halyard brushing against the mast.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE CULTURE OF NARCISSISM, by Christopher Lasch. (Warner, $2.95.) A leading social historian surveys, with somber force and occasionally dark wit, the way Americans live now, particularly their attitudes toward work, the family, sexual mores, sports  and concludes that they are woefully absorbed in themselves. A best seller in hardcover.

title: I'm Nobody. Who Are You?; Women
description: IN recent years there have been several attempts to bring the concerns of feminism to the study women writers. With varying degrees of subtlety and success, critics such as the late Ellen Moers

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL; New Era for G.O.P.? ... Geography Test
description: THE odds seem good that Connecticut will have its first woman state chairman of a major political party.

title: Crooks and Gates Excel In English Soccer Action
description: LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP)  Garth Crooks of Stoke and Eric Gates of Ipswich scored three goals each today in English League soccer play.

title: ONEIDAS FILE A SUIT FOR UPSTATE TRACT; Indian Tribe Seeks 3 Million Acres, Saying It Was Taken Illegally by Treaty in 18th Century
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  In a continuation of their legal battle with the State of New York, the Oneida Indian Nation filed suit in Utica this week to regain more than three million acres that they say was illegally taken by treaty in the 18th century.

title: Arab League Encouraged to Join Common Market in the Mideast
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 8 (Reuters)All Arab League members were urged today to join the Arab Common Market as soon as possible.

title: OPPONENT'S VIEW
description: PREPARING to play Walt Frazier was always extremely difficult because he was close to being unstoppable as oneonone player. He could go to the hoop with either hand, and he also liked to take one dribble and go up with a jump shot or use a screen for a jumper. His rate of success with both maneuvers was so great that there simply was no formula against him except hard work and luck.

title: Mailbox: A Call To Abolish Boxing; The Jets Will Trade; Robinson  That's Sad
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fighting Cancer:; Fighting Cancer: Some Patients Receive Treatment at Home
description: MANHASSET SHE has been married for 39 years to a wonderful man; she has a son, a daughter and four wonderful grandchildren. It would seem she has it all. And more. She also has advanced lung cancer, for which she receives chemotherapy injections every other week.

title: Getting a start On Campaigns Hasn't Been Easy; Iran a TwoEdged Sword
description: WASHINGTON  The ceremony in the glittering, chandeliered East Room took just nine minutes, applause included, and when it was over and Jimmy Carter and Walter Mondale had posed arminarm for the inevitable announcement portrait, the field in the 1980 Presidential sweepstakes looked finally to be complete. With the President's formal declaration last week, there are now 17 candidates in all 10 Republicans, three Democrats and four minor party challengers  and they are engaged in what is likely to be one of the longest, costliest and most unpredictable campaigns for national office in this country.

title: Sunday Observer; Murder Most Foul
description: A strange story was buried in the Whatever Happened To column. of last month's Executive's Digest. It concerned one Pringle Sideshaft who had been quietly let go by a large Eastern corporation after shooting his desk. What made this remarkable was that Sideshaft just 18 months earlier had led the list in Executive Digest's Young Men to Watch column, in which he was called dynamic, harddriving and a demon memo writer.

title: San Rafael, Calif., Paper Is Sold To Gannett Publishing Company
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Dec. 8 (UPI) The Gannett Company, the nationwide newspaper publishing group with headquarters in Rochester, N.Y., has announced the purchase of The San Rafael IndependentJournal.

title: History in a Holiday Mood; Historic Homes Put on Holiday Airs
description: The New York Times /Carl T. Gossett

title: Martha McCahill Bride Of Robert E. Cowden 3d
description: The marriage of Martha McCahill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Woods McCahill of Albany, to Robert E. Cowden 3d, son of Mrs. Cowden Jr. of Dayton, Ohio, and the late Mr. Cowden, took place yesterday in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Albany. The Rev. Dr. Laman Bruner performed the ceremony.

title: 2 Airlines Vying to Serve 3 Small New York Towns; The Day Empire Ended Service
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  At a time of reduced service to many small communities as a result of the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978, the Civil Aeronautics Board has scheduled arguments next Wednesday by two commuter lines that want to serve the same area of upstate New York.

title: Concord, N.H.,School Chief Bars Distribution of Bibles by Gideons
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 8 (UPI)  The school superintendent says a group of Gideon will not be allowed to distribute Bibles in the public school system, saying it would open the floodgates to all religions.

title: LETTERS; Shostakovich
description: Shostakovich

title: DANCE VIEW; Bournonville's; Art Glows; At Centenary
description: The Royal Danish Ballet's Bournonville Centenary Festival, held in Copenhagen from Nov. 24 through Nov. 30 to commemmorate the 100th anniversary of August Bournonville's death, was a huge success. Two images symbolized this extraordinary week honoring Denmark's great 19thcentury choreographer of the Romantic ballet. One was the sight of flaming torches on the roof of the Royal Theater  lit only on special occasions and thereby marking what turned out to be an unprecedented international ballet event. The other image alludes to the special nature of Bournonville's art. It was the glimpse of a little blonde girl in a folk costume held up stage by a parent in Bournonville's The King's Volunteers on Amager. In this cozy Christmascard setting, the child is squealing silently with delight, waving her arms and beaming with joy. Outside the torches shoot brilliant reds and oranges into the night sky.

title: The Wooing of a Jersey Mayor; POLITICS
description: MR. SMITH went to Washington the other day to engage in some political handholding with President Carter and Vice President Mondale, and although he said he was willing to be wooed, he added that he wasn't ready to be won  at least not iust vet.

title: Church Member Set; For Foreign Mission
description: GLORIA GERALD had enough projects at the Grace Baptist Church to keep her busy for lifetime, but the Mount Vernon resident felt she could contribute something special in Liberia.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 PM: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Blacks Say Racism Is More Subtle
description: STAMFORD RACIAL relations in suburban communities have been drawn into the headlines in recent months with scattered incidents of cross burnings places like Norwalk and Ridgefield and efforts by the Ku Klux Klan to attract attention in Danbury  as well as incidents in other parts of the New York metropolitan area.

title: LETTERS; Gasoline Tax
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Agnes de Mille Steps Out With An Old Friend  Oklahoma! De Mille; And a New; Oklahoma!
description: The revival of Oklahoma! that opens Thursday at the Palace will have one important thing in common with the original production of 1993. Its dances, which helped to revolutionize American musical comedy, have been supervised by their creator, Agnes de Mille. After Isadora Duncan and Martha Graham, Miss de Mille has done more than anybody to give dance a foothold in this country. Nearly 90 years ago, captivated by the prairie openness and vigor in her ballet classic Rodeo, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d asked her to do the choreography for their first collaboration. Hoping for freshness, they got genius.

title: Swedish Communists Urge Utah To Reverse Conviction of Joe Hill
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 8 (UPI)  The Swedish Communist Party has sent a letter to the Governor of Utah asking that the state reverse a 1915 murder conviction of Joe Hill, a Swedish immigrant who was a labor organizer and songwriter.

title: CALENDARS; Motor Sports; Horse Shows; Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Long Island Sports Car Association 100mile noviceoriented rally; start at Howard Johnson's, Route 112 at Exit 64 of Long Island Expressway, Medford, L.I. Registration: 9:30 A.M.; first car off 11:01.

title: Airline Fined $7,000 For Failing to Resolve 2 Bumping Incidents
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The consumer office of the Civil Aeronautics Board has charged American Airlines with failing to resolve two cases of bumping passengers off overbooked flights and has levied fines totaling $7,000 against the company.

title: $1,000 Boon to Salvation Army
description: NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Dec. 8 (UPI)  An anonymous woman has donated $1,000 to the Salvation Army, saying she wanted to repay the organization for helping her family when she was a child. Capt. Lesley V. Jordan Jr. said the woman interrupted a meeting of his group's advisory board yesterday Friday to donate the money.

title: Ending Social Promotion  Pros, Cons and Uncertainties; Mr. Macchlarola
description: SOCIAL promotion, the practice of advancing children in school on the basis of age and social development, rather than academic performance, has been much criticized in recent years by a public weary educational failure. And school systems have begun abandoning it.

title: Quilting Is Alive and Well At Classes in Old Saybrook
description: OLD SAYBROOK LUCILLE BALL, Hedda Hopper and Paulette Goddard did it in Hollywood in the 1940's, and our greatgrandmothers did it long before that: they saved bits of fabric, cut them up and put them together in patchwork quilts. Women are quilting again in substantial numbers. Some consider that quilting is replacing the needlepoint and macrame crazes of recent seasons.

title: The Streamlined Look
description: First developed as a photoretoucher's tool, the airbrush has also been a valuable tool of popular graphic art and animation. Its ability to spread tones evenly and in varying degrees of intensity allowed artists of the 1920's and 30's to achieve that streamlined Art Deco look. AIR POWERED: The Art of The Airbrush with text by Elyce Wakerman, designed by Bob Zoell, Rick Probst and W. Scott Griffiths (Random House, $25) is a handsome collection of work by such masters of the airbrush as the caricaturist Garetto, the pinup artist Alberto Vargas and the French poster designer A. M. Cassandre, as well as contemporary practitioners. The more recent examples include the slick renderings of Charles E. White III (below) and the satires of Mick Haggerty (above).

title: Pollster Terms Alienated Youths Key to 1980 Vote; Holding Down Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  The most significant voting bloc of the 1980 Presidential election could be alienated baby boom Americans who reached voting age in the 1960's and 1970's but have yet to cast their first ballot, says Robert M. Teeter. a Republican pollster.

title: HOME CLINIC; How to Take Off Those Unsightly TableTop Rings
description: A white ring or watermark on a finely finished table top  a minor disaster that seems to occur all too often at this time of year after friends have stopped by for a holiday drink  can often be successfully removed by the doityourseller without need for completely stripping the finish off the entire piece, or even off the top.

title: Society Figure Is Found Slain in Her Trenton Home; Stabbed 30 to 40 Times
description: A scion of a prominent New Jersey family was slain in her newly bought Trenton home Friday, apparently after being tortured, authorities in the state's capital reported yesterday.

title: UPSTATE TAX REVOLT MIRED IN LEGAL FEES; Hardenburgh Will Spend $100,000 in Defense of Tax Exemptions to MailOrder Ministers Two Budgets, One for Highways We Have to Defend Ourselves First Amendment Lawsuit
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 6  The Town of Hardenburgh has just approved spending $100,000, about 68 percent of its general budget, for lawyers fees next year in lawsuits that arose from its policy of granting tax exemptions to property owners who declared themselves ministers of the mail order Universal Life Church in 1976 and 1977.

title: Music: David Rubinstein, Pianist
description: David Rubinstein is accustomed to championing unfamiliar or neglected music  he has devoted himself in the past to such offbeat fare as the piano music of Sibelius and Charles Griffes and the complete sonatas of MacDowell. Last Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall, the pianist was exploring again, this time the seldomencountered Tchaikovsky Sonata in G (Op. 37), the 16 Brahms Waltzes (Op. 39) and two premieres by contemporary Americans.

title: December Baseball? Yes, in Stamford
description: STAMFORD RISTMAS music is heard along Bedford Street, utility poles are adorned with wreaths, the evergreen in Latham Park is ablaze with lights and downtown store windows invite the shopper. It looks a lot like Christmas everywhere.

title: White House Rejects Plea by Carey To Move Quickly in L.I.R.R. Strike; White House Rejects Plea by Carey To Move Quickly in L.I.R.R. Strike
description: Governor Carey called on President Carter yesterday to move quickly to set up an emergency factfinding board to end the Long Island Rail Road strike, but the White House said it had no intention of intervening immediately.

title: B. S Gentry Fiance of Eugenie Isbrandtsen
description: The engagement of Eugenie Isbrandtsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jakob Isbrandtsen of Greenwich, Conn., to Bradford Stokes Gentry, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stokes Gentry of Burlington, Vt., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Big Zonk Looks to 80 Now; Sports of The Times
description: In trying to explain what it's like to be a running back, Larry Csonka once said, Eight yards doesn't seem like much until you put 11 guys in those eight yards, meaning the 11 trying to tackle him. With that in mind, try to imagine what it's like to gain 8,000 yards. Only six runners in National Football League history have scaled that plateau  Jim Brown with 12,312 yards, O. J. Simpson with 11,198, Jim Taylor with 8,597,

title: A Key Ayatollah Warns Teheran On Breaking Azerbaijani Accords; Trouble Growing Elsewhere
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 8  Ayatollah Kazem ShariatMadari, the dissident religious leader, warned today that agreements he had made with top revolutionary leaders were being broken and that if the situation continued he would not be responsible for what happened in the troubled region of Azerbaijan.

title: Music Notes: Good Neighbor Concerts; Notes on Music; Little Nightingale; HEMIDEMISEMIQUAVERS:
description: When a LatinAmerican musician comes to New York for the first time, his first telephone call is usually to the Center for InterAmerican Relations. So says James Wolfe, advisor to the center. He should know, because his organization is the main sponsor of cultural events by Latin Americans and Canadians in this city. On Thursday, it will open its annual Classic Guitar at the 92d Street Y series, with a recital by Manuel Lopez Ramos, who comes from Argentina. It had already started another annual series, Artists of the Americas at the Y, this time with a recital by Roberto Bravo, a Chilean pianist.

title: DelBello Musters 50 Backing Carter
description: THE CarterKennedy struggle for Presidential primary delegates came to Westchester in real terms last week when County Executive Alfred B. DelBello announced that 50 city, town and village officials had joined him in supporting the President's bid for reelection.

title: FastShooting Kings Sink Knicks, 145129; Knicks Drop to .500
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) Julius Erving scored 31 points and led Philadelphia to a 11796 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight, stretching the 76ers winning streak to eight games.

title: Working for Farben; Slaves
description: THIS short book is of extreme importance. Benjamin B. Ferencz arrived in the United States from Transylvania as a child. He was 13 when Hitler came to power. During World War II, as an American officer, he saw the horrors of the concentration camps as they were liberated. After the war, as a warcrimes investigator, he was among the first to examine the Nazi records of the holocaust. Later, after he became a lawyer, his special area of concern was compensation for the victims of what is known as slave labor. He rightly calls his book, based on the experience of 35 years of dedicated legal work on behalf of the survivors, Less Than Slaves.

title: World News Briefs; Britain Given Troop Figures Of Rhodesia but Not Rebels'
description: LONDON, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  In a surprise move, Zimbabwe Rhodesia disclosed its troop strength to Britain today during the peace talks between Government and guerrilla representatives.

title: Holiday Music Gets an Early Start; Nassau County Suffolk County
description: WITH bells, bugles and baritones (and, of course, sopranos), Long Island music makers will get their observance of the holiday season off to an early start this year  today, to be exact.

title: Election Laws: It's Time For a Change
description: IN the recent election, voters of New York State were confronted with a ballot listing candidates of five officially recognized parties.

title: A Bitter Exit For a Pioneer; A School Pioneer Leaves Stamford
description: STAMFORD

title: Romney Won't Stay on Sidelines; Early SmallCar Advocate
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Dec. 8 (AP)  George Romney, retired automobile executive and former Michigan Governor, Cabinet member and Presidential aspirant, is busy these days working in the Mormon Church, but he refuses to stand on the political sidelines.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY; A Black in Suburbia: The First Years Are the Hardest
description: By REGGIE SIMS

title: Wintering Mildly in Greece; Wintering Mildly in an Uncrowded, Calmer Greece
description: On any day from June to September, the Acropolis has more tourist buses than columr0; on many of the Greek islands a hotel room is as difficult to obtain as a table in a restaurant; and the press of visitors everywhere strains hospitality to the edge of surliness. It is little wonder that the Greek Government is considering putting a brake on the tourist influx if it rises to 8 million from its present level of 5.7 million a year. (The nation's population is 9 million.)

title: Anthony J. Nerad, 79, A Jet Engine Pioneer, Dead in Schenectady; Worked on U.S. Space Effort
description: Anthony J. Nerad, a pioneer in the field of jet and rocket propulsion, died Friday in Schenectady, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in nearby Alplaus.

title: Once Again, The Dollar Is Ailing; It's Ailing Again
description: LONDON  As if to add insult to American anxiety over the hostages in Iran, the often battered dollar was once again on the skids last week while the price of gold, once again, was surging.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR; Prejudice to Iranians Should Be Discouraged
description: The Westchester Journal of Nov. 25 included an item about and a photograph of the owner of a Mamaroneck auto repair shop and one of his employees displaying a sign that read We do not service cars owned by Iranians. These men should be criticized and not given encouragement for their action.

title: A Publisher Who Sells Books; Snyder
description: RICHARD SNYDER, the 46yearold president Simon & Schuster, has never been shy about his opinions, and on a recent sunny Sunday afternoon the publishing issue foremost on his mind was money  specifically the record $3.2 million that had been paid the previous week by Bantam for paperback rights to Princess Daisy, a new novel by Judith Krantz.

title: Sports News Briefs; West Virginia Appoints Nehlen as Football Coach Barclay Plager Resigns As Coach of N.H.L. Blues EichelbergerBreer Lead Mixed Team Golf by Shot Miss Ramsay in Final Of Women's Squash Event W.B.C. Orders Rematch For Conteh, Muhammad Camel and Parlov Battle To a Cruiserweight Draw
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Dec. (AP)  Donald Nehlen, an offensive backfield coach at the University of Michigan, was named head football coach at West Virginia University today.

title: Dance: Korean Program, Aak, Offered
description: A splendid evening of Korean court music and court dance on Friday night at Carnegie Hall was the first offering in the Asia Society Performing Arts Program's new season.

title: Birthday Bicycle
description: We found the following note from a friend under the door: I celebrated my 62d New York birthday today by being hit by a bicycle. Rider, an adolescent, was proceeding the wrong way on a oneway street. He hit me on my blind side while I was looking in the direction from which traffic might be expected. I felt an enormous pain out of nowhere, staggered but did not fall, and was being hollered at by the rider: Are you O.K., mister?

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Ireland's Good Friends
description: LONDON  People who care about Ireland  all of it, its ordinary people, their freedoms and wellbeing should mourn the resignation of Jack Lynch as its Prime Minister. With John Hume, the newly elected leader of the Social Democratic and Labor Party in Northern Ireland, Mr. Lynch has been one of the very few people who have consistently shown wisdom, restraint and imagination over the intractable politics of that divided island.

title: Transit Agencies Around Nation Using Rebuilt Buses to Cut Costs; Rising Demand for Old Buses
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 8 (AP) Wanted: Used bus. Need not be in running condition. Reply C.F. Weeks, CAT, Harrisburg.

title: AROUND THE Garden; This Week:
description: Don't delay to finish cutting down stalks of perennials and cleaning up borders. . . . Put pebble mulches underneath delphiniums and poppies if basal rot has been a problem. . . . Mulch lateplanted bulbs to encourage root growth. . . . Clean, oil and store hand tools and Dower mowers.

title: Officers Foil Robbery, Rescuing 17 Hostages; Officers Foil Robbery of Jeweler, Rescuing 17 Taken as Hostages
description: The man who planned the $4 million robbery of the Pierre Hotel in 1972 was seized by the police along with three other men yesterday morning as the four reportedly held 17 hostages in an attempt to rob the Spritzer & Fuhrmann jewelry company at 5 East 57th Street.

title: The Run on Safe Deposit Boxes
description: With the surge in the value of gold and silver, as well as valued family heirlooms, has come a surge in demand for oldtime security  the safe deposit box. Locked deep within a bank's vault, these boxes have also grown in popularity with the rising rate of burglaries. The result is that there no longer are enough of the boxes to go around.

title: Emily Saltzman, Executive, Engaged to Mark Haldeman
description: The engagement of Emily Saltzman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Saltzman of New York, to Mark K. Haldeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Haldeman of Rome, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: 2 Face Discipline After Patient Is Charged in Killing
description: A 43yearold mental patient from Mineola, L.I., who had threatened to kill his estranged wife, was charged yesterday with her murder, two days after he was released on a pass from Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital.

title: POLICE GOT WARNING OF BOMB AT MISSION; Man Speaking in Spanish Informed Guards Before the Explosion at Cuban Staff Building
description: Two police officers standing guard in front of the Cuban Mission to the United Nations restrained and searched a Spanishspeaking member of the mission's staff when he attempted to warn them of a bomb shortly before it exploded late Friday night at the mission building at Lexington Avenue and 38th Street in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Arts and Leisure Guide in section 2 of The Times today incorrectly identifies the current Hayden Planetarium sky show. It is the traditional holiday show, Star of Wonder, which will be shown through Jan. 8.

description: This Week

title: Security Being Stiffened at Prison That Mrs. Chesimard Fled From; The Escape Method
description: TRENTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  State prison officials are reorganizing security at the Clinton Correctional Center for Women to include tank traps of the Normandy beachhead type, following the escape of Joanne Chesimard, who had been convicted of murdering a state trooper.

title: A Century of Symphonies on Disks; A Century of; Symphonies
description: The symphonic form as it developed in Central Europe between 1800 and 1900 is the dominant element in the repertory of orchestras all over the world. During the last 25 years, these boundaries have become fixed and firmly define a century of symphonies ushered in by Beethoven and brought to a blazing conclusion by Mahler. True, works written before Beethoven and after Mahler are played today, but they are mainly considered either novelties or hors d'oeuvres even a Haydn symphony usually serves as a throatclearer to the major business of the evening, a grandly scaled 19thcentury masterpiece. While this may not be the healthiest of situations, it is a fact of life. One need only scan the record releases of the past few months for proof: virtually every star conductor has weighed in with at least one familiar work from this symphonic golden age.

title: Iran Reports 4 More Are Shot
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 8 (Reuters)Four persons have been executed by a firing squad in the southern Iranian city of Shiraz after being doomed by revolutionary courts, the state radio said today. It. said three of the men had been convicted of starting a fight. The fourth, an army officer identified as Col. Azematollah Fahandzadeh, was convicted of having taken part in the slaying of Iranians demonstrating against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Left, Right; India
description: HERE are the memoirs of two engaging, marginal men of the left and the right. Reading them side by side is to realize how much lives are the product of environment, and how success mainly a matter of timing.

title: Phoenix Pollution Alert in 2d Day
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 8 (AP)  The first airpollution alert in four years in Phoenix, capital of a state identified with clear air, was in effect for a second day today, and no improvement was expected until tomorrow. State health officials said there was no breeze to disperse normal pollutants, and ill and elderly people were advised to remain indoors.

title: Notes; A Roundup of Winter Vacation Ideas
description: As temperatures drop in the Northeast, the hoteliers in sunny places and the tour packagers complete their plans for tempting the traveler to take a winter vacation. The inducements are many: free beach bags, bottles of perfume, golf balls, Tshirts, and the facilities range from riding stables to private jet landing strips.

title: Stenmark Continues Giant Slalom Streak; Yugoslav Is Second
description: VAI D'ISERE, France, Dec. 8After pronouncing himself only 80 to 90 percent fit, Ingemar Stenmark unleashed a powerful second run today and won the first men's giant slalom of the World Cup skiing season.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The District of Columbia, which is full of traffic circles and intersections with acute angles and some of the most jumbled traffic jams in the nation, finished spending $250,000 this week to put up No Turn on Red signs at 3,100 traffic lights.

title: Appeal by Czech Dissidents Set
description: VIENNA, Dec. 7 (Reuters)  Appeals by six Czechoslovak dissidents against sentences for subversion will be heard by the Supreme Court in Prague Dec. 20, migr sources said today. The dissidents, supporters of the illegal Charter 77 human rights movement, include the playwright Vaclav Havel, who was jailed for four and a half years.

And yet, it might be argued that tne viennese composer, wno emigratea to America after Hitler marched into Austria and who died in Larchmont in 1942, was one of the pivotal artists of this century. Before you snort at that, consider the Zemlinsky case carefully.

title: A New Look; for Local Independent Stations
description: Next Sunday at 8 P.M., viewers in the metropolitan area will have the opportunity of watching Queen of Hearts, a onehour docudrama based on the life of Eva Peron. A couple of weeks later, they will be offered a group of primetime specials that include Leonard Bernstein conducting Beethoven, Brahms, Mozart, Tchaikovsky and Berlioz in a series of onehour concerts; James Mason narrating Hollywood, a 13week anthology series about the silentfilm era; Edward and Mrs. Simpson, a sixweek historicaldrama series about the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, and Top of the Hill, a fourhour original teleplay by Irwin Shaw, set during the 1980 Olympics and starring Elke Sommer and Mel Ferrer. These ambitious, celebrityladen presentations will not be seen on either network or public television, as one might expect. Rather, they belong to the primetime lineups of New York City's three unaffiliated stations: WNEWMetromedia (Channel 5), WOR (Channel 9) and WPIX (Channel 11).

title: ANTIQUES; Social History in Slate and Stone
description: HARTFORD IN a sense, old gravestones are the truest of heirlooms, pieces made specifically for use generation after generation in one place, and never intended to be removed from their original settings. Slate, sandstone and fieldstone document New England social history. They delineate our changing attitudes toward life, death and transfiguration, social status and moral justice. They are folk art in situ. Over the years, natural weathering, pollution, vandalism and neglect have left many ancient stones almost illegible, so worn that their inscriptions cannot be photographed or their carvings cast in plaster. With great care, however, they still can be rubbed, the designs transferred to rice paper with cobbler's wax.

description: Blanca Uribe is an exceptionally fluent and cultivated pianist who was born in Colombia, studied at Juilliard and in Vienna, and teaches at Vassar College. Her fingerwork is crystalline and crisp, and she sets forth her interpretive intentions with complete clarity.
