description: COMO, Italy, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  The police today freed a kidnapped industrialst and arrested two men who had held him prisoner in an apartment near Como. Francesco Massoni, 75 years old, had been abducted four days ago from his home in Pavia, 40 miles to the south.

title: Marquette Is Upset by Michigan On Late Free Throws, 63 to 60; Louisville 77, Tennessee 75
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 8 (AP)  Marty Bodnar sank two free throws for the decisive points with 58 seconds left as Michigan rallied from a 13point deficit to upset Marquette, 6360, in college basketball tonight.

title: SPOTLIGHT; He Even Counsels Kennedy
description: When Alan Greenspan became chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in 1974, his was not exactly a household name outside of business and economic circles. And his critics at the time complained that his theories dated from the Pleistocene Age.

title: How Can Towns Manage Change?
description: WESTPORT I AM frustrated, sad and angry from watching developers who, in the name of legally exercised property rights and of making money, convert our horizons into parking lots and buildings so monstrous that they often alter the whole aspect of life in a town.

title: Duck Hunter Drowns on L.I.
description: Kenneth Kunow, 23 years old, of Albany, drowned in Hewlett Bay yesterday while duck hunting with two friends in the swampy area off Broad Channel in Nassau County, the police said. Mr. Kunow was visiting his family in the area and had gone out in a small boat yesterday morning when the choppy water and gusting winds overturned the craft. His two companions were able to swim to shore.

title: Marriage Announcement 7  No Title
description: Pamela Rolquin Is Engaged

title: Making Part of the Nuclear Case
description: President Carter was convinced before the accident at Three Mile Island that the nation needed nuclear power, and he remains convinced today. After reviewing the report of his Three Mile Island Commission, the President now endorses most of its recommendations and calls safety his top priority. But he warns that, with critical energy needs unmet, we cannot shut the door on nuclear power.

title: Concord Reverses Ban On Trees at Christmas
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 8 (AP)  The smell of evergreen will be back in Concord's public buildings this Christmas, and it won't have to come from a spray can.

title: Ho Ho Humbug
description: They are a tough bunch of streetwise Santas who've seen a lot of Christmases come and go. From Midtown to Wall Street they stand, tinkling a tiny bell next to a cardboard chimney.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:30 A.M. (Channel 4) Prime of Your Life: Financial Planning for the Elderly. Arthur Kopit and Constance Cummings, guests.

title: A Holiday List of Boating Books
description: With the approach of Christmas, boatman's thoughts are likely to turn to books. And why not? Boating books appear on the market in great regularity and quantity. Whether one is a sailor intent on mastering the fine points of tuning and tactics or one is an armchair seafarer seeking adventure, here are some suggestions for your Christmas list.

title: HOME CLINIC; How to Take Off Those Unsightly TableTop Rings
description: Awhite ring or watermark on finely finished table top  a minor disaster that seems to occur all too often at this time of year after friends have stopped by for a holiday drink  can often be successfully removed by the doityourselfer without need for completely stripping the finish off the entire piece, even off the too.

title: THE PARTY'S OVER FOR THE POLITICAL PARTIES TWO PARTY TWO PARTY TWO PARTY
description: THE PARTY'S OVER FOR THE POLITICAL PARTIES

title: New Hampshire Officials Hopeful In Lobster Dispute With Maine
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 8 (AP)  New Hampshire lobstermen may still have chance to get back the 57 traps that were seized this fall by the Maine authorities, spokesman for Gov. Hugh J. Gallen says.

title: Wider Road Seen As Spur to Roosevelt
description: ROOSEVELT TOMORROW morning the Nassau County Board of Supervisors is expected to approve $2.2 million widening plan for Nassau Road in Roosevelt. County, town and village officials say it could be the catalyst for almost $12 million in improvements to the economically ailing community; others say it is the last chance to save Roosevelt.

title: Oklahoma Death Row Awaits Executions by Drug; Those Awaiting Such Execution
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 8 (AP)  At the Oklahoma State Penitentiary in McAlester, some prisoners refer to it sardonically as the ultimate high.

title: Egypt Moving Into High Gear On Driver Test; Standard's Were Tightened
description: CAIRO, Dec. 8  It was examination time at the shabby traffic department office in the Giza suburb of Cairo. License applicants waited nervously to demonstrate their proficiency by driving forward, then backing up and parking alongside a white line painted on the asphalt.

title: Mortgages Still Available for New Homes; LONG ISLAND HOUSING
description: MORTGAGES have become hard to find, but for purchasers of new homes there is still plenty of financing available and, in many instances, mortgage terms are as favorable as ever. Builders lined up their mortgage commitments several months ago when mortgage money was still easily available, so the present crunch has not yet affected newhome sales.

title: Stokowski  A Pioneer of Sonic Splender; Stokowski  A Pioneer of Sonic Splendor
description: My musical acquaintance with Leopold Stokowski, the famous conductor, dates back half a century to a time when I and the art of electrical recording were very young. It must have been 1929 or thereabouts when my father, who kept up with such things, imported the most advanced sound equipment of its day to my native city of Vienna. It was an enormous Telefunken phonograph, and, unlike its tinhorned predecessors, it played records through an amplifier and a big speaker behind the fretted curlicues of the thickly veneered cabinet. Even as a child, I was struck with the difference produced by the new electric process: for the first time, I could hear the low notes and get a sense of the golden richness of orchestral sound.

title: Nkomo, Mugabe: Watchful; Allies in Quest for Power; Mugabe's Spoils
description: Rhodesia's Muzorewa Is Handicapped by Association With Ian Smith

title: LETTER TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR; Long Island, A LittleKnown Region
description: Regarding the question Who knows about Long Island?, my experience demonstrates that very few Long Islanders know and most do not care, including some educators and newspaper editors.

title: Rhodes Calls for a Nuclear Navy As He Helps Launch a Submarine
description: GROTON, Conn., Dec. 8 (AP)  John J. Rhodes, the minority leader of the House of Representatives, helped launch the Phoenix, a nuclearpowered attack submarine, today and he called for increased defense spending and a greater emphasis on a nuclear navy.

title: Signe Wennberg Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benkt R. Wennberg of Wyncote, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Signe Wennberg, to Charles Francis Treadwell Merritt, son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Merritt of Southport, Conn. and Camden. Me.

title: Sheryl Parker Wed To David K. Ford
description: Sheryl Louise Parker and David Kent Ford, New York lawyers, were married yesterday in the FlatbushTompkins Congregational Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Gard L. Rowe performed the ceremony.

title: Article 3   No Title
Heating Aid to Go To More in North
description: WASHINGTON THE final formula for heating assistance under the new $1.6billion Federal legislation will permit about 11 times as much aid this winter to 1.6 million lowincome and elderly families in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut as under last winter's modest crisis intervention program.

title: Boston Scientists Report A New Variety of DNA
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  A variation of DNA, the molecule that is the basic building block for all forms of life, has been discovered by a team of scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, it was reported yesterday.

title: IRANIANS CONTINUING AIR TRAINING IN U.S.; Pilot Trainees Grounded by Crisis, but Embassy's Payments and Air Force Classes Go On
description: DEL RIO, Tex., Dec. 7  Despite the crisis between the United States and Iran, the Iranian Government continues to pay for the training of its Air Force and Navy pilots and technicians at United States military bases  pilots who, United States fliers say, might someday use their skills against American armed forces. However, none of the Iranians are being allowed to fly planes now.

title: Less Risky Screening Methods To Detect Breast Cancer Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)  New methods of screening for breast cancer are needed to avoid the inherent risk to the health of women who undergo Xrays, the Federal Public Health Service has reported.

title: Iranian Immigrants, Totaling Perhaps a Million, Bring Wealth and Diversity to the U.S.; Perhaps a Million in the U.S.
description: More than three years ago, Dr. Fahim Gheybi, a radiologist in residency at St. Lukes Hospital in New York City, came to the United States for refuge from what he calls political oppression in Iran. Now that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has been deposed, he plans to return  but not until he completes his training.

title: STAMPS Postal History Featured On Hill Commemoratives
description: There has never been a year for stamponstamp issues that reproduced rarity after rarity; or a year for postal histories of countries, as this year's tribute to Sir Rowland Hill, the father of the adhesive postage stamp.

title: How Bradley Won On Windfall Tax
description: States News Service

title: Taiwan Praises Goldwater
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Sun Yunsuan today praised Senator Barry Goldwater, the Arizona Republican, as a defender of the values on which the United States is founded.

title: Power Players Go Overboard; The Power Play Goes Overboard
description: PRINCETON DAVID MORELL and Andrea Asaro are bemused when fellow antinuclear activists ask them how they could have even considered designing, producing and marketing board game in which the winner is the first player build a nuclear power plant.

title: GARDENING; Care and Feeding of the Poinsettia
description: HAVE you noticed that poinsettias are much more rugged than they used to be? There once was a time when it was considered an achievement to be able to nurse one through the holiday season without having it drop all its leaves.

title: Unresigned Artist Shown in Princeton
description: PRINCETON THE art world is plagued with resignation. Many artists, it seems, are resigned to explore esthetic areas that have already been explored by others. They might bring something individual to their explorations, but one often wonders whether the attempt is worthwhile.

title: ART; Pictorial Statements That Hint of Social Change
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE forms and moods of the city have fascinated photographers since the invention of the camera. Some have made objective records of its architecture, while others have concentrated on the lives of its people; still others have tried to capture the interdependence of the environment and its inhabitants.

title: Television This Week
description: OF SPECIAL INTEREST

title: Outbreak of Encephalitis in India Kills 37, Many of Them Children
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 8 (UPI)  An outbreak of encephalitis in the central state of Andhra Pradesh has killed 37 people, most of them children, in the last month, the Press Trust of India news agency reported.

title: 2 Teachers From U.S. Meet Iranian Militants
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 8 (AP)  Two University of Kansas teachers, described as foes of the ousted Shah, visited the occupied United States Embassy today but were not permitted to see any of the 50 American hostages.

title: Miss Kim Captures Laurels
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 8 Dec. 8 Nellie Kim of the Soviet Union won the women's allround title tonight by pitting her classic, uncluttered style against the difficult moves of her younger rivals in the world gymnastics championships.

title: Heating Aid to Go To More in State
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. THE final formula for heating assistance under the new $1.6billion legislation will permit about 11 times as much aid this winter to 1.6 million lowincome and elderly families in Connecticut, New York State, and New Jersey as under last winter's modest crisis intervention program.

title: Exploring Schumann's Piano Music; Exploring Schumann
description: We tend to think of the standard repertory as a pantheon of great composers, their places fixed like stone statues. Actually the situation is more malleable than that. Composers rarely disappear entirely from serious consideration once they've been accorded it. But their popularity can wax and wane. Mozart, although overtly slighted by some a century ago, has generally been considered a master. But it's only been in recent decades that he's been played as much as he is now.

title: ART; Tibet: A Lost World at the Neuberger
description: THE Newark Museum's Collection of Tibetan art has gone on the road and, under the title of Tibet : A Lost World, may be seen at the Neuberger Museum through Feb. 28 at the State University of New York at Purchase. This is to be its last stop before a tour of Australian museums.

title: DINING OUT; Stellar Cuisine in Greenwich; ** The Homestead Inn
description: GREENWICH ONE look at the Homestead Inn's newly refurbished dining room, and one's spirits soar. It is surely one of the most inviting restaurants we have seen in ages, with taste and understated elegance.

title: On Language Machisma; Fungible; Be Advised
description: Clare Boothe Luce recently predicted that a new adjective would have to be coined, on the analogy of macho, to stand for exaggerated female pride. She suggested facho. But that seemed too derivative, like Adam's rib, and might lead to the noun fachism. I wrote: Readers of this space are urged to send in suggestions.

title: Rosemary Cerussi Wed in Bronxville to Carlos A. Ferrer
description: Rosemary Cerussi and Carlos A. Ferrer were married yesterday in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. John V. Wilkinson performed the ceremony.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE; PROGRAM ON BOXING
description: A tribute to Rocky Marciano, who died in 1969, is being held at 10:30 this morning at the Purchase Country Club, Port Chester. It is being sponsored by the American Association for the Improvement of Boxing Inc., in conjunction with the Building and Construction Trades Council of Westchester and Lower Putnam Valley.

title: Letters to the Editor; Traveling by Train
description: To the Editor:

title: KENNEDY IS BATTLING FOR SUPPORT IN IOWA; As Caucuses Approach, He Fights Suspicion About His Past and Strength of Carter Camp Caucuses in Six Weeks Gathering the Names Suspicions About Kennedy
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Dec. 8  Senator Edward M. Kennedy was about to speak to a bar association luncheon in Des Moines yesterday, and Paul Tyler, a local lawyer, was musing about the intense and often testy race for the Democratic nomination.

title: GARDENING; Care and Feeding of the Poinsettia
description: HAVE you noticed that poinsettias are much more rugged than they used to be? There once was a time when it was considered an achievement to be able to nurse one through the holiday season without having it drop all its leaves.

title: News Summary; International
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1979

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: CONCERNED that the Village of Larchmont might sell to housing developers a 60acre parcel conaining two reservoirs that it no longer uses for its water supply, a group of citizens has formed a committee called Friends of the Reservoir. The committee, according to one of its organizers, is now trying to find a way to save the land.

title: For a More Humane Technology
description: HAMDEN THE plight of the snail darter in its losing battle for the territory of the Tennessee Valley Authority  a threeinch fish fighting hydroelectric power  is symbolic of the crisis of our age. Ecology is in, technology is out. We fear for the fauna and flora of the planet.

title: Recital: Narciso Yepes, Guitarist
description: Nobody plays the guitar like Narciso Yepes. For one thing, no other guitarist plays a 10string instrument, a Yepes invention that yields an unusual, and unusually rich, assortment of sonorities. For another, Mr. Yepes cultivates a playing style that seems outside the Segovia tradition.

title: VATICAN CONDEMNS BOOK BY U.S. PRIESTS; Denounces Liberal Sexual Attitude Contained in 2YearOld Work
description: ROME, Dec. 8  The Roman Catholic hierarchy has issued a sharp new condemnation of the liberal view of human sexuality contained in a book published by American priests more than two years ago

title: Folk Music With a TexMexAccent; TexMex Folk Music
description: Back at the beginning of the folkmusic revival, it was generally assumed that the folk spoke and sang in English  quaint, colorful English, rife with archaic mountain useages and blues neologisms, but English all the same. In 1952. Folkways Records issued its pioneering Anthology of American Folk Music, three tworecord sets edited by Harry Smith, and of the 84 selections, only five numbers by Louisiana Acadian groups were sung in a language other than English. Many enthusiasts were quite amazed to discover that the lively. diverse music in the Smith anthology (which is still in print and still wonderful) was originally recorded, in the 1920's and 30's, not by folklorists but by commercial record companies out to turn a profit. America's folk heritage was right at our fingertips, preserved not in some musty archive but on the old 78rpm records that littered thriftstore bargain bins across the continent.

title: Beauty THE YEAR OF THE TRICHOLOGIST
description: Anyone looking for a hairraising experience might consider consulting trichologist. After all, lots of movie stars and famous people see one of these haircare practitioners once week and swear by their treatments.

title: Other Ideas &Trends; Hands Ott, on Census
description: The United States Catholic Conference confirmed last week that the church would not encourage illegal immigrants participation in the 1980 census. Hispanic and black groups are disappointed since the whole number of persons in each state helps determine Congressional representation and Federal dollar contibutions to welfare programs. They had hoped for nationwide church aid in getting accurate tallies, although individual dioceses will be helping illegal immigrants to step forward and be counted.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: C. Sauers

title: Barney's Barney: A NoBunkOriginal; Calls With New Ideas
description: Every day without fail, Barney's clothing store receives a collect call from an 84yearold Miami Beach man who asks, What's selling? What's new? What's old? The old man's call is never refused, and the information he is seeking  even secret sales figures  is readily divulged.

title: Those Nostalgic English Music Halls; Evenings of Nostalgia in England's
description: As on so many occasions in Britain, the evening begins with a loyal toast to the Queen. To our great and glorious Majesty, says the crowd, pint glasses raised high. Queen Victoria  God bless her!

title: ANTIQUES; Some Good Seats; At CooperHewitt
description: Most antiques collectors who are furniture enthusiasts focus on one period or style  be it Baroque, Biedermeier or Bauhaus  and rarely investigate others. They are so busy tracking down a certain type of chair, desk, table or chest, that they never seem to take the time to stand back, take a long look at the objects of their concern and see how they compare to what was crafted in other ages by other people.

title: Will 1941 Make Spielberg a BillionDollar Baby?
description: LOS ANGELES Ashabby little biliousgreen building nestled just outside the walls of the vast Burbank Studios, home of both Warner Brothers and Columbia Pictures. The onestory green building  an exstorage facility houses 31yearold Steven Spielberg's ATeam Productions, a name that implies, perhaps, that everything on the more splendiferous side of the studio wall is, by comparison, BTeam.

title: Trans Am to Merge Two Racing Classes; Affordable Racing Is Goal
description: The Sports Car Club of America has announced changes for 1980 in its TransAm series for sports coupes. New rules are aimed at reducing the size and cost of the cars competing and at enabling more drivers to run in the nationwide series of professional races.

title: Issue; of Title IX Continues Under New Guidelines
description: Resistance to Title IX, the Federal law banning sex discrimination in education, does not appear to be as widespread among athletic directors as it was when Congress enacted the law seven years ago. But those who remain opposed to Title IX are just as vociferous now as they were then and appear ready to fight over the issues involved.

title: MASSACHUSETTS UNIT FIGHTS AUTO THEFTS; Governor Names 21 to a Panel State Has Had Worst Record in the Nation for Decade
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  Gov. Edward J. King has asked a panel of 21 policemen, insurance experts and others to propose ways to end Massachusetts dubious distinction of being first in the nation in automobile thefts.

title: Khalid Reopens Mosque After Rout of Attackers
description: MECCA, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 7 (Reuters)  Thousands of worshipers crowded into Mecca's Grand Mosque today, open for Moslem Sabbath prayers for the first time since a band of religious extremists seized the shrine two and a half weeks ago.

title: Give Iran a Lesson, Say Some Europeans
description: Q. To what extent do Europeans feel that the crisis In Iran concerns them?

title: RURAL HEATING AID IS TERMED A FAILURE; Only 1,072 Homes Winterized by U.S. Programs, Senate Panel Is Told by Interest Group
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)  An organization with programs for the rural poor has charged that Agriculture Department programs for insulating rural homes against the winter cold have failed because of a lack of commitment from the Carter Administration.

title: A Tenement's Transformation in Brooklyn
description: BROOKLYN PICTURE six long, low, redbrick buildings set around a grassy court. Peaked roofs and dormers are of slate, in shades of gray, green and rust. Arched doors and windows, symmetrically spaced, rest on granite sills. Exclusive new condominium? Not at all.

title: ABOUT CARS; Answering the Mail
description: WITH the continuing uncertainty about gasoline shortages, sales of dieselfueled cars are growing by the day. And for owners of these vehicles, the coming of cold weather can signal problems that are in many ways different from those faced by drivers whose cars have conventional power plants.

title: PAF's Good Evening,a Seriocomedy That's Fitfully Funny; THEATER IN REVIEW
description: HUNTINGTON BEING funny is a serious business. Michael Barrie and Jim Mulholland have tried to write a funny play about it  with some serious comments that come out more as afterthought than thoughtful.

title: ART; A HusbandWife Show
description: JERSEY CITY IT TAKES a certain courage for a husband and wife to exhibit their art together, not only because of today's engulfing tide of individualism, but also because of the revelations involved.

title: Delaware Captures A Crown; Low Scoring at start
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 8 (AP)  Scott Brunner passed for 296 yards and three touchdowns today to spark Delaware to a 3821 victory over Youngstown State that gave the Blue Hens the National Collegiate Division II football championship.

title: GIRL SCOUTS SEEKING TO RECRUIT LEADERS; Greater New York Council Appeals to Men and to Retired People in Its Drive to Fill Posts Membership in City Drops Leaders Given More Latitude Job Is Found Rewarding
description: The Girl Scouts Council of Greater New York is now scouting for leaders.

title: Marsha Stern Is Fiancee Of J. Alan Mack, Lawyer
description: Marsha Stern of Amherst, N.Y., a senior financial analyst with the electrochemical division of the Hooker Chemical Company in Niagara Falls, N.Y., and J. Alan Mack of Lewiston, N. Y., division counsel for Hooker's specialtychemicals division, will be married Jan. 12 in Somerville, N.J.

title: POLITICS Legislators Ponder Staffing and Workload
description: HARTFORD SOME legislators frustration with the way the General Assembly operates is producing a new round of proposals for change.

title: Fashion; MANY SPLENDORED HUES OF JEWELS
description: Photographs by Eva Sereny; hair, Kerry Warn; makeup Pierre Larache

title: Shows and Events
description: Today  Antiques and crafts sale and flea market, Fair Lawn High School, Berdan Avenue, Fair Lawn. More than 100 exhibits. Hours: 10 A.M.5 P.M. Donation of $1 will go to the Charity Fund of the Knights of Pythias. For information, call (201) 7913145.

title: Major News; Ethnic Divisions; Inflame Iranians; Hostage Hopes Rise
description: In Summary

title: The Gifts That Keep On Giving
description: WHAT'S a perfect gift? I've had so many I should know. The handknitted sweaters I live in from fall through spring, for instance, gifts of my aunt, my mother's sister. I remember wearing Margit Neni sweaters in my childhood, and now, in my anecdotage, I have a wardrobe of four.

title: The Ski Lodffe That the W.P.A. Built
description: If every joke were worth a dollar, the Federal Government's projects of the W.P.A. in the Depression would have made the whole country rich. W.P.A. crews were the frequent butt of jests (Let em share a shovel to lean on) but they paved roads and built post offices, painted murals and wrote plays, planted parks and designed playgrounds, and created one of the enduring heirlooms of the period  Timberline Lodge on Mount Hood in Oregon.

title: Rosalynn Carter, on Tour in South, Stresses President's Stand in Crisis; There Is Only One Issue Advisers and Supporters A Typical American Girl
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 8  Winding up her last major scheduled fundraising tour before the Christmas holidays, Rosalynn Carter made appearances in Georgia and Arkansas today as part of a weeklong drive that was expected to raise more than $2.5 million for President Carter's reelection campaign.

title: Posters Go Up at New Peking Site As the Old Democracy Wall Closes; Poster Says No More Posting
description: PEKING, Dec. 8  It was a good place to sell ice cream bars even on days when the air was colder than the ice cream. Candied crabapples far outsold underground magazines, and bicycle parking spaces outsold everything. There was usually a sea of bicycles parked spoketospoke in front of Democracy Wall.

title: Tiffany Museum Opens in Store
description: ST. JAMES I ENJOY life and I have the feeling I'm here to do something to make life nicer for other people. Andrew Havrisko, proprietor of the General Store established in 1857  was giving one reason why he recently converted his shop's second floor into a museum housing a number of the tools, sketches, raw glass and brilliant windowpanes created at the turn of the century by Louis Comfort Tiffany.

title: Sweet Sound Lures Miss Munsel
description: LATTINGTOWN PATRICE MUNSEL'S current appearance in the Northstage Theater production of The Sound of Music places her in familiar territory, both geographically and professionally.

title: Recalling Walt Frazier: Style on Court and Off
description: With Walt Frazier every move had a meaning. There was a beauty and a balletic style in the way he played basketball and the way he used his body. Frazier conveyed his style with anticipation and his deception. Except for his flashing eyes, the expression on his bearded face was an austere blank. He did things quickly and quietly, was seldom ruffled, rarely worked up a sweat and never disputed an official's call. But when he didn't like the way things were going he would have an injury, and let it all calm down while he lay on the court, recuperating.

title: Editors Choice
description: DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Golding. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A magic fable that explores the darkness of human nature through the fortunes of Matty, brushed by fire as a boy during a World War II blitz, and of numerous people he later encounters in Britain and Australia.

title: BIG BUSINESS ON THE OFFENSIVE
description: After decades of reticence, the business community has quietly become the most influential lobby in Washington.

title: Connecticut /This Week; ART
description: BRIDGEPORT  Handcrafted scenes from The Nutcracker by Hilda Farber. Christmas scenes in gingerbread, collection Alice in Wonderland figurines, through Jan. 4, Library, 925 Broad St. Free. 5767413. EAST LYME  Paintings by Louis Posner, through Dec. 20, Library, Town Hall and High School. Free. 7396926.

title: Westport Contest; Goes to High Court
description: WESTPORT AWESTPORT School Board election contest centering on majorityminority representation has been turned over to the State Supreme Court for a decision.

title: In Community Orchestras, It's Music for the Joy of It
description: THEY arrive promptly, instrument cases in hand, ready to become working musicians for two hours a week. For most, once they are inside the rehearsal room, the day's pressures and demands are forgotten.

title: Moves of Soviet At Sea Puzzling NATO Experts; Military Analysis
description: NORFOLK, Va.  The comparative inaction of the Soviet Navy in the face of the largest United States Navy buildup in the Indian Ocean since World War II is an enigma to American staff planners. One theory put forward here at naval headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is that the Russians are waitMg to learn where United States crisis deployments will create a vacuum in maritime security.

title: THEATER; Some Errors Mar A Rousing Yankees
description: HARTFORD WHILE I'M sorry to report that I didn't agree with them, the Hartford Stage Company's audience seemed to have much more fun than I didat Damn Yankees. Not that I saw the original Broadway production in 1955, which racked up 1,022 performances before it closed. But I do have an original cast recording that has been played to death and a history of canceling appointments whenever the film version shows on television with most of the original Broadway people, including Gwen Verdon and Ray Walston.

title: Article 4   No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIESTI

title: Marriage Announcement 9  No Title
description: Judy Ellen Veroneau Affianced

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE; PICTURES BY CHALIRPIN
description: Greenwich Library is holding what appears to be the first retrospective exhibition of the work of Boris Chaliapin, best known for his 400 Time magazine covers, Friday through Jan. 13.

title: Greeks Seek Cleaner Fuel to Cut Acropolis Damage
description: ATHENS, Dec. 8  After considering ways of halting the ruinous effects of air pollution on the Acropolis monuments, which according to an official will cease to exist within 30 years if something is not done, the Greek Government has conchided that that the best solution is for Athenians to burn only lowsulfur fuels.

title: Navajo and Hopi Tribes Agree on Arizona Land
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  The Navajo and Hopi Indian tribes say they have agreed on a settlement of a centuryold dispute over reservation lands in Arizona and will now ask Congress to consider it.

title: Mother Teresa in Oslo for Prize
description: OSLO, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  Mother Teresa arrived today to receive the Nobel Peace Prize for her work with destitute people in Calcutta, India. The 89yearold Albanianborn nun will receive the prize on Monday, the anniversary of the death of Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite and founder of the award.

title: THE WORLD OF MOTHER TERESA; MOTHER TERESA
description: In the sprawling slums of India, 1979's Nobel Peace Prize winner nurtures the poorest of the poor and envelops them with love.

title: Behind the Chase's New Vigor; Rockefeller's; Tough Strategy; The Man Behind the Chase Bank
description: When Indira Gandhi was ousted as Prime Minister of India, a joke went around the financial world that David Rockefeller would put her on the board of the Chase Manhattan Bank. And when the deposed Shah of Iran needed help in getting into the United States in October, he found he had Mr. Rockefeller behind him.

description: Today: Leading Events

title: OFFICER IS ACCEPTED DESPITE OLD CODE; New Breed of Cop Gains Respect for Citing Alleged Instances of Corruption on Force What He Thought Was Right Threats to Family
description: It would have been easier if I did not know them, if we hadn't spent so much time on the job talking about wives and kids and personal stuff. But I had to put aside feelings of friendship and act as a police officer.

title: Half in Guyana Deaths Linked to Welfare Pay;
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (AP)  California's Secretary of Health and Welfare has issued a report showing that half the 992 persons who died in the People's Temple massacre in Guyana received welfare payments from the state at some point in their lives.

title: Correction
description: An error in the transcription of Denis Donoghue's review of the Harvard Guide to Contemporary American Writing (Oct. 28) resulted in an inadvertent change in the meaning of a sentence, which should have read: Gerald Weales's essay on American drama proceeds without melodramatic intent. The printed version changed without to with.

description: Today

title: Town Makes Plea to NASA;
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 8 (UPI) The Town Council of North Smithfield has asked the Federal Government to send a U2 spy plane over the state to take infrared pictures to determine whether hazardous chemical wastes are leaching into the town water supply from two landfills. But the National Aeronautics and Space Administration official says a U2 plane took infrared photos of Rhode Island in 1977 to monitor surface water flows. Copies of the photographs will be relayed to the town.

title: Portugal's Business Families Returning to New Era; Political Shift in Four Years Revolution Came to a Halt Great Loss to the Country Families Take on Foreign Partners
description: LISBON, Dec. 6  On March 11, 1975, Jorge Espirito Santo was grabbed by the employees of his family's bank, the biggest in Portugal, and thrown in jail. A bizarre and amateurish rightwing uprising, halfheartedly led by Gen. Antonio de Spinola, had collapsed in confusion, and Portugal's roller coaster of a revolution turned sharply to the left.

title: A Harrowing Film About Ireland Today:A Harrowing Film on Ireland
description: A naked prisoner sits strapped to a wooden chair in a basement interrogation room, while his questioner prods him with electric shocks. When he still refuses to talk, another questioner coolly breaks his fingers with the edge of a brown plastic tray, then disgustedly leaves him lying unconscious on the concrete floor.This 10-minute torture scene is part of a harsh new motion picture called "The Outsider," which just opened here, shocking British audiences by deeply disturbing this country's image of itself. The directorial debut of Tony Luraschi, a 40-year-old American, the film is a stunningly accurate portrayal of the violence in Northern Ireland. And the British are so dismayed by its view of the troubled province because, as the critic Tom Hutchinson wrote in Now magazine, "the gloating inquisitor who is applying the electric pain and smashed fingers is on our side."In a way that often recalls how Americans used to feel about the Vietnam war when it was still in progress, the British do not like to talk or even think about what they call "the troubles" in Northern Ireland. During the past decade, two thousand people have been killed in the battle that the Roman Catholic republicans are waging to drive the British off the island. But the deaths rarely rate more than a couple of paragraphs anymore in the newspapers."The Outsider" is the story behind those short articles  "I.R.A. Gunmen Kill Magistrate," "Protestant Gang Kills Catholic Legislator," "Troops Kill 12-year-old Terrorist." But unlike those little newspaper items, the film is impossible to ignore, which is why one magazine article described it as "merciless," and why Alexander Walker, a critic for The Evening Standard, called it "an addition to the debate on Ulster that uses the unrivaled power of cinema to involve us in the uneasy morality of civil war."Like "The Deer Hunter" and "Apocalypse Now," Mr. Walker wrote, "The Outsider" is able to "bring an unpopular war home to people through the medium of popular entertainment, with an artistic skill that can sharpen perceptions and not blunt them, as the ever-repeated news of I.R.A. violence does on TV or in the press."Before its London premiere (the movie will open in the United States early next year), British officials and Army officers, concerned that the film might glorify the terrorist cause, asked for a special preview  and, to the irritation of Mr. Luraschi, they were given one. But they needn't have worried. Virtually no one in the "The Outsider" emerges with any glory, and the terrorists are no more sympathetically portrayed than the British "occupiers."The film tells the story of Michael Flaherty (Craig Wasson), a young American who has grown up enchanted by the tales that his grandfather (Sterling Hayden) tells of his glorious exploits as a fighter in the Irish Republican Army. Fired by the idealism of the battle against "the Brits," Michael (the "outsider" of the title) leaves his comfortable home in suburban Detroit and goes to Ireland to help the I.R.A.Soon after he joins their ranks, however, the I.R.A. leaders in Dublin, always worried about the flow of contributions from the United States, decide that he can best help the cause by getting killed in battle, and they plan how to bring about his death. The equally devious British Army command also tries for a propaganda gain by planting the idea that Michael is a spy, so that the I.R.A. will kill him in one of its ritual executions.British audiences are shocked by the sight of Army officers plotting murder in an office that is serenely surveyed by a wall photograph of Queen Elizabeth. But the film is equally unsparing about the fuzzy green haze of Irish romanticism that blinds so many republicans, who even today are killing in the name of nationalism. In Michael's childhood, his grandfather had lulled him to sleep with ballads about the brave fighters who "loved dear old Ireland and never feared danger." The old man had constantly reminded him of the revolutionary dictum that "in every generation must Ireland's blood be shed." But after he gets to the scene of the battle as an adult, Michael learns that, up close, most of those sentiments are as elusive as the morning mist that hangs over Ireland's rolling green countryside, and they are often far less noble than they first seemed."My film just declares the facts of the situation," explained Mr. Luraschi, who directed the film from his own screenplay, shooting most of it in the Repulic of Ireland, with the permission of the Irish Government. "It doesn't have a point of view. It just tells what is happening."London reviewers gave the film mixed, though generally favorable, reviews. Several of them distinguished between its merits as a work of art and its political significance. Nigel Andrews, for example, writing in The Financial Times, found some artistic flaws, especially in the climax of the picture. But he hailed "The Outsider" as "a substantial breakthrough, nonetheless, in tackling the Irish question." Mr. Andrews continued: "Luraschi shows a scrupulous lack of favoritism in his attribution of idealism and cynicism to either side. He also captures the slow-burn horror of a war conducted by sabotage and ambush rather than open confrontation on the battlefield." Writing in The Daily Mail, Margaret Hinxman said the film "will inevitably cause a furor" and added, "One can only be ashamed at the timidity of the commercial British film industry in refusing to touch this hot potato."Surprisingly, Mr. Luraschi had never set foot in Ireland before 1976, when he first read "The Heritage of Michael Flaherty," a novel, then unpublished, by an American journalist named Colin Leinster. Although he had had a good deal of experience in film making  as an assistant director under Roger Vadim, Ruy Guerra and Alberto Lattuada, among others  he had never directed a full-length feature."I wanted to do something about terrorism, and I realized that Colin's book was it," Mr. Luraschi explained in a recent interview in his two-room apartment on the Left Bank in Paris. "So I took an option on the book, and then set out to learn about the Irish problem."Moving with his wife into a white stone farm cottage in County Cork, not far from the sea, Mr. Luraschi, an alumnus of North Hollywood High School and the California Institute of Fine Arts, spent six months writing his screenplay and talking to people on both sides of the 300-mile border separating the Republic from the British province. Finally, he sold the idea to Paramount Pictures, of which his father, Luigi Luraschi, is a vice president.Like other Americans who have come to study the Irish problem, Mr. Luraschi was shocked at what he called "the British blindness" about Ireland. "To them, the Irish are stupid, lazy, the subject of jokes," the director said, his intense brown eyes opening wide in indignation. "But that's all. They don't want to admit what is really happening, or what is being done in their name."One of the most pernicious figures in "The Outsider" is Nigel Percival (David Collings), a young major in British Army intelligence, stationed in Belfast. It is he who conceives the idea of setting up Michael as a spy and who acquiesces in the torture of another republican sympathizer by the Northern Irish police.The sight of Nigel, huddled in a furtrimmed overcoat and watching the man being beaten and maimed because he will not talk, is all the more shocking because the young officer's appearance and manner  vaguely reminiscent of, say, Alec Guinness in "The Bridge On the River Kwai"  have stood in so many films for the right-mindedness of British authority and such traditional British virtues as decency, civility and honor. As Mr. Luraschi says, the scene makes it "harder for us to wash our hands of it than if it had been of Arabs torturing each other, or a Nazi concentration camp."The way in which this young major with his upper-class English accent has been brutalized by his duty in Northern Ireland is as true as a real incident there last February: a 20-year-old British soldier on guard duty in a particularly hazardous part of Belfast suddenly went berserk and began firing indiscriminately, killing one fellow trooper and wounding another, before a fourth soldier shot him dead.And it reflects one of the aspects of the problem that most trouble the thoughtful people of Northern Ireland  the way violence and its threat have become routine, brutalizing everyone. Shoppers entering a supermarket in Belfast no longer even notice, or interrupt their chatting, when they are frisked for guns and their purses are searched for bombs. Out in the green countryside, no one (except the occasional sniper) pays any attention anymore to the four-man army patrols, in camouflage battle fatigues with automatic rifles, who pick their way carefully through the most charming and picturesque villages, with the last man walking backwards to cover the rear, as if in a hostile jungle.But the soldiers suffer from it. The father of the young man who went mad on guard duty last winter said that the four months' service in Northern Ireland had "finished" his son. And he added, echoing the sentiments of Mr. Luraschi, "perhaps this tragedy will make someone in England realize that this can't go on and on and on."Anyone familiar with Northern Ireland is struck by the way the fiction of "The Outsider" constantly overlaps with reality. Fund-raising in America really is one of the I.R.A.'s main concerns; whatever one may think of the film as a work of art or entertainment, it is a fact that the ambushes in the film are as real as the attack that killed Earl Mountbatten last August. And, ironically, the real climate of violence and sectarian recrimination portrayed in the film will make any theater owner in Belfast wary of showing it, for fear that one group or the other will set off a bomb. The film also depicts the little routine horrors of daily life in Belfast: the small boys in an alleyway, earnestly comparing bomb-making techniques at an age when they should be talking of football or cricket; the sweet little grandmother, with a gold cross around her neck, who puts down her cup of tea at the sound of trouble and rushes to the door, calling out to the friendly neighborhood terrorists as they run by, "Get one of the bastards for me. Kill the bastards. God bless you lads.""The Outsider" leaves the viewer with a conclusion that many visitors to the troubled island have already drawn: that the agonizingly complex Irish problem will not yield to simple solutions, neither the loyalists' demand for more police presence and more police powers, nor the republicans' facile cry, "Brits out." The film presents all the complexities in a troubling and ambiguous episode about a 12-year-old boy who is shot dead as he tries to throw a homemade fire bomb into a building that had been the bunker of loyalist snipers.His death in the film would be far simpler emotionally if he were killed by accident. But he is not. He is, in fact, acting like a terrorist, although the soldier who shoots him, peering dimly through the familiar Irish mist, has no idea that his target is so young. ("Jesus Christ, it's a kid," the soldier says in anguish, when he sees the corpse up close.)A terrorist, yes. But still a 12-year-old boy who at first doubts that he can even come along with his older friends on the bombing attack, because "my ma won't let me out after dark." So he sneaks out to play with the big boys, and a few hours later is lying face down, dead, in the wet mud of a back alley in Belfast.

title: Oriental Businesses Growing in County
description: A cluster of Japanese shops, catering to Japanese and Korean families and to Americans who like Oriental foods, gifts and services has grown in Hartsdale at the intersection of Central and Hartsdale Avenues, with a few shops down Central Avenue just over the Scarsdale border.

title: Richard Bergman Jr. Weds Kathryn Baker
description: The Upper Ridgewood Community Church in Ridgewood, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kathryn A. Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Baker of Ridgewood, to Richard Gregory Bergman Jr. He is a son of Major Bergman, U.S.A.P., retired, and the late Barbara Hawkinson Bergman of Rockford III. The Rev. David C. Van Sickle performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: MAKING DEFENSE INTO AN ART FORM
description: WHEN I first came to the New York Knickerbockers in November 1971, I was rather apprehensive about coming to the one team that I had deemed an enemy. One of my anvrehensions was how I would fit into the backcourt of the Knicks. They already had, in my mind, a really formidable backcourt. First, there was Dick Barnett, who I thought was the steadying force.

title: HOME CLINIC; How to Take Off Those Unsightly TableTop Rings; ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: A white ring or watermark on finely finished table top minor disaster that seems to occur all too often at this time of year after friends have stopped by for a holiday drink  can often be successfully removed by the doityourselfer without need for completely stripping the finish off the entire piece, or even off the top.

title: Indoor Tennis Center a Success; A Successful Operation
description: The U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center, the $12 million complex that Slew Hester built in Flushing Meadows, is beginning to pay off in more ways than just the Open championships.

title: Desire And Memory; VANISHING ANIMALS
description: INFIDELITY is to modern fiction what courtly love was to the 18thcentury sonnet: a rhetorical convenience, an excuse for the imagination.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IF it had been in a televison doctor show, the scene might not have made it through the censors. A 48yearold woman had fallen down a flight of stairs, and now she was lying on her back on a metal examination table, moaning softly. The pain was caused by a gash on the head and a possible neck fracture, but she was also suffering from a possible internal disorder that had left her pink nightgown, and later the white hospital robe, drenched in blood.

title: BRITAINMENT'S ESTABLISH SPIES
description: On May 25, 1951, at the height of the cold war, two British diplomats, Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean, disappeared from Great Britain just as they were about to be apprehended as spies for the Soviet Union. The defection of these members of the establishment stunned the nation. It also shattered what Andrew Boyle, in The Fourth Man, describes as the traditional publicschool convention of mutual trust obtaining between colleagues who shared the same privileged social backgrounds. ... That a Communist conspiracy could have so atrophied the normal impulses of patriotism that men in positions of responsibility would betray their country's secrets to the Soviet Union out of conviction seemed quite incredible. Alas, an official conspiracy of silence set in. Shock, embarrassment, grievance, bewilderment, these and other negative responses to inconceivably bad news were fortified by the ageold instinct of the British ruling class to sit tight and say nothing when in doubt and difficulty. The stiffupperlip technique irritated the general public and was derided by the press. Fleet Street finally nosed out, bit by bit, an unsavory tale of omissions which the authorities would have been happier to bury and forget.

title: Republican Treen Apparent Victor In Runoff for Louisiana Governor
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sunday, Dec. 9 (AP)  Representative David C. Treen, a conservative Republican, apparently succeeded yesterday in his attempt to break the Democratic Party's 102year hold on the Louisiana Governor's mansion.

title: Beautiful Dreamers; Sports of The Times
description: The most important thing in the Olympic Games is not to win but to take part, just as the most important thing in life is not the triumph but the struggle.

title: Carey's Telegram
description: Following is the text of the telegram sent yesterday by Governor Carey to President Carter on the Long Island Rail Road strike:

title: 3 Agencies That Fight Against the Pain of Poverty; HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: It is ironic in this year designated by the nations of the world as the International Year of the Child  in this year in which eloquent words have been svoken about the needs and rights of children  that for many children it has proved to be a year of great rhetoric and little action. A more realistic designation might be the Year of Pious Platitudes.

title: Croton Author Sees; a ChildCare Crisis
description: ACCORDING to Dr. Jane Price of Croton, whose experience with her 3yearold daughter Erica prompted her to write her newly published book, How to Have a Child and Keep Your Job, the United States is now in the throes of childcare crisis.

title: Slayer Tells Reason for Park Murder
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 8 (AP) Kim Jae Kyu, South Korea's former intelligence chief, testified today that he assassinated President Park Chung Hee to end oneman rule and restore democracy to this country. He said he had sought to kill Mr. Park for years.

title: PETER PANAND HOW; HE GREW
description: With the play Peter Pan charming audiences on Broadway yet again, there is a certain fascination in peering back at its origins, at the London of the late 19th century where Sir James M. Barrie was one of the most prominent playwrights of his time. He was a man of what many would call peculiarities. Short in stature, asexual in nature, he seemed to gravitate quite naturally toward children, a number of whom became his very close friends. Of these, the closest were the five young sons of his friends Sylvia and Arthur Llewelyn Davies. The high spirits and uninhibited taste for mischief of the Davies boys provided Barrie with much of his inspiration for Peter Pan, the story of a boy hero who has run away from home to keep from growing up and gone to Never Never Land, where he lives in

title: For the Complete Boulevardier
description: COLLINSVILLE By a quiet country pond in a corner of this rural community 15 miles northwest of Hartford, the E. J. Marshall Corporation is busily honing an old tradition.

title: Tenant Groups Trying to Organize RentersLobby; Lowest Vacancy Rate
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8  Concerned about rising rents, the increasing conversion of apartment buildings to condominiums and other issues that affect their pocketbooks, tenants organizations around the country are attempting to form a national renters lobby.

title: Future Events; Holiday Galas Galore
description: By PHYLLIS A. EHRLICH

title: Baseball's Boys of Winter
description: NEW ROCHELLE speak music fills the air along North Avenue and store windows of red and green bespeak the Yuletide season. But wait. Can that be the crack of ball meeting bat  that unmistakable sound of spring and summer?

title: Katherine Bryan Is Affianced to Carl Jenks
description: The engagement of Katherine Vera Bryan, daughter of Dr. Russell B. Bryan of Palo Alto, Calif., and Mrs. Francois Gravier of Colombo, Sri Lanka, to Carl Major Jenks, son of Dr. and Mrs. Major B. Jenks of Cleveland, has been announced.

title: Schools Struggle With Fuel Costs; Schools Facing FuelCost Rise
description: LAST year, the Mamaroneck school district paid 43 cents a gallon for oil to heat its schools. Last week it was paying 70 cents. In a couple of weeks, after the planned meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, it is likely to be 80 or 85 cents, according to John P. Fleming, the district's supervisor of buildings and grounds. And that's only a guess, he added.

title: PARIS KILLING LINKED TO IRAN POLICE AIDE; Lawyer Ties Slaying of the Shah's Nephew to a Trip by General
description: PARIS, Dec. 8, (Reuters)  The lawyer of the assassinated nephew of the deposed Shah of Iran alleged today that the secret service chief of Iran's revolutionary Government visited Paris only days before the murder.

title: 225,000 Miles in Jet, Lost Cat Is Returned
description: MELBOURNE, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) Sherry, a Siamese cat that spent 32 days in the hold of a Pan American World Airways jetliner, has been reunited with her owners.

title: Theater: Burrell']s Solitary Hessat the Entermedia; The Cast
description: In Hess, the onecharacter play that he wrote and is appearing in Wednesday through Sunday at the Entermedia Theater until next Sunday, Michael Burrell is walking a knife's edge. For the unreconstructed 86yearold Nazi  the lone remaining prisoner at Spandau  is shown in all his repellent characteristics, arrogant, spewing hate, blind, except for one brief moment, to the enormity of Nazi crimes or the destructive extent of the war, yet somehow also posing those questions that still trouble men of good will.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE; HANUKKAH PARTY
description: Today

title: Housing Crunch Plan Runs Into Opposition
description: WHITE PLAINS  HOUSING has become a survival issue, according to County Legislator Richard L. Brodsky. People who never thought they'd have to worry about finding a place to live will in the next decade unless something is done immediately.

title: Library's Jazz Series Keeps em Stompin
description: SHREWSBURY N MANY Sunday afternoons at the Monmouth County Library on Route 35, they move back the reading tables and put away the Quiet, Please signs.

title: Indians Reviving Area at Kent
description: IN 1967, when Irving Harris of Litchfield was elected chief of the Schagticoke Indians in Connecticut, his demoralized people were dispersed throughout the state. Ten years earlier the State Supreme Court had ruled against them on a claim for land adjacent to their 450acre reservation in Kent, which itself lacked fulltime residents and was poorly maintained.

title: Harvey Kopell, 60, Held Surgeon's Post for V.A.
description: Harvey Kopell, chief of orthopedic surgery at Castle Point Veteran's Hospital near Beacon, N.Y., died Friday in his home in Peekskill, N.Y. He was 60 years old.

title: Stage: Reflected GloryFrom the 30's; The Cast
description: Whenever she passes a mirror  any mirror  or sits at her dressing table, Muriel Flood takes a quick, sometimes lingering look at herself. She is always adjusting her emotions and measuring the effectiveness of her image. It is as if she is constantly watching herself over her shoulder. Off stage as well as on stage, she is often accused of acting. Muriel is the actressheroine of George Kelly's Reflected Glory, a role that was written for Tallulah Bankhead, who played it on Broadway in 1936.

title: 5 Indicted in Drug Conspiracy
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury indicted five Peruvian nationals yesterday on charges of conspiring to import and distribute nearly 20 pounds of cocaine with a street value of more than $10 million. Those named were . Frank Rogelio MartinezPerez, 37 years old; Carlos Enrique Babilonia, 29; Humberto Flores Babilonia, 32; Juan Raul LunaZevallos, 32, and Maria Luz GuedesLagomarsino, 35.

title: Trans World Buys a Boeing
description: One of the great dogfights in the fierce battle for airliner sales ended last week with the Boeing 767 downing the Airbus, its rival from Europe.

title: PAPERBACK TALK; PAPERBACK TALK
description: The movie tiein game. The book you can't put down is now the movie you can't miss! Exciting adventure based on a $40million spectacular film!

title: WHAT THEY ARE SAYING
description: Al Hrabosky, asked if he was worth the $5.9 million he will receive for pitching for the Atlanta Braves for the next five seasons: The most obvious answer is, No, you're not. But somebody's willing to pay it then yes, you are.

title: New Works in Midtown by an Old Hand
description: Although Edward Larrabee Barnes has had his offices here for three decades, he had never designed a new building for Manhattan until this year. But he is catching up in a hurry and in a big way.

title: Mexico Bets on Industry to Make the Most of Its Oil Boom
description: MEXICO CITY  Two years ago, in the quiet days of recession, Mexican officials spoke with trepidation of the boom that the country's new oil wealth would soon bring. The problem was not whether the economy would recover, but whether they could control it when it did.

title: MUSIC; Noteworthy Harvest Of Yuletide Cheer
description: THERE are still 16 days to go, but judging from the Connecticut arts schedule, you would think that Christmas had already arrived. In fact, I cannot recall a richer harvest of musical Yuletide cheer than you will find today, with at least a dozen choral concerts, a couple of Nutcrackers and even a big brass band. Some of these events were previewed in this column two weeks ago, others are listed in the calendar elsewhere in this section, so let me just dwell on a few programs that seem to hold special promise.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS; PRO BASKETBALL
description: The Knicks meet the Indiana Pacers Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. and the Boston Celtics Saturday at 8 P.M. at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks will honor Walt Frazier before the game with the Celtics. The Nets play the Knicks Friday at the Rutgers Athletic Center in Piscataway, N.J., at 8 P.M.

title: Pincay's Celebration Is $1,810 Premature; Six Mounts Listed Today
description: A solid gold emblem was presented yesterday to Laffit Pincay to mark his surpassing the $8 million mark in purses won in a single season. The champagne flowed, the television cameras whirred and flash bulbs popped. There was one thing wrong, though.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW; Masterful; Gardening By Atget
description: With European gardens as the subject, how can a photographer miss? At least when he (or she) works in black and white, and thus is not tempted by autumn leaves or spring flowers? Erica Lennard, a young American whose photographs of European gardens are on view at Sonnabend Gallery, 920 West Broadway, through Dec. 22, does not miss. Neither does Eugene Atget, the celebrated photographer early 20thcentury Paris, whose photographs of royal gardens in or near the French capital are on view at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 99th Street, through Jan. 6, 1980.

title: Nancy B. Elkind, Lawyer, Bride of Roger W. Hibbard 3d
description: Nancy B. Elkind, an associate with the Denver law firm of Arkin, McGloin & Davenport, and Roger W. Hibbard 3d, a student at the University of Denver College of Law, were married yesterday in the lobby of the Equitable Buildinn in Denver. Edward E. Prin gle, recently retired Chief Justice of the Colorado Supreme Court, performed the ceremony.

title: IRAN PLANS A PANEL FOR A TRIALOF U.S.; Foreign Aide Asserts International Body Will Review the Crimes by Washington Since '53
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 8  Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh announced plans today for an international panel to review the dossier of crimes by the U.S. Government in Iran since the Central Intelligence Agencybacked coup that overthrew the Nationalist Government of Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh and restored the nowdeposed Shah to the throne in 1953.

title: ANTIQUES; Something Old As a Yuletide Gift
description: LYNDHURST SHOULD you be wondering what to give the man in your life for Christmas, here is a list of suggestions from the world of antiques. Some of the items may have been sold by the time you reach the store, but many similar ones are still available in the various antiques shops throughout the state.

title: GARDENING; Care and Feeding of the Poinsettia
description: HAVE you noticed that poinsettias are much more rugged than they used to be? There once was a time when it was considered an achievement to be able to nurse one through the holiday season without having it drop all its leaves.

title: Dance: Ailey Company In Faison's Suite Otis
description: People started clapping and shouting about halfway through George Faison's Suite Otis on Friday at City Center, where the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is two weeks into its monthlong winter season. It looks as if the company has another signature piece in the Faison work, which is one of the most successful of the jazzrock suites now in vogue.

title: A Homemaker and Briton Win World Bowling Titles
description: MANILA, Dec. 8 (AP)  Lita De La Rosa of the Philippines and Gerry Bugden of Britain won the women's and men's titles today in the ninth World Bowling Championships.

title: Lisa Winton Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Winton of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Davenport Winton, to Daniel Hughes Callahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Callahan of Darien, Conn. Plans have been made for a wedding next September.

title: Timothy L. L. Davis to Wed Diana Radway in February
description: The engagement of Diana Radway, daughter of the Marchioness of Linlithgow of London and the late John S. Radway of New York, to Timothy Logan Bakewell Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Nathan Davis of Madrid and London, has been announced. A wedding is planned in February in London.

title: Paul B. Wishart Is Dead at 81 Former Honeywell inc. Chairman
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 8 (UPI)  Paul B. Wishart, former chairman of the board of directors of Honeywell Inc., died yesterday at his home at Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: TRENTON JOHN J. DEGNAN, the state Attorney General, is stirring up another political beehive, but thus far he has avoided being stung.
