But some experts believe that biomass, coupled with other energy sources, may at least tide the world over the energy famine that threatens the coming decades.

title: De Gustibus A Middle Eastern Cereal and Its Various Guises
description: Although I have dined on dishes made with bulghur (also spelled bulgur, bulghour and boolgur), the crackedwheat cereal that is essential to the cuisine of the Middle East, I had never been so thoroughly informed until a rash of correspondence arrived countering a column in which I had dismissed it as a transliteration of the Turkish word burghul.

title: Final to Miss Barker
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 9 (AP) Sue Barker of Britain took just 57 minutes to beat Roslyn Fairbank of South Africa, 60, 75, in the final of a $100,000 tennis tournament.

title: Sports Today
description: Oilers vs. Pittsburgh Steelers, at Houston (Television  Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio WCBS,9 P.M.)

title: Survey Finds Carter's Popularity Has Risen Sharply in Iran Crisis
description: Public approval of President Carter's performance in office has increased dramatically in the month since the United States Embassy in Teheran was seized and hostages held by militant students, according to a poll by the Gallup Organization.

title: Giants Fall
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9  Ottis Anderson ran left, and he ran right. He dodged some tacklers and floored others with forearms. And when he was finished today, he had the National Football League record for most yards gained in a season by a rookie running back, as well as a tie for the Cardinal record of most 100yard games in a career. And St. Louis had a 2920 victory.

title: Soviet Aide in East Berlin
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  First Deputy Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov left today on his first trip abroad since his appointment to the ruling Politburo last month. Mr. Tikhonov, 74 years old, is heading a delegation to East Berlin for talks on economic and scientific cooperation.

title: Cuevas Knocks Out Espada to Keep Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (AP)  Jose (Pipino) Cuevas of Mexico City knocked out Angel Espada of Puerto Rico at 1 minute 18 seconds of the 10th round last night to retain the World Boxing Association's welterweight championship after a rugged battle.

title: Iranian Says Hostages Are Safe and Observer Can. Visit the Embassy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9  Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, Iran's Foreign Minister, assured Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today that the American Embassy hostages were safe and could be visited by a neutral observer, a spokesman for the United Nations said.

title: Cabaret: Novella Nelson
description: OBSERVING the development of Novella Nelson as a, cabaret singer since she made her debut 11 years ago at the Village Vanguard has sometimes been fascinating. sometimes disconcerting.

title: Federal Loan Deadline Extended
description: MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 9 (AP)  The Small Business Administration has extended the filing deadline for disaster loan applications for Hurricane Frederic victims until next Jan. 13. The 30day extension of the previous deadline came at the request of Gov. Fob James. We're also responding to indications from hurricane victims that many may need additional time to evaluate property losses, said James D. Barksdale, district director of the agency.

title: Model Plane Injures 2 at Shea
description: Two spectators were injured during halftime of the JetsPatriots game at Shea Stadium yesterday when a radiocontrolled model airplane crashed into the stands.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  For the first time in five days, supplies of food and water were sent yesterday to more than 250,000 refugees in a huge makeshift encampment straddling the ThaiCambodian border, Bangkok newspapers reported today.

title: Carter Backers Envision A Vietnam for Kennedy
description: We'll try to make New York Kennedy's Vietnam, said Joel McCleary, President Carter's chief political worker in the state, explaining strategy in an area that is generally considered to be Kennedy country. even with Senator Edward M. Kennedy's organizational problems in New York.

title: INDIA IS COMBATING EFFECTS OF DROUGHT
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 9- By all accounts India is suffering from one of the worst droughts of the century.

title: BondPrice Dip Called a Trend
description: The credit markets, which had difficulty last week deciding which way to turn, ended the week with bond prices heading downward, and both traders and investors presumed the trend would continue this week.

title: New Israeli Outpost Under Way
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 9  Bulldozers began work today at the site for a new Israeli settlement on the occupied West Bank after a futile attempt by local Arab residents to disrupt the project.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON  In the last year the world oil price has nearly doubled - pushed up not so much by OPEC decision as by the pressure of demand. OPEC ministers, meeting next week in Venezuela, will raise the price again. And then the exporting countries, setting their production targets, will almost certainly announce that they are eoine to produce less in 1980.

title: Legislative Snags Peril Foreign Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 9  A significant cutback in lending activities in the third world by the World Bank and its sister institutions is threatened by a HouseSenate deadlock over foreign aid appropriations.

title: Official Entrepreneurs
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  A new kind of entrepreneurship, with a new kind of entrepreneur, is booming. The most aggressive risktakers are not found in corporate board rooms and executive suites; instead, they are in our town halls, city council chambers, state capitols, and Congressional offices. These entrepreneurs are elected officials who are taking risks for business with taxpayers dollars and with job and environmental conditions.

title: Pincay Exceeds $8 Million
description: Laffit Pincay had only one victory at Aqueduct yesterday, but it was one he wanted dearly. His winning ride aboard Raymond Z. in the fourth race of the program enabled him to become the first jockey to earn $8 million in purses in one season.

title: Amid Rioting in Zambia, Croquet as Usual
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 3  There remains in every former British colony a tight, sizable group of old colonialists who see a clear and present crisis as passing thing, something to which person of perspective adiusts temporaiily but nothing to be made too much of. So it went with the recent demonstrations against the British here.

title: Jody Mass, Teaching Assistant, Married to Eli Borochoff
description: Jody Mass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Mass of New York and Goldens Bridge, N.Y., was married last night to Eli Borochoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rachamim Borochoff of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Abraham Ginsberg performed the ceremony at the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Flushing, Queens.

title: Stars Turn Back Gems by 10892
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 9  The New York Stars stayed atop the Women's Basketball League's Eastern Division by scoring a 10892 victory over the New Jersey Gems tonight.

title: Heavy Week to Test Five Areas of Market
description: Interest rates in five areas of the credit markets will be tested this week as a heavy volume of corporate and local government financing is scheduled for sale. The Treasury has only its weekly bill auction, and no Federal agency financing is expected.

title: Sports World Specials
description: When Bert Sugar, an author of many books on sports, bought Ring Magazine and The Ring Record Book last summer, he declared his ambition was to make the record book as complete, thorough and accurate for boxing as The Baseball Encyclopedia, published by Macmillan, is for baseball. That's the greatest sports reference book in the world, said Sugar.

title: Union Leader in L.I.R.R. Strike
description: Edward Yule Jr., leader of the Long Island Rail Road's striking conductors and trainmen, likes to tell about the day in 1959 when he was held up.

title: Music: Vaughan Williams's Tudor
description: IT might seem odd that a major work by Ralph Vaughan Williams composed in 1936 would be receiving its first New York performance at this late date. But that was what was claimed for the New York Choral Society's account of Vaughan Williams's Five Tudor Portraits at Carnegie Hall Saturday night.

title: GOING OUT Gulde
description: SEE HOW THEY RUN Last Christmas over 60,000 children, their parents in tow, attended and tried out an industry assembly of batterypowered toys and games at the Union Carbide Building, Park Avenue and 97th Street. At the new holiday display. on view today through Dec. 22, the public is invited to sample some 500 items, among them wireless microphones that transmit voices over radios, a batterypowered Scrabble game, space and land vehicles with remotecontrol responses and an Incredible Hulk that collapses a stone wall on cue. Alarm clocks sound off to the voices of Mickey Mouse, Bugs Bunny, Raggedy Ann and the Sesame Street crew. There is even a game called Pothole, where you race your van over a moving belt of pavement hazards.

title: Official Ankara Changing Guard
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 9  A suave Turkish banker said ruefully the other day that he had been twiddling his thumbs in an honorary post in a government bank for two years but that he now hoped to get a managerial job because his party won the recent elections.

title: In West Bank, Nablus Mayor Is on Pedestal
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 9  Even when he is smiling broadly, as he was last week after his release from an Israeli prison, Bassam alShaka has the slightly worried face of a beleaguered grocer, his thin, neatly trimmed mustache twitching with every wellworn, uncompromising political clich:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: YoYo Ma, Cellist
description: THE Whoever and Friends title idea may be of recent invention, but it's already been so overused as to become hackneyed. But it is still emerging as a valuable way of satisfying the complementary needs of musicians and public for an ever greater and more varied fare of chamber music. Yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center began the latest in the ... and Friends configurations, this one built around YoYo Ma, the cellist of Parisian birth, Chinese ancestry and American residence. To judge from the really unusual excellence of the performances, this is a series worth seeking out.

title: Fouts Leads Rout of Saints
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9  Though the professional football playoffs are still to come, the strongest candidate for quarterback of the year if not player of the year is Dan Fouts of the San Diego Chargers. Fouts, whose Special to The New York Times countenance includes a thick black beard that makes him look fierce, displayed his considerable credentials today as the Chargers beat up on a weak defensive team, the New Orleans Saints, winning in the Superdome, 350.

title: AvantGarde: Ronald Jackson
description: RONALD SHANNON JACKSON and his group, the Decoding Society, who gave a concert Saturday night at Soundscape, 500 West 52d Street, are in the vanguard of an intriguing new musical fusion. Mr. Jackson and a number of other musicians are interestea in combining the improvisational freedom and harmonic density of contemporary jazz with dance rhythms and amplified instrumentation, and the results are going to be very interesting indeed.

title: 2 Golds for Thomas and Russian
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 9  Aleksandr Ditiatin of the Soviet Union and Kurt Thomas each won two gold medals tonight in a battle for supremacy in the individualevent finals of the world gymnastics championships, but Thomas and his United States teammates scored an important moral victory.

title: Books of The Times
description: WE'RE with the Soviet psychologists. In Central Asia in 1931. The psychologists are trying out some sylloeisms on Uzbek peasants. For inTHE MAKING OF MIND. A Personal Account of Soviet Psychology. Edited by Michael Cole and Sheila Cole. Introduction and Epilogue by Michael Cole. 234 pages. Harvard. $15.

title: Rangers Set Back Islanders By 54
description: After 54 minutes of confusion, controversial calls and the strange kind of hockey that characterizes the RangersIslanders rivalry, last night's game at Madison Square Garden turned on the execution of a simple centering pass durine a Dower play.

title: British Governor Faces Formidable Task in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Dec. 9  Lord Soames, the British politician and diplomat named last week as Governor of this rebel colony, will face host of problems in guiding it to legal indenendence under Mark rule.

title: Mideast Envoy Is Skeptical on Autonomy Deadline
description: CAIRO, Dec. 9  The Carter Administration's new special envoy to the Middle East, Sol M. Linowitz, said today that he doubted that Egypt and Israel could agree on a formula for Palestinian autonomy by the deadline of next May.

title: Sports Briefs
description: John Doyle, a St. John's University junior, rallied for a 300yard victory over Rejean Gauthier of Canada in a halfmarathon at Flushing MeadowsCorona Park yesterday.

title: Moscow Again Warns Washington Over Use Of Force in Iran Crisis
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Soviet newspaper Pravda said today that American hawks were pushing the Carter Administration toward dangerous adventurism in Iran, and warned that any military action there by the United States could have. grave. consequences It was the second time in four days that the Communist Party paper had sharply criticized American attitudes in the Iranian crisis. A commentary in Pravda on Wednesday accused Washington of having decided to intensify the crisis and of using crude military and political pressure.

title: Hostage's Family Lives in Hope and Uncertainty
description: KRAKOW, Mo., Dec. 9 - It was the Sickmans second family trip to Washington. In October, they left this town near St. Louis with their son Rodney Virgil Sidman, known as Rocky, to see the sights and celebrate his graduation from the Marine Corps guard school in nearby Quantico, Va.

title: Music: Premiere of Deak's Heidi, Part I
description: MOST people are under the impression that Richard Strauss carried program music to its farthest point with such wordless dramas as Don Quixote and Ein Heldenleben. But Jon Deak's Heidi, Part I of which was performed by the Westchester Conservatory Symphony Orchestra Saturday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, reaches farther.

title: Draw Is Criticized
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 (AP)  Most boxing experts here agreed today that the 15round draw in last night's world cruiserweight title match, between Mate Parlov of Yugoslavia and Marvin Camel of Missoula, Mont., was unjust and that the victory should have been awarded to Camel.

title: U.S. Studying Ways to Bolster Strength in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  President Carter has instructed his senior advisers to examine several alternatives for bolstering American military power in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf, including the establishment of a permanent military base in the region, Government officials said today.

title: ATTEMPT TO MOVE CHURCH BUILDING FAILS: A structure that was donated to the Pilgrim Missionary Baptist Church of Pine Bluff, Ark., was about to be moved by truck to a new site. . .
description: .. . when the building tilted and collapsed. A mover threatened by the collapse ran to safety, and no one was hurt.

title: Carter Says He Prays for Captors In Iran As Well as for Hostages
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)  President Carter said today that he prays for the Iranian militants as well as for the 50 American hostages they are holding in the American Embassy in Teheran.

title: D.&H. Granted A New Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The United States Railway Association has approved an additional $2 million loan to the Delaware and Hudson Railway, raising to $32 million the amount the Federal Government has lent to the debtridden carrier.

title: Chess:
description: Jan Timman, a 28yearold Dutch grandmaster, won the recent fifth Milan Vidmar Memorial Tournament in Bled and Portoroz, Yugoslavia, with an 119 score against a strong field. Grandmasters Bent Larsen of Denmark and Zoltan Ribli of Hungary shared second place with scores of 105.

title: In Beatty, Nev., She's One of a Kind
description: BEATI'Y, Nev., Dec. 9 (UPI)  On another night it might have been a fundraising event for local church or a needy family. But proceeds from the latest benefit dance go to Fran's place, the bordello just outside town. A fire on Nov. 20 nearly destroyed Fran's Star Ranch, about three miles north of town. To raise funds to rebuild it, the local Veterans of Foreign Wars post and its Women's Auxiliary held fire dance last night and raised more than $5,000.

title: ArafatQaddafi Disagreement Breaks Into the Open
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 9  A split between Yasir Arafat of the P.L.O. and the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, has broken into the open with the guerrilla organization appealing to Libya to end a siege of its office in Tripoli. A P.L.O. official also reportedly was expelled today by Libya.

title: Borg Dominates Connors Again
description: Associated Press

title: Cosmos Likely to Draft Ebert
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 9  Don Ebert, a junior from Southern Illinois, Edwardsville, who played in today's National Collegiate championship game here against Clemson, will probably be the first player selected, by the Cosmos, in the North American Soccer League draft tomorrow.

title: Dance: Chiang Ching Troupe in Varied Program
description: THE Chiang Ching Dance Company, formed in 1973 by Chiang Ching, a graduate of the Peking Academy of Dance who had settled in New York, offered a stimulating program of originality with works by several choreographers Saturday night at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse.

title: Brown Backs Challenger in San Francisco Mayor Race
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s endorsement of the challenger in Tuesday's mayoral race has injected another imponderable into an already close and bitter contest.

title: Miracle on 34th Street: Living Through Holiday
description: When you get 15 to 20 people waiting for you and breathing hard at you like now, it can get frantic, the frazzled saleswoman said, brushing back wisps of hair. But I've learned over the years that if you are a little jovial, they understand. Or else they can just go to the next register.

title: Graham Mourns Sheen As a Great Preacher
description: Upon hearing of the death of Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, the Rev. Billy Graham said that the death was a great loss to the nation and both the Catholic and Protestant Churches.

title: Islamic Center, in Rural Indiana, Feels Shock Waves of Iran Crisis
description: PLAINFIELD, Ind., Dec. 9 (AP) The sign greeting travelers along the rural road in central Indiana reads, The Islamic Center: the Muslim Student Association of the U.S. and Canada.

title: Coast Guard Assists Sunken Tug Leaking Diesel Oil in Jersey Inlet
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Coast Guard tried today to plug a fuel , leak from a tug that ran aground and sank with two other vessels near the Absecon Inlet jetty.

title: 7,000 Will Face Trial in Nicaragua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 9 (AP) About 7,000 people accused by the new Government here of war crimes and collaboration with the Somoza regime are facing trials that could start as early as this week.

title: OPTIMISM IS FADING FOR REAGAN IN IOWA
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 7  In the past six weeks the campaign leaders for Ronald Reagan in this pivotal Middle Western state have carefully pulled back from their earlier optimism and toned down forecasts of wide victory in the Iowa Republican caucuses on Jan. 21.

title: REUNITING OF NATION IS DREAM OF KOREANS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 9  We sometimes find North Korean leaflets up here, said a South Korean hiker, looking down from the granite mountains 2,000 feet above Seoul. No one knows whether they are dropped from balloons or by hand.

title: Musical Oh, Johnny! At Playhouse on 18th St.
description: Oh, Johnny! , a new musical set during World War II, is at the playhouse at 436 West 18th Street.

title: Recruiters Say Crisis in Iran Is Improving Morale
description: The Iranian crisis appears to be improving morale  if not business in every region for the nation's military recruiters. It feels a little better to be in uniform, Maj. Lawrence Swank, the Army's top recruitment officer at Fort Meade, Md., said last week.

title: RHODESIA JETS RAID REBEL BASES AGAIN
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  Jets of the Zimbabwe Rhodesian Air Force attacked Patriotic Front guerrilla bases in Mozambique and Zambia today, military headquarters said.

title: Market Place
description: THE International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the nation's 11thlargest industrial corporation, has been out of favor on Wall Street for several years.

title: Eddie and Mal, But Mostly Fitz
description: THREE names warmly remembered made the obituary pages within the space of two days. On Thursday Dr. Mal Stevens, the Yale halfback who coached the Yale, New York University and Brooklyn Dodgers football teams, died in the Bronx at 79. The next day Eddie Gottlieb, founding father of professional basketball in Philadelphia, checked out by way of Temple University Hospital. He was 81. The same edition that told of Eddie's passing reported that Fred Fitzsimmons had suffered a fatal heart attack several weeks ago in Yucca Valley, Calif. Fitz was 78, baseball age.

title: Dialogue on Farm Policy Bringing Out Complaints
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Dec. 7 When more than 800 farmers crowd into overheated auditoriums and sit for eight hours listening to their colleagues talk to the Secretary of Agriculture about this country's farm policy, they hear far more complaints about what is wrong with than suggestions on how it could be improved.

title: Egypt's Oil Sales Steadily Growing
description: CAIRO, Dec. 9  Egypt is riding the boom of escalating oil prices by selling a steady if modest amount of its output in the world's spot oil market.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: I'm not a saint, Seymour L. Butan concedes. It is more important in life to be a man than a gentleman. Promoters are a dying breed. We make things move, we like to build.

title: Study Seeks Halt of Dual Benefits From Civil Service and the Military
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  A study by the General Accounting Office has recommended that Congress eliminate legislative loopholes that allow dual benefits for former military people who later retire from civilian jobs in the Federal Government.

title: Emerson Electric's Profit Push
description: ST. LOUIS  As they do every three months, the chiefs of the 40 farflung divisions of the Emerson Electric Company assembled here recently for corporate judgment. This, in essence, is what they were told:

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON AMERICAN sources report that the British are angry about Washington's efforts to freeze Iranian assets in the London branches of American hanks. They add that G. William Miller, Secretary of the Treasury, and Sir Geoffrey Howe, Chancellor of the Exchequer, have already had some harsh words on the subject.

title: American Symphony Offers New Siegmeister
description: ALL three works that Sergiu Comissiona conducted with the American Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall had points of interest, even if the concert as a whole left slightly lukewarm impression. First, Mr. Comissiona presided over the New York premiere of Elie Siegmeister's Five Fantasies of the Theater, composed in 196667 and presenting musical portraits of five 20thcentury playwrights: Beckett, Ionesco, Brecht, Pirandello and O'Casey.

title: FIGHTING BREAKS OUT FOR TABRIZ STATION; 3 REPORTED KILLED
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 9  Students and militiamen loyal to the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini recaptured the radiotelevision station here today from dissident Azerbaijani Turks, but they were driven out again tonight in gun battle that reportedly left three people dead and 60 iniured.

title: Radio
description: 7 A.M.Noon, WNYCFM: Morning Pro Musics. Beethoven's Birthday Bash, Bach.

title: Commodities
description: NO commodity market analyst is ever at a loss to explain a market's behavior after the fact; rare is the one, however, who can predict a price trend for a year ahead with accuracy.

title: Robert Hocq, Cartier Executive, Is Killed by Automobile in Paris
description: Robert Hocq, chairman of the board of CartierParis and a hero of the French underground during World War II, died Saturday in Paris after being struck by an auto while crossing a thoroughfare near his office in the Place Vendome. He was 60 years old.

title: Cuba Unhappy In Establishing A U.N. Record
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 After 58 secret ballots, the 152 members of the General Assembly have set a new record, failing to give either Cuba or Colombia the necessary twothirds maiority vote to to fill a seat on the Security Council.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  A damned outrage, said a former member of the Supreme Court.

title: Stability and Prosperity Pledged by Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that the Indian economy was in shambles and declared that her CongressI Party would lead the country to economic stability and prosperity.

title: CARTER STAFF KEEPS WATCH ON KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  Senator Edward M. Kennedy had scarcely finished his speech last week assailing President Carter's farm policies in Iowa when Agriculture Department officials were on the phone to The Des Moines Register with rebuttal.

title: Soviet Tells of Infant Prodigy
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Moscow radio says a Leningrad infant prodigy was speaking at the age of months, knew the alphabet at 12 months and was reading 2 months later. Taras Chernienko is now 3, the radio said, and can add and subtract and point out various countries, rivers and seas on a globe.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: U.S. Ponders Conflicting Signals From Iranian Official
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh said today that Iran intended to go ahead with an investigation by outstanding international figures into alleged United States wrongdoing in Iranian affairs and that he doubted any of the 50 American hostages could be released beforehand.

title: 2 Nonpolitical Women Battle Atomic Plant License
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 9 (AP) Holly Keck just wants to get back to farming, raising her children and milking her goats. Patricia Smith misses spending time with her daughters and competing in golf tournaments.

title: Special Phone Numbers In Use During Walkout
description: Following are emergency telephone information services set up in the Long Island Rail Road strike:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many major league clubs has Dave Ho w Kingman played for? How many home runs has he hit?

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: General Motors is unusually gloomy about the auto industry's prospects in 1980. It forecast a mild downturn for the overall economy for most of next year and cut its projected 1979 total of domestic and foreign car and truck sales to 14.1 million units, or 1.4 million below yearearlier estimates. It predicted the 1980 sales would about equal the 1979 level. [Dl.]

title: Chrysler Selling Boat Company
description: DETROIT, Dec. 9 (AP) - Six executives of the Chrysler Corporation's boatmanufacturing subsidiary will buy it, the parent company announced during the weekend. The sales price was not disclosed.

title: Piers Paul Read Asks, What Do I Write Now?
description: Camera Press

title: Julie Weiss Bride Of Thomas J. Press
description: The chapel of Temple EmanuE1 in New York City was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Julie Susan Weiss, daughter of Margot Haberman Lance of New York and Alan Richard Weiss of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Thomas Jay Press, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving E. Press, also of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Richard S. Chapin.

title: News Summary
description: Ayatollah Khomeini's followers retook Iran's radio and television station in Tabriz from dissident Azerbaijani Turks who had seized it on Thursday, but were driven out again in a battle that reportedly left three people dead and 60 injured. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Weill s Rise and Fall the City of Mahap:nny, 8.

title: Grain for Russia
description: WASHINGTON  The Carter Administration has approved largescale grain sales to the Soviet Union without clearly understanding how they will affect our economic and foreignpolicy interests.

title: TV: A Dark Portrait Of the Other Mark Twain
description: WITH Dan O'Herlihy in the title role, Mark Twain: Beneath the Laughter seems to be designed as an antidote to the folksyhumorist image popularized in Hal Holbrook's oneman stage show. The point now beine emphasized is that Twain, especially in his later years, was a profound cynic, convinced that the man race is a race of cowards. While he was indeed a professional humorist for 40 years, he finally confessed that the humor was only a fragrance, a decoration.

title: Jazz: Lester Bowie Leads a Quintet
description: LESTER BOWIE has made several albums of his own during the last few years, and they have defined a personal territory somewhat different from that of the Art Ensemble of Chicago, his principal musical association since the mid60's.

title: G.A.O. Says Tips Over Hot Line Are Curbing Government Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)  Since last January, when a tollfree Federal fraud hot line was set up, Americans have informed on more than 7,100 of their coworkers and neighbors.

title: Cypriot Leader Arrives in Greece
description: ATHENS, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus arrived in Athens today for talks with Greek leaders. He is expected to meet Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis tomorrow.

title: Eichelberger Duo Wins Golf
description: LARGO, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP)  Dave Eichelberger and Murle Breer birdied their way back from an overpar start to a 20under 268 finish today and a onestroke victory in the Mixed Teams Rolf tournament.

title: Dolphins, Rams Win Division Titles
description: Two division championships were clinched, but the four others were still in question, after yesterday's games in the National Football League.

title: Carroll Impresses Olympic Coach
description: Dave Gavitt is constantly on the go, being the coach of the United States Olympic basketball team. During the summer, he scouted European teams. Early in the present college season he went to Texas to watch the touring Soviet Union team. On Dec. 1 he was in New York to watch the Knicks play at Madison Square Garden.

title: President Choi's Chance in Korea
description: Has the chill of repression already snuffed out this autumn's Seoul spring? The authoritarian spirit the slain Park Chung Hee seems to carry on in the recent actions of some of his heirs. Their behavior adds weight to the case for urgent constitutional reform and early elections. What chance remains for a more open political system depends on whether the newly chosen President, Choi Kyu Hah, can regain the momentum of a oncepromising transition process.

title: 4 L.I. Students Are Held In Christmas Tree Theft
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Dec. 9 (AP) The police said an attempt to conceal evidence did not work early today for four students who allegedly stole a decorated Christmas tree and then hid it from a policeman who had to leave them unguarded for a few minutes.

title: Southern Illinois, Edwardsville, Wins N.C.A.A. Soccer Final, 32
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec.9  Matt Malloy scored all three goals to give Southern Ilinois, Edwardsville, its first Division I National Collegiate soccer title today with a 32 victory over Clemson.

title: Steps to Aid Rail Riders In Walkout
description: Following are emergency measures announced by officials in New York City and on Long Island to help move commuters in and out of the city during the Long Island Rail Road strike.

title: New Zealand Holds Soviet Ship
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  A Soviet trawler has been detained by a New Zealand Navy frigate and is due to arrive in Wellington tomorrow. M. L. Cameron, head of the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, said the trawler was held southeast of New Zealand yesterday but gave no details.

title: Yeshiva U. Opens a Campaign to Raise $100 Million
description: Yeshiva University, which has grown into a fourcampus institution with 7,000 students since its start as a Lower East Side elementary day school, announced a $100 million fundraising campaign yesterday to lead into its 100th anniversary in 1986. The sixyear effort is to introduce and intensify programs.

title: Critic's Notebook: Art in a City of Angels
description: LOS ANGELES THINGS had better work here, Joan Didion once said of California, because here, beneath that immense bleak sky, is where we run out of continent.

title: The Eagles Aren't Sitting Ducks Anymore
description: PHILADELPHIA AN icy December wind stabs at the crowd, but the 66,128 fans in Veterans Stadium don't feel the cold. They are staying to the end, savoring their team's most onesided success in 26 years.

title: Building Evacuated in a Smoky Fire
description: As firemen battled a blaze eight stories above, a tenant of the building at 331 East 29th Street in Manhattan cuddled the sole possession she was able to take from her apartment. The Fire Department reported no injuries; the cause of the fire was not immediately apparent.

title: Trial's Spectators Reflect Crown Heights Tensions
description: They come to bear witness that justice will be done  the Hasidic Jews with beards, skullcaps and dark overcoats, and the members of the Black United Front in dress ranging from sports clothes to dungarees.

title: Takeoff Aborted to Avert Crash
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (AP)  The takeoff of a Hughes Airwest DC9 was aborted when an American Airlines Boeing 707 carrying 48 passengers taxied onto the same runway at Los Angeles International Airport, the Federal Aviation Administration said today. The pilot of the DC9 was warned by the control tower to abort the takeoff just before noon yesterday when an air controller noticed that the American jet had inadvertently taxied onto the runway, the aviation agency said.

title: Matthews Takes Honolulu Marathon
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 9 (AP)  Dean Matthews, a 21yearold Clemson University student, won today's running of the Honolulu marathon in record time, crossing the Waikiki finish line after 2 hours 16 minutes 11 seconds. The previous course record, set last year by Don Ka rdong, was 2:17:04.

title: Music: St. Nicholas Play
description: THE Play of St. Nicholas, which received its premiere performances Thursday through yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine  or, more precisely, its premiere modern performances  is a 12thcentury liturgical drama that has been drawn from the Fleury Playbook, the source of The Play of Daniel and The Play of Herod. the modem version is by Frederick Renz's Ensemble for Early Music, and has a better claim to become a Christmas institution than the other two, since the fourthcentury Bishop of Myra was the prototype of Santa Claus.

title: China Reports 4 New Coalfields
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  Chinese geologists have discovered four coalfields with estimated reserves of more than four billion tons in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region in northwestern China, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: Ending of CutRate L.I.R.R. Fares Is Termed a Target of the M.T.A.
description: A state legislator, a consumer advocate and a leader of a group of train commuters said yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority might end cutrate fare programs on the Long Island Rail Road in an attempt to reduce its deficit.

title: Advertising
description: ALLAN MORRELL, who began Youth Beat as a weekly newspaper supplement in January 1978 and suspended publication three and a half months later, has drastically altered the concept and is planning for a rebirth Jan. 7. It is part of what he calls The Continuing Saga of One Man's Lonely Fight To Be An Important Publisher.

title: Trenton Police Report Few Leads In Murder of Jersey Society Figure
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9  Residents of the historic Mill Hill neighborhood here expressed shock today at the torturemurder Friday of Emma Jane Stockton, a 37yearold woman from a prominent New Jersey family. Police officials assigned about 20 detectives, nearly the entire division. to the case.

title: Patricia A. Weill Wed to T.G. Eaton
description: The Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in Manhattan was the setting last evening for the marriage of Patricia Anne Weill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy A. Weill of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Thomas George Eaton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Eaton of New York and Gallatin, N.Y. Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein, the senior rabbi, and the Rev. A. Lopes Cardozo officiated.

title: TheaterCabaret: Spoof Of BrechtWeill Musicals
description: OUT of the Yale Cabaret has come a parody of the Brecht/ Weill musicals called  why not?  Dreck / Vile and subtitled The Opera Bert and Kurt Never Wrote. Played out on the tiny stage of the Chelsea Encore Cabaret, 407 West 93d Street, over the weekend (it will be repeated next Friday and Saturday evenings), the 45minute skit follows Bert Dreck and his blond wife, Helena Wiggle; Kurt Vile and his blackhaired wife, Alotta, and a narrator, who plays a cast bordering on thousands (customs agent, farmer, policeman, theater owner) on a trek from Berlin to New York to Los Angeles with the antithetical purposes of founding their own theater and making money.

title: Estates and Trust Funds Help Neediest as Appeal Begins
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened its 68th annual appeal yesterday with $625,509.76 already donated by estates, trust funds and individual contributors.

title: Quakes Jolt Yugoslav Region
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  Two earthquakes jolted a mountainous region 110 miles south of here today, but there were no reports of casualties or damage, officials said.

title: Matt Bahr, the Smallest Steeler
description: EVEN the name of the team connotes toughness and bigness  the Pittsburgh Steelers, football players forged in flaming furnaces. Their success enhances the image. As the only team to have won three Super Bowl games, the Steelers reign as the National Football League champions. And except for Lynn Swann, the gazelle at wide receiver, most of their celebrated players project size and strength  Terry Bradshaw, the blond and brawny quarterback; Franco Harris, the dancing bear at fullback; Mean Joe Greene, the massive defensive tackle, and Jack Lambert, the middle linebacker with the wild look. Even their uniforms add to the aura of intimidation. With their black jerseys and black helmets, the Steelers resemble a motorcycle gang with shoulder pads.

title: Outlook Dampened by Loss to Cards
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 10  As other players trudged into the locker room today to begin their final week of the long National Football League season. one Giant starter carried two cotton swabs over to another. Here, he said, offering the swabs, put these in your ears. Now ask me why.

title: Genstar's Flintkote Stake
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  Genstar Ltd. said its Dorster Inc. subsidiary now owned about 80.6 percent of the Flintkote Company's Outstanding common stock. Genstar said the holding consisted of the 1.4 million shares held before the subsidiary's offer to pay 155 apiece for Flintkote common and the shares tendered in response to that offer, about 61.4 percent of those outstanding.

title: Dorothy Gardiner, 85, Writer of Historical And Mystery Novels
description: Dorothy Gardiner, a writer of historical novels and mysteries who was also a historian of the West, died last Tuesday at the Presbyterian Home in Buffalo. She was 85 years old and had formerly lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Mrs. Murphy Quits Labor Board, Rejecting Interim Appointment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  Betty Southard Murphy, one of two Republicans on the fivemember National Labor Relations Board, announced today that she was resigning.

title: Senate Freshman Class Doesn't Defer to Anyone
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Although he has been in office less than a year, Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, last week defeated one of the most powerful men in the Senate and broke a small filibuster to win a $22.5 billion increase in the Senate's proposal for a windfall profits tax on the oil industry.

title: City Ballet: A Debut As Cavalier
description: CILDREN may think of the New York City Ballet's magical production of The Nutcracker in terms of its special effects or fairytale characters. But for balletomanes, Nutcracker season means an unparalleled chance to see debut after debut as the company's younger dancers try the same new roles.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, Dec. 10 (AP)  In what a Federal judge termed an incredible error by the State Department, a defendant in drug smuggling trial has vanished from Caribbean island, the authorities disclosed today.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: John J. Weisberger, a newspaper reporter, died yesterday at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan of cancer. He was 80 years old.

title: Carter Names Price Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) President Carter appointed six members to a Price Advisory Committee, the counterpart to the 18member Pay Advisory Committee that has the lob of recommending new wage standards for the second year of the Administration's wageprice guidelines. The members are:

title: PoliceCaused Deaths Held Underestimated
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)  A New York criminologist contends that the actual number of citizens killed by the police each year could be underestimated by 50 percent or perhaps even more.

title: U.S. Counseled to Make Permanent Its Human Rights Drive Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Concern for the human rights of people in other countries should be an important and permanent aspect of the conduct of United States foreign policy, a panel of the United Nations Association of the United States said today.

title: BLHonda Pact Held Near
description: TOKYO, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  BL Ltd., the British auto maker, and the Honda Motor Company will sign an agreement in Tokyo before Christmas to produce Japanesedesigned small cars in Britain under license, industry sources said today. Honda declined to comment, but the sources said the two companies had agreed to produce four versions of a new model developed by Honda at BL factories from mid1981.

title: RCA LOSES CONTACT WITH NEW SATELLITE
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP)  The RCA Corporation lost contact with a new communications satellite today when technicians on earth sent command to fire a small engine to put the $20 million craft into permanent orbit.

title: Load of Nuclear Waste Crashes
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Dec. 10 (AP) cargo of lowlevel radioactive waste from the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania continued on its way today after the crash of the tractortrailer rig carrying the waste, the authorities said. Rick Leavell, the Missoula County Civil Defense director, said the cargo apparently remained intact when the rig slid on ice and hit an abandoned car, and there was no radiation danger. He said the cargo of extremely lowlevel waste material was bound for the radioactive materials dump on the Federal Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State.

title: MEMBERS OF PHILADELPHIA RADICAL GROUP GO ON TRIAL
description: An unidentified woman member of Move, left, a communal group whose headquarters was disbanded by Philadelphia police 16 months ago, being taken to court yesterday. Nine members faced charges of killing a police officer during their eviction, but trial was adjourned when courtappointed defense lawyers did not appear. Proceedings have been delayed for 11 months by hearings.

title: Science Watch
description: As if preparing for a concert was not nervewracking enough, the prolonged practice it demands of a professional violin or viola player can result in a swollen discolored lump on the neck that the musician may mistake for cancer. According to a report in the December issue of the Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology, the lump is caused by pressure of the base of the instrument against the neck. Normally, the player's arm supports the instrument, but the arm may tire during the lengthy practice sessions before a concert, allowing the instrument to rest against the neck.

title: Tenants Said to Lose U.S. Refund
description: Representative Leo C. Zeferetti of Brooklyn said yesterday that thousands of tenants in federally financed housing projects in New York City might not receive their share of $60 million in rent refunds because United States officials had failed to supervise properly the distribution of refund applications.

title: 3 Found Dead on Fishing Craft
description: PRINCE RUPERT, British Columbia, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  Three bodies were found today on a 30foot fishing boat off the Alaskan coast about 50 miles north of here and seven more people, some of them children_ were feared dead. The heavily damaged Salinta, reported missing Friday, was located by a Canadian Forces helicopter. The craft had had seven children aboard, aged 3 to 14.

title: Carr and Lanier Fined $1,500 Each by N.B.A.
description: M.L. Carr of the Boston Celtics and Bob Lanier of the Detroit Pistons have been fined $1,500 apiece for separate incidents in recent National Basketball Association games.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1979

title: Rail Negotiations Set for Tomorrow
description: The National Mediation Board arranged yesterday for negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and its 17 unions to resume bargaining tomorrow in the strike that shut the rail line at 12:01 A.M. Saturday.

title: JAZZ DEFEAT WARRIORS:
description: Associated Press

title: Books of TheTimes
description: W. H. AUDEN insisted that he wanted no biography of him written, and urged his friends to destroy his letters. It was a futile wish, of course, and one that he himself would have been sorry to see obeyed. For all his professed disdain of such endeavors, Auden was an inveterate literary gossip. He reviewed biographies, memoirs and collections of letters with illconcealed enthusiasm, and his poetry was no less anecdotal than his criticism; Letter to Lord Byron, published when he was 29, gave a great many particulars about his own background and character. Toward the end of his life, he became more candid still, discoursing in plain language on the intimate details of his life. For Auden, recalled the pianist Charles Rosen in a memorial volume of tributes, the distinction between public and private was a serious game in which he decided all the rules.

title: Got a Big Date? Send a Big Flower
description: Eric Appel is an artist and a designer who used to build theater props to earn a living. One day, about a year ago, somebody asked him to make a very large calla lily.

title: 30 More Youngsters From Africa Arrive in Havana for Instruction
description: HAVANA, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  Thirty children from GuineaBissau arrived in Cuba today for schooling, bringing to 74 the number from that African country being educated on the Isle of Youth, 100 miles south of Havana.

title: U.S. Expresses Its Regret To Cuba Over Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  The United States expressed deep regret today over a bombing last Friday at the Cuban Mission to the United Nations.

title: 11 Killed in India Truck Plunge
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  At least 11 people were killed and 31 injured when a truck plunged into a river near Sambalpur in India's eastern Orissa State, the Press Trust of India reported, today. The news agency said the truck was taking employees of a local mine and their relatives to a picnic.

title: Team Aims at .500 and 1980 Season
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 10  Suddenly a second season has emerged for the Jets, who are cramming it into their final week.

title: Copenhagen Statue Vandalized
description: COPENHAGEN, Dec. 10 (Reuters) The famous statue of the Little Mermaid on Copenhagen's harbor waterfront was covered with white paint last night, the nolice said The statue. which represents the heroine of a Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale, has been daubed with paint twice before in the last 10 years. The police were seeking three youths in connection with the vandalism.

title: Summary of Strike Services
description: After leaving their cars in the parking lot at Roosevelt Raceway yesterday morning, commuters waited on a long line to board buses for Manhattan.

title: Medical School Applicants Face Demanding Route
description: Jed Stern was an A student at Yale. He presented excellent recommendations from his teachers and impressive summerwork credentials.

title: The Explosion in the Moslem World: A Roundtable on Islam
description: First came the seizure of the Ameri can Embassy in Teheran by followers of a religious leader who proclaimed that the struggle between Iran and the United States was one between Islam and blasphemy. Then Pakistani youths, described like those in Iran as militant Islamic students, burned the American Embassy in Islamabad in the mistaken belief that the United States had sponsored an attack on the holiest of Moslem shrines, in Mecca.

title: Opera: New Group's Elixir of Love
description: NEW YORK is full of plucky little groups that stage opera on a shoestring, giving young professional singers an opportunity to perform before an audience. One of the most recent arrivals is the Opera Ensemble of New York, which evolved this year out of the OperainProgress Workshop that Ruth Bierhoff founded in 1977. The Ensemble's first production, Donizetti's The Elixir of Love, is being presented at the Church of the Holy Trinity on East 88th Street, and remaining performances are scheduled for Friday and Sunday.

title: About New York
description: For those who remember when the public library was a place of books, books that exuded a rich and musty bouquet of preserved words, there may be mixed feelings about the expansion of the library into a community center, with films and tapes and electronic appurtenances. Yet libraries always served the community and the multiplication of their services is probably of piece with what is going on in neighborhoods.

title: Turks Back Missile Plan
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec.10  The Turkish Government has indicated that it supports the North Atlantic Treaty Organization plan to station advanced nuclear missiles in Europe but warned that this must not detract from the modernization of conventional forces.

title: U.S. Auditors Question Chicago School Outlays
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  Federal auditors said today that the financially troubled Chicago school system had misused or overclaimed more than $3 million in Government funds and recommended that the money be returned.

title: Ohio State Conquers West Virginia, 7255
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Dec. 10 (AP)  Jim Smith scored 17 points tonight as Ohio State defeated West Virginia, 7255, in a college basketball game that produced 49 fouls.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The leader of Libya set aside past threats against America, saying he wants to improve relations between the United States and the oil exporter. We wish to intensify our dialogue with the United States, Muammar elQaddafi said in an interview. He also said expected President Carter to win reelection. [Page A1.]

title: 2 Directors Leave American Express
description: The American Express Company announced today the resignations of two of its directors, apparently clearing the way for the company to go ahead with its proposed $175 million purchase of a 50 percent stake in a cable television subsidiary of Warner Communications.

title: Business Records
description: Petition Filed by:

title: Minimum NewOil Tax Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) Senate Democrats, seeking to increase the windfall profits tax substantially, today proposed a minimum tax on newly discovered oil and on crude that is difficult and costly to recover.

title: ENVOY OF TEHERAN IN TABRIZ FOR TALKS
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 10  A leading member of Iran's ruling Revolutionary Council arrived here today to begin negotiations on ending a challenge to the central Government in Teheran by ethnic Turks in the Azerbaijani region.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Verdl's Aida, 8.

title: Transcript of Televised Interview With Marine Guard Held Hostage in U.S. Embassy
description: Following is the transcript of an NBCTV interview with Cpl. William Gallegos, a marine held captive at the United States Embassy in Teheran, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Proxmire: Provocative Antagonist
description: WASHINGTON PROFESSOR Sherry Ortner was high in a remote Himalayan village, presumably wrapped in her United States Governmentbought Roosedown parka, when word came by mail some months ago that something was amiss with her Fedeal research grant. A letter from the National Science Foundation alerted her that Senator William Proxmire was asking impertinent questions about her $39,660 grant from the agency to study the relationship between mountaineering and the changing practice of Buddhist religion among the Sherpas of Nepal.

title: Race at Watkins Glen Teetering
description: PARIS, Dec. 10 (AP)  The United States Grand Prix East, at Watkins Glen, N.Y., faces cancellation or probation Thursday at a meeting of the International Auto Sports Federation.

title: Neurologist Says Clasen Had Concussion in Ninth
description: A neurologist who specializes in head injuries told a state investigating committee yesterday that it was clear to him from the videotape of Willie Classen's fatal bout last month that the boxer suffered a concussion a round before the knockout punches that killed him.

title: 9 Americans Arrested in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  Nine American citizens have been arrested here on suspicion of fraud and violating Colombian immigration laws, the Administrative Security Department said today.

title: Dance: Miss de Lavallade In Portrait of Billie
description: DON'T miss Carmen de Lavallade tomorrow in Portrait of Billie when this fabulous danceractress makes another guest appearance with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the City Center.

title: R.A.F. Pilot Killed in Crash
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  One pilot was killed and a second seriously injured today when two Royal Air Force Jaguar fighter aircraft crashed in Aberdeenshire, Scotland, while on a lowflying training exercise. A ministry spokesman could not confirm reports quoting witnesses that the planes collided in midair.

title: In Iran Crisis, Patriotism Became Important Again
description: KETTERING, Ohio, Dec. 8  Jake Schumacher was a child when the United States entered World War II. He remembers the grownups talking of little else and keeping their ears riveted to radios for every snippet of information.

title: Notes on People
description: J. K. Rainey, an Atlanta tire dealer, has attracted a lot of attention by erecting a huge billboard atop his store, warning Atlantans and visitors to use extreme caution in the city, because the police are underpaid, undermanned and underequipped.

title: Taxes
description: HOMEOWNERS who want to sell their houses and, in these moneytight times, are reluctantly forced to act as lenders because potential buyers cannot get mortgages, may reap a tax benefit by allowing purchasers to pay in installmpnrc.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Thick layered overcast stretchs from the upper lake region to the northern Rockies and low overcast is scattered from the Ohio and Missouri Valleys to Texas. High thin clouds are visible as streaks from the Northern Plains States to the Sierra Nevada and broken shower clouds are visible In the Pacific Northwest.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY. DECEMBER 10. 1979

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Jazz: Harlow and Combo
description: THE pianist Larry Harlow, who's best known as the leader of a successful Latin dance orchestra and a member of the Fania All Stars, led a small combo at the jazz club Fat Tuesday's over the weekend.

title: L.I.R.R. Strike at a Glance
description: Following are the issues and other details on the strike by the United Transportation Union against the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Afghan Guerrilla Says Soviet Has Greatly Expanded Adviser Forces
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 10  A spokesman for Islamic guerrilla groups fighting troops of the Marxist Government in Afghanistan said today that the number of Soviet troops and advisers there had jumped to 25,000 and that in the 19 months of war 250.000 oeoole had been killed.

title: JAMES HUNT JR. DIES; DEPUTY C.I.A. CHIEF
description: James Ramsay Hunt Jr., a senior operations and counterintelligence officer of the Central Intelligence Agency in Paric and Washington for 23 years. died of cancer last Saturday at the Doctor's Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. Mr. Hunt, who was 70 years old, had lived in Florida in the winter months since his retirement from the C.I.A. 10 years ago.

title: Letters;
description: To the Editor: Although the year of George Orwell's message is scarce four years away, why is it that I feel myself a hostage in the events surrounding the Shah's wanderings and my country's marching with a unanimous voice? Even Senator Kennedy's criticism of the former ruler of Iran is drowned in a chorus of denunciation from all sides.

title: Despite Problems, Solar Cell Advances
description: AS a way of unlocking the sun's energy, solar cells that generate electricity are usually expensive, sometimes inefficient and often extraordinarily airocuit to manufacture. The good news is they could revolutionize the way we receive our energy, if not the price we pay for it.

title: Miriam E. Girard, Aide For G.O.P. in State, 62
description: Miriam Eaton Girard, who was active in the New York State Republican Party for many years, died yesterday in her home in Manhattan. She was 62 years old.

title: Miss Connelly to Leave City Post and Rejoin Garth.
description: Maureen R. Connelly, Mayor Koch's press secretary for two years and one of his most important advisers, announced yesterday that she would leave the city administration at the end of January.

title: Partisan Review Opens Its Action Acainst Rutzers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 10 A long feud between Rutgers University and the Partisan Review over ownership of the magazine's archives reached open court today, with the trying of a lawsuit Special to The New York Times by William Phillips, the journal's cofounder and editor, to regain possession of the papers from the university library.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Harpsichord Sonata No. 3, Arne; Moulinet Polka, Strauss; Hungarian Rhapsody No. 15, Liszt; Excerpt from LesMerits de la Tour Eiffel, Poulenc.

title: Head of Parley on Aging Named
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  President Carter announced today that Sadie Alexander of Philadelphia, the nation's first black woman to earn a doctorate of laws, will be chairman of the 1981 White House Conference on Aging. Dr. Alexander, who is 81 years old, plans to retire from her law firm on Dec. 31 after 52 years of practice.

title: Rosenbloom to Be Named
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10  Steve Rosenbloom will be named general manager of the New Orleans Saints this week, it has been learned. John W. Mecom Jr., the Saints majority owner, will appoint Rosenbloom to head the football operations, succeeding Eddie Jones, who will take another position in the Mecom oil and real estate businesses.

title: New Psychiatric Definitions Expected to Affect Therapy
description: PSYCHIATRISTS, sometimes accused of making diagnoses by intuition or by even less systematic criteria, will soon release detailed definitions for schizophrenia, depression, phobia, mania and most other mental disorders.

title: IN THE NATION Idea Man From Illinois
description: The Democrats nominated George Who? for President in 1972, and elected Jimmy Who? in 1976. Does that make conceivable that the Republicans might nominate John Who? in 1980?

title: Compromise Is Devised On Chrysler Aid Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Proponents of Federal loan guarantees for the failing Chrysler Corporation devised a new bill today designed to reconcile major differences between the House and Senate versions of the Chrysler assistance package.

title: Perseverance Counted on Long Island
description: There are 660,000 people in Nassau and Suffolk Counties who head for work each day to jobs elsewhere on Long Island. No one paid them much attention yesterday. Nearly all of them drive to work, and they were little affected by the Long Island Rail Road strike, except for traffic that was a little heavier than normal.

title: West Pointer Helps Neediest
description: A West Point cadet, Timothy S. Bensley, has sent a $10 check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, along with contrite letter. The letter said, in part, I If everyone had as many excuses as did, there could not be a Neediest Fund, I but if everyone only gave just a fraction of what they could afford, there would not have to be a fund in the future.

title: Fashion Sets: They Lead a Double Life
description: Twofers, that venerable Broadway tradition that enables two people to see a show for the price of one, has been adapted to fashion for spring.

title: Cherrys Song Triumphs
description: YONKERS, Dec. 10  Cherrys Song, owned by Estelle Cherry of Wynnewood, Pa., outdueled Gibson Lobel in the stretch to win the $7,500 trottine feature by a neck as Yonkers Raceway-opened its 59th meeting tonight. Second in his previous effort although going off gait near the finish, Cherrys Song tonight covered the mile in 2:05 1/5 and returned $16.40 for $2.

title: Volatile van Breda Kolff Pride of W.B.L.
description: The more things change for Butch van Breda Kolff, the more they remain the same.

title: Associated Press
description: A captive Marine corporal, sitting between a picture of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and an antiShah propaganda poster, said in a televised interview yesterday that all was well with the hostages in the United States Embassy in Teheran, and he provided a few glimpses of their daily routine.

title: Cyclops to Buy Silo Inc.
description: The Cyclops Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement for the acquisition of Silo Inc., operators of appliance discount stores. Under the terms of the agreement, Silo shareholders would receive $24 in cash for each Silo share.

title: Guitarist: Tanenbaum
description: DAVID TANENBAUM, a young American guitarist who played in Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday afternoon, has been performing with some frequency in this country over the last two years. During that time he has picked up awards in several guitar competitions, including those recently held in Carmel, Calif., and Toronto. His New York debut took place in September 1978.

title: The Doctor's World
description: NO case has been more tangled in the web of medicine and politics than that of the deposed Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, now convalescing at Wilford Hall Air Force Hospital in San Antonio. His case has raised anew the clash between two rights  a patient's right to privacy and the public's right to know.

title: MRS. CARTER DISPLAYS WHITE HOUSE CHRISTMAS TREE:
description: Room yesterday, Rosalynn Carter showed off the official White House Christmas Tree, an 18foot Douglas fir decorated with ceramic ornaments created by students of Washington's Corcoran School of Art. We're going ahead with Christmas activities, Mrs. Carter commented, but it probably won't be as loud as in previous years. She alluded to concern over hostages in Iran.

title: NAVIGATION PROBLEM SUSPECTED IN CRASH;
description: Initial analysis of a crashresistant flightdata recorder shows no signs of structural or mechanical failure that could have led to the crash of an Air New Zealand DC10 jumbo jet in Antarctica on Nov. 28, American aviation officials said yesterday.

title: Commercialism, Yea
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  I like what is sanctimoniously referred to as the commercialization of Christmas.

title: Pierson M. Hall, Federal Judge; Appointed by Roosevelt in 1942
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Dec. 10 (UPI) - Federal Judge Pierson M. Hall, who spent almost 60 years in public service, died of cancer Saturday at his home here. He was 86 years old.

title: Television
description: 5:50(5)New Zoo Revue

title: Arab Oil Lands Tell Producers Side In SteppedUp Public Relations Drive
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 5  To counter the negative publicity that greets each new rise of oil prices, Arab oil producers are stepping up a global public relations campaign, particularly in Western Europe, Latin America and Japan.

title: Sports Today
description: Columbia at St. John's, 8 P.M. (Radio- WGBB, 8 P.M.).

title: Takeover Stocks Lead Market Higher
description: Precious metal, gambling and takeover stocks scored the best gains yesterday as the stock market in general moved slightly higher.

title: TV. John Albok, a Tailor With a Life of Dignity
description: JOHN ALBOK is a tailor with a small shop on upper Madison Avenue. Now 85 years old, he traveled to New York from HunRary in 1921. His plan was to stay three years and save $5,000 to set up a business in his native land. But, he recalls, the magic of America pulled me here.

title: British Question Iranian, Reportedly in Paris Case
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP)  A Home Office spokesman said today that a young Iranian was being questioned in Dover, but the official declined to comment on reports linking the youth to last week's assassination of a nephew of the deposed Shah in Paris. It was understood from police sources that the detention and questioning were linked with the killing.

title: Korean Dissident Says He Feared for His Life While Jailed
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 10  The house is just one story high, with a small garden and a large Alsatian dog in a cage in the yard. A sign fixed to the arched entrance bears the three ideographic characters for kim and dae and Jung, and the walls are surrounded by barbed wire.

title: The Region
description: ROXBURY TOWNSHIP, N.J.  Officials have attributed the fire in which five children died Saturday night to a timelapse of 15 minutes from when the fire was discovered by a 13yearold baby sitter until fire and police officials were notified.

title: A United Nations Session That Is a Model of Diplomacy in Action
description: Although they have neverbeen to China, 15 students from the Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School in Manhattan stanchly represented that country's policies at the United Nations over the weekend.

title: U.S. Panel Asks Doubling of Aid to FoodShort Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  President Carter's Commission on World Hunger declared today that the problem of mal. nutrition was getting worse rather than better and urged that the United States double its aid to the poor and underdeveloped countries.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Dr. Theodore Dubin, a member of the pathology department at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center and a specialist in coronary disease, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 55 years old.

title: Talk With Begin Cheers Linowitz
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 10 (UPI)  Sol M. Linowitz, President Carter's special envoy for the Middle East, met today with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and said the session left him immensely heartened that the Palestinian autonomy negotiations would be successful.

title: Youngsters at Hearings on Institutionalized Children
description: Huddled together under portraits of notables of New York's past, youngsters gathered at 65 Liberty Street to listen to testimony from their contemporaries who had been placed in institutions. The hearings were conducted by members of Children's Express, a magazine written by and for young people. Witnesses at the hearings, which will continue today, included City Council President Carol Bellamy and experts and officials concerned with juveniles.

title: Board of NOW to Oppose Carter, Charging Lag on Women's Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The executive board of the National Organization for Women, the largest feminist organization in the country, has decided to oppose President Carter's renomination or reelection, no matter who is running aeainst him.

title: Concert: Waverly's Renaissance Hits
description: THE Waverly Consort presented an early music tour of Europe at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, a concert that featured many familiar items from the pretsarogue repertory  in fact the program might well have been billed as The Renaissance's Greatest Hits. Almost all the music was by 16thcentury composers who practiced their art at the courts of the Medici in Florence, Elizabeth I of England and Maxmilian I of Germany's Holy Roman Empire, and most of the selections have long ranked high on the oldmusic hit parade.

title: About Education
description: HARVARD has launched a comprehensive review of its relationship with the nation's elementary and secondary schools. The university's Graduate School of Education intends to shift its attention from the reform of central systems and the shaping of social and pedagogical policies to the improvement of education at the local schoolhouse level.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the Federal Government's appeal from an order to pay the Sioux $105 million as compensation for an illegal seizure of reservation lands more than a century ago.

title: The City
description: Judge Mary Johnson Lowe of Federal District Court in Manhattan issued a preliminary injunction to prevent New York City from requiring licensed peddlers to pay a $65 fee to recover merchandise seized by the police.

title: Army's Secretary Clears Portsmouth Oil Refinery
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  Army Secretary Clifford L. Alexander announced today his final decision approving construction of a $600 million oil refinery complex at Portsmouth, Va., subject to environmental safeguards.

title: Topics
description: A word fitly spoken, says the Book of Proverbs, is like apples of gold on beds of silver. During a long ministry, Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen was excelled by none as a speaker fit to translate the Message into every modern medium. With silver mane and scarlet robe, he had a demeanor equal in intensity to his words; he was the incarnation of the Church Traditional.

title: Iranians Offering to Fight the Israelis in Lebanon Meet Early Setback
description: 1 TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 10 (Reuters) I About 300 Iranians chanting Islamic slogans waited in vain at Teheran's Mehrabad Airport today for a plane to take them to southern Lebanon to fight alongside Palestinian guerrillas against Israel.

title: The Weary Commuter as Arbiter
description: The first day of the Long Island Rail Road strike passed with less difficulty than can be expected if drags on very long. Perhaps a quid( settlement will emerge from the meeting the National Mediation Board has called for tomorrow, but the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the railroad's 17 unions have been talking for months, to no effect. Plainly the unions now believe they will do better by generating some public anger and impatience. Governor Carey and the M.T.A. want the White House to declare an emergency, to require mediation while the trains run for another 60 days; they either fear the public's impatience with a strike or want a Federal hand in any costly settlement that may ensue  or both.

title: Retail Sales Rose 1.8% Last Month
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  Retail sales rose by 1.8 percent to $77 billion in November, the Commerce Department reported today, in contrast to a 1:7 nercent decline in October.

title: EARNINGS Esmark Profits Up 12.5% for Quarter
description: Esmark Inc., the Chicagobased holding company that includes Swift & Company foods and STP automotive products among its major interests, yesterday reported a 12.5 percent profit increase for the fourth fiscal quarter ended Oct. 27.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BALKAN BONANZA Since most Americans are unfamiliar with Yugoslav art, a new showing of contemporary graphic works at the United Nations can serve as an introduction. Sponsored by Unesco, the display of 82 works by 15 prominent artists has been organized by the Fine Arts Gallery of BosniaHerzegovina in Sarajevo and the Yugoslav Press and Cultural Center in New York. The pictures are on view in the main lobby of the General Assembly Building, First Avenue at 47th Street.

title: High Court Rules Miners' Union Not Liable for Wildcat Strike Losses
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Supreme Court rejected today an effort by a West Virginia coal mine operator to hold the United Mine Workers international union financially responsible for wildcat strikes called by three union locals.

title: News Summary
description: Washington accused Japan of having undercut American efforts to use economic pressure against Iran to gain the release of American hostages. A high White House official said that Japanese companies had rushed to buy Iranian oil that had been set for delivery to the United States before Washington halted oil imports from Iran. The official also charged that Japanese banks had gone overboard to help Iran cope with Washington's freeze on Iranian assets. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Seven Killed in Fiery Auto Crash
description: MITCHELL, S.D., Dec. 10 (AP)  A fiery twocar collision near Mitchell has taken the lives of two adults and five teenagers. Sheriff Lyle Swenson said that one car carried six teenagers. Killed were Daniel D. Lucid, 17 years old, the driver; Troy VanWalleghin, 15; Randall L. Ruml, 14; Joseph M. Northrup, 17, and Sally K. Hohbach, 17. Killed in the other car were Verlyn Nelson of Sioux Falls and his wife, Loretta.

title: Huston: I Want to Keep Right on Going
description: TORONTO, Dec. 10  The youthful bustle is overpowering in the arena. Young men come and go, hauling gear and syeakine crisnlv into walkietalkies. Young women in makeup, their hair disheveled just so, pass in and out. Passersby stop to stare. Hangerson act important. Technicians arrange wires.

title: OBSERVER Under The Black Robe
description: Bob Woodward and Scott Armstrong have peeped under the black robe of the Supreme Court, and a dismaying sight it is as they tell it in The Brethren.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets on disaramament and election of a nonpermanent member of the Security Council at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Masterwork Chorus
description: DVID RANDOLPH'S performances of Handel's Messiah are a familiar feature of every Christmas season. Typically. Mr. Randolph has his lame amateur choruses attempt to combine the tonal richness and weight that lie naturally at their disposal with the agility and intimacy of a chamber group. Sunday night's performance at Avery Fisher Hall, in which Mr. Randolph conducted the Masterwork Chorus, was no exception.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  The Miller Brewing Company, the nation's secondlargest brewer, announced plans today to build a large brewery in Trenton, Ohio, at a cost of more than $411 million.

title: 2 Still in Hospital After Shea Mishap
description: Two men remained hospitalized yesterday as a result of head injuries suffered Sunday when a model airplane that was part of the halftime entertainment at football game in Shea Stadium crashed out of control into the crowded stands.

title: Bush's Campaign Is Facing Strong Opponents in South
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C., Dec. 7  The line went over well when George Bush first tried it in his lecture to the Southern politics class at the University of Smith Carolina campus here.

title: Best Chemistry Students Are Drawn to Medicine
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Dec. 9 (AP) The United States brightest chemistry students are turning away from test tubes and toward more attractive careers in medicine, according to a national study.

title: I.C.C. Approves $3 Million Autotrain Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Interstate Commerce Commission has given conditional approval to a $3 million financing plan for the Autotrain Corporation, and the company said today that it had arranged to get the money from the Revere Life Insurance Company.

title: Montreal Plans Fare Cut to Get People Out of Cars
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 9  Subway and bus riders in Montreal, like their counterparts in New York and other large cities, are accustomed to fares that go up but never down. But last week the Quebec government proposed to lower the cost of public transport to the rider by 30 percent in an effort to wean people away from their cars and save energy.

title: She'll Polish Your Performance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Vada Ward Marcantonio, a former actress who succeeded Theresa Wright in the Broadway comaany of Life With Father more than 35 yearsago, still has cases of stage fright. Only now they belong to other people, who come to Mrs. Marcantonio for help.

title: U.S. Doctors Use a Satellite Link For Consulting With Micronesia
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 10 (AP)  One of the most popular programs in that sprawling area of the Pacific called Micronesia is the brainchild of two doctors at the national Center for Disease Control here in Atlanta.

title: US. Aides, Shunned in Iran, Complain of TV Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Day after day, Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh of Iran is interviewed on American television by American reporters. Day after day. State Department officials acknowledge they have been Unable to establish direct contact with Mr. Gotbzadeh or others in the Iranian Government.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Jerome S. Kriska, a former managing editor of The Daily News Record, a men's wear and textile trade journal of Fairchild Publications, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Strauss, in Bid to Spur Carter Drive, Recruits Allies for Campaign Posts
