description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK, N.J., Dec. 11  The Salem I nuclear generating station will remain shut down for another two weeks and may not generate electricity before the end of the year, spokesmen for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company said today.

title: Violence Erupts at a Rally in Tabriz for Teheran Aide
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 11  Supporters of Iran's revolutionary Government rallied here today to back negotiating efforts by an official of the Teheran Government. But the rally ended in scuffling and shouting, with members of the Azerbaijani minority challenging the Teheran authority.

title: Cincinnati's Safety Aide Offers CrowdControl Plan
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 Crowdcontrol laws that would require city permits for major gatherings and would bar generaladmission seating in many cases were proposed today by the city's Safety Director.

title: 2 Million U.S. Workers Get Dec. 24 Holiday
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  In the spirit of the season, President Carter today excused 2.1 million Federal employees from working the day before Christmas, giving them a fourday holiday weekend.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: JOHN LE CARRE writes so well that he almost defeats his purpose. He leads us to expect the normal rewards of the novel: profound human interchange, which is difficult to achieve in a spy novel in which all of the action occurs outside of life, so to speak, in the limbo of conspiracy where no one exists in his own right, but is concealed in a spurious identity, and where an obsession with procedure replaces the ordinary flow of passions.

title: Ammonia Import Quotas Rejected by President
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  President Carter, countering a 3to2 recommendation by the International Trade Commission, has decided against imposing quotas on the import of anhydrous ammonia, used mainly in fertilizers, from the Soviet Union.

title: Stravinsky Estate Fight Resolved
description: An eightyearlong battle over Igor Stravinsky's estate between his 92yearold widow and his children by his first wife has been settled with the filing of court papers signed in Manhattan. Paris and Switzerland.

title: Winds and Tides Offer Hope on Energy
description: As surely as the wind blows, the sun warms ocean waters and the tide ebbs and flows, there is a diversity of renewable energy sources, now largely unexploited, that the world will come to depend on in the next decade or so for small but increasingly significant amounts of its electricity.

title: Summary of Emergency Services During Strike
description: Following are emergency measures and services that have been put into effect to help move commuters in and out of New York City during the Long Island Rail Road strike.

title: Violations Rise In New Pattern In Apartments
description: The pace of deterioration of apartment buildings in middleincome neighborhoods in New York City accelerated rapidly in the last year and is now faster than in poorer neighborhoods, according to study of housing code violations to be released today.

title: Syracuse Area Backs Bonds to Draw Brewery
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 11  The Onondaga County Industrial Development Authority today approved a plan for a $250 million bond issue to enable AnheuserBusch Inc. to buy and rework a brewery now owned by the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company in Raddison, about 20 miles northwest of here.

title: Carey Orders Release Of SetAside Gasoline To Ease Strike Impact
description: Citing official estimates that the Long Island Rail Road strike could increase the demand for gasoline by as much as million gallons a week, Governor Carey yesterday ordered the immediate release for sale in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and parts of New York City of 1.9 million gallons of the state's December setaside reserve.

title: Italian Truffles Rival Their French Peers
description: Although summer is generally considered the season of greatest gastronomic bounty, sophisticated palates are more likely to be beguiled by the subtle and luxurious specialties of autumn. Count among those culinary treasures not only game, foie gras and the black truffles of France but also the even more odiferous and pungent white truffles hunted by trained dogs in the Piedmont section of Italy.

title: Christmas FROM THE Kitchen
description: SITTING before a warm and open hearth recently with nothing more compelling to do than throw another log on the fire, I started mulling over the requests I would address to Santa.

title: Possibility of Civil War Cited
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 11 (UPI)  Ayatollah ShariatMadari warned today that civil war will take place if Ayatollah Khomeini makes mistakes again in handling the revolt in northwest Iran.

title: Rangers Win, 21
description: The Rangers defeated the Red Wings, 21, in Detroit on goals by Don Maloney and Walt Tkaczuk. Article is on page B11.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Harold S. Geneen, who will step down as board chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on Dec. 31, a few weeks before his 70th birthday, has asked the company to buy out his contract, industry sources disclosed yesterday. I.T.T.'s board of directors is scheduled to consider the request today.

title: U.S. Suit Against Iran Goes to Deliberations In International Court
description: THE HAGUE, Dec. 11 (AP)  The International Court of Justice today began considering in private session the United States suit against Iran, court officials said.

title: Housing Violations By Neighborhood
description: The following table shows the number of buildings with housing violations in 1979, by community district. It also shows the percentage change from 1978.

title: Events
description: HAMLET, by Shakespeare, directed by Marshall W. Mason; starring William Hurt and Beatrice Straight, the Circle Repertory, 99 Seventh Avenue, 7.

title: Soviet Imports Of Grain Rising
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  The Agriculture Department said today that the Soviet Union's reduced harvest this year was forcing it to import nearly 5 percent more grain than had been thought previously.

title: New York's Next Crystal Palace
description: After ten years, two sites and two designs, New York City's latest proposed Convention Center seems, delightfully, to be the right building in the right place. The facility will outclass  there is no other word for  and outdistance all its competitors.

title: One Dispute Ended, Israel Takes On More Mayors
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 11 - Less than a week after resolving a conflict with one Palestinian mayor on the occupied West Bank, Israeli authorities began a confrontation today with two more mayors, putting them on trial for allegedly shoving a police sergeant outside a courtroom more than a year ago.

title: Baking Bread and Making Friends: A Film Maker's Other Life
description: Every year, on Dec. 24, Mel London bakes 15 loaves of bread. He keeps one loaf for himself and his wife for their Christmas dinner on Fire Island. The other 19 loaves are decorated with a sprig of homegrown holly and delivered to the 19 neighbors sharing winter weekends on the island.

title: O'Neill to Light Capitol Tree
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., in an annual ceremony, will light the Capitol's Christmas tree at 5 P.M. Friday. The tree, a 52foot white spruce from Wisconsin, will be illuminated by 2,400 amber, clear and twinkling blue lights. It will be lighted each night from 5 P.M. to 10 P.M. until Jan. 2.

title: Wire Defended in Club Fire Trial
description: COVINGTON, Ky., Dec. 11 (AP) Aluminum wire like that used in the Beverly Hills Supper Club is a necessity in modern construction, not a time bomb set to start fires, a defense attorney said today in a suit brought by survivors of a fire at the club and by relatives of some who died.

title: Rutgers 84, Massachusetts 68
description: PISCATAWAY, N. J., Dec. 11  Rutgers put five men in double figures, topped by Kelvin Troy's 19 points, and gainedits fourth consecutive triumph tonight, an 8468 victory over Massachusetts.

title: S.I. Ferry Is Returning To FiveBoat Schedule
description: The Staten Island ferry service will resume tomorrow a fiveboat schedule during rush hours, with a boat every 10 minutes Mondays through Fridays from 8 to 8:30 A.M. Manhattanbound and from 5 to 5:30 P.M. Staten Islandbound.

title: Topics
description: The Russians have joined Ayatollah Khomeini in urging OPEC members to quit selling oil for dollars and to withdraw their petrodollars from the United States. According to a commentator for Tass, the Soviet news agency, the dollars held in American banks are vulnerable to inflation and to seizure; OPEC is paid too little on deposits and thirdworld countries are charged too much for loans.

title: Music: Prague Orchestra
description: LEADERLESS orchestras are not exactly the newest thing under the sun, but in this age when conductors are arguably the most glamorous figures in the music world the appearance of such a phenomenon can still bring one up short especially if the group is as accomplished as the Prague Chamber Orchestra, which played in Carnegie Hall on Monday night.

title: U.S. JUDGE PROHIBITS MIGRATION CHECKS ON IRANIAN STUDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  A Federal district judge today ordered an immediate halt to special immigration checks on the more than 50,000 Iranian students in this country and forbade the Government to use the information it had already gathered from the students.

title: A Vicious Circle in the Kennedy Campaign
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy is making his first appearance in New York City today since he announced his Presidential candidacy last month. But two of the state's leading Democrats, Governor Carey and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who were once countea in the Kennedy camp, are not scheduled to meet the Massachusetts Democrat.

title: Haughey Is Elected Irish Premier
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  Charles J. Haughey, 54 years old, was chosen by Parliament today as the new Prime Minister of Ireland despite strong criticism from the opposition.

title: Martin: Steinbrenner Sick
description: KINGSTON, R.I., Dec. 11 (UPI)  Billy Martin, in his first public appearance since being dropped as New York Yankee manager Oct. 28, labeled his former boss, George Steinbrenner, as sick tonight and said he would never return to the team as long as Steinbrenner was the owner.

title: Soviet Attempt Reported To Rifle Pakistan Ruins
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  Soviet security men tried to search the smoldering ruins of the United States Embassy in Islamabad after mob set it afire last month, but were ordered away by Pakistani soldiers, intelligence sources said today.

title: Eurodollar Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it would begin rating certificates of deposit issued by savings and loan associations in the Eurodollar market. It said it would assign ratings to longterm C.D.'s issued by associations that are members of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. It will continue its policy of not rating C.D.'s issued in the United States. The Eurodollar market involves American currency held abroad.

title: NOW'S CARTER STAND PERPLEXES FEMINISTS
description: Representatives of many women's groups around the country reacted with surprise and, in some cases, consternation yesterday at the news that the policymaking board of the National Organization for Women decided last weekend to oppose President Carter for reelection, no matter who runs against him.

title: Seoul Slayer Drops His Lawyers
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 11 (AP) The admitted killer of President Park Chung Hee dismissed his 21 defense attorneys today, saying that they could not help him explain his national revolution to restore democracy in South Korea.

title: Government Joins Suit Charging Police Tests City Used Were Biased
description: The United States Department of Justice charged yesterday that last June's New York City Civil Service examination for new police officers discriminated against black and Hispanic candidates.

title: Resistance to Carter's EnergySaving Bids
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The calls by the Carter Administration for the voluntary conservation of energy, aimed at both the American people and foreign allies, appear to have run into political and economic resistance.

title: Deaths
description: DUBINDr. Theodore. The Departmenu of Pathology at Cornell University Medical College sadly mourns the death of our esteemed faculty member. Dr. Dubin was an outstanding scientist and valued member of the department. His loss is irreparable. We extend our condolences to his beloved wife, Lois, and mother, Henrietta.

title: At Trade Center, a Hotel Rises
description: The underground level of the World Trade Center is dusty with the byproducts of nonstop construction and redolent of auto exhaust from the huge underground parking lot. It is easy to lose your way in the labyrinthine corridors of the center's vast food and service delivery systems.

title: How Wholesome Is Natural Food?
description: NATURAL is the consumer catchword of the 70's. Natural cereal, natural bread, natural fruit juice, natural flavor, natural fiber, natural beer, natural cheese, natural apple sauce, natural potato chips  naturalyounameit. If it's natural, it's got to be good. Right? Wrong.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Soars to Peak On European Buying
description: The price of an ounce of gold soared to record levels on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday on strong and persistent buying by European banks and major bullion dealers.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Shubert May Run National Theater
description: The National Theater in Washington has asked the Shubert Organization to take over its management. In what was apparently a nearly unanimous vote, the National Theater's board of directors voted on Monday, according to Maurice Tobin, president of the board, to ask the Shubert Organization to bring the National back to its old glory. The National ended its old management arrangement with the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in October.

title: Spanish Woman Who Performed Abortions Gets 10 Years in Jail
description: MADRID, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  A Madrid court has sentenced a woman to 10 years imprisonment on charges of carrying out abortions, justice sources said today.

title: Duke Stays Undefeated by Beating Penn Five, 7057
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11  In a game pitting an unbeaten college basketball team against one that had not won this season, form held up as Duke scored a 7057 triumph over Penn in the Palestra tonight. It gave the Blue Devils a 60 wonlost record and left Penn 04.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Tasman Family
description: CANBERRA, Australia  The other day I saw a sticker in an automobile rear window here that said Help Stamp Out New Zealand.

title: Nouvelle Cuisine For American Tastes By American Chefs
description: BY now, just about everyone interested in highfashion eating must be aware of France's nouvelle cuisine, the newwave cooking developed and championed by such chefs as Paul Bocuse, Michel Gurard and the Troisgros brothers. This 15yearold culinary movement stresses light sauces, the use of fresh, seasonal produce and inventiveness that allows for a freer and more creative use of ingredients and techniques than did the hidebound classic cuisine.

title: Soviet General Denies Any EastWest Disparity in Europe
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 11  The Soviet Union and the West are on the eve of a crucial test of their relationship, a vote by the NATO alliance on whether to accept a new generation of American missiles as an answer to growing Soviet strength in Eastern Europe.

title: IRAN CENTRAL BANK SEEKS SHAH'S ASSETS
description: TEHERAN. Iran, Dec. 11  The Iranian central bank, as part of a legal strategy designed to retrieve what it says are assets embezzled by the deposed Shah, said today that it had filed a petition with the Prosecutor General here alleging about $600 million in misappropriations by the fogy mer ruler and his family.

title: He Can Build His Own Church
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 11  Rich Campbell, quarterback at the University of California, is a manysplendored tower of gristle who wants to play professional football and save souls, in that order. A junior majoring in religious studies, he has another season of undergraduate play ahead of him, and if he gets through that in one piece he will unquestionably be grabbed in the first round of the pro draft. That will give him a bankroll big enough to endow his own church.

title: Real Estate
description: WE analyzed the downtown market as it came out of the recession, said Simon Mild, and we found that there were many buildings that could be bought cheap. You might say they were relics of the recession.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets on Israeli practices, Namibia, Palestine and apartheid at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: News Summary
description: Economic sanctions against Iran are being weighed increasingly by Washington, a high State Department official said after Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance found support in Western Europe. But the official stressed that the Administration would not press for any collective action until it had fully assessed the impact of such a move on the safety of American hostages in Iran. [Page A1, Columns 45.]

title: Bridge:
description: A recent notable innovation in bridge publishing is a series of pamphlets each dealing with an aspect of the game, almost all about bidding. They are primarily the work of Ron Andersen of New York, although other leading figures have contributed their names.

title: Deaths
description: KOSHLANDDaniel E. The Brandeis Community mourns the passing of Daniel E. Koshland, one of the pioneering members of the University's Board of Fellows and a chief interpreter of the University on the West Coast. We extend our deepest sympathy to the bereaved family.

title: For 1803 Bordeaux, No Sale at Sotheby's
description: A bottle of Chateau LafiteRothschild of the 1803 vintage, the oldest to be put on the auction market in modern times, failed to sell yesterday in a wine auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet & Company in London.

title: Accountants Exempted On Unaudited Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission today exempted accountants from liability for false and misleading financial information in unaudited business reports.

title: Pittsburgh Moves to Integrate Schools
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11  This city's ninemember school board, to which three persons who favor integration were recently elected, has adopted a timetable for action to integrate the schools next year and hopes that the conflicts integration plans have provoked in other cities can be avoided here.

title: Skogmo's Stock Up On Merger
description: The common stock of GambleSkogmo Inc. shot up 7, to 36, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday because of an announcement by the Wickes Corporation of San Diego that it had agreed to acquire GambleSkogmo for debentures and nonconvertible notes worth $200 million.

title: A Growing Despair in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Dec. 12  The bottom line is not money in the bank. The bottom line is 4729 Conner Street, the unemployment line, next to the SpartanAtlantic discount house and the United Wig Shop.

title: BETSY LIDSKY
description: Dr. Betsy Lidsky, a pediatrician, died Monday in her son's home in Madison, N.J. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan, where she had been on the staff of the New York Infirmary from 1953 until her retirement in 1970.

title: Law Against Business Abuse Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  A broad alliance of consumer, labor, religious and environmental groups contended today that there was a growing abuse of power by big business. The alliance called for legislation to set Federal standards of behavior for large corporations.

title: New Homes For Furniture
description: The tipster said, It looks like moving day in the furniture business, and went on to say that new homes had been found for the Pennsylvania House division of General Mills, billing at least $4 million, and part of the furniture group of Sperry & Hutchinson, billing about $1 million.

title: Runaways Gain a New Refuge
description: The 105 runaway youngsters who slept on the floor of the Covenant House Under 21 center on Eighth Avenue last night will have beds, even bedrooms by next Monday.

title: The Cobra Looks Ahead
description: The Cobra, whom many people consider the best baseball player on the planet, is pursuing the winter's work this week with a sore throat and a message: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who thrive on adversity, will not be spoiled by success.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  A Federal district judge today ordered the publisher John P. McGoff to obey subpoenas from a Government agency investigating his possible ties with South Africa.

title: Citibank Claim By Iran Barred
description: PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP)  A Paris court today rejected a request by Iran's central bank, Bank Markazi, to order the French branch of Citibank of New York to release $50 million on deposit here.

title: Female Smoker Warned About Cancer of Lungs
description: BOSTON, Dec. 12 (UPI)  American men are smoking less but women are smoking in record numbers and their health is declining, according to the Surgeon General of the United States, Dr. Julius Richmond.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Chromalloy American Corporation, St. Louis, has elected Richard L. Wachtell chairman and chief executive officer and Martin Epner president and chief operating officer.

title: Chrysler Unit Sale Talks Held
description: DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation is negotiating the sale of a 75 percent interest in its Australian credit subsidiary to the Barclays Group of Australia, Chrysler said today.

title: Talking Business
description: More than half of the businesses of the Bell & Howell Company, circa 1971, are no longer there. They are, in large part, the planned casualties of a battle strategy designed by Donald N. Frey, and frequently revised, to keep the struggling Chicagobased company alive by narrowing its horizons, investing in its strengths. That plan. he says, is virtually complete.

title: Murdoch Gains Ansett Control
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 12  Rupert Murdoch today gained control of Ansett Transport Industries, the owner of two television stations, an airline and other interests.

title: Police Hunt 2 Men in Bombing at SovietU.N. Mission
description: The New York City Police Department searched yesterday for two suspicious looking men who were seen near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street shortly before a powerful bomb exploded there Tuesday night.

title: No Hostages Will Be Sentenced To Death, Says an Iranian Leader
description: QUM, Iran, Dec. 12 (UPI)  Iran's most powerful revolutionary judge said today that none of the 50 American hostages would be sentenced to death.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE great emphasis on the need for insulation and weatherstripping to conserve energy sometimes makes the homeowner and the apartment dweller forget that there are many other steps that can be taken by almost everyone, often at little or no cost, to reduce the energy consumed by a typical household.

title: Q & A
description: Q. The kitchen cabinets in my house are faced with a plastic laminate in a color that I dislike very much. Can this plastic be painted successfully? C. M. G., Brooklyn.

title: Business Records
description: STEPHEN J. KATZNER, 34 W. 9th St., N.Y. Liabilities, $1,982,552; assets, $1,335.

title: Carter Meets With Media Adviser Sought by Kennedy's Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  David Garth, the consultant on the new media, met today with President Carter to discuss the Presidential campaign, officials said. Mr. Carter's supporters in New York State, where Mr. Garth has run several successful political campaigns, have been trying to persuade Mr. Garth to help in the President's reelection effort.

title: Neville's Request Granted
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 12  Tom Neville, who rushed off to a hospital last night feeling dizzy, who woke up this morning with his face feeling numb, who has spent the better part of the last 15 years banging his head in National Football League trenches, will start his last game Sunday, just the way he wanted.

title: Text of the President's Message to Business Council on Nation's Military Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The following is the prepared text of President Carter's address to the Business Council. as released by the White House:

title: Giants Confirm Signing Stennett, May, Wohlford
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants confirmed baseball's poorest kept secret today when they announced the signing of Rennie Stennett, Milt May and Jim Wohlford, all free agents who were selected by the Giants in the recent reentry draft.

title: Survey of Michigan Sees 50,000 Sources of Potential Water Pollution
description: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 12 (AP) Michigan's underground water supplies are threatened by 50,000 sources of potential pollution, some of them dangerous, state environmental experts disclosed today.

title: Rangers Top Black Hawks, 52
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 12  Tacked on the bulletin board in the Ranger dressing room in Chicago Stadium was a clipping from a local newspaper that evaluated the Rangers strengths and weaknesses. Explaining the weaknesses it read, Defensively the Rangers are in a class with such flunkies as Washington and Edmonton.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
How David Dukes Solved a Problem in Playing Bent
description: ONE day last October, David Dukes found himself running madly up Broadway. Beebeebeebee, bybybyby, he enunciated again and again, ignoring wary reactions from people he passed. Dashing into the Martin Beck Theater on West 45th Street, he practiced bounds and leaps and hung from sprinkler pipes backstage.

title: Scholars Foresee New Age Of International Terrorism
description: A group of experts on terrorism suggested yesterday that the taking of American hostages in Iran could be indicative of a new age of terrorism.

title: Soviet Is Said to Hinder Olympic Periodical Sales
description: Roland Algrant, president of Distripress, an international organization of distributors and publishers of newspapers, periodicals and paperback books from 70 countries, charged yesterday that his organization is meeting a lot of frustration in getting the Russians to agree to the distribution of newspapers and magazines during next summer's Olympics.

title: The Mayor Tips His Hat to Neighborhood Beautification Efforts
description: Mayor Koch modeling a tricorn hat presented to him by Bob Mangieri of the Remsen Park Coalition during ceremonies at City Hall yesterday honoring the winners of the eighth annual Dress Up Your Neighborhood Contest. Arlene Francis, the actress, center, joined Molly Parnis, the fashion designer and sponsor of the contest, and Mr. Koch in awarding a total of $5,450 to 35 community groups for successfully carrying out projects that were innovative.

title: Iran Strife Ruffles Quiet Life of Tabriz Rug Family
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 12  In the back of Asghar Binavai's house on Shambayghazan Street, behind the courtyard that contains grape vines and a tiny water tank, there is a small room in which the old man and three of his sons spend nine hours a day weaving carpets. This room is so far from the street that no traffic noise floats in.

title: 6 Jewish Settlers Held in Attack on West Bank School for Arab Girls
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 12  The police announced today that six Jewish settlers on the occupied West Bank had been charged with smashing windows and firing shots into a school for Arab girls at a refugee camp on Nov. 27.threatened deportation to Jordan of Mayor Bassam alShaka of Nablus, who was released last week after Israeli military authorities annulled the expulsion decree.

title: Chrysler Aid Debate Set. But Long Siege Looms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The House Rules Committee agreed today to schedule floor debate tomorrow on aid to the Chrysler Corporation, but indications were growing that Congress would probably not take final action on the controversial aid package before the Christmas recess.

title: Geoffrion Resigns as Coach of Canadiens
description: Bernard (Boom Boom) Geoffrion kept his promise last night. He had decided before accepting the only hockey coaching job he wanted  with the Montreal Canadiens, his dream job that if he could not motivate the players, he would forget the threeyear contract and leave. He left last night after 31 games and before me return of the health problems that had forced him to give up two other coaching jobs.

title: Satellite Photograph
I.R.S. Tells Specialists: Take Care
description: They sat at lifttop desks that evoked elementaryschool memories, and listened attentively to talk of lump sums and rollovers. They guffawed appreciatively at the declaration that penalties are never tax deductible, broke into applause after one speaker's pithy exegisis of pension plans, and got into a spirited discussion of residential energy credits.

title: Judge in Connecticut Rules The Death Penalty Is Illegal
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 12  Connecticut's sixyearold capital punishment law, which specifies conditions under which the death penalty may be imposed, was held unconstitutional today by Judge David M. Shea in State Superior Court.

title: Canada Raises Fuel Prices in SelfSufficiency Move
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 12  Canadian motor ists paid 17 percent more for a gallon of gasoline this morning than they did yesterday, in a first step toward the goal of realizing selfsufficiency in energy in the 1990's.

title: When Deployed in 80's, the New Missiles in West Europe Could Strike at Soviet
description: The significance of the acceptance yesterday by the Atlantic alliance of the eventual installation of 464 cruise missiles and 108 Pershing2 ballistic missiles is that the West will then have nuclear weapons in Europe capable of hitting targets within the Soviet Union.

title: Wicker, Wicker Everywhere
description: THERE are those with accents of wicker on their porches. There are those who enjoy a wicker highlight in their breakfast rooms. There are even those who like a froth of wicker in their boudoirs. And then there are Pamela and Richardson Scurry.

title: Chief Ramokgopa's Appeal
description: The South African Government of Prime Minister P. W. Botha has made several recent pronouncements which, if carried out, would mean improved conditions for the blacks who make up the great majority of that country's population. Blacks have been granted the right to join trade unions, for example. And Mr. Botha has questioned other laws that support the system of apartheid. Sadly, though, a dispatch last week from our colleague John Burns reveals that South Africa is still cruelly resettling blacks against their will. The pronouncements, therefore, may be empty propaganda.

title: New Look at Two Showrooms
description: TWO prestigious furniture companies, Knoll International and Thonet, have recently opened new showrooms in New York. Traditionally, these spaces are designed as a backdrop for the furniture, but they also serve to convey the design image a company wants to project.

title: Capital Drones To Monotony Of Long Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  In a spirit of moderation, Ken Montville does not stock the Nuke Iran Tshirt that some passersby have been requesting at his Georgetown street stand. Instead he has designed and printed a middleoftheroad shirt with a multiple choice reading:

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1979

title: New Step in Drive on Smuggling
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  The commandant of the Coast Guard today ordered all personnel boarding recreation boats to wear sidearms to protect themselves from drug smugglers. Adm. John B. Hayes said that he had taken the action because of a sharp rise in the use of small, privately owned boats for transporting illegal drugs.

title: Music: Juilliard Ensemble
description: THE conductor of Tuesday night's concert by the Juilliard Contemporary Ensemble in Alice Tully Hall was Mario di Bonaventura, who has done a lot for today's composers through commissioning programs, as director of the Congregation of the Arts music festivals at Dartmouth College from 1963 to 1969 and now as director of publications at G. Schirmer/Associated Music Publishers. His choice of works for this program struck a nice balance between the relatively old and new, between pieces of American and European origin.

title: Police Arrest 5 Iranian Students After San Antonio City Hall SitIn
description: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 12 (UPI)  Police officers today dragged five Iranian students screaming Khomeini! Khomeini! Khomeini! through the City Hall lobby to a police wagon, ending their threeday sitin on the building's steps.

title: Fire Destroys Coast Transit Car
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP)  A Bay Area Rapid Transit rail car was destroyed by a fire and another was damaged today, sending 11 persons sprinting for safety. There were no injuries reported in the fire, but the damage was estimated at $750,000.

title: Cutting Your Own Christmas Tree
description: WITH less than two weeks before Christmas, there are still two weekends to go into the countryside and cut your own Christmas tree. It is an expedition that can be both nostalgic and economical.

title: REAGAN CHALLENGED TO JOIN IOWA FORUM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 John B. Connally, stepping up his attack on Ronald Reagan, challenged the former California Governor to come out of the closet to join the Republican Presidential forum in Iowa and accused Mr. Reagan of making more inflammatory comments on Iran than Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Rangers Down Hawks, 52
description: The Rangers played excellent defense, holding Chicago to 23 shots on goal, as they beat the Black Hawks, 52. Article is on Page D22.

title: Public to Vote On Awards For Movies
description: The theatergoing public will have a chance to select its own best film, actors, actresses, directors and other personages next month when balloting begins in 2,500 theaters to choose winners of the new American Movie Award, a gold statuette called the Goldie.

title: Suits Contest Shell's Merger
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec.12 (AP)  The Mobil Corporation and Texaco Inc. filed suits in Los Angeles Superior Court today in connection with yesterday's $3.65 billion takeover of the Belridge Oil Company by the Shell Oil Company, the largest corporate merger in history.

title: Jets Vote Powell M.V.P.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 12  Marvin Powell was voted by his teammates as the most valuable Jet today.

title: World Airways Strike Ends
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI)  A 131day strike against World Airways has ended with the approval of a new contract by pilots, mechanics, flight attendants and ground crew personnel. The airline's president, Edward J. Daley, said that the company would soon announce schedules, dates and fares for its services, which will include lowcost transcontinental service between Newark and Los Angeles.

title: Regents to Meet Today on Revision Of Rules on Licensed Professionals
description: Confronted with evidence of a breakdown in the state's system for disciplining 450,000 licensed professionals, the New York State Board of Regents meets today to begin enacting parts of a major program for change.

title: David Kershaw Dead; Executive Was Expert On Reform in Welfare
description: David N. Kershaw, senior vice president of Mathematica Inc. of Princeton, N.J., a social science research organization, died Saturday of cancer at the Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived in Hopewell, N.J.

title: A Correction
description: The leather case in a caption in the Discoveries column in The Living Section yesterday was incorrectly identified. It is sold at Barney's.

title: 2,937 Apply for Posts
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that 2,937 persons had applied for the 10 to 20 places open for the second class for space shuttle astronauts.

title: Notes on People
description: Mayor Koch became 55 years old yesterday, and said, among other things, I can't believe it.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Blasts Damage Puerto Rico Refinery
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 12 (AP)  A series of explosions destroyed parts of a sprawling Japaneseowned oil refining complex on Puerto Rico's southern coast late yesterday, jolting nearby towns and injuring 11 workers. Two were reported in serious or critical condition.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TransAtlantic

title: COLUMNIST OF TIMES REBUKED BY MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 12 A Soviet commentator today accused James Reston, the New York Times columnist, of using his reputation to lend credence to the malicious and nonsensical inventions of American intelligence in regard to the situation in Cambodia.

title: Travelers Share Headache, But Not Many Share Cars
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 11  Like many Long Islanders who commute to New York City, Zachary Fabrizi, a Smithtown resident who works at Federal Plaza in Manhattan, has been up at 5 o'clock these mornings to face the journey to the city without the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Reinterpreting the Classic Bowl
description: AT a ceramic exhibition at the Florence Duhl Gallery, 20 potters have expanded the definition of a bowl with a variety of vessels and containers that demonstrate how volume can be enclosed, pierced, squeezed or expanded by an enveloping form.

title: I.T.T. Reaches Geneen Accord
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday that its board of directors had approved in principle an agreement governing the future relations with the company of Harold S. Geneen, I.T.T.'s chairman.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the transcript of the roundtable on Islam in The Times on Tuesday. a paragraph beginning The Moslem world today suffers from special disparities and special traumas was misattributed. The speaker was Eqbal Ahmad, fellow of the Transnational Institute of the Institute for Policy Studies.

title: Reagan Is Undecided On Taking U.S. Funds In Primary Campaign
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 12 Ronald Reagan said tonight that he had not yet decided whether he would accept Federal campaign matching funds in his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination and would not make a decision until after Jan. 1.

title: U.S. Panel Gets Atom Plant Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, using lessons it learned from the Three Mile Island accident last March in Pennsylvania, today outlined a fiveyear plan to improve safety at atomic power plants.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Bohack Corporation, one of the first of many supermarkets to file for bankruptcy in recent years, announced yesterday it had been discharged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: ARTHUR F. MONROE
description: Arthur F. Monroe, former vice president of J. M. Mathes Inc., an advertising agency, died Tuesday in his home in Hackensack, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: Sound
description: ASSUMING a munificent Santa prone to grant even the most extravagant desires, our Christmas audio shopping guide now moves into rarefied precincts. Nothing but the best is this week's motto.

title: TV: Drunken Driving and Pretrial Jailing Studied
description: THE scheduling of two strong documentaries in prime time is unusual enough for public television these days. But adding an extra fillip of interest to tonight's presentations is the fact that each received production funds from New York governmental agencies. Until I Get Caught, being shown at 9 o'clock on WNETTV, Channel 13, is a study of drunken driving and was made possible by an appropriation from the New York State Legislature (with additional support from Aetna Life). Presumed Innocent, an essay on pretrial detention, at 10 o'clock, was started by WNET's TV Lab and completed with funds from the New York Community Trust and the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: 7% Raise for City Workers Is Unaffordable, Koch Says
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city could not afford a wage settlement with municipal labor unions at the 7 percent level of Federal guidelines.

title: F.C.C. Adopts New Rules to Foster Competition in Data Transmission
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The Federal Communications Commission, in an effort to increase the variety and availability of services to customers in the field of international data communications, approved several policies today to foster broader industry competition.

title: Nancy Lopez Player of Year
description: Nancy Lopez, winner of a record season's total of $215,987 on the 1979 women's golf tour, has been named the player of the year for the second straight season.

title: Charter Flights to China Planned
description: PEKING, Dec. 12 (UPI)  Tourists will soon be able to fly directly from Hong Kong to Peking on chartered flights once every eight days, the official New China News Agency announced today. A plane operated by China's General Administration of Civil Aviation will carry up to 150 people on the chartered flights from Dec. 22 to April 5, 1980, it said. There was no mention of what the fare would be.

title: Sports Today
description: C.W. Post at St. Francis, 8 P.M.

title: ???????? In Leap to Tracks
description: Injuries in Kings County Hospital after ??umping in front of an IND subway rain at the BroadwayEast New York station in Brooklyn.

title: Portion of Landauer Expected to Be Sold
description: Announcement is expected today of the purchase of a portion of Landauer Associates. Shearson Loeb Rhodes & Company is expected to share ownership of the real estate consulting firm with four foreign property consulting companies and a group of Landauer executives.

title: Britain's Man For Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Dec. 12  Eleven years ago, when a Labor Party Government appointed Christopher Soames to the prestigious and important position of Ambassador to France, it seemed to many to be a most unlikely choice. Al

title: Princeton Beats Fordham, 5343
description: Princeton played the kind of patient basketball for which it is noted last night and earned its first victory of the season, beating Fordham, 5343, at the Rose Hill gymnasium.

title: Simulated Flight Test For Space Shuttle Is Set
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP)  Astronauts and full ground crews will begin the first major simulated flight test of the space shuttle sometime this weekend, according to space agency officials.

title: Foremost's Stock Plan Hits a Snag
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12  A move by ForemostMcKesson Inc. to prevent a takeover by going private has run into a roadblock  national economic policy.

title: Scenery at Olympic Sites Captivates Inmate Crews
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 12  The prisoners who volunteer to work on the Olympic mountains are realists who appreciate the value of a good illusion.

title: JOSEPH TEITELBAUM
description: Joseph Teitelbaum, a former plumbing contractor and real estate executive in Manhattan's Yorkville section, died Tuesday at his home at 440 East 79th Street. He was 94 years old.

title: House Passes Bill to Aid Victims of Family Violence
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Seeking to stem a growing incidence of violence in the American household, the House today passed a bill to help states and municipalities deal with the problem.

title: 120% DUES INCREASE APPROVED BY MINERS
description: DENVER, Dec. 12  By warning members that the United Mine Workers of America, once the nation's richest union, has nearly run out of money, the miners' new president, Sam Church Jr., today won a 120 percent increase in dues at the union's national convention here.

title: ??our ??eaeration Begins Hostages Petition Drive
description: ?????????????? ??millionmember American Federation Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today began a nationwide tition drive demanding the release of e American hostages held in Iran.

title: Madrid Rights Office Bombed
description: MADRID, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  A gasoline bomb yesterday damaged the Madrid office of Amnesty International, the rights group, the police said. No one was injured. An Amnesty spokesman said it was the third attack this year.

title: Hers
description: Gail Sheehy

title: U.S. Peace Corps Worker Seized
description: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 12 (UPI)  A United States Peace Corps volunteer has been taken hostage by leftists who seized a downtown market to press demands for salary increases, witnesses said today

title: Barrera, Pincay Eclipse Victors
description: Laz Barrera and Laffit Pincay, the trainer and the regular rider of Affirmed, were named winners yesterday of the Eclipse Awards for outstanding trainer and jockey.

title: RHODESIA RESTORED TO COLONIAL STATUS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec.12  This nation returned to legality under the British Crown today when Lord Soames, the man named to guide the transition to black majority rule, arrived to assume his duties as Governor.

title: Max Habernickel Jr., 77, Clothing Chain Founder
description: Max Habernickel Jr., founder and chairman of the Haband Company, which owns the Haband chain of men's clothing stores in northern Jersey and a mailorder house in Paterson, N.J., died Monday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood. He was 77 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Jersey Students Volunteer for Fingerprinting in Search for Vandals
description: KINNELON, N.J., Dec. 12  Six hundred of Kinnelon High School's 752 students in this wealthy Morris County community voluntarily filed into a temporary crime laboratory set up in the school library today to be fingerprinted.

title: Crisis in Iran Alters '80 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The latest Gallup Poll has snatched from Senator Edward M. Kennedy the most compelling argument he had for his challenge to President Carter; the strong appearance so early in the campaign that he had a

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1979

title: Advertising
description: THE morning after Wayne Fickinger took the giant step from president and chief operating officer of the North American operations of the J. Walter Thompson Company to president and chief operating officer of the whole worldwide show, there was little apparent change in his workday circumstances other than a new corner office. But that, of course, is merely the surface.

title: MRS. FEINSTEIN KEEPS COAST MAYORAL POST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12  Mayor Dianne Feinstein, almost alone among top officeholders, managed to retain her post yesterday in elections that swept from office the District Attorney, the sheriff and four of five County Supervisors on the ballot.

title: Unarco and Estel Plan Steel Venture
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 12  Unarco Industries Inc. and Estel N.V., one of Europe's largest steel companies, announced plans today to build a structural steeltubing mill here with annual capacity of 200,000 tons.

title: Radio
description: 9 A.M.Noon, WFUV. Sonatina No. 1 in F sharp minor, Sibelius; Trio No. 2, Schubert; Symphony No. 41, Mozart; First Rhapsodie for Orchestra and Solo Clarinet, Debussy; Henry V Suite, Walton.

title: After Decade, Uta Hagen Finds Play to Her Liking
description: Uta Hagen will return to Broadway in February in Charlotte, a twocharacter play by Peter Hacks, a West German writer, in which she will play Goethe's mistress. The other character, her husband, will be played by Charles Nelson Reilly, who, however, will speak not a word. Miss Hagen, who has not been on Broadway since 1968, will have them all.

title: The Strings on John Connally
description: How do you win when you're behind? asks the young lawyer in the old story. Well, replies the senior partner, when you've got the law on your side, pound the law. When you've got the facts on your side, pound the facts. When you've got neither, pound the table. John Connally's life as a Republican Presidential candidate has been a bit like that this season. He has tried without much success to draw out frontrunner Ronald Reagan on issues. He has tried to buy national television time to offset national familiarity that two previous campaigns have given to the name Reagan. But there has been no noticeable change in Mr. Reagan's 2to1 lead in the polls. And so Mr. Connally has decided to pound the table.

title: Summary of Strike Services
description: Alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations will be suspended in Queens and Brooklyn during the strike so that commuters going to Manhattan can park their cars on both sides of the street and walk to subway stations. All other traffic regulations remain in effect.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Oil Price Rise Near, Yamani Says
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 12 (Reuters) The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said today that his country would raise the price of its oil before next Monday's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Caracas. Venezuela.

title: Architecture: Designs for Catalogue Emporiums
description: PROBABLY the most talkedabout recent store design in the nation is the series of showrooms designed for the Best Products Company by the architectural and sculptural group called Site. The showrooms are conventional, and rather banal, cataloguesales stores inside, but have altogether spectacular exteriors  one has a brick wall that appears to be peeling off, another has a jagged top that suggests that the facade has just begun to crumble into a pile of bricks, and still another has a notch cut out of the facade that serves as a doorway.

title: Damages Awarded in Air Crash
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 12 (UPI)  The parents of a computer company executive killed in the 1978 crash of a Pacific Southwest Airlines jetliner here were awarded $125,000 today, to be paid by the airline. A Superior Court jury awarded the money to Henry and Doris Burzminski of Edmonton, Alberta, for the death of their son, Ronald Burkley, 34 years old. The crash killed 144 persons.

title: Nature Fantasies for City Children's Rooms
description: APAIR of friendly tigers, together with a parrot, a monkey and a giraffe, watch over 5yearold Gideon Brown and his 14monthold brother, Daniel, in their Upper West Side nursery, while across Central Park the Upper East Side bedroom of 2yearold Bevin Kaplan is guarded by chipmunks, squirrels, blue birds, lady bugs and one owl.

title: Satcom III Upsetting Cable TV
description: The apparent loss of a newly launched RCA satellite, which has been missing in space since Monday, has created confusion and some panic in the cabletelevision industry, which was depending on it for a range of national programming.

title: Fund for the Neediest Is Included On Annual Cause List of Couple
description: Merry Christmas! was the cheerful, seasonal greeting that accompanied Virginia and Taze Huntley's $10 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. This is the third contribution by the Huntleys, who live in Peterboro, N.Y., almost the geographical center of the state.

title: Distressing Furniture For an Antique Look
description: IN the finishing trade, distressed furniture does not mean furniture in dire straits, but pieces that have been purposely abused to give them that livedin look. Depending upon the victim, this is neither illegal nor immoral; it is a timehonored practice that is supposed to add an aged look to raw or young furniture to simulate the years of wear and tear that antique and older pieces show.

title: Prices Up 1% In O.E.C.D.
description: PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP)  Inflation in the 24 member states of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose by 1 percent in October and 11 percent from the yearearlier month, the O.E.C.D. said today.

title: Bogus Kennedy Letter Circulated by Iranians
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 12  Teheran newspapers and the Teheran radio distributed a letter today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy ostensibly wrote to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini pledging his support and seeking a meeting. But a Foreign Ministry spokesman later dismissed the letter as a hoax.

title: Pop: Hall And Oates
description: THE apparent transformation of Hall and Oates from a white souldisco act in a club band with a rock-and-roll sound would seem to be one of the more surprising popmusic events of the year. But the secret of the success of Hall and Oates is that they've been able to fit into various categories  first they were rocking blueeyed soul, then discopop, now danceoriented rock without really changing their approach very much. That says more for their stylistic integrity than it does for the utility of popmusic categories.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets dropped yesterday for the fourth consecutive day, declining sharply in price after the Federal Reserve drained some money temporarily from the banking system. Some shortterm interest rates got within a stone's throw of their Oct. 23 highs.

title: Rhodes Says He Expects to Quit as Republican Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Representative John J. Rhodes, Republican of Arizona, said today that he did not expect to seek another term as minority leader in the next Congress, but he added that he would run for the Speaker's post if the Republicans gained control of the House next year.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: St. Louis Bank Cuts Rate
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 (AP)  The Southwest Bank of St. Louis, which often acts before larger institutions, lowered its prime rate today by onequarter point to 15 percent. Southwest, the seventhlargest bank in St. Louis, has assets of $140 million.

title: 31 Food Establishments Cited on Health Violations
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the names of 31 food establishments that have violated the Health Code.

title: Pakistan's Prisoner
description: The arrest of Salamat Ali, Pakistan correspondent of the Far Eastern Economic Review, on Nov. 13 and his sentencing two weeks later to a years hard labor by a summary military court brought to the fore the issue of democratic rights in Pakistan. By convicting Mr. Ali of publishing a news report on Baluchistan that allegedly promoted hatred between different classes and provinces, Pakistan's martiallaw authorities have enacted a complete parody of the motives they expressed when they seized power in July 1977.

title: Deaths
description: PAULJulia K. We are saddened to announce the passing of a wonderful Person who was an important member of our family for 32 years. She was there when we needed her, always helpful and happy. We will all miss her very much. Our sincerest condolences to her family, friends and to those who knew her.

title: Eloise Clark Doyle Is Dead at 56; Former Executive at Newsweek
description: Eloise Clark Doyle, 56, former operations director of the international edition of Newsweek magazine, died of cancer Monday at Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. She was 56 years old and lived in Heritage Hills, Somers, N.Y.

title: Judge Rejects Delay of Execution Of a Murderer in South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 12 (AP)  A Federal district judge refused today to delay the execution of Joseph Carl Shaw, a murderer who is scheduled to be electrocuted Friday.

title: EARNINGS
description: West PointPepperell Inc., makers of a variety of textiles for the household, apparel and industrial markets, reported yesterday that the company had a 39.2 percent surge in profits for the first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 24 on a sales gain of 21.9 percent.

title: Mediator Offers 2 Wage Proposals in L.I.R.R. Strike
description: Negotiations in the Long Island Rail Road strike recessed shortly before midnight last night after a Federal mediator Submitted two alternative proposals for a settlement and asked for further talks today.

title: U.S. F111 Is Missing in England
description: OXFORD, England, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  A United States Air Force F111 fighter with a crew of two was missing and presumed down in the North Sea, the Air Force reported tonight. The plane, from the 20th Tactical Fighter Wing at the nearby base of Upper Heyford, was on a bombing exercise when it disappeared off the eastern coast of England. The names of the crew were withheld.

title: Continental Air Picks New Chief
description: Continental Air Lines announced yesterday that A. L. Feldman, currently president and chief executive officer of Frontier Airlines, would assume these same positions at Continental Feb. 1.

title: NATO APPROVES PLAN TO INSTALL MISSILES AND PROMOTE TALKS
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 12  The North Atlantic allies decided today to install mediumrange United States nuclear missiles in Europe and at the same time to seek talks with Moscow that would limit both Soviet and American weapons of this type.

title: For Sale: Medieval Way of Life
description: LAXTON, England, Dec. 7  Peter W. Evans, a tall, squarejawed agricultural official from Nottingham, replaced his beer glass on the bar of the Dovecote Inn and reached for his man.

title: REAGAN'S AIDES VETO NEW YORK PROPOSAL
description: ALBANY, Dec. 12  Backers of Ronald Reagan for the Republican nomination for President refused today to go along with a plea by New York party leaders to support uncommitted delegates to the national convention.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN a season of bloated novels and tiredout talents, what relief to come upon two writers who are challenged by the fragile form of the short story. Though their works

title: Knicks Bow to Hawks, 114102
description: ATLANTA. Dec. 12  Although Bill Cartwright had a gamehigh 29 points and 14 rebounds, and Joe C. Meriweather blocked 10 Atlanta shots, the New York Knicks still could not stop the Hawks tonight in the Omni. With freethrow shooting playing a key role in the outcome, the Hawks rolled to their 19th victory in 32 games. 114102.

title: Koch Lights Official Tree
description: Mayor Koch, assisted by several children, threw a remotecontrol switch yesterday to light the 55-foot-high official Christmas tree in City Hall Park. At the same time, 34 other trees were lighted in other New York City parks and in front of the five borough halls. A crowd at City Hall heard carols sung by members of the Talent Unlimited High School Chorus.

title: Record Set By Amex Index
description: Sparked by price gains in oilandgas Issues, the marketvalue index of the American Stock Exchange rose to record heights yesterday.

title: Negro Ensemble Staging Home at the St. Marks
description: The Negro Ensemble Company is presenting Home, a play of verse and dialogue by SammArt Williams, through Jan. 6 at the St. Marks Playhouse, 133 Second Avenue.

title: Rules for Western Land Issued by Interior Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  The Interior Department today released regulations that will govern the use of more than 56.6 million acres of Federal land in the West while the Government decides what should eventually happen to the land.

title: A New Opinion Survey Will Poll Only Blacks
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychologist and educator, and Percy E. Sutton, a former Manhattan Borough President, announced yesterday the formation of a survey organization they said would, for the first time, poll the opinions of black Americans nationwide.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWARZAnn. Solomon Schechter High School of Brooklyn mourns the loss of its dedicated former PTA President Ann Schwarz. We express our deepest condolences to her son, Paul.

title: Linowitz Visits Cairo With Israeli For a Hasty Meeting With Premier
description: CAIRO, Dec. 12  Sol M. Linowitz, new head of the American team for talks on Palestinian selfrule, brought together the chief Israeli and Egyptian negotiators today and asserted that progress had been made.

title: Phone Industry Measure Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Communications, plans to unveil a new bill tomorrow to promote competition in the domestic telephone and data communications industry. his staff said today.

title: Market Place
description: COMMERCIAL properties, long an investment medium for wealthy professional people and executives, sometimes are accessible to investors with limited funds, too. What generally happens is that a developer looking for money for, say, a new shopping center will sell participations in one he has completed. Or he may decide to raise money directly to finance the building of a new project.

title: North Korea Will Return the Body Of U.S. Soldier Killed in the DMZ
description: TOKYO, Dec. 12 (AP)  North Korea said today it had recovered the body of a United States soldier who strayed into the Communist side of the demilitarized zone and would return it to the United Nations Command, the official North Korean Dress agency reported.

title: Help for Tardy Christmas Shoppers
description: SO you put off your Christmas shopping for so long that the stores won't guarantee delivery, and your local Post Office won't make any promises about regular parcel post service. Your packages can still be delivered on time.

title: Concert: The Bostonians
description: ASOLOIST who agrees to appear on the same program with Le Sacre du Printemps is either an unwary soul or a remarkably confident artist. Stravinsky's earthshaking tone poem, even 67 years after its composition, still can be a flabbergasting experience if the orchestra and its conductor have the score so well in hand that they can make it go with all its inexorable power from start to finish. Pity the poor soloist whose concerto performance must try to make an impression against this aural juggernaut.

title: Deaths
description: COURTMANNathan S., 87, died In Eugene, Oregon, December 12th, 1979. Survived by daughter. Selma S. Neely and son, David M. Courtman, grandfather of Jeanne N. Knudsen, James D. Neelv, William W. Neelv, Robert J.. William A. and Donald T. Courtman and three greatgrandchildren. Services are private.

title: The Region
description: WASHINGTON - Governor Byrne and a key New Jersey legislator said they would review the moratorium on development in the Pinelands and posbly make changes to accommodate e concerns of local communities. After meeting with United States representatives and Senators, Governor Byrne said he would consider eas??g the moratorium to allow more small singlefamily developments in ??e socalled fringe areas of the Pinelands. State Senator Frank J. Dodd, hairman of the Energy and Environment Committee, said it would hold earings in January.

title: OilProfit Tax Wins Senate Test
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 13 President Carter won a significant victory on the Senate floor yesterday when his supporters turned back an effort to kill a proposed minimum tax on oil producers as part of the windfall profits levy.

title: Celtics Conquer Nets, 116 to 102, After Opening Up 17Point Lead
description: BOSTON, Dec. 12  If the New Jersey Nets learned one thing tonight in their 116102 loss to the Boston Celtics, it was that they have a consistent problem. That problem is inconsistency.

title: Alexander's Plans Store In World Trade Center
description: A contract will be signed shortly for Alexander's Inc. to open in the World Trade Center the first department store in lower Manhattan in decades, according to statements yesterday from both parties.

title: Regents Panel Votes Ban On Hitting Church Pupils
description: ALBANY, Dec. 12  Despite the opposition of religious educators, some of whom invoked the Bible to argue their point, a committee of the Board of Regents voted today to prohibit corporal punishment in churchaffiliated schools as well as in public schools in the state.

title: Ford's Bombs' Put Celtics in High Gear
description: BOSTON, Dec. 12  In assessing the Boston Celtics' rejuvenation from a team with a 3250 wonlost record last season to a club with a 227 record, the best in the National Basketball Association this season, there are plenty of factors to point to.

title: RUNAWAY OIL WELL STILL FOILING MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 12  Bad weather and bad luck have continued to thwart Mexico's efforts to cap a runaway offshore oil well that has been spewing record amounts of oil into the Gulf of Mexico for six months.

title: Bridge:
description: Following a considerable expansion of tournament events designed specifically for newcomers, which means players with fewer than 20 master points, the Greater New York Bridge Association, recently decided to award a trophy to the most successful newcomer each year.

title: Hesitation in Haiti
description: Is the honeymoon over for human rights in Haiti? Although the regime of PresidentforLife JeanClaude Duvalier should never be mistaken for a democracy, it was starting to move away from the worst practices associated with the rule of his father, the notorious Francois Duvalier, Papa Doc.

title: Ethics Panel Postpones Rep. Flood's Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  The House ethics committee today rejected arguments that Representative Daniel J. Flood was not competent to respond to allegations of financial misconduct, but it voted an indefinite delay in testimony by the Congressman.

title: Lawyer Named for Navy Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  President Carter announced today that he was nominating Joseph A. Doyle, a New York City lawyer, to be assistant secretary of the Navy for logistics, manpower and reserve affairs. A partner in the firm of Shearman & Sterling, Mr. Doyle would succeed Edward Hidalgo, who is now Secretary of the Navy.

title: How Tight the Screw?
description: President Carter now wants to tighten the screw on Iran so that the price for holding 50 American hostages will gradually increase. By not fully defining the threat and not setting deadlines, Mr. Carter leaves time for Iran to react to the pressure without appearing to succumb to it. But the economic war has in fact begun. It requires a mature understanding of the risks and opportunities, and a careful calibration of means and ends.

title: Ballet Theater Proposal Is Rejected by Dancers
description: The dancers of American Ballet Theater have rejected the company's latest offer in a labor dispute that resulted in the company's current lockout of its dancers. Negotiations had resumed Monday between Ballet Theater and its 77 dancers, represented by the American Guild of Musical Artists. At that time, the dancers had made a proposal that was met by the company's counterproposal.

title: Two L.I. Youths Enter Guilty Pleas And Apologize in a Cross Burning
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 12  Two young men accused of burning a cross on a black man's lawn in East Meadow last Sept. 3 pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today. In entering their pleas, they offered to make a public apology, to shovel snow and do construction work for their victim and to make three public appearances in a campaign against racist vandalism arranged by the United States Attorney's office.

title: U.S. Asking Iran To Remove Most Of Its Diplomats
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The United States today ordered the expulsion of most Iranian diplomats in retaliation for the continued detention of the 50 American hostages in the embassy in Teheran.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSONSaul. The National Council of Young Israel with deep sorrow mourns the loss of Saul Abramson one of the stalwart visionaries and founders of the Young Israel Movement. His Inspiration shall always live on. May the family be comforted together with the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Letters
description: Keeping Family Ties Over Long Distance [Dec. 6], concerned as it was with the problems of assembling fa flung family members for holiday celebrations, struck a sympathetic chord.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Holiday Crafts Fair, Columbia University, 115th Street and Broadway.

title: In Alaska, a Brief Day Dawns at 24 Below
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Dec. 12  The sun's heat and warm air must be enjoyed in memory, like the birdsongs and the creeks trilling over rocks, because here all of nature now is frozen stillness under a black sky that shades

title: Ski Areas Ready
description: This is the time of year ski area operators across the United States begin to fidget if there is a snow shortage. As of yesterday, most of them were fidgeting.

title: Israelis Raze Sinai Base and Load Trucks for New Pullout
description: REFIDIM, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, Dec. 5  The desert can be cold this time of year. A raw wind whips across the dunes, sending wisps of sand into the air like smoke. Bundled in khaki parkas, a few remaining Israeli soldiers stand near a huge bonfire, watching a bulldozer break up wooden barracks and push the debris into the flames.

title: Stenmark Wins 3d in Row, Taking Giant Slalom Race
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Dec. 12 (AP)  Ingemar Stenmark, Sweden's ski star, nearly fell on the first run, but recovered and scored his third straight World Cup victory in the men's giant slalom today.

title: President Calls for 4.5% Increases In Military Budgets for Five Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  President Carter, apparently in an effort to build broader Senate support for the treaty to limit strategic arms, today proposed a fiveyear increase in the military budget of 4.5 percent a year.

title: TREEN VICTORY CAPS POLITICAL COMEBACK
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 As his campaign plane sliced through the night toward a strobelighted runway, Representative David C. Treen twisted his hands in an uncharacteristic display of nerves. This is the last flight of the campaign, he said. If I get killed, Louis Lambert will be Governor.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: IF you leave a house empty in the winter to go on vacation, or have a country house used only on weekends, it can be helpful to have a warning system that indicates a heating system failure. Lack of heat  from a storm knocking out power lines, for example, or from the heating system malfunctioningcould cause serious and expensive damage if pipes freeze.

title: KENNEDY ADVOCATES MORE AID TO ISRAEL
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy called yesterday for increased aid to Israel to compensate for inflation and, at a $1,000aplate dinner in New York City, sought funds for his own campaign.

title: Hazel M. Osborne, Social Worker With Children and Teacher, Dies
description: Hazel M. Osborne, who was active for many years in social work with children, died last Saturday in New York HospitalCornell Medical Center. She lived in Manhattan and was 75 years old.

title: Balmy Weather Stays, But Change Is on Way
description: The New York metropolitan area basked in yet another day of unseasonably warm weather yesterday as temperatures rose to 65 degrees, just three shy of the record for the date, set in 1933.

title: Brazil's Grand Prlx Saved
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 12 (UPI) A cigarette company, a brewer and a manufacturer of jeans rescued the 1980 Brazilian Grand Prix race with sponsorship money today, and the race will be held as scheduled on Jan. 27 at Sao Paulo's Interlagos track.

title: How to Grow Salad Garnishes Indoors
description: HOW about a ready supply of homegrown salad garnishes? It's possible and fun. All you need is a bright sunny windowsill and some patience until things get growing. To start, try cress, that pungent garnish with a flavor somewhere between watercress and mustard greens. Sometimes called peppergrass, these pretty, tiny leaves lend a piquant flavor to salads and soups or they can be chopped up and mixed with cream cheese or sour cream for sandwiches and dips.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON  The effort to carry out the next phase of the Camp David agreement has inevitably lost the attention of the public, and of distracted Washington officials, during the Iranian crisis. But the problem is there, and current developments are making it, if anything, more urgent to find a solution.

title: Hibernate? And Miss
description: IT was almost too much to bear. There was Mayor Koch nuzzling a large bear. And Peter C. Goldmark Jr., executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, didn't recognize his mother. But maybe that was because, unbeknowst to anybody, Frances Salant Was all dressed un as a Mama Bear.

title: Bomb Warning Proves To Be Just a Dog Sitting
description: Members of the Police Department's bomb detail cordoned off a street next to the Hotel Pierre last night after one of their explosivessniffing dogs indicated, during a routine search, that there might be explosives in a car parked near the hotel's side entrance.

title: CHARLES L. TAYLOR, THEOLOGIAN, IS DEAD
description: The Rev. Charles L. Taylor, former head of the American Association of Theological Schools in Dayton, Ohio, died yesterday at the NewtonWellesley Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 78 years old.

title: About Long Island
description: GLENWOOD LANDING, L.I., Dec. 9  The Long Island Rail Road is not running these days, and many Islanders are rearranging their lives to cope with transport. Standing on the brink of Mott's Cove here and looking out over the broad reach of Hempstead Harbor, the historically minded observer will remember the days back in the 1920's when islanders such as J. P. Morgan or Arthur Loew would not have been delayed a moment by ructions on the railroad.

title: KOREAN ARMY RULER SEIZED IN PARK CASE AFTER A GUN BATTLE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Dec. 13  South Korea's martial law commander and several other generals were arrested last night and accused of involvement in the murder of President Park Chung Hee on Oct. 26. Their arrests came after exchanges of gunfire in which five persons were reportedly wounded.

title: Pop: Diane Snow, Singer
description: THE newest cabaret in SoHo is a big, spacious, highceilinged restaurant called Greene Street, which is at 101 Greene Street, between Prince and Spring. With terraced tables and, as a backdrop, a vast brick wall, two stories high, the room itself is dramatic enough to challenge a performer for attention.

title: Economist Running for President On American Independent Ticket
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI) The political party that nominated George C. Wallace for President in 1968, has chosen Percy Greaves as its Presidential candidate for 1980.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Rhodesia and decolonization.

title: Embargo on Iran Meets Doubts at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 United States diplomats here are voicing serious reservations about a trade embargo against Iran.

title: 28 Cited for Violations Of City's Dumping Law
description: Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel has released another list of violators of the city's dumping law. One or more summonses have been issued to the following 28 dumpers, indicating the borough in which the violation occurred:

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1979

title: Peking Gang Warfare Is Disclosed by China; 1 Killed as 140 Clash
description: PEKING, Dec. 12  Gang warfare erupted in Peking last summer and one fight involved more than 140 men armed with knives, shovels, metal springs and even homemade guns, the Peking Daily disclosed today.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The Laotians call it the yellow rain. It struck four times during the month of February, 1978, killing and sickening hundreds of Hmong tribesmen near Xiangkhoang.

title: Rail Strike Tests the City's Transit System
description: Bus and subway riders in Queens suffered the heaviest rush hour yesterday since the start of the Long Island Rail Road strike, according to officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Elizabeth Swados Musical To Play at the Beacon
description: An Elizabeth Swados musical, The Incredible Feeling Show, designed for and performed by children, will open Christmas week at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 79th Street. It will be limited to 10 performances.

title: Deaths
description: HYMANBRANDESEsther. Wife of Howard Brandes, devoted mother of Arlene Ruderman and Dr. William Hyman, dearest grandmother of Melissa, Gary and Kenneth Ruderman and Robert and Eric Hyman, loving sister of Morris Packer. Services Thursday 10AM Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chaples Queens Blvd, 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: News Summary
description: Missile deployment in Western Europe was approved by NATO ministers, along with new efforts for talks with Moscow to limit both Soviet and American weapons. The decision to proceed with installation of mediumrange nuclear missiles was endorsed after sharp argument and modification of a prepared communiqu to meet objections by the Dutch, who seek to stress arms control over defense modernization. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Traces of a Toxic Chemical Found in Vietnam Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  For the first time, laboratory tests have revealed traces of dioxin, a dangerous chemical, in men who were exposed to Agent Orange when that defoliant was sprayed in Vietnam, the Veterans Administration said today.

title: U.S. Pondering Rhodesia Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  The United States withheld its decision today on lifting sanctions against Rhodesia while specialists reviewed the legal and political problems involved. But highranking Administration officials said they expected President Carter to announce his decision by the weekend.

title: Home Beat
description: HANUKKAH begins tomorrow night, and this year there are notable reinterpretations of the menorah, the traditional candelabrum that is used during the eightday festival. Lucidity, at 775 Madison Avenue, has clear plastic menorahs in two sizes, for $42 and $60. And Ceil Skydell, manager of the Jewish Museum shop at 1109 Fifth Avenue, said that she has noticed more menorahs made out of ceramics. Examples include menorahs by Joan Mesnik ($80), Rene Vichinsky ($54) and Edith Fishel ($50 to $80). They're all different; I never copy one from another, Mrs. Fishel said. Moriah, 699 Madison Avenue, also sells Mrs. Fishel's work; for special orders she can be reached at 2899594. The exhibition See and Sanctify: Exploring Jewish Symbols, on view at Yeshiva University, 500 West 185th Street, through next June, includes an unusual range of both contemporary and antique menorahs.

title: No, Let's Debate Our Iran Policy
description: What experience and history teach, wrote Hegel, is this  that people and governments never have learned anything from history. Washington today would seem to Drove Hegel's point.
