title: Interest Increased On Savings Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Treasury Department today increased the interest it will pay on many United States savings bonds to 7 percent from 6.5 percent.

title: Report Fauits Computer Schools
Year's Oil Cost Up 80%, U.S. Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Anthony M. Solomon, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, reported today that prices being paid for oil from all sources were now more than 80 percent higher than a year earlier.

title: Body Left at Bronx Playground
description: A slashed, bulletriddled body with plastic bags around the head was found yesterday morning in a cardboard box in a South Bronx playground. The police said that the victim, Nelson Albaladejo, 25 years old, a neigborhood resident, had been killed elsewhere and left at the playground, at 141st Street between Alexander and Willis Avenues. The motive was not established immediately.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OLD GOLD Several new exhibitions are definitely worth investigating during the hectic holiday season, starting with a genuine, oldfashioned Christmas plum.

title: Events Today
description: OKLAHOMAI book and lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d, music by Richard Rodgers, choreography by Agnes de Mille, starring Laurence Guittard, Christine Andreas and Mary Wickes, Palace Theater, 1564 Broadway, 6:15.

title: Islanders Rally in 3d To Tie Penguins, 33
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec 12  The New York Islanders stole a point tonight. Outplayed for nearly 45 minutes by the Pittsburgh Penguins, showing signs of fatigue and not able to get more than 10 shots in two periods, they came back to score two goals and salvage a 33 tie.

title: Two Ad Executives Are Promoted by Times
description: Fred D. Thompson, vice president for advertising of The New York Times, has been appointed assistant to the president of The New York Times Company, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the company and publisher of The New York Times, announced yesterday.

title: The City
description: A police officer and three other men here indicted yesterday in the robbery of the Friendly Holidays Travel Agency in Kew Gardens, Queens, on oct. 19.

title: Glen Race Approval Is Likely
description: PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP)  A total commitment to improving facilities appeared today to have saved the 1980 United States Grand Prix East for the Watkins Glen track in upstate New York.

title: Gas to Rise 0.7 Cents a Gallon Despite Koch's Protest
description: 1 federally approved increase of 0.7 cents a gallon in the retail price of gasoline is to take effect Saturday despite opposition from the Koch administration.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Otto G. Stolz, 37 years old, has been elected president of the Cannon Mills Company, the world's largest sheet and towel manufacturer, which he joined only about two years ago. Andrew W. Adams, 39, has been named assistant chairman, historically a toplevel position at the corporation. Both had been executive vice presidents.

title: U.S. to Accuse Mobil And Hess of a Billion In Overcharges on Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 13 The Energy Department plans to accuse the Mobil Oil Corporation and the Amerada Hess Corporation of having overcharged for petroleum products by a total of more than $1.1 billion from 1973 to 1976.

title: The Stage: Roni Dengel's Charades
description: IN her debut as a playwright, the actress Roni Dengel displays a decided ability to create vigorous scenes that delineate the banalities of suburban life with a vicious wit. Still, she shares a tendency common among some new playwrights  a tendency to unconsciously borrow, in tribute or imitation, from those who have done it all before.

title: Dance: Mooche Revived By the Ailey Company
description: ONE of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's revivals this season is The Mooche. Mr. Ailey choreographed it in 1975 in anticipation of the Duke Ellington festival he staged the next year with his company at Lincoln Center.

title: U.S.O.C. Gets Flood of Corporate Sponsors
description: Once, the United States Olympic Committee was criticized for doing too little in behalf of American athletes. Now, as U.S.O.C. officials begin final preparations for the Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y., and for next summer's show in Moscow, they are packaging the Olympic logo on everything from Chanstick to Camnbell's Soup.

title: Music: Student Orchestra
description: STUDENT orchestras generally sound inferior to the grownup kind in several respects: a shallower, more timid tone, attributable to inferior instruments and a tentativeness of attack; muddied ensemble and a certain foursquareness designed to overcome such muddiness. There can be exceptions to these complaints. But for all its occasional virtues, the concert offered Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall by the National Orchestral Association was indubitably by a student orchestra.

title: World News Briefs
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 12 (AP)  A powerful earthquake in the ColombiaEcuador border area before dawn today leveled homes and touched off big waves, killing at least 133 persons and injuring as many as 2,000, officials said.

title: Confession Is Held Admissible in the Renee Katz Case
description: The confession of a man accused of pushing a young woman in front of a subway train last June is admissible as evidence, an Acting New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday. The man's lawyer had contended that his client had confessed after being threatened during interrogation.

title: U.S. Will Destroy Nuclear Device By Detonating 2d Nuclear Device
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Dec. 12 (UPI) The Department of Defense said today that it would detonate a nuclear device Friday that would destroy another nuclear device that was damaged in a fall more than four years ago.

title: Policeman Walks Friendly Beat on West 72d St.
description: Bounded by Central Park and the Hudson River, West 72d Street embodies what the Upper West Side once was and what it is becoming. Within four blocks there are transient hotels and exclusive apartment houses, discount cosmetics stores and European boutiques. For all their individuality, however, many of the people who live and work there had the same question on their minds recently.

title: The Renovation Of an 1872 Firehouse
description: Noel DuMAURIER, a young builder and designer, had wanted a solidly built, spacious building where he could create a home for himself. What he found was the old headquarters of Engine Company 215 in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. built in 1872.

title: Thomas Vaughan Dies; A Retired Executive, 71
description: Thomas R. Vaughan, former president, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Freeport Minerals Company of New York, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: James Gibson, a Cornell Professor
description: Dr. James J. Gibson, a professor emeritus of psychology at Cornell University who was known for his studies in the field of perception, died Tuesday at the Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Angolan Plans Moscow Visit
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola will visit the Soviet Union later this month, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today. It will be his first visit since he succeeded Agostinho Neto, who died in a Soviet hospital on Sept. 10.

title: Auctions
description: THE pace of the auction season slows in midDecember, but there are a few specialty sales to go before the galleries close late next week for their yearend resnite.

title: A Mass for Mae Nyquist Bowler Set for Monday at Sacred Heart
description: A memorial mass for Mae Nyquist Bowler, librarian for the old New York Herald Tribune for nearly 40 years, will be held Monday at 4:30 P. M. at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, 457 West 51st Street. Mrs. Bowler, who lived at 625 East 14th Street, died Dec. 5 at Bellevue Hospital after a long illness.

title: Israeli Held in Alleged Plan To Sell a Stolen Tintoretto
description: A 42yearold Israeli citizen was arrested in Manhattan yesterday and accused of attempting to sell a Tintoretto painting stolen during World War II from the Dresden Gallery of Art, now in East Germany.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Rally Ends Recent Slump Treasury Bills Rise
description: The credit markets, responding to new signs of slackening loan demand, rallied yesterday afternoon for the first time in five sessions. Bond prices closed with substantial gains.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration /UPI

title: Obituary 3
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 13 (UPI) Edward A. Mitchell, a former member of the House of Representatives, died Tuesday in a nursing home after an eightmonth illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Power Shortage in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 13 (Reuters)  Electric power will be cut off in Istanbul for eight and a half hours a day because of a shortage of fuel oil to run the main power plant, the state radio reported today. The city of 4.5 million already had a fourhour morning cut.

title: KHOMEINI APPROVES GRAND JURY PLAN; Also Backs Visits to Hostages Japan to Buy Less Iranian Oil
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini approved today Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh's plan for an international investigative team to look into aggressor policies of the United States in Iran.

title: Lehigh Valley Plans To Drop 3 Units
description: Lehigh Valley Industries Inc. said its board had authorized a program to restructure and strengthen the financial condition of the company. The plan includes the discontinuance of three unprofitable or marginal subsidiaries.

title: Carmen McRae Salutes Billie Holiday
description: Carmen McRae ends each of her sets at Marty's, Third Avenue at 73d Street, where she is appearing tonight and tomorrow with a group of Billie Holiday songs. One reason she is doing this, the singerpianist tells her listeners, is because this year is the 20th anniversary of Miss Holiday's death.

title: Pageants, Plays and Puppets
description: Today

title: Ohio Congressman's Last Term
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  Representative William H. Harsha of Ohio will not run for reelection, his office said today. Mr. Harsha, 58 years old, was first elected to Congress in 1960 and is the senior Republican on the House Public Works and Transportation Committee.

title: Not to Worry
description: Now there's another health threat to worry about worry itself. Beyond diet, alcohol, smoking and exercise, a study in the New England Journal of Medicine focuses on the extremely important influence of mental health on physical health.

title: The Region Fingerprinting Ends At School in Jersey
description: KINNELON, N.J.  The Kinnelon police and the Morris County Sheriff's Department yesterday ended the fingerprinting of 650 students at Kinnelon High School, but they said they had not yet identified suspected vandals responsible for $10,000 in damage to the school last month.

title: World News Briefs; CenterRight Lisbon Party Has 3Seat Parliament Edge Cambodian Guerrillas Seize Vietnamese Food Depot Execution of Invaders Of Mecca Mosque Expected Rains Bar Relief Flights After Colombian Quake Empty Supertanker Rocked By Blast and Fire Off Oman
description: LISBON, Dec. 13 (AP)  Final results from the Portugese general election Dec. 2 gave the centerright Democratic Alliance led by Francisco S Carneiro a threeseat majority in the National Assembly and the right to form a government.

title: Taiwan Regime Arrests 14 Foes Demand New Elections
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 13  Taiwanese security agencies arrested 14 opposition activists today in a move representing an apparent shift by the Government from its policy of earlier this year when it allowed the publication of opposition magazines and approved some antiGovernment rallies.

title: A Dual Role for Carson? Lloyd Waiting in the Wings
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 13  Harry Carson, featured player next week in the television soap opera One Life to Live, was asked today about a second life to live the National Football League, this one as a fullback.

title: City Council of Churches Picks Successor to Potter Polk Gets Standing Ovation
description: The Council of Churches of the City of New York yesterday chose the Rev. Robert L. Polk to replace the Rev. Dan M. Potter, whose leadership as executive director of the council had been under criticism since Dr. Potter was accused last year of being an Albany slumlord.

title: Iran Seeks Marks For Oil Payments
description: GELSENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Dec. 13 (AP)  Veba Oil A.G. of West Germany said today that it had been told by the National Bank of Iran to pay West German marks for its last shipment of Iranian oil loaded late in November.

title: Carter's Plans For Arms Rise His New Views Linked To End of Vietnam Era News Analysis Eve of Election Year Some Hyperbole Suspected LongTerm Solution Attitude Began to Change Other End of Spectrum
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Four years ago, Jimmy Carter, as a candidate, called for a cut of $5 billion to $7 billion in I the annual military budget and argued that it could be made without endangering the defense of our nation or our commitments to our allies.

title: Americans and Poles in Warsaw Hold Service for Hostages in Iran
description: WARSAW, Dec. 13 (Reuters)  Western diplomats and hundreds of Poles prayed tonight in a Warsaw church for the wellbeing and release of the Americans being held hostaee in Teheran.

title: Sheen Rites at St. Patrick's
description: Behind the high altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral, the ornate bronze doors of the crypt stood open yesterday as Terence Cardinal Cooke said the funeral mass for Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, who died Sunday at the age of 84.

title: E.E.C. Parliament Bars Budget
description: Paris, Dec. 13  Europe's first directly elected Parliament today decisively rejected the $23.5 billion proposed budget for 1980 on the ground that members are overspending on what the Parliament says is the European Economic Community's wasteful and protectionist farm policy.

title: Tories Keep Seat in a ByElection
description: LONDON, Friday, Dec. 14  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party retained a parliamentary seat in the London suburbs yesterday in the first byelection since she took office. Some Tory strategists had feared that her tough economic policies might tip the election to the opposition.

title: Japan Limits Oil Imports From Iran To Counter Growing U.S. Criticism Bankers Asked to Cooperate Imports $9.8 Percent of Needs U.S. Understanding Sought
description: TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 14  In a move to counter United States criticism of heavy Japanese purchases of Iranian oil, the Government decided today to reduce imports from Iran to the level prevailing before students in Teheran seized the United States Embassy, taking American hostages.

title: Bridge: Regional Tourney to Open A Three-Day Stand Today
description: The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which begin today at the New York Hilton Hotel, will crowd a greater variety of events into three days than any of its predecessors. Among the innovations will be two midnight speedball Swiss team events, with a fast time limit, which have proved popular with insomniacs in other areas.

title: Revels and Dance Enliven Season
description: SOME exuberant antics will flavor events in the city's churches in the days ahead, appropriately reflecting the joy of the holiday season. A rehearsal the other night in the Ansonia Hotel on West 73d Street gave a hint of things to come:

title: Russian Mission Refuses Barriers Against Attacks
description: Soviet authorities have rejected a proposal by the New York City Police Department to place security barriers outside the Soviet mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street. A bomb was set off there Tuesday night by persons believed to be members of Omega 7, an antiCastro Cuban terrorist group.

title: Harold K. Milks, 71 An Editor in Arizona And Reporter for A.P.
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 13 (AP)  Harold K. Milks, Latin affairs editor of The Arizona Republic and former Moscow bureau chief for The Associated Press, died yesterday at his home in suburban Paradise Valley. He was 71 years old.

title: 2 World Bank Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) The World Bank today announced loans totaling $137 million to South Korea and Thailand. The Petroleum Authority of Thailand is to receive $107 million from the bank for 20 years to finance development of natural gas reserves in the Gulf of Thailand. South Korea is to receive a $30 million, 17year loan from the bank at its standard interest rate of 7.95 percent for a birthcontrol project.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The New York Times /William E. Sauro and Jack Manning

title: Joyful Choruses Abound in City Joyful Choruses Abound in City From Tidings to Psalms A Convocation of Tuba Players Computer Star Raising on 16th St.
description: EVERY season, and increasingly so in recent years, thousands of New Yorkers crowd concerts halls, churches, museums and other public places where they can find varied and choice selections of Christmas and New Year's music from all that has accumulated over the centuries. And what a rich accumulation it is  from ancient plainsong hymns such as Veni, Emanuel and Puer Natus Est through Medie val and Renaissance carols and motets, the Baroque can tatas and oratorios of Schutz, Charpentier, Bach and Handel, the organ noel variations of Daquin, Peter Cor nelius's Christmas songs, Liszt's Christmas Tree for piano, Reger's Weinachten, 1919, for organ, Vaughan Williams's Fantasia on Christmas Carols, Britten's Ceremony of Carols, Poulenc's Christmas motets and more, oh, so much more.

title: NOW'S CHIEF BARRED FROM CARTER PARLEY Group Conducts a Protest Outside White House as Other Women Confer on Rights Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  As a small group of demonstrators from the National Organization for Women protested outside in the rain, representatives of two dozen other national women's groups met with President Carter at the White House today to discuss the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

title: Grounds For Belief
description: Well, it looks as though coffee is going down for the count, what with all the talk about it nullifying your B vitamins, the caffeine, and something now about cancer. I'm not saying that's bad, but I just don't want to see it happen without a certain littleknown fact or two about the rise of Western Civilization being made public. Let me explain.

title: Television TOP WEEKEND FILMS
description: Morning

title: Three Hostages Are Permitted to Make Telephone Calls to Families The Students Are Really Trying
description: Three hostages in the American Embassy in Teheran called their families yesterday, and one one told his mother that he was being treated well but that his release depended on whatever President Carter does, she said later.

title: Woman Loses Rights to Her Son, Abandoned Near Manger Scene
description: LONGVIEW, Tex., Dec. 13 (AP) The woman who abandoned a baby near the manger scene of the First Baptist Church here has lost all rights to her son.

title: For One Adolescent Mother, The Door to the Future Is Open Chosen to Attend Meeting I Am His Parent
description: When she was 13 years old, she became pregnant. When she was 14, she gave birth. Now, at 17, she has been to Washington to give the commissioners of the International Year of the Child recommendations on meeting the educational and employment needs of teenagers. And on her way to her home and her 3yearold son in Omaha, she stopped for an interview at Yale University, where she has applied for admission.

title: Judge Dismisses Last Part of Police Brutality Suit Against Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (UPI)  A Federal district judge today dismissed as naked allegation the remaining portion of the United States Justice Department's suit charging police brutality by the city of Philadelphia.

title: ICL Reports Profit Rise
description: ICL Ltd., the British computer group, announced yesterday in London that its net profits for the year ended Sept. 30 climbed to the equivalent of about $75.4 million from $58.3 million the year before. The company also said its board of directors had proposed a 4for1 stock split.

title: Study Is Critical of Banks on Privacy Bill Submitted by President
description: Among other things, according to the survey, the great majority of banks do not inform their customers of the types of records kept on them; the uses to which these records are put, or allow access to the material, even if it is unfavorable.

title: Fighting Irish Are Grappling With Title IX Notre Dame Grapples With Athletic Equity Welcomed Development Time Ripe for Change
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 13  The first name is Kelly, as in Kelly Tripucka. But the player driving to the hoop at practice here yesterday was not the 6foot6inch Kelly Tripucka, the allAmerica junior forward who has been Notre Dame's leading basketball scorer the last two seasons.

title: U.S. Money Supply Rise Lower Than Expected Loans at Big Banks Are Down
description: Most market participants had expected an increase of about $1 billion, and they responded positively to news of the lower figure. Prices of longerterm securities rose smartly.

title: Conferees Agree on Plan to Ease Noise Standards for Jet Aircraft New Aircraft Preferred
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  HouseSenate conferees have agreed on the outlines of a bill to ease the noise standards for two and threeengine jet aircraft that were to eo into effect in 1983.

title: Oil Tax Compromise Reported in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Senate leaders, working in closed negotiating sessions, reached tentative agreement tonight on a resolution of problems that have held up final passage of President Carter's controversial windfall tax on the oil industry.

title: Film: California Goes To War in '1941':Pearl Harbor Plus 6
description: THE year: 1941. The month and the day: Dec. 13. The hour: dawn. A young woman appears on a misty, lonely beach in northern California. Identified by the logo on the back of her robe as a member of the Polar Bears Club, she runs merrily, innocently, toward the water, shedding her robe as she goes and plunging into the icy waters. The music becomes ominous. The young woman frollicks with abandon as . . . as . . . but I'm not allowed to tell you any more except that this is not only the opening sequence of Steven Spielberg's elephantine new period comedy, "1941," but also the best gag in the picture.The film, which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is an attempt to bend history in a comic way to recall what happened after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor when a lone enemy submarine appeared off our West Coast and ineffectively lobbed a couple of shells into an oil field (transformed into an amusement park in the movie).In the vision put together by Mr. Spielberg and the screenwriters (Robert Zemeckis and Bob Gale, with the help of John Milius, who worked with them on the story), it's something of a wonder that, in the panic that accompanied the attack, California did not disappear under a six-foot blanket of custard-pie fillings, marshmallow frostings, splattered eggs, paint, chicken feathers and the other decontrolled substances that are the ordnance of slapstick comedy.To find a movie to compare with "1941," one has to go all the way back to 1963 and Stanley Kramer's "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World," which, like "1941," was made by a director who has no special knack for being funny. Yet Mr. Kramer did have the sense to hire the very talented William Rose to write the screenplay and some of the world's greatest living comedians to star in the picture.Though they can't give coherence and over-all style to "1941," which documents, hour by hour, the day and the night that California almost died of fright, there are some extremely comic actors at work in this enterprise. Had the film succeeded, it would have been the last critical word on Darryl F. Zanuck's lugubrious mock-documentary about Pearl Harbor, "Tora! Tora! Tora!" though "1941" is far more spectacular.Among the pleasures of the film are John Belushi, who lurches in and out of the action as a monomaniacal National Guard pilot, certain that there's a secret Japanese airfield "somewhere in the clover fields around Pomona"; Dan Aykroyd, as a gung-ho tank sergeant who delivers a very funny peroration on the meaning of Americanism (a speech that is not all that different from some of the things being said these days in connection with the crisis in Iran); the ever-reliable Warren Oates, who plays a certifiably crazy fellow named Mad Man Maddox; Robert Stack, who plays the real-life Gen. Joseph (Vinegar Joe) Stilwell, later the hero of the Burma Road, but who, at the outbreak of the war, was stationed in California and, according to the movie, spent most of that night of infamy watching "Dumbo" at a downtown Los Angeles theater.There are lots of other talented people, including Treat Williams ("Hair"), Toshiro Mifune, Ned Beatty, Christopher Lee, Penny Marshall, Slim Pickens and Wendie Jo Sperber, most of whom are on and off so quickly you tend to forget they're there. Patti Lu-Pone, who plays the title role in Broadway's "Evita," is prominently listed in the cast but doesn't seem to open her mouth here.The huge, profligate scale on which Mr. Spielberg ("Jaws," "Close Encounters of the Third Kind") has constructed "1941" works against the intended hilarity. There are too many characters who aren't immediately comic. There are too many simultaneous actions that necessitate a lot of cross-cutting, and cross-cutting between unrelated anecdotes can kill a laugh faster than a yawn.Everything is too big. We don't laugh at a gigantic riot of servicemen in and around the Los Angeles United Service Organization Club. We are stunned by what appears to be the thousands of extras  enough to fill a Yugoslavian-made biblical epic. The sight is dumb-founding. When, in an old two-reeler, Laurel and Hardy set out to repair the roof of Stanley's house and, instead, reduce it to kindling wood, we are reduced to tears of laughter because, among other things, the scale is small. The house looks like a glorified tool shed. It is not real life but a representation of it, as is all slapstick comedy. In "1941," when a full-size, two-story house falls over a cliff, we groan at the effort.It may possibly be that Mr. Spielberg has chosen gigantic size and unlimited quantity as his comedy method in the awareness that he has no gift whatsoever for small-scale comic conceits. The slapstick gags, obviously choreographed with extreme care, do not build to boffs; they simply go on too long. I'm not sure if it's the fault of the director or of the editor, but I've seldom seen a comedy more ineptly timed."1941" is less comic than cumbersome, as much fun as a 40-pound wrist-watch."1941," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some vulgar language and gestures.

title: Dressing Up in Short Skirts: New Look for Night Life Blass Showed Three Styles
description: Ask Bill Blass what he thinks is the biggest fashion change in the offing and he'll tell you it's short skirts  for evening. For dinner, concerts, parties, theater openings  any time men are in black tie.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Succession Taking Effect at Woolworth
description: Richard L. Anderson, as had been expected for some time, was named yesterday to become president and chief operating officer of the F.W. Woolworth Company when the incumbent, W. Robert Harris, retires at the end of the year at the age of 65. Edward F. Gibbons, 60, will remain chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Shipping/Mails Outgoing
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Trainer's License? $5 Please; Sports of The Times
description: After Willie Classen was punched to death, a man said: Only in boxing can a man walk in with a $5 bill and get a license as a manager or trainer. You have to pass a driving test to get a driver's license. You need a blood test for a marriage license. But a $5 bill will get you licensed to handle fighters.

title: DOCUMENTS IN IRAN LIST DEBTS OF SHAH Papers Released by Central Bank Also Say Family Appropriated Some Nationalized Land
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13  The central bank has accused the deposed Shah and his associates of forging documents, diverting nationalized land into private holdings and illegally taking over a company as part of a plot to embezzle hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Readings for a Milestone At Tomkins Sq. Library
description: The Tomkins Square Library, at 331 East 10th Street on the Lower East Side, will celebrate its 75th anniversary tonight at 6 with readings by representatives of four of the ethnic groups that have lived in the neighborhood: Pietro di Donato, author of Christ in Concrete; Yuri Kapralov, author of Once There Was a Village; Fay Chiang, an arist and poet, and Tato Laviera, a young Hispanic playwright and poet. Mr. Laviera recalls first learning English in the children's reading room of the library.

title: Stage: Oklahoma! Returns to Broadway; Free as the Breeze
description: THERE was a considerable agerange in the audience with which I saw the freshly revived Oklahoma! at the Palace. As I went up the aisle at intermission, I noticed one and all were beaming. Some were smiling because they remember. The others were smiling because they will.

title: New Iranian Delegate to the U.N. Is Scheduled to Assume His Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 Mansour Farhan, Iran's new delegate to the United Nations, was scheduled to arrive here today, a spokesman for the world organization announced.

title: Restaurants Chinese chic with a Continental tone.
description: FORTUNATELY, the absurd custom of serving Chinese food only in dining rooms that resemble the pagoda telephone booths in Chinatown, is falling out of favor. New York now has several highly successful Chinese restaurants decorated in modern or Continental styles, totally devoid of bricabrac that looks as though it came from a souvenir shop in the Hong Kong airport. But nothing we have had so far can begin to compare with the dazzlement of the gleaming modern interior designed for Mr. Chow, the recently opened branch of the restaurant that has already captured chic clienteles in London, where it originated, and in Beverly Hills.

title: Rep. Wilson of California Facing House Ethics Inquiry Ranking in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct said today there was reason to believe that Representative Charles H. Wilson, Democrat of California, had padded his payroll, converted campaign funds to his own use, accepted improper cash gifts and committed perjury.

title: About Real Estate In West Village, Converting From Ink Making to Coops
description: When the Stafford Ink Company went out of business in the West Village couple of years ago, it left behind its old facilities: three old tenement buildings connected to a genuine factory building. The smell of ink lingered on, seemingly imbedded m the floors, as Jeff Bliss remembers it.

title: U.N.'s Relief Chief Defends Soviet
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13  Henry R. Labouisse, a United Nations relief official, took issue today with a Central Intelligence Agency report accusing the Soviet Union of blocking the distribution of food and medicine in Cambodia.

title: Cleveland Mayor Seeks to Restore Business LeadersFaith in the City Plea to Private Sector Other Economic Problems State Help Is Available Economy Is Relatively Stagnant
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 13  Mayor George V. Voinovich's new Republican administration has devoted its first month in office to assessing the extent of Cleveland's fiscal problems, with plans to correct them awaiting the outcome of extensive audits of the city's books.

title: COMPANY NEWS Texas International Is Sought by UNC
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va., Dec. 13 (Reuters)  UNC Resources Inc. announced today that it had offered to acquire the Texas International Company for about $220 million in cash and stock, prompting the NFC Corporation to pull out of a merger agreement with Texas International.TOKYO, Dec. 13 (Reuters)  The Sony Corporation said today that would expand its color television assembly factory at San Diego to help increase production in the United States next year to 700,000 sets from 400,000 this year.

title: The GreenIrish Prime Minister Charles James Haughey
description: DUBLIN ; They call Charlie Haughey the Teddy Kennedy of Ireland. The two share several attributes: popularity among rankandfile political workers, a certain magnetism that comes across even in their inarticulate moments, private wealthand its privileges, membership in a political dynasty and a rather cloudy past. It need hardly be added that Charles James Haughey, like Edward Moore Kennedy, has powerful enemies as well as positive friends.

title: Acrobatics in Atlantic City
description: What happened to the tough standards that state leaders promised when casino gambling was legalized in New Jersey? Now that a temporary license has been granted by the Casino Control Commission to Bally's Park Palace, a subsidiary of Bally Manufacturing, a lot of people in New Jersey are as baffled and disappointed as we are.

title: Proposed Rises in Military Budget Appear to Aid Drive for Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  President Carter's proposal to increase the military budget appeared today to have improved the prospects of Senate approval of the treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: Obituary 10  No Title
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 13 (UPI) Edward A. Mitchell, a former member of the House of Representatives, died Tuesday in a nursing home after an eightmonth illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Opera: Puccini's Rondineat Juilliard The Cast
description: If any Puccini opera can be said to have the sugared eroticism of Massenet, it is La Rondine. It had its premiere in 1917, and it looks back to La Boheme and Tosca as well as ahead to the chinoiserie of Turandot. But it never really has held the stage, thanks to an inferior plot that almost seems stolen from La Traviata and Die Fledermaus, and also thanks to music that some listeners find disagreeably sweet. That said, the Juilliard American Opera Center revived La Rondine on Wednesday night, and it was a pleasant experience. Yes, the music is sentimental. It started as an operetta, commissioned by a Viennese theater, and it is full of waltzes and pretty tunes. But harmonically it is more sophisticated than most operetta; the vocal parts are more difficult; and the melodies, they seldom rise to Puccini at his best (though there is a smashing quartet), contain the essence of the Puccini style. Thus one wonders why the opera has been so neglected.

title: NATO Offers New Plan for Reducing Forces in Europe Focus on Manpower
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13  Foreign ministers of the Atlantic alliance countries approved a new proposal today for reducing armed forces in Central Europe in an attempt to break an EastWest deadlock on the issue.

description: Two welldressed men walked into the Park Lane Dairy at 5905 52d Avenue in Woodside, Queens, around 11 A.M. yesterday and walked out minutes later with $22,000 in cash. The police said that several employees had been handcuffed and that their mouths had been taped.

title: Henley to Welcome Women
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, Dec. 13 (AP)  The Henley Royal Regatta, one of the last strongholds of maledominated sports, is to welcome women competitors.

title: Economic Decline Till Summer Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) The United States economy will be in a recession until next summer, while 1980 inflation and unemployment levels will be considerably higher than it previously forecast, the Business Council said today.

title: Screen: Two Vehicles For Mastroianni at Thalia:An Innocent in Chicago
description: THE extraordinary gifts of Marcello Mastroianni, who has resolutely refused to leave Europe to become a Hollywood star, are the principal subject of the double-bill opening today at the Thalia Theater  Ettore Scola's "My Name Is Rocco Papaleo" (1971) and Elio Petri's "Todo Modo" (1976). Both films, which are being commercially released here for the first time, demonstrate not only Mr. Mastroianni's mastery of his craft but also the vast differences that sometimes exist between the popular European cinema and our own."My Name Is Rocco Papaleo," which appears to have been shot entirely in Chicago (and is being shown here in a dubbed English-language version), is the sort of grim political fable that European audiences accept more readily than we do. It's about Rocco Papaleo (Mr. Mastroianni), a nave Italian immigrant who comes to Chicago from Canada to see a prize fight and, in the course of one mishap after another, becomes politicized.Rocco is nave but he has the tourist guide's instinct for finding the colorful locale. As Rocco wanders from one side of Chicago to the other, from the Gold Coast to Skid Row and back, he is taken up by a beautiful, neurotic model (Lauren Hutton) and assorted bums, pimps and whores. He is ridiculed, patronized, seduced, philosophized to and robbed, finally becoming a not-so-passive observer of most of modern society's ills."My Name Is Rocco" is probably too schematic for American tastes, but once one accepts its style, it is an often fascinating tale of a contemporary pilgrim. Mr. Scola ("A Special Day") is relentless in the way he records the squalid, the ugly and the cruel, though the point of view of the camera is, essentially, that of its humane hero. Because Mr. Mastroianni is a sophisticated actor, we are aware at first that he must play down to Rocco. After we are in the film, however, it's the intelligence of the actor that illuminates the performance.Mr. Petri's "Todo Modo" (taken from St. Ignatius of Loyola's quote, "All means are good to find the divine will") is conceptualized film making that is almost totally unknown in this country. It's a surreal fable about power, politics and religion in contemporary Italy. The setting is a luxurious, modishly decorated underground religious retreat where Italy's ruling elite  then the Christian Democrats  have repaired to participate in various spiritual exercises designed to make them worthy of ruling in God's name.Shortly after its original release in Italy, "Todo Modo" was banned, reportedly according to some Italian newspapers, for being a threat to the re-election of Aldo Moro, who was later kidnapped and assassinated by terrorists.The movie is not easy to follow for someone not privvy to the Italian social and political scene. I assume it is full of inside jokes and references that go over my head. I also tend to resist movies in which we are told of terrible events off-screen, which are never actually explained, and in which one principal character is identified only as "Him," though everyone else has a proper name.It's not difficult to understand, though, that Mr. Petri is convinced that the Christian Democrats, the church and capitalistic society are all rotten to the core. The movie consists of a series of confrontations between the head of the retreat, a world-weary priest played by Mr. Mastroianni, and members of the establishment who have come to the retreat for guidance (and, instead, are murdered one by one).Chief among the politicians is the president, a supposedly pious, modest man consumed by ambition and guilt, a role beautifully played by Gian Maria Volonte. Mr. Mastroianni's performance is limited only by the material, since this is a movie in which political attitudes and positions are more important than character.

title: Bronx Bookkeeper Is Indicted
description: A bookkeeper who worked part time at a Bronx community center was indicted yesterday on charges that he had more than tripled his salary by altering the amounts of his own paychecks, according to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Merola said Allan Larsen, 46 years old, of 3150 Bailey Avenue, was charged with 102 counts of grand larceny in connection with the theft of $12,900 from September 1978 to September 1979 from the Kingsbridge Heights Community Center.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1979

title: 5th Ave. Is a Holiday Mall
description: Fifth Avenue between 34th and 57th Streets will be closed to cars this Sunday and next, and be turned into a milelong mall to let holiday shoppers and strollers enjoy the Christmas windows and a collection of bands, choirs, choruses, dancers, mimes, puppets and other entertainment assembled for the holiday.

title: Stage: Royal Dramas At the Circle Rep Venturesome Duo
description: U NDERthe direction of Marshall W. Mason, the Circle Repertory Company has deservedly established a reputation for presenting new and significant American plays. In a daring maneuver, this week Mr. Mason leaped into the classical repertory with productions of Mary Stuart and Hamlet. Mr. Mason's version of Mary Stuart is an intelligent and direct encounter with this monumental historical tragedy. His Hamlet is curious but never less than intriguing.

title: Auden Poem Cited and Recited at Trial on His Papers Worked on Operas Together Issue of Documentary Proof
description: A dispute between an 86yearold retired Manhattan dentist and the New York Public Library over which of them owns $340,000 worth of manuscripts, notebooks and other papers of the late W. H. Auden has led to a trial in Manhattan Surrogate Court.

title: Publishing: A Novelist's Biography of Peter Finch
description: WRITING, the novelist and playwright Elaine Dundy said once, writing seems to be the only thing in the world a person can do without being asked. Well, it is true that no one asked Miss Dundy to write a life of the actor Peter Finch, who died in 1977, but there was a tug neverthless, an undefined force that drew her to the man.

title: In Our Time Captures Holly Stakes in Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 13  In Our Time followed in the hoofprints of Davona Dale tonight in winning the $54,300 Holly Stakes for 2yearold fillies at the Meadowlands. Davona Dale, winner of this sixfurlong dash last year, was this year's Eclipse Award winner for distaff 3yearolds.

title: Broadway Changes a musical about two couples.
description: CHANGES, a new musical put together, at least in part, by two of the people who put together, at least in part, Your Own Thing, will open at the Theater De Lys early in February. It will star Kelly Bishop, Alan

title: Music by Two Bachs at Brooklyn Academy
description: Music by two Bachs will be per formed by a chamber ensemble this weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue. The program will feature J. S. Bach's Sonata in D major for viola da gamba and harpsichord and his Italian Concerto in F for harpsichord; the Sonata in G minor for oboe and harpsichord by Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach will also be played.

title: Davis Cup Draw Helps U.S. Team Doubles More Doubtful
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 (UPI) The heavily favored United States team facing Italy for the 68th Davis Cup final got its first big break today. The draw paired John McEnroe against Adriano Panatta in the opening singles match tomorrow night.

title: First Hanukkah Light To Be Kindled Tonight
description: The Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, which commemorates the successful fight for freedom of Judah Maccabee begins at sundown today with the lighting of the first candle. During the holiday, also known as the Feast of Lights, an increasing number of candles is lighted on each of eight nights and placed in a menorah or candlelabrum.

title: Themes of Carter and Kennedy Campaigns Are Emerging News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Senator Edward M. Kennedy's bid for the Democratic nomination, unlike other recent challenges to incumbent Presidents, is based less on an argument over what to do than one over who could do it better, his aides acknowledge.

title: Jon Hall, Movie Actor, 66, Dead Star in Hurricaneand Sudan
description: Jon Hall, the actor who played the hero opposite Dorothy Lamour in the original The Hurricane, filmed in 1937, died yesterday at his North Hollywood home of gunshot wounds that were apparently selfinflicted, according to a spokesman in the Los Angeles County Coroner's office. Mr. Hall was 66 years old. His body was discovered by a sister, who said that the actor had been under treatment for cancer.

title: Gold and Energy Stocks Rise Sharply; Strength In Defense Issues
description: Rising world prices for gold and oil sent common stocks based on these commodities sharply higher on Wall Street yesterday. The stock market's action underscored investor concentration on natural resource issues as hopedfor hedge against high inflation rates and the erratic performance of the dollar.

title: Books of TheTimes Full of Demiurges Vagrant, Platonist, Naif
description: MERRY Christmas. More properly, this book should have been published shortly after Easter instead of iust before Christmas. Back around A.D. 100, one of the principal differences between the orthodox Christians and the heretical gnostics had to do with whether Jesus had been resurrected in body or merely in spirit. By A.D. 200, the materialists owned the franchise, authority by apostolic succession was established, and the Gospels according to Philip, Thomas, Mary (Magdalene) and James (the putative twin brother of Jesus) were suppressed. We would have to wait until the 16th and 17th centuries for Martin Luther, Jacob Bohme, George Fox and William Penn. We would have to wait until the last quarter of the 20th century for boutique Christianity, or what to wear in the desert while one's soul is being grilled.

title: News Summary International
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1979

title: New York City Finds Composite Utility Bills Up 35% Over Year Ago
description: Heating, cooking and electricity bills for a composite New York City household were 35 percent higher last month than a year ago  $108.95, compared with $80.56 in November 1978, the Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 13 (AP)A state appeals court today refused to block the prosecution of Gary Thomas Rowe Jr., a former F.B.I. informer, for the 1965 slaying of a civil rights worker, Viola Gregg Liuzzo.

title: Is Deporting Iranians Legal? Is It Wise?
description: Some people thought it unwise to crack down on Iranians with student visas when President Carter ordered the program a month ago. Now a Federal judge in Washington has ruled that the executive branch doesn't even have the authority to carry out such a program. We are far from persuaded by Judge Joyce Green's opinion on the legal question. But we find ourselves joining those who question the program on policy grounds.

title: Governor in Rhodesia Issues Ruling Prohibiting Raids and Executions Press Constraints a Target RHODESIA GOVERNOR BANS MILITARY RAIDS Release of Detainees Pressed Ban Follows Raid on 2 States
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 13 Lord Soames began asserting his authority as Britain's colonial Governor of Rhodesia today, making it clear that the Salisbury administration must cease military raids into neighboring black countries, halt executions and review the cases of about 70 blacks remaining in detention with a view to releasing most if not all of them.

title: I.M.F. Gold Sale Jan. 2
description: The International Monetary Fund announced yesterday in Washington that it would hold its next regular monthly gold auction on Jan. 2, offering 444,000 ounces of bullion at marketrelated prices. The gold will be delivered to the successful bidders later in New York.

title: Fed Warns on Divestiture
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) The Federal Reserve Board said today that it might prosecute bank holding companies that do not get rid of nonbanking activities by the deadline for divestiture, which is Dec. 31,1980.

title: R. L. Stott, ExHead of Exchange; Helped Change Aura of Exchange
description: Robert L. Stott, a member of the New York Stock Exchange for half a century and its chairman from 1941 to 1943, died Wednesday of a heart ailment at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived at 700 Park Avenue.

description: Police Chief Darryl Gates of Los Angeles boasted recently that he could take one of his department's SWAT teams into Teheran and bring out the American hostages alive. That was only slightly more wrongheaded than President Carter's plan for a new quickstrike or rapiddeployment force to police the Indian Ocean and the third world.

title: Reagan Calls For Repeal of Limits On Campaign Funds and Spending Comments on Connally Decision
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 13  Ronald Reagan, who accepted Federal matching funds for his 1976 Presidential campaign, said today that he was opposed to Federal financing of elections and called for repeal of election laws that placed limits on contributions or campaign spending.

title: Portuguese Priest Seeks Backing For an Independent East Timor Little Likelihood of Withdrawal
description: A frail 63yearold Portuguese priest who says he witnessed a threeyear genocidal war in Indonesia against the people of eastern Timor is in the United States seeking help from Congress and the United Nations.

title: Beacon Screens a Bolshoi Festival Those Fabulous Sightlines
description: The Russians are coming this weekend to the Beacon Theater, at Broadway and 74th Street, in the persons of Galina Ulanova, Maya Plisetskaya and Vladimir Vasiliev, to name a few. No, the Bolshoi Ballet hasn't returned to New York. But a fair approximation of the great Soviet company will be on view at the Beacon, with a marathon Bolshoi Ballet film festival running from tomorrow at 3 P.M., when the first showing of the classic Bolshoi Romeo and Juliet, with Miss Ulanova, goes on, to about 10:30 on Sunday night, when the last credits for Miss

title: Dispute in Iowa Attests to Ebbing Confidence in U.S. Domestic Programs Congress Tightens Reins
description: OTFUMWA, Iowa, Dec. 13 When two Republicans here were running for the Legislature last year, the most frequent complaints they heard from voters were allegations of abuses by a community action agency that, through the distribution of Federal funds, had become a major economic power in the area.

title: Automobile Sales Slide Layoffs Set Big 3 Report 25.4% Drop For Dec. 110
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13 (UPI)  The Big Three domestic auto makers reported today that they sold 25.4 percent fewer cars in early December than in the comparable period a year ago 161,212 new cars versus 216,057.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The House of Representatives opened debate today on legislation to provide up to $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees to save the Chrysler Corporation, the nation's thirdlargest automobile manufacturer.

title: Economic Scene Smaller Cars Cost Problems
description: IS there big money in small cars? Apparently not for Detroit, or at least not for years, and untold innovations, to come. The press for better mileage, impelled first by mandated Federal standards and now by the marketplace, has collided headon with the auto industry's traditional strategy of pricing its products by the pound. The late Alfred P. Sloan's insight  that large cars are much more profitable to sell than expensive to make  has been reversed. The industry's sword is turned in upon itself.

title: The Deadly Shells of Sandy Hook
description: SANDY HOOK, N.J.  The National Park Service last summer put up little signs everywhere warning people not to pick up shells on this spit of sand and poison ivy that guards the southern reach of New York Harbor. They are not sea shells but artillery cases and mortar rounds and even cannonballs  the legacy of an old Army ordnance proving ground where guns and ammunition were tested from 1879 through 1917, when it was moved to a new proving ground at Aberdeen, Md.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  The United States gave a guarded welcome today to i Iran's apparent decision to allow outside observers to check on the condition of the 50 American hostages now in their 40th day of confinement.

title: Screen: Widower's Tale In Simon's 'Chapter Two':Second Time Around
description: THE two lovers in Neil Simon's "Chapter Two" have what one of them sardonically calls "a fortune-cookie romance," trading pithy wisecracks and epigrammatic pillow talk. He, George Schneider (James Caan), is a well-heeled writer mourning the death of his first wife when he meets Jennie Mac-Laine (Marsha Mason), an actress who is destined to become his second. Their love affair is a whirlwind courtship with a gentle, lazy pace, which is one of many reasons why the film version feels self-contradictory, or at least incomplete. Fortunately, Miss Mason gives a vibrant, appealing performance that minimizes the movie's troubles and encourages the audience to sit back and enjoy the scenery.George begins the story in a wounded daze, and Mr. Caan acts the injured party convincingly. He rattles around a house filled with memories of his late wife, goes on a preposterous blind date, and listens miserably to the pep talks of his pushy brother Leo (Joseph Bologna). Then he meets Jennie, and they begin to trade smart remarks, with Mr. Caan struggling noticeably to keep up his end of the conversation. He appears much more comfortable with the dolorous aspects of the story than he does with banter.But Jennie blooms so unmistakably during the course of the romance that George's troubles are hardly evident after a while. Robert Moore's direction works so hard to minimize George's importance, In fact, that the last part of the film seems given over to shots of Mr. Caan's attentive back, as he listens to Miss Mason's soliloquies.Mr. Simon's screenplay shifts the emphasis from George, who was the center of his semi-autobiographical play, to Jennie. Perhaps this is why the movie's George never feels like a full character, why his grief isn't real or his rebirth surprising. Although much of the story is set in George's house, which is full of what ought to be revealing artifacts, not much sense of him emerges. His nature, which is supposed to be alternately loving and resentful, isn't well-enough delineated to give the ending of the film much urgency.His status as a famous writer remains similarly ill-defined. Indeed, George's sense of his place in the world, relative to both women and success, is strangely absent in the story; "Chapter Two" could well have benefited from the kind of unobtrusive acknowledgement of celebrity that turns up in "10."There are too few subsidiary characters, too few establishing details, for the story to concentrate so closely on love without becoming artificially narrow.Miss Mason, who has been acting more confidently and looking prettier with each successive movie, is this time every bit as sunny and intelligently appealing as Mr. Simon's screenplay means her to be; the material rests the weight of the movie upon her shoulders, and she carries it ably. The story doesn't move much, and neither, consequently, does Miss Mason's character. So there are no great depths to the performance, but there's a lot of fire. This is especially evident in Miss Mason's scenes with Valerie Harper, who plays her best friend and looks horrifyingly thin, especially in comparison to the radiant, healthy air of Miss Mason."Chapter Two" now incorporates a horse, a tropic isle and Zabar's in the interests of opening up the play. It also involves a fair amount of treacle, especially when the lovers are sweet-talking one another or making a series of cute phone calls. Marvin Hamlisch's score is in much the same vein."Chapter Two" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It includes occasional strong language and one discreet bedroom interlude.

title: Movie: Steve Martin Stars in 'The Jerk':Birthday Surprise
description: A SEEDY character, a man, screeches into a service station in a hot rod, and hands the attendant a very stolen-looking credit card. "Fill 'er up, uh . . . Mrs. Nussbaum?" asks Steve Martin, thus demonstrating his suitability for the title role in "The Jerk." But in the course of playing a happy idiot, Mr. Martin proves himself  often hilariouslyto be nobody's fool."The Jerk," which opens today at the Gemini I and other theaters, is by turns funny, vulgar and backhandedly clever, never more so than when it aspires to absolute stupidity. And Mr. Martin, who began his career with an arrow stuck through his head, has since developed a real genius for playing dumb. This time, he's gone way beyond the silly tricks of those early days  notwithstanding the scene that shows him toddling despondently with his pants at his ankles, wearing a bathrobe and carrying a ping-pong paddle and a chair. This time, the emphasis is on comic sophistication, as when he sends back a vintage bottle in a fancy restaurant, crying to the waiter "Let's splurgebring us some fresh wine!"The initial joke, which like many of the gags in "The Jerk" is reworked so many times it eventually wears thin, makes Mr. Martin the abnormal son of a black sharecropping family  the only child, for instance, for whom tuna, Tab and Twinkies constitute a favorite meal. Finally, on his birthday  about his 35th, it appears  his parents inform him that he is not their natural child. Stunned by this news, he decides to hit the road.The funniest gags in "The Jerk" are the ones that capitalize on sentimental movie traditions, dopey to begin with and made even dopier here. Deciding to leave home, Mr. Martin stands outside his family's shack for hours until a truck comes by. "How far you goin'?" the driver shouts. "St. Louis  how far you goin'" Mr. Martin inquires. "To the end of this fence!" is the answer, and Mr. Martin hops in, with a merry cry of "O.K.!" Several seconds later, the journey is over, and Mr. Martin is thanking the driver for his company. Mr. Martin plays this with a marvelously asinine optimism, and a ridiculous overabundance of good cheer.As directed by Carl Reiner, "The Jerk" is comfortably slapdash; unlike "Oh, God!," which Mr. Reiner also directed, it doesn't seem strained. The laughs aren't steady, but they're persistent, and the film moves fast enough to compensate for its unevenness. Even when it's crude  which is quite a lot of the time  it's not mean-spirited. In comedy this broad, that's half the battle.Mr. Martin and his co-star, Bernadette Peters, work very sweetly together, even when they sing a duet of "Tonight You Belong to Me," carrying sweetness to what could easily have become an intolerable extreme. Miss Peters is all pouts and dimples as the nice girl Mr. Martin marries, the wife for whom he builds a dream house featuring "an all-red billiard room with a giant stuffed camel." Her obligatory counterpart, the predatory female of the piece, is played by Catlin Adams, riding a motorcycle and wearing black leather. Mr. Reiner appears in the movie, in a cameo role that makes use of his ready ability to cross his eyes. Jackie Mason plays Mr. Martin's employer at the gas station, in a sequence that ends with the abduction of a small, white church by a blue Chevrolet.

title: New Route for Office Party; Big Winners at the Party
description: Christmas is upon us, and with it the holiday spirit and the annual office party. Tis time to beckon the meek and the mighty into one room, break out the bubbly, light up the tree and whoop it up. Tis time, at last, to see what the boss really looks like, and to find out who really knows how to have a good time and who does not.

title: POLICE CONVICTIONS RESTORED BY JUDGES; High State Court Voids Freeing of 7 in New York City Bribe Case
description: The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday reinstated the bribery convictions of seven former New York City policemen who had been accused of receiving $20,000 a month from gamblers in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Art People Drawn to drawings.
description: PAUL CUMMINGS calls drawings musings on paper and finds even the most finished of them more immediate and revealing than any painting. At the same time, he believes that the subjectivity of viewers inevitably prevents them from getting exactly what the artist intended.

title: Military Men Join Protest March in Tabriz Retaliation Is Feared
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 13  Tens of thousands of Azerbaijanis, including hundreds of men from the Iranian army, air force and the local police, marched through the streets of this city today, declaring their support for Ayatollah Kazem ShariatMadari and their protest against Iran's new Islamic Constitution.

title: Aide at New Mexico Quits Amid Inquiry Football Players Also Involved
description: Manny Goldstein, the University of New Mexico's suspended assistant basketball coach and chief recruiter, resigned yesterday, one day before he was to appear before the university's athletic council to answer questions originating from an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Koch Renews Criticism Over Bail Despite Acquittal Judge Comments on Criticism
description: Mayor Koch yesterday reiterated his criticism of a judge's action last April in releasing without bail a man subsequenly acquitted of attempting to murder a decoy police officer.

title: Cooper Buys 5.22% Stake in Bausch
description: Cooper Laboratories, a leading producer of medical and dental products, disclosed yesterday that it had purchased a 5.22 percent stake in Bausch & Lomb Inc., the upstate optical company.

title: Export Issue Snags Canada Pipeline
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 13 Canadian sponsors of the socalled prebuilt natural gas pipeline project halted virtually all further expenditures and Preparatory work, saying conditions imposed on fuel exports approved last week by the National Energy Board scuttled plans to use exports to underwrite the cost of early construction of sections of the Alaska Highway gas transmission system.

title: Watkins Glen Keeps Prix Race
description: PARIS, Dec. 13 (UPI)  The International Auto Racing Federation voted unanimously today to retain Watkins Glen on the 1980 Grand Prix Formula One circuit, but switched the original Oct. 12 date for the race to April 13.

title: Kennedy, in City, Denounces President Will We Accept That?
description: DENVER, Dec. 13  Senator Kennedy told a cheering crowd of mine workers today that the United States should turn to coal as a way to end its reliance on foreign oil.

title: Americans in Libya Walk Warily After Embassy Assault Most Dependents Are Gone
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 13  Ten days after the assault, the American Embassy here stands deserted, two of its three floors ransacked, its windows pried open and its walls impregnated with tear gas the Americans used in a desperate attempt to stop Libyans from breaking into the building.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  The Energy Department, as had been widely expected, said today that the Mobil Oil Corporation and the Amerada Hess Corporation might have committed additional violations of oil pricing regulations totaling more than S1.1 billion.

title: Queens School Custodian Slain
description: A 46yearold Long Island man was found shot to death yesterday morning outside a Queens high school where he was employed as a custodian. According to The Associated Press, the police said the man, William Smith of 114 Bernice Drive, East Meadow, had been shot in the head. He was found about 7 A.M. slumped behind the wheel of his car across the street from Springfield Gardens High School. The police said robbery was apparently not the motive.

title: Music: Zemlinsky's Lyric Symphony The Program
description: ALEXANDER ZEMLINSKY is name that will ring a bell in the mind of anybody who has done any reading about the Second Viennese School  the SchoenbergBergWebern axis. He was a wellknown conductor and composer at the turn of the century. He was the only composition teacher that Schoenberg ever had. He also was Schoenberg's brotherinlaw. Schoenberg married his sister.

title: Flyers Top Nordiques, 64 Unbeaten Streak at 25
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (UPI) Goals by Reggie Leach and Bill Barber highlighted a fivegoal third period tonight that carried Philadelphia to a 64 victory over the Quebec Nordiques and extended the Flyers unbeaten string to 25 games, three shy of the National Hockey League record.

title: Union Chief Quits Rail Talks, Warns of Long Strike
description: Edward Yule Jr., president of the United Transportation Union, along with his bargaining committee, walked out of negotiations with the struck Long Island Railroad early today, warning that it could be a long time before the walkout is settled.

description: OTTAWA, Dec. 13  The Supreme Court of Canada upheld minority language rights in Quebec and Manitoba today, including the right of a Frenchspeaking Manitoban not to pay a $5 traffic ticket because it was worded only in English.

title: Art: Morgan Shows Dutch Treasures
description: IT is the particularity of the Dutch royal collections that very few people know what to expect of them. Everyone knows about the great age of Dutch painting  the age of Rembrandt, Frans Hals, Jan Vermeer. Jacob Ruvsdael, Aelbert Cuyp and many others  and almost everyone knows where to look for it. But whereas the ancestral collections in London, Madrid and Vienna are well known to every interested traveler. the collections of the House of Orange are not.

title: Opera: RosenkavalierIn Met Season Premiere
description: THERE are certain operas Tosca, for instance  that can get by and sometimes thrive on one or two firstclass voices. And then there is Der Rosenkavalier, where the casting must be deep and strong if even a passable performance is to be brought off. The Metropolitan Opera, which has had its ups and downs in the matter of deepcasting in recent seasons, put on a Rosenkavalier last night that was one of the ups. This was the first production of the Strauss opera this season.

title: Boxing Banned in State Pending Safety Reforms Proposed by Goodman

title: Art: 18 in the Constructivist Tradition
description: AMONG the many contending schools of modernist painting and sculpture, the tradition of Constructivist art based on the conventions of geometric form  has proved to be one of the most durable. When. some 60 years ago, the great Dutch painter Piet Mondrian urged his followers to ignore the particulars of appearance and turn their attention instead to the straight line and . . . clearly defined primary color, this tradition could already claim some of the most remarkable talents in Europe. There have been notable defections, of course, and a great many schisms within the movement, but through good times and bad, its influence has persisted without interruption down to the present day. Today it continues to command the allegiance of a great many new and ambitious artists.

title: Hebert Hospitalized in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 (UPI)  For mer Representative F. Edward Hbert, Democrat of Louisiana, has been hospitalized with congestive heart failure, officials at Touro Infirmary confirmed, today. A hospital spokesman said that Mr. Hbert, 78 years old, was in stable condition and was receiving treatment for fluid backup in his heart, a chronic ailment that he has suffered. Mr. Hebert, former chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, retired in 1976 after more than 30 years in Congress.

title: Cabaret: Sandy Stewart
description: THE onagain, offagain cabaret policy at Downey's, the restaurant on Eighth Avenue near 44th Street, is on again. And, as has happened before, Arthur Siegel, the singer and pianist, is part of the proceedings. But this time, in addition to Mr. Siegel's enthusiastic recollections of overlooked show tunes, he is joined three nights a week by another singer, Sandy Stewart. (Miss Stewart's three nights this week were Monday through Wednesday, but starting next week she will appear Thursdays through Saturdays.)

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 13 (AP)  The New Jersey Casino Control Commission today called off its 13day experiment with professional card counters, saying that they were costing the casinos too much money.

title: The Editorial Notebook So Many Iranian Students
description: For all the argument about checking on the status of Iranian students in this country, another, prior question has not been given adequate attention. Why are there so many Iranian students in the United States in the first place? The commonly used estimate of 50,000 is probably very low. There may be twice that number. Iranians constitute by far the largest single bloc of the 235,000 foreign students from all countries.

title: Study of Student Grant Program Finds 55% of Payments in Error Rapid Growth Since 1973
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  A Federal study concludes that more than half the payments in the Government's largest aid program for college students have been either too large or too small.

title: WASHINGTON The Tyranny Of Polls
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  In the last few weeks, with the help of Ayatollah Khomeini and Senator Kennedy, President Carter has gained 18 to 20 points in the political popularity polls.

title: 2 Face Ouster in Freeing of Patient Held in Slaying 2 Doctors Face Ouster in Freeing Of Patient Later Held for Slaying
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 13  New York State today began proceedings to dismiss two psychiatrists at Pilgrim State Hospital who, despite warnings from prosecutors about a mental patient's homicidal tendencies toward his former wife, furloughed him last week. The patient, Adam Berwid, surrendered to the police last Friday at the woman's home, where he had kept an allnight vigil beside her body. He has been charged in her murder.

description: LONDON, Dec. 13  The price of gold hurtled to another record in European bullion markets today after word was received that four oil producers, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Abu Dhabi and Qatar, were raising prices.

description: Attorneys for the exiled Shah of Iran said in a Fort Worth court yesterday that his condition may have worsened during his convalescence at Wilford Hall Air Force Hospital in San Antonio.

title: City Aids Queens Merchants
description: Four Queens shopping areas have been given a $750,000 city grant aimed at keeping merchants from abandoning marginal businesses, United Press International reported. The money will be used to remodel storefronts, improve security and create a more appealing shopping atmosphere, Borough President Donald Manes said on Wednesday. The areas are Steinway Street in Astoria, Myrtle Avenue in Ridgewood, Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside and Linden Boulevard in St. Albans.

title: Argentina Said to Bar Shah Over Stand by Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Carter Administration officials reported today that a cablegram sent to Washington by the United States Ambassador to Argentina indicated that one of the reasons the Government there showed no interest in granting asylum to the deposed Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, was Senator Edward M. Kennedy's strong criticism of the deposed leader of Iran.

title: 7 Top Generals Are Held in Seoul Military Power Struggle Is Seen Seven Key South Korean Generals Being Held in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 13  At least seven generals holding key posts in the Seoul area were reported detained early today by the head of the Army Security Command, an internal security service. Two of the generals were reoorted to have been iniured.
