title: Tucson: A Boom Town Becomes a Desert Metropolis; Few Environmental Restrictions
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 11  At the fringes of this city, housing developments are edging close to the Titan 2 missile silos built by the Air Force 15 years ago, seemingly in the wilderness; traffic jams and air pollution have begun to bedevil the vaunted desert life style; city dwellers are at war with ranchers because of fears there will not be enough water for all the people who want to move here.

title: Fear Seizes a Witness And Slows Testimony In Trial of 2 in Slaying
description: The principal prosecution witness in Manhattan murder trial became so frightened that he was unable to speak yesterday when he took the witness stand in State Supreme Court.

title: The Pop Life
description: WE hear a lot of talk these days about dinosaurs veteran rock bands that are supposedly being swept into oblivion by some rude young power popper. But in the last few months the dinosaurs have shown a remarkable tenacity. Several of them are topping the charts just now, and are showing very few signs of becoming extinct.

title: Business Records BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT
description: Thursday, Dec. 13, 1979

title: Miners Changing Strategy in Strikes Fear of Avoiding Commitment
description: DENVER, Dec. 13  The 1,270 delegates at the United Mine Workers convention today gave their new president, Sam Church Jr., another leadership victory by shouting approval of a multimilliondollar selective strike fund to be used in 1981 against the Consolidation Coal Company. Such a strike would mark the first change in the union's strike strategy in 30 years.

title: Byrne Sets Off Carter's Campaign In Jersey by Forecasting a Victory Gibson and Dunn Backing Carter
description: NEWARK, Dec. 13  Governor Byrne started President Carter's reelection campaign in New Jersey today by conceding that the President would lose the primary to Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts if it were held soon, but predicting that Mr. Carter would be the stronger candidate by the June 1980, when it will be held.

title: Holmes to Fight Zanon for Crown
description: Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, will make his next title defense against Lorenzo Zanon of Italy in Las Vegas on Feb. 3, Don King, the promoter, said yesterday.

title: Spice House Wary Spice House Fears a Takeover Several Large Customers AT A GLANCE McCormick & Company Continued From Page 33
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 14  McCormick & Company, the venerable Baltimore spice house that markets parsley, sage, rosemary and thyme, along with a lot of other seasonings and flavorings, is trying to fend off what may be a foreign takeover attempt.

title: SaudiU.S. Relations: New Test Over Oil Costs News Analysis SaudiU.S. Relations: New Test on Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Relations between the United States and Saudi Arabia, strained repeatedly in recent years by both politics and economics, may now face another test. The reason: the world's largest oil exporterand three other producers  Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar  raised prices yesterday by up to 33 percent, the largest single increase infive years.

title: Opera: Leinsdorf Leads Tosenkavalier at the Met
description: There are certain operas  Tosca, for instance  that can get by and sometimes thrive on one or two firstclass voices. And then there is Der Rosenkavalier, where the casting must be deep and strong if even a passable performance is to be brought off. The Metropolitan Opera, which has hadits ups and downs in the matter of aeepcasting in recent seasons, put on a Rosenkavalier Thursday night that was one of the ups. This was the first production of the Strauss opera this season.

title: Rate Rise For Small Saver Set Rate Rise For Small Saver Set ontinued From Page 33
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The agencies that regulate the nation's financial institutions today announced a series of moves aimed at helping the small saver.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: VINNIE SMITH

title: COMPANY NEWS Western Electric In $1 Billion Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Gelco Corporation of Eden Prairie, Minn., had violated accounting procedures in its truck purchases.

title: Your Money On Managing Christmas Debt
description: ALTHOUGH Christmas is a time for giving and sharing, it is also the time at which more people get into debt than any other. So as the holiday season moves toward a climax, a few words of caution are in order.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Handel's Messiah Tomorrow
description: A performance of Handel's Messiah, with chamber orchestra and chamber choir, will be given tomorrow night at 7:30 in St. Ignatius Loyola Church on Park Avenue, between 83d and ?? Streets. In an effort to duplicate the character of the first performances of the oratorio in Dublin in 1732, the parts given to altos will be sung by a countertenor. Johannes Somary will conduct. There is a suggested contribution of $3. For further information, call 8845048.

title: A New Voice for Protestants Robert Lawrence Polk
description: When Robert L. Polk was in his late teens in postwar Chicago, I wasn't headed any place, my life was unfocused  until a minister encouraged him to join a local congregation.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jets Shooting for .500 Mark in Finale Jacobs Filling Shoes
description: MIAMI, Dec. 14  The New York Jets end tomorrow the decade they had entered as the Super Bowl champions. Their final game of the 1970's pits them against the Miami Dolphins at the Orange Bowl, where they won their Super Bowl in 1969.

title: A.C.L.U. IS CRITICAL OF A BURGER LETTER Group Questions Propriety of Chief Justice's Querying a Lawyer in Challenge to Execution Letter Viewed as Personal A.C.L.U. Sees Intimidation Future Guidance Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger sent a private letter last month to a member of an American Civil Liberties Union advisory cornmittee, questioning the role of an A.C.L.U. staff lawyer in seeking a lastminute stay of execution at the Court for a condemned murderer in Nevada.

title: For Teachers Licenses
description: ALBANY  It is time to recognize teaching as a profession. The State Education Commissioner's recent recommendations on teaching as a profession would do this, in the context of other efforts by the State Board ofEducation and the Board of Regents to strengthen the performance of both teachers and students.

title: Hypothermia
description: New York State and City have been ordered by State Supreme Court justice to provide, at least temporarily, 750 new beds for the helpless and hopeless men of the Bowery. Whether government is in fact legally obliged to provide such shelter and for how many people, will be decided later in court. But in human terms, the order obtained by derelicts with the help the Legal Aid Society came just in time: winter is here.

title: Nicaragua Debt Talks Are Opened Bankers Hopeful At First Session More Borrowing Expected Recovery Program Detailed
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 19  Weighed down by a huge foreign debt inherited from the Somoza regime, which was deposed last July, Nicaragua's revolutionary Government today began talks aimed at refinancing $490 million owed to some 90 private foreign banks.

title: At 81, a Blind Teacher Gives a Lesson in Determination Allowed to Audit Courses Challenge Accepted With Zeal
description: It was just a year ago that Jessie Bain finally accepted what her doctors had been telling her for years. When I couldn't read my Christmas cards, she remembers.I just gave up and admitted I was legally blind.

title: British Criticize Kennedy, Citing Personal Traits Emblem of the Distasteful
description: LONDON, Dec. 14 When a panelist on one of the British Broadcasting Corporation's talk shows criticized Senator Edward M. Kennedy the other night, the studio audience cheered.

title: Korean General Filling Key Posts With His Men to Bolster Power Americans Refuse to Comment General's Allies Named Korean General Forces His Allies on New Government Malaysians Are Alarmed
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 14  The general leading a revolt in South Korea's armed forces has moved in the last two days to force the new Government to place men of his choice in key posts left vacant after he arrested 16 senior officers, sources close to the armed forces said today.

title: Basketball Star Is Ineligible
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  Earl Jones, a twotime high school AllAmerican, has been declared ineligible to play in interscholastic athletics this semester. He will become eligible on Feb. 1.

title: Walt Frazier Night at Garden
description: Dave DeBusschere, Willis Reed, Phil Jackson, Cazzie Russell and several other of Walt Frazier's former teammates will be scattered throughout Madison Square Garden tonight. In the private box of David A. (Sonny) Werblin, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, will be Eula Frazier, Walt's mother; Ethel Wynn Frazier, his grandmother; three sisters; his brother Keith, and Walt Frazier 3d, his 12yearold son.

title: Brown Defends Military Budget Says Purpose Isn't to Aid Treaty Iran Statements Less Negative
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Secretary of Defense Harold Brown defended President Carter's proposed military budget today against varied Congressional charges that it was too much, that it was not enough and that it had been decided upon for the wrong reasons.

title: California, Temple Open Bowl Season The Scramblers Brian Broomell of Temple, a scrambler who throws when defenses expect runs.
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.Starting with today's Garden State Bowl at Giants Stadium, the 15 major college bowl games over the next 17 days will provide many examples of the two basic styles of quarterbacks  the pure passer who drops back and the scrambler who runs as well as he throws.

title: KENNEDY SEES DEAL IN CARTER REVERSAL Stance on Aircraft Carrier at Issue  White House Denies a Pact Details of Allegation Helms and Brown Rebut Kennedy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14  Senator Edward M. Kennedy and President Carter were challenging each other's accuracy and integrity today in a dispute over why Mr. Carter had dropped his opposition to building a new nuclear aircraft carrier.

title: Nuclear Blast Destroys Damaged Atom Device
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Dec. 14 (UPI)  The Department of Energy today detonated a nuclear device that destroyed another nuclear device damaged in a 40foot fall more than four years ago.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 28.

title: Tremor Shakes Yugoslav Coast
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  A strong tremor shook parts of Yugoslavia's south Adriatic coast today. The tremor caused alarm in thetowns of Budya and Cetinje and around the Bay of Kotor, officials said, but there were no reports of damage or injuries. Yesterday, a tremor shook the area around the port of Ulcinj, near Albania.

title: BUSINESS Digest Energy
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 15,1979

title: Magazine Wholesaler Alleges a Trade Pact by 2 Rivals,; Investigation Is Under Way
description: A magazine wholesale business based in Queens alleged in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday that two larger wholesalers and a dozen national distributors and publishing concerns had conspired to deprive it of business in an attempt to force it out of existence.

title: Shah Nephew Planned Return, His Sister Says
description: PARIS, Dec. 14  Mustapha Chafik, the nephew of the Shah of Iran, was murdered last week because he was about to return to Iran as a counterrevolutionary, his sister said here yesterday.

title: Sea Search for 4 Suspended
description: The Coast Guard, Navy and Air National Guard yesterday suspended their search of the Atlantic for two men and two women whose 50foot sailboat sank 240 miles southeast of Cape Cod stormyseas a week ago, United Press International reported. Those missing are Gene Weiss of San Francisco, the owner of the boat; Larry Dane of Allen Park, Mich.; Kathy Hamilton of Rockport, Mass., and Roseann Cutler of Hull, Mass.

title: Books of The Times Angst or Entertainment?; A Malaise too Profound
description: Although most crime novels are intended as entertainment, there are some that are penitential. Society, which is to say you and I, is the criminal, and reading the novel is our punishment. The bark of such a book is usually worse than its bite. That is tosay, the author's rhetoric is more painful than his accusations. The quality of his writing is the most serious indictment of our culture, which made it possible. We are sentenced to his sentences.

title: Money
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1979

title: The Fuel Squeeze on Apartment Houses
description: The recorded violations of New York City's housing laws have risen by 60 percent since 1976. More than 1.6 million of them are now inscribed in the city's computers. That's an average of 12 violations for each of the city's 135,000 apartment houses. Many leaky roofs, littered stairwells and walls of broken plaster have gone unfixed for years. It is tempting to call the situation intolerable  or, like Assemblyman CharlesSchumer, to demand more state inspectors at a yearly cost of $20 million. But the mounting total of unresolved deficiencies proves that while inspectors can inspect and housing court judges can fine, no one can force landlords to invest money they do not have or fear lose in a doomed cause.

title: Undefeated Cooney Stops Boone in Sixth Cooney's Jab Effective
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 19  Gerry Cooney took another step upward tonight on the carefully built ladder designed to raise him to the world heavyweight championship.

title: Constance Hicks Is Wed To Joseph F. McMahon
description: Constance Anne Hicks, coanchor of the FarrisHicks Report on WCKTTV, an NBC affiliate in Miami, was married at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday to Joseph F. McMahon, an investigator with the Organized Crime Bureau, Dade County Public Safety Department, inMiami. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., pastor of the church, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. Francis X. McGuire of St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, also in New Canaan.

title: Rabbi Bertram Korn Wrote a Book on Role Of Jews in Civil War Book Called Definitive Study
description: Dr. Bertram W. Korn, senior rabbi at Reform Congregation Keneseth Israel in Elkins Park, Pa., a historian known for his studies of Jews in the American Civil War, died of a heart attack Tuesday while visiting in New Orleans. He was 61 years old and lived in Wynecote, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia.

title: Soul: Shortstuff Is in Town
description: Shortstuff, a blues and soul band from Milwaukee that performed at both the Lone Star and Kenny's Castaways this week, came armed with an impressive array of press notices proclaiming it the best band of its kind in the Middle West. At Kenny's Castaways late Thursday night, this listener found them somewhat uneven, but, in certain respects, intriguing.

title: Golfers, Amid Birdies and Bogeys, Try to Aid Goose; Goose Makes Daily Escape
description: WAYNE, N.J., Dec. 14  By all accounts, it's a wildgoose chase. The goose showed up at Packanack Lake in late October, its head and beak entwined inthe loops of a white, plasticframe used to bind sixpacks of beer or soda. Since then, it has been hissed at, pecked at and ostracized by other Canada geese in the flock of 100 or so that stay yearround on the lake or on the fairways and ponds of the Packanack Golf Club just across Dam Road.

title: British Set Final Session, Giving Ultimatum on Rhodesia CeaseFire Plan Guerrillas Insist on Guarantees
description: LONDON, Dec. 19  Britain, making lastditch effort to persuade the Rhodesian guerrillas to agree to a ceasefire plan, announced today that it was holding the final session of the constitutional conference here tomorrow morning.

title: 4 AMERICANS KILLED IN ISTANBUL AMBUSH Military Man and 3 Civilians Shot Going Home From Allied Base
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 19  Four Americans  a military man and three aircraft company employees  were fatally shot in Istanbul today as they were returning home from work at a North Atlantic Treaty Organization base. The assailants fired from an automobile and escaped.

title: Britain Cites Cut In Trade Deficit
description: LONDON, Dec. 14  The British Government today reported a sharp improvement in the nation's balance of payments during November as industry recovered from the effects of a long engineering workers dispute.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1979

title: Prime Rate Cut to 15% By Citibank Most Big Banks Stay at 15% Reuss Expresses Disappointment
description: Citibank, the nation's secondlargest bank, continued the trend of recent weeks toward lower interest rates by decreasing its prime lending rate yesterday to 15 percent from 15 percent.

title: World News Briefs Red Brigades Gunmen Raid Three Fiat Plants in Turin Thai Says Vietnamese Kill 20,000 Civilians in Cambodia 24 Hurt as Crowds Riot In Northeast India
description: Special to The New York Times

title: The Demand for Iran News Journalists Covering Takeover at U.S. Embassy And Students Tend to Serve Each Other's Needs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 14  The tele vised interview on Monday night with an American hostage, obtained at the price of seven minutes of unedited, primetime speechmaking by one of the student captors, has caused considerable controversy in the United States over whether NBC. and, by extension, the rest of the news media are being manipulated by thesupporters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Spain's King and Queen Visit Equatorial Guinea
description: MADRID, Dec. 14  King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia arrived in Equatorial Guinea yesterday in a gesture intended to consolidate Spain's influence in its former colony, which until four months ago was ruled by a savage dictator protected by the Soviet Union and Cuba.

title: Obituary 10  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Le Grand Cannon Jr., Author, 80
description: Le Grand Cannon Jr., an author of historical novels, including Look to the Mountain, a work highly regarded by literary critics during the early 40's, died Wednesday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: Soviet Five Tops Old Dominion; A Perfect Tour
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 14  To look at the faces on the Old Dominion women's basketball team, you would have thought the nation's No. 1 quintet had won. Tears, mixed with perspiration, streamed down the the players cheeks, and the team clung together in congratulatory hugs.

title: OBSERVERThe Incredible Shrinking Life
description: When we moved to New York we had to get rid of the children. Landlords didn't like them and, in any case, rents were so high. Who could afford an apartment big enough to contain children?

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Special Legislative Session On Mortgage Rate Planned; Legislators Criticise Plan; Parties Clash Over Proposal
description: Governor Carey yesterday abandoned his hopes of getting an increase in the in terest rate on mortgages before the end of the year. But he said he would call a spe cial session of the Legislature to consider the matter immediately following the beginning of its regular 1980 session in January.

title: ExRep. Hebert Hospitalized
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (UPI)  Former Representative F. Edward Hebert was listed in stable condition today at Hotel Dieu hospital under treatment for chronic heart ailment.

title: Around the Nation Nevada Nuclear Dump Bans Nine California Shippers
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Dec. 14 (AP) Nine California institutions, including the University of Southern California, have been temporarily banned from making shipments to the nuclear waste dump at Beatty, according to a Nevada official.

title: Canada Delays on Fighter
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 14 (Reuters) Canada will not make a decision on which new fighter aircraft it will purchase until after the general election campaign, Prime Minister Joe Clark said today. The two finalists for the $2.34 billion contract are the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's F18A and the General Dynamics Corporation's F16.

title: The City; Rent Rises Sought For Fuel Increases
description: A group of landlords said yesterday that the city's Rent Guidelines Board would be asked to approve a fuel passalong rent increase of $12.4 million for tenants in 310,000 rentstabilized apartments.

title: Letter: On Capital Gains Taxes A Stimulus That Cost the Treasury Nothing
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancers Reject New Offer,. Postpone Plans for Benefit Arbitration Called Dead Issue
description: The dancers of American Ballet Theater, locked out since Oct. 29 in a labor dispute with the company, have announced the postponement of a benefit performance scheduled for late December, because of financial and casting difficulties.

title: Carter Described as Encouraged By Hostage Crisis Developments Carter Called Encouraged by Hostage Developments
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  President Carter was reported today to be moderately encouraged by developments in the Iran crisis, and some Administration officials said they were hopeful that at least some of the 50 American hostages would be released before Christmas.

title: Alfred Cardinal Bengsch, at 58 Archbishop of Berlin Since 1962 Raised to Bishop in 1961
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 19  Alfred Cardinal Bengsch, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Berlin and spiritual leader of the 1.4 million Catholics in East Germany, East Berlin and West Berlin, died at his residence in East Berlin last night, church officials announced today. He was 58 years old.

title: Industrial Output Off By 0.5% November Drop Is Tied in Part To Auto Slump Factory Output Off 0.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Slippage in auto sales combined with reduced activity in the home goods and construction sectors led to a decline of fivetenths of 1 percent in industrial production last month, Government figures showed today.

title: A Team That Is Worth $100 Million Sports of The Times
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 14 Brownell Combs was on the phone in his office, talking about the most valuable team of athletes ever assembled.

title: PRESIDENT DIRECTS STRIKERS ON L.I.R.R. TO RETURN TO JOBS SERVICE ON MONDAY POSSIBLE Carter Order Effective for 60 Days as InquiryPanel Is Named 10 Unions Reach Accord
description: President Carter signed an executive order yesterday directing the Long Island Rail Road strikers and their supporters to go back to work for at least 60 days.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: HARRY R. BUSH

title: Turtles Sex Linked to Egg Incubation Temperature
description: Whether the offspring of some species of turtle are female or male appears to be determined, at lea'st in part, by whether the eggs they emerge from have been relatively warm or cold.

title: Soviet Companies to Do Russian Gin Game
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14  The American play The Gin Game, which ended a run of seven Moscow performances, with Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, last night, has been so popular here that it is being translated into Russian and rehearsed by Soviet casts in Moscow and Leningrad.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Dec. 14, 1979

title: Man in Wheelchair Killed by Train
description: REDDING, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)  A quadraplegic was killed last night when his motorized wheelchair became stuck in railroad tracks and he was hit by a train, the police say. Charles Faulkner,22 years old, made frantic calls for help on his citizens band radio after becoming stuck, the police said. Two men who were monitoring the emergency citizens band channel heard his calls but arrived too late.

title: DEADLOCK IS BROKEN 11Year Revenue Proposal Gives the White House a Qualified Victory
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  After more than four weeks of wrangling and intermittent deadlock, the Senate approved today the basic outline of a tax on windfall profits that will divert $178 billion from the oil industry to the Government over the next 11 years.

title: Gen. Laurence Kuter, 74, an Architect of Air Force One of Youngest Flag Officers
description: Gen. Laurence S. Kuter, an architect of the United States Air Force and a planner of air power use in World War II, died Nov. 30 at his retirement home in Naples, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: Ford and His Old Advisers Meet to Talk Current Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  For an hour, nobody mentioned the hostages in Iran.A President and his national security adviser, a dozen White House aides and some professors and reporters talked about politics and inflation and defense spending, but not about Iran.

title: Last Defendant in a Firebombing Is Released From Carolina Prison Long Struggle for Freedom
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 19 (AP)  The Rev. Benjamin R. Chavis, the leader of the socalled Wilmington 10, was paroled today, two weeks ahead of schedule.

title: Patents Computer For Use by Composers Target for Sharpening A Marksman's Aim RearView Mirror Made of Plastic Device Details Conditions On Land, Sea and Aloft
description: WASHINGTON

title: Adm. James B. Ricketts Officer Served in Pacific
description: CUPERTINO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP) Rear Adm. James B. Ricketts, retired, Navy officer for more than 40 years who served in the Pacific in World War II, died yesterday at the age of 77.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths

title: The Wolfe at the Door
description: AKRON, OHIO

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Nets Stymie Knicks Backcourt To Win, 118105 Jordan Gets 25 Johnson Excels on Defense Associated Press
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 14 Word has been spreading in the National Basketball Association that any success the Knicks have depends on how well Ray Williams and Michael Ray Richardson score points, move the ball, make steals and refrain from committing silly fouls, especially at crucial stages of the game.

title: Daughter of Chrysler's Founder And Her Spouse Die in Maryland Donation to National Gallery
description: Bernice Chrysler Garbisch, a daughter of the founder of the the Chrysler Corporation and a major collector of American folk art, died yesterday in Cambridge, Md., hours after the death there of her husband, Col. Edgar William Garbisch, a retired corporate executive who had beenan AllAmerica football player at the United States Military Academy in the 1920's. She was 72 years old and he was 80.

title: U.S. Studies Charges of Poor Work at L.I. Atom Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has begun an investigation of allegations of shoddy construction practices at the Long Island Lighting Company's Shore ham nuclear power plant.

title: Profiles of L.I.R.R. Study Board Members; James J. Reynolds
description: James J. Reynolds, a 72yearold labor relations expert with broad experience in government and private industry, will serve as chairman of the Presidential factfinding board ...served this year with Ida Klaus and Nicholas H. Zumas on two similar boards . . . Was appointed by President Harry S. Truman as a member of the National Labor Relations Board, and served from 1946 to 1951 . . . Served as Assistant Secretary of Labor from 1961 to 1967 and Under Secretary of Labor, the department's No. 2 post, from 1967 to 1969 . . . Was president of the American Institute of Merchant Shipping from 1969 until his retirement in 1978. . . Born on Jan. 8, 1907, in Brooklyn, where he attended public elementary and secondary schools, and graduated from Columbia University in 1928 . . . Worked in Wall Street and became a member of the New York Stock Exchange in the 1930's . . . During World War II, as a naval officer, was an adviser on labormanagement relations to the Under Secretary of the Navy . . . Employed by the United States Pipe and Foundry Company In Bessemer, Ala., from 1939 to 1943 and 1951 to 1953 in various jobs, including director of industrial relations and vice president in charge of employee relations . . . Later was vice president of manufacturing services for Alco Products Inc., of Schenectady, N.Y. . . . Married and lives in Washington, D.C.

title: Teachers to Vote on Offer as Strike Goes Into  11th  Week in Cleveland Busing Program Threatened
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 19  Cleveland schoolchildren have marched against it, and their parents have occupied the Board of Education building to protest it, but the longest teachers strike in Cleveland history will enter its 11th week next Monday with no settlement possible until next Friday at the earliest.

title: Bank in Bronx Robbed of $2,000
description: A gunman fled with $2,000 yesterday after robbing a Bronx branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank, The Associated Press reported. The police said the man walked into the bank, at 2 East Kingbridge Road, at 3:30 P.M., waited in line and then pulled a revolver out of a pocket. The teller handed over the money and sounded a silent alarm. The police said they had no suspects.

title: McEnroe, Gerulaitis Give U.S. 20 Lead in Cup Final A New Phenomenon Crowd Cheers Barazzutti
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 Adriano Panatta called him a new phenomenon, and John McEnroe played that way tonight with another overpowering performance that staked the United States to a 20 lead over Italy in the 1979 Davis Cup final.

title: Arkansas Judge Named To Appeals Court Seat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  President Carter announced today that he would nominate Judge Richard W. Arnold of Little Rock, Ark., to a newly created seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 25.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1979

title: House of Commons Is Dissolved And Election Date Set in Canada Drop in Popularity for Clark
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 14  Canada's 31st House of Commons, elected only last May, was dissolved today and a new election was called for Feb. 18 following last night's stunning defeat of Prime Minister Joe Clark's Progressive Conservative Government.

title: I.M.F. Pressure Embitters Turks Fund Reported To Ask Tighter Austerity Plan I.M.F. Pressure Is Embittering Turks
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 14  Reports that the International Monetary Fund is demanding new austerity measures from Turkey are bringing sharp protests from embittered Turks.

title: Photographer for Six Years
description: After a month of visiting showrooms on Seventh Avenue, I decided there was no point in opening a downtown department store, said Linda Rodin, who instead opened a very personal shop that reflects her own special taste.

title: World Court to Decide Today on Iranian Issue
description: THE HAGUE, Dec. 14 (AP)  The International Court of Justice said today that its decision on Washington's request that it order the immediate release by Iran of 50 American hostages would be announced tomorrow.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: For Timerman, Human Rights Has Been Lifelong Fixation; Rigorous House Arrest
description: When Jacobo Timerman was a child in I Argentina in 1933, world history, in the person of his mother, would periodically erupt athwart the family's meals, outings and other projects.

title: It's a Feast of Lights and Latkes The Symbolism of the Candles Every Day a Celebration
description: Eight first graders at the Manhattan Day School on the Upper West Side, their heads topped with paper flickers of red representing the candle flames of the Feast of Lights, sang of latkes and other goodies as they celebrated the start of the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah yesterday.

title: On Immigration Policy
description: The defects of our present immigration policies are painfully evident in the special trauma of the thousands of refugees from Vietnam, as well as in the persistent illegal inflow of hundreds of thousands of undocumented workers coming here every year, mostly from Mexico. What is not so obvious, however, Is that our policy dilemmas arise not only from the realities by which our aims are severely constrained but also from myths and assumptions that often run counter to the available evidence.

title: SANTA FE FEAR RISES OVER FOUR FUGITIVES Police Chief Says People Are in a Panic Stage as Search Fails to Net Escaped Convicts
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Dec. 19 (AP)  Frightened residents of the affluent neighborhood of Seton Village are locking their doors, loading their shotguns and telephoning the police when a jogger trots by the door.

title: Events Today Music Dance
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA. Verdi's Aida, 1:30, and Ponchleill's La Gioconda. 8.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly described terms of the proposed acquisition of Gamble Skogmo Inc. by the Wickes Corporation. According to the agreement in principle, the acquisition would be for debentures and nonconvertible preferred stock.

title: Abortion: Facing Realities
description: VILLANOVA, Pa.  When I left the United States a little more than a year ago, I believed that the controversy over abortion had been finally, if unhappily, settled. With one million or more legal abortions every year, mostly involving women with no previous history of abortion, there seemedto be a growing committed constituency on the side of the courts, if not of the angels. The vociferous prolife minority appeared to be struggling for a hopeless cause. To talk of searching for a middle position seemed pointless at best.

title: Screen: 4 Dances by the Bolshoi Ballet at the Beacon:The Program
description: Three new Soviet dance films and one old one, each with the Bolshoi Ballet, go on view today and tomorrow at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and West 74th Street.For those who don't care to sit through eight hours straight of screenings  separate tickets are required for each show  some preferences might be in order. There is only one clinker in the lot, and that is "Ivan the Terrible" (1977). By contrast, "Spartacus" (1975), with magnificent performances by Vladimir Vassiliev and Maris Liepa is not to be missed. "Romeo and Juliet," a rerun of the famed 1954 film version of Leonid Lavrovsky's ballet with the great Galina Ulanova is hors concours as a classic and deserves to be seen on those grounds alone.That leaves "Anna Karenina" (1974), the only Bolshoi production in this series never seen live on an American stage. It is very openly a vehicle for Maya Plisetskaya, the Bolshoi's prima ballerina, and any opportunity to see her flick an eyelash is a privilege. The choreography is credited to Miss Plisetskaya  at the 1972 premiere, Natalia Ryzhenko and Viktor Smirnov were called assistant choreographers  and it is not difficult to arrive at the conclusion that Miss Plisetskaya is a greater dancer than a choreographer. Aleksandr Godunov is the passionate Vronsky to Miss Plisetskaya's Anna.With a dramatic score by Rodion Schedrin, this "Anna Karenina" as both ballet and film falls far short of its subject. The tone is more Pierre Cardin than Tolstoy, and Mr. Cardin did, in fact, design the pretty chiffon bustles that Miss Plisetskaya wears from scene to scene. Certainly it is more of a film with ballet than a filmed ballet. Shots of real snow, real buildings and a real train are crosscut with stage sets while the camerawork is strongly stylized.Miss Plisetskaya's sympathies are clearly with the adulterous heroine rather than with the disapproving milieu around her. Yuri Vladimirov as the stationmaster of the novel is nonetheless made to act as Anna's symbolic conscience, and there is a clear attempt at psychological interpretation in such scenes as the pas de trois of Anna, Vronsky and Karenin, portrayed by Vladimir Tikhonov.In its theme of Anna versus society, however, this is a pretty schematic rendering of a great novel. Divided mainly into ensembles and duets, it gives Miss Plisetskaya and Mr. Godunov some fine melodramatic movements, but the choreography is conventional. The celebrated scene at the races comes off best. In bit parts, Nina Sorokina is seen as Kitty and Mariana Sedova as Betsy.Yuri Grigorovich's "Spartacus" already familiar to American audiences, comes into its own here as both ballet and film. The inherent cinematic approach in Mr. Grigorovich's staging of Aram Khatchaturian's score falls perfectly in place. The soliloquies become closeups, and no back curtain is needed for what were the simulated dissolves on stage. Vladimir Vassiliev, as the slave who leads an unsuccessful revolt against the Romans, dances and acts on a heroic level that is the performance of lifetime. Maris Liepa matches him on every point magnificently as the villain, the Roman general Crassus. Natalia Bessmertnova and Nina Timofeyeva round out the ballet's great original cast. With its phalanxes confronting the camera head-on and its slow-motion shots of Mr. Vassiliev soaring through the sky, the film takes its chances. It is also one of the best dance films ever made.Unfortunately, the camera has ruined any strong dramatic points made in Mr. Grigorovich's "Ivan the Terrible." Some of the best choreography, such as the battle with the Mongol invaders, is lost in a blur of multiple exposure. We are left with Yuri Vladimirov's impressively crazed facial expressions and the support given him by Miss Bessmertnova and Boris Akimov. The closeups however, recall Sergei Eisenstein's own film of "Ivan the Terrible," and not to this version's advantage.Screening times for both days are "Romeo and Juliet," at 3 P.M., "Ivan the Terrible" at 5, "Spartacus" at 7 and "Anna Karenina" at 9.

title: BLOOD SUBSTITUTES FROM OIL PROMOTED

Here in this small town on the Delaware border, among the pipelines and brick buildings of an oil company, one of the compounds that could become part of the answer to America's search for a blood substitute was discovered.

title: Social Security Clears $9.5 Billion of Incorrect Wage Report Backlog
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP)  The Social Security Administration has announced that it has Cleared up $9.5 billion of the $69 billion in incorrect wage reports that had piled up since 1937.

title: THE U.N.
description: The crisis over the hostages in Iran once again focused attention on the United Nations. For years, Americans have discounted the U.N. as an inconsequential talk shop, the more so because its talk is usually directed against the United States. But the U.N. is not inconsequential. Its views help shape attitudes in the real world and its decisions have a cumulative impact. When the General Assembly endorses Marxist liberation organizations in Africa and the Middle East, that helps them ultimately to achieve power. When the Assembly decrees that Zionism is racism, Israel  and Jews elsewhere suffers a significant erosion of support among the nations of the world. When the U.N. demands a new international economic order, the industrialized countries are forced eventually to respond to the pressure.

title: Mabry Rogers, Lawyer, Marries Jeanne Edwards

title: America's Oil Weapon
description: The topic of the day, the week and the decade is the price of oil. There is hardly a piece of news that does not turn on it. In Washington, the Senate staggers sleeplessly toward enactment of a windfall tax on newly decontrolled domestic oil. In Ottawa, Joe Clark's Conservative GoVernment falls within hours of imposing a new tax on gasoline. In Tokyo, the Ohira Government, stung by American criticism, hastens to review its oil purchasing from Iran. And in Caracas, the countries that export oil will meet tomorrow to raise prices yet again. What will the countries that import oil do about it?

title: Agencies Affirm and Sustain Man's Dignity

This dignity is allpervasive and permits no exception. To assist the needy in maintaining their dignity, to help them in their daily struggle for existence, is one of the vital functions of Catholic Charities. While conditions change, the essential obligation to help our fellow human beings remains unaitered.

Music: Pierrot Lunaire' By the Kennedy Players
description: Arnold Schoenberg composed Pierrot Lunaire in 1912, and it is one of the seminal works of the century. It is a setting of 21 poems by Albert Giraud in German translation, for voice and small instrumental group. Schoenberg's vocal setting was neither song nor speech; it was a sort of semipitched declamation. In the period after World War II, when Schoenberg and his school became the demiurges of the next few decades, the type of vocal setting represented by Pierrot Lunaire could be heard again and again, ad nauseum to those who never liked it in the first place.

title: D.L. White Fianc Of Elizabeth Buck
description: Mr. and Mrs. Willis R. Buck of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Locke Buck, to Donald Lewis White, son of Edward White Jr. of Wyckoff, N.J., and the late Donna Louise DeVoe White.

title: A Town Named Lonely Keeps Radar Vigil in Alaska
description: LONELY, Alaska, Dec. 15 (AP) Three hundred miles above the Arctic Circle, a radar dome stands watch over the vast skies and hushed landscape of the tundra.

title: Tenants Sue for Their Safety
description: Theresa Tenant leased an apartment in a luxury building with a 24houraday doorman. Some months later, the landlord eliminated a doorman from the graveyard shift, from midnight to 6:00 A.M. One night, after Theresa had entered the lobby, she was assaulted by an intruder who had entered the lobby through the formerly guarded doors. He forced her at knifepoint into her apartment, where he raped and robbed her. She sued the owner, claiming that the assault resulted from the landlord's negligence in failing to provide adequate protection for her and other tenants.

title: Terise Louise Aglietti Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hugo L. Aglietti of Lake Success, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Terise Louise Aglietti, to Martin Stephen Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Levine of Long Boat Key, Fla. A wedding is planned in May.

title: Janet J. Allen, Banker, Bride Of P.P. Vote
description: Janet Joslin Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon E. Allen of Westfield, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Presbyterian Church to Peter Paul Vote, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas G. Vote of The Hague. The Rev. Richard L. Smith performed the ceremony.

title: Explosion Rocks Grain Elevators
description: RALSTON, Neb. (AP)  An explosion rocked a line of grain elevators here today and touched off a fire that burned out of control for more than an hour, the authorities said. Firemen from Omaha, Ralston and three other Omaha suburbs fought the blaze at United Seeds Inc. Authorities said no one was believed to have been inside the structure at the time of the explosion, and no one was injured in the fire.

title: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI
description: A band of clouds extends along a frontal system from the Gulf Coast to the South Atlantic States. A second band of clouds stretches along a front from the Pacific Northwest to the northern Rockies, the Intermoutain Region and the western lake region. Clear skies are apparent In moat other sections of the country.

title: Deaths
description: GLASSERDr. Daniel, doctor in Crown Heights,Bklyn for 37 years, resident of Los Angeles, died on December 11. Beloved husband of Sunny (Erbstein), cherished brother of David devoted father of Dr. Bernard and Dr. Susan Glasser, Dr. Richard and Debbie Glasser and Martin and Rochelle Glasser, loving grandfather.

title: New Mexico Council Asks Coach's Ouster
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 15 The University of New Mexico Athletic Council, an advisory group involved in the hiring and firing of personnel, recommended today that the contract of the school's head basketball coach, Norm Ellenberger, be terminated immediately for violation of Western Athletic Conference and National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: Columbia Professor Studied for Federal Court Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  The Carter Administration has taken a preliminary step toward nominating Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a professor at Columbia Law School and a leading advocate of women's rights, for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: The Case for Deducting Savings Interest
description: The American housing industry is in deep trouble, largely as a result of the shrinking supply of mortgage funds.

title: Liverpool Triumphs, 30, And Retains First Place
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP)  Liverpool defeated Crystal Palace, 30, today and retained first place in the English First Division soccer standing.

title: Militants Say Trials Are Inevitable
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 15A spokesman for the Islamic militants holding the American Embassy said today soon after learning of the deposed Shah's departure for Panama that spy trials for the 50 American hostages here would definitely begin.

title: Time for Making a List and Checking It Twice  for 79 Tax Breaks
description: ALBANY, Dec. 15 (AP)  New York State's Commissioner of Taxation and Finance has reminded taxpayers that they have only a few more weeks to take advantage of tax breaks that can lessen their 1979 tax bills.

title: G.A.O. Calls Justice Dept. Weak On Gaining Cash in Fraud Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP)  The General Accounting Office has criticized the Justice Department on the ground that it failed to make full use of civil penalties to recover taxpayers' money lost through fraud in Federal programs.

title: Funny Work
description: GEORGE S. KAUFMAN never thought he wrote for the ages, and, in the last years of his career, that was a view shared increasingly by critical observers of the American theater. After more than

title: Elizabeth Dugdale Wed To Forrest R. Old Jr.
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Anne Dugdale, daughter of Mrs. Edward McGill of New York and the late Harold F. Dugdale, to Forrest R. Old Jr. took place yesterday in the Christ Chapel of the Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin performed the ceremony.

title: Why Neiman Picked County for New Site
description: LAST week NeimanMarcus, the highfashion department store chain based in Texas, announced that it would move into Westchester County next September. The announcement not only heralded the company's entry into the New York metropolitan area market, but it also provided an insight into how big business feels about the county's future.

title: U.S. to Put Neighborhood Doctor in South Bronx
description: A new Federal program designed to put the neighborhood doctor back into impoverished sections of the South Bronx was announced yesterday by the regional director of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Maryland 113, Catholic 79
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 15 (UPI)  Albert King and Ernest Graham scored 28 points each to lead Maryland to a 11379 victory over Catholic University tonight.

title: European Relatives
description: IT is only when a book like this comes along that one realizes how narrow In scope most of our comparative studies are. Robert Wohl devotes equal space to five countries In the decades between 1900 and 1930: England, France, Germany, Spain and Italy. Of course, one reason why comparativists don't try harder is that no scope is wide enough. In this case,

title: The Nation
description: John B. Connally contends that the combination of election process and journalistic priorities gives incumbent politicians the edge in Presidential campaigns, and events last week supported his view.

title: The Recession: It's just Around the (Next) Corner
description: WASHINGTON  Economists always seem to have particular trouble predicting turns in the economy, but the slip from growth to recession this time around is proving even more elusive than usual. Since the spring, the economists have been in- sisting with regularity that the economy was in a recession, only to be confounded by new statistics suggesting just the opposite.

title: Deaths
description: AARONDr. Harold H. Beloved husband of Hannah. Devoted father of Julie Baraz and Janet Nightingale. Loving grandfather of Daniel, Kamil and Alec. Dear brother of Cecile Cohen and Leslie Aaron. Services Sunday, 11 A. M. at The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Marilyn R. Kaplan Plans a May Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bertram M. Kaplan of Roslyn Estates, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Ruth Kaplan, to Jeffrey George Grody, son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin H. Grody of West Hartford, Conn., and Stratton, Vt. The wedding will take place in May.

title: FARMERS IN FLORIDA PONDER ENERGY GAP
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP)  While the energyrelated problems of Florida tourism dominate headlines, the state's second largest industry, agriculture, quietly assesses its own chances for survival in the face of the same energy shortages.

title: State Attorney General's Office Joins in the Trial on Auden's Papers
description: The State Attorney General's office complained last week that it had not been notified of a Surrogate's Court trial to determine whether the New York Public Library or a retired Manhattan dentist, 86yearold Dr. Edward Kallman, owns a $340,000 collection of papers of the late poet, W. H. Auden.

title: Music: Chamber Society's Sonorities
description: The program for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night concentrated for the most part on the warm midRomantic sonorities of Schumann and Dvorak, but the eyecatcher of the evening was the opening selection, a Quartet for Winds and Piano by Amilcare Ponchielli. A younger contemporary of Verdi, Ponchielli is known as a onework composer, and his lovable piece of grandopera hokum, La Gioconda, is rarely out of the repertory.

title: Fashion
description: After establishing themselves as this winter's smash success, sweaters are getting set to take on spring with snug shapes and nubby knits in citrus colors.

title: Buffalos Are Beautiful but They Graze on Crops, so Alaskans Differ
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Dec. 10 (AP)  The descendants of a herd of buffalo imported from Montana in 1928 for the pleasure of big game hunters are arousing mixed emotions around Delta Junction, far to the north.

title: Share the Bomb Burden in New York
description: Last Tuesday, a terrorist bomb ripped the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, injuring six. Five days before, the Cuban Mission was also attacked. Omega 7, a minuscule but bloodyminded antiCastro group, claimed responsibility for both attacks. Thus the United States, just as it was condemning other countries for failing to protect American missions, was made to look foolish and inept. Still, the outrages can serve an unintended purpose if they finally focus Federal attention on two longstanding police problems. The first is the unfair financial burden placed on New York City by requiring it to assume the national duty of protecting the United Nations. The second problem is worsening thuggery by antiCastro fanatics.

title: LETTERS
description: The Itch To Start A Magazine (Dec. 2) realistically portrays the obstacles a dedicated publisher must overcome in today's chancy, expensive world of magazine creation.

title: Long Island /This Week
description: ALBERTSON  Photographs by Dr. Eugene A. Cohen; through December; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. For hours, CH 87363.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHETHER you like antiques is a matter of opinion, but one visit to Florence Eisenberg's Great Neck shop, called a Matter of Opinion, should be enough to sway anyone's taste toward treasures from the past.

title: Betsey B. Price Wed to Prof. fed Buchwald
description: In the Knox College Chapel in Toronto yesterday evening, Betsey Barker Price, daughter of Mrs. W. R. Rose of Dearborn, Mich., and Dr. S. K. Price of Crown Point, Ind., became the bride of Prof. Jed Z. Buchwald of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Buchwald also of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frank Marvin, a Presbyterian minister of Dearborn.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Amendment to legislation on socalled windfall oil profits to raise the tax base on Alaska's Cook Inlet oil to about $13 a barrel from about $6, passed, 61 to 19, Dec. 10.

title: Equity Library Theater To Do Romeo and Juliet
description: Romeo and Juliet, the Equity Library Theater's fourth production this season, will be staged at the theater's playhouse on Riverside Drive at West 103d Street, Jan. 10 through 27.

title: Linda Joy Landes Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton H. Landes of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Joy Landes, to Brian Andrew Barlaam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Barlaam of Ossining, N.Y. The future bride is a senior at Syracuse University, from which her fianc received a B.A. degree in psychology last year. He is studying for a master's in school psychology at Fairfield University.

title: Liberals Ask Trudeau to Stay
description: Former Prime Minister Trudeau of Canada was asked to lead the Liberal Party in elections called after the defeat of the Clark Government. Page 4.

title: Engineer to Marry Rebecca L. Lapidus
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Lapidus of Fair Lawn, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Lynn Lapidus, to Curtis Drumheller, son of Lenore Drumheller of New York and the late Curtis Drumheller of Clermont, Fla. The wedding will take place next month.

title: GARDENING
description: TO make winter more comfortable for the birds that make the otherwise drab winter garden a more interesting place, feeders and shelters can be erected and kept filled with a suitable mixture of seeds. Chunks of suet provide a much needed energy source to enable the birds to withstand cold temperatures. When natural water sources have frozen over, it is important that water be made available.

title: Jewelers See a Gold Rush on the Island
description: THEY come singly, or in couples, sometimes even a whole family, peering curiously into the store counters as their eyes seem to reflect the glitter of the tiny gems or the dull glow of the gold.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: I walked through the maze of Checkpoint Charlie. On Unter den Linden, I found a taxicab that stood some distance from the omnipresent carbineslung polizei. Without disclosing the exact address, I asked the driver to take me to a certain street on the outskirts of East Berlin. After a halfhour ride, the driver dropped me off in Koenenick. a pleasant residential district of twostory row houses. I waited until the cab was out of sight before finding the right house at the end of the street. But Hans Joachim Schaedlich wasn't hiding; he stood in the doorway and welcomed me. I was afraid for him, but it was too late for him to be afraid for himself.

title: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.3900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO (516) 7470500: SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800: CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767
REGENT BOARD HEAD MAY BAR A 2D TERM
description: ALBANY, Dec. 14  Theodore M. Black, the Long Island publisher who has headed the State Board of Regents the last five years, told the other board members today that he might not seek reelection as Chancellor when his term expired in March.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IN an unusual step, United States Attorney Richard Blumenthal and Chief State's Attorney Austin McGuigan announced last week that they had concluded their investigations into allegations of a building leasing scandal during the administration of former Gov. Thobmas J. Meskill, who is now a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Lehigh Routed By 307
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) Eastern Kentucky used a bruising running game by Dale Patton, Alvin Miller and Nicky Yeast to cruise to a 307 victory over Lehigh in the National Collegiate Division IAA football championship game today.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: TROUBLESHOOTING a balky doorbell or doorchime circuit, either because the unit works only spasmodically or not at all, is one type of electricalrepair job that any doityourselfer can handle safely and easily. This is because the low voltage involved poses no danger of fire or serious shock.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: One of the brightest jewels in the crown of Connecticut public higher education is the system of state technical colleges. For students who desire technical careeroriented education, as opposed to more traditional forms of higher education, these fine schools are eagerly sought after and attended. For Connecticut industry, which chronically complains of too few young people entering the job market, the graduates of these schools are highly prized recruits.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: TROUBLESHOOTING a balky doorbell or doorchime circuit, either because the unit works only spasmodically or not at all, is one type of electricalrepair job that any doityourselfer can handle safely and easily. This is because the low voltage involved poses no danger of fire or serious shock.

title: Idaho Seeking to End Discharge Of Radioactive Waste at U.S. Lab
description: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 15  For nearly 27 years the Federal Government has been dumping radioactive liquid waste into a well in southeastern Idaho. Gov. John V. Evans is insisting that the practice be stopped, even though a recent state study found that there should never be a detectable effect upon the Idaho citizenry from the radioactivity.

title: Reporter's Notebook: In North Iran, Traitors or Patriots?
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 13  His critics in the central Government variously characterize him as a radical, a terrorist or a troublemaker intent on inflaming separatist emotions among the Turkishspeaking Azerbaijanis, Iran's largest ethnic minority.

title: Excerpts From World Court Finding in Iran Crisis
description: THE HAGUE, Dec. 15 (Reuters) Following are excerpts from the official text of the order issued by the International Court of Justice on the United States demand for release of American hostages in Teheran:

title: The Black Hole Casts The Computer as MovieMaker
description: When Walt Disney Productions' liveaction deepspace adventure The Black Hole first flashes on the screen Friday at Manhattan's National and Loew's 86th Street Theaters, audiences will see new kind of Disney animation. Generated by computer rather than drawn by hand, it is the most visible evidence to date of the growing impact of the computer on movie making.

title: The Region
description: In Summary

title: Spoon River Lives Again in Montclair
description: WHEN Edgar Lee Masters' Spoon River Anthology was first published in 1915, the book disturbed many people. Some, however, only pretended to be shocked when reading its accounts of marria2es made in hell. girls

title: Jennifer Wise, Editor, Bride
description: Jennifer M. Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Wise of Bedford, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Francis Marsh 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marsh Jr. of Dedham, Mass. The Rev.

title: Text of Statement By the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP)  Following is the text of the White House announcement on the departure of the Shah of Iran from the United States:

title: Kids' to Lose Theater Base at Stony Brook
description: WITH the administration of the State University at Stony Brook apparently tightening up on the community use of its facilities, Kids for Kids Productions, a nonprofit organization that gives youngsters a chance to perform for other youngsters, will lose its home base at the university after the spring semester.

title: The Changes of Arniri Baraka
description: AMIRI BARAKA, formerly LeRoi Jones, has lost none of his fury since the Black Power movement of the 1960's. He has, however, sacrificed artistic vitality on the altar of his political faith. Selected by Baraka, the work gathered in these two volumes is offered as a summation of his creative life.

title: Dance: Karole Armitage
description: There was one serene moment in Do We Could, the new dance that Karole Armitage offered Thursday night at the Kitchen. It came at the very beginning. The houselights went out, leaving the room bathed in the soft dim light that filtered in from the street through the auditorium's windows. Somehow, it was soothing just to sit while nothing happened. Eventually, however, the stage lights came up and the dancers entered. From then on, Do We Could was compulsively busy.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: UNCERTAINTIES over the potential hazards from the remnants of the thousands of artillery shells, cannonballs and other ammunition that the Army testfired on Sandy Hook between 1874 and 1919 have forced the closing of that popular recreational peninsula  it is known officially as Sandy Hook National Park  for the last five weeks. And nobody is predicting if it will be reopened in time for next summer's swimming season.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: If any one fact about human nature can be taken for granted. it is that people like to see how other people live. Open House means just what it says. You go to see someone. He makes you welcome and gives you something to eat and something to drink. But before all and above all he opens his house. People love it when this happens by direct personal invitation, but they also love it when a house is opened in a more general way, as is the case with countless houses both here and in Europe. Some people decry it as voyeurism. Others exalt it as human curiosity. Either way, they all go.

title: A Christmas Appeal: Give to The Neediest Cases Fund
description: The smell of cooking makes Marcella B. nauseous as she prepares dinner for her two children on the small stove in her welfarehotel room: She is five months pregnant and can barely keep her meals down. The air is dank in the poorly ventilated room, illuminated by the glow of a television set.

title: TV VIEW
description: JOHN J. O'CONNOR

title: Iran Recalling Envoys in France, West Germany and Scandinavia
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Saturday, Dec. 15 (Reuters)  Iran is recalling its ambassadors from France, West Germany and the Scandinavian countries for consultations, the Pars news agency said today.

title: Dr. George Degenshein, 61, Head Of Surgery at Maimonides Center
description: Dr. George A. Degenshein, director of surgery at Maimonides Medical Center of Brooklyn, died Thursday of a hears attack in his Brooklyn home. He was 61 years old.

title: Riders Can Score Conrail Performance
description: THE boss wouldn't believe the train was late? Now you can have it in writing. Last Tuesday, Conrail began a new program designed to ease some of the frustrations of commuting to Manhattan.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: It was nice to see an article in the New Jersey Weekly about Orthodox Jewish day schools [Yeshivas Prospering in Bergen County, Nov. 25]. The brief coverage was quite inclusive and informative, but there was an error.

title: GOING FOR THE GOLD
description: The quadrennial quest for an Olympic gold medal began last week for American skiers with the start of the annual World Cup racing season at Val d'Isre, perched high In the French Alps. Only two months from now, that competition will peak at the 13th Winter Olympic Games at Whiteface Mountain near Lake Placid, N.Y., when American slalom specialist Phil Mahre, and his twin brother, Steve, face an array of the world's finest racers, including such hopefuls as Liechtenstein's Andreas Wenzel. While American women skiers have scored well in past Olympics, the men's team has yet to take a gold medal since Alpine competition was introduced in 1936. Phil Mahre aims to change that in February.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: It will be almost a normal chambermusic week in New York. Almost, because the preChristmas week traditionally is slow in concert halls everywhere. But today will see the KalichsteinLaredoRobinson Trio in Hunter College. Thursday will see Chamber Music at the Y. The Elysian Trio will hold forth on Saturday in Carnegie Recital Hall. And on Tuesday and Wednesday the national conference of Chamber Music America will be held in Abraham Goodman House. On the agenda will be such topics as Getting Your Foot in the Philanthropic Door (and Not in Your Mouth).

title: 4 Give Congress a Troubled Appraisal of the Condition of U.S. Science
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  On the very day this week when four American scientists and an economist picked up their Nobel Prizes in Stockholm, four previous winners trooped up to Capitol Hill and asserted that the American scientific enterprise was in deep trouble.

title: Off Off Broadway Group Attacks Equity Proposal
description: The Off Off Broadway Alliance, an organization of small theaters, said Friday that Actors Equity was forcing almost 100 shoestring theaters out of business over the issue of performers' salaries.

title: Islanders Tied, 3 to 3, In Last Five Seconds
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 15  With 25 seconds remaining in the game, the New York Islanders held a 32 lead tonight and were counting the two points for a victory at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Identical Sets Track Mark In Taking the Gallant Fox
description: Eric Beitia, an apprentice from Panama who faces a sevenday suspension at Aqueduct starting tomorrow, rode Identical to a frontrunning victory in the Gallant Fox Handicap yesterday.

title: Clyde Steals Show In Return to Garden
description: His name and number were announced, and the capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden rose from their seats to let out a thunderous roar that was reminiscent of the Knicks' championship days.

title: Demand for Custom Houses Holding Up
description: At a time when housing starts nationwide are declining, builders say that custom homes often costing $500,000 or more are being built in many areas of the metropolitan region. And real-estate agents report that building lots in the above$100,000 category are still being sold.

title: THE MARKETS
description: It was a week of peaks. Gold bullion soared last week to record prices amid concerns about the beleaguered dollar and the rising price of world oil. The American Stock Exchange, replete with listings of naturalresource plays, scaled new heights in its market value index. While the Dow Jones industrials dawdled, this junior Amex index has doubled since the start of 1978, closing Friday at 240.61.

title: Help Is Available To Crime Victims
description: SEVERAL weeks ago Manhattan Borough President Andrew J. Stein was robbed at knifepoint. He was later quoted as saying, You can't understand it unless you live through it.

title: MUSIC
description: THE Christmas calendar continues to provide a bountiful harvest for Connecticut music lovers, but at least one ensem- ble is taking note of the festival of Hanukkah, which began Friday night. It is the 20voice Connecticut Hebrew Chorale, conducted by Carol Kozak Ward, a group devoted to the performance of works by Jewish composers and other pieces in the Jewish folk or liturgical traditions.

title: Art at the Squibb:
description: ANY conventional description of Eleanor Hubbard's art, currently on view at the Squibb Gallery, would make it seem ridiculous.

title: Clemson 98, Rider 73
description: CLEMSON, S.C., Dec. 15 (AP) Billy Williams and Larry Nance hit for 20 points apiece today as Clemson remained undefeated with a 9873 victory over Rider of New Jeresey.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
U.S. TO END EMBARGO ON RHODESIA TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  President Carter announced today that he would end economic sanctions against Rhodesia at midnight tomorrow.

title: IndianaKentucky Basketball War Whips Up Partisan Passions
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 15  Mention the pairing, and blood pressure automatically rises.

title: Navajo Miners Sue on Radiation
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 15 (UPI)  A $30 million lawsuit has been filed in Federal District Court here contending that seven energy companies exposed Navajo uranium miners to longterm radiation contamination. The suit was filed by a group of Navajo uranium miners, widows and children. It names as defendants the Kerr McGee Corporation of Oklahoma; KerrMcGee Oil Industries Inc. of Oklahoma; the Foot Mineral Company of Pennsylvania; the Vanadium Corporation of America, which merged with Foot in 1967; AMEX Inc. of New York; the Climax Uranium Company of Colorado; and the Climax Molybdenum Co. of New York.

title: Spending By State May Force Tax Rise
description: STORM warnings are being raised almost daily at the State Capitol because Connecticut is facing the prospect of new or higher taxes next year.

title: Crime in Newark: Patience Is Needed
description: THE truth is that Newark residents are afraid to walk the city's streets after dark. That is why they campaigned for a larger police force and why the City Council passed an ordinance mandating a minimum of 1,200 police officers.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FRANK LAZZARO, a floral designer from Floral Park, stood on a ladder decorating a Norfolk pine when he suddenly froze at attention  a reaction that was a holdover from his Army days. Glancing over his shoulder, he had noticed that President Carter was admiring his work.

title: City Hall Brass Finds a Queens Group That's Trained to Grill
description: Joseph C. Hess has been a New York City fireman for 33 years, so he knows all about heat. But in his current job as an assistant chief of the Fire Department, he has rarely felt the flames of public indignation as he did on one recent Monday night in the borough of Queens.

title: Anne Hollis, J.D. Ireland 3d To Wed Jan. 5
description: Anne Fayssoux Hollis, an associate with the government securities department of Morgan Stanley & Company, and James Duane Ireland 3d, a vice president with the corporate finance department of Salomon Brothers, will be married Jan. 5.

title: Letters
description: It is time the U.S. Government took strong measures to resolve the Iranian crisis. We ought to round up our timid friends to support us visibly in this confrontation, which is also theirs, and we ought to warn our adversaries that any meddling in this affair on the wrong side will cost them dearly. We could begin, for example, by issuing a strong demarche to the Soviet Government.

title: Vines Can Be More Than Window Dressing
description: For several years, I lived in the kind of apartment plant lovers dream about. It was located in a renovated brick factory building and had four huge windows which faced south. There was sun all day.

title: Fordham 73, Santa Clara 64
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15 (AP) Dud Tongal scored 20 points in the first half to lead Fordham to a 7369 victory over Santa Clara tonight in the consolation game of the 14th Volunteer Classic. Host Tennessee faced Arizona State in the final.

title: OPEC Role May Expand in a New Oil Era
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 15  Seven years ago, OPEC was an acronym known only to oil specialists; today it is practically a household word. To some, it has been the savior of the third world, to others the scourge of the first. Whatever the perception, since its inception in 1960, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has evolved from what was considered a hapless group of upstarts into one of the most powerful groups on earth.

title: 3Car Wreck Kills Man And Hurts 4 in Queens
description: One person was killed yesterday and four were injured in a threecar accident on the Long Island Expressway in Queens, the police said.

title: U.S. Aids Colombia After Quake
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  The United States is sending 300 large tents and 1,200 doubledecker cots to Colombia to aid people left homeless by the earthquake that struck that country this week, American aid officials said today. The supplies will be flown to Colombia from stockpiles in Panama. The earthquake left about 40 people dead and 500 injured in the city of Tumaco.

title: IN THE NATION
description: If President Carter was trying to rescue the SALT II treaty when he announced a fiveyear increase in the military budget of 4.5 percent a year after inflation, he has agreed to a high price for a ratification he still can't be sure of winning.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Due Today for Brief, Busy Visit to U.S.
description: LONDON, Dec. 15  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is flying to the United States tomorrow for a twoday visit designed to promote and reflect what the British still cherish as their special relationship with the Americans.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR; Energy Problem? No, Leadership Problem
description: I found it symbolic that all Representative Lester L. Wolff, in the article L.I.'s Fate in the Next 20 Years: Energy Is Called the Key [Nov. 18], could offer regarding the future was blurred suggestions that somebody else do something to solve our energy problem.

title: Heirs of Indian Chief Claim Land In Kansas Under an 1825 Treaty
description: WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 15 (AP)  The heirs of the 23 children of a Kaw Indian chief assert that an early 19th century treaty entitles them to land in northeast Kansas that includes an industrial park, a grain elevator, a factory and many homes.

title: Let's Write a Play, He Said. (Why Argue With a Genius?)
description: Since the day Isaac Bashevis Singer and I sat down to turn his erotic campfire tale Teibele and Her Demon into fable for the stage, I've been asked time and again what's he like, and if he's as elusive as his stories. On different days I find myself giving different answers. I'm never entirely sure what the truth is, even though I've worked closely with Isaac for six years on our play which opens tonight at the Atkinson.

title: Laborlike Talks Help Bring $40 Million to St. Paul
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 15 (AP) Using a novel laborstyle negotiating system, Federal, state and city planners have reached an agreement to pump more than $40 million in Federal funds into downtown St. Paul.

title: Segregation in Texas Is Charged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Federal investigators have found a high degree of racial segregation in the state universities, colleges and junior colleges in Texas, according to officials here and in Texas and documents obtained by The New York Times.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: SOMEBODY'S DARLING, by Larry McMurtry. (Popular, $2.50.) The world that's called Hollywood observedthrough the lives and words of an actress who came on strong in her first picture and hasn't done so well since, an aging hack writer of television films and a crude former football player who yearns to be a producer. Our reviewer, Jonathan Yardley, said that, as in Larry McMurtry's earlier novels, the mood keeps shifting and the structure is erratic but the characters are always touching and the prose style is constantly amusing.

title: Jazz: By Chico Hamilton
description: Chico Hamilton is, by his own admission, a projector of emotions, of moods. In the early days of his quintet, 20 or more years ago, the mood tended to be sensuous, exotic, typified by Blue Sands, a drum solo that Mr. Hamilton developed with padded mallets. In those days, his group was also distinguished by the presence of a cello.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTON  On a balmy day last May, a House Armed Services subcommittee met behind closed doors and was told by the Central Intelligence Agency that a Soviet truck manufacturing plant built largely with American technology was producing engines for military vehicles.

title: Freehold Merchants
description: MERCHANTS in this Monmouth County town have come up with a new weapon to help combat competition from shopping malls: a credit card specifically for use in Freehold itself.

title: Company Conference Centers: Getting Down to Business
description: Ten years ago, the First National City Bank bought a 400acre estate in Rye, N.Y., with the idea that it would build a centralized transaction center, a computer plant to keep track of its customers' accounts.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Christmases on the Hudson are the theme of a gettogether along its banks at 3 P.M. today. The Yonkers Audubon Society is sponsoring a tea for anyone interested in the future health of the river, and has invited members of the Fishermen's League of Yonkers, the Clearwater Sloop environmentalists and the Canoe Club of Yonkers to participate.

title: Buoy to Do Man's Job As Lightship Is Retired
description: TONGUE POINT, Ore., Dec. 15 (UPI)  Strike the jack; strike the ensign; strike the Coast Guard flag, and strike the commissioning pennant.

title: On Language
description: In Henry Kissinger White House Years  I presume that's the title; there is no colon after the name, and the byline is placed on top of what would ordinarily be the title all the doubts are grave and all the misgivings are serious. Never a mild doubt or a lighthearted misgiving.

title: Black Gold, Yellow Gold: Both Are Up Again
description: The fears persist. Iran. Inflation. Oil. The pessimism quotient is reflected in the price of an ounce of gold. And that price rose to a record last week touching $464.10 Friday in New York. Gold is now worth 23 percent more than on Nov. 4, the day the 50 American hostages were seized at the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: Ex-Congressman Sherman Lloyd; Utahan, 65, Is a Victim of Cancer
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 15 (AP) Sherman P. Lloyd, a former Republican Congressman from Utah, died of cancer today at his home.

title: L.I.R.R. Crews Prepare for Tomorrow's Rush Hour
description: Five hundred striking Long Island Rail Road employees, returning to work yesterday under a Presidential order, began moving 132 trains into position for tomorrow morning's rush hour.

title: Editors' Choice
description: DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Golding. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A magic fable that explores the darkness of human nature through the fortunes of Many, brushed by fire as a boy during a World War II blitz, and of numerous people he later encounters in Britain and Australia.

title: Dancers With Big Aspirations
description: GATHERED in a basement dance studio at the New York State Theater in Manhattan two hours before a Saturday evening performance of the Nutcracker, the group of leotardclad children looked like countless other young ballet students warming up for class.
