description: OUTSIDE the John A. Mulcahy Campus Center at Iona College early this month, a cold rain was falling, sending students scurrying for cover inside the twostory athletic complex.

In addition, the Interscope Porsche will be entered in all United States Auto Club sanctioned Indy car events.

title: Fire on Yonkers Piers Destroys a Warehouse
description: A fouralarm fire burned out of control for three hours on the Yonkers waterfront last night, and at least one warehouse collapsed in flames. There were no serious injuries or threats to residential or business sections of the city, the Yonkers Fire Department said.

title: CHESS

The 35yearold Gheorghiu, who has been a grandmaster since he was 21, tallied 103.

title: Finding Suckers for Savings Bonds
description: Uncle Sam has a new deal for savers  gullible savers, that is. The Treasury Department has raised the annual interest paid on Series EE U.S. Savings Bonds from 6 to 7 percent  provided the bonds are held a full 11 years. That doesn't sound half bad, unless you know that any corner bank is offering 9.85 percent on amounts as small as $500, and more than 12 percent on $10,000 certificates held for six months.

title: Chaplain Will Wed Ellen Bennett
description: William Tapley Bennett Jr., United States representative to NATO, and Mrs. Bennett of Brussels and Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Pierrepont Bennett, to the Rev. title: The Long Island: A Stress Test for the M.T.A.
description: Four days after he took office last month as the new chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Richard Ravitch held his first news conference. And he had bad news. Before any new wage settlements with the transit unions and without any fare increases, he said, the various components of the M.T.A.  the city's buses and subways, the Long Island Railroad and Conrail  faced deficits of at least $200 million next year.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Mark Blekh, another in the growing ranks of Soviet emigre musicians, made his New York debut last Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The Ukrainianborn violinist, who came to this country in 1977 and is a scholarship student at the Juilliard School, gave the recital as a winner of annual auditions held by Artists International.

title: U.S. Is Worried Over Korea Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  The Carter Administration is deeply worried over the crisis within the South Korean military but for the moment officials say they are still hopeful that the trend toward a  more moderate political structure will continue.

title: PACIFIC RESORT ISLE NEW HAVEN OF SHAH
description: PANAMA, Dec. 15 (AP)  The Shah of Iran arrived here by air from Texas today and then boarded a helicopter to fly to the resort island of Contadora, United States and Panamanian officials said.

title: A Judge Will Decide Proposal for Housing Derelicts on Wards I.
description: A State Supreme Court justice will attempt this week to resolve a dispute over a plan by New York City to move 180 destitute men from the Men's Shelter on the Bowery to a building near the Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island.

title: Miss Luckett Has Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Winkler Luckett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Luckett 3d of Raleigh, N.C., and Pittsburgh, was married yesterday in New York to Edward Lloyd Hinkley 3d, son of Virginia Sargent Binkley of Denver and Dr. Edward L. Binkley Jr. of Tamuning, Guam. The ceremony was performed in Calvary Episcopal Church by the Rev. Stephen Garmey.

title: LETTERS
description: I want to thank Caroline Seebohm for her generous review of my book, With Child: A Diary of Motherhood (Oct. 21). She admires [me] greatly for writing it; it has romantic charm and intellectual insight. However:

title: Jim Marshall in Viking Farewell
description: It's time for me to go, said Jim Marshall, and today he goes. The right defensive end of the Minnesota Vikings leaves pro football after his team plays the New England Patriots at Foxboro, Mass. After he has gone Marshall's extraordinary qualities will begin to be fully appreciated, in the opinion of his coach, Bud Grant. We take Jim for granted, said Grant, and that's been our luxury.

title: City's Christmas Tree Is Stolen
description: ANTIOCH, Calif., Dec. 15 (UPI)  The Christmas tree in front of City Hall was stolen this week while the City Council was debating a $4.2 million program for improved security at government buildings. The theft was discovered Tuesday night just after the City Council approved the measure. I can't imagine anyone stooping so low, Mayor Verne Roberts said. Bah.

title: STAMPS
description: At this time of year we always see stamps that evoke what is in the hearts of mankindto help the less fortunate, such as the children, the handicapped, the old and the infirm.

title: Pop: $5 Show's 4 Groups
description: The $5 Rock n Roll Show, which was presented by Ron Delsener, in association with CBS records and WNEWFM, at the Palladium on Thursday night, suggested more about changes in the rockandroll business than it did about changes in music.

title: What's Doing in ALEXANDRIA, Va.
description: OLD TOWN  Suburban Alexandria, Va., its highrise condominiums and fastfood joints sprawling within sight of the Washington Monument, at first seems no different from the other communities that have grown around Washington since World War U. But the port city actually claimed its place on the Potomac in 1749, long before its favorite son, George Washington, ever dreamed of founding the more famous Federal city across the river.

title: J. F. Welles Weds Maud Iselin

title: Income Tax Conviction Upset on Use of a TV Tape
description: An opponent of income taxes has won a reversal of his conviction in an unusual tax case because the prosecution used a prejudicial videotape of his appearance on a television program.

title: Jordan to Buy 5 Tristar Airliners
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 15 (Reuters) Jordan's national airline, Alia, has decided to purchase five Lockheed Tristars to replace its fleet of Boeing 707 airliners, All Ghandour, chairman of Alia, said today. Delivery will begin in 1981.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: It's Sunday. Do you know where your communications satellite is? The RCA Corporation has been looking for theirs since Monday, when it vanished after a simple orbital adjustment. But RCA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the North American Air Defense Command and other interested parties do not know where to find it. And with its radio transmitter mysteriously dead, the satellite isn't helping.

title: Louisiana Governorship Success Last Weekend Was Encouraging
description: WASHINGTON  Any time the outs win a statewide election in Louisiana and a 9,492vote margin survives the sort of rechecking that is one of the many distinctive factors of that state's politics, the winners can honestly claim a success. But while Representative David Treen's victory last weekend made him the state's first Republican governor in more than a century, it provided his party with its only significant accomplishment in the South in a year that offered several good opportunities to establish beachheads for 1980.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the former ruler of Iran, secretly left the United States this morning for exile in Panama, the White House announced.

Men go to jail or are released, great corporate structures are dissolved or left intact, laws are upheld or overturned, men regulate their future conduct on the basis of what judges write. Most writing, of course, as

title: U.S. Wins Doubles, Keeps Cup
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15  Today may have marked their last hurrah in Davis Cup doubles, and they knew it.

title: Collector Searches for Crosses for 40 Years
description: THEY are made. of gold, silver, bronze, brass, precious and semiprecious gems, marble, jet, pottery, wood, glass, shells, fossilized stone and human hair. There are 450 of them, ranging in size from under one inch to almost one foot in height, and in price from $2 to $450.

title: Texas A. and I. Champion
description: McALLEN, Tex., Dec. 15 (AP) Emmuel Thompson's 100yard interception return gave Texas A. and I. a 2014 victory over Oklahoma Central State today and the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics championship. Texas A. and I., which finished the season with a 121 wonlost record, captured its seventh N.A.I.A. championship.

title: COUNSEL SEEKS CUT IN TROY'S JAIL TERM
description: A lawyer for Matthew J. Troy, the former Democratic party leader in Queens, said last week that because of a legal technicality Mr. Troy's jail term on a grand larceny conviction might be cut sharply.

title: Srah Du Bois Affianced to Robert Kingsley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Seton Maitland Du Bois have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Fisher Du Bois, to Robert Logan Kingsley, son of Robert A. Kingsley Jr. and the late Jennifer Logan Kingsley. Both families live in Philadelphia. A wedding is Manned in June.

title: DEMOCRATS DISPUTE WISCONSIN PRIMARY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  Joseph Checota, chairman of Wisconsin's Democratic Party, has accused party leaders in Washington of twisting party rules to give President Carter an unfair advantage in the race for the state's 75 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Deaths
description: COHENMeyer. We record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed Past Commander. We shall miss his true friendship, noble deeds and deep devotion to our Post. Our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Anguished Searc h to Cure Infertility
description: They arrive one by one at the back door; stealing through the night, afraid to be recognized by the neighbors. A woman answers and they enter, awkwardly taking their places on the brown corduroy couch, clutching their overcoats to their laps like armor. One lights a cigarette. Another twists the ends of her hair.

title: The Violin: SungJu Lee
description: Since making her New York violinist debut three seasons ago as a Young Concert Artists audition winner, SungJu Lee has graduated from the Juilliard School, won a special citation in the 1978 Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, made festival appearances in Korea, the landof her birth, and performed in Hong Kong and Taiwan in addition to a number of American cities. On Tuesday night, Miss Lee came to the 92d Street Y to play her second recital under Young Concert Artist auspices.

title: Deaths
description: LAMBERTStanley, of Short Hills, NJ on Friday, Dec 14, 1979, husband of Ann Horrigan Lambert, father of Ian and Craig Lambert, stepfather of Morgan Mitchell, son of Jeanne Helsen Akerman, brother of Olaf C. Lambert, also survived by 3 grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at Smith and Smith (Suburban), 415 Morris Ave, Springfield, NJ on Sunday, Dec 16 at 2PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Bill to Change the System Cleared Committee Last Week
description: WASHINGTON  To Senator Howard W. Cannon's mind, it was a simple and sensible suggestion. Since the Aviation Trust Fund was overflowing with billions of dollars, he proposed that the Government cut the airline ticket tax  the source of the fund's income  from 8 percent to 2 percent.

title: Notes
description: The architecturally exciting Sydney Opera House, one of the most talked about structures in the world and a leading attraction for Australiabound travelers, is the highlight of several recently announced tours, two of which originate in Sydney and two from the West Coast.

title: Marland Gale, 77, Dies; Was Active in New Deal
description: Marland Gale, a retired New York attorney with the firm of Reavis, McGrath who had been active in various New Deal agencies, died Friday at the Carmel Richmond Nursing Home in the Grasmere section of Staten Island. Mr. Gale, who was a resident of Dongan Hills for many years, was 77 years old.

title: Lindsay Scdtt Wed To Edgar Scott 3d
description: In the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Kennett Square, Pa., yesterday afternoon, Lindsay Scott, daughter of Mrs. Marshall West Jenney of Cochranville, Pa., and the late Josiah Marvel Scott of Wilmington, Del., became the bride of Edgar Scott 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott Jr. of Unionville, Pa. The Rev. Albert P. Neilson performed the ceremony. The families are not related.

title: TelevisionThisWeek
description: 8 P.M. (4) CHRISTMAS LILIES OF THE FIELD. A madefortelevision sequel to the 1963 film Lilies of the Field, in which a former soldier returns to the chapel he helped build years before and finds the nuns need his help again; with Billy Dee Williams and Maria Schell.

title: Fireman Killed and Four Injured As House Burns Near Port Jervis
description: SPARROW BUSH, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP)  One firefighter died, another was critically injured and three others were hospitalized today after they were caught in a burst of flame as they fought a house fire near Port Jervis, the Fire Chief said.

title: POLITICS
description: FURTHER proof that the Democratic race for President has taken a back seat to the Iranian crisis came last week when President Carter's New Jersey campaign was officially launched without a return shot being fired by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Broadcasters Are Switching to Narrowcasting
description: The biggest news in television these days is not that a homevideo revolution is underway but rather that the parent companies of the three major television networks have decided to lead the revolution. In a surprising development, ABC Inc., CBS Inc. and

title: Headliners
description: Igor Stravinsky was a complex man who wrote complex music, but his $3.5 million estate was his alltime masterpiece. After eight years of litigation in France, the United States and Switzerland, Vera Stravinsky, the composer's 92yearold widow, has composed her differences with Stravinsky's children by his first wife. He had left everything to her during her lifetime, but since the estate consists largely of royalties collectible all over the world there was plenty of opportunity for applying the law of other lands and making a great mess. In the end, the settlement gives the Stravinsky children a voice in the administration of the estate, and Mrs. Stravinsky a 38.93 percent community property interest in the royalties.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: How's business? Last spring, long before high interest rates, drops in automobile sales and layoffs in auto plants began making frontpage headlines, the denizens of Publishers Row began mumbling their concern about the state of their trade. The paperbounders were first, with talk of business being sluggish, then flat, then considerably off. Later the hardcover folk began acknowledging that they, too, were troubled.

title: Rhodesia Ultimatum: Did British Misjudge?
description: LONDON, Dec. 16 Four times during the three months of the Lancaster House negotiations on Rhodesia, the British have issued ultimatums to the Patriotic Front guerrilla alliance. Three times, the tactic worked, but yesterday the guerrillas leaders balked in the face of the fourth deadline.

title: Entertainment Events Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier, 8.

title: StrippingA Law onStrip Mines
description: WASHINGTON  When, on Aug. 3, 1977, President Carter signed a law to control the adverse effects of stripmining, he said, I would prefer to have a stricter stripmining bill. Now, a bill, overwhelmingly approved by the Senate, awaits passage in the House. It would significantly weaken the original statute.

title: 32 in U.S. Named Rhodes Scholars NEW ENGLAND MIDDLE ATLANTIC SOUTHERN GREAT LAKES MIDDLE WEST GULF SOUTHWESTERN NORTHWESTERN
description: Thirtytwo United States college students were named yesterday as this year's winners of Rhodes Scholarships for two years of study at Oxford University in England beginning next fall.

title: Colts Rout Giants, 317 Giants Beaten by Colts, 317
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 16  On a perfect day for gloom, the Giants season ended officially today with a 317 loss to a team that had won only four of 15 previous contests.

title: East Europeans Voice Support for the U.S. on Iran A Policy of Equivocation East Germans See Evil Attempts
description: WARSAW, Dec. 16  Although East European governments have been noncommittal or critical toward the United States in its crisis with Iran, support for Washington's position is strong among the people of the region, especially in Poland.

title: AT HOME ABROAD Turning Point In Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Dec. 16  After 14 grinding weeks of negotiation, the London Conference on Rhodesia has come to an inconclusive end. An extraordinary diplomatic effort is in the balance. Violence may again overwhelm the hope for a political settlement in that battered country.

title: Opera: Galina Savova Sings Ada
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's difficulties in finding a plausible cast for Ada this season were further complicated Saturday afternoon when Rita OrlandiMalaspina became indisposed. Thechoice for her replacement in the title role fell on Galina Savova, a soprano from Bulgaria. Miss Savova, who has been acting as a cover artist for the Met's performances of La Gioconda, was making her American debut as well as her first appearance at the Met.

title: Cowboys Oust 'Skins From Playoffs Fantastic,'says Landry
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 16  Roger Staubach and the Dallas Cowboys, with spectacular drives that resulted in two touchdowns in the last 140 seconds, eliminated the Washington Redskins from the National Football League playoffs today.

title: Strangler of Wife and 3 Children Is Found Hanged in Ossining Cell
description: A Queens man serving 15 years to life in the Ossining, N.Y., Correctional Facility for strangling his wife and three young children was found hanged in his cell yesterday.

title: Commodities Looking  At Buyers And Sellers
description: AS frenetic buying of gold and silver pushed prices of the metals to record levels last week, professional Wall Street analysts were more interested in the identities of the buyers and sellers than in the actual market values at any given moment.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 PM.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Play: My Sister's Keeper Staged by Hudson Guild Battling Siblings
description: IN My Sister's Keeper, Ted Allan has written a twocharacter psychological play that may be clinically accurate but is dramatically unconvincing. So much so that by the second act his people seemed to be demonstrating psychoanalytical propositions in a textbook rather than the conflicts of genuine human beings. Mr. Allan is more puppeteer than playwright in this exercise at the Hudson Guild.

title: Around the Nation Union Leaders Call Strike Of Chicago Transit System
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UPI)  Union leaders called a strike tonight against the Chicago Transit Authority, a move that would disrupt train and bus service for 200,000 commuters tomorrow morning.

title: Last Week's Active Issues
description: For the week ended Dec. 15. 1979

title: Sports World Specials
description: Running for His Life

title: CORRECTION
description: Terms of the proposed acquisition of Gamble Skogmo Inc. by the Wickes Corporation were incorrectly described in Business Day on Thursday. According to the agreement in principle, the acquisition would be for debentures and nonconvertible preferred stock.

title: In Hong Kong, 8778 Can Be the Road to a Fortune
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 16  They are small and rectangular and made of metal. with numbers and letters like other license plates. But that is where the resemblance ends.

title: Connecticut Reactor Emits Radioactivity Level Is Termed Safe Control Valve Failed
description: Radioactivity that exceeded Federal limits by up to 40 percent was released into the atmosphere for 45 minutes after a malfunction at the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant at Haddam Neck, Conn., yesterday morning, but the plant's operator and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said the accident posed no danger to the public.

title: Back to the Bargaining Table
description: WITH only seven shopping days left before Christmas, some baseball players are getting restive. Their everloving helpmeets expect to find swatch of sable or a star sapphire under the tree on Christmas morning, but the World Series paychecks that were to have provided these trinkets have not arrived. Some noses could be out of joint.

title: World News Briefs Actions Against P.L.O. By Libya Are Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Libyan authorities closed the Palestine, Liberation Organization's office in Benghazi today and expelled three P.L.O. representatives from the country, the Palestinian news agency Wafa said.

title: Murder Trial of 9 in Radical Group Seen Heating Up Diatribes Delayed Hearings
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16  The trial of nine selfstyled revolutionaries, accused of the murder of a policeman in 1978 shootout, is expected to heat up in its second week of testimony, according to prosecutors and lawyers who are assisting the defendants.

title: Soviet Navy Building Its First NuclearPowered Carrier Other Developments Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  Defense officials say they have confirmed that the Soviet Union is building its first nuclearpowered attack carrier, marking a major step forward in Moscow's plan to assemble a powerful deepwater navy.

title: The U.N. Today
Cornelia Wallace Going Full Tilt In Palm Beach Hails Family Treatment
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. Cornelia Wallace, the flamboyant former First Lady of Alabama, has become deeply involved here in what she calls a cause that's greater than myself the rehabilitation of alcoholics.

title: GEORGE HALAS JR., 54, DIES IN CHICAGO President of Pro Football's Bears Was Son of Team's Founder
description: George Halas Jr., the president of the Chicago Bears of the National Football League since 1963, died yesterday of a massive heart attack at his home in Chicago's North Side. Mr. Halas, who had served in the team's administration since 1950, was 54 years old.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices Mark Time Pending Oil Moves
description: The credit markets, after seeing interest rates shoot upward in October, descend part way in November and then start climbing again in the first half of December, are winding up the year without a deepseated sense of direction. This week, they must find outhow much the price of oil is going to be raised and then begin to assess the impact on fixedincome investments.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PEOPLE We were so poor, George Burns writes of his Lower East Side family, as one of 12 children, that our idea of somebody being rich was the Feingolds who lived on the corner. They had curtains on the windows. Making a rare public appearance today, one of America's bestknown comedians will meet new and loyal fans as he signs copies of his new book, The Third Time Around.

title: Egorov Knows He's on Pianistic Spot Subject to Scrutiny
description: CLASSICAL music has been marked in recent years by performers who have made their marks through clever promotion by managers and publicity agents. This is nothing new in American culture, to be sure  remember Jenny Lind. But since Van Cliburn's eruptiononto the music scene in 1958, we have seen several similar attempts to start careers by the exploitation of a competition victory or some quirky biographical twist. Eugene Fodor and Lazar Berman come to mind as recent examples.

title: SHCNARANSKY CASE: AN EMIGRE'S VERSIONFormer Prosecutor in Soviet Says Dissident's Accuser Worked for K.G.B. to Save Father
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 15  A significant footnote has been added to the case of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Jewish dissident whom President Carter publicly defended when Soviet authorities arrested him in 1977 on charges of working for American intelligence.

title: TV: House Calls, Situation Comedy, in Premiere
description: CHARLEY is a bachelor doctor at Kensington General. Ann, recently divorced, is the hospital's new administrative assistant. Amos, chief of surgery, is senile but, as they say, shrewd. Combineand mix vigorously, and the not unpromising result is House Calls, a new weekly situation comedy having its premiere on CBSTV tonight at 9:30.

title: Harvard Education Cost Rising to $9,000 a Year
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16 A rise of 11 to 14 percent next year will bring the cost of a Harvard education to more than $9,000 annually, apparently the biggest increase in tuition, room and board in the 343year history of the college, a Harvard official said.

title: Only a Better Defense Is Better
description: There is more than one motive for President Carter's pledge to raise military budgets by more than 4.5 percent a year until 1985. Militarily, he argues that some defense preparations have for too long been neglected. Diplomatically, he thinks his plan will pay the Senate's ransom for ratification of the SALT II treaty, itself a contribution to security. And politically, Mr. Carter thinks it will position him neatly between those who still judge military spending as too high and those who find it dangerously inadequate.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: 10Year Plan for Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 15 (Reuters)  Taiwan's ruling party, the Kuomintang, has approved a 10year development plan that calls for economic growth to be maintained at an annual 8 percent rate in real terms throughout the 1980's. It would increase Taiwan's gross national product to $125 billion at current prices by the end of 1989.

title: Slowdown Leads to Stoppage
description: McDONOUGH, Ga., Dec. 16 (AP)  The excitement, drama and display of youthful basketball skills were missing when Henry County faced Fayette County in a high school basketball game won by Henry County because of insufficient action last night.

title: Kentucky Bail Plan Cuts Defendants'Time in Jail Outlawed Bond for Profit
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 13  John Meyers was arrested on charges of armed robbery in September, and a judge set his bail at $10,000 full cash. Unable to raise the money, Mr. Meyers faced the prospect of languishing in jail until his trial date in January.

title: Egyptian Prices Up
description: CAIRO, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Egypt increased the prices of gasoline, cigarettes and soft drinks today in an attempt to reduce the country's big budget deficit and maintain subsidies on essential goods. The Government put the 1980 budget deficit at $1.41 billion, but Western economic experts said $2.8 billion or more was likely.

title: Public in Poll Considers Half U.S. Taxes Wasted
description: More than half the taxes sent to Washington, Americans feel, are wasted, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Ellyne LeVine Is Bride of Arthur Nordlinger, Engineer
description: Ellyne June LeVine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Bruce LeVine of Tampa, Fla., was married there yesterday to Arthur Lee Nordlinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Nordlinger of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Martin Sandberg and Cantor William Hauben at Temple Rodeph Sholom.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOMEONE  no doubt a novelist  once said that a journalist is a novelist who has not yet written a novel. If that observation is true, then Susan Cheever, formerly a writer for Newsweek, and Laurence Gonzales, an editor and reporter for Playboy, are no longer journalists. On the other hand, they are not yet quite novelists.

title: Obituary 1 4 No Title
description: ISRAEL B. GREENE

title: Postal Employee Says He Warned Of Job Hazards Asserts Death of Handler Need Not Have Occurred
description: A former mail supervisor at the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center in Jersey City charged yesterday that a 25yearold mail handler might not have died in a conveyorbelt accident on Saturday if postal officials had heeded his repeated warnings about conditions at the center.

title: Officer Shoots Patient In an Emergency Room
description: A Brooklyn man being treated this morning at Kings County Hospital for wounds suffered in an attempted suicide was shot and critically wounded by a police officer in the hospital emergency room when he a attacked another policeman, the police said.

title: Innovation and Unity Mark Coal Union Convention News Analysis
description: DENVER, Dec. 16  In the 20 years since the late John L. Lewis retired after 40 years as its president, the United Mine Workers of America, the oldest and once the most powerful of industrial unions has become a fractious and anemicparody of its former self.

title: Control Over School Budget Long Debate on Recovery Plan Ends In Agreement for Monitoring by City News Analysis A LittleKnown Warning Cause of Current Deficit Mayor in a Delicate Position Residual AuthorityCited
description: In the end it came down once moreto the State Financial Control Board's calling the tune.

title: Second Burial
description: SUMMIT HILL, Pa.  On a gray, cold morning when the wind swirled down from the ragged mountains that rim this old coalmining town, Pennsylvania, the family and friends of Gregory Tallick recently gathered to lay the 69yearold former miner to rest.

title: 16 in Correction Posts Accused of Negligence In Escape by Morales
description: Acting on a report issued five months ago, the New York City Department of Correction is preparing charges against five department captains and 11 guards for alleged laxity in the escape of William G. Morales, the Puerto Rican terrorist, from the Bellevue Hospital prison ward last May.

title: Rivera Frescoes in Detroit At Center of Museum Battle Hazard to Murals Cited
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16  Rivera Court is a peaceful place, where visitors to the Detroit Institute of Arts stroll past the frescoes of Diego Rivera, the Mexican artist who tried here to capture the essence of industrial America in the tumultuous 1930's.

title: West Point Congregation SendsGift for a Neediest Cases Agency
description: Enclosed is the Designated Offering in the amount of $194.03 from the Episcopal Congregation of West Point, the letter read. Please contribute this amount to Protestant Welfare Agency. It was

title: Mexican President Unexpectedly Opposes Legalization of Abortion Campaign Is 4 Years Old
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16  Amid a growing campaign in Mexico in favor of the legalization of abortion, President Jos Lpez Portillo has unexpectedly described abortion as a barbaric practice and has expressed outright opposition to it.

title: Hostae Crisis Hurts Some Iran Businesses But the Impact Bypasses Many
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13  The crisis between Iran and the United States that grew out of the Nov. 4 seizure of the American Embassy and the incarceration there of 50 hostages has introduced uncertainties and complications into some lines of Iranian business.

title: 19 Senators Ask Carter for Delay On Arms Treaty Letter Said to Recommend Bolstering of U.S. Forces
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  Nineteen Senators have sent a letter to President Carter asking him to consider delaying vote on the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union until after next year's Presidential election.

title: Mosque Attack Called Attempt to Seize King
description: The attack on the Grand Mosque in Mecca by Moslem guerrillas was really an attempt to kidnap King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, Newsweek magazine reports in its current issue.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Arrives For Talks With Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher arrived in the United States today for an official visit during which she will hold talks with President Carter on two sensitive issues, Iran and Rhodesia.

title: The City 4 Men Shot in Legs Cult Fight Suspected Aiding Handicapped Woman Found Slain In East Side Flat
description: Four men were shot in their right legs just before midnight Saturday at 68th Street and Lexington Avenue, outside Hunter College.

title: Sporting Gear Compact Exercise Equipment
description: Exercise equipment need not be bulky or heavy, especially when the principle that resistance is equal to the force applied is involved. Such a machine is the Portagym, which is small enough (5 by 10 inches) to carry in an overnight bag and adjustable so that a powerful man or a 6yearold child can use it with equal benefits and without danger of injury. The exercise consists of pulling a nylon rope, wound around a cylinder. The resistance matches the force supplied by the user. The base can be held by the feet or attached to a wall or a door, allowing different parts of the body to be exercised. The apparatus sells for $60, plus shipping, and is available from Portagym International, 2 A Byram Brook Place, Armonk, N.Y. 10504, (914) 2732171.

title: Article 1 No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Soccer Fans Fight in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  The police fired into the air and troops were called in to break up a battle between rival soccer fans at a match between Ugandan and Tanzanian teams yesterday. Tanzanian spectators, mostly soldiers in civilian clothes, stormed onto the field and attacked the referee and members of the Ugandan team. Several of the players were taken to a hospital.

title: Pollution Damages Carnations
description: DENVER, Dec. 16 (AP)  Air pollution, which causes flowers to wilt, is eating into carnation crop yields in Colorado, the nation's second leading producer of flowers, says a Colorado State University study. Dr. Joe J. Hanan, a horticulture professor, said the pollution was responsible for a 15 percent reduction in flower crop yields, totaling at least $9.7 million annually.

title: New York's Many Christmases New York's Christmas Is a Million Different Things
description: Christmas isn't something that just happens, it something you make, and there was solid evidence last week that New Yorkers  and thousands of visitors, too  were busy making Christmas in million ways that reflected the diversity and the spirit of Manhattan as it prepared for the great holiday.

title: News Summary International Energy National Metropolitan
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1979

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: IRAN STAGES MARCH TO DENOUNCE PRESS Crowd Demands Foreign Reporters Be Expelled if LiesContinue 300 Covering Events in Iran Concern About Some Reports
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16  In an implicit warning to Western reporters working in Iran, the authorities staged a public march through the streets of Teheran today to denounce alleged imperialist and Zionist distortions in the foreign press coverage of events here.

title: Constance Lynn Longstreet  Married to Thomas Compton
description: Constance Lynn Longstreet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Carl Longstreet Jr. of Sea Girt, N.J., and Thomas Adkerson Compton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Sothoron Compton of Greensboro, N.C., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dudley L. Rapp performed the ceremony in the Trinity Episcopal Church in Asbury Park, N.J.

title: Opera: Francis Robinson Stars The Arena Wants Blood
description: THE stage of the Metropolitan Opera House was set last night: the backdrop, the white and silver Viennese ballroom from Act II of Der Rosenkavalier; the cast, luminaries from the Met. Itwas not just another night at the opera, though. It was an onstage patron's dinner given for Francis Robinson, tour director of the opera, but better known to millions of television viewers as host of Live From the Met. And for a man who has worked behind the scenes for 32 years, it was fitting indeed that he should at last appear on the great stage itself  not as a performer, but as the guest of honor.

title: Patricia Zohn Wed To N. H. Pfeiffer
description: Patricia Jane Zohn, daughter of Sally Barnett and Arnold H. Zohn, both of New York, was married yesterday to Norman H. Pfeiffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Pfeiffer of Bremerton, Wash. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the couple's Manhattan apartment.

title: Shah Says He Feels at Home on Tropical Island
description: CONTADORA ISLAND, Panama, Dec. 16The deposed Shah of Iran, resting on this resort island where peacocks roam the airstrip, told reporters today that he felt much better and said he felt at home here.

title: Illinois Fire Kills Four
description: ERIE, Ill., Dec. 16 (UPI)  Two children and their parents were killed and another child was seriously burned in a fire in a frame house yesterday, the authorities said. Officials said the blaze apparently began in the kitchen and quickly spread smoke through the house. Firemen found Warren Bealer, 38 years old, and his wife, Patricia, 37, in a downstairs bedroom. Their daughter, Elizabeth Beth Ann, 13, and 5yearold son, B.C., were found dead upstairs. The Bealers 15yearold son, Warren 3d, the only survivor, was in critical condition at a hospital,

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: The Four Days of Christmas Varying Strategies
description: For millions of American workers, today is the last Monday they will work in 1979.

title: Gov. Carey Says He Wasn't Told Of Scotto Tactic Knew of No Evidence on Donations, He Asserts
description: Governor Carey, who testified as a character witness for Anthony M. Scotto, says he was not told that the defense in the Scotto trial was going to allege that illegal cash contributions were made to his campaign for reelection last year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Betz Laboratories Inc., Trevose, Pa., a manufacturer of watertreatment chemicals, has elected as chairman Robert B. Marsh, who will retain the title of chief executive officer. Also elected were John F. McCaughan as president and chief operating officer and Louis P. Gala as executive vice president.

title: KHOMEINI IS SILENT ON HOSTAGE TRIALS Ghotbzadeh Deepens Confusion Captors at Embassy Adamant
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16  There was no word today from the one man, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who will ultimately decide whether the departure of the deposed Shah from America will mean Islamic trials for the 50 hostages being held here.

title: LIBYA, KEY SUPPLIER FOR U.S., INCREASES PRICE OF OIL BY 15% HOPE FOR UNIFORMITY UPSET On Eve of OPEC Talks, Indonesia Also Lifts Rate Past Level Set Thursday on Saudi Crude
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 16 Libya, one of the largest suppliers of crude oil to the United States, has raised the price of its light oil by $4 a barrel, to $30, retroactive to Nov. 1, Izzidin alMabruk, Libya's oil minister, said today.

title: Letters Solution to an EastWest Quandary Called Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: United Auto Workers Due to Ballot on a Tentative Pact With Caterpillar Ratification Steps Discussed
description: PEORIA, III., Dec. 16 (AP)  Membeit of the United Automobile Workers union are expected to vote this week on new contract with the Caterpillar Tractor Company following a 76day strike, the longest in the concern's history.

title: Jazz: The TaylorRoach Duo Concert
description: THE longawaited Cecil TaylorMax Roach duo concert finally took place at Columbia University's McMillin Theater Saturday night  it was postponed this fall when Mr. Taylor was hospitalized for short time. One anticipated the eveningwith special interest because Mr. Roach, the most creative and adventurous drummer to emerge from the first generation of modern jazz in the 1940's, would be working with the premier jazz pianist of the 60's, and because Mr. Taylor has often been exceptionally demanding in his encounters with other artists.

title: U.S. May Ease Auto Regulations In Effort to Save Industry Money
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16  The Carter Administration is making a fundamental reassessment of Government regulation of the ailing American automobile industry, placing emphasis on cooperative rather than adversary relationships.

title: Shell Criticized On Jet Fuel Fee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (Reuters) Four international airlines have accused the Shell Oil Company of discriminating against its international customers in sales of jet fuel and asked the Government to reimpose fuel price and allocation controls.

title: Playoff Jigsaw Needs Only One Piece Buccaneers 3, Chiefs 0
description: The National Conference of the National Football League put its playoff format into focus last night after the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Dallas Cowboys had nailed down division championships to join the Los Angeles Rams, who clinched their seventh straight Western Division title a week ago.

title: City U. Trustees Will Meet Today In Effort to Pick Hunter President New Board Still Unnamed
description: The City University of New York's Board of Trustees, divided over the merits of four final candidates for the presidency of Hunter College, will meet today in another effort to choose a new president. However, selection of a candidate is considered highly uncertain, university officials said yesterday.

title: Computing Impact Of Oil Price Rise
description: Here is the way oil analysts compute the effect of the Libyan price increase on retail prices in the United States: If Libyan crude oil goes up $4 a barrel in price, thatequals almost 10 cents for each gallon in a 42gallon barrel. Because Libya supplies only about 10 percent of the oil used in the United States, the overall price of oil in the United States should rise by only 10 percent of the 10 cent increase, or 1 cent a gallon. However, the price of about 10 percent of the oil produced in the United States is tied to the price of oil imported from Libya, so that adds another penny to the overall effect of the Libyan price increase.

title: The Selling of the Mets: An Amazin'
description: LIKE the making of the President, the selling of the Mets is a complex and intriguing operation. But the intrigue will reach a critical point this Thursday at 1 P.M. when money bids must be submitted by the finalists from 21 original candidates competing to win one of the most intensive auctions in baseball history.

title: HOW TO AID THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the follow ing organizations:

title: Polish Dissidents Say 80 Are Held by Police In Move to Bar Rallies Dissident Group Issues Statement
description: WARSAW, Dec. 16  The police have arrested more than 80 activists throughout Poland in an apparent effort to head off protest demonstrations planned for tomorrow and Tuesday, dissident sources said today.

title: Truth in Mileage
description: Is your 1979 sipmobile a secret tippler? Millions Americans are discovering that cars with high fuel efficiency ratings from the Government in fact deliver far fewer miles per gallon than expected. At the least, prospective buyers need a more realistic guide to fuel efficiency than the numbers currently published by the Environmental Protection Agency. And it is time take a hard look at Government requirements to see whether the public would be better served by tougher standards over the next five years.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: DEPARTURE OF SHAH IS CALLED A VICTORY BY IRANIAN OFFICIAL BIG CHRISTMASFOR CAPTIVES Foreign Minister Promises Group of Clergy Will Visit Them Carter Not Displeased
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, in the first authoritative Iranian response to the departure of the Shah from the United States, said today that it was a victory for Iran.

title: KENNEDY CONVINCED CARTER IS IN FRONT Senator Believes President Will Be Ahead Until Campaign Turns to Economic Matters Finds Carter in Front Stresses Economic Issues Some Resistance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  Senator Edward M. Kennedy says he now believes that President Carter is the frontrunner for the Democratic nomination and that he will probably remain so until the Iranian crisis ends and the campaign again focuses on economic issues. If he is to defeat the President, Mr. Kennedy believes, that shift in public attention must come by late winter or early spring.

title: TURKISH UNIVERSITY NO LONGER STORMY Ankara School, a Center of Revolt in Early 1970's, Is Now Called a Model for Education
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 16  A university near here that only a couple of years ago was known as a house of anarchy is now being acclaimed as a model for Turkish higher education.

title: California Is Increasing Trade With Pacific Rim California Is Increasing Trade With Pacific Rim
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16  In the general boom in trade between the United States and the countries of the Pacific Basin, California, in particular, has been taking special advantage of the trend. This year California's international trade will reach nearly $42 billion. Some $30 billion of that business will he with Asian countries  a sizable increase over 1978.

title: Rhodesian Rebels and British Talk
description: LONDON, Dec. 16  British officials had informal contacts today with representatives of the Patriotic Front guerrilla alliance, in the continuing effort to end the deadlock on terms for a ceasefire in the Rhodesian civil war.

title: Paterno BravesA Stormy Season
description: AFTER reading and hearing about Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State and his players who just go out to have fun blocking and tackling each Saturday, Coach Bo Schembechler of Michigan remarked in 1977, Nobody is that good, and no program is that perfect.

title: Advertising Resolving Dispute on Ad Content
description: AMERICAN Express has stopped running those television commercials for its traveler's checks that drew complaints from at least one competitor and were under investigation by the ad industry's selfregulating organization. The advertiser says that the schedule was completed.

title: ESSAY Patience Is Not Fortitude
description: WASHINGTON  What is our standard of success in the Iranian crisis? What criterion will determine if the Carter Administration succeeded in meeting the challenge?

title: U. S., Wary of Islamic Upheaval, to Increase Broadcasts to Moslems Extra $2 Million for Radio Liberty
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  In a response to what the White House perceives as the prospect of longterm ferment in the Moslem world, President Carter last week approved portions of a plan to expand United States radio broadcasts in Persian and in seven languages of Moslems in the Soviet Union, Administration officials say.

title: Outdoors: Competitive CrossCountry Skiing Snowballs Ski Guides
description: CROSSCOUNTRY skiing is a sport whose time has come in a hurry. Recognized as a recreational pursuit in America only in the past decade, cross country now has some four million participants. It is, according to a Federal survey, the fastestgrowingoutdoor sport in the country. The ranks are expected to increase at the rate of 35 percent a year for at least the next three years, says Howard Peterson, marketing director of the United States Ski Association.

title: Do Female Scientists Face Bias? Columbia Sociologist Says No; Disbelief at Findings
description: A new study by a Columbia University sociologist asserts that there is little discrimination against women in the upper levels of American science, thereby flying in the face of widespread beliefs and data to the contrary.

title: Cartwright: KnicksCenter Of Attraction Bill Cartwright: Center of Attraction
description: MORE than anything else, Hal Fischer remembered the touch, the remarkable thing that happened whenever Bill Cartwright shot a basketball. Fischer had coached Armed Forces basketball teams, he had coached teams in international competition, he had given clinics all over the world, he had evaluated players as the West Coast scout for the Knicks, but he had rarely seen anything like this.

title: WorkerDirectors: Exportable?
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany Eugen Loderer, acting chairman of Volkswagenwerk A.G.'s supervisory board, gathered his materials for the board meeting: the proposal for a $50 million purchase of a Chrysler subsidiary, an outline for another $50 million in overseas plant outlays and a review of the company's outlook.

title: Zambia Finds That Life as Rhodesia Neighbor Isn't Sunny
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 12  The theme, and the theme song, of Zambia's Ministry of Information and Broadcasting and Tourism is Zambia in the Sun, a hopeful catch phrase not literally attainable in these days of the rainy season,nor figuratively within reach this morning, 24 hours after Rhodesian forces bombed and strafed two battalions of Patriotic Front guerrillas 50 miles south of here.

title: Expert on Iran Suggests Sending  Group to Reason With Khomeini
description: Before President Carter applies economic sanctions to Iran, a group of Islamic scholars should be sent to reason with Ayotollah Ruhollah Khomeini, an IranianAmerican expert said yesterday.

title: Soviet Emphasizing Withdrawal Of Its Offer on Nuclear Weapons Talks Are Expected Anyway
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16  The Soviet Union repeated today that it was no longer ready to withdraw mediumrange nuclear forces from the European theater after last week's decision by NATO to produce and deploy 572 new American missiles in Western Europe starting in 1983.

title: Soviet Georgia Jews Win Prime Time Spot Voice Overflows With Longing
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R.  Isai Goldshtein, a Jewish humanrights activist who has been refused permission to emigrate, bounded from a table laden with festive dishes and bottles of Georgian wine to greet two visitors.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: David Bookstaver

title: Royal Visit Disrupted In Equatorial Guinea
description: MALABO, Equatorial Guinea, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Crowds of hungry Equatorial Guineans rioted while waiting for food parcels last night outside a hall where a banquet was being given in honor of King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain.

title: The Theater: Teibele and Her Demon' A Lover From Hell
description: IESPECIALLY liked the idea of a demon with a head colds There he is, straight from the fiery nether regions, stripped to the waist in anticipation of a night's amorous revelry and shivering like crazy.

title: Dividend Meetings
AntiAmericanism Said to Ebb in Greece, but Is Still a Political Issue Socialists Demand Ship's Ouster Only One Car Firebombed
description: ATHENS, Dec. 16  When the United States missile carrier Albany sailed into Greece's main port of Piraeus recently on a courtesy call, there were no antiAmerican incidents. In contrast with the turmoil of previous years, there were no demonstrations or firebombings ofAmerican cars, and the ship's 1,000 crew members enjoyed an unthreatened five days in Athens.

title: A Return to Cincinnati Suggested
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 16 (UPI)  The lead singer of the Who suggested that the rock group return for a well organized show in Cincinnati.

title: Christmas Retail View Is Uncertain Inflation And Weather Cloud Results
description: The year's Christmas business, with a little more than a week to go, remains uncertain across the nation, reflecting not merely the expected inflationrecession concerns but also the slowing influence of warm, unseasonal weather.

title: Supplementary OTC Listings
description: Week Ended Dec. 14, 1979

title: Study Finds Illicit Aliens Are Burden in Northeast
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 16 (AP)  The apparent increase in illegal immigrants in the Northeast could create a permanent underclass of people with no way out of poverty, a report says.

title: Tunneling to Start for Buffalo Subway Service Scheduled for '84
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 16  Deep in a rock cave 95 feet under a State University campus here, workers are assembling the first of the giant mechanical moles that will bore part of the city's new 6.5mile subway system.

title: CableTV Rights Fight May Stall Start of Queens Service for Years Division Opposed by City
description: A major battle over cable television rights in Queens  potentially the nation's largest single cable franchise  is heating up amid threats of new litigation that could further delay installation for years.

title: Rachel White Adams Dies at 74 Wife of Top Aide to Eisenhower
description: LINCOLN, N.H., Dec. 16 (AP)  Rachel White Adams, wife of Sherman Adams, former assistant to President Eisenhower, died today at her home. She was 74 years old. A spokesman for the family said she suffered a heart attack.

title: De Gustibus Savory Reference to Derby Day Food
description: There is probably not a food anthology in or out of print that doesn't refer to the Christmas dinner served in the Cratchits home in Dickens's Christmas Carol.

title: Shell Shrapnel Kills Soldier
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Dec. 16 (AP)  A soldier died after being struck by shrapnel from an exploding artillery shell during livefire exercises on Friday at Fort Campbell, the Army reported yesterday. Maj. Larry Bates, spokesman for the 101st AirborneAir Mobile Division, said the artillery round, believed to be from a 105mm.weapon, apparently fell short.

title: Nets Lose, 115112, Despite 52 by Newlin Like the Old Celtics
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 16  It was a game that, in retrospect, appeared to defy logic, at least from the New Jersey Nets point of view. The Nets had so many highlights tonight against the Boston Celtics that the outcome, a 115112 loss in overtime, seemed almost incomprehensible to them.

title: Michelin in Nova Scotia Labor Strife; Michelin Awaits Result of Labor Law Strife; New Plant Set for 1882; How Far Do You Go?
description: TORONTO, Dec. 16  A major labor confrontation involving an American union, a French tire manufacturer and a Canadian provincial Government has erupted in Nova Scotia.

title: Radio Contact Is Reestablished With Voyager 1 on Trip to Saturn
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 16 (UPI) Scientists reestablished radio contact today with the Voyager 1 spacecraft that had been lost 660 million miles from Earth since last Thursday on the leg of its voyage from Jupiter to Saturn.

title: Sports News Briefs Miss Austin Beats Miss Navratilova
description: TOKYO, Dec. 16 (AP)  Tracy Austin, the 1979 United States Open champion, easily beat Martina Navratilova, 62, 61, and won a $200,000 international women's tennis tournament today.

title: Three Die and Three Are Injured In a Crash on 195 in Connecticut
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 16 (UPI) Two New York men and a Connecticut woman died and three other persons were injured, one of them critically, in a twocar crash early today on Interstate 95, the state police said.

title: Market Place Opportunities In Energy Crisis
description: EVER since such stocks as Avon Products and Simplicity Pattern peaked as growth vehicles, Wall Street has been looking for the next group of companies to lead the market.

title: Snag in Peace Talks Dismays the British in Rhodesia Governor's Spirits Lifted
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 16  The unease felt by British officials here at reassuming colonial responsibility ahead of a ceasefire has worsened considerably with the latest impasse at the peace talks in London, according to officials close to the newly appointed Governor.

title: Torrijos's Quick Assent on Shah Surprised Jordan Torrijos Quickly Said Yes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  It was 10 P.M. Tuesday when Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, walked into the living room of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera in Panama City. The two men, who had grown close personally during the long negotiations over the Panama Canal treaties, greeted each other like father and son.

title: 70 Arrested at New Haven Rock Concert by the Who Released on Bail
description: About 70 people were arrested on a variety of charges at a rock concert by the British group the Who in New Haven Saturday night.

title: Japan's Trade Deficit at Peak
description: TOKYO, Dec. 16 (AP)  Japan reported a record trade deficit in November but said trade with the United States showed a larger surplus than in October.

title: LateSeason Successes Bolster Jets Losing Inspires Meetings
description: Perhaps it was the euphoria of victory, or the carefree feeling in a jet plane, or it might have been induced by what was in the glass he enveloped with a huge hand, but Coach Walt Michaels permitted some insight into himself after the Jets closed out their season on Saturday with a victory at Miami.

title: Bridge: Brazilian Star Finds Going A Bit Difficult in Regionals
description: The onset of the Christmas season did not prevent a throng of players from converging on the New York Hilton Hotel for the winter regional championships during the weekend.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Iranian Economy Shrank by 12% This Year, Central Bank Estimates Comparisons Held Unfair
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13  Iran's product:on of goods and services contracted by 12 percent in the months following the revolution of last winter, according to an unpublished estimate by the staff of the nation's central bank. Such a drop wouldbe a catastrophe in a Western industrialized nation. In this country, however, battered by political upheaval and with the deposed Shah's grand economic plans in disrepute, many Iranians would regard it as a triumph merely to stem the loss of production and jobs.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has there ever been a National Collegiate Athletic Association champion in both basketball and foot. ball in the same school year?

title: LOWTAR CIGARETTES TAKE MARKET LEAD For First Time, More Than Half of Brands Are Listed in Category by Federal Trade Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  For the first time, more than half the cigarette brands on sale are lowtar varieties, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

title: Notes on People June Bride
description: A nonpolitical announcement came from the Kennedy family over the weekend, with the news that Mary Courtney Kennedy, one of the 11 children of Ethel Kennedy and the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy is to be married next June to Jeffrey Robert Ruhe, an employee of the American Broadcasting Companies.

title: Barbi Charash Wed To Reuven Yellin
description: Barbi Nan Charash, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leon I. Charash of Woodbury, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Reuven Yellin, son of Menachem Yellin of Holon, Israel, and the late Mrs. Yellin. Rabbi Daniel Fogel of the North Shore Synagogue in Syosset, L.I., performed the ceremony at the Cold Spring Country Club in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Cantor Phyllis Cole assisted.

title: Part of Wayne's Estate Is Sold to Pay Tax Bill
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 16 (UPI)  Tax problems have forced the sale of the Red River Land Company, coowned by the late actor, John Wayne, for more than $30 million. It is one of the largest farm and ranch sales in Arizona history.

title: Influential FreshmenAid College Fives Meyer's 601st Victory
description: James Worthy, Teddy Grubbs, Clark Kellogg, Steve Stipanovich and Isiah Thomas came into the college basketball ranks this season with the tags freshman of influence. Saturday night, four of them displayed their importance in winning roles. But Thomas got into early foul trouble and Indiana, the nation's topranked team, suffered its first defeat in five games.

title: Chamber: Trio Plays At Hunter Three by IrvingDue in April
description: JOSEPH KALICHSTEIN, Jaime Laredo and Sharon Robinson, who play the piano, violin and cello in the KalichsteinLaredoRobinson Trio, began appearing together as participants in chambermusic concerts at the 92d Street Y. Twoyears ago, as an outgrowth of that experience, they decided to become a formally constituted chamber group, and they have since begun touring on a regular basis. Yesterday afternoon, their schedule took them to the Hunter College Assembly Hall as part of the People's Symphony concert series.

title: Chess. In the Depths of Last Place Lies Promise for the Future A Forgotten Precedent
description: It was predictable that Ji Jingxuan would have a difficult time in the strong Milan Vidmar Memorial Tournament in Bled and Portoroz, Yugoslavia, for China entered international chess only in the last few years.

title: Ford Labor Executive
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16  The Ford Motor Company has announced the appointment of Peter J. Pestillo, 91 years old, as its new vice president for the union relations staff, effective Jan. 21. Mr. Pestillo is currently vice presidentof employee relations at the B.F. Goodrich Company. Mr. Pestillo succeeds Sidney F. McKenna, 57, who last week announced early retirment from Ford as its vice president for the union relations staff after 38 years with the company.

title: Udall Is Reported Ready to Endorse Kennedy Bid Reportedly Rejects Advice
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Representative Morris K. Udall, President Carter's most persistent opponent for the 1976 nomination, has decided to endorse Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the 1980 race, sources close to the Congressman and the Senator said today.

title: Scotto's Dealings With Politicians Are Subject of New Investigations New Investigations Examining Scotto's Dealings With Politicians Providing Funds and Workers Advice on Port Position A Hand in Other Appointments Carey EncouragedDeparture Scotto on State Board Not a Cup of CoffeeResponse to Rackets Allegations Relationship to Governor Role in Newspaper Strike Settlement Before Election Day Investigation of Fabber Leases With the City Higher Standardsin Effect Favorable Financial Terms
description: Official scrutiny of Anthony M. Scotto, the Brooklyn longshoremen leader, did not end with his conviction last month on charges of taking payoffs from businessmen on the waterfront, and it will not end next month when he is sentenced.

title: Takeover of Grand Mosque Said to Be Political Act Fundamentalists Joined Group
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  A senior Saudi Arabian official says that the take over at the Grand Mosque last month was accomplished by 500 disciplined, heavily armed guerrillas intent on destabilizing Saudi Arabia.

title: Washington Watch Advertising And Oil. Politics
description: WASHINGTON IN an uncharacteristic burst of anger, Treasury Secretary G. William Miller growled that he had been misquoted and persuaded Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman of the Mobil Corporation, to pull out ads that would have run in six newspapers. nere are still some unanswered questions in tne unusual tale of two avenues (Pennsylvania and Madison), which, even on the basis of what is known, show some of the raw tendons of oil politics.

title: Korean Testifies He Alone Planned Park's Murder Kim Was Close Friend of Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 16  The confessed assassin of President Park Chung Hee said in court here yesterday that he had planned the killing alone and had acted without assistance from a general who was close to the building in which Mr. Park was shot.

title: Yet Another Assault on Abortion
description: However tired others may get, the House never seems to tire of pushing the Senate against abortion. Congress recently reached a compromise in its annual argument about whether to pay the costs of abortions for poor women. But annual arguments must seem too infrequent; the House has tacked antiabortion amendments to yet another piece of legislation even though knows the Senate will balk.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Marvis Frazier Wins on a Knockout
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, Dec. 16 (AP) Unbeaten Marvis Frazier, son of a former world heavyweight champion, Joe Frazier, scored his 43d victory as an amateur today, leading five American gold medalists in the first World junior amateur boxing championships.

title: Susan R. Levy Is Bride Of Dr. Robert Mascitelli
description: Susan R. Levy and Dr. Robert J. Mascitelli, an attending cardiologist at the New York University Medical Center, were married yesterday evening at the St. Moritz Hotel by State Supreme Court Judge Philip J. Chetta. The bride is with the patientservice administration of the New York Hospital.

title: Robert Kohler Marries Joan Fishman, Executive
description: Temple EmanuEl in New York was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Joan E. Fishman, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Hodax of Jamaica Estates, Queens, to Robert Kohler, son of Mrs. Samuel Kohler of West Orange, N.J., and the late Mr. Kohler. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated. The bridegroom is assistant national director of the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: A Clerk Saved Ali From Jail
description: AT the time, the Supreme Court's decision appeared be so unanimous, so harmonious, so decisive. That morning Muhammad Ali, driving through the South Side of Chicago, parked his greenandwhite Lincoln Mark III and went into a neighborhood store for a glass freshly squeezed orange juice. A moment after Ali strolled out, flipping an orange in the air, the store owner hurried after him.

title: Unity Dayin U.S. for Hostages
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  President Carter signed a Congressional resolution today designating Tuesday as national unity day in support of the 50 American hostages in Iran. He asked individual Americans and organizations to observe that day by prominently displaying the American flag.

title: Bobcat Pelt Exports Curtailed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)  Five states will not be allowed to export bobcat pelts this winter as the result of a Federal judge's decision. The Defenders of Wildlife successfully sued the United StatesFish and Wildlife Service and the Endangered Species Scientific Authority, contending that the bobcat was in danger of extinction. The states are Florida, North Dakota, Wisconsin, Massachusetts and New Mexico.

title: G.O.P. RACE FOCUSES ON SOUTH CAROLINA Connally and Reagan Forces Field Strong Organizing Effort for March 8 Primary Contest
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 14  A new and early spot on the campaign schedule and the lack of a competing Democratic primary has set up the South Carolina Republican Presidential primary as potentially the most important early showdown between Ronald Reagan and John B. Connally in the 1980 Republican Presidential nomination race.

title: Physicists to Test Theory on Atoms'Slow Decay Test in Lake Erie Mine
description: A revolutionary theory predicting that all matter will eventually disappear is creating widespread excitement among physicists. Several largescale experiments have been planned to test it.

title: The Region Policeman Killed By HitRun Driver
description: A Nassau County highway patrolman giving out a traffic summons was killed by a hitandrun driver on the Long Island Expressway yesterday.

title: PublicIssue List Heavy
description: The Treasury and the Farm Cred System again have a heavy schedule of financing this week as they raise money to refund $19.8 billion of maturing securities and borrow $2.47 billion of additional cash.

title: Letter: On Chicano Roundups New Guidelines to Protect Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: SteelersHam Out for Season
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 (UPI)  The Pittsburgh Steelers said today that Jack Ham, an allpro linebacker, would not play again this season because of an ankle injury he sustained in the game last Monday night at Houston. A Steeler spokesman said team doctors made the decision yesterday.

title: L.I.R.R. Service Is Resumed Day Earlier Than Expected Parking Rules Reinstated
description: The Long Island Rail Road resumed regular service yesterday after eight days lost to a strike, as railroad workers ordered back to on the job Friday by President Carter completed the task of preparing the trains one day earlier than expected.

title: Nicaragua Debt Focus of Talks
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16  After an initial meeting that both sides described as very positive, the Nicaraguan Government and its private foreign creditors agreed to meet here again next month to discuss the refinancing of Nicaragua's foreign debt.

title: Newark Woman Killed As a Falling Gun Fires
description: NEWARK, Dec. 16 (AP)  In what the police described as a freak accident, a Newark woman died a day after a pistol fell in a selfservice laundry and shot her in the head.

title: General Foods Shifts 3 Cereals
description: General Foods is consolidating its cereal advertising in two ad agencies, which means that Benton & Bowles is losing three brands to Grey Advertising and Ogilvy & Mather.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Creating a U.S. Company From a Foreign Unit
description: Johnson & Johnson, the giant healthcare products company, has traditionally built up its subsidiaries first in the United States, and then, when conditions warranted, overseas. Now for the first time, Johnson is creating an American organization for what had been strictly a foreign subsidiary and has named one of its executives as the head.

title: Dance: Mimi Garrard and Company :Lathe of Heaven Movie Coming to WNET Jan. 9
description: THE lighting was the star of the show at the Mimi Garrard Dance Company's Saturday night performance at Miss Garrard's loft at 155 Wooster Street. The concert made use of a new computercontrolled lighting system designed by James Seawright, and before the program began Mr. Seawright spokeabout his invention and demonstrated some of its possibiltiies.

title: BUSINESS. Digest International
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1979

title: Davis Cup Problems Overshadow Glory The New Phenomenon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16  When the United States was losing Davis Cup matches at such foreign outposts as Ecuador, Colombia, Mexico and Argentina, defeats were taken as national disasters. Now that the Americans have won the sterling silver bowl for a second consecutive year, their victory here has been greeted with more yawns than hoopla.

title: Tanzanians Urged by President Not to Panic Over Food Shortage
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  President Julius K. Nyerere has told Tanzanians not to panic over food shortages but has warned them that the country's overall economic crisis is likely to last some time.

title: Weekly LottoNumbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 30, 9, 11, 32, 15 and 2. The supplementary number was 18.

title: 140Hour Test Starting To Check Space Shuttle
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP)  A major 140hour test was to begin tonight in preparation for the first flight of the space shuttle, which is tentatively scheduled for June 30.

title: Armco in $353 Million Soviet Contract A Time of Tension
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16  In a major development in longstalled United StatesSoviet industrial trade, Armco Inc., the Ohiobased industrial and steel manufacturer, has negotiated $353 million equipment contract for the Novolipetsk electrical steels plant south of Moscow.

title: Rangers Tie Flyers, 11
description: The Philadelphia Flyers and the New York Rangers tied, 11, last night, stretching the Flyers unbeaten string to 27 games, one short of the National Hockey League record set by the Montreal Canadiens in 1977.

title: Justice Dept. Urges. Nixon's Immunity on Wiretaps Qualified Immunity'Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  The Carter Administration has urged the Supreme Court to give former President Nixon and three of his top aides absolute immunity from liability for damages in three lawsuits brought by individuals whose telephones were illegally wiretapped in a Nixon Administration effort to trace sources of information passed to news reporters.

title: Dissident Hospitalized in Prague
description: VIENNA, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Jiri Lederer, a jailed Czechoslovak dissident, has been moved to a prison hospital in Prague to be treated for stomach and back problems, migr sources here said today. They said Mr. Lederer, who wassentenced to three and a half years jail in October 1977 for distributing material damaging to the state, had been moved from prison in Ostrava, east of Prague, to Pankrac prison hospital.

title: Hostage Tells Family He's Well Remembered Brother's Birthday
description: CHICAGO. Dec. 16 (AP)  When Gloran Lewis answered the phone yesterday afternoon, she was told her son was calling from Iran. She hung up, thinking it was a crank call.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. (Television  Manhattan Cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio  WNEW, 7:30 P.M.)

title: The Region
description: The Federal Government filed a civil suit yesterday against two manufacturing companies in Southington, Conn., charging that they present an imminent and substantial danger to the health and environment of that area because of improper disposal of toxic wastes.

title: U.S. Assessing Persian Gulf Forces
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  A Defense Department team has been sent to the Persian Gulf area for talks with leaders on access for American naval and air forces to military bases in the region, Government officials disclosed today.

title: Improved Technology Aids Wider Oil Search
description: THE crew of S9 left town before sunup. The thumper drivers and a couple of mechanics, jug hustlers and the head jerb, an engineer and the doghouse observer, the party manager and a geophysicist from the home office  doodlebugs all, seismic surveyors, and they were setting out for the desert to look for oil.

title: Weill Celebration to Open Whitney Showcase Series
description: A Kurt Weill Celebration will open the annual Composers Showcase series at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Jan. 4.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CHOICE CUTS Film buffs can hear Douglas Sirk discuss his work at three screening events this week. Tonight at 7:30 the Germanborn Hollywood director attends a showing of his Written on the Wind (1956) at City University's Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. More information: 5982371.

title: India Incumbent's Camnain Theme: Back to the Soil
description: SHIVPURI, India, Dec. 15  Charan Singh, the 78yearold Prime Minister and underdog candidate, is pursuing his singular campaign, running not only against his two opponents but against 30 years of development policies and against Jawaharlal Nehru, the late and , widely revered first leader of independent India.

title: Radioactive Gas Release Is Laid to a Faulty Valve
description: A malfunction Sunday at a nuclear power plant in Haddam, Conn., that released a small amount of radioactive gas was caused by a faulty level control valve in a water degasifier, a spokesman for Northeast Utilities said yesterday. The utility is the major owner of the plant.

title: Roundfield Honored
description: Dan Roundfield of the Atlanta Hawks has been named the National Basketball Association's player of the week. The 6foot8inch power forward helped the Hawks gain three straight victories last week, scoring 53 points and getting 37 rebounds.

title: Payment Charge Denied In Egyptian Phone Pact
description: CAIRO, Dec. 17  Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil of Egypt has released a statement from a European telecommunications consortium denying accusations that the Egyptian Government acted improperly in awarding the consortium a $1.8 billion contract.

title: N.B.A. Starts McGinnis Inquiry
description: The National Basketball Association opened an inquiry yesterday to determine whether there was any deliberate intent by George McGinnis of the Denver Nuggets to harm Jesse Kersey, referee, during a game in Seattle on Sunday night.

title: KIM HALL
description: Kim Hall, the director and a founder of the Asian golf circuit, died of cancer on Dec. 2 at his home in Hong Kong. He was 58 years old. Mr. Hall, who was born in Dinas Powis, Wales, was a golfer of note and a longtime official of the Asian tour, which visited such areas as Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and Korea. He is survived by his widow, Lily, and three children, Stephen, Jon and Elspeth.

title: Topics
description: Panama is a small country but there is nothing smallminded about its peppery leader, Gen. Omar Torrijos. In welcoming a friendless Shah, without conditions, the General rewarded the Carter Administration for its risky embrace of the Panama Canal treaties. And he showed that at least someone in the third world occasionally feels compassion for the difficulties of the first.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The belated agreement of the Patriotic Front parties to British proposals for a ceasefire in Rhodesia represents a triumph of goodwill and accommodation on both sides. It brings an end to a 14year rebellion and a sevenyear war, and holds out the promise of a peaceful transition to a democraticallyelected regime.

title: Czechoslovak Six Ties Finland
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (AP)  Finland and Czechoslovakia tied today, 44, in a hardfought match in the Izvestia ice hockey tournament. Sweden crushed Canada. 72.

title: 2.3577 Cheers for the 1970's, If You Ask Me
description: The 1970's crept up on me with no more warning than a lizard slithering across ancient stone. I began my first full decade as an adult by reclining on a rattan chaise lounge, drinking champagne, with the towers of Angkor Wat my only company that last night of 1969.

title: Grants for Fishing Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Richard A. Frank, head. of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, has announced that grants totaling $10 million will be offered to help develop and strengthen the nation's fishing industry.

title: Quake Hits Province in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17 (UPI) minor quake, measuring 4.9 on the Richter scale, shook Khorassan Province in eastern Iran today, but caused no serious damage, the Pars news agency said.

title: Yankees Trade Tommy Cruz
description: The Yankees traded Tommy Cruz, a minor league outfielder, from their Class AAA Columbus farm club to Minnesota's Toledo affiliate yesterday in exchange for Dave Coleman. an outfielder.

title: Gusting Winds Brrring a Preview of Winter
description: After weeks filled with comfort and coy suggestions that it might never arrive, winter gusted into the metropolitan area yesterday in a burst of cold that hunched shoulders, rattled teeth and led the mind to contemplate distant springs.

title: ;Polling Association Adopts Public Disclosure Code
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  An association of 16 major polling organizations, including some of the nation's largest, adopted a code today requiring the disclosure of information on how a poll is taken when that poll is released to the public.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Ihe Arts and Leisure section Sunday gave an incorrect date for a program by the Waverly Consort at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The program will be given Friday night.

title: New Afternoon Paper Planned
description: Plans for a new fiveday afternoon newspaper aimed at commuters homebound from Manhattan were announced yesterday by Michael Goldstein, founder and former publisher of The SoHo Weekly News.
