The paper, to be known as The Wall Street Final, is planned for publication during the first quarter of 1980. It will sell for 25 cents a copy Monday through Friday on 100 newsstands in Manhattan only and concentrate on closing Wall Street stock quotations and other business news, according to Mr. Goldstein. He estimated startup costs at $1 million and said the paper would have to sell 10,000 copies a day and two pages of ad vertising to break even.

title: Yamani Demands His Host's Suite
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 17 Mien Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, arrived last night at the Hotel Tamanaco, the site of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries conference, he refused to register beCLIS( the Presidential Suite was occupied.

title: Vital Triangle: Wasps, Figs, Clever Apes
description: Aplant, an insect and an ape that have a unique dependence on each other for their existence have aroused the curiosity of scientists who have begun to explore the evolutionary results of such a relationship and how the ape's role may relate to the size of the human brain.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: GURFEINJudge Murray I. The Officers and Members of the Board of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, record their deep sorrow at the sudden and untimely death of Judge Murray Gurfein, honorary member of the JDC Board and a dedicated activist In Jewish Communal Service. To his bereaved family we offer deepest sympathy.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1979

title: CITY'S SCHOOLS SEEK $2.68 BILLION BUDGET
description: A $2.68 billion hold the line school budget, an increase of $360 million over this year's, was submitted yesterday to Mayor Koch. The School Chancellor said the increase was essential to help educate tens of thousands of academically deficient students.

title: Music: Perahia at Piano
description: MURRAY PERAHIA'S piano recital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall was greeted as a major event by an adoring audience, and in most respects it deserved to be so treated. Mr. Perahia has emerged as a pianist with a real and valuable personality. He plays music with a rare sensitivity and intelligence. But unlike, say, Christoph Eschenbach, with whom he could in some respects be compared, he seems to invest his precise and careful musicmaking with a winning degree of oldfashioned heart. And he explores the repertory in a thoughtful way, as well.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bonds Climb in Light Trading
description: Treasury bill rates rose moderately yesterday in the Government's weekly auction, and a large number of new taxexempt bonds were tentatively priced for sale this week to give somewhat higher yields than underwriters expected earlier. Most prices in the credit markets rose slightly, however, while trading activity was exceedingly light, dealers reported.

title: Senate RollCall
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  Following is the 74to24 rollcall vote by which the Senate passed a $178 billion windfall profits tax on the oil industry tonight :

title: Esquire Editor, Publisher Raise Ownership Stake
description: By purchases announced yesterday, Phillip W. Moffitt and H. Christopher Whittle, editor and publisher, respectively, of Esquire magazine, have become majority owners of the 1330 Group, Esquire's parent company, and the 1330 Group has become 100 percent owner of the magazine.

title: Stage: Kern's Oh, Boy!
description: NO, the Goodspeed Opera House does not have the franchise on the revivals of cheerful, elderly musicals. The New Princess Theater Company is doing Oh, Boy! at the Park Royal Theater, and this is about as cheerful and elderly as you can get. The 1917 Jerome Kern musical opens with Let's Make a Night of It, closes with a reprise of Till the Clouds Roll By, and has a lot of amiable nonsense in between. It flourishes with innocent charm.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1979

title: Morton's Future Is Uncertain
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17  He still loves the game and the challenge. But, for the first time in his football career, Craig Morton is thinking that the future may now.

title: Preliminary Israeli Vote Backs a Curb on Abortions
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 17 Led by politicians from the religious bloc, Prime Minister Menachem Begin's coalition succeeded today in winning a preliminary vote to repeal a section of an Israeli law allowing abortions for family and other social reasons.

title: Concert: 3 Young Singers
description: THE Gala Opera Concert held in Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon was a noble but illadvised gesture to give public exposure to three littleknown young singers: Sandra Ruggles, soprano; Mario Buzoianu, tenor, and Norman Carlberg, bassbaritone. The idea was to present them with Pablo Elvira, a leading baritone with the New York City and Metropolitan Opera companies, who would supply the lure to attract a wide audience and critical attention.

title: Carter to Forgo Holiday at Home
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Jofy Powell, the White House press secretary, said today that because of the Iranian crisis, President Carter would not go to his home in Plains, Ga., over the Christmas holidays. He feels his traditional Christmas at home would not be appropriate under the circumstances, Mr. Powell said, adding that the President would divide his time between Camp David and the White House.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Cyanimid Company, Wayne, N.J., a chemical and pharmaceutical company, has appointed Gordon D. Sterling president of the organic chemicals division.

title: Broadway Pays Tribute to Ethel Barrymore
description: Broadway gathered yesterday at the theater that bears her name to honor, bit belatedly, the centenary of the birth of one of the great figures of the American stage, Ethel Barrymore.

title: Koch Cites Lesson of Hanukkah
description: Using a torch kindled at the tomb of the Maccabees in Israel, Mayor Koch lighted four candles yesterday on a menorah at City Hall to mark the fourth night of Hanukkah. Noting that the small band of Maccabees had overcome Syrian oppression 2,040 years ago, the Mayor said that the spirit of Hanukkah to fight the good fight was important in present times.

title: Energy and Metals Stocks Lead Advance
description: Preciousmetal and energy stocks moved higher yesterday in the wake of record prices for gold bullion abroad and the latest round of oilprice increases by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. It was a market, analysts said, that defied Wall Street's rule that sharply rising prices for gold are anathema to the general list of stocks. But in the present inflationary environment, they noted, old rules can fly out the window.

title: EVA KORNBLITH
description: Dr. Eva Kornblith, a periodontist who opened her practice in Newark 55 years ago, died of a stroke Saturday in St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. She was 91 years old.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: COHENPhilip. Age 86, of Miami Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Sophia, father of Stanley and Arthur, fatherinlaw of Ruth and Marion, grandfather of Michael, Randle, Steven, Andrew and Daniel; brother of Faye Korn and Pearl Rosenthal. He will be sorely missed as a beautiful influence on all hIs family and friends. Services Wednesday, 1:45 at Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapel Queens Blvd and 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Democrats Face Maze of Convention Rules
description: Some pointed humor at a meeting of the Democratic State Committee last week focused on the maze of rules, quotas and affirmative action goals that will bind state delegates at the Democratic National Convention in New York City next August.

title: Police Work on jewel Plot Has a Certain Brilliance
description: As he looked at the metal handcuffs and the strips of white adhesive tape, the detective immediately recognized the mark of an old adversary.

title: Byrne Signs High School Diploma Bill
description: TRENTON, Dec. 17  Governor Byrne today signed a bill that under most conditions requires New Jersey's 1.3 million public school students to meet minimum standards before receiving high school diplomas.

title: Business Records
description: Petition Filed by: BASIL JAY WINSTON, 501 E. 87th St., N.Y. Liabilities. 872,667; assets, S4,686.

title: WINDFALL OIL TAX RAISING $178 BILLION IS VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The Senate gave final approval tonight to a tax on the windfall profits of the oil industry by a vote of 74 to 24.

title: Chargers Conquer Broncos, Capture A.F.C. West Title
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17  They came to celebrate, wearing gold Tshirts, waving gold handkerchiefs and singing a disco fight song. A woman sprayed holy water on the field to keep the Devil away. It was to be San Diego's night to Special to The New York Tunes shine and shed its identity crisis as the city west of the mountains, east of the Pacific, north of Mexico and south of Los Angeles.

title: MRS. THATCHER VOWS TO BACK U.S. ON IRAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher promised Britain's full support today in the event the United States asked the United Nations Security Council to impose economic sanctions on Iran as part of its efforts to obtain the freedom of 50 American hostages.

title: Modern Silver That's Meant to be Used
description: There's nothing sacred about the silver created by Grant Macdonald. The Englishman's designs are not meant just to be admired, though they are pleasing to the eye, but rather are for everyday use. I like domestic things, Mr. Macdonald said on a recent visit to introduce his work to this country. I like things to be used.

title: School to Aid Neediest Cases
description: Alice and Allan Kaplan of Syosset, L.I., have been contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for 15 years, and they have already sent in a check for $100 as usual. But this year their daughter, Caroline, is joining them in their efforts. albeit indirectly.

title: Con Ed Gas Raise of 8.7% Urged
description: ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP)  An administrative law judge with the state Public Service Commission has recommended that the commission allow Consolidated Edison to increase its gas rates by 8.7 percent. If approved, the raise would increase Con Edison's annual revenues by $31 million. The company's last gas rate increase took effect in October 1977. The decision of the administrative law judge, Edward Block, is only a recommendation.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: IRANIAN VOLUNTEERS DEPART TO JOIN PALESTINIANS: Members a group of about 40 Iranians that volunteered to join Palestinian guerrillas fighting against Israel in southern Lebanon, waiting last light at Teheran's international airport for flight to Damascus, Syria. Lebanese authorities have closed the courtry to the Iranians, who hope to filter in from Syria.

title: Bradshaw, Stargell Sportsmen of 1979
description: Terry Bradshaw and Willie Stargell, Pittsburgh's football and baseball heroes, have been selected as 1979 sportsmen of the year by Sports Ilstrated magazine.

title: Ballet: Neubert Troupes In Rats of Paris Opera
description: THE Neubert Ballet Company and the Children's Ballet Theater offered The Little Rats of the Paris Opera Sunday afternoon at the Fashion Institute of Technology. In case anyone is unacauainted with balletic slang, it had better be said right away that the work had nothing to do with rodents.

title: Corporate Earnings; DRESSER INDUSTRIES (N); DWG (A); ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS (N); ENTWISTLE (O); FOOTHILL GROUP (O); GREAT BASINS PETE (A); HARVEY GROUP (A); JEWELCOR (N); MARK PRODUCTS (O); NATIONAL GAS & OIL (O); REALTY & MTGE INVEST (O); ROYAL PALM BEACH COL (A); RUSSELL STOVER CANDIES (O) STERCHI BROS STORES (N); SUPREME EQUIP & SYS (O); UNI BRAZE (O)
description: For periods as shown. ( N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Reversal Allows a LawyerPriest To Wear Cleric Garb Before Jury
description: Five years ago the Rev. Vincent LaRocca, a Roman Catholic priest who is an attorney with the Legal Aid Society in Brooklyn, fought unsuccessfully to wear his clerical dress while arguing cases before juries. His appearance in such dress could prevent a fair trial by prejudicing a jury  for or against his client  New York State courts ruled, and the United States Supreme Court declined to review these findings.

title: Howard Johnson, Imperial Link Set
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)  The proposed merger of the Bostonbased Howard Johnson Company with Imperial Group Ltd. of London was approved by Howard Johnson stockholders today.

title: 3 Charged With Stealing $25,000 From L.I. Bank in Billing Scheme
description: Three Brooklyn men have been accused of stealing $25,000 from a Long Island bank through a scheme that involved billings against stolen credit cards.

title: Theater: Yale Repertory Performs Measure for Measure
description: IN John Madden's production at the Yale Repertory Theater, Measure for Measure is no longer a problem play  it is comedy with a moral message  but there still is a problem. In every other production of Measure for Measure that I have seen  from Central Park to StratfordUponAvon  the pivotal characters have been the virginal Isabella and her erstwhile seducer, Angelo. Through them, we have seen the interplay of sanctity and corruption. The third principal character, the Duke of Vienna, is usually somewhat removed, although he is the one who manipulates the other characters, defines the title and summarizes the play.

title: Red Cross Warns Cambodia on Blocking Aid Supplies
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 17  The International Committee of the Red Cross has issued a warning to the proVietnamese Government in Phnom Penh that it may not indefinitely continue its deliveries of relief materials if local authorities do not distribute the supplies.

title: TV: 5 Points of View on Blindness
description: SCARCELY anyone who has ever helped a blind person across street has not found himself thinking that whatever problems he may have fade into insignificance.

title: G. CHAPMAN, 77, LED PUBLIC LIBRARY
description: Gilbert W. Chapman, a former president of the New York Public Library and an industrialist who was a leader in New York City cultural and educational affairs, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan after a short illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Factories Using Less Capacity
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) Factories operated at 84.4 percent of capacity last month, the lowest level of the year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Judge M.I. Gurfein, Who Allowed Pentagon Papers Publication, Dies
description: Judge Murray I. Gurfein of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, who rejected the Nixon Administration's attempt to bar The New York Times from publishing the Pentagon Papers in 1971, died, apparently of a heart attack, Sunday at his home at 530 Park Avenue. He was 72 years old.

title: Canada's Hub Shifts to West
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 17  The sudden election called for Feb. 18 reflects a historic shift in power from East to West, from the industrial heartland of Ontario to the vast oil and eas fields of Alberta.

title: FOOD CONTAMINANTS TERMED UNDETECTED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Toxic substances in foods may often pass unnoticed for years until their presence is indicated by acute human or animal poisoning, according to a report by the Office of Technology Assessment, an advisory arm of Congress.

title: Toyota, Datsun Output at Peak
description: TOKYO, Dec. 17 (AP)  Japan's two largest automobile manufacturers announced today record vehicle production for November.

title: Ford Is Pessimistic On 80 Sales
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17  Automobile sales in the United States, already at their lowest levels since 1979, are likely to plunge as much as 10 percent in 1980, the Ford Motor Company predicts in its yearend economic forecast, released here today.

title: Two Reported Killed by Grenade In Iranian Girls Training Session
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17 (AP) grenade exploded accidentally during military training session for young girls, killing the instructor and a girl and seriously injuring 13 others, a Teheran newspaper said today.

title: U.S. Banks Refusing to Honor Iranian Student Checks
description: Throughout the United States, bank tellers and merchants are refusing to honor Iranian students checks, in some cases leaving them without money for tuition or living expenses.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Cuba Still 4 Votes Short Of Seat on U.N. Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 17 Cuba came within four votes of winning vacant Security Council seat today.

title: TV: Report on Homosexuals
description: THE ABC News Closeup on Homosexuals was bumped off the schedule in October by a rainpostponed game of the World Series. The documentary can now be seen tonight on Channel 7 at 10 o'clock.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies, parent organization for the nation's biggest insurance brokerage concern, announced yesterday that it was considering making an offer to purchase C. T. Bowring & Company Ltd., one of Britain's leading insurance brokers and a prominent member of Lloyd's of London.

title: Choosing of President For Hunter Postponed
description: The Board of Trustees of the City University of New York, unable to agree on a candidate for the presidency of Hunter College, decided again yesterday to postpone the selection of a new president.

title: Arrival of Shah Brings Protests In Panama City
description: PANAMA. Dec. 17  While the Shah of Iran rested today on the resort island of Contadora, several hundred Panamanian students in the capital protested his presence.

title: Rich States, Poor States and Oil
description: A critic was once defined as someone who comes down to the field after the battle and shoots the wounded. The battle over a windfall tax on oil, now ended the Senate, creates a contrary opportunity, to be a critic precisely by attending to the wounded.

title: A Reserve Proposed to Help City Sell Bonds
description: A municipal bond specialist at Citibank has suggested that New York City may be able to return fully to the longterm borrowing market in 1982 if it sets up a reserve fund to pay a full year's interest on the bonds in the event of a temporary crisis.

title: China Undecided on U.S. Engine Plan
description: PEKING, Dec. 17  Chinese manufacturing officials described as premature and optimistic today assertions by an American business group that it plans to sign a contract to manufacture an Americandeveloped engine in China. The American business executives said a 15year contract for an asyetunproven multifuel engine would be signed by the end of next March.

title: AMCA Halts Bid for Swasey
description: The AMCA International Corporation, a subsidiary of the Montrealbased Dominion Bridge Company, announced yesterday that it would not proceed with its $75ashare cash offer for any and all of the 3.5 million outstanding shares of the Warner & Swasey Company. The action opens the way for the acquisition of Warner & Swasey by the Bendix Corporation for $83 a share, or a total of about $290 million in cash and stock.

title: Regional Planning Unit Predicts. Use of Gasoline Will Fall by 47%
description: Regional gasoline consumption will drop 47 percent in the last quarter of this century, despite a 23 percent increase in the number of miles vehicles travel, according to a study by the Tristate Regional Planning Commission that was reported by The Associated Press.

title: Plants Are Cloned to Prevent Extinction
description: IN an antiquated building here just across the Berkeley city line, a United States Department of Agriculture researcher, Bernard Finkle, is freezing cell groups from sugar cane and date palms to the temperature of liquid nitrogen  close to absolute zero. Then he thaws the cell groups out and grows whole plants from them with the aid of hormones.

title: Wharton Sale Plans
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP) The University of Pennsylvania plans to sell a controlling interest in its Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates unit, according to Lee R. Morris, president and chief operating officer. He said negotiations are well under way with three unnamed wouldbe buyers as part of a plan to convert the concern from a notforprofit into a profitmaking organization.

title: Giants End Promising Year on Sour Note
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 17  The Giants quit yesterday, just as they quit the week before and in the second half of the week before that, because, in the mortal words of Gary Jeter, Man, it's hard to play when you're behind.

title: Mail Bomb Injures 2 in England
description: DOVER, England, Dec. 17 (AP) package bomb blew up in a sorting office here today, injuring two postal workers slightly, the police said. A rash of letter bombs in central England in June was attributed to the Irish Republican Army.

title: Lawe Renamed by Transit Union And Hell Lead 1980 Wage Talks
description: John E. Lawe has been elected president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union for a second twoyear term in a fourway contest, the union announced yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
Iran Expelling 2 Time Reporters
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17  Time magazine's two correspondents in Teheran were ordered expelled today on charges that their publication had done nothing but arouse the hatred of the American people for Iran.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ATLANTIC CROWN (Atlantic Container Line). Antwerp Dec. 25, Gothenburg 27 and LeHavre 28; sails from Port Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Marines to Open Hearing Today On 2 Charges Against ExP.O.W.
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., Dec. 17 (AP)  After nearly nine months of preparation, the Marine Corps is scheduled to begin unveiling its case tomorrow against Pfc. Robert Garwood, a 33yearold former prisoner of war who faces charges of desertion and collaboration with the enemy in Vietnam.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Your Dec. 2 editorial Half a Trillion Is Real Money makes the point that small sums have a way of adding up quickly. Had you applied the same logic to your discussion of a phaseout of the proposed windfall profits tax on decontrolled domestic crude oil, your conclusion would have been to support rather than oppose a phaseout.

title: Electronic Postal Plan Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The United States Postal Service, which has faced opposition in its quest for authority to enter the electronic mail business, received limited rights today to set uo such a system in 25 cities.

title: U.N. CODE OUTLAWS TAKING OF HOSTAGES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 17 The General Assembly adopted without dissent today a code to outlaw the taking of hostages.

title: RHODESIAN GUERRILLAS AGREE TO BRITAIN'S CEASEFIRE PLAN; SIGNING IS SET FOR TOMORROW
description: LONDON, Dec. 17 The leaders of the Patriotic Front guerrilla alliance agreed tonight to a British ceasefire plan aimed at ending the sevenyear Rhodesian civil war.

title: Miss OwenSpencer, Galanes Ski Victors
description: CABLE, Wis., Dec. 17 Jim Galanes was a surprise winner and Alison OwenSpencer was an expected one on the opening day of the North American crosscountry skiing championships.

title: Some Progress for Jets and Giants, and Some Hope
description: On the surface, it appears that both the Jets and the Giants stood still this season. Finishing with three consecutive victories, the Jets had an SS wonlost record, the same as they did last year. Finishing with three consecutive losses, the Giants had a 610 record, the same as they did last year. And yet each team achieved some significant, if subtle, progress.

title: Book Critics Circle Nominates 6
description: Some name novelists  Norman Mailer, Philip Roth, William Styron and Elizabeth Hardwick  are competing in the fiction category for the annual awards of the National Book Critics Circle, the organization of professional critics and editiors.

title: Reduced Growth Is Seen for E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 17 (AP)  The latest round of oil price increases will cut the European Economic Community's 1980 economic growth rate to at least 1.5 percent. down from the 2 percent predicted only two weeks ago, the Republic of Ireland's Finance Minister, Michael O'Kennedy. said here today.

title: Imports Cause Japan Deficit
description: TOKYO, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Soaring imports, apparently a result of rising oil prices, pushed Japan's currentaccount deficit to a record monthly high in November, the Government announced today.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: LIFFAnnaDecember 17,1979. Devoted wife of Joseph, beloved mother of Walter and Arthur and grandmother of Perry and Stephen, Nancy and Howard. Services Tuesday December 18 at 10 A.M. at Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 11403 Queens Boulevard, NYC.

title: About New York
description: What do these bankers, lawyers and accountants do all night in those wellappointed rooms above Eighth Avenue?

title: After Being Sacked, Chemise Is Back
description: When the chemise came off the runways of the Paris salons in 1957 and started appearing on the backs of women, it was greeted with guffaws. Cab drivers interviewed by the press voiced their disapproval of what was quickly dubbed the sack dress. Cartoonists immortalized it with a bow on the behind and pretty soon the nowaistline style was laughed off the scene.

title: U.S. Exasperated by Conflicting Signals From Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The United States voiced frustration today over the disagreements within the Iranian leadership on the hostage issue and vowed that new economic pressures would be applied to Iran unless the Americans were freed. As the crisis entered its 44th day, the mood at the White House and State Depart ment was one of anticipation that the crisis was nearing a turning point. This was because it was perceived here that the Iranians seemed to be debating whether to resolve the affair soon through some facesaving formula or to go ahead with trials of some or all of the Americans, which would heighten ten, sions.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: STRUGGLE ON ICE: Fred Barrett of North Stars trying to stop Dave Williams (22) of Maple Leafs from going after Mike Polich (16), who was scuffling with Lanny McDonald in the first period last night. The game, won by the North Stars, 51, was marked by 132 minutes in penalties.

title: City's Police Test Barred in Ruling On Minority Suit
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that New York City could not use its latest Civil Service examination to select new police officers until he decided on a plan that could assist black and Hispanic applicants to the Police Department.

title: The City
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci or Queens said yesterday that his office was looking into the death of a New Hampshire man who was hit by a model airplane at Shea Stadium Dec. 2.

title: Company In Record E.E.C. Fine
description: PARIS, Dec. 17  The European Economic Community imposed its largest fine ever today  $9.8 million against a major Japanese electronics manufacturer and its European distributors on charges of price fixing.

title: New Mexico Drops Ellenberger as Coach
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 17 (AP)  Norm Ellenberger, under Federal investigation in connection with an alleged mailfraud and bribery scheme involving a basketball player's New Mexico Drops Ellenberger as Coach juniorcollege transcript, was dismissed as the University of New Mexico coach today by the university president. William E. Davis.

title: Tennessee Subdues Minnesota by 7164
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 17 (AP) Howard Wood, a reserve center, scored 16 points in the second half to rally Tennessee to a 7164 college basketball victory tonight over previously undefeated Minnesota.

title: Pentagon Aide Rates a GRAPE For Waging War on Acronyms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  A senior official in the Department of Defense has undertaken to dilute the Pentagon's mania for acronyms and jargon, a task akin to trying to dig the Panama Canal with a teaspoon.

title: Changing Face of Fox Film
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  In the highpressure, emotioncharged movie industry, stars, producers, directors, even the executives, live on a merrygoround. Switching jobs is so common that people here joke about the chances of keeping one until the paint dries on the curbside parking stall that goes with it.

title: East Germans Expand Military Expenditures As Counter to NATO
description: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 17  East Germany announced today that its military expenditures would be increased as part of a program to strengthen the fighting power and efficiency of the Warsaw Pact.

title: OBSERVER
description: How many people out there are old enough to remember the fried seafood platter? You don't see the fried seafood platter in restaurants very often anymore, do you? And when you go to somebody's house for dinner, that somebody doesn't surprise and delight you these days with the fried seafood platter, right?

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Sam Bowie of Kentucky gaining possession of the ball as he went up against Georgia's Jimmy Daughtry during first half last night in Atlanta.

title: The Who Concludes U.S. Tour
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  Security was tighter than usual when fans of the British rock group the Who turned out for the group's last performance of its United States tour. An estimated 15,200 persons saw the group without incident yesterday. However, in New Haven, Conn., on Saturday about 70 persons were arrested in assault, bread; of peace and disorderly conduct charges, the police said Eleven persons were killed at the group's concert in Cincinnati two weeks ago wher fans rushed for general admission seats.

title: InterestPaying Checking Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The House approved a bill today to allow interestpaying checkingtype accounts to continue nationwide for at least three more months.

title: $12 FUEL FEE ADDED TO MONTHLY RENTS FOR 300,000 TENANTS
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board approved a fuel surcharge last night of $12 a month from January through June for 300,000 rentstabilized apartments. It applies only to tenants whose leases took effect between July 1, 1978; and June 30 of this year.

title: After a Long Conflict, The Truce Is Received Quietly by Rhodesians
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 17 After seven years of war and more than 20,000 deaths, Rhodesians quietly received the announcement of a ceasefire agreement in London tonight, many of them unconvinced that Britain can succeed in holding the Salisbury Government and its guerrilla foes in the Patriotic Front to the peace terms.

title: Starrett Housing Omits Dividend
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation said it had omitted its thirdquarter dividend. In previous quarters the builder of highrise residential and office buildings disbursed 7 cents.

title: J. M. Willem Jr., 70, Former Vice President At Thompson Agency
description: John M. Willem Jr., a former senior vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, the advertising agency, died Saturday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: Judge Halts S.E.C.s Wheeling Inquiry
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 (UPI)  A United States District Court judge today ordered the Securities and Exchange Commission to halt an investigation into trading negotiations of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation.

title: Judge Gurfein's First Case
description: Murray Gurfein was one of those sturdy but softspoken men who make their mark by the force of intelligence and the service of principle. He was a brilliant attorney, an energetic prosecutor, a concerned citizen of the community and, for the last eight years, a distinguished district and appeals court judge. We saw all sides of the man on his very first day on the bench in 1971, when he had The Times in the dock.

title: Steel Output Up for Week
description: Steel production rose to 2.318 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 1.2 percent from the previous week's 2.290 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 80.1 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 79.1 percent in the previous week.

title: Khomeini Backs Hostages Captors And Denies They Make Own Policy
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, said today that the militants occupying the United States Embassy were expressing the will of the people and were not setting a separate foreign policy.

title: Guest in Coast Hotel Surrenders After Bomb and Hostage Threats
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 (AP)  A man who said he had a bomb and hostages surrendered to the police about five hours after having barricaded himself inside a room in a downtown hotel, the authorities said.

title: Jean Kerr Minetti Is Dead at 55; Wife of ExC.A.B. Vice Chairman
description: Jean Kerr Minetti, the wife of G. Joseph Minetti, a lawyer and former vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, died last Saturday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., after a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 55 years old and lived in Sumner, Md., a suburb of Washington.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Toshihiro Tomabechi has been named president of the Mitsubishi International Corporation, the American subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Group, the giant international trading company that has annual sales of $45 billion. He succeeds Yohei Mimura, who is returning to the parent company in Japan as an executive vice president.

title: Music: Copland Joins Paul Jacobs in a Journey
description: THE first of Nonesuch Records showcase engagements for its classical artists at the Bottom Line took place Sunday night, with Paul Jacobs joined by Aaron Copland. The program was full of ingratiating music. But its conceptual framework seemed a little shaky.

title: Medical Team Going to Thailand
description: The New York HospitalCornell Medical Center and the International Rescue Committee are organizing a rotating medical team to work in one of the Cambodian refugee camps in Thailand, the coordinator of the project said yesterday.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Continues to Rise; Dollar Declines Abroad
description: Gold continued its recordsetting spiral yesterday, trading as high as $474 an ounce in Zurich before falling back a bit at the close as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began meeting on oil prices.

title: OPEC Session Opens Amid Pricing Discord As Iran Confirms Rise
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 17 Iran's oil minister, Ali Akbar Moinfar, confirmed that his country had raised its crudeoil prices by $5 a barrel to $28.50 as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began its ministerial meeting here this morning.

title: Advertising
description: THE life insurance industry, which has already communicated with the socalled thoughtleader segment of society. will next seek grassroots support in its battle against what it believes to be the four causes of inflation. And where else would you go with a long message to the grass roots but to the Reader's Digest?

title: Iraq Calls for the Release Of 16 Seized by Iranians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17  Iraq, which has been feuding with Iran for months, today demanded the release within 48 hours of 16 Iraqi teachers seized a week ago in the Iranian port of Khur ramshahr.

title: Jazz: Terumasa Hino's Septet
description: TERUMASA HINO, a jazz trumpet player from Japan, has been in the United States since 1975, but despite acclaim from fellow musicians, he is not yet as well known to the jazz public here as he is in his native land. In this country, he works as a side man (with Dave Liebman, with George Russell), but in Japan he performs as a leader.

title: Fire Kills Mother and 4 Children
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Dec. 17 (UPI)  A mother and her four children were killed early today in a fire that swept their home while they slept. County sheriff's deputies identified the victims as Kathleen Thompson and her children Michael, 15 years old; John, 10, and Mark and Mary, both 8. They said that the cause of the fire was under investigation.

title: Dissimilar Political Activists Sue Against Election Campaign Law
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)  Political activists representing liberal and conservative philosophies today announced a series of lawsuits to challenge the constitutionality of certain parts of the Federal Election Campaign Act.

title: Did Eye Ailment Add to Emily Dickinson's Woes?
description: IN an unusual collaboration of science and literature. a Hartford opthalmologist recently teamedup with his former English professor at Yale University to see if they could explain one of the mysteries of Emily Dickinson's life.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why doesn't an electric eel shock itself?

title: SLEEP MEDICATIONS ARE TARGET OF DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  Expressing concern about the nearly 9 million Americans who use prescription sleeping pills, the Government today began a campaign to educate doctors and the public about sleep disorders and their Drooer treatment.

title: Activists of 1968 and 72 Again Helping a Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Stephen Schlesinger started in politics with Robert F. Kennedy in 1968. Then, four years later, he wrote speeches for Senator George McGovern. and when that crusade ended in failure, he went off to practice journalism and wait for the next time.

title: Pianist: Youri Egorov Plays 24 Chopin Etudes
description: UP to now, Youri Egorov, one of the bright new talents on the pianistic scene, has been concentrating on Romantic music. Last night in Carnegie Hall, he went a little afield, playing a very long program that demanded two intermissions. True, he did play all 24 of the Chopin Etudes. But he started with Bach's E minor Partita and then played the Bartok Piano Sonata before going into the Chopin.

title: State High Court Back Hynes
description: The State Court of Appeals upheld the authority of Deputy Attorney General Charles J. Hynes to include hospitals as well as nursing homes in his sphere of investigation. His authority had been challenged by an accounting firm in an effort to block a subpoena for financial records from hospitals. The state's high court ruled that the Attorney General had power to expand Mr. Hynes's mandate without additional legislative approval.

title: Around the Nation
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 17 (UPI) Oil executives began filing bids today as a Federal court removed another legal roadblock to an attempt to find marketable levels of oil or natural gas on Georges Bank, a rich Atlantic fis:ling area about 100 miles off southeastern New England.

title: Bengals Oust Coach With All His Aides
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 17 (AP)  The Cincinnati Bengals, concluding that it was rather obvious to all that a change had to be made, dismissed Coach Homer Rice and all his assistants today.

title: ARNOLD A. WEINSTEIN
description: Arnold A. Weinstein, a lawyer who was president of the Henry George School of Social Science in Manhattan from 1968 to 1973, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and a resident of the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Notes on People
description: It was in a home movie in 1976 that Mr. Bill first appeared on NBC's Saturday Night Live  a little clay figure shattered regularly by existential disasters.

title: Stunt Man Breaks Sound Barrier on Land
description: ROGERS LAKE. Calif., Dec 17 (Reuters)  A Hollywood stuntman, Stan Barrett. has become the first man to break the sound barrier on land.

title: For the Arkansas Hunt, A $1,000 Jumping Mule
description: POCAHONTAS, Ark., Dec. 14 When Lawton Robinson brought Barney, the white jumping mule, in from California on a pickup truck, all the coon hunters laughed. They laughed until they saw Barney leap flatfooted over a fourfoot fence and take his owner prancing off tallyho after the hounds while all the other old boys were standing kneedeep in the Black River swamp with nothing to ride but their rubber boots.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: GURFEINMurray I. The Officers of The United Jewish AppealFederation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign mourn the passing of a distinguished lurist and communal leader, who was a past president of HIAS and a member of U.J.A.'s Board of Directors. A recipient of the Joseph M. Proskauer Award, he played for many years a prominent role in the legal profession's humanitarian efforts in behalf of the endangered, oppressed and needy in Israel, around the world and here in New York. We offer heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family.

title: About Education
description: Apowerful new coalition of academic and corporate leaders has urged an action program to create at least 10 federally funded, universitybased research centers to help solve the nation's energy problems. Beyond the importance of this specific goal, the agreement signals recognition by corporate managers of the universities as an indispensable resource in shoring up the nation's industrial and economic strength. Academic observers hail the step as a sign that the campuses may once again be encouraged to play a leading role in the nation's service.

title: Chicago Transit Workers Strike, Affecting a Million
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17  Bus drivers and train motormen struck the Chicago Transit Authority today for the first time since 1922, leaving more than a million commuters scrambling for alternative ways of getting to work in subfreezing weather.

title: Iran Shifting Trade From U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Helped by reduced demand for imports, Iran has been able to buy from elsewhere essential items previously purchased from the United States, according to Administ ration officials.

title: At White House Gala Dinner, Decor to Complement the Guest
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Carleton Varney arrived at the airport here this morning carrying 500 anemones. Mr. Varney is a decorator, not a florist, but some things he doesn't leave to chance. One of those things is the details of a White House state dinner.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Iran's oil minister confirmed a price increase to $28.50 a barrel during the first day of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting in Caracas, Venezuela, further clouding hopes for uniform pricing. Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates vowed to stay at $24, at least through the first quarter of 1980. [A1.]

title: Market Place
description: THE market performances of Mesa Petroleum shares and its spinoff, Mesa Royalty Trust, suggest that something unusual may be happening on the tax front. That is, some investors appear to be using Mesa options and the stock itself achieve current tax losses with the result that the shares of Mesa have been uncommonly strong.

title: Dentists Try New Ways To Quell Fear
description: NO matter how much the patient fears the dentist the needle, the drill, the overweening power of the man above the chair  the dentist may dread the anxious patient just as much, for canceling appointments, arriving late, refusing to sit in the chair, cringing, gagging and generally making him feel like a torturer.

title: Long Island's Trains Are Jammed, And This Time the Riders Love It
description: The commuters who had struggled with jammed buses and subways and congested highways during last week's Long Island Rail Road strike gladly packed themselves aboard the trains yesterday, the first weekday since the line resumed operating under a Presidential order.

title: COMMODITIES Gold and Silver Futures Rise Sharply, Then Ease
description: Futures prices tor silver and gold shattered records for the fourth straight session yesterday but closed on a weak note as traders studied oilpricing developments at the meeting in Venezuela of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: 2 Refiners Lift Gas Price 6
description: Wholesale gasoline prices have been raised 6 cents a gallon by the Exxon Corporation and the Chevron U.S.A. division of the Standard Oil Company of California, the companies an nounced yesterday. Both said their actions had come because of Saudi Arabia's decision last week to increase crude oil prices by $6 a barrel to $24, retroactive to Nov. 1.

title: Chamber: Aeolian Players
description: THE Aeolian Chamber Players wound up a series of three weekend concerts in Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night. Trios by Beethoven and Mendelssohn were the main order of business, and participating in the performances were Lewis Kaplan, violinist; Ronald Thomas, cellist; Thomas Hill, clarinetist, and Jacob Maxin, pianist.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Norhtern Ireland, Dec. 17 (AP)  A gunman killed a prison guard near Belfast's Crumlin Road Jail today, raising to seven the number of people killed in Northern Ireland in a 24hour period, the police reported.

title: Allen Klein Loses Tax Appeal
description: Allen Klein, former manager of the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, yesterday lost his appeal of a tax evasion conviction that resulted in a twomonth jail sentence and a $5,000 fine, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Klein, who is 48 years old and lives in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was convicted last April of filing false income tax return for 1970 by failing to declare money earned from the sale of records made by the Beatles and others.

title: Events Today
description: A CHRISTMAS GARLAND, by Eileen Atkins; directed by John TIflinger; starring Ed Hermann, Joan Moore, Eileen Atkins and Mr. Tillinger, at the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street, 7:30.

title: Science Watch
description: The rocket engines that have given the developers of the space shuttle so much trouble underwent a successful test firing yesterday at the National Space Technologies Laboratory at Bay St. Louis, Miss.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Thick layered clouds cover eastern Maine and low clouds or snow cover are visible in lake region, the Middle West and the middle Tennessee Valley. High and middle level clouds stretch from the Northern Plains States to the northern Rockies while dense stratified rain clouds cover the Pacific Northwest.

title: New York Tech Wins
description: Kelvin Hicks scored 10 points in the first 4 minutes 24 seconds of the second half as New York Tech tallied 17 consecutive points en route to a 7859 victory over visiting Elizabeth City of New Jersey last night. The victory was Tech's seventh without a loss this season and its 11th consecutive victory over two seasons.

title: Books of The Times
description: THIS is Hugh Thomas unbuttoned. The English historian who is usually specialized see his books on the Spanish Civil War, on Suez and on John Strachey  is found here in an agreeable sprawl. He begins with the monkey, the newt, the sealily and the bacterium from which man derives. He ends the day before yesterday, with pocket calculators and communications satellites. In between, with much circling around in a blizzard of crossreferences, he contemplates the horse, the potato, the irrigation ditch, the magnetic compass, the tin can, monotheism, leprosy and so on.

title: Klan Case Arraignments Set
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Dec. 17 (AP) The 19 men charged in connection with the slaying of five persons at an antiKu Klux Klan rally will be arraigned the week of Jan. 7 before a special Superior Court judge, the authorities said today.

title: Court Kills Award to Man Taught as Retarded Pupil
description: The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday dismissed a $500,000 award to a Queens man who as a child had been improperly assigned to classes for the mentally retarded. The attorneys and educators involved said that the case had been the country's only successful educational malpractice suit.

title: U.S. Increases Reliance On Intelligence Satellites
description: CAN the United States make good the shortfall in intelligence about the Soviet Union that has resulted from the loss of listening posts in Iran and other neighbors of the Soviets?

title: WarmUp for the Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  In politics as in sports, warmups are a time for grand bluffing and false modesty, a time for awing an opponent with your fireball practice serve while poormouthing your chances with calculated confessions about your bad ankle and your tennis elbow.

title: New N.F.L. Team Sought For Los Angeles Coliseum
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (UPI)  As the Los Angeles Rams were playing their final regularseason game in the Memorial Coliseum, the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee and the Coliseum Commission agreed on plan to finance the remodeling of the old stadium with the hope of wooing another National Football League team next year.

title: Tough General Who Appears in Control of Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 17  For the time being, a military analyst here said today, a twostar general who heads a military intelligence unit appears to be in control of Seoul. But, the analyst asked, how long will it last?

title: Inquiry on Churchill Case Barred
description: LONDON, Dec. 17 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has rejected a call for a security inquiry into the link between Winston Churchill and the former wife of a Saudi financier and arms dealer.

title: Bears Survive Enormous Odds to Reach N.F.L. Playoffs
description: When the day, last Sunday, was only three and a half hours old, Mugs Halas, the 54yearold president of the Chicago Bears and the son of the ownerfounder, George Halas Sr., died of a heart attack. The team then played a seasonending game of apparently little importance against the St. Louis Cardinals and won it, 426, scoring the highest number of points any Bear team had made in 14 years.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: VENEZIANOMichael, M.D. With Profound sorrow, we acknowledge the passing of a beloved and respected member of our medical staff, Michael veneziano, M.D. He dedicated his life to the care of others. As a distinguished surgeon, he served as Director, Department of Surgery, al the Brooklyn Hospital, in medical education he served the hospital and as Clinical Associate Professor of Surgery at Downstate Medical Center, he assisted us in building a better hospital by faithfully serving as a member of the Medical Board. He made our community a better place in which to live. His kind, gentle ways and leadership will be deeply missed and never forgotten. We extend our sincere condolences to his bereaved family.

title: U.S. Urged to Keep Import Curbs on Color TV Sets
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Manufacturers of color television sets asked the Government today for an extension of restrictions on imports from Japan, South Korea and Taiwan.

title: EDUCATION
description: EDUCATORS are becoming aware that most of today's children enter kindergarten after having watched thousands of hours of television. By the time they graduate from high school most students will have spent 18,000 hours with the TV curriculum compared with 12,000 hours in the classroom.

title: The Woman From Downing Street
description: Political stereotypes can be swiftly broken. When Margaret Thatcher became the first woman to serve as Britain's Prime Minister, it was nearuniversal wisdom that she would make her mark in domestic policy. With just a touch of chauvinism, male observers called her a tyro in diplomacy, handicapped by rightwing doctrines and likely to stumble badly, the first time out, on Rhodesia; she seemed an Iron Maiden without the velvet touch.

title: Taxes
description: WITH rising Social Security taxes consuming a greater share of company profits, more and more businesses are turning to a new payroll approach that can cut their assessments.

title: News Summary
description: A final accord on Rhodesia was reached as leaders of the Patriotic Front guerrillas accepted a British ceasefire plan aimed at ending the sevenyear civil war. The agreement, achieved after 14 weeks of intensive negotiations in London, also provides for a new independence constitution and early parliamentary elections. The guerrilla leaders said that private assurances by Britain had helped convince them of fair treatment under the truce. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Businessman Is Given 6 Years in G.S.A. Fraud
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 17 (UPI)  A Washington businessman was sentenced today to six years in prison for defrauding the Federal Government in the General Services Administration scandal.

title: Carter's Campaign in New York Chooses a Hispanic Coordinator
description: President Carter's New York campaign picked a Hispanic coordinator yesterday  Councilman Robert Rodriguez of the Bronx. looked upon by some politicians as a rival of Herman Badillo.

title: Bridge.
description: The format of Swiss team competition tends to produce exciting finishes, and the concluding event of the Winter Regionals of the Greater New York Bridge Association in the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday was no exception.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: BENEDICKCatherine (Nee Doyle) of Brooklyn, New York. Formerly of Teaneck, N.J. on December 16, 1979. Beloved wife of Abe. Devoted mother of Catherine Carberry and the late John Smith. Loving sister of John and Edward Doyle, Helen Sharp, Frances John, Margaret O'Brien and Jean Mullen. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from the Boulevard Funeral Home 1151 River Road, New Milford, N.J. on Wednesday, December 19, 1979 at 9AM, thence to Ascension R.C. Church, New Milford where the Funeral Mass will be offered at 9:30AM. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Friends may visit on Tuesday, 24 and 79PM.

title: Strife in Seoul: U.S. Fears a Wider Danger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Despite their preoccupation with the crisis in Iran, officials in the Carter Administration have on their hands in Korea an emergency that some say is potentially more dangerous than that in Teheran.

title: Seoul Prosecutor Asks Death for Accused Killer of Park and 6 Others
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 18  Military prosecutors demanded the death penalty today for the confessed assassin of President Park Chung Hee and for six associates who were charged as coconspirators.

title: Arthur G. Blair, an Inventor, 88; Was Owner of Yonkers Shipyard
description: Arthur G. Blair, an inventor of elevator control devices and a former executive of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, died last Thursday at the age of 88 at his home in Yonkers.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 18 (AP) Army troops killed 25 leftists, wounded four and captured 16 in a gun battle today at a coffee plantation 30 miles west of here, the Government announced tonight.

title: TV: She Loves Me
description: THE word for She Loves Me, the Jerry BockSheldon Harnick musical that opened on Broadway in 1963, has always been charming. The British Broadcasting Corporation's new production, which can be seen tonight at 9 on WNETTV, Channel 13, is indeed that and more. It is something on the order of sensationally charming.

title: Liberal Cleric Under Attack
description: Unlike the Rev. Edward Schillebeeckx, the Dutch theologian whose views were examined by Vatican officials last week, the Rev. Hans Kng has refused to take part in what he calls inquisitional procedures that pertain to his work.

title: Muzorewa Delays Return to London for Truce Signing
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 18  A hitch in Britain's plan for the formal signing of its Rhodesia peace plan developed today when Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa announced that he was delaying his return to London for the signing until he received clarification on the ceasefire provisions of the pact.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: HERE now in the season of nostalgic reminiscence, let us pay tribute to a very important person  someone who has been ignored in the hoopla over the subway system's Diamond Jubilee. We refer, of course, to Miss Subways. You remember her, vivacious, versatile, the fresh new face on the placard every month. Although the Transit Authority axed the beauty contest in 1976, Miss Subways is still of mythic significance to many in our city. We consulted Mayor Edward 1. Koch to see if he was one of them. Sure, he mused. Even now, I can sit in the subway, and look up at the ads, and close my eyes, and there's Miss Subways, he said. She wasn't the most beautiful girl in the world, but she was ours. She was our own Miss America. We asked if it might be appropriate to revive the lady, for old time's sake. No, he said. I don't believe in repeating the past. Try to do that and all you get is kitsch. But maybe the M.T.A. should have a little contest  you know, about what should replace Miss Subways.

title: Fox to Release 12 Features By TimeLife In Next 3 Years
description: In its new association with Time Inc., 20th CenturyFox will release up to 12 feature films to be produced by TimeLife Films in the next three years. An announcement of the plan was made yesterday by Alan J. Hirschfield, vice chairman of 20th CenturyFox, and Bruce L. Paisner, president of TimeLife Films. David Susskind, TimeLife senior executive producer, will supervise the production schedule.

title: The Complaints of the Women's Lobby
description: We've held back comment on the rejection President Carter's candidacy by the National Organization for Women. The nominating convention is eight months off and the election is 11 months off. Perhaps, we thought, there is a way out of that tightly painted corner, or an explanation. Alas, the ineptitude stands unrelieved. NOW should try to get out of its corner even before the paint dries.

title: New Starts In Housing Down 14%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  The construction of new homes plummeted 14 percent last month to an annual rate of 1.5 million units, further evidence that the Federal Reserve's tightmoney policy has begun to slow the nation's economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Fertilization Clinic in Virginia Is One Step Away From Approval
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 18 (AP)  Efforts to establish the nation's first socalled testtube baby clinic today won the approval of the State Health Coordinating Council, the nexttolast step in a review process.

title: Man Dies in Dormitory Explosion
description: PULLMAN, Wash., Dec. 18 (AP) man was killed and five persons were injured today in an explosion in a dormitory at Washington State University, the authorities said.

title: Stage: Beckett's Piece of Monologue
description: DAVID WARRILOW stands at the edge of the stage, a thin, spectral figure made even more ghostly by his garb. He is dressed in a white nightshirt  or is it a hospital gown? His hair is whitened. In the middle of the stage is floor lamp with a round skullsize white globe. The man and the lamp are twin sentinels, tall totems. There is third object: the foot of a bed, which barely extends into our field of vision. After a pause, the man, identified as the Speaker, begins to talk: Birth. Birth was the death of him.

title: The Region
description: Two men charged with killing four people in the Westchester community of Bedford Hills last May were found guilty yesterday of robbing guests at a Brooklyn party 17 days after the Westchester slayings.

title: Britian Plans Water Reactor
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  The British Government today announced plans to build an American pressurizedwater nuclear reactor similar to the type that leaked radioactive gases at the Three Mile Island plant near Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Prominent Theologian Censured by Vatican For His Liberal Views
description: ROME, Dec. 18  The Vatican, in a stern move to uphold traditional doctrine, today censured a leading liberal theologian, the Rev. Hans Kiing, and barred him from teaching.

title: Pianist and Cellist Win Fisher Artist Prizes
description: Mona Golabek, pianist, and Sharon Robinson, cellist, have received the first two Recital Awards of the Avery Fisher Artist Program, it was announced yesterday by Lincoln Center. The noncompetitive awards, which consist of $1,000 and a recital in Alice Tully Flail, are given annually to young musicians who deserve greater public recognition.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The price of gold passed $480 an ounce for the first time yesterday as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continued to meet to decide how much to raise oil prices.

title: Udall Backs Kennedy; Asserts He Can Unite Party's Constituencies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Representative Morris K. Udall, who was runnerup to Jimmy Carter for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976, today endorsed Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts for the nomination in 1980 on the ground that Kennedy is better on leadership and better on policy.

title: Mandatory Narcotics Sentence Is Upheld by U.S. Appeals Court
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld a sentence, imposed under strict drug laws passed at the bidding of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, that had sent a Brooklyn truck driver to prison for 15 years to life for being in a car containing narcotics, United Press International reported.

title: Screen: 'Kramer vs. Kramer':East Side Story
description: THERE may be no place in the world that seems quite as civilized and reassuring as Manhattan's East Side  when you're feeling good and have money in your pocket. It's expensive but value is given. It's a privilege simply to look into the windows of Madison Avenue boutiques that keep their doors bolted against customers who don't measure up. The sidewalk musicians on Fifth Avenue play Purcell and Vivaldi and one never has to travel very far to find a restaurant where the food is worth the king's ransom it costs. Unlike those on the West Side, most of the apartment building doormen on the East Side wear uniforms that differentiate them from the muggers. Everything seems forever.When things are going wrong, though, Manhattan's East Side immediately reflects the unhappiness of an upwardly mobile people who have no idea where they're going or why. Everything is ridiculously expensive. Walls are thin and ceilings low. Cab drivers are rude. Husbands are self-centered and unreliable and wives, who have been urged to realize themselves, start by seeing an analyst. As rats command the sewers, vaguely understood fears run amok through the corridors of the fancy new high-rises above.This is the hermetic world of Robert Benton's fine, witty, moving, most intelligent adaptation of Avery Corman's best-selling novel, "Kramer vs. Kramer," which opens today at Loews Tower East and other theaters."Kramer vs. Kramer" is a Manhattan movie, yet it seems to speak for an entire generation of middle-class Americans who came to maturity in the late 60's and early 70's, sophisticated in superficial ways but still expecting the fulfillment of promises made in the more pious Eisenhower era.Ted Kramer (Dustin Hoffman) is a self-described take-over guy who left Brooklyn for Manhattan's East Side and is speeding to the top at his advertising agency. Everything in his life is working out as planned. When "Kramer vs. Kramer" opens, the elated Ted has just been handed his agency's most valued new account. As he says a few minutes later, this has been one of the five best days of his life.It is with some surprise, then, that he returns home to find his wife, Joanna (Meryl Streep), jaw-set and teary-eyed, determined to depart forever, leaving Ted not only with an entire ad presentation to prepare for the next day but also with their six-year-old son, Billy (Justin Henry), to take care of. Ted is not someone who always gets his priorities straight."Kramer vs. Kramer" is one of those rare American movies that never have to talk importantly and self-consciously to let you know that it has to do with many more things than are explicitly stated. It's about fathers and sons, husbands and wives, and most particularly, perhaps, about the failed expectations of a certain breed of woman in this day and age.Though much of "Kramer vs. Kramer" is occupied with the growing relationship between the abandoned father and son, through tantrums and reconciliations and playground accidents, the central figure is that of the movingly, almost dangerously muddled mother, played by Miss Streep in what is one of the major performances of the year. Joanna is not an easily appealing character, especially when she returns after 18 months of therapy in California and seeks legal custody of the child she walked out on.Though beautiful, intelligent, well-educated and no more than casually self-assertive at the start, she grows into one of those fiercely determined people who talks about "finding" herself even as we  and she  suspect there may be nothing to find except another series of compromises. She seems to be a woman in transit to disappointment. Maybe not. She's not a character who can be conveniently categorized, and she is fascinating.Mr. Hoffman is splendid in one of the two or three best roles of his career. It's a delicately witty performance, funny and full of feeling that never slops over into the banal, which is the greatest danger faced by an actor who must play most of his scenes with a small boy who is as down-to-earth and pragmatic as Justin Henry. There is no way that Mr. Hoffman can avoid being upstaged when Billy, watching his father make a mess of French toast, says carefully. "I don't like it folded.""Kramer vs. Kramer" is densely packed with such beautifully observed detail. It is also superbly acted by its supporting cast, including Jane Alexander, Howard Duff and George Coe.The man responsible for the photography is the gifted Nestor Almendros, whose earlier credits include Terrence Malick's "Days of Heaven," Franois Truffaut's "The Story of Adele H." and Eric Rohmer's "Clair's Knee," among other things. The Manhattan he shows us is familiar enough but we see a lot more than a series of pretty surfaces."Kramer vs. Kramer," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language and some discreet nudity.

title: What Price Charisma?
description: As the Iranian crisis makes abundantly clear, the President holds our future in his hands. His personality may be our destiny. His character may spell the difference between war and peace, destruction and survival. It matters very much, in short, who is there at a given moment.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: FLOODING KILLS THREE IN WASHINGTON STATE: Heavy rains in western Washington caused extensive flooding, forcing more than 200 people from their homes.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Matthew A. R. Bassity, a parttime copy editor of The New York Times News Service and a former president of the Overseas Press Club, died Sunday of heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

title: Personal Health
description: THE tree, an aromatic fir, is trimmed and lighted, with the beautifully wrapped presents arranged beneath it. A fire crackles in the hearth, mistletoe hangs from the doorway and a poinsettia and candles form the centerpiece on the dinner table. The bar is set with nothing but the best. A puppy is in hiding in the basement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Beehive International, Salt Lake Citybased manufacturer of computer display equipment, has named John Bodell vice president of sales.

title: TV: Asner in a Drama
description: EDWARD ASNER steps out of his Lou Grant role in The Family Man, which will be shown from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on CBSTV. He is such an intelligent and ingratiating actor that it is almost impossible to dislike anything in which he appears, but this one comes close.

title: Obituary 9  No Title
description: STEINBERGJulie. On Dec. 15, 1979 after a long illness. Wife of the late Harris B. Steinberg, mother of Jane Marks and Robert, grandmother of Benjamin and Sarah Steinberg, Joshua and Christopher Marks, sister of Woodrow Sandler, Dorothy Haines, and the late Janice Shapiro. Memorial gathering Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Legal Aid Society or Graham Windham Services For Children and Families, 1 Park Avenue, N.Y.C., 10016.HOLLANDMichael In fond memory of our loving father who passed away 37 years ago today. Always In our hearts.

title: Kitchen Equipment On Stock and Stockpots
description: IT'S funny, really, to see those little 13ounce cans of chicken or beef broth in the store, the kind of broth that is commonly substituted for stock in recipes. Clear stock, prepared in great volume, is at the heart of the sauces and soups that have warmed my life. It is something I have always thought of in terms of gallons or quarts. I would no sooner buy stock in ounces than I would wine.

title: Murderer in Georgia Asks Death To Stop Pain of a Bullet in Spine
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 18 (AP)  Jack Howard Potts, a convicted murderer on death row here, says that the policeman's bullet that shattered his jaw and lodged in his spine four years ago when he was arrested has turned his life into one of torture and pain.

title: Figure in Jordan Case Pleads Guilty to Drug Charge
description: John Conaghan, who allegedly supplied cocaine to Hamilton Jordan at the Studio 54 discotheque, pleaded guilty yesterday to a separate narcotics charge in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: ABCTV Tops Nielsens
description: AFTER 13 weeks of the television season, the primetime ratings race has settled into a twonetwork contest, with CBSTV steadily encroaching on ABCTV's lead. Although ABC was the dominant network last week, CBS has ranked first in three of the last five weeks.

title: Mine Union, in a Shift, Trims Legal Assessment
description: DENVER, Dec. 18 (AP)  Delegates to the United Mine Workers convention today reduced by half a special $20aperson legal assessment, rolling back an assessment approved yesterday.

title: A Chemical Web Of Contamination
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec.16 (AP)  A Food and Drug Administration report, summing up the web of contamination from a single spill of a toxic chemical at a Montana meat plant, says that perhaps no other PCB contamination incident has been as farranging or as complex.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: WHEN I was a very young chef in France, the world seemed like a very well ordered universe where the variety of foods was concerned. There were peas to be turned into petits pois a la Franaise, carrots for making dishes named Crcy and asparagus for all those foods listed on menus as Argenteuil. The vegetables in the garden were all well catalogued and finite.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: COHENHelen M. On December 17, 1979. Wife of the late Harry Cohen, beloved mother of Marge Lotuto, Lt. Col. Richard Korman and Serette Harding. Dear grandmother of Sarah Weinreich. Service Wednesday, 2 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

title: Knicks Beat Hawks, End Slide
description: The Knicks survived Atlanta's famed pressure defense in the final quarter last night and defeated the Hawks, 10199, at Madison Square Garden. In posting their 15th victory of the National Basketball Association campaign, the Knicks snapped a fivegame losing streak and the Hawks fourgame winning skreak.

title: Advertising
description: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH INTERNATIONAL, the 12thlargest American agency worldwide, is planning to acquire Barickman Advertising, a general agency with offices in Kansas City, Mo., and Denver, and Bernard Hodes Advertising, recruitment advertising specialists, which has 11 offices coast to coast and an outpost in London. Together their billings come to $90 million.

title: Hatfield and Gov. Atiyeh Ask Destruction of Nerve Gas Stored in Oregon
description: HERMISTON, Ore., Dec. 17  The United States Army's Umatilla munitions depot, nine miles from here in the heart of the Oregon desert, is 20,000 acres of sagebrush dotted with 2,001 grassy humps that the Army calls igloos. The igloos, sodcovered concrete Quonset bunkers, store a substantial part of the nation's medium ordnance: bombs, bullets, rockets, shells and, for the last 18 years, a large store of deadly chemical warfare agents.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE MIRACLE MACHINE. by Doug Gilbert. 314 pages. Illustrated. Coward, McCann &; Geoghegan. $10.95.

title: Rutgers Assistant Chosen Columbia's Football Coach
description: Bob Naso, an assistant coach at Rutgers the last 21 years, was named head football coach at Columbia University yesterday. He succeeds Bill Campbell, who resigned after six years of frustration.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN LEADER (U.S. Lines). Rotterdam Dec. 29 and Felixstowe 30; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: General Mills Net Sets Marks
description: General Mills Inc. achieved record results in the quarter and halfyear periods ended Nov. 25 with profits up 21.5 percent and 11.2 percent, respectively, according to yesterday's report of the giant food processor.

title: City Begins Leasing Space Under Bridges
description: A wine shop will be installed in three vaults beneath the Manhattan approach to the Brooklyn Bridge by group of bidders who won a fiveyear lease on the space at a public auction.

title: Bus Shelter Talks Collapse; Trial of Civil Suit Is Ordered
description: Attempts to negotiate a settlement that would have allowed construction of new bus shelters to resume in New York City broke down yesterday and Justice Bentley Kassal of State Supreme Court ordered the start of a civil trial, tentatively set for March 3.

title: Having Admitted Shah, Panama Is Said to Seek U.S. Aid
description: PANAMA, Dec. 18  Foreign diplomats said today that Panama's strongman, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, admitted the Shah last weekend in the hope of winning more United States support for Panama's economy.

title: Claus Leaves North Pole Seeking Job Opportunity
description: NORTH POLE, N.Y., Dec. 16  For nine years he worked right here, and he still lives nearby in his bright red house with its closets full of bright red clothes  everything from a red leisure suit to a big pair of red swimming trunks.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sinfonia in minor, Vivaldi ; Sonata No. 2 (Op. 26), Boismortier.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Gold and silver futures set new highs for the fifth consecutive day yesterday, and cotton futures were drawn in their wake to new season's highs.

title: Catholic Bishop for Sacramento
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  Auxiliary Bishop Francis A. Quinn of San Francisco has been appointed Roman Catholic Bishop of Sacramento, Calif. The Rev. Jose de Jesus Madera, pastor of St. Lucy's Church in Fowler, Calif., has been named coadjutor of the Fresno, Calif., Diocese with the right of succession to Bishop Hugh A. Donohoe. The appointments by Pope John Paul II were announced by Archbishop Jean Jadot, Apostolic Delegate in the United States.

title: Giants Begin Search To Improve Offense
description: Where do the Giants go from here? Ray Perkins and George Young leave this morning for Montgomery, Ala., where they will begin their search for a fullback, tight end and offensive linemen, maybe a cornerback or two, and a nose guard.

title: Threatened Editor Quits Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18  The British editor of an Englishlanguage newspaper here has left Argentina with his family, driven out, he said, by people who want to keep the country in the grip of darkness.

title: Texts of Vatican Declaration and Priest's Statement
description: Following are the texts of the Vatican declaration on the theological doctrine of the Rev. Hans Kung, translated from Latin by the Vatican, and a statement by Prof. Kng, both made public yesterday:

title: PreciousMetal Issues Up
description: With gold fever gripping bullion markets abroad, preciousmetal stocks produced smart gains on Wall Street yesterday while the general market sagged in heavy trading.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Middle and high level cloudiness extends from the Middle Atlantic States through the lake region to the northern Rockies. Snow cover Is visible in the western sections of the Northern Plains States and in the Rockies. Dense layered clouds are visible In the Pacific Northwest. Clear skies are apparent in the rest of the country.

title: To Satisfy A
description: NO matter who else may or may not be made merry during this season, it's a cinch that dentists and owners of reducing spas have every reason to celebrate.

title: Marine Accused of Desertion Faces First Witness
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., Dec. 18 Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, accused of wartime desertion in Vietnam and mistreating American prisoners of war there, today faced the first witness against him in a military pretrial investigation here.

title: Robert S. Gordon, 81 ; Scarsdale Civic Leader Fought Book Banning
description: Robert S. Gordon, a longtime civic leader in Scarsdale, N.Y., who in 1949 fought a campaign to eliminate books by authors suspected of being proCommunist from the school system died Monday at his Scarsdale home. He was 81 years old.

title: Watch What They Say
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Early in the Nixon Administration, Attorney General John N. Mitchell, advised civil rights leaders to watch what we do, not what we say. As a lawyer and politician, he should have known better than to attack rhetoric. While actions sometimes speak louder than words, words speak more clearly: They supply meaning to our actions. Mr. Mitchell may have finally realized that what is said is often more important than what is done.

title: Film: Seeking 'Solutions':Scientific Odyssey
description: THE Search for Solutions," which opens today at Cinema 2, is not the sort of film you would expect to find playing in Bloomingdale country. Only two theatrical engagements are scheduled, in New York and in Los Angeles. It will be shown on public television next spring and be distributed to schools and colleges.The stated purpose of "The Search for Solutions" is to stimulate interest in science and technology, primarily among the young. The film comprises nine 18-minute sections touching on various aspects of scientific inquiry that its makers say can be shown as a whole, as it is in this engagement, or in any combination of its parts.Each of the sections bears a portentous title and touches on eight to 14 illustrative subjects. The first section, for example, is called "Context," and deals with such diverse matters as the use of an upright airplane wing instead of a sail on a boat, the "singing" of humpback whales, the ancient clay tokens that are thought to represent the earliest known use of human language, the discovery of the X-ray, the invention of a canvas tube that is safer and quicker than a ladder or a rope for descending, say, from a burning building, and the physiology of hibernating bears.It is difficult to watch "The Search for Solutions" from the viewpoint of the youngsters for whom it is primarily intended.
