A long and distinguished list of academic advisers took part in making it, and a companion study guide will be issued for use by teachers.Thus, the film may well achieve its purpose, but for an adult viewer the segments of only a minute or two or three bring to mind the technique of television commercials, and the connections made between the wildly different disciplines listed above, for example, often seem arbitrary. The narration, by Stacy Keach, often seems both windy and patronizing. At one point he says, for example, "An idea that works in one situation may not work in another; it has to be appropriate."Indeed, the failure to examine any of the fields the film touches on and the absence of a coherent historical context create an effect that might almost be described as antiscientific. In this respect, "The Search for Solutions" seems much inferior to such series as the "The Ascent of Man" and "Connections" that have been shown on public television.Technically, however, "The Search for Solutions" is quite good. It was produced by James C. Crimmins for Playback Associates, a maker of industrial and documentary films, under a $1.4 million grant from the Phillips Petroleum Company, and directed by Michael Jackson. The filming, mainly documentary but including brief historical re-creations, was done in 14 countries. The proceeds of the scheduled three-week theatrical engagement in New York will be given to the program for minorities in science and engineering at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Plane Diverted by Bomb Threat
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 18 (AP)  A Trans World Airlines Lockheed L1011 flying from Philadelphia to Los Angeles was diverted here tonight because of a bomb threat, the authorities said. The passengers aboard TWA Flight 37 disembarked safely, and there was no Iword on whether a bomb was found.

title: When Trapped by a Bore, Don't Just Stand There!
description: The first clue is a glazed expression, the second is a fixed smile. The clincher is a conversation in sounds, rather than words (listen for such giveaways as ah ha, and mmmm.). Put the three together at any party, and they add up to someone stuck with a bore.

title: CITY POLICE REVAMP SCREENING PROGRAM
description: The New York City Police Department is revamping its new psychological screening program following criticism that it is racially discriminatory and may not be weeding out potentially unstable individuals from the ranks of new police officers.

title: Notes on People
description: The actress Michael Learned, who won three consecutive Emmy awards for her portrayal of the mother in the familyconscious The Waltons television series, and William Parker, who has some script writing for the show among his credits, assembled some of their own relatives yesterday for a sequel  their wedding at the Park Avenue United Methodist Church.

title: Salute to Bones Dillard, Who Ran Them Over in the Olympics
description: When Barney Ewell felt the tape against his chest at the finish of the Olympic 100 meters, he went into a wild victory dance, leaping and whirling, hands clasped overhead. He had drawn the No. 2 lane, with Harrison Dillard on the extreme outside and Lloyd La Beach of Panama between them in No. 3 or 4. Finishing third, LaBeach had a clear view of the runners ahead of him. Mon. he told Ewell, you don't win it. Bones win. The judges confirmed him, and Harrison Dillard had more than his first gold medal. He had brought off one of the truly extraordinary achievements by beating the world's best in an event that wasn't his. He was a hurdler first and sprinter second, incomparably the best hurdler alive. From July of 1947 to June of 1948 he had won 82 consecutive races over fences high and low at every distance from 50 yards to 220, but in a shocking final tryout for the United States Olympic team he failed to qualify.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I notice in many recipes that beer is called for as an ingredient in place of milk or water. Is there a reason?

title: Clabir Agrees to Buy General Host Shares
description: The Clabir Corporation said yesterday that it had entered into an agreement in principle with its coinvestors under which Clabir would acquire the options, or other rights, to purchase the 338,000 shares of the General Host Corporation held by them.

title: An Ice Cream Maker For the Home  $675
description: Some people will do anything for fresh homemade ice cream. Which is why WilliamsSonoma, the California gourmet food people, decided to import what may well be the most expensive kitchen gadget going. It's the Minigel ice cream machine, making one creamysmooth quart of ice cream, sorbet or Italian ice in less than 25 minutes without the mess of ice cubes or salt.

title: Italian Workers Making Strikes A Big Business
description: ROME, Dec. 18  In recent days, Italian workers have gone on strike, or have threatened to strike, in hospitals, schools, banks, farms, newspapers, airports, railroads, ferryboats, department stores, shops, theaters, films, television networks, construction companies, chemical and textile factories and the metallurgical industry.

title: Israeli Military Vessel Becomes First to Dock at an Egyptian Port
description: PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  The missile boat Tarshish today became the first Israeli military vessel to dock at an Egyptian port.

title: SAUDIS SAID TO DELAY WEAPONS FOR YEMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Carter Administration officials said today that Saudi Arabia had interfered recently with an American program for arming Yemen, prompting that country to turn to the Soviet Union for weapons.

title: Japanese Assure U.S. of Support In Moves to Put Pressure on Iran
description: TOKYO, Dec. 18  In terms that were lowkeyed and cautious, at least for public consumption, the Japanese Government has assured the United States that would cooperate in international efforts to gain the release of the 50 Americans held hostage in Iran.

title: WASHINGTON The Dangerous Decade
description: In her first and all too brief visit to the United States as Prime Minister of Great Britain, Margaret Thatcher gave the political leaders of this country a few things to consider.

title: Dr. Owen J. Cheevers Dead at 68; Surgeon and ExHead of Hospital
description: Dr. Owen J. Cheevers, a surgeon and former president and chairman of the medical board of St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Manhattan, died Sunday at West Hudson Hospital in Kearny, N.J. He was 68 years old and lived in Lakewood, N.J., where he had moved from Yonkers, N.Y., on his retirement last year.

title: Saudi Says Mosque Raid Inquiry Shows No Foreign Involvement
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18  Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia has announced that investigations into the takeover of the Grand Mosque in Mecca last month turned up no evidence of involvement by a foreign power, according to the Riyadh radio.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Saudis Criticize Reports Of a Plunge in Reserves
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia. Dec. 18 (Reuters)  The Saudi Arabian Ministry of Finance and National Economy today described reports of a serious decline in the official foreign exchange reserves of the kingdom as totally misleading.

title: Music: Jupiter Symphony
description: WHEN Jens Nygaard announced his new Jupiter Symphony, it was to be an orchestra of between 48 and 75 players, depending on repertory. The first performance, in October at Carnegie Hall, fell within those limits, although admittedly toward the lower end. But Monday night's Jupiter Symphony prograin at Alice Tully Hall was a chamber concert, pure and simple. And apoorly attended one, to boot, which makes one worry that Mr. Nygaard's ambitious schemes are already running short of money. Even if they aren't, it's still confusing for a new organization that is trying to build a following to announce a symphony concert with no further qualifications and then present something like this.

title: GOLDIN EXONERATED BY TUNNEL INQUIRY
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has been exonerated, in a letter from the New York City Commissioner of Investigation, of any improprieties in connection with contracts for a new water tunnel.

title: Dr. Nolan D. C. Lewis Dies at 90; Psychiatrist Was Leader in Field
description: Dr. Nolan D. C. Lewis, a former director of the New York State Psychiatric Institute and an internationally known figure in neuropathology, died yesterday at the Frederick (Md.) Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Frederick.

title: Fed Official Explains Resignation
description: Rudolf Thunberg said yesterday that he had been asked to resign as vice president and assistant research director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York last week because he had invested a modest sum in a municipal bond trust shortly after the Fed announced in late October that it had made substantial errors in reporting its money supply figures.

title: Martin to Stop His Criticizing
description: ONEIDA, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP)  Billy Martin, former manager of the Yankees, spoke with the conviction of a man making a New Year's resolution tonight and said he's through talking about his former boss, George Steinbrenner.

title: We Cannot Operate in Cambodia
description: The international groups supplying food to Cambodia have gone out of their way not to antagonize the regime in Phnom Penh, the Vietnamese supporting that regime and the Soviet Union, which supports Vietnam. When the rest of the world condemned all three for not allowing enough food into Cambodia, the relief agencies remained quiet enough to get some supplies in. was a wise gamble; more than 50,000 tons of food and other supplies have reached Cambodia. More is arriving daily.

title: Comparing Ducks on the Market
description: THE following ducks were tested over a twoweek period and included a selection of white Pekin, mallard and Muscovy ducks purchased at a variety of markets. Birds were judged according to overall appearance, flavor and texture and are listed in order of preference within each breed.

title: Chicago Mayor Orders Some Transit Service Restored
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 18  Two days into transit strike that has inconvenienced more than a million commuters and caused the loss of millions of dollars to businesses, Mayor Jane M. Byrne ordered a partial restoration of service on the city's rapid rail lines.

title: Small Earthquake in California
description: YUCAIPA, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP) small earthquake was recorded in this high desert town today, but it caused no damage. The earthquake registered 3.3 on the Richter scale and was centered three miles southeast of Redlands, at the outskirts of Yucaipa, said Dennis Meredith, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology's seismology laboratory in Pasadena.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: ARNOLDNewton S. Suddenly on Dec. 16, 1979. Beloved husband of Irene; dear brother of Allene Daube, Genevieve Wetmore, Tex Arnold. Services Monday, Dec 23, 9:30AM at Gutterman's, 331 Amsterdam Ave at 76th St. Friends may visit at Gytterman's Sat. from 79PM.

title: No Big Change in Taxes Expected in New Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. IS  Administration policy makers now expect that the budget President Carter sends Congress next month will make no major tax proposals either for reductions in personal and corporate taxes or for an increase in the Federal gasoline tax.

title: TV Special: Holmes, Tate Bouts
description: Larry Holmes and John Tate will defend their world heavyweight boxing titles against separate contenders on a twocity program March 31, and, if both are successful, will fight each other to decide the undisputed champion, probably in September. The promotion of a television card involving two professional heavyweight champions in separate bouts on the same night is unprecedented.

title: Private Lives
description: THERE is a drum on the desk. Inside the drum are scraps of paper on which our names have been scribbled. Outside is a sort of elbow, as if the drum were a mimeograph machine. Hours loll by. Empty of mind  well, perhaps not entirely empty: sawdust sifts in the skullcase; cobwebs lick the sockets of the eyes we stare at the drum. The drum does not stare back. Nor do our keepers. Our keepers are also inward, averting their glance. Behind our little blue badges, we are nothing to look at. Lapsed in afghans that signify, variously, our leisure or our indigence or our remorse, we are wary and spectral. As the hands have been removed from the clock on the wall, so are the minutes gone, stolen, vandalized, from our blank faces.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Ron Nessen's otherwise exemplary article on political wisecracks makes one error in reporting that the late Alben Barkley was famous for his line about two brothers: One ran away to sea, the other was elected Vice President, and nothing was heard of either of them again. Barkley was indeed famous as a political raconteur, but this line should properly be credited to one of his predecessors, Thomas Riley Marshall.

title: OPEC'S BOARD URGES KEY CHARGE BE KEPT AT $24$25 A BARREL
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 18  The economic commission of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has recommended a benchmark oil price of $24 to $25 a barrel, Venezuela's oil minister, Humberto Calderon Berti, said today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Dec.18,1979

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Assuming there will always be conflicts of interest between governments, the Iranian situation presents us with a continuing case study in sound principles for the management of international conflicts.

title: Best Buys
description: ZABAR'S has finally done it. Not only has the 43yearold Upper West Side food emporium nearly doubled its space in the last week (making the shopping crunch a little less crunchy), but it has also come out with Zabar's Deli Book, a virtual smorgasboard of all the things people love about deli food in general and Zabar's in particular.

title: Presidential Board Hears L.I.R.R. Unions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Presidential Emergency Board named last week to halt the Long Island Rail Road strike held its first meeting today with the seven unions that have refused to sign contracts and, although the board turned down two procedural requests, a spokesman for the unions said that they were pleased with the talks.

title: Music: Da Capo Players
description: THE Da Capo Chamber Players gave special prominence to their flutist at the group's concert Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Patricia Spencer was featured in the New York premieres of two works for flute and piano, Elie Yarden's Ode (1976) and Diana McIntosh's Luminaries (1978).

title: Election Panel Approves Funds For 1976 Labor Party Candidate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  The Federal Election Commission, after an unexpected closed meeting, voted today to approve an application for Federal matching funds for Lyndon H. La Rouche, a Presidential candidate.

title: Trudeau Agrees to Lead Liberals in Canadian Elections Set for February
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 18  Former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today accepted a Liberal Party draft to lead it in the election scheduled for Feb. 18 and put an end to 'unacceptably bad government by the Progressive Conservatives.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  Gov. Edward J. King took control of the nearly insolvent Boston regional transit system today and said he favored raising its 25cent fare.

title: The Christmas Gold Rush
description: The Christmas shoppers at Lord & Taylor's jewelry counter peered into the glass cases full of gold chains and bracelets, concentrating as carefully as if they were examining exotic butterflies.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Exports Fuel U.S. Crop Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Despite another year of bumper crops, cash grain and feed prices are edging up again as exports to the Soviet Union and other large foreign buyers continue at record rates.

title: Georgia Tech Drops Rodgers
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 18 (AP)  Pepper Rodgers, hired six seasons ago as Georgia Tech's football coach to put the sting back in the Yellow Jackets, was dismissed today.

title: Real Estate
description: THE new president of the Pahlavi Foundation, Manoucher Shafie, is a dapper 92yearold man with graying hair and a mustache. He is to be found in a modest office on an unfinished floor of the foundation's sole American asset, the halfoccupied office building at at 650 Fifth Avenue. A color rendering of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini exhorting the faithful is affixed to the wall at his right.

title: OilRights Bids Top $800 Million
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 18 (Reuters)  The Government received high bids totaling more than $800 million today for oildrilling rights to the Georges Bank in a sale at which protesters hurled oilfilled plastic bags at oil company executives.

title: Where NOW Has a Point
description: The National Organization for Women and other groups have raised a more persuasive complaint against a Federal judge in Boise, Idaho, who is hearing a court challenge that could kill the Equal Rights Amendment. The judge, Marion Callister, also holds a high position in the Mormon Church, one of the most energetic opponents of the amendment.

title: Pupils Letters About Hostages Reflect Feelings of GrownUps
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The letters are carefully penned in the precise, ordered hand of childhood, but the range of sentiments  the pleas and the demands  reflects the feelings expressed in boardrooms and barrooms around the country.

title: Court Approves Further Inquiry On a Surrogate
description: An appeals court yesterday empowered the State Commission on Judicial Conduct to go forward with a longdelayed investigation into the financing of Surrogate Marie M. Lambert's 1977 election campaign in Manhattan.

title: Amtrak to Offer a 25% Discount To the Elderly and Handicapped
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Amtrak, the federally supported national passenger railroad, said today that beginning Jan. 1 it would grant a 25 percent discount to elderly and handicapped travelers on all trips that regularly sold for $40 or more oneway.

title: Natural Gas Found By Amoco in U.S.
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  The Amoco Production Company said today that it had discovered potentially significant natural gas reserves in deep Tuscaloosa wildcat well drilled near Denham Springs, La.

title: The City
description: More than 2,400 city managerial employees will receive salary increases of up to 7 percent based on performance, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Connecticut G.O.P. Picks Woman as Its Chairman
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 18  The Republican State Central Committee chose Jo McKenzie tonight as its new leader, the first woman to be chairman of a major state political party in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Princess Grace Bejewels a Disco Party
description: Princess Grace of Monaco, dripping with diamonds and wearing a Dior gown of Christmas red, caused some of New York's most jaded partygoers to act as though they were really enjoying themselves the other night at the Xenon discotheque.

title: Inland Steel Furloughs
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP)  The Inland Steel Company has announced the temporary layoff of 2,460 workers, primarily because of an automotive market slowdown. The company said 1,860 employees were furloughed for one week beginning last Sunday. Another 600 will be furloughed for one week beginning this Sunday, at which time the others will return to their jobs.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: HIRSHFIELD Pearl, on December 17, beloved wife of the late Abraham Hirshfield, devoted mother of Jack and Robert, loving grandmother of Laurie and Jane. Services Wednesday 12:15PM The Riverside 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Uniting to Help the Neediest

But officials expressed confidence that the ceremony would take place Thursday, and continued to regard the settlement as an accomplished fact.

In lieu of flowers memorial gifts to the White Plains Hospital Medical Center or Church of St Joseph of Arimathea would be appreciated.

title: Bowring Regret On McLennan Bid

Bowring & Company, one of Britain's largest insurance brokerage groups, announced in London yesterday that it viewed with regret the announcement by the Marsh & McLennan Companies, one of the biggest American insurance brokerages, that it was considering making a takeover bid for Bowring.

title: Screen: 'Roller Boogie':Round and Round
description: A WARM hearty welcome to "Roller Boogie," the dopiest movie of the year. This is a film about blithe young Californians who skate, just skate, that's all they do. A sampling of their conversation may perhaps reveal why they are so little qualified for anything else. Old fogey (he's at least 25): "I'm off to Arizona to watch the cactus grow." Kid: "That'll take forever!" Boy to girl, very seriously: "You got a mental problem or somethin'? You wanna skate and then you don't wanna skate? What is it with you?""Roller Boogie," which opens today at the Forum and other theaters, stars chunky little Linda Blair and was directed by Mark Lester, who seems to have expended most of his energies in efforts to make the leading lady look as leggy as the extras. Miss Blair plays a disgustingly carefree rich girl who spends the movie's saddest moments running away from home and sleeping in her lonely sports car. She's supposedly a brilliant flutist, but a musical career means nothing to her ("So what, I'm a musical genius. What a drag!"). The only thing that will make her life worthwhile, she says, will be winning a skating contest with the poor boy  he has to work for a living  who has been giving her lessons. The skating contest becomes the movie's dramatic climax, as well as its only event.Irwin Yablans, the producer credited with the story for "Roller Boogie," seems to have taken most of his dramatic inspiration from old episodes of "Charlie's Angels." So the latter half of the movie, after the skating subsides, is devoted to a lot of babble and intrigue about a gangster's taking over the kids' favorite rink. Because the kids are essentially fighting for the right to do nothing all day, and because they pay an awful lot of attention to the cut of the gangster's expensive suits, they don't make especially sympathetic victims.The early moments of the movie, devoted solely to skating, are happily stupid and have a fair amount of physical momentum. But 103 minutes is an awfully long time to watch people whiz along the boardwalk. The novelty wears off in a hurry."Roller Boogie" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains strong language, mild leering and one instance of teen-agers necking on a beach.

title: The Arduous Path To Her M.D. at 54
description: NEWTOWN, CONN. FOR a while, eight was enough for Barbara Jean Gretsch. Two sons and five daughters punctuated the first decade of her marriage to Richard Gretsch, an industrialist, and seven years later, the sixth daughter completed the family portrait.

title: Britons Are Warned by the Police On Letter Bombs in Holiday Mail
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP)  The police warned Britons today to beware of thick Christmas letters posted in Belgium because two of them exploded yesterday and a third was received today by a homeowner who gave it to detectives.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18  Federal and California agencies filed a $45 million suit against the Occidental Chemical Company today, charging that the concern illegally dumped hazardous wastes that then leaked into underground water supplies.

description: DES MOINES, Dec. 18 (AP)  John B. Connally said today that President Carter should brief all major Presidential candidates on the situation in Iran.

description: A judge has frozen the assets of nine corporations and 17 individuals suspected of peddling fraudulent futures in crude oil.

At the 1939 World's Fair, Mr. Harrison was responsible for the Trylon and Perisphere, the theme of the exhibition. He also created the Albany Mall.

title: Chicago's New Urban Woes

description: LEWISTON, Idaho, Dec. 18 (AP) bomb found at the Bonneville Power Administration's Hatwai substation northeast of here could have caused millions of dollars in damage if it had exploded, officials say.

Joseph Papp, the producer who initiated the idea for the exchange, has notified the Russians that his efforts to raise $1 million have failed. As a result, he said Monday in a cable, he sees at the present no possibility of A Chorus Line going to the U.S.S.R. and the Moscow Art Theater Coming to the U.S.

The plane landed safely and no one aboard was injured, the officials said.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Here is the 271to136 roll call Tuesday by which the House approved a $3.43 billion package of aid to the Chrysler Corporation, including $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees.

description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 18 (AP) There were bank robberies right up to game time and holdups right afterward, but it looks as if the crooks took a break to watch the game in this footballcrazy city.

title: Written Caution Cited in Release Of Accused Man
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 18  Two psychiatrists ignored a warning penned in red ink on the cover of a mental patient's medical file that the police, his wife and her lawyer were to be notified immediately if he escaped, state mental health officials said today at a public hearing.

title: Carter Aide's Call to Tax Agency Helped Ease Pressure on Chicago

title: Boxings Treaty Of Pragmatism
description: Historians remember the Treaty of Westphalia that followed the Thirty Years War, the Treaty of Vienna that followed the Napoleonic Wars and the Treaty of Versailles that followed World War I. Now, for boxing historians, negotiations have begun for the Treaty of Pragmatism between the two rival entrepreneurs, Don King and Bob Arum, that would result in the coronation next September of an undisputed world heavyweight boxing champion, either Larry Holmes or John Tate, provided each continued to punch out opponents while the treaty is being hammered out. Treaty might even be too optimistic a word. Considering the conflict involved, truce might be more accurate.

title: Italian Utility Loan

The amount was increased from $300 million because of heavy oversubscription, it said. The eightyear loan, which is guaranteed by the Italian Government, bears interest at threeeighths of 1 percent above the United States prime lending rate for the first four years and onehalf of 1 percent thereafter.

title: Water Shortage Hits River Town
description: NATCHEZ, Miss., Dec. 19 (AP)  Officials urged residents today to conserve water, but they were also counting on warmer temperatures to help overcome a critical water shortage in this old Mississippi River town.

title: Regan Asks End to Hidden Deficit

title: Associated Press

Baker Jr., the Senate minority leader, a Republican Presidential candidate, in Concord, N.H., where he suggested creating a 50,000member First Brigade trained in antiterrorist, antihijacking and antikidnapping techniques. As dangerous as the situation is in Iran, the real danger to this country is the growing impression throughout the world that you can push on Uncle Sam and nothing ever happens in return, he said. It's a long time since a Russian embassy was invaded or hostages were taken.

In at least one instance, a Congressman has suggested that the coverage has been less than patriotic.

title: Jazz: Red Norvo's Sound

The hard, ringing sound that most vibraharpists produce becomes, in Mr. Norvo's hands, a warm, singing sound that snakes its way through the performance by the quartet he is leading in the King Cole Room of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel.

title: Sun to Settle 1971 Dealers Suit
description: The Sun Company has tentatively agreed to pay $7.5 million in partial settlement of a 1971 lawsuit in which a group of gasoline station dealers accused Sun and 24 other oil companies of violating antitrust laws in their gasoline marketing practices, according to a proposed settlement filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Philadelphia unaer tne proposed settlement, the dealers, who leased their stations from Sun, would be allowed to buy gasoline from other oil companies. In the settlement, Sun also agreed that it would not refuse to sell gasoline to any dealer simply because the dealer was associated with another oil company.

title: Bridge:
