description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 19  The Iranian militants occupying the American Embassy here announced tonight the arrest of Iran's Ambassador to Scandinavia and produced what they said were embassy documents to accuse him of having collaborated with the United States.

title: Renault Buying Into Volvo Unit
description: GENEVA, Dec. 19  Renault, the stateowned French automobile manufacturer, has agreed to purchase a 10 percent interest in the passengercar business of Volvo, the Swedish engineering concern, for $40.7 million, the two companies announced today under an agreement covering cooperation in the technical and industrial fields, which the presidents of the two companies signed at a ceremony here, Renault may expand its interest in the Volvo Car Corporation, a subsidiary, to up to 20 percent.

title: Halston's Special Way With Tradition
description: WITH his exquisite sense of timing, Halston showed his spring madetoorder clothes just before Christmas so his customers could have a respite from gift collecting for others and concentrate on themselves for a moment.

title: Market Up in Reduced Trading
description: Precious metal stocks, the recent stars of Wall Street, finally gave ground yesterday as investors apparently chose to take some profits. The popular market averages showed token changes, although stocks recouped the hulk of their losses after a weak open ing.

title: Japan Banker Balks on Iran
description: TOKYO, Dec. 19 (AP)  Japanese banks cannot go along with United States banks in declaring loans to Iran in default, a leading Japanese banker said today.

title: Stage: Celeste Holm as Janet Flanner
description: JANET FLANNER, who dispatched her Paris letters to The New Yorker for more than half a century under the nom de plume Genet, possessed a style at once elegant and utterly colloquial. Whether she was reporting on Li'dbergh's famous transAtlantic flight, Josephine Baker's latest scandalous revue, French politics or a riot in the Place de la Concorde, Genet managed to sound as if she were gossiping with an intimate friend in her room at the Hotel Continental. Acerbic, wry, enthusiastic, she made her readers feel as if they had been taken into her confidence.

title: A State Agency Forbids Job Bias Against Addicts
description: Drug addicts who are being treated cannot be barred from employment because of their addiction if they are capable of working in a reasonable manner, the New York State Division of Human Rights ruled yesterday.

title: Finance Aide Resigns From Connally Camp; New Tactics Are Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)  John B. Connally's campaign finance director has resigned, partly because of differences over new moneyraising decisions that stem from the candidate's rejection of Federal matching funds, it was learned today.

title: VOTE FRAUD CHARGE AT U.N. IS REPORTED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 The United States and Colombia have reportedly raised the possibility of fraudulent balloting in the heated contest for a vacant seat on the United Nations Security Council.

title: Leo W. Farland, Seller of Posters By Young U.S. Artists Since '65
description: Leo W. Farland of New York and Water Mill, L.I., chairman of Poster Originals Ltd., publisher and distributor of art posters, died of cancer Monday night at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: EARNINGS A.T.&T. Net Rose 5.9% in 3d Quarter
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest business enterprise, reported yesterday that net income in the three months ended Nov. 30 rose 5.9 percent from the yearearlier period.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied General Nuclear Services, Barnwell, S.C., a joint partnership of the General Atomic Company and Allied Chemical Nuclear Products, wholly owned subsidiary of the Allied Chemical Corporation, has appointed Robert B. Holden president.

title: Upstate Youth, 17, Is Sentenced In Slaying of Telephone Lineman
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 19 (AP)  A teenager received a 15yeartolife sentence today for the slaying of a telephone lineman.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: THERE are numerous small fire extinguishers made specifically for use a home, boat or car. For the safetyminded, small fire extinguishers are particularly useful in the kitchen where grease fires can occur. And during the holidays, with a lighted tree inside, it is a good precaution to have extinguisher on hand. (Consumer's Union recommends having several  in kitchen, bedroom area, garage and basement.)

title: 4 Israelis Said to Assault Arabs In Reprisal for Stoning of a Bus
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 19  Four Israelis reacted violently yesterday to the stoning of a bus and injuring of two women in the Arab town of Khalkhul, near Hebron, the West Bank military governor's office said tonight. The Israelis were accused of assaulting customers in a store, breaking windows and smashing merchandise.

title: Jailed Soviet Poet's Book on Asylums Due in U.S.
description: Institute of Fools, an imprisoned Soviet poet's description of the use of mental institutions to rehabilitate dissidents, is being published in the United States in February.

title: O.E.C.D. Outlook Is Gloomy
description: PARIS, Dec. 19  Industrialized nations face doubledigit inflation in 1980, economic stagnation and substantially higher unemployment, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today.

title: Distillate Supply Off For Week
description: Stocks of distillate fuels dropped 6.7 million barrels last week to 231.9 million barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: Gilhooley Plans To Quit as Head Of Bus Concern
description: John J. Gilhooley disclosed yesterday that he planned to step down shortly as chairman, president and chief executive officer of Transport of New Jersey, the nation's largest privately owned commuter bus operation, which is on the verge of a takeover by the state.

title: CYRIL BLISS
description: Cyril Bliss, a cameraman for CBS News in London, died there Monday after a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: Glass Concern Cited In Patent Violation
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 19 (AP)  A Federal District Court judge has ruled that the Emhart Corporation violated another glass manufacturer's patent on device used in glassmaking machinery.

title: Philharmonic: Stoltzman Plays Mozart
description: MOZART'S Concerto for Clarinet (K. 622), composed in the last year of his life, is not so much a happy as a giddy work. It is full of comedy, but Mozart's laughter, unlike Haydn's or Beethoven's, is airy and inaudible, as if unfit for mortal ears. An inspired performance will not set off any chuckles, but it can evoke strains of divine merriment. Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, Richard Stoltzman produced such a performance, accompanied by the New York Philharmonic under James Levine.

title: U.S. to Review Methods For Evaluating Aircraft
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The Department of Transportation today initiated an independent examination of the Government's procedures for approving the safety features of new aircraft.

title: Stage: SammArt Williams's Home
description: PLAYING a character named Cephus Miles, Charles Brown sits in a splinteredback rocking chair, swats mosquitoes as big as turkeys and spins tales that seem to be as tall as his cornfield. He talks about shooting craps on top of tombstones with his good buddies, such as JoeBoy and HardHeaded Herbert, and he tells us how he learned to speak Injun from a monosyllabic black man who called himself Chief. Mostly, Cephus extols the land. He is a natural environmentalist, and he is wedded to farming as a way of life.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issue:

title: Wood Furnaces Are Hot Sellers
description: EVERYBODY and his grandmother are buying wood furnaces, said Carl Flink, director of Energy Testing Laboratory, an independent agency in Maine that tests woodburning equipment. The numbers bear him out: 10 years ago the wood furnace industry was dead, but last year Americans spent $1 billion on wood furnaces, stoves and accessories. Wood is now the main source of heat in 5 percent of American homes, according to industry estimates.

title: 7 Crewmen Are Rescued in Wreck Of Danish Ship in Northern Spain
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  Seven crewmen from a Danish coaster were rescued today from rocks on which the vessel was wrecked in an overnight storm, maritime sources said.

title: SENATE, BY 53 TO 44, BACKS CHRYSLER AID; INTERIM HELP LOSES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The Senate approved $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation tonight after defeating a proposal to provide emergency, interim financing for the company while the larger package is assembled.

title: Contacts by Phone Reported
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 Secretary General Waldheim declined today to comment on the disclosure that he had asked for a delay of United States moves against Iran until he had completed his talks with Iranian representa tives.

title: Donald N. Elberfeld Dead at 53; Lawyer and ExWorld Bank Aide
description: Donald N. Elberfeld, a lawyer who specialized in international transactions, died last Saturday at St. Joseph's Convalescent Hospital in Ojai, Calif., after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived in Ojai.

title: Kng Delivers Lecture
description: TUBINGEN, West Germany, Dec. 19 (AP)  The Rev. Hans Kling defied a Vatican order that he no longer be recognized as a teacher of Roman Catholic theology and delivered a lecture today at Tbingen University. He was cheered by an audience of several thousand.

title: Miss Nadig Wins 3d Downhill in Row
description: ZELL AM SEE, Austria, Dec. 19 (UP1)  MarieTheres Nadig, finishing half a second ahead of her nearest rival, won her third consecutive downhill race today and moved back to the top of the World Cup ski standing.

title: Amid Canapes, Vietnam Serves A China Roast
description: PEKING, Dec. 19  Responding to handdelivered invitations, journalists began arriving at the Embassy of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam shortly after 3 P.M. and were greeted with smiles and bows at the front door.

title: Film: Ashby-Kosinksi 'Being There':Watching TV
description: "BEING THERE" is a stately, beautifully acted satire with a premise that's funny but fragile. Chance, the hero of Jerzy Kosinski's novel and now his screenplay, is a slow-witted innocent who has spent all his adult life in seclusion, working as a gardener and watching television. These two pursuits, and only these two, have shaped his notion of the rest of the world. "Being There" explains, among other things, how illiteracy, ignorance and a sweet attitude can lead to riches, fame and a glamorous social career.Chance, who is played with brilliant understatement by Peter Sellers, is immediately mistaken for Chauncey Gardiner, an aristocratic businessman (because he wears his former benefactor's elegant hand-me-down suits) and witty raconteur (because he laughs at other people's jokes). He is admired for his fluent knowledge of Russian; this comes from nodding knowingly at a Soviet diplomat at a party. Chance also advises the President, and appears on something like "The Tonight Show." He has been commenting on how the changing of the seasons means that all is well in the garden, and everone mistakes this for a metaphor about economics.Hal Ashby directs "Being There" at an unruffled, elegant pace, the better to let Mr. Sellers's double-edged mannerisms make their full impression upon the audience. Mr. Sellers never strikes a false note, as he exhibits the kind of navet that the film's other characters mistake for eccentricity. Not knowing polite conventions, he answers even perfunctory questions ("Will you be seated?") with hilariously excessive enthusiasm ("Yes, I will!"). Not knowing figures of speech, he begins standing like a stork when a doctor advises him to keep his weight off one foot. Not knowing the answers to certain questions, he simply doesn't answer them. This impresses his new friends as reticence of the cagiest kind.The other fine actors in "Being There"Melvyn Douglas as a poignantly ailing rich man, Shirley MacLaine as his sexy, sprightly wife, Jack Warden as a suspicious President and Richard Dysart as the sick man's quietly watchful doctorconspire to accept Chance as a plausible figure, and thereby keep the story in motion. There is superb ensemble playing in "Being There," particularly in scenes that bring Mr. Sellers and Mr. Douglas together. The timing is often so perfect that the film, at its very wittiest, strips conversation down to its barest maneuvers and stratagems.The idea of Chance's miraculous success in the world is a slender one, though, and "Being There" eventually takes it farther than it will go. Chance's adventures begin to have a similar ring; the story doesn't so much progress as repeat itself after a while. And Mr. Ashby, who ruptures the film's exaggeratedly uppercrust mood with an early sequence of Chance in the ghetto, and with frequent doses of television noise, stays close to reality when the story most needs its air of the fantastic. The references to television begin delightfully, as when Mr. Ashby cuts from a jubilant mattress commercial to a man on his deathbed. But since the point of these snippets is made early on and then reiterated quite a lot, the film at times begins to drag.There's also something precious about Mr. Ashby's elaborate, solemn, approach to even the most airy and delicate aspects of Chance's story. But for the most part, "Being There," which opens today at the Coronet, moves handsomely, and ingeniously, to make a whimsical dream of a story come true."Being There" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains a few sexual references and one relatively discreet masturbation sequence.

title: Wood Heat: Cutting Free of the Fuel Crisis
description: MILLINOCKET, ME. JAMES A. FARLEY deftly cut large beechwood log into twofoot pieces with his chain saw while his son, Jeff, threw the pieces on top of a fivefoothigh pile of wood that stretched the length of their driveway.

title: Third Casino Gets Permit To Open in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 19  The Casino Control Commission today granted the Bally Manufacturing Corporation an operating certificate to open this seashore community's third casino on Dec. 27.

title: Talks in Cairo End Inconclusively
description: CAIRO, Dec. 19  Egyptian, Israeli and American delegations concluded the seventh, and briefest, round today in their Palestinian autonomy talks, with no sign of progress on major issues in the sixmonthold negotiations.

title: Fuel Oil Spilled in Boston Harbor
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  More than 250,000 gallons of No. 6 fuel oil spilled into Boston Harbor early today from the Japanese tanker Donau Maru, which was unloading its cargo at Castle Island, the Coast Guard reported.

title: 3dPeriod Output Revised Down a Bit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  The Government today revised slightly downward its estimate of the nation's total output for the third quarter, but the 3.1 percent annual rate of growth was still the strongest for any quarter this year.

title: U.S. Is Said to Waste Funds on Furniture
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  The Federal Government, which spent $1.2 billion this decade on new furniture, is storing usable furniture at 78 warehouses in the Washington area, the chairman of a Senate subcommittee said today.

title: A Variety of Inventive Ideas From One Young Designer
description: HOW does a designer get an idea? It sort of forms, and pops in my head, said Kevin Walz, a 29yearold New York designer whose recent projects offer some ingenious and inspirational innovations.

title: CLAIRE CARLETON
description: Claire Carleton, an actress on Broadway and in films, died of cancer at her home in North Ridge, Calif., on Dec. 11. She was 66 years old.

title: Kennedy Plane Too Expensive, Editors Assert
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The high cost of accompanying Senator Edward M. Kennedy on his campaign plane is forcing some news organizations to cut back or modify their coverage of him, and some have asked the Senator to provide a detailed breakdown and explanation of the cost of traveling on his craft.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOLARS DENOUNCE CENSURE
description: Sixty leading American and Canadian Roman Catholic theologians endorsed a statement yesterday that protests the censure by the Vatican of the Rev. Hans Kling, a leading liberal theologian, and its order that he no longer be recognized as a teacher of Catholic doctrine.

title: Snow and Winds Leave Roads Slick and Perilous
description: The New York Times, Neal Boenzi

title: Choosing The Logs To Burn
description: THERE'S an old adage that firewood warms you twice  once with the heat generated in getting it and again when it is burned. Felling trees and cutting and splitting logs are hard and sometimes dangerous work, and you should read about how to do it before charging out with ax and power saw.

title: Germany in the 70's: A Sex Peddler's Saga
description: BAD PYRMONT, West Germany Taking the waters up here in this wellordered little retreat, where enforced gentility hangs everywhere like a lace curtain, are a retired admiral, the 80yearold widow of a major Nazi general and the former personal secretary of Konrad Adenauer. And, here along with them, is, an excon named Kurt Kohls.

title: ExC.I.A. Officer Charges Agency Withheld Data on Korean Bribery
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  A former Central Intelligence Agency officer who was stationed in South Korea has charged in court documents that the agency intentionally concealed from the Justice Department its knowledge of South Korean efforts to bribe members of Congress.

title: Beaths
description: ARNOLD  Newton S. Suddenly on Dec. 16, 1979. Beloved husband of Irene; dear brother of Allene Daub. Genevieve Wetmore, Tex Arnold. Servicts Sunday, Dec 23, 9:30AM at Gutterman's, 331 Amsterdam Ave at 76th St. Friends may visit at Gutterman's Sat. from 79PM.

title: AT HOME ABROAD Lessons Of Rhodesia
description: LONDON  At an early stage of the London Conference on Rhodesia, Ian Smith, the white rebel leader, said to one of the British negotiators: You offered us better terms on Tiger and Fearless. That sullen comment threw unintended light on what Smith cost his people over his years in office.

title: Mayor Byrne Looks to Courts in Strike And Offers a New School Finance Plan
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 19  Mayor Jane M. Byrne today continued her efforts to resolve two major crises besetting the city - an insolvent school system and the first transit strike since 1922  by floating yet another bailout proposal for the schools and asserting that the strike must now be resolved in the courts.

title: Morrison Hired As Lobo Coach
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 19 (AP)  Joe Morrison, former New York Giants football star and the Southern Conference's 1979 coach of the year, was hired today as coach at the University of New Mexico. He signed fiveyear contract at $45,000 a year.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)  A Federal judge refused today to block a Government plan requiring nine major refiners to share their crude oil supplies with the Ashland Oil Company, which was badly hurt by the Iranian oil cutoff that followed the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: OPEC Talks Go to Fourth Day Without Price Accord
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 19  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries failed to reach an agreement on oil prices today after a third intense day of negotiations. It was the first time one of the group's pricing meetings had ever gone into a fourth day, and there were dear signs that a meaningful accord was out of reach for now.

title: Topics Manners and Murals
description: Two plaques were recently installed at a Chemical Bank to mark the old site of the Metropolitan Opera House on Broadway between 39th and 40th Streets. The plaques lacked space, perhaps, to say that the Met rose out of one of the most fiery battles of 19thcentury New York  the victory of New Money over Old. The Met went up because New Money couldn't get boxes at the Academy of Music on 14th Street. The Academy had only 18 boxes, all occupied by Old Money .Astors, Belmonts, Lorillards, Beekmans, Schuylers. The Academy offered to install a few more, but New Money  Vanderhilts, Rockefellers, Whitneys, Goulds  decided to build its own.

title: ESSAY A Call For Disunity
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  A sixweek period of appeasement has given Iranian terrorists no incentive to return the hostages. Six weeks of handwringing, the rulingout of force, the dispatching of Ramsey Clark, and the harassing of Iranian students here has given the populace of Iran no reason to pressure the Khomeini regime and its terrorist representatives to return to civilization.

title: JULIE STEINBERG
description: Julie Steinberg, who taught Romance languages for 20 years in New York City high schools, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 69 years old.

title: Calendar: Quilt Show, Tree Sale
description: A seasonal exhibition of quilts from the museum's permanent collection is on view through March 30 in two rooms in the firstfloor gallery.

title: Home Improvement
description: THERE is a new device to eliminate the problem of pipes banging or hammering when the water is turned on or off. This often happens with washing machines whose electrically operated valves shut the water off quickly at the end of a filling cycle.

title: Beaths
description: GREENWALD  Alexander J. The officers and Employees of TeAmo Geryl Inc. express their sorrow at the passing of their employer and friend and extend deepest sympathies to the family.

title: Economists See Mild Recession
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP)  The United States economy will continue in a moderate recession in 1980 because of a restrictive monetary policy and rapid increases in world oil prices, University of Pennsylvania economists predicted today.

title: Film Critics Cite Kramer, Dustin Hoffman and Sally Field
description: Kramer vs. Kramer, Robert Benton's film about a couple battling for custody of their son, was voted best picture of 1979 by the New York Film Critics Circle yesterday. Dustin Hoffman, who stars in that film, was cited as best actor and Sally Field was voted best actress for Norma Rae.

title: In a Teheran Teahouse, the Talk Is of Jobs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 19  When Kalamollah Mohammedi sauntered into the Aineh teahouse on Khosrow Street late this afternoon, he spotted Ali Almasi, his friend, on a wooden bench puffing a hookah under a faded picture of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on a wall of flaking paint and exposed brickwork.

title: Opera: Rigoletto at Met
description: BECAUSE the Metropolitan Opera's production of Rigoletto  new in 1977  is hardly old enough to be scrapped, its peculiarities are likely to be with us for a long time. As the season's first performance of the Verdi opera revealed Tuesday night, however, they do not become more lovable with age.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press printed in The Times yesterday, on the upholding of a Florida murder verdict against Ronny Zamora, incorrectly identified the victim of the killing. She was Elinor Haggn rt, 83 years old.

title: Free Enterprise, Chrysler Style
description: When business is bad, don't despair; pack your lobbyists off to Washington. That, in effect, is what the Senate said yesterday to corporate America and its unions. Both the House and the Senate have now approved a loan guarantee for Chrysler that might as well be upholstered in rich Corinthian leather. It will risk more than a billion dollars in public money, yet ex tract only token concessions from Chrysler's highly paid workers. Congress is setting a precedent that the country is likely to regret.

title: HOUSE SEEKS OPTION IN AUTO SAFETY LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  The House voted today to require automobile makers to offer car buyers a choice between airbags and seat belts, beginning with 1982model vehicles.

title: Weiss Continuing Fight To Halt Funds for SST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  When he first arrived in Congress three years ago, Representative Theodore S. Weiss said, he had a list of concerns that he knew he would have to deal with.

title: State High Court Dismisses Suit By Moon Church Against Times
description: The New York State Court of Appeals dismissed yesterday a libel suit brought by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church against The New York Times for publishing articles alleging ties between the church and the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.

title: The Secrets of a Roving Guest
description: ALMOST two years ago I sat on a neighbor's front steps watching as a truck carrying almost all my possessions headed uptown to a storage warehouse. Assuming that I would be homeless for about six months while looking for a suitable place to live permanently, I had retained only what I thought vital to life: a few clothes, a few books, a typewriter, a portable television set and a set of hot rollers.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1979

title: ExP.O.W. Testifies Marine Wore Enemy Uniform
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., Dec. 19 (UPI)  A former prisoner of war said today that hp once encountered Pfc. Robert R. Garwood in the mountains of South Vietnam wearing the uniform of a Communist soldier and boasting of going into combat against American forces.

title: Settlement Set Between Kush, Arizona State
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 19 (AP)  Arizona State University announced a settlement tonight with Frank Kush, who had named the school in a $40million damage suit over his dismissal on Oct. 13 as head football coach.

title: Danish Farmers Riding Tractors Snarl City Traffic in Tax Protest
description: COPENHAGEN, Dec. 19 (AP)  Some 5,000 farmers on tractors snarled traffic today in a protest here and in 11 other cities against a Government plan to impose a windfall tax on their gains from devaluation of the Danish crown.

title: Food Handling Blamed in Deaths Of 5 Patients at Marlboro Hospital
description: TRENTON, Dec. 19  Two reports released today on the deaths of five patients at the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital several weeks ago blamed improper foodhandling practices and raised questions about the quality of medical care the patients had received.

title: Dutch Cabinet Is Backed on Missiles
description: THE HAGUE, Thursday, Dec 20 (Reuters)  The Dutch Parliament today defeated an opposition resolution that would have forced the Government to resign over a decision by the Atlantic alliance to modernize its Europeanbased nuclear missiles.

title: Uganda War Broke Tanzania's Treasury but Not Its Spirit
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Dec. 14  War with Uganda broke this country. sucked away its foreign exchange reserves and set it behind 8 to 10 months in payments to foreign creditors. Shortages are everywhere. Butter, cooking oil, flour, gasoline, rice and sugar come at a premium, when they come at all.

title: Simulated Space Shuttle Flight Fails Anew and Is Reset for Today
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 19 (UPI)  Attempts to complete a computersimulated launching and orbital flight of the troubleplagued space shuttle Columbia failed today for the third time and officials rescheduled the test for tomorrow.

title: Rangers Subdue Canucks
description: The note that once hung in Don Murdoch's locker read: Dear Mr. Murdoch, I would like to introduce myself. My name is Don Maloney and I play left wing. Thanks for listening.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday s Weather at 1 P M National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, UPI

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Talking Business
description: Like thousands of other retailers, Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largestvolume department store chain, is taking both a shortrange and longrange view of business these days.

title: Beaths
description: PRYOR  Marianna Brand. Of Essex Fells, New Jersey. Wife of William Young Pryor. Mother of Ann Love Pryor and William Brand Pryor. Service at the Dancy Funeral Home, 9 Smull Avenue, Caldwell, N.J. on Saturday at 10AM. Friends may call Friday 24 and 79PM.

title: U.S. Seeking Clearer and More Precise Food Labels
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The Food and Drug Administration and the Agriculture Department, hoping to achieve the first major overhaul of Federal food labeling laws in 40 years, today proposed that food processors be required to give complete listings of their products ingredients and more fully disclose the amounts of the ingredients.

title: State Boxing Ban Ends Next Month
description: The State Athletic Commission announced yesterday that professional boxing in New York would be allowed to resume next month, by which time, the commission said, safety reforms prompted by the death of the middleweight Willie Classen should be in effect.

title: Stone Worker Unions to Merge
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)  The Granite Cutters Union has voted to merge next month with the Marble Polishers Union, it was announced today by Joseph Ricciarelli, president of the granite union. Robert Georgine, president of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of 1. abor and Congress of industrial Organizations, said that the merger can immeasurably strengthen heir individual positions and that of the a trade union movement, especially in the area of collective bargaining.

title: F.C.C. Backs Off on Children'sTV Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The Federal Communications Commission backed away today from a proposal to require networks to televise at least seven and a half hours of children's programs weekly. Instead, the commission proposed a range of options to enhance programs for young viewers.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: MAMAJI is two books that happen to occupy the same space. One of these books is a painstaking. ironic and almost inflectionless account of the life and hard times of group of middleclass Hindus in the India of the Raj during the 19th and 20th centuries. As if he had dropped from Mars in a flying saucer on Lahore

title: What's Dragging the Dollar Down
description: Gold and silver are once again hitting historic highs while the dollar falls. Unexpected events may intervene, but the futures markets suggest that 1980 will bring more of the same. Investors will keep selling dollars and buying precious metals.

title: Sun to Sell Its Becton Interest
description: The Sun Company, which lost a landmark court case last July over its secret purchase of a nearly $300 million stock interest in Becton, Dickinson & Company, the big New Jersey hospital supplier, agreed yesterday to divest itself of its controversial 32 percent stake in Becton. The move would settle all litigation against the company.

title: Nets, Paced By Boynes, Beat Sonics
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 19 (AP)  Winford Boynes scored a seasonhigh 32 points tonight to spark the New Jersey Nets to a 122119 National Basketball Association victory over the SuperSonics, snapping Seattle's fourgame winning streak.

title: Notes on People
description: Muhammad AU, who has already added acting to his postretirement arsenal, may have yet another sidelineboxing coach in China.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  The police defused two more letter bombs today, bringing to five the number of explosive devices mailed in a campaign against leading Britons this week.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CURTAIN UP The neon scene hats a real Christmas gift  a festive package called On Stage (265.3800). This brandnew oasis for food, drink and entertainment is in the heart of the theater district, on Restaurant Row at 349 West 46th Street.

title: 8Inch Snow Cover Buoys Pocono Skiers
description: A heavy snowstorm yesterday had deposited as much as eight inches of powder by midafternoon on the Poconos and proved a bonanza in that part of Pennsylvania for skiarea operators preparing for the Christmas weekend.

title: Entertainment Events
description: COMI N UP, by Philip Rose and Peter Udell. directed bv Mr. Rose; starring Gregor, Hines. the Winter Garden Theater.1634 Broadway, 6:30.

title: Richard C. Pistell, Businessman And Former Banker, Dead at 51
description: Richard C. Pistell, a former invest ment banker who became chairman of several big companies, died Monday of a heart attack at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan and Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Sports Today
description: Centenary at Long Island University, 8 P.M: Medgar Evers at Brooklyn College, 8 P.M. Knicks vs. Clippers, at San Diego (Radio WNEW, 10:30 P.M.)

title: 2d Senate Panel Now Likely to Give Arms Pact Views
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  After a heated debate behind the scenes, the Senate Armed Services Committee reportedly agreed today on a formula for making public a report condemning the pending nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Changes at WNYC Prompt Debate Over Extent of City's Control
description: It goes back more than a half century, and for most of that time, the city's Municipal Broadcasting System has just sort of been there  playing classical music for the genteel, covering city hearings for the civicminded and generally finding itself routinely, if not always benevolently, ignored. No more.

title: Poinsettias Are For Keeping
description: LIKE any other flowering species, the poinsettia needs food, light, water and good soil. The plants should be kept moist at all times but the soil should not be soggy, so never leave water in the saucer. They respond best in a cool room, away from heat or sunny windows.

title: Are the Swedes Being Battered by Prejudice in N.H.L.?
description: The score was tied, 11, in the second period at Madison Square Garden the other night when the puck came free at center ice. Only three players were near it. Two were Philadelphia Flyers and the other was the Rangers Ulf Nilsson. The Swedish center got to the puck first. With a flick of his wrist, he slid it behind Moose Dupont. With switch of his hips and three quick strides, he was around Bob Dailey and in alone on the goal. Almost.

title: News Summary
description: Chicago's crises over school financing and a threeday transit strike led Mayor Jane M. Byrne to seek state aid for the insolvent school system and to assert that the costly walkout must be settled in court. Terming the strike illegal, the Mayor rejected an offer by the transit unions to accept a compromise that was worked out in her office more than a week ago. [A22:13.]

title: Saudis Term Asset Drop Slight
description: LONDON, Dec. 19  Sheik Abdulaziz alQuraishi, the governor of the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency, which functions as the Saudi central bank, said today that Saudi Arabia had sustained slight declines in its foreignheld assets as a result of the kingdom's deficit budget in the last two years and as a resuit of some transfer of private capital outside the country.

title: Britain Schedules Signing of Peace Pact for Tomorrow
description: LONDON, Dec. 19  The British Government today scheduled the signing of the Rhodesian peace agreement for noon on Friday, having received what it regards as a definite assurance that Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa will be here.

title: Korchnoi Wife Says Son Gets Jail Term in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (Reuters) The son of Viktor Korchnoi, the Soviet chess grandmaster, was sentenced to two and a half years in a labor camp by a Leningrad court today for evading the military draft, his mother said.

title: Turkey Prolongs Martial Law
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  The Turkish Parliament prolonged martial law today in 19 key provinces for two more months as part of continuing efforts to halt political violence that has taken about 1,800 lives this year.

title: Scotto Fighting Port Body Order That He Testify
description: A lawyer for Anthony M. Scotto, the convicted labor leader, went to State Supreme Court yesterday to try to quash subpoena requiring him to appear before a hearing of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Argentine Junta Gives Program for Restoring Elected Governments
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19  Argentina's military junta today announced a set of political principles and procedures that it said would return the nation to democratic rule at some unspecified time but that would reserve a special role for the armed forces in an elected civilian Government.

title: Ms. Magazine Selects Its Women to Watch
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  Ms. magazine has selected a list of Women to Watch in the 80's, and few of them are known nationally.

title: Advertising
description: LONG before the crisis in Iran led some people to boycott Iranian pistachios, the folks at Bozell & Jacobs/ West, Los Angeles, were creating a droll comparative TV commercial supporting its client's Californiagrown nuts. They were doing it for Tenneco West, which was going national with its Sun Giant brand of dried fruits and nuts.

title: Design Notebook
description: THERE was a time when the image of Fifth Avenue  not to mention much of midtown Manhattan  was established by stone. Solid, formal blocks of limestone gave Fifth Avenue a dignity that made it much more than a commercial street; it managed to be a grand, formal boulevard, as appropriate for promenading as for shopping.

title: Legal Services Strike Now in Its 6th Week; Big Issues Unresolved
description: The impasse in a strike by lawyers, paralegal employees and clerical workers against Community Action for Legal Services Inc. entered its sixth week in New York City yesterday, with issues relating to salaries and the control of agency operations still unresolved.

title: Shearson Changing Name
description: Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. announced yesterday that shareholders at the annual meeting here had approved a change in the corporate name to Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc. In May, Shearson Hayden Stone agreed to acquire substantially all of the business and properties of Loeb Rhoades, Hornblower & Company, a privately held securities concern with 150 domestic and 11 foreign branches.

title: Candidates Opening Drives in New England
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19  Nearly one month ago, a caravan of five cars loaded with parkas, files and newspaper clippings traveled from Los Angeles to Boston to set up quietly at 89 State Street the national campaign headquarters for Gov.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Near $500 in Europe As Dollar Closes Mixed
description: The price of gold came within a few dollars of the $500anounce mark in European trading yesterday but backed off on profit taking before reaching that level.

title: COMMODITIES Gold Loses Early Gains Amid a Rash of Rumors
description: Gold futures prices rose to record highs again yesterday, only to fall dramatically amid a rash of rumors.

title: Market Place
description: CAN it be that the Federal tax on privileged items bites so hard that the ultimate effect for some outoffavor stocks to become irrationally underpriced?

title: Soviet Trade in Review, Nominee Tells Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Philip M. Klutznick, the Chicago real estate developer nominated last month as the new Commerce Secretary, reported today that the department was taking a new look at export licensing procedures in the wake of bureaucratic infighting over shipments to the Soviet Union.

title: As Santa in Paraguay
description: Once in n life, I played Santa Claus. I am female. very slim, and sing soprano.

title: Walden Moore, 78, Dies; Founded Atlantic Union
description: Walden Moore, a founder and former executive director of the Atlantic Union Committee, now part of the Atlantic Council of the United States in Washington, died last Friday in St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Morningside Heights.

title: Enid Haupt's Poinsettias
description: THE season is Christmas and that, of course, means poinsettias. At least as far as Enid Haupt is concerned. And when this wellknown flower fancier matches plants to season, you can be sure she won't settle for just one or two blooms.

title: Rebuilding American Intelligence
description: WASHINGTONThe Iranian crisis illuminates tragically the low state to which the United States centralintelligence system has been reduced. In the last five years, savage newsmedia and Congressional criticism as well as CarterMondale punitive restrictions on the Central Intelligence Agency have disastrously weakened our capability for conducting clandestine intelligence operations abroad.

title: AID FOUND LACKING FOR DISEASES OF JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Inadequate workmen's compensation programs financed by employers are causing workers disabled by jobrelated diseases to turn for help to Social Security and welfare instead, according to a report drafted by the Labor Department.

title: Senate Panel Backs Amendment to Balance Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  A proposed constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget was approved today by a 5to2 vote of Senate Judiciary subcommittee. It was the first time that the idea had been embraced by any Congressional panel.

title: The New York Times
description: David Rockefeller announced yesterday that he would step down as the chief executive officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank and its corporate parent, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, on Jan 1.

title: Radio
description: 9:45 A.M.Noon, WBAI: A Consort of Early Music. Ted Cohen. host. Christmas Story. Schutz; Rosary Sonatas. Biber; LatinAmerican and early American Christmas music.

title: Apartment Rents Are Not Yet Right
description: New York City's Rent Guidelines Board has offended practically everybody by adding, a $12 fuel charge to the monthly rent of more than 300,000 stabilized apartments. Tenants complain that their leases were unilaterally changed in midterm. Landlords are angry because the increase was not larger, and will not apply to another 550,000 apartments subject to the Stablization Law. In settling on $12, the board, under a new chairman, Marvin Markus, combined courage with discretion. But it still needs to find a way to protect all stabilized apartments from the deterioration that follows the diversion of maintenance money fuel bills.

title: Passaic Rent Law Ignored on Advice of City Attorney
description: PASSAIC, N.J., Dec. 19  Some landlords in Passaic are ignoring a rentcontrol law on the advice of the City Attorney, who helped draw up the ordinance.

title: Suspect Held in Brooklyn Killing
description: Ramon Gutierrez, 25 years old, of 700 West 176th Street, has been charged with the fatal shooting of Naziro Palen, 25, of 622 46th Street, Brooklyn, and the wounding of another person in a bar at 3906 Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn Tuesday night, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Mr. Gutierrez was arrested after his car was stopped for a minor traffic violation.

title: REGULATORY REFORM PASSES SENATE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  In the first sign of progress on overhauling the morass of Federal regulations, a compromise bill supported by the Carter Administration was approved today by a Senate subcommittee.

title: Rare Chance for New Yorkers
description: New York City investors rarely get a chance to buy topquality bonds yielding 7 percent that are exempt from all three income taxes they have to pay.

title: The Region
description: JERSEY CITY (AP)  Service between Harrison, N.J., and Journal Square in Jersey City on the Port Authority Trans Hudson lines was halted late yesterday when mechanical problems at the Hackensack River Bridge caused the structure to remain open, PATH officials said.

title: DualFurnace Flue Rules
description: Since installing a new flue for woodburning furnace is such an expense (up to $1,000), it's a controversial subject and building regulations vary greatly. The National Fire Protection Association's voluntary standards specify that each furnace must have a separate flue. The association is concerned that if only one flue is used, a back draft might blow combustible gases into whichever furnace is off and cause an explosion. Another concern is that wood smoke deposits flammable creosote on the flue walls, If the flue isn't regularly inspected and cleaned, a chimney fire could occur.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1979

title: Sound
description: LIKE most Iastminute Christmas shoppers, I'm rushing to beat Santa to the chimney, gathering small items for audiominded friends. One splendid item literally small enough for a stockingstuffer is actually a complete sound system. Just introduced by Sony, it is a stereocassette player hardly bigger and not much heavier than a pack of cigarettes and it plays through a special set of earphones hardly larger than those of a hearing aid. Called the Sound about, it measures 3x5x1 inches and weighs less than 14 ounces including batteries, vet the sound rivals a quite respectable stereo system in clarity and fullness  an unusual feat for anything so small and light. You can just stick the player in your pocket and, if you put on a hat, hardly anyone will notice that you're wearing the earphones.

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 (UPI)  A ship loaded with 57,000 barrels of crude oil collided with a line of barges on the Mississippi River tonight, sending flames 300 feet into the air, the state police said.

title: PANAMA SUPPRESSING PROTESTS OVER SHAH
description: PANAMA, Dec. 19  Panama's armybacked Government moved today to suppress growing protests against its decision to grant the Shah of Iran exile on the Pacific resort island of Contadora.

title: Cosmos Sign 2 New Players
description: The New York Cosmos yesterday signed two wellknown South American players who could be with the North American Soccer League team the next 10 years.

title: Hormuz Strait Called Key to Any U.S. Action on Iran
description: The military and political turbulence in the Persian Gulf region will eventually focus on control of the Strait of Hormuz, which connects the oil ports of the gulf with the Indian Ocean and the shipping routes to Europe, North America and Japan.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert M. Gardiner, 57 years old, has been elected president of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., in a move that was viewed on Wall Street as solidifying Mr. Gardiner's position as the No. officer of the company, one of the nation's largest securities firms.

title: 12 Iranians at Jackson State U. Reported Suspended in Protests
description: JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 19 (AP)  At least 12 Iranian students at Jackson State University have been suspended for participating in campus demonstrations last month and 20 others have been placed on probation, according to a spokesman for the students.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Dec. 19, 1979

title: The City
description: An offduty transit patrolman surprised two youths who had broken into his home yesterday in Brooklyn and shot and killed one and wounded the other, authorities reported.

title: School Project in Bronx Undergoes State Audit
description: The $76 million Northeast Bronx Educational Park is being audited by Edward V. Regan, the State Comptroller, the Board of Education announced yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The door leading to my bedroom  is covered with wood paneling on the outside. It appears to be hanging level with relation to the door frame and the floor, but when it is left in the open position it slowly swings closed. How can this be corrected without using a door stop or a hook of some hind?  S. P. H., New York City.

title: 3 Energy Bills Lag in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Prospects that Congress will send President Carter any of his energy program in final form before Christmas dwindled today as lawmakers failed to make significant progress on three major bills. With a holiday recess coming up at the end of the week, leaders in both houses concluded that the legislation for a tax on windfall oil company profits that finally cleared the Senate Monday night would not be sent to the White House in final form until January or even later. The House of Representatives passed its version last summer and the bill is now in a conference committee to resolve differences.

title: Chase's Voice of Free Enterprise
description: When Willard Carlisle Butcher speaks, he sounds more like a fireandbrimstone preacher than a banker. His two favorite, and not unrelated, topics are the freeenterprise system and the Chase Manhattan Bank. Colleagues attribute his intense commitment to capitalism to his success in climbing the executive ladder at the Chase Among the nation's banks, Chase is the third largest, after the Bank of America and Citibank.

title: Even China's Termites Play Part In the Rural Development Drive
description: PEKING, Dec. 19  While tens of thousands of educated Chinese youths continue to attempt to beg or bribe their way back to the cities from job assignments in the countryside, the press continues to extol the virtues and opportunities involved in pastoral employment.

title: Safety Inspection Cuts Urged in Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Senator Richard S. Schweiker, with bipartisan support from members of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, introduced legislation today that would exempt most work places from safety inspections by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

title: Financial Troubles Force Cincinnati Stingers to Fold
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 19 (UPI)  Cincinnati is without a hockey team for the second time in a year.

title: Hers
description: Gail Sheehy

title: In the City
description: There are no prohibitions against having a wood stove installed in New York City, provided it satisfies the building code and does not cause an air pollution problem.

title: About Westchester
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Dec. 18  It would be easy to donate pity in the course of giftgiving at Blythedale Children's Hospital. Here, in the midst of Westchester County greetingcard country, youngsters up to the age of 18 are walking, even hobbling; speaking, or barely speaking, words that are in the mind and cannot get out of the mouth; moving on wheelchairs or stretchers. But the staff, the children and the colorful premises do not encourage or even welcome pity.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury sold twoyear notes yesterday at an average yield of 11.43 percent, down from 12.29 percent in November and even further below the 12.66 percent peak rate set in October.

title: Hilda Sonnenberg Dies; Widow of the Publicist
description: Hilda Caplan Sonnenberg, the widow of Benjamin Sonnenberg, the public relations man, died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived on East 79th Street.

title: Home Beat
description: SHE has been a weaver for seven years, and also a film editor. I finally decided this year to make a body of work and get it out, said 34yearold Janet Swanson, shown at right. So she created a gallery in the front part of the loft she shares with her husband, Todd Smith, a graphic designer, and their 8monthold son, Evan. On the walls, she hung her oneofakind, brilliantly colored wool rugs. They're all made of Paternayan yarn, the kind often used for needlepoint, Miss Swanson said. Instead of a hand tapestry technique I use the mechanics of the loom. There's an infinite variety possible, depending on the colors and the width of the stripes. Her weftfaced rugs are either solid or striped. They are durable, meant to be walked on and can be drycleaned. She designs the patterns, draws the designs on graph paper to scale and picks out the colors, but hires other weavers to make them. She also works with designers and clients on special commissions. None of the rugs are more than four feet wide because that's basically the limitation of my loom, she said. The rugs cost $40 a square foot; 4- by 6foot rug is about $1,000. Miss Swanson's studio / gallery is at 3079 Canal Street, 4313696.

title: Griffith Stars as Louisville Stuns Ohio State
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 19 (UPI) Darrell Griffith powered a secondhalf rally in which Louisville scored 14 straight points and the Cardinals went on to upset previouslyunbeaten Ohio State, 7565, in college basketball tonight.

title: Spacecraft Links With Salyut
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (UPI)  The Soyuz T space freight ship, launched Sunday, today linked up with the Salyut 6 orbiting space station, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. Both vehicles are functioning normally, Tass said. Salyut 6 has been orbiting the earth since Sept. 29, 1977.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Your Dec. 9 editorial Making Part of the Nuclear Case raised two questions which it said needed answering. I believe we have come a considerable distance in answering these questions.

title: Acrobats of Taiwan Open Holiday Run at Minskoff
description: THE Chinese Acrobats of Taiwan, who opened Tuesday night at the Minskoff Theater for a holiday run, have been regular visitors to New York for several years. The latest version of the show is livelier, more polished and spruced up with the addition of two acts by a magician.

title: Banking Bill Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)Congress gave final approval today to a bill that allows banks and other saving institutions to continue issuing interest on checking accounts and providing savingstochecking fund transfers until March 31.

title: KOREA SENTENCES 7 TO DIE FOR MURDER OF PRESIDENT PARK
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Dec. 20  A military court today sentenced seven men, including Kim Jae Kyu, the former head of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, to death in connection with the assassination of President Park Chung Hee and five of his bodyguards on Oct. 26.

title: Associated Press
description: HANDANDFOOT BATTLE: Lakers Mike Cooper fighting for rebound under Los Angeles basket with Hawks Tom McMillen, left, and Steve Hawes in the first period. Atlanta won, 119112.

title: For Lawyers Club, an Era Is Vanishing With Its Home
description: Since 1912, the Lawyers Club of New York has provided a hushed, leisurely lunchtime ambiance for its members and their guests atop the Realty Building in the Wall Street area, in a room that looks like nothing so much as a medieval refectory.

title: End of an Age Seen in India's Politics as the Race Quickens
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 19  Political scientists here insist that India's intensifying national election campaign signals a historic transformation of this country's political institutions and points to a revitalized democracy.

title: More Gasoline Price Increases
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, Conoco Inc. and the Atlantic Richfield Company raised their gasoline prices yesterday as price increases announced in recent days by other oil companies begin showing up at the nation's gas pumps.

title: House Votes Bill Imposing Curb on Ivory Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)  The House today passed a bill restricting ivory imports in an effort to help save the world's 1.3 million elephants from extinction.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Industrialized nations face doubledigit inflation in 1980, economic stagnation and markedly higher unemployment, according to a forecast issued in Paris by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. [D1.]

title: U.S. Soccer Makes Its Arrival
description: Kurt Lamm, the secretary general of the United States Soccer Federation, laughed heartily the other day when he was told that an English soccer magazine had reported that the arrival of American soccer was at least 500 years away.

title: Slumping Canadiens Suffer Sixth Straight Loss, 52
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 19 (AP)  Thirdperiod goals by Mike Polich, Greg Smith and Steve Payne lifted the Minnesota North Stars to a 52 victory over Montreal tonight, handing the Canadiens their sixth straight defeat.

title: 7 More Oil Concerns Get Price Violation Notices
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The United States Department of Energy said today that seven oil companies had been involved in more than $1 billion worth of probable violations of Federal price rules and regulations, bringing to more than $10 billion the amount of allegedly illegal overcharges by the oil industry.

title: Galanes, Miss Paxson Win CrossCountry Ski Races
description: CABLE, Wis., Dec. 19 Jim Galanes of Brattleboro, Vt., captured his second straight North American crosscountry skiing championship today at Mount Telemark. He won the 30kilometer race after capturing the 15kilometer competition on Monday.

title: ANN DVORAK DIES; SCREEN ACTRESS, 67
description: Ann Dvorak, whose dark beauty and dramatic intensity made her one of Hollywood's busiest performers in the 30's and 40's, died in a Honolulu hospital on Dec. 10. She was 67 years old.

title: The Screen: Roy Scheider Stars in 'All That Jazz':Peter Pan Syndrome
description: JOE GIDEON, the Bob Fosse surrogate figure in "All That Jazz," is riding for a spectacular fall. He is directing and choreographing a new Broadway musical, editing a multimillion dollar film that's months behind schedule and sleeping with as many women as he can sneak into his schedule. Also demanding his time are his beautiful, patient young mistress, his talented, mostly sympathetic former wife and his 12-year-old daughter, who adores him. He smokes too much and drinks heavily. The day begins with Dexedrine, AlkaSeltzer, eyedrops and a hideous confrontation with the face in the mirror.Because Joe Gideon's career closely resembles that of Mr. Fosse, who not only directed and choreographed "All That Jazz," but also wrote the screenplay with the late Robert Alan Aurthur, there will be a tendency to see the film as Mr. Fosse's answer to "8 ," in which Federico Fellini wittily examined his own life at a point when he feared his creativity was at an end. "All That Jazz" even looks like a Fellini film  especially "Juliet of the Spirits"  having been photographed by Giuseppe Rotunno, Fellini's favorite cameraman. But looks and autobiographical details are, I think, deceiving."All That Jazz" is much less an "8 " than it is the most forthrightly candid variation ever worked out on Peter Pan and all other middle-aged boys who have refused to grow up. The film, which opens today at the Cinema I, is an uproarious display of brilliance, nerve, dance, maudlin confessions, inside jokes and, especially, ego. It's a little bit as if Mr. Fosse had invited us to attend his funeral  the wildest show-business sendoff a fellow ever designed for himself  and then appeared at the door to sell tickets and count the house; after all, funerals are only wasted on the dead."All That Jazz" is an essentially funny movie that seeks to operate on too many levels at the same time, but Mr. Fosse, like Barnum & Bailey, believes in giving the customers their money's worth. Some of it makes you wince, but a lot of it is great fun. There are big, beautiful, steamy, typically Fosse production numbers, small, intimate dance routines, shots of openheart surgery that may send you under your seat, soul-searching, gags, fantasies, flashbacks and, finally, emerging from the machine-made fog, the figure of a man who isn't always likable but who deserves the attention he affords himself. Not even Fellini, Ingmar Bergman or Woody Allen  all of whom are similarly guilt-ridden  has ever celebrated himself quite so cruelly.However, it's the excesses that make "All That Jazz" as appealing as it is, in much the way that Joe Gideon's incredible self-absorption fascinates the people around him. They see it as what they have to put up with to associate with the charm and talent that go with it.We take the flamboyance of "All That Jazz" not as an artist's indiscretion but as the fundamental nature of the enterprise. After carefully attending to the screen versions of other people's dreams ("Cabaret" and "Lenny"), Mr. Fosse is here attending to his own.A key to the success of the production is the performance of Roy Scheider as Joe Gideon. There's an initial shock in seeing Mr. Scheider as the obsessed genius of Broadway. We associate him with the physically tough, none-too-imaginative characters he's played in "The French Connection," "Jaws" and "Sorcerer." He doesn't seem to be at home in the theater, but it's largely because of this that we come to believe Joe Gideon is as special as Mr. Fosse insists he is.With an actor of less weight and intensity, "All That Jazz" might have evaporated as we watched it. Mr. Scheider's is a presence to reckon with. With him, the film's extraordinary finale becomes coolly comic. He's a defiant Don Giovanni who's beaten not by the Devil but by a coronary occlusion, which may be all that a sinner can hope for in this permissive day and age.The supporting cast is extremely good, beginning with Ann Reinking ("Movie, Movie"), who has legs to match Cyd Charisse's, is a fine dancer and an excellent comedian, who plays Joe Gideon's mistress; Leland Palmer, who plays his former wife; Erzsabet Foldi, as his daughter, and Deborah Geffner as one of his one-night stands. Cliff Gorman, who played Lenny Bruce in the Broadway show but not in Mr. Fosse's film "Lenny," plays Lenny in the film-within-this-film, and Anthony Holland has one very funny scene as a Broadway songwriter.One of Mr. Fosse's lesser inspirationsand the film has more than one  is a character identified in the credits as Angelique, played prettily and vacuously by Jessica Lange. Angelique is a figure who appears in Joe Gideon's fantasies and may possibly be the angel of death. She reminds me more of the sort of flesh-and-blood Tinkerbell who would be the perfect companion to Mr. Fosse's projection of himself as a kid who'd rather die than grow up.Also prominent in the cast are Willian LeMassena, David Margulies and John Lithgow. "All That Jazz" demonstrates once again the richness of New York's acting talent.

title: Waldheim Asks U.S. to Delay Bid On Iran in U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The Carter Administration said today that Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations had asked for a delay in American moves to seek economic sanctions against Iran and that the United States had agreed.

title: Nissan Expects Rise in Exports
description: TOKYO, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Japan's motor vehicle exports in 1979 will rise 7.8 percent to a record 4.95 million vehicles, including cars assembled abroad, the Nissan Motor Company, maker of the Datsun, said today.

title: Convictions Stand In Franklin Case
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the conviction of three former top officials of the Franklin National Bank for concealing the loss of millions of dollars in 1974 before the bank collapsed in the largest banking failure in the nation's history.

title: Inspection Finds Safety Violations at Postal Center
description: After touring the New Jersey postal facility where a mail handler died in an accident last Saturday, a Congressman and the staff director of a House postal subcommittee charged yesterday that safety at the facility was secondary to the movement of mail and that many of the safety violations they observed on a similar tour nine months ago had not been corrected.

title: RightWing Alliance in Portugal Wins Most Posts in Local Voting
description: LISBON, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  The rightwing Democratic Alliance won control of about 60 percent of Portugal's town and parish councils in last Sunday's local elections, according to official figures published today.

title: Soviet Writer Says He Is Quitting Union in Protest
description: MOSCOW. Dec. 19  Vasily Aksyonov, regarded as one of the best Russian writers of the postWorld War II generation, said today that he was resigning from the official Union of Soviet Writers to protest its refusal to reinstate two young authors expelled for joining a protest against censorshhip.

title: The Future Is Now And It Talks
description: IN the coming year, manufacturers hope to add speech to many products for the home that now sit silently on store shelves. Using microprocessors, which are actually miniature computers, the new talking machines contain an electronic voice box that the minicomputer is programmed to operate. The speech mechanism can be shrunken to almost microscopic dimensions, and the working vocabulary can be quite extensive.

title: Cruise Missile Test Continues
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP)  The Boeing Company has logged its eighth successful cruise missile flight in Utah in a competition with General Dynamics missiles for a billiondollar defense contract, Air Force spokesmen said today. The contract calls for 3,000 of the missiles, the first 20 of which are expected to be ready by December 1982.

title: Fatal Blast in Women's Dormitory Is Attributed to a Broken Romance
description: PULLMAN, Wash., Dec. 19 (AP) The authorities say that an explosion in a Washington State University dormitory that killed an 18yearold man stemmed from a broken relationship between him and a female resident of the dormitory.

title: Relief Official Praises Phnom Penh
description: LONDON, Dec. 20  The director of Oxfam's relief program in Cambodia today vigorously disputed recent charges that Russians and Vietnamese there had been blocking the distribution of food and medical supplies to starving peasants.

title: Certain Holiday Items Termed a Peril to Pets
description: Several of the most common Christmas items could prove fatal to household pets if accidentally swallowed, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said yesterday in a statement reported by The Associated Press

title: Screen: For Zappaphiles:A One-Man Enterprise
description: "BABY SNAKES" is a shapeless, inexcusably long concert film made of, by and about Frank Zappa, whose particular blend of avant-garde pretension and sophomoric glee doesn't do much to make the time fly. Mr. Zappa, with the members of his band, performs lengthy musical selections and complains obscurely about his former record company. He and the band also play with a toy police car, a gas mask, and an inflatable female doll, which they maul with either unabashed misogyny or a rather too subtle satirical imitation of same."Baby Snakes," which opens today at the Victoria Theater, also contains sequences of stop-motion clay animation, deftly executed by Bruce Bickford but with an exhausting emphasis upon maggoty shapes and putrefaction. Mr. Zappa, in the production notes, explains the "story" of one of the animated sequences this way:"In one scene (and you won't believe this if you haven't seen it yet) two clay people are watching a movie. One guy really likes it. He likes it so much his head turns into a hamburger. He turns to the guy sitting next to him and uses his hamburger-head to bite the face off the other guy, allowing the upper bun to close on the remnants of the victim's features. When it opens again, a tiny version of the victim appears in the middle of the murderous burger patty. Behind the little victim a building grows up (a disco) and dozens of tiny cars (about the size of eraser crumbs) drive through a portal in it."Mr. Zappa's film includes interviews with his fans, who explain why they think he is so wonderful. "Baby Snakes" is for them and them alone.

title: Horton, Mariners Agree
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 20 (AP)  The Seattle Mariners and Willie Horton, theiroutstanding designated hitter, have come to terms on a threeyear contract, the team announced today.

title: Blame for DC10 Crash in Chicago Split 3 Ways by U.S. Agency's Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The staff of the National Transportation Safety Board said today that blame for the DC10 jumbo jet crash in Chicago last May should be shared by the airline, the plane's builder and the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Upstate Judges Are Bitter About Temporary Transfers
description: ALBANY  On the eve of a huge temporary transfer of 242 upstate judges into the New York metropolitan area and three upstate urban counties, many of them are voicing bitterness over having to make up for what they view as the inefficiency of other courts.

title: Eli Basse, Humor Writer, Dead; Worked for Top Comedy Stars
description: Eli Basse, a comedy writer known in show business as The Funny Man's Funny Man, who wrote special material for such stars as Joe E. Lewis, Red Buttons, Milton Berle, Sophie Tucker, Jackie Gleason and many others, died yesterday at the Brookdale Medical Center in Brooklyn. He would have observed his 75th birthday next Thursday.

title: U.S. Growing Pessimistic on Peaceful Iran Outcome
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  For the first time in the 47-day-old Iranian crisis, senior White House and State Department officials are openly saying that time may be running out for finding a peaceful formula for the release of the 50 Americans being held hostage at the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: Stalin, The Last Bolshevik
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Josef Stalin would have been 100 years old today. His life can demonstrate the strange turns a revolution can take and the part a leader can play in this process.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES ANTITREATY REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  A majority of the Senate Armed Services Committee said today that the proposed treaty with the. Soviet Union to limit nuclear arms was not in the security interests of the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Company has appointed Mark Schneiderman vice presidentorganization and management resources and William F. Reilly vice presidentbusiness development of the corporate development office.

title: 75 Debutantes Presented At 44th Cotillion and Ball
description: Seventyfive young women made their formal bows to society last night at the 44th annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Rush H. Kress was honorary chairman for the event, proceeds of which went to the New York InfirmaryBeekman Downtown Hospital, as a result of last month's merger of the ball's longtime beneficiary, the New York Infirmary, with the Beekman Downtown Hospital.

title: Hotchkiss Bucks Era of. Permissiveness
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn.  In this sleepy town nestled in the foothills of the Berkshires, the clamor of the world seems as remote as the gray mist on the horizon at dusk. But to officials at the Hotchkiss School. an elite board-

title: Art: Photos Evoke Lost World of Japan
description: NO period since the invention or the camera and the photographic print has experienced as wide a range of photographic revelations as ours. From every realm of modern life and from virtually every corner or tne worm, a veritable torrent of photographic images now crowds our attention. And almost daily, it seems, the exploration of 19thcentury photography adds something fresh and unexpected something newly discovered  to this flood of unfamiliar pictures.

title: City Fears Aid Loss if Illegal Aliens Aren't Counted
description: Officials in New York said yesterday that if illegal aliens were not counted in the 1980 United States census, the city could lose up to $500 million in Federal aid over a decade and the state could lose millions more. Also, they said, the state could lose up to three seats in Congress.

title: IN THE NATION Iran Proves What?
description: In an article in The New York Times, Ray Cline, a former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, argues both for a revival of American covert operations abroad and for changing the agency's namehence abolishing the C.I.A. Regrettably, Mr. Cline concludes, the name is a liability abroad.

title: Widow of Cofounder of Revlon To Get $15 Million From Estate
description: Jaquine Lachman, fourth wife of the late Charles Lachman, cofounder of the Revlon cosmetics empire, was awarded an estimated $15 million from her late husband's $30 million estate yesterday, the Associated Press reported.

title: GEORGIA IS CLOSING A FAMOUS HOSPITAL
description: Roosevelt and Other Polio Victims Were Treated at Warm Springs

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Issue Sets A Record
description: With bidders losing much of the enthusiasm they showed only one day earlier for twoyear notes, the Treasury yesterday sold fouryear notes at an average rate of 10.52 percent. The auction was the first sale of fouryear notes since the Federal Reserve tightened monetary policy on Oct. 6, and the rate set a record for these securities.

title: Young Pupils From Two Schools Send Gifts to the Neediest Cases
description: Estelle Nisenson, a thirdgrade teacher at Public School 49 in Middle Village, Queens, wrote of her class recently: The children are great helpers, doers and givers. This month, their project was to collect money to send to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. They are happy to contribute $35 with the hope that it will be used to help a needy youngster.

title: Irritation on New District Lines Persists at City Hall
description: News Analysis

title: Canadien Slump Spurs Executive Meeting
description: In an attempt to snap the Canadiens' sixgame losing streak, their longest since the 193940 National Hockey League season, the club's managing director has called a meeting for today in Montreal to review our entire position.

title: Jazz: Cybill Shephard
description: CYBILL SHEPHARD, who has been a successful model, a notsosuccessful film actress and a less successful cabaret singer, is back in town in the guise of a jazz singer.

description: Christmas Exhibition

title: Books: No Cure but Time

title: Flyers Tie Penguins, Equal N.H.L. Record Of 28 Without a Loss
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20  It took all the guile and perseverance they could muster, but the Philadelphia Flyers finally managed to get the puck past Greg Millen of the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight at the Spectrum.
