title: Philharmonic: Stravinsky and Mozart
description: JAMES LEVINE and the New York Philharmonic were heard last night in Mozart's problematic C minor Mass, as well as in the much shorter Symphony of Psalms by Stravinsky. The Mozart work is problematic because either he never finished it or the completed materials have long been lost. Scholars today believe he never finished it. The first edition of 1890 is corrupt as well as incomplete, and scholars have spent over a hundred years putting together what has remained of the C minor Mass as best they can.

title: Art: Rediscovering 2 Unsung Painters
description: TO be an American painter in the last week of the 1970's is to have a claim on what everyone now recognizes as a tradition to be proud of. American art is now matter for big talk, big money and big hopes. When the Metropolitan Museum opens its new American Wing it will fulfil a dream for which many an Ameri-

title: Bush Will Forgo Protection Until After Primary in New Hampshire
description: HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 20  George Bush has made a tentative decision to forgo Secret Service protection, at least until after the New Hampshire primary.

title: EARNINGS
description: Beatrice Profits Up 10% in Period

title: Short Interest on Big Board Up by 4.2 Million Shares
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 4.2 million shares in the month ended Dec. 14 to 53.8 million shares. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 42.6 million shares_

title: Portuguese Air Strike Ended
description: LISBON, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  Air Portugal flight engineers called off their strike after agreement with management early today on a work and wage package, a union spokesman said. He said he expected the line, which has been grounded for six days, to be flying tomorrow.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES A COMPROMISE PLAN ON AID TO CHRYSLER
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 21 Congress gave final approval early today to compromise legislation to provide $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees to the struggling Chrysler Corporation, the largest Federal rescue plan ever for an American company. The bill now goes to President Carter, who is expected to sign it by Christmas.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Solarz Endorses Carter and Says He Could Carry Brooklyn District
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn endorsed President Carter for reelection today and praised his courageous leadership and his integrity and decency.

title: Restaurants
description: IT is more disappointing to come across a restaurant that is a nearmiss than it is to encounter a total failure. A case in point is Toscana, an Italian restaurant that would almost certainly be worth two stars if the dining room and kitchen were operated with a little more care and discipline.

title: Korean President Assumes Office; Doubts Democratic Shift Before 81
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Dec. 21  Choi Kyu Hah took office this morning as South Korea's fourth President and indicated that a shift to democratic rule would be put off at least until 1981.

title: Chicago's Transit Unions Agree to Order to End Strike
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 20  A county judge ordered transit workers today to end their four-day-old strike and return to work immediately, and both unions involved in the walkout indicated that they would comply. The judge also ordered the city and the unions to submit to binding arbitration.

title: 4th Reactor of Utility Shut Down
description: SURRY, Va., Dec. 20 (AP)  The Virginia Electric and Power Company has no nuclear generators in service after the automatic shutdown of the No. 1 reactor at the Sorry nuclear plant. The reactor shut itself down at 2 P.M. yesterday when one of three reactor coolant pump motors burned out, a utility spokesman said. The utility's three other reactors were out of service previously.

title: Economic Scene
description: ECONOMIC pressures on the industrial base in the East and Middle West have caused tremors at the bargaining table and in union halls. Collective bargaining structures that facilitate uniform treatment of employees within an industry have been eroded by competitive forces. Wage for- mulas that passively link increases in compensation to past productivity trends and changes in consumer prices have become a cause of instability in an environment of sluggish growth and hyperinflation. The status quo in labor relations is giving way to an uneasy period of transition.

title: Finding Shelter From the OPEC Tax
description: Thope OPEC meetings to raise the price of oil are becoming dangerously routine in American perceptions. The problem for the United States is not whether the cartel can be held to 1979 price increases of merely 100 percent by the good guys of Saudi Arabia, or whether it splinters into a greedy search for even larger individual increases. Prices now range from $24 to $30 a barrel, with substantial amounts of oil being sold on the spot market for more than $40. Oil prices have already reached a level that the United States cannot  should not  afford. Stronger measures than ever are needed to cut oil imports; the shift to alternative energy sources has to be speeded.

title: William Spaulding, 81, Is Dead; ExPresident of Houghton Mifflin
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  William E. Spaulding, who rose from salesman to be president and chairman of the Houghton Mifflin Company, died yesterday at the New England Rehabilitation Center in Woburn. He was 81 years old.

title: Vandalism by Drivers Cited in Weekend Night Ban in Park
description: For months it was one of those minor inconveniences that almost anyone who owns a car in New York City grows resigned to and does not think of protesting.

title: Auctions
description: Big season for the giants.

title: The City
description: City College's faculty senate withdrew its three representatives from the college's presidential search commit-tee yesterday, charging that City University officials had withheld names and resumes of potential candidates. The senate also called for the resignation of the committee's chairman, Stuart Scheftel, a member of the boardof the trustees of the university.

title: Stock Prices Up as Gold Fever Cools
description: Stock prices on Wall Street posted a small advance yesterday as investors took some encouragement from a cooling of the gold fever in European bullinn markets.

title: Quebec Not Asking Sovereignty Yet
description: QUEBEC, Dec. 20  The Quebec government will ask voters next spring for a mandate to negotiate a new agreement with Canada on a basis of equality, but will do nothing to change Quebec's political status until it gets approval in a second referendum.

title: Drug Company Faces $147 Million Lawsuit Over Birth Deformity,
description: A woman born 21 years ago with deformed feet filed a $147 million damage suit yesterday against Richardson-Merrell, the manufacturer of the drug Bendectin, charging that her defects were caused by a morningsickness pill taken by her mother during pregnancy.

title: Ballet Theater Dancers Accept Pact
description: The corps de ballet of the American Ballet Theater late yesterday unanimously accepted a management salary proposal, thus ending an eightweek labor dispute that resulted in a lockout of the dancers and the cancellation of the company's December season at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Carter Plans Tens of Millions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The Carter Administration plans to propose a significant boost in Federal expenditures next year to help rural and small communities handle their growth, a top domestic adviser said today.

title: Connors to Skip Australian Open
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors has withdrawn from the $350,000 Australian open tennis tournament, which begins in Melbourne next Monday.

title: Jazz at Noon Celebrates 15th Birthday
description: Jazz at Noon. the weekly sessions at which businessmen, lawyers, doctors, cabdrivers, artists, ministers and other closet 3377 musicians come out to ;am with one another and with a guest professional, will celebrate its 15th birthday today at Storytowne, 58th Street between Madison and Park Avenues, with Clark Terry, the trumpeter and fluegelhornist as guest. The celebration will, of course. start at noon.

title: Moscow Marks Stalin's Centennial, Ambivalent in Judging His Legacy
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20  The Soviet Union is preparing to mark Stalin's 100th birthday tomorrow with the mixture of tribute to his accomplishments and ambivalence about his abuses that has been reflected during the 15 years Leonid I. Brezhnev has been in power.

title: Mondale Recovering From Flu
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Vice President Mondale has been at home suffering from influenza for two days, a spokesman said today, adding that the Vice President was expected back in his office tomorrow.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) Larry Jones, director of player operations for the Women's Basketball League, said yesterday that the league revoked Eric Kraus's ownership of the Philadelphia Fox three weeks ago and was running the team until a new owner could be found.

title: Garwood Role as Guard Described
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., Dec. 20 (AP)  Marine Pfc. Robert Garwood, accused of deserting and collaborating with the enemy in Vietnam, stood guard over American prisoners of war at a camp run by the North Vietnamese, a former prisoner of war testified today.

title: Feminists Cool To NOW Stand Against Carter
description: In the aftermath of last week's controversial condemnation of President Carter by the National Organization for Women, women's groups around the country are reassessing their own agendas. Despite NOW's generally accepted position of leadership, most women's groups seem to be deciding that, as Joyce Miller, president of the Coalition of Labor Union Women, put it : Each group has to do its own thing.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: To anyone who would like to escape the remorseless cheer and the ton of coffeetable books that the season is about to dump on us, I hereby recommend Piers Paul Read's new novel. A Married

title: How to Get the Most Out of Christmas in New York
description: CHRISTMAS is fabled in New York. Poets write of t; choirs sing of it; Miracle on 34th Street was a movie about it. Christmas in New York is a legend and a myth and a romance, sometimes elusive and difficult to find. Then, when it is found, it may be full of contradictions. Struck by the contradictions, 0. Henry wrote a short story about Christmas in New York: The Gift of the Magi. If Christmas in London is plum pudding and Dickens, in New York it is Saks's windows and a Bensonhurst creche, Rockefeller Center and tinsel in Bay Ridge. Mostly, however, it is a celebration in familiar places.

title: In New Ethnic Violence in Iran, Baluchis Battle Persians
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 20A new outburst of ethnic violence with anti-Government overtones erupted in a remote province of Iran today as the situation of the American Embassy hostages in the capital remained deadlocked.

title: DISPUTE OVER ALIENS SNARLS CENSUS PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  Plans for the 1980 census have been thrown into confusion by a constitutional dispute over whether illegal aliens should be included in the count for reapportioning the next Congress and distributing Federal aid.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.( N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) over-the-counter.

description: James R. Harvey has been named president and chief operating officer of the Transamerica Corporation, a San Franciscobased conglomerate.

title: New School Aid For the Disabled Ordered in City
description: Calling New York City's efforts to educate handicapped children inadequate, a Federal judge has ordered that from now on school officials must act within 60 days to evaluate and place such children in appropriate programs once they are identified as possibly handicapped.

title: The Pop Life
description: ONCE again, just in time for Christmas, comes this year's list of the 10 pop records that gave this writer the most pleasure  as opposed to whatever other kinds of recorded music might seem worthy in an absolute sense. Last year, tor instance, Steve Reich's Music for 18 Musicians placed No. 3 on the list. Mr. Reich is a classical composer, but his disk was on the ECM jazz label and received some progressiverock air play and promotion. This year, there was Philip Glass's Einstein on the Beach. Mr. Glass has many things in common with Mr. Reich. But Einstein is a fourdisk opera, and it simply can't count as a pop record. If it were included, then Sweeney Todd might have to be, too. And then there would be the new, threeact Lulu of Alban Berg, and all notions of category would collapse.

title: Green Light for Coal Gas Plant
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The corporate sponsors of the nation's first plant to convert coal to gas for pipeline transmission announced plans today to begin construction in April.

title: RATE ON MORTGAGES OF 12.5% EXPECTED IN NEW YORK STATE
description: Interest rates on home mortgages are expected to increase to 12.5 to 13 percent in New York State, bankers and state officials said yesterday, following Congressional action that would suspend all states ceilings on mortgage rates until March 31.

title: Child Custody: Jurists Weigh Film vs. Life
description: Kramer vs. Kramer, which opened here this week to critical acclaim, is a divorce movie that transcends the genre of divorce movies. It looks beyond the private struggles of men or women to focus on the fundamental and public issue of a child of divorce who becomes the center of a legal custody battle.

title: Arrest Leads to a Drugs Cache
description: The police subdued a 23-year-old man who had barricaded himself in his girlfriend's apartment for 45 minutes yesterday and had threatened to kill himself, The Associated Press reported. An estimated $30,000 worth of drugs were found in the apartment, at 321 West 24th Street, the police said. The woman, Stephanie Hollingsworth, 39, called the police after the man, Garry Madder, reportedly began beating her, After subduing Mr. Madder, who had a revolver, the police arrested Miss Hollingsworth on drug possession charges.

title: The Vatican And Rebels
description: News Analysis

title: Student Shoveling Snow Is Shot
description: A 19-year-old college student was shot in the stomach by two robbers early yesterday while shoveling snow in front of his Brooklyn home, The Associated Press reported. Two boys aged 13 or 14 tried to hold up the older youth  Jimmy Mak, a marketing student at New York Community College  around 12:30 A.M. outside the Mak home at 2807 Glenwood Avenue in the Flatbush area, the police said. Mr. Mak resisted and was shot by one of the two. The police said doctors had removed a slug from Mr. Mak during surgery at Kings County Hospital. His condition was described as fair to guarded.

title: WASHINGTON The New Cult of Personality
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  Nothing fascinates this city more than the struggle between personality and policy. It is the oldest game in town. It was going on between Mr. Jefferson and Mr. Hamilton in Philadelphia over The Federalist papers even before this mud flat on the Potomac was chosen as the compromise capital of the new Republic.

title: 2 Suspects Not Guilty, Trial Witness Testifies
description: A man testifying under immunity said yesterday that a bartender on Manhattan's West Side was killed by a paid police informant, and not by the two men on trial for the slaying.

title: Kennedy Camp Appoints Crangle National Director for Party Affairs
description: Joseph F. Crangle, the Erie County Democratic chairman, was appointed yesterday as a national campaign director for Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Presidential drive, one of the top positions in the organization.

title: Broadway
description: CALREINER has been here before and has no delusions. Tough to Get Help, which he directed on Broadway in 1972, closed after one night. His own play, Something Differ- ent, which he directed in 1967, managed to hold on for a longer, yet still disappointing run of 103 per- formances.

title: McGinnis Suspended, Loses pay
description: Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, yesterday suspended George McGinnis of the Denver Nuggets for 10 days without pay after deciding that McGinnis deliberately knocked a referee to the floor during a game last Sunday night.

title: About Real Estate The Catch in Rent Abatements for Elderly
description: One of the ways the city of New York helps many elderly citizens is to exempt them from rent increases that would put their rent above a third of their annual household income. A tenant 62 years old or older is eligible as long as the household's income not exceed $6,500.

title: CARTER SAID TO BAR AN OIL IMPORT FEE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 what ap pored to be another blow to advocates of raising gasoline prices to encourage cone nervation, President Carter has told his top advisers that he does not want to impose a fee on imported oil to force a price increase, according to Administration officials.

title: Messiah SingIn
description: Starting at S tonight, the walls of Avery Fisher Hall may seem to bulge. The roof will appear to arch upward and then, after a great shudder, the building itself will seem to lift off amid a mighty Hallelujah! chorus.

title: U.S. Funds Allocated For Carter and Baker
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) President Carter and the Senate Republican leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, today became the first contenders for Presidential nominations for whom matching campaign funds have been allocated by the Federal Election Commission, but they cannot pick up their checks until Jan. 1.

title: U.S. Companies Seek Rhodesian Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  One of the first among the many American corporations to seek a green light from the Commerce DepArtment for sales to Rhodesia after President Carter lifted the sanctions against that country. was Walt Disney Productions of Burbank, Calif.

title: Baker to Support Neutrality For New York G.O.P. Slate
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. said yesterday that at the moment he would abide by the a request from the New York State Republican chairman, Dr. Bernard Kilboum, not to contest an uncommitted slate of delegates to the party's national convention.

title: Dance: Debuts Spark Nutcracker
description: THE New York City Ballet's production of The Nutcracker continues its marathon course, but not always with familiar faces in familiar roles. On Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, Susan Gluck made her debut as the Sugar Plum Fairy and JeanPierre Frohlich made his debut as her cavalier. Another new Sugar Plum Fairy on Sunday night was Kyra Nichols.

title: Screen: 'Black Hole' By Disney:Ultimate Knowledge
description: IF you like outer space, "The Black Hole" is the latest version of the next best thing to being there. Produced by the Disney studios, it cost half as much as "Star Trek" and looks better  not as lavish, perhaps, but more original. The special effects are fancy, and the design even more so. The sets are so eye-catching, in fact, that they distract attention from the actors, which in movies of this genre is almost always a good idea. The cast includes Anthony Perkins, Maximilian Schell, Ernest Borgnine, Yvette Mimieux, and a robot named Vincent who is a whole lot livelier than his flesh-and-blood friends.Like "Star Wars," which it uses as a point of departure rather than a blue-print, "The Black Hole" concentrates on those little, personal touches that can make a spaceship comfy instead of austere. So the bunks of the crew members have Space Art on the walls, and instead of portholes there are big, beautiful picture windows. The emphasis is on homeyness, rather than hardware, and the results are friendly and inviting. The movie's design, by Peter Ellenshaw, borrows from painters like Chagall and Mondrian to achieve a decorative, dated modernism, perhaps to suggest that if we ever do get Out There, our present notions of futuristic design will seem cheerfully quaint with hindsight.The plot, unfortunately, trundles toward that towering bugaboo of science fiction movies, Ultimate Knowledge. One character in this story is after it, and to get what he wants he's willing to turn the others into slaves and ashtrays. His quest will eventually take him into the Hole of the title, which leads the film makers, at the finale, to attempt grandiose effects that, by comparison with the easier gimmicks of the preceding hour and a half, look a little silly. Incidentally, "The Black Hole" lasts only 97 minutes, which means not that it is skimpy, but that it's mercifully without padding."The Black Hole," which opens today at Loew's Orpheum 2, is attractively unpretentious and at times quite snappy  among the more sensational stunts is a shot of a huge, molten meteor rolling towards a crew of tiny people, who appear to be right in its path. Its story, about a band of explorers and a wicked space tyrant who pretends to be nice, has a comic-book feeling. But as comic books go, this one is pretty much a page-turner."The Black Hole" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains a couple of mild scares, and a nasty murder.

title: Jail Escape Revives Shadowy Terror Group in Spain
description: MADRID, Dec. 20  The bizarre case of the terrorist organization known as the First of October Antifascist Resistance Groups, which is widely suspected of having been infiltrated by diehard Francoist secret policemen, was reopened this week when five important members of the supposedly farleft band escaped from a prison in Zamora through a tunnel.

title: Abandoned as a Child in Korea, He'll Be Coming Home
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 20 (UPI) James Daniel Bronson, because he is a Caucasian, has spent most of his 24 years shunned as a nonperson in Korea, living in military compounds, orphanages and even in the forest for a time.

title: Two Escape Over Berlin Wall
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 20 (Reuters) Two young men climbed over the Berlin wall from the East last night, the police reported today. More than 50 people have been shot and thousands arrested trying to cross the 12I/2foot wall since it was built by the East German Communist Government in 1961.

title: The Day After a Snowstorm, the City's Parks Are Still Winter Wonderlands
description: While the rest of the city coped yesterday with graying slush or icy puddles laced with road salt, New York's parks remained relatively free of the ravages of plow and sander. Visitors to Washington Square Park strolled past snow- covered benches in a scene reminiscent of a Currier and Ives lithograph. Today's forecast calls for partly sunny skies with a high temperature of about 40 degrees. Clouds will roll in Saturday to mark the first day of winter.

title: F.C.C. Takes Steps to Encourage Minority Ownership of Stations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  The Federal Communications Commission moved Wednesday to encourage minority ownership of radio and television stations and improve television service in New Jersey.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: Tanzania's Worries: Farming, Nyerere
description: DAR ES SALAAM. Tanzania, Dec. 15  In an office here at State House, an elaborate beachfront piece of scrollwork on grounds exploding with bougainvillea and frangipani, a ranking official spoke candidly of national concerns.

title: Events and Openings; Friday
description: Films

title: New Plan Offered For PetroCanada
description: TORONTO, Dec. 20  Prime Minister Joe Clark, in one of his first campaign appearances for the Feb. 18 national election, announced an amended plan today to turn ownership of PetroCanada, the $2.5 billion Government oil company, back to the people.

title: Airports Fearful as Court Backs Jet Distress
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20  A recent California Supreme Court ruling upholding the right of people who live near airports to sue for damages for emotional and mental distress resulting from the noise of jet aircraft is sending shock waves through the aviation world.

title: Chemical Found in the Brain May Be Key in Pain Control
description: A brain chemical that is 200 times more powerful in action than morphine and 50 times more powerful than any previously known substance of its kind has been discovered by scientists at Stanford University and the California Institute of Technoloev.

title: 2 Women Charged in Holdup
description: Two young women were arrested yesterday minutes after they attempted to hold up a Bowery Savings Bank in midManhattan, United Press International reported. The women allegedly entered the bank at One Penn Plaza at 3 P.M. and approached a teller, who gave them $2,700 and sounded an alarm. Two bank security guards immediately arrested the suspects, the police said. They were identified as Mary Weisse, 21 years old, of 2750 Johnson Avenue, the Bronx, and Carol Gallagher, 19, of Pine Hill, N.Y. Each was charged with attempted bank robbery.

title: Kentucky Couple Meet Militants Holding the Hostages in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 20 (AP)  A Kentucky couple were allowed into the United States Embassy compound today to meet with some of the Iranian militants holding 50 American hostages but were not allowed to talk with the Americans.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Executions Reported in Shanghai As City Steps Up Fight on Crime
description: PEKING, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  Three criminals have been executed in Shanghai in the last nine days as the city stepped up its drive against crime, Liberation Daily of Shanghai reported.

title: STUDY OF SWEETENER FINDS TIE TO CANCER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The National Cancer Institute and the Food and Drug Administration today released a study of thousands of bladder cancer patients that found that heavy users of artificial sweeteners ran a greatly increased risk of developing cancer, especially if they also smoked cigarettes.

title: A 64Foot Christmas Card Is Carried to the Embassy
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 20  That isn't a carpet you have brought, is it? the youthful Islamic activist at the gates of the United States Embassy here asked the young American who stood outside the compound, a large rolled bundle balanced on his left shoulder.

description: James Eugene Goddard, a former Republican Assemblyman from Monroe County and a Court of Claims judge for five years until his retirement in 1971, died Tuesday after suffering a heart attack while driving from a business appointment in Rochester to his home in East Rochester. He was 78 years old.

title: Ban on Change To Cooperatives In Ft. Lee Voided
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 20  A 19month ban by Fort Lee on the conversion of rental apartments to owneroccupied condominiums and cooperatives was overturned today by a state judge.

title: Rock: Fusion at Hurrah
description: BY far the most fascinating phenomenon on the Manhattan underground rock scene just now is the infusion of energies from the black jazz community  an infusion that is making more fresh and exciting music than any time since tne nascence of the punk scene in 1975. James (Blood) Ulmer started it at the Tin Palace and then at the rock clubs, and the work was continued with the jazzblues jams at the Squat Theater.

title: Muzorewa Off to London to Sign Peace Pact
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa left for London today to sign a peace agreement with the Patriotic Front guerrillas designed to end one of Africa's longest, harshest and costliest wars.

title: Screen: Rossellini, Brook and Mostel:'Teacher' and Curio
description: ANOTHER of the late Roberto Rossellini's extraordinary "teaching films," the two-hour "Augustine of Hippo," made in 1972, has its New York theatrical premiere today at the Thalia on a bill with a 1968 English curio, "Red, White and Zero," three short films directed by Peter Brook, Lindsay Anderson and Tony Richardson."Augustine" is a leisurely, graceful recollection of the great Christian philosopher's most productive years when, toward the end of the fourth century, he returned to North Africa from Italy having abandoned Manichaeism and embraced Christianity. First in Tagaste and then at Hippo, where he was named Bishop, Augustine evolved the doctrines that gave him the reputation as the founder of Christian theology.Knowing that no movie could conceivably cover all of the accomplishments of Augustine's later life, Rossellini here relies on an almost impressionistic approach to facts  with references to the Donatist controversy, the Pelagian heresy, the fall of Rome in 410 (for which the abolition of heathen worship by Christians was blamed) and Augustine's teachings and writings relating to original sin and the sacraments.Though Rossellini's concern for content is as rigorous as it is in his other "teaching films," especially in "The Age of the Medici" and "Socrates," the style of "Augustine" is unexpectedly cinematic, with lovely sets, costumes, music, sound effects and, seemingly, more camera movements than in all of the other films put together. The color photography is splendid."Red, White and Zero" is something else entirely. The best segment is Mr. Anderson's "The White Bus," a surreal, funny examination of postwar England in the form of a guided tour of a dreary English industrial city. The picture was shown in New York some years ago in a Museum of Modern Art retrospective devoted to the director's short films.Mr. Brook's "The Ride of the Valkyries" is a hopelessly unfunny slapstick comedy in which the late Zero Mostel plays an opera singer desperately trying to get from the airport to the opera house in time for the wrong performance. Mr. Brook clearly appreciates this kind of comedy, but understands it not at all.Mr. Richardson's "Red and Blue" looks to have been fatally influenced by Jacques Brel or maybe Michel Legrand, being an entirely "sung" fable about a beautiful, unhappy chanteuse (Vanessa Redgrave) and her affairs with various men played by, among others, Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and Michael York. The songs, by Cyrus Bassiak and translated by Julian More, are hilariously awful. Sample lyric: "Orly/Paris/The time is minuit."

title: INDIRA GANDHI WINS IN A CONTEMPT CASE
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 20  A contempt charge against former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was dismissed here today by a judge who ruled that since Mrs. Gandhi had not been asked to swear an oath she was not legally obliged to testify before a Government commission that looked into her conduct in office.

title: New Face: Harry Groener Oklahoma!
description: HE bounds on stage, fresh as the morning sunlight that imaginary though it be bathes the scene. His head is as full as his carpetbag with wondrous things. He has been far away, in the great wide world, where he saw a skyscraper seven stories high! Where they turn the knob on a thingamabob called a radiator and heat comes out. He has been, in short, to Kansas City! And then Harry Groener, playing Will Parker, Ado Annie's hayseed swain in Oklahoma! proceeds to enthrall the folks out front with Everything's Up to Date in Kansas City.

description: CHRISTMAS has changed. Roast geese have been replaced byfrozen turkeys. Aunts and uncles no longer gather in the parlor, but around the phone. And nowadays swirling, weeklong snowstorms that obliterate the ordinary world mostly mean tnat traffic will be bad. But in the place of yesteryear's holiday traditions the city and its environs are once again offering a uniquely rich collection of diversions for youngsters. Everything from the Metropolitan Museum's traditional Baroque Christmas tree and crche to a disco fairy tale for the 80's wait to be discovered.

This one, at the Mu- seum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street (through Jan. 28) brings us au courant with the artist's printmaking activi- ties, celebrating his 20year collaboration with the Swiss publisher Gerald Cramer and the Parisian master printer Jacques Frelaut.

title: Film: A New Mastroianni:Romance Across Time
description: NASTASSIA KINSKI plays the vixenish young girl who very nearly makes a fool of Marcello Mastroianni in "Stay as You Are," a movie with attractive stars, interesting ambitions and not much follow-through. The premise calls for stable, married, well-heeled Giulio (Mr. Mastroianni) to become smitten with the beautiful Francesca (Miss Kinski), though he knows she's young enough to be his daughter. What he doesn't know, until after they become involved, is that she may very well be his daughter, since her mother was someone he loved and forgot about, just the right number of years ago.Giulio worries about this, of course. What makes the film somewhat novel, or at least modern, is that the intimations of incest don't bother Francesca in the slightest. She likes older men, she explains; that's why she has posters of Hemingway and Einstein on the bedroom wall.And she likes Giulio. And even if he is her father, biologically speaking, he didn't raise her and he hardly knows her and she doesn't have any strong feelings about him one way or the other. She shrugs. Giulio worries. They eventually resolve their differences, but the problem is more engaging than its solution.Mr. Mastroianni attacks his role earnestly, affecting a middle-aged fussiness and seeming genuinely troubled, even torn. He has some excellent moments with a wife and daughter  she is about Francesca's age, and almost as promiscuous  that help supply the film with a broader sense of family relationships, and of the differing mores of different generations.Much of this information is presented and then ignored, but Mr. Mastroianni gives Giulio as much depth as the material will allow. There are hints throughout "Stay as You Are," which was directed by Alberto Lattuada, of the much more memorable movie this might have become.Miss Kinski, who is really the daughter of the German actor Klaus Kinski, looks very little like her father and a lot like the very young, very beautiful Ingrid Bergman. The resemblance is strictly facial and it doesn't go more than skin-deep, perhaps because Miss Kinski's manner and bearing are so much less remarkable than her appearance. She makes a convincingly coltish teen-ager, which is really all this role demands. But she's more captivating to look at than to listen to, and her Francesca eventually becomes terribly whiny, even dull."Stay as You Are," which opens today at the Beekman, is dangerously smarmy at times  dangerous because its cheapness undermines Mr. Mastroianni's essentially serious performance, which is the backbone of the movie. The film works best when the story seems to generate its sexual encounters spontaneously. But there are too many times when the plot looks like a pretext for stringing together amorous interludes.

Using overtone techniques found in both the cathedrals of the West and in Central Asian chanting, the eightmember ensemble directed by David Hykes, sings fundamental chords from which soar delicate, flutelike melodies. They are performing tonight at 8 at the Alternative Center for International Arts, 28 East Fourth Street (admission $4; information : 4736072) and tomorrow night at 8 in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam and 112th Street, where they are in residence, and where the re- sounding acoustics particularly suit their singing. Its treasury will almost certainly contain hundreds of millions in surplus when the fiscal year ends next June 30. Until this week, however, this listener had never heard works composed expressly for trumpet and marimba. But, on Wednesday night, a program of them was performed at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Wilder Duo Robert Levy, trumpeter, and Gordon Stout, marimbist. According to a program note, the players adopted the ensemble name of Wilder because of their admiration for Alec Wilder, the composer.

title: Film: 'Cuba' in Richard Lester's Eyes:Mercenary Madness
description: RICHARD LESTER'S "Cuba," which is set in Cuba late in 1958, in the weeks immediately preceding the triumph of Fidel Castro's revolution, is a straightfaced romantic melodrama that's almost as lunatic as Mr. Lester's "Help!" and "How I Won the War," both written by Charles Wood, who also wrote the screenplay for the new film.I can't help but suspect that at some point during the production, which was shot in Spain, Mr. Lester and his associates decided that there was absolutely no way to realize the Harold Robbins-like potential of the story and chose, instead, to make a film that is a crazy fanatsy about old-time Hollywood melodramas, the sort turned out by Warner Brothers, directed by Michael Curtiz and starring Humphrey Bogart and perhaps Eleanor Parker. Seeing the film through this fog of memory, you might find it as outrageously endearing as I did."Cuba," which opens today at the Cinerama 1 and other theaters, is about Robert Dapes (Sean Connery), an English mercenary of such high principles you can't believe he'd hire himself out as a dog-catcher, much less as a man brought in by the Batista Government to squash the guerrillas hiding out in the Sierra Maestre. It's also about a rich, beautiful, ambitious, American-sounding Cuban woman, Alexandra Pulido (Brooke Adams), who, 15 years earlier, had an affair with Dapes, but who is now married and happily running a tobacco factory.In the way of Harold Robbins fiction, there are lots of subsidiary characters who may or may not be what they seem  a sweaty American businessman (Jack Weston), Alexandra's weak-willed husband (Chris Sarandon), a venal corporal-turned-Batista general (Martin Balsam), an English entrepreneur of dubious scruples (Denholm Elliott) and a fiery young Fidelista (Danny De La Paz), who spends as much time running around Havana avenging his sister's honor as he does working for a Castro victory.This are a lot of characters to keep track of. To bring them together, Mr. Lester and Mr. Wood rely mainly on coincidence  to such an extent you eventually get the feeling that Cuba is even smaller than Nantucket. Though a lot of the dialogue would seem absurd even on daytime soap opera, the movie keeps coming up with scenes so arresting or eccentric you are aware of the wicked intelligence behind them. No one but Mr. Lester would dare to introduce us to the toppling dictator, at home, as he watches a Dracula movie on television, or to allow his lovers, who've just rediscovered each other, to take a dreamy, idyllic walk through the slums of Havana at sunrise.The members of the excellent supporting cast play the film without ever cracking up, which couldn't have been easy. Mr. Connery dominates things with the benign, elegant manner of a guest who, though perfectly polite, has no intention of staying longer than he has to. Miss Adams seems delighted to be playing opposite such a charming fellow, but there are hints she has no more idea of what's going on than we do.

title: Screen: Redford-Jane Fonda Comedy:Cowboy and the Lady
description: THE movie about the cowboy and the lady has been around a long time, even before there was one called "The Cowboy and the Lady" in 1938, when Gary Cooper was the cowboy and Merle Oberon the lady he instructed in nature's improving ways. Just why the story should be so durable I've no idea, unless it reflects our guilty longing to behave morally and ethically in a society that doesn't always pay top-dollar for generous thoughts and proper deportment. The untutored innocent is a steadfastly appealing character, even though you might not want your sister to marry one.Just how durable this story is may be seen in "The Electric Horseman," Sydney Pollack's invigorating new comedy that is acted to the nines by a fine cast, in particular by Robert Redford as an over-the-hill rodeo rider, now the photogenic but boozy spokesman for a cereal called Ranch Breakfast, and Jane Fonda as a reporter who goes after him for a story and winds up with considerably more. The film opens today at Loews Twin 2 and other theaters.Robert Garland's screenplay sounds as hip as a television talk-show host's opening monologue, what with references to conglomerates, the celebrity of television journalists, Las Vegas and Madison Avenue, but down-deep the movie's heart is pure 1938, which is not at all bad. Further, Mr. Redford and Miss Fonda are not only excellent actors, but they are also among the few actors of our day who qualify as screen personalities on the order of Cooper and Miss Oberon or John Wayne and Jean Arthur, who did this turn in 1943 in "The Lady Takes a Chance.""The Electric Horseman" even advocates a kind of appealingly dopey populism that isn't much different from that of "The Cowboy and the Lady" and "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," which may help put Miss Fonda's well-publicized political opinions into historical context. Our Rosa Luxemburg turns out to be only a little to the left of Shirley Temple Black. The film is, I think, anti-Big Business, though not in any revolutionary way, and demonstrates how a straight-thinking loner, with the help of the television newswoman who loves him, can bring to its knees a conglomerate the size of Gulf & Western.However, the point of the screenplay is not its politics, but its gently satiric view of some aspects of contemporary life as represented by the cowboy, Sonny (Mr. Redford), and Hallie (Miss Fonda), the sharp-as-nails lady from back East. They come together at a huge Las Vegas convention designed to celebrate the corporate swallowing up of something called Omnibank by another company, the seemingly evilly named Amco.Sonny, whose Ranch Breakfast contract is owned by Amco, sobers up long enough to object to the manner in which Amco flunkies are mistreating a prize-winning racehorse named Rising Star. In a moment of decision, Sonny steals the horse and rides serenely away from the splendors of Caesar's Palace and Las Vegas, planning to turn Rising Star loose in the sheltered foothills of Utah.The movie has a good deal of fun at the expense of corporate clichs, which aren't always benign, but it only hits its stride when Sonny and Hallie are on the great trail to horse freedom, pursued by the state police, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and character assassins in the pay of Amco.Miss Fonda, in addition to being a fine dramatic actress, is a first-rate comedian, whether she's stumbling over a Utah mountain in her chic, spike-heeled, patent-leather boots or suddenly becoming shy after a night well spent in the cowboy's sleeping bag.Mr. Redford is equally funny and equally at ease, both in the early sections of the film as the duded-up, break-fast-food spokesman and, later, as the natural man who realizes his particular American dream.Mr. Pollack has also cast the supporting roles with care, especially Willie Nelson, the country-music star, as Sonny's laid-back rodeo pal; Valerie Perrine as Sonny's sweet but not infinitely patient former wife, and John Saxon as the amusingly ruthless head of Amco.At this point, I think it's reasonably safe to say that "The Electric Horseman" is the best American romantic comedy of 1979."The Electric Horseman," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some slightly vulgar language and some harmless references to sexual congress.

title: Around the Nation
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 21 (UPI) The Public Utility Commission voted today, 4 to 0. against a request by the Metropolitan Edison Company for an immediate rate increase of $55 million to offset costs of replacing power lost by the shutdown of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, the center of the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident on March 28.

title: Arrows Clip Wings, 1310, Tie Indoor Soccer Record
description: UNIONDALE, L., I., Dec. 21  The New York Arrows, after dissipating a 53 secondperiod advantage, scored four times in the third quarter to beat the Wichita Wings, 1310, tonight in a Major Indoor Soccer League game at Nassau Coliseum before 4,454 fans. The 23 goals tied a league record, established last week, when Cleveland heat Pi t tsburith by a similar score.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 21 (UPI) Peace Corps worker was freed by guerrillas today after being held hostage for 10 days at a San Salvador market.

title: Kennedy Keeps Up Attack on Carter Energy Policy
description: BEDFORD, N.H., Dec. 21  The disagreement between Senator Edward M. Kennedy and President Carter over energy policies flared again today, with the Massachusetts Democrat asserting that the President had broken a 1976 promise to hold down oil prices and the White House countering that the Senator was playing fast and loose with his political campaign.

title: Rickover Asks Bar to Investigate Corcoran as Long Feud Goes On
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  The longrunning personal feud between two aging veterans of the capital's political wars, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover and Thomas G. Corcoran, took a new turn this week when the admiral asked the District of  Columbia Bar to investigate reports that Mr. Corcoran tried to lobby two Supreme Court Justices in behalf of a client 10 years ago.

title: A Basically British Dry Cleaner
description: They started with a shop in the Belgravia section of London 10 years ago. We knew that we had to have a good name and a graphic symbol, said Sydney Jacob of Jeeves, the English dry cleaning and laundry establishment that just opened at 770 Madison Avenue, at 66th Street.

title: Bridge:
description: Safety plays come in two varieties, automatic and sacrificial. If you have A-x-x in your hand opposite K109xx. it is automatic to cash the ace and finesse the nine. It guards against Q-Jxx on your left and costs nothing. This is simply the right way to play this suit combination, and it can be argued that it is not a safety play at all.

title: Rutgers Women Try Again
description: In 1977, when the Rutgers women's basketball team made a trip to Madison Square Garden for a Christmas tournament, the emotions on the bus ride from New Jersey were a mixture of anticipation and dread. The mystique of playing in the Garden, against some of the top teams in the nation, pitted excitement against pressure.

title: Trail Blazers Rally To Beat Nets, 10097
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 21 (AP) Tom Owens scored on a driving layup with 28 seconds left to play tonight for the winning basket as the Portland Trail Blazers posted a 10097 victory over the New Jersey Nets in the National Basketball Association.

title: Rights Leader Reports That Iran Invited Him To Visit the Hostages
description: The Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said yesterday that the head of Iran's mission in Washington invited him about two weeks ago to visit the 50 Americans being held hostage in the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: Uncertain Outlook on OPEC's Output
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  After most meetings of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the consuming world at least knows the bad news  how much higher prices will be until the next semiannual price- setting.

title: Duke Victor, 70 to 64, Over Boston College
description: PROVIDENCE. R.I., Dec. 21 (UPI)  Mike Gminski scored 24 points, including five in overtime, and led Duke to a hardfought 7064 victory over previously undefeated Boston College tonight in the Industrial National Classic.

title: MAKES APPEAL ON TV
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  President Carter, accusing Iran of arrogant defiance of the world community, said today that the United States had decided to ask the United Nations Security Council to impose economic sanctions against Iran in a further effort to free the 50 American hostages.

title: Security Council Votes to End Rhodesian Embargo
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 21 (Reuters)  The Security Council voted today to lift its 13year economic embargo against Rhodesia, which has resumed colonial status under a British Governor while preparing for elections leading to independence.

title: Nixon to Share Cost of New Office
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nixon has decided to share the cost of his new office with the Government when he moves to New York City, paying for the space he and his secretary occupy.

title: A New Image for the Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21  Ollie Hanson remembers the old days, the days when his beloved, fistswinging heroes enjoyed being known as the Broad Street Bullies.

title: A Murder That Still Echoes in Mill Hill
description: TRENTON  Was Emma Jane Stockton killed because of who she was or where she lived?

title: Congress Adjourns for Holidays, Leaving Many Items Unresolved
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  Congress left town after a final burst of activity early today, but many major items of Iegiclative business remain unresolved.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1979

title: Boxing Group Institutes New Medical Plan
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 21 (UPI)  The World Boxing Council announced a medical program today to improve boxer safety and said the program would be implemented by 96 countries.

title: Books of The Times Not-so-Mute Testimony
description: Now that we have a minimum wage in this country, perhaps we ought to have a minimum language, too, a subsistence level of articulation below which no one should be allowed to fall. It could be argued that language is the wage of consciousness and that poverty of consciousness deserves our attention as much as the other kind.

title: Transcript of Carter Request for Sanctions by U.N.
description: From the first day the American Embassy was invaded and our diplomatic staff were seized as hostages by Iran. we have pursued every legal channel available to us to secure their safe and prompt release.

title: Postal Worker's Death Sparks Work Stoppage
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 21 (AP) Some workers at the Postal Service's bulkmail facility here are refusing to man conveyor belts since an employee died last week after getting caught in the mechanism of one of them, an official said today.

description: INTEROFFICE MEMO

title: November Orders Off In Durables
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  New orders received by the nation's factories for durable goods fell 1.2 percent in November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Union Sets Strategy On Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21  Leaders of the United Automobile Workers union outlined today what their strategy would be in bargaining with the Chrysler Corporation following passage of Congressional legislation last night for $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees.

title: Police Seize Men Holding 5 as Hostages in Manhattan
description: Two gunmen who had held five persons hostage for more than four hours in a Lower East Side drugstore surrendered early this morning. The suspects had been trapped by police officers who were responding to a report of a holdup in the store.

title: Arthur White, a Labor Dept. Aide
description: Arthur J. White, who servea as a regional director of the Federal Department of Labor in the New YorkNew Jersey area for nearly 15 years, died of a heart attack Thursday at the Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: Stocks Are Weaker; Precious Metals Up
description: After a twoday setback, preciousmetal stocks bounced back into favor yesterday amid lingering concern over the United States dollar and the fear of higher prices for imported oil. The general market turned progressively weaker, partly because it marked the final session for establishing regularway profits for 1979 incometax returns.

title: Airline Deregulation Is Working
description: WASHINGTON  After the United States airlines were deregulated last year, a record number of travelers saved $2.5 billion though lower fares, and the industry earned the highest profit in its 50year history.

title: Czechoslovakia Frees Dissidents Arrested During a Court Appeal
description: PRAGUE, Dec. 21 (Reuters)  The Czechoslovak authorities today released several dissidents who were arrested yesterday during an unsuccessful appeal by six human rights activists convicted of subversion, dissident sources said.

title: Dr. Shalala of H.U.D. Is Selected As President for Hunter College
description: After a 10month search that generated a bitter dispute, Hunter College got a new president yesterday.

title: Blast Near Taiwan's U.S. Office
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  An explosive device detonated today near the office of Taiwan's representatives in the United States, the police said. There were no reports of damage or injury. The blast occurred near the Bethesda, Md., office of the Coordinating Committee for North American Affairs, which has represented Taiwan's interests since the United States ended diplomatic relations.

title: Goldschmidt Cutting Number of Passengers At Airport at Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  Transportation Secretary Neil E. Goldschmidt today announced a plan to reduce the number of passengers at congested National Airport, which is just outside Washington.

title: Jersey Motorists Facing Increases In Car Insurance
description: To Pay Higher Premiums as They Renew Policies

title: Rhodesia Has Traveled Tortuous Road Since 1965 Revolt
description: The British Empire had nearly passed into history when the whites of Southern Rhodesia, one of its few remaining segments, resisted London's demand that majority rule be instituted and issued their unilateral declaration of independence on Nov. 11, 1965.

title: New Revue, Paris Lights, Is Based on 1920's Authors
description: Paris Lights: The All Star Literary Genius Expatriate Revue, a musical based on works by American authors living in Paris in the 1920's, will begin performances Jan. 13 at 3 P.M. at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street.

title: Events Today; Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Weill's Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonnv, 2:30, and Strauss's Der Rosenkavaller, 8.

title: G.M. Raises Car Prices By 2.8%
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21  The General Motors Corporation today announced an average increase of 2.8 percent, or $186, in the base price of its 1980 model passenger cars, effective Jan. 2.

title: Suspect Held on Stolen Securities
description: A Pennsylvania man who allegedly attempted to sell $5 million in stolen stocks and bonds to an undercover agent posing as a broker for unscrupulous businessmen has been seized by Federal authorities in New Jersey, bringing to light a threemonth investigation of black mar ket securities.

title: Autopsy in Boxer's Death Under State Investigation
description: The New York State Senate's Committee on Investigations has been looking into charges that tissue samples from an autopsy at the Medical Examiner's office in New York City were deliberately switched in an effort to embarrass Dr. Elliot M. Gross. Dr. Gross became Chief Medical Examiner this fall after years of controversy and power struggles in the office.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Boycotting Iran, Buying Time
description: Encouraging the Pope, the P.L.O. and others to intercede for the Teheran hostages bought a week. Moving the Security Council from a show of concern to a unanimous resolution bought three weeks more. Getting a ruling from the World Court was good for two. Demanding now that the United Nations impose economic sanctions against Iran should buy another week or two, and longer if they are put into place. President Carter is playing for time, from the American people, to avoid using force.

title: Evelyn fetter, Engineer And Inventor, 52, Dies
description: Evelyn Jetter, an RCA engineer who invented the automotive ignition transistor, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. She was 52 years old and lived in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: Stalin Made Mistakes, China Says On Birthday, but Was Great Man
description: PEKING, Dec. 21  How do the people in Stalin's hometown evaluate him 26 years after his death? What attitude do they take toward this great man who for more than 30 years led the Soviet people in traversing an arduous course?

title: Reduced Growth in E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 21 (AP)  Failure by the oil cartel to set new uniform prices threatens the European Economic Community with an end to economic growth and could force the nine Common Market countries to reduce their 1980 oilimport targets, Guido Brunner, European Energy Commissioner, said today.

title: Jury Acquits a Suspect Released Over Mistrial
description: Eric Michael, a suspect in a robbery and rape whose conviction was overturned in the state courts because of judicial misconduct, was acquitted yesterday of Federal charges brought to keep him behind bars.

title: Idzik, Offensive Coach, Ousted in Jets
description: Coach Walt Michaels's handling of the Jets quarterback situation created problems not only between him and Richard Todd and Matt Robinson but apparently also has resulted in the dismissal of John Idzik, the quarterback coach and chief architect of the team's potent offense.

title: SOVIET BUILDUP SEEN AT AFGHAN FRONTIER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  The Soviet Union has moved three army divisions to its border with Afghanistan and has recently sent at least 1,500 combat soldiers into the country, Carter Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. Olympic Six Triumphs
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 21 (UPI)  The United States Olympic hockey team defeated a Czechoslovak squad last night, 30, in the preOlympic tournament here.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on puge 21.

title: Dance: Irene Feigenheimei
description: Irene Feigenheimer is a familiar enough quantity on the New York dance scene, as a former member of the Anna Sokolow, Cliff Keuter and Don Redlich moderndance companies and a regular concertgiver here. She has an unusual presence, a sure and deftly offhanded sense of self, both as a performer and choreographer. And a program by her Dancemoves company on Thursday at the American Theater Laboratory, where the group will perform through Sunday, was one of the most quietly rewarding of the season.

title: Iran Freeze Is Upheld In France
description: PARIS, Dec. 21.  French courts refused today to make a United States bank repay a $50 million Iranian Government deposit frozen by President Carter in retaliation for the seizure of American hostages in Teheran. They also upheld the earlier sequestering of a valuable Iranian Government investment in a big international nuclear project.

title: DC10 Crash Laid to Jet's Maker, Airline and F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  The National Transportation Safety Board said today that a combination of improper maintenance and vulnerable design of key structures had led to the crash of a DC. It) jumbo jet in Chicago last May in which 273 persons were killed.

title: Canadiens Looking For Home Comforts
description: Claude Ruel, the Montreal Canadiens new coach, told club officials yesterday that his team had been uptight but that he expected its sixgame losing streak to end tonight at the Montreal Forum, where the Canadiens play their next four eames.

title: President Speeds Lifting Of Controls on Heavy Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 President Carter sought today to spur additional domestic production of petroleum by accelerating the lifting of price controls on heavy crude oil.

title: Grand Metropolitan Seeks Liggett Stock
description: MONTVALE, N.J., Dec. 21 (Reuters)  Liggett Group Inc. said today that Grand Metropolitan Ltd. had advised Liggett of plans to purchase additional Linea common stock.

title: Hepatitis Oysters in Florida
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21 (AP)  Oysters associated with 10 cases of hepatitis in Alabama and Georgia in November have been traced to Apalachicola Bay, Fla., the national Center for Disease Control said today. Medical investigators theorized that the contamination could have been caused by increased runoff associated with Hurricane Frederic in September.

title: California Drive Trying to Alter G.O.P. Primary
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21  In department stores and on street corners, some 2,000 Californians are collecting signatures this weekend in a race against time aimed at narrowing Ronald Reagan's chances of winning the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Theater: The Babes in Toyland
description: The Babes in Toyland, the holiday extravaganza for children now playing at the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden, is sunny and funny, an entertainment that is visually colorful and aurally pleasing, even with pre-recorded sound.

title: SERVICE FOR HOSTAGES
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered tonight that arrangements be made for clergymen to visit the occupied American Embassy over Christmas to hold services for the 50 hostages.

title: Celtics Top Spurs for 7th in Row
description: BOSTON, Dec 21 (UPI)  Larry Bird scored 26 points and grabbed 19 rebounds and M.L. Carr tossed in 12 secondquarter points to lead Boston to a 133119 triumph over the ailing San Antonio Spurs tonight. The victory was the Celtics seventh straight.

title: ExConvict Guilty of Bilking Union
description: A former convict who built a $20 million real estate empire before it collapsed in 1975 pleaded guilty yesterday to having bribed a New York City union official in an alleged scheme to obtain $3 million in loans from the union's welfare fund.

title: Philadelphia Subway Called Worst That Could Happen
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 Cynthia Brown and her friend Sharon Acree, laden with Christmas packages after fighting their way through a rush of pedestrians, faced a more crushing experience once they boarded the city's Broad Street Subway.

title: Notes on People
description: Thirtyone years ago last May in Paris, Garry Davis renounced his United States citizenship to become a citizen of the world, saying that the people of the globe were too intertwined to be artificially separated by national boundaries.

title: Mainichi Shimbun
description: REPORTED TO BE AILING: Leonid I. Brezhnev meeting with Japanese visitors Tuesday in Moscow. Atter the Soviet leader failed to appear yester- day at a luncheon for Angolan officials, Radio Moscow announced he was suf- fering from a cold. The disclosure, which a Western diplomat in Moscow called highly unusual, may have been made to avoid allegations that he was snubbing the Angolans or to preclude speculation about his health. Mr.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 28.

description: Even though Wagner's 22game winning streak in basketball is tempered by the fact that it encompasses only regularseason games, the Seahawks arrival as a local Division I power demands no qualification.

description: The Joyce Trisler Danscompany is performing at the new performingarts center of the EmanuEl Midtown Y.M.Y.W.H.A., at 344 East 14th Street, near First Avenue, presenting the company's 10 regular dancers and seven more dancers in Stravinsky's Sacre du Printemps.

title: U.S. Officials Expect Uphill Task In U.N. to Get Sanctions on Iran
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21 The United States faces an uphill task in its search for the needed nine votes on the Security Council to impose sanctions against Iran, diplomats here agreed today.

title: Southern Pacific Agrees to Amtrak Demand for Passenger Train Priority
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI)  The Southern Pacific Railroad agreed today to give Amtrak's New OrleansLos Angeles Sunset Limited priority over freight trains but said it had been doing so all along.

title: Stalin's Second Century
description: Yesterday the Communist world marked the centennial of Stalin's birth. Only in North Korea and Albania, where he remains in the official pantheon, was it an occasion for undiluted praise. But all Communist countries, including the prime victim of Stalin's terror  the Soviet Union  felt obliged to emphasize the nositive aspects of his record.

title: Soviet Nuclear Blast Reported
description: HAGFORS, Sweden, Dec. 21 (UPI) The Hagfors Observatory said today that it had registered seismic signals from a presumed nuclear explosion in the Soviet Union. The explosion, which registered 5.0 on the Richter scale, occurred in the Semipalatinsk region.

title: Ashe Looking Ahead
description: Arthur Ashe pulled open his powder blue pajama top, puffed up his chest and proudly exhibited the incision bisecting his upper body; then he rolled up his trousers to display scars running from knee to ankle.

title: 35 in Galveston Held on Charges Of Smuggling Marijuana Into U.S.
description: GALV ESTON, Tex., Dec. 21 (AP) Thirtyfive persons have been arraigned in Galveston on Federal charges of smuggling 50 tons of Colombian marijuana into the United States.

title: C.A.B. Permits Air Fare Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved across-the-board domestic air fare increases today of up to 3.3 percent, effective Jan. 1, because of higher fuel costs.

title: The City
description: Four construction workers on a platform 300 feet underground received minor injuries when a cable gave way and the platform fell in stages another 480 feet to the bottom of a water tunnel shaft at Columbus Avenue near 100th Street in Manhattan.

title: The Region
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I. Drivers and maintenance workers for the more than 300 publicly operated buses in Nassau County said yesterday that they would not work without a contract if a new one is not reached before the current one expires Dec. 31. They asked for a 30 percent increase in wages and benefits in each of the next two years.

title: Chanting Crowds on Decline at U.S. Embassy in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21 Perhaps it is because the days have become very chilly and the nights colder, or because Taleghani Street has been reopened to traffic or because the occupation of the American Embassy has been going on so long that it is no longer a novelty. Whatever the reason, the crowds in front of the sprawling diplomatic compound have become thinner in recent days.

title: Associated Press
description: PEKING, Dec. 21  A public ceremony consecrating a Roman Catholic Bishop of Peking was held today at Nantang Cathedral here in the most open display of official tolerance toward religious practice since the 1978 Constitution gave Chinese the right to believe or not to believe in religion.

title: PRICES ROSE BY 0.670 IN NEW YORK REGION
description: Consumer prices continued to rise in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area last month, reflecting higher costs for housing, transportation and medical care, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Labor Leader Names Assistant
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  Lane Kirkland, president of the American Fed eration of Labor and Congress of Indus trial Organizations, announced today that he had appointed the labor organization's legislative director, Kenneth Young, as his executive assistant.

description: Two men were found not guilty last night in a murder trial in Manhattan in which the judge had initially planned to have two juries hear the case simultaneously in the same courtroom.

description: QUEBEC, Dec. 21  The prospect for prolonged indecision over Quebec's political future is causing new concern in political and business circles after publication of the question the provincial government will put in a referendum next spring.

title: Barrier Is Set at Mississippi Site To Curb Agent Orange's Seepage
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  The Air Force and Navy said today that they would build barriers to prevent further seepage of a contaminating agent from a Mississippi base formerly used to store the defoliant Agent Orange.

title: Byrne Signs Bill to Raise Mortgage Interest Rates
description: TRENTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  Governor Byrne today signed a bill permitting higher home mortgage interest rates in New Jersey, even though President Carter may soon sign a Federal bill to lift all such state controls until March 31. the two bills are creating some uncer tainty in the banking and real estate industries, which have been stalled for months because of tight credit.

title: Dancers' Pact to Raise Cost of Tickets
description: The executive director of the American Ballet Theater said yesterday that the contract agreement reached this week after long negotiations with the dancers would mean a gradual increase in ticket prices and more and more and more fundraising.

title: The City Needs a Cop of the Block
description: Two hundred New York City police officers with an average of 11 years of police experience were asked to re- spond to this statement: The public supports the police. Eightyfour per- cent of these officers disagreed or stronely disagreed with that state- ment; only 7 percent agreed.

title: Telbele's Demon Feels Sure He Is Going to Be Famous
description: Intensity gripped him. Passion overtook him. F. Murray Abraham was firing off words in bursts. On Broadway, he said, the Method has been a disaster  no craft, no technique. I'm fed up with it. The only people who came to Stanislayski and were successful were the ones who had the craft in the first place. Mr. Abraham has opinions, some of which are absolute convictions. I believe I'm the best comic actor in the country, he said now, only slowly. He did not sound vainglorious; he sounded sure.

title: Tear Gas and Firebombs Disrupt Demonstration in Dutch Church
description: S HERTOGENBOSCH, the Netherlands, Dec. 21 (Reuters)  Gasoline bombs and teargas grenades were thrown into a Roman Catholic church here last night when 200 people gathered to demonstrate against the deployment of new nuclear missiles in Western Europe, the police said today.

title: Rhodesians Sign Peace After a 7Year War
description: LONDON, Dec. 21 The parties to the sevenyear Rhodesian civil war finally came together today and signed a pledge of peace.

title: British Governor Will Face Difficult Task in Putting the Accord into Effect
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 21  The only visible British activity here in recent days has been a Royal Air Force Hercules transport, a white cross on its camouflaged nose, practicing bush air-

title: November Consumer Index Rose 1% Despite Energy and Food Lag
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  Despite some slackening in the rise of food and energy prices, the Consumer Price Index increased 1 percent in November, continuing its 1979 climb of about 1 percent a month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Florence S. Klopfer Dead at 73; Wife of Random House Founder
description: Florence Selwyn Klopfer, the wife of Donald S. Klopfer, chairman emeritus and cofounder of Random House, the book publishers, died Thursday at her home in New York City after a long illness. Mrs. Klopfer, an active volunteer in maternity and child health care, was 73 years old.

title: Pullman Named In a Second Suit On Subway Cars
description: New York City and the Transit Authority yesterday brought a new $80 million lawsuit against Pullman Inc. and named as defendants four other companies involved in the production of 754 defective subway cars.

title: The Arm in the Subway Door
description: Problem: People have crowded into the subway car. The trainman, looking out his window at the platform, pulls a switch to close all doors. As he does so, a late arrival sticks his arm through one door. Rubber cushions prevent the arm from being crushed. Indeed, he could remove his arm. But he cannot get on the train because the door will not open. And the train cannot start until the doors are fully shut. Trainman can now open all doors and admit Late Arrival or wait for him to remove his arm. Waiting is common.

title: For Hunter College, a Long Search Is at an End
description: Donna E. Shalala, political scientist, feminist, Carter Administration housing official and better than average tennis player, was changing planes at the airport in Grand Forks, N.D., yesterday afternoon when she telephoned Woman in the News her secretary in Washington for messages.

title: Yields on Bills Off at Treasury
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and the 182day maturities.

title: Concert: Messiah
description: Musica Sacra's annual Messiah performances have for several years been considered the best in New york, and the installment Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall was the best Musica Sacra Messiah this writer has heard. It was played with sensitivity and even spirituality, it was sung superbly by the chorus, and the four vocal soloists all had their virtues. It was so good that the full 3 hours and 15 minutes between the first and last notes, counting one intermission, passed with remarkable swiftness.
