description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 21 (AP)  Topseeded Guillermo Vilas advanced to the semifinals of the $150,000 New South Wales open tennis tournament today by defeating a local favorite, Brad Drewett, 64, 61.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The preview schedule for Lillian Ilellman's Watch on the Rhine was reported incorrectly in Weekend yesterday. Previews start tonight at the Golden Theater.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1979

title: Gonna Help My Uncle Ted Be President?
description: DES MOINES, Dec. 19  The young man arrived in an expensive gray business suit and scuffed hiking boots, booming his special name out with the pride of dynasty.

title: Car Rustproofers at Crossroads
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21 The people who rustproof cars have been startled and worried by recent announcements of American automobile makers that anticorrosion warranties would be as standard as ignitions and door keys on 1980 cars.

title: Domestic Goals Prompted British Officials to Take Risks at Every Stage
description: News Analysis

title: U.S. Judge Warns He May Order ExAgent to Suppress C.I.A. File
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 21 A Federal district judge said today that if the Government intervened in a private lawsuit here, he would probably be willing to issue a broad secrecy order enjoining the plaintiff from divulging sensitive information that he obtained in 15 years of employment with the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Jazz: A Roy Eldridge Salute
description: The Salute to Roy Eldridge presented by Jack Kleinsinger's Highlights in Jazz at New York University's Loeb Auditorium on Thursday evening was an overstuffed Christmas stocking, flowing over with jazz goodies. In addition to Mr. Eldridge, those who took part in the tribute included Clark Terry, the fluegelhornist and singer; Slam Stewart, the humming bassist ; the singer Maxine Sullivan, and Panama Francis and his ninepiece band, the Savoy Sultans.

title: Aiello Asserts Board of Education Will Resist City Over Hiring Policy
description: Defying attempts by New York City to exert control over the school system's budget, the president of the Board of Education, Steven R. Aiello, said yesterday that it would oppose any such interference with its hiring procedures. in a letter to mayor Kocn ana Lomptroller Harrison J. Goldin that was made public yesterday, Mr. Aiello said: The board agrees that it should not and will not hire people for whom it does not have appropriately budgeted money. The Board of Education cannot agree to interference by the Office of Management and Budget in the hiring of either pedagogical or nonpedagogical personnel.

title: Clark's Plan to Privatize PetroCanada Criticized
description: TORONTO, Dec. 21  Opposition po!itical parties criticized Prime Minister Joe Clark today for his announced plans to sell off or give away a majority of shares in PetroCanada, this country's national oil company.

title: Japan Sets Bigger Cut in Fuel Consumption
description: TOKYO, Dec. 21  Alarmed by the prospect of higher costs for imported oil, the Japanese Government initiated steps today to reduce the country's fuel consumption by 7 percent next year instead of the previously planned 5 percent cut.

title: Sports Today
description: Pace at C.W. Post, 8 P.M. (Radio  WCWP, 8 P.M.; at Fairleigh Dickinson, 2 P.M. (Radio  WFDU, 2 P.M.); St. Bonaventure at St. Francis, 8 P.M.; Fordham at Manhattan, 2 P.M. (Radio  WFUV, 2 P.M.); Villanova at Rutgers, 8 P.M. (Radio WRSUFM, 7:56 P.M., Wagner at College of Staten Island, 8:30 P.M.; York at Adelphi, 8 P.M.

title: Draths
description: ARNOLDNewton S. Suddenly on Dec. 16, 1979. Beloved husband of Irene; dear brother of Allene Daube, Genevieve Wetmore, Tex Arnold. Services Sunday, Dec 23, 9:30AM at Gutterman's, 331 Amsterdam Ave at 76th St. Friends may visit at Gutterman's Sat. from 7.9PM.

title: OPEC Chief Favors Price Unity
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 21The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, troubled by disagreement on a pricing structure, has come under the presidency of a leading proponent of price unity and a strong exponent of heavy OPEC aid to third-world countries.

title: A Spark of Hope for Troubled Students
description: Milling students exchanging noisy season's greetings filled the corridors at Julia Richman High School in Manhattan yesterday, the last day before Christmas vacation. But in one small room on the fourth floor, students seated in a circle that forged a barrier against external distractions continued to work.

title: Lopez Will Defend Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (AP) Danny (Little Red) Lopez, the World Boxing Council featherweight champion, will defend his title in Phoenix, Ariz., on Feb. 2 against the No. 1 challenger, Salvador Sanchez of Mexico (.'it y.

title: Officials Disagree on Cost Of Order to Aid Disabled
description: Jose Perez cannot hear or speak, is afflicted with cerebral palsy and for the first 16 years of his life he did not attend school.

title: White House Studying Homosexuals
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  The Carter Administration is telling homosexual activists that it is willing to consider charges of Federal discrimination against homosexuals but feels most situations are covered by existing law.

title: Kinney Set to Buy A Las Vegas Hotel
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 21 (AP) - The National Kinney Corporation announced today that it had reached an oral agreement in principle to buy the Aladdin Hotel for $105 million and would rename it Johnny Carson's Aladdin.

title: Strike Closes Spanish Ports
description: MADRID, Dec. 21 (UPI)  Some 13,500 Spanish longshoremen staged a oneday strike today that shut ports from the Canary Islands to the Basque country. The strike was called to back demands that their union be recognized as the representa live of all dock workers.

title: Gov. Brown Says Carter Is Politicizing
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 21  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, in the strongest criticism to date by a prominent politician of President Carter's handling of the Iranian situation, accused the President tonight of politicizing what ought to be a statesmanlike effort.

title: William Spaulding, 81, Is Dead; ExPresident of Houghton Mifflin
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  William E. Spaulding, who rose from salesman to be president and chairman of the Houghton Mifflin Company, died yesterday at the New England Rehabilitation Center in Woburn. He was 81 years old.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday Weather at 1 P M National Oceanic and Almosphem Adnaniseation UP

title: National Steel Signs Ship Contract
description: The National Steel and Shipbuilding Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of MorrisonKnudsen Inc., said it had signed a contract valued at about $239 million for the construction of up to five productscarrier vessels for American Tankships Inc. American Tankships is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Ingram Corporation.

title: McGinnis Is Given Ban Stay
description: George McGinnis's 10day suspension, on a charge that he deliberately knocked Referee Jess Kersey to the floor during a game last Sunday night, was stayed yesterday by Larry O'Brien until a hearing is held next Thursday afternoon.

title: Your Money
description: Deborah Rankin

title: Panamanians Opposed to Shah Battle Guard Anew
description: PANAMA CITY, Dec. 21  Leftist students opposed to the presence of the deposed Shah of Iran in Panama clashed with National Guardsmen again today, while an opposition coalition charged that the country's strongman, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, had ignored public opinion in allowing the Shah to come here.

title: Inflation Affects Christmas Trees, Too
description: For 25 years Charlie Whitey has been selling Christmas trees to retailers and the public at the Brooklyn Terminal. His sevenfoot Scotch pines from Michigan and Nova Scotia balsam fetched $12 to $15 a decade ago. This year they sell for $25 to $30. Douglas firs, imported from Oregon, are the Cadillacs of Christmas trees. They can be had for $45 each. In 1970 they were not even available in the East.

title: A Class on L.I. Helps Neediest For Tenth Year
description: A letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reads: Stop! Hold Everything! Rent-a-Pen has done it again!

title: About New York
description: There is a touch of class to the Boys Brotherhood Republic that radiates not only from the building in which it stands on East Sixth Street, near Avenue D, but also from the boys for whom it stands. It is all refreshingly cleancut, building and boys; and street wise, with smirk and swagger, is not an adtective that prevails here.

title: Performance Art: Pat Oleszko
description: Anyone in search of holiday festivity somewhat out of the ordinary would be advised to visit the Kitchen until Jan. 5, from 1 to 6 P.M., for an exhibition of Pat Oleszko's art work, and more especially to check out the last of Miss Oleszko's live peformances there, tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: Singer Completes Credit Arrangement
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 21 (Reuters)  The Singer Company said today that it had completed arrangements for a new $250 million, threeyear revolving credit facility with a group of 20 banks.

description: A Longtime McGraw-Hill Executive and the Author of Two Novels

title: SCHOOLS IN CHICAGO PAYLESS ON PAYDAY
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 21  The insolvent Chicago school board was unable to pay its 50,000 employees today and its officials held out the possibility that the schools might not be able to afford to reopen after the Christmas recess ends Jan. 2.

title: Associated Press
description: ISRAELIS PATROL IN BETHLEHEM: Soldiers outside the Church of the Nativity. Yesterday, a small group of prominent Arabs attempted to meet at a mosque in Deir el Hatab in the West Bank to protest against the construc- tion of Israeli settlements. They were halted by such a pa- trol and chose to hold prayers on a nearby rocky hill.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Charter Company announced yesterday that it planned to make an offer to acquire the ERC Corporation, an insurance holding company, in a transaction valued at about $547.8 million.

title: Citibank Attaches Iran's Krupp Share
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Dec. 21 (AP)  Citibank has obtained an attachment of Iran's 25 percent interest in Fried. Krupp G.m.b.H., parent of the diversified West German industrial concern, a Krupp spokesman said today.

title: At Dance Audition For Youngsters, PresenceCounts
description: There was typical school corridor bedlam: strident young voices all talking at once. Some pushing. Even a little punching. But the tall, theatrical-looking young man was having none of that. He wore a loose white cotton shirt and pants and cowboy boots and had a shock of mobile black hair. And when he spoke, they listened.

title: Styrofoam To the Aid Of Plants
description: Those weightless Styrofoam peanuts, which often arrive as packing around Christmas gifts, are great for protecting breakables. But gardeners have yet a better idea save them until spring to use as a drainage layer in the bottoms of patio tubs and planters.

title: Christmas Shopping in Wonderland of New York
description: Bill Cunningham

title: OBSERVER A Case For Dickens
description: Give me a December twilight in a glittering city, a fine dusty snow sifting down on bustling crowds, the tinkle of bells in the air. Rosy cheeks, merry laughter, jolly greetings friend to friend.

title: 2 Women's Fives Fold
description: The 19team Women's Basketball League, midway through its second season, announced yesterday that the Washington Metros and the Philadelphia Fox franchises had folded because of insufficient funds.

title: Miles Donis, 43, Writer And Movie Ad Director
description: Miles Donis, a novelist, screenwriter and former advertising director for Columbia Pictures in New York, died Thursday in a Burbank, Calif., hospital: he was struck by a car Sunday near his home in Hollywood. He was 43 years old.

title: U.S. Urged to Lead Drive to Control Fluorocarbons
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  Warning of a growing threat to human health and to the earth's food supply, the National Academy of Sciences today called on the United States to organize and lead a worldwide effort to control fluorocarbons, chemicals that deplete the ozone.

title: New Mexico U. Beginning A 3d Athletic investigation
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 21 (UPI)  Another investigation began today at the University of New Mexico, this one by the university's athletic advisory council.

title: The Nikolais Way Of Dancing
description: Alwin Nikolais was born in Southington, Conn., and the Nikolais Dance Theatre, which will begin a twoweek season at City Center on Thursday, is based in New York. But for the past decade, the tenmember company  known for multimedia productions in which the dancing is transformed by lavish theatrical effects  has done a majority of its performing abroad, making successful tours throughout Europe, the Middle East, South America and Asia. Mr. Nikolais dates his group's international reputation from a 1968 appearance at the Paris International Dance Festival.

title: New Goals Set for Rail Service
description: STATE officials hope to spend a further $265 million over the next four to seven years to improve rail service in Connecticut, but their immediate fiscal plans center on a 10 percent fare increase early next year.

title: Susan Amy Powell Wed To Michael Jeffrey Gold
description: Susan Amy Powell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell M. Powell of Great Neck, L.I., was married there yesterday in Temple Israel to Michael Jeffrey Gold, son of Barbara Naiditch of Baltimore and the late Joseph A. Gold. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: Practical Traveler: European Weekends
description: Of all the places one can spend a weekend this winter, how about Europe? It will not be cheap, but little in Europe is these days.

title: ART A Sensual and Enigmatic World
description: SOUTHAMPTON ENGLISHBORN Mary Frank comes from a humanistic school of sculptural expression that counts Elisabeth Frink and Reg Butler among its most vener- able representatives. Miss Frank is both younger and more vital than most of this group. Clay, rather than bronze or stone, is her major medium, and she handles it with a grace and assurance that owes as much to the mastery of drawing as to facility with three-dimensional forms.

title: Deaths
description: ACKERMANNathan, on December 20th. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Arline Lazarus and Ronnie. FatherInlaw of Brian. Most loving grandfather of David. Brother of Sylvia Nurko and Beatrice Streit.

title: Paterson Eases Patients
description: PATERSON WHEN Mark Blumenkehl was a baby, he was ill and, to pay the doctor bills, his family spent everything it had. I was always in hock, his mother, Doris Blumenkehl, recalled the other day. My husband had to work day and night. I know what it is to pay medical bills. I knew it when I had to take a halfpound of chopped meat and make a meal for three.

description: Oaths, Plain and Fancy . . . G.O.P. on a Diet

title: Concert: Chamber Series
description: Chamber Music at the 92d Street has proved so successful over the last two years that three extra concerts have been scheduled this season to handle the overflow crowds. On Thursday night, the first of the new miniseries took place, and it featured two spacious works by Brahms, the Quintet for Clarinet and Strings in B minor (Op. 115) and the Quartet for Piano and Strings in G minor (Op. 25).

title: Conservationist Faults U.S. Plan to Save Condor
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 22  A conservationist has charged that Government efforts to save the California condor from extinction may do more to harm the huge birds than to help them.

title: Kim Ayvazian Fiance of William Ullman
description: Dr. and Mrs. John H. Ayvazian of New York and Lakeville, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kim Ellen Ayvazian, to William John Ullman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ullman of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Dance: Tucovic Ensemble of Belgrade
description: The Dimitrije Tucovic Ensemble of Belgrade, which appeared with a Yugoslav children's troupe at Carnegie Hall Friday night, looks like a perfectly good folk dance ensemble until one remembers the Yugoslav folk troupes of 20 years ago.

title: ART Photographs of Peru Go Beyond Instruction
description: ANTHROPOLOGY may have its heart in the right place, but it's disturbing the way it is visited by the rich cultures on the poor, by the civilized on the supposedly less so  all of course in the name of salvation. An anthropological mu- seum is a place where one hopes to see (but hasn't so far) dioramas about modern man and his rituals (like charring food in his backyard, for instance) as well as interpretations of old-fashioned man's customs.

title: President Gives Final Approval To Pan Am and National Merger
description: President Carter yesterday gave final approval to the merger of Pan American World Airways and National Airlines into a single entity that will be the nation's fourthlargest air carrier.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: CAR POOL is a noun and sometimes a bad verb, as in Harold has decided to carpool. But, grammar aside, the word is always transitive and usually denotes discomfort.

description: BY ORDER of the United States Government, all sludgedumping in the Atlantic Ocean must cease on Dec. 31, 1980. it is a virtual certainty that it will not.

title: Sylvia Wyman Sets Wedding To Prosecutor
description: The engagement of Dr. Sylvia Cheney Wyman to Thomas McKean has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Wyman Jr. of Brookline, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Quincy Adams Shaw McKean of South Hamilton, Mass., and Pinehurst, N.C., and the late Mr. McKean.

title: Hilary Ryan Is Fiance Of Adam Gregory Norton
description: Mrs. Paul McGrath of New York and Edmon Ryan of Anchorage, Ky., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Shelton Ryan, to Adam Gregory Norton, son of Lord and Lady Rathcreedan of Henley-onThames, England.

title: Times Square's Potential Inspires the Developers
description: Several builders are proposing to develop mammoth complexes about Times Square if the city exercises its urban renewal condemnation powers to acquire sites for the development.

title: GARDENING Deck the Halls and Dream
description: TO the druids, holly was a symbol of the return of spring, and its evergreen boughs laden with red berries were used in their winter solstice celebrations. Christians first considered it to be unholy because of its association with such pagan rites, but they eventually adopted it as a part of their own religious festiVities. One legend arose that described Christ's crown of thorns as having been made from twigs of prickly holly.

title: Rapid Deployment Force, Indian Ocean Buildup Are First Steps
description: WASHINGTON  As the crisis over the hostages in Iran drags on, the Carter Administration is gradually being forced to address perhaps the most significant strategic question in over a decade: whether spreading political turbulence and Soviet advances in the Persian Gulf require new American military responsibilities in the region.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: WHEN New Jersey's voters were being asked to approve a constitutional amendment to allow casino gambling in Atlantic City, Governor Byrne and the Legislature made a lot of promises.

title: Broncos Tackle Campbell
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 22  The defensive players of the Denver Broncos, a distinguished bunch that was No. 1 in the National Football League at stopping running plays this season, will meet Earl Campbell, No. 1 in rushing, for the first time here tomorrow in the Astrodome.

title: Frank Clifford Ingriselli Fianc of Mary Tursone
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Tursone of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Long Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Tursone, to Frank Clifford Ingriselli, son of Constance Ingriselli of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Frank Ingriselli. A wedding is planned next summer.

title: The 68th Appeal
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was established in 1912 by the late Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The Times. That year, 117 contributors donated a total of $3,630.88 to be distributed among three private socialservice agencies.

title: Nonprofit Groups Find Rent Rates Uncharitable
description: The Foreign Policy Association moved from the United Nations neighborhood to the furniture district. The March of Dimes moved to Westchester County. The Council on Hemispheric Affairs decided to stay in the Western Hemisphere, but head for Washington. The American Civil Liberties Union bought its own building near Times Square.

title: Rangers, Down by Two, Beat Penguins, 43
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22  The New York Rangers helped the Pittsburgh Penguins break their recent habit for ties tonight in a National Hockey League game at the Civic Arena, as New York wiped out a twogoal deficit and beat the Penguins. 43.

description: For people seeking a dog for showing, protective purposes, hunting, or just as a pet, some good advice is offered in a variety of books on the current publishers' lists. There is even howto book on grooming.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Kandel of New Rochelle, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Cyd Kandel, to James William Carroll, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Carroll of Stamford, Conn.

title: Headliners
description: The Shah of Iran's friend at the Chase is phasing himself out. David Rockefeller announced last week that he would retire as chief executive officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank and its parent, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, on Jan. Mr. Rockefeller will continue as chairman of both until the annual meeting in April, and will be succeeded in both positions by Willard C. Butcher, currently president of both organizations. Mr. Rockefeller said he would like to devote more time to the affairs of the Rockefeller family (which may not be different from running the Chase after all) and more time for projects to benefit New York City.

Services Monday, December 24th 10am at the Riverside 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Please omit flowers.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH the fallwinter weather has been fairly mild so far this year, there is little doubt that in the near future the usual deep freeze will set in, with temperatures dropping below freezing and staying there. And, if the last two or three winters are any indication, long stretches of belowfreezing weather will mean that some home- owners will be caught by surprise when unprotected pipes that pass through un- heated areas or cold outside walls freeze up.

description: HONG KONG, Dec. 22 (Reuters)  Vietnam accused Thailand today of acting in collusion with China to aid the remnants of the Cambodian forces of the denosed Prime Minister, Pol Pot.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Romer Shoal Dredging Fought
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority wants two million cubic yards of sand from an area on or adjoining outer New York Harbor's Romer Shoal, and there are many people who bitterly oppose this.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Avital Shcharansky wanders from country to country in the West, hoping that her presence and quiet passion will bring attention and deliverance to her husband, Anatoly, the im- prisoned Soviet dissident. She emigrated to Israel in July 1974, the day after her marriage in Moscow, believing that her husband would soon follow. But his visa was denied, and trumpedup charges landed him in jail last year. As he was sentenced, he said to his wife and the court, Next year in Jerusalem.

title: Centuries of Historic Tradition Trim the Christmas Tree
description: This year especially, a spirit of hope centers around the Christmas tree. The festive lights send out messages of glad tidings and decorative trimmings recall happy traditions of times past.

title: Keepsakes and Valentines
description: HISTORY has not been kind to Sara Teasdaie. You will not find her poems in the Norton An- thology of Modern Poetry, the Oxford Book of American Verse or the Mentor Book of Major Ameri- can Poets. But in the teens and the 1920's, her rhymed lyrics of love and loss were hugely popular -her vol- umes were Keepsakes and valentines, the coed's un- failing companion, and the Bible of every disap- pointed lover, as her friend Louis Untermeyer envi- ously noted in his memoirs - and she was respected by critics and fellow poets. She won a Pulitzer Prize and saw a book of her verse on the best seller list, a feat no poet today is likely to duplicate.

title: Michigan Again Draws Largest Football Crowds
description: MISSION, Kan., Dec. 22 (AP)  The University of Michigan, running its streak of 100,000plus crowds to 29 in 1979, led the nation in college football attendance for the sixth straight year, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Libya Cuts P.L.O. Tie In Dispute, Returning Its Material Unopened
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22  Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, has stopped dealing on an official level with the Palestine Liberation Organization and has instructed his Government and political party offices to return, unopened, any documents and communica- tions bearing the seal of the guerrilla movement, the Palestinian press service reported yesterday.

title: Senate's Oil Sheiks Have Own Cartel
description: WASHINGTON  As energy becomes a household word, the acronyms linked to it are beginning cling to the mind of the crisisminded citizen. MEOW Mix, one might remember, was once the do-it-all energy package  President Carter's Moral Equivalent Of War. OPEC, of course, needs little explanation. AGA, however, does not refer to principal sheik in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, but rather to the American Gas Association, the hospitality of whose members is equally legendary.

title: Spirit of a Swedish Christmas Lights Up Homes
description: AT Thanksgiving, Connie and Gunnar Eng of Darien and their family sit down to an Americanstyle roast turkey with all the trimmings. But come Christmas and the Engs, like many other Americans of Swedish descent, revert to the customs of the old country, holding an open house for their friends, serving glcigg, hot spiced wine, and on Christmas Eve offering the typical Jul smorgasbord for 10 to 20 family members. Then on Christmas Day there is the traditional julotta, a 6 A.M. service in Swedish.

title: Flyers' Streak No. 6 in Sports

Outdoors, landscaping twinkles with colored lights, and  when nature cooperates  the first wtute drifts of snow glisten in the moonlight. Indoors, sparkling holiday ornaments and party decorations cheerily reflect the warm glow from the fireplace, candles and Christmastree lights.

title: Penn St. Conquers Tulane

title: Food

These dishes, also known as en casserole, are hearty fare for winter menus.

Out of a florist truck on Park Avenue hurries Larry Rawl with a balsam wreath slung over his shoulder. Everywhere, swags of greens and holly boughs roll by in supermarket carts, on hand trucks, by bicycle. And a cab driver who stops for a fare at Rockefeller Center says: Just slide the poinsettia over, lady.

title: Dance: Ailey Butterfly
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater reveled in ambiguity last Tuesday night at the City Center55th Street Theater by offering the season's first performances of two curious works. Usually, clarity is extolled in dance. Yet ambiguity can also be a virtue, for an ambiguous dance is not necessarily the same as a merely vague or obscure dance. If its choreography is genuinely capable of having multiple meanings that enhance one another, then an ambiguous dance can be rich indeed.

title: CRIME
description: You can't say that PRIVATE SECTOR by Jeff Millar (Dial, $9.95) doesn't part with a bang. There is a hijacked truck, the deliberate destruction of an encite small town, a suicide squad and a big question mark. Then we switch to a pair of lovers. She is an investigative reporter for The New York Times. He is a television anchorman slated to replace Walter Cronkite. They work independently on sto- ries, never exchanging notes or ideas. That way they preserve their integrity. So they begin to dig into a big story, each going an independent way, and even- tually, of course, their paths cross.

title: Deck the Halls and Dream
description: TO the druids, holly was a symbol of the return of spring, and its evergreen boughs laden with red berries were used in their winter solstice celebrations. Christians first considered it to be un- holy because of its association with such pagan rites, but they eventually adopted it as a part of their own religious festivities. One legend arose that described Christ's crown of thorns as having been made from twigs of prickly holly.

title: On an Athlete Quitting Young and Facing His Future
description: FINISH what you started, never quit in the middle, self control. Those were key words in my life, and lying in the greentiled operating room in Baltimore's Children's Hospital, Sept. 29, 1978, I was losing control. The countdown had begun, the anesthesiologist had given the shot ; there were 10 seconds left in the game, and no more time outs. I was about to undergo spinal surgery that would end my career with the Baltimore Colts and begin a new life.

In the centre of the window was a Christmas tree with silver needles, and decorated with baubles of mint lumps and wine gums. It had been raining since morning, but the day had turned cold and the raindrops had frozen on the shop window, coating it with crystal pebbles that crazed the light and made it merrier.

description: Marge Harrison is opening a Pandora's box of problems when she advocates the takeover of Lilco [Opinion Page, Dec. 9]. Lilco stockholders have just been informed that part of their latest dividend comes from Lilco's capital and not from earnings. Second, obfuscating over the term public utility does nothing to inform readers. The complete term investorowned public utility fully describes Lilco.

title: Motion Sickness: Why It Happens, How Sufferers May Be Helped
description: On a pleasant day last summer Dr. Rolf Ulvestad and some friends were touring country roads, dipping and swaying and occasionally bouncing over surfaces only a rollercoaster fan could love. Dr. Ulvestad was riding in the back of the vehicle, one of those station wagons in which passengers sit sideways and cannot really see where they are going and the world rushes past like a fast camera pan. Suddenly Dr. Ulvestad did not feel very well. He was, and is, a perfectly healthy 32-year-old. In fact, he is an otolaryngologist, a physician for the ear, nose and throat and his specialty is the study of motion sickness.

title: Lure of Jobs Outweighs Discrimination and Victimization
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Celestino Rojas left the harsh climate and perpetual poverty of the Colombian Ilanos three years ago looking for El Dorado. Like millions of his countrymen, he hoped to find job in Venezuela's booming oil economy. Since I've been here, he said, I've been arrested seven times, deported three times and cheated out of almost year's pay. The authorities treat me like dirt. But at least I can work.

title: MUSIC Still 2 for the Holiday
description: MOST of Westchester's holiday concerts have al. ready come and gone, but for members of the last- minute brigade, there are still two events that can add a musical glow to this last Sunday before Christmas. The first is the joyous festival of lessons and carols, a fusing of Bible readings and diverse yuletide pieces that has become a cherished tradition at Kings College in Cambridge, England. The American edition of this ceremony begins at 11 this morning at the North Yonkers Community Church in Hastings-on-Hudson. A handbell choir will provide an instrumental prelude, after which the more vocal parish choir will be joined for the festival itself by the soloists Margaret Geard, Josephine Wasson, Ron Neff and John Tiebout, assisted by D. DeWitt Wasson, the organist. You can expect to join in some congregational caroling along the way, incidentally, and the chorus is planning an interesting assortment of holiday music by Bach, Mendelssohn, Honegger and others.

title: Kentucky Triumphs Over Purdue, 61 to 60
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP)Kyle Macy's clutch shooting put Kentucky ahead to stay and Fred Cowan added the eventual winning points on free throws tonight as Kentucky defeated Purdue, 6160, in the final of the 27th University of Kentucky invitation college basketball tournament.

title: Lori L. Jaffe and Mark Brous Will Be Married on Aug. 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jaffe of Middletown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Lynn Jaffe, to Mark David Brous, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Brous, also of Middletown. The wedding is planned on Aug. 24.

title: New Comedy at Henry Street
description: Friends, a fourcharacter comedy about two enduring marriages, will open at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater at the settlement's Arts for Living Center, at 466 Grand Street, on Jan. 10 and will run, Thursdays to Sundays, through Jan. 27.

title: The Geek of Poetry
description: THE same light that had played over the stones in his hand began to play aver his mind. . . The revolution within had really begun. A new declaration of independence wrote itself within him. The gods have thrown the towns like stones over the flat country, but the stones have no color. They do not burn and change in the light, he thought.

title: Miss Horvath Gains Final In Orange Bowl Tennis
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla. (UPI)  Pablo Arraya of Peru and Rual Viver of Ecuador made it an allSouth American final in the Orange Bowl 18-andunder junior tennis tournament today with straightset victories.

title: Backgammon:
description: Eschew the Obvious to Force Miss Muffet off That Tuffet

title: An End to the Committee Approach at Chase
description: For 33 years the Rockefeller name has been synonomous with the Chase Manhattan Bank, lending the institution both prestige and stability. Last week, David Rockefeller, the bank's 64yearold chairman, announced that he was stepping aside as chief executive officer Jan. 1, although he would retain his chairmanship until April 1981.

title: STAMPS
description: SAMUEL A. TOWER

title: United Press International
description: FOUR KILLED AS PLANE CRASHES IN FLORIDA LAKE: A helicopter lifting the wreckage of a small twinengine plane that crashed into a lake yesterday in downtown Orlando, killing four persons on the plane. In a 24hour period Friday and Saturday, 11 crashes of light planes in seven states killed 23 persons. Poor visibility because of fog was blamed in several of the mishaps.

title: Naming Names
description: Whatever Christmas may stand for in other places, it is the season in Manhattan apartment houses for shedding anonymity. The season begins, around the middle of December, when the newspaper appears on the doorstep with an unaddressed and unsealed envelope. Inside, there is a card with the picture of an old English coach on it. And inside the card, there is a message of good will from the newsboys, Carl and Andy.

title: The Piles of Grain Grow Bigger While Railroads Rot
description: When Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland on Thursday concluded a month of talks with farmers on farm policy, found unanimous agreement on only one issue the Federal Government should do something right now about the rural transportation system.

title: Long Island This Week
description: ART

title: Democrats Hedge On Taking Sides For Presidency
description: LONG Island Democrats, like their colleagues throughout the state, are splitting over the Democratic Presidential nomination, but Democratic public officials are for the most part remaining on the fence.

title: A Group of Notable Books Illuminating Collectibles
description: Collectibles of whatever age and category are booming in popularity these days. But the most sought after of all, judging by the large number of books on the subject, date from the late 19th century to World War H. Many are little more than glossy catalogues offering little or no esthetic or historical evaluation of the material covered. But others are far more than picture books of what the fashionable collect. The following are among the more notable volumes published recently.

title: Pfister Beats Vilas, 76, 75
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 22 (AP)Hank Pfister of Bakersfield, Calif., upset topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 76, 75, today and reached the final of the $150,000 New South Wales open tennis tournament.

title: In Spirit of Christmas Past
description: I love to see this day well kept by rich and poor; it is a great thing to have one day in the year, at least, when you are sure of being welcome wherever you go, and of having, as it were, the world all thrown open to you.

title: Involvement Is Key to Programs
description: At a time when the conditions of life seem to rob us of hope, it is easy to turn away from the problems of others. But to do so, to live for ourselves alone, is the ultimate defeat. Not only are we ac- cepting conditions that make living a tragedy for many, but we are also all inexorably caught up in what happens around us. In fact, we cannot isolate ourselves.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: ED REITER

title: NuclearSafety Aide Dreams of Space
description: LONG ISLANDERS

title: Kennedy Seems to Lead in New Hampshire
description: NASHUA, N.H., Dec. 22  With the New Hampshire primary campaign going into hibernation for the holidays, Edward M. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan appear to be leading in the race to perpetuate the legend that victory here is a prerequisite to winning the White House.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GHRISTMAS activities with tha family may be augmented activities with the family may augmented this week by taking advantage special programs at minimal cost designed not only for the season, but also for coping with children home from school. The following are a few items gleaned from the schedules of theaters, movie houses, galleries and museums. A longer listing appears on Page 12.

title: Defects Found in Locomotives
description: WHITE PLAINS THREE locomotives, the first of seven being extensively rebuilt with state bond money, have developed new mechanical defects since their return to service on Conrail's commuter lines.

title: Tis the Season to Defend It
description: OUR friend The College Student settles into my kitchen on Sunday afternoons, smashing Brazil nuts and trying to save me from myself. Although he feels it is all right for me to occupy space on this planet, my head is stuffed with gar-

title: Education Commissioner Named
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)  President Carter has nominated William Lee Smith as Commissioner of Education, a job that will be abolished next year when the new cabinetlevel Department of Education is established. Mr. Smith, now director of the Teacher Corps at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, would succeed Ernest Boyer, who resigned.

title: EXTORTION SUSPECT HELD IN CHINATOWN
description: Cooperation by Restaurant Owner Is Cited by Police in Arrest of Alleged Gang Member

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)  Peak electricity demand, which had been expected to rise as much as 7 percent this year, came to a virtual standstill during the summer.

title: Editors' Choice
description: DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Golding. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A magic fable that explores the darkness of human nature through the fortunes of Matty, brushed by fire as a boy during a World War II blitz, and of numerous people he later encounters in Britain and Australia.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P M National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration UPI

title: Judith Pollard to Be May Bride
description: Judith Pollard, an account executive with Johnson & Higgins of Massachusetts Inc., an insurance concern in Boston, and Murray Snell Danforth 3d, a financial investor in Boston and son of Mr. and Mrs. Danforth Jr. of Providence, R.I., plan to be married next May.

title: The Arrival Last Week of Iranian Volunteers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  After showing the world statesmanlike profile by trying, unsuccessfully, to gain the release of American hostages in Teheran, Yasir Arafat was less than elated last week when Iranian volunteers threatened to tar his Palestine Liberation Organization with the brush of their Ayatollah's radicalism.

title: Two Employees Slain At an East Side Disco In Apparent Robbery
description: A bookkeeper and a handyman were found shot to death yesterday after an ap- parent robbery attempt at a discotheque on Manhattan's East Side, the police said.

title: Sidney Blauner, Who Founded Dress House; A Leader in the Field
description: Sidney Blauner, a longtime leader in the apparel field who founded Susy Perette, the dress house, in 1928, died Friday after a long illness at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Blauner, who lived in Manhattan, was 74 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails; Outgoing
description: SAILING TODAY

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: MAMARONECK HROUGHOUT the holiday sea- son, one should arrive in this village at dusk. Then, natural and artificial light seem frozen in perfect balance, and the red, green, gold and blue lights strung high above the streets stud the lavender sky like iewels in a smooth enamel surface.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: SCAVENGER HUNTCloris Leachman puckers up to a horn in a winner-take-all chase among 15 heirs to an eccentric millionaire's estate. The film, directed by Michael Schultz, opens Tuesday at local theaters.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: MASS MARKET

title: Theater: `Big Issues Examined
description: It is a frequent complaint that the theater today often fails to address the greater issues of life, that new playwrights tend to opt for the wellturned phrase and the entertaining vignette in lieu of more significant matters. Cer- tautly Alexander Francis Horn's Sharon Shashanovah, currently playing at the 78th Street Theater Lab, cannot be accused of triviality; all the big questions about Identity and Love and Art are at stake here. But though one applauds Mr. Horn's ambition, his handling of these themes remains so ponderous, so relentlessly self-important that one is also left longing for phrase or vignette that might supply bit of needed relief.

title: Realty News More Houses Now Qualify For Warranty
description: Realty News More Houses Now Qualify For Warranty

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11 A.M. (2) Newsmakers: Barry Feinstein, chairman of the New York State Public Employee Conference.

title: SEYCHELLES FINDING LETHARGY AN ENEMY.
description: VICTORIA, Seychelles, Dec. 18 Everything about these lovely, mossand fernbacked Indian Ocean islands suggests lethargy, and that, putting it bluntly, has for most of the two-anda-half-year a-half-year administration of President France Albert Rene been the Government's only consequential enemy.

title: Geraldine Thomas Plans a June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. G. Brooks Thomas of Roland Park, Baltimore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Geraldine Brooks Thomas, to Charles Carroll 9th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll 3d of Ruxton, Md. A wedding is planned in June.

title: Fordham Conquers Manhattan
description: TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 22  Marvin Wiggins, a 6-foot-2 freshman guard, hit a 20foot jump shot with 38 seconds left today to lift Fairleigh Dickinson University to a 7069 victory over Long Island University.

title: Society No Longer Believes Anything Is Nobody's Fault
description: CINCINNATI  A rotting dam in Buffalo Creek, W. Va., collapses and the racing flood waters sweep dozens people to their deaths. A posh supper club in Kentucky turns inferno, taking the lives of more than 150. Thousands of rock fans push and shove their way into a Cincinnati coliseum, crushing 11 youngsters.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: N EW Rochelle is a city that's really a village, said its Mayor, Vincent R. Rippa. It's a city with all the bigcity problems, but then it's a village where everybody knows everybody else's business.

title: Lines at Polish Shops Turn Holiday Rush Into a Wait
description: WARSAW, Dec. 22  A shopper waiting in a long meat line is driven beyond endurance. He stalks off, announcing to a friend that he is going to find the official responsible for Poland's economic problems and assassinate him. Several hours later he returns, crestfallen.

title: Montgomery, Payton: Their Runs Say It All
description: WALTER Payton stopped talking Tuesday. Wilbert Montgomery is just beginning. In the National Football League, one does not gain more than 1,500 yards by word of mouth.

title: U.S. Is Reported Considering Offer Of Somalia Base
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  The Somali Government has offered the United States access to the former Soviet naval and air base at the port of Berbera, on the Arabian Sea, according to Somali, Congressional and Defense Department sources.

title: Barbara Ann Picariello Fiancee of Gregory Blass
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Picariello of New York and South Jamesport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Picariello, to Gregory Jay Blass, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Blass of Freeport, L.I. A spring wedding is planned.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Arts and Leisure Guide in section 2 today, the director and source of the film The Awful Truth are listed incorrectly. The film, with an original screenplay, was directed by Leo McCarey.

title: MAILBAG; Musicians Speak Out for Nonesuch
description: Earlier this month, Warner Communications announced changes that appeared to many observers as the termination of Nonesuch, its classical record line. In particular, Teresa Sterne, director of Nonesuch label for the past 14 years, is to he dismissed at the end of this year. It was under Miss Sterne's guidance that Nonesuch produced over 300 recordings, most of them esteemed internationally by critics, musicians and music lovers for their high artistic merit, musical quality and careful presentation. This development has inspired the following letter.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: CAR-POOL is a noun and sometimes a bad verb, as in Har- old has decided to carpool. But, grammar aside, the word is always transitive and usually denotes discomfort.

title: Some RushHour Lessons About Friendship, Loss and Time
description: WHEN I moved to Stamford a few years ago, I regarded the prospect of commuting without enthusiasm. Yet wonderfully, the portion of the commuter platform on which I elected to stand soon proved to be a stage that cemented unique and enduring friendships. The gang at the crack, so called because of a slim fissure in the concrete, was molded slowly by strong ties of communication that in time made it an entity like no other band on Conrail on any train at any hour.

title: Flyer Streak Hits Record 29 Games
description: BOSTON, Dec. 22  One of these days or nights, the Philadelphia Flyers are going to catch their skates on a banana peel and finally lose a hockey game. But it didn't come close to happening this afternoon at Boston Garden.

title: A Minus3 Credit Safety Course for Drivers
description: AN eighthour course in defensive driving at the Mercy College Center for Continuing Education in Yonkers and at the Boces PutnamNorthern Westchester adult education division in Yorktown Heights offers an enticing graduation gift  three penalty points off your driver's license.

title: Mailbox: No Miracles In Cowboys' Victory
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The New
description: The Public Broadcasting Service is about to begin a new life, the third life in its 10year history. But although the transformation is set to take place next month, it probably won't make itself evident on the home screen until the spring.

title: KUNG REPORTS POPE WILL DISCUSS HIS BAN
description: BONN, Dec. 22  The Rev. Hans Kiing, the liberal Roman Catholic theologian whom the Vatican prohibited from teaching this week, said today that Pope John Paul II had decided to discuss the controversial case with West German bishops after Christmas.

title: Historic Facelift for Coast Hotel
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 (AP)  Long closed but not forgotten, the Dunbar Hotel is due for an extensive facelift that is focusing attention again on what the city considers a historic structure.

title: ART
description: MONTCLAIR RELIGIOUS art has not been as popular in the modern age as in past centuries, mostly because religion itself has not been so popular.

title: The Arts and Politics In New York State
description: Earlier this year, the Queens Shakespeare Theater Foundation  an ambitious but inexperienced producing group  applied for a grant to the New York State Council on the Arts, which is the official state agency for cultural support. Soon after, the directors of the foundation were informed that their application would probably be turned down because of the Council's policy against support for organizations which have not been in existence for at least two years. A few months later, however, the Queens Shakespeare Foundation received $50,000 in state aid.

title: Tenor Neil Shicoff: I Can't Just Stand There and Sing
description: Sure, , I'm nervous when I perform, confides Metropolitan Opera tenor Neil Shicoff, and very highstrung. But someone told me once, and I believe it, that it's the faults and the fears that make a person a star. The public identifies with those elements. That's why I need a solid character on which I can concentrate dramatically. It's too difficult to just stand there and sing  I have to bethe character. Otherwise, I can't summon up the courage to go out onstage. And it does take courage. You have to put your life on the line.

title: Topics Winter Diet
description: At first, the land seemed barren of color, scund, even life. The crows wheeling in the slate gray sky contributed nothing, nor did the stark, silent trees, devoid of leaf except for the dry shreds rattling on the beeches. Snapping on skis and gliding into an old cornfield, we entered the emptiness of the season's first snow, and were almost immediately surprised by signs of life.

title: PRESIDENT TO DELAY A PRICE DECONTROL TO SPUR OIL TAX BILL; 1% OF U.S. CRUDE IS AFFECTED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  As a means of keeping pressure on Congress to give final shape to the windfall profits tax on the oil industry, President Carter will withhold the next phase of oilprice decontrol, possibly costing the industry $700,000 a day, the White House said today.

title: Article 8 -- No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Theater: Marlowe's Faustus
description: Christopher Marlowe's Doctor Faustus is a loosely episodic play held together by the power and music of the verse. But one would not know it from the supple and engrossing version now showing at the CSC theater on East 13th Street. Credit that result to the actors in the two principal roles, Robert Stattel and Philip Kerr, and to the direction of Christopher Martin.

title: Marijuana From Many Sources Softening Cancer Chemotherapy
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 22  Along the grapevine of suffering that unites cancer victims, their families and physicians, the news about marijuana and chemotherapy has traveled far, fast and forcefully enough to change the drug laws of 21 states, the policy of the Food and Drug Administration and the hearts of smalltown police chiefs.

title: Janet Lisa Fishbein Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Fishbein of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Lisa Fishbein, to Bart Kenneth Mandell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mandell of Fort Lee, N.J. The future bride, a graduate of Beaver College, is an associate buyer in designer sportswear with Bergdorf Goodman. Her fiance, an alumnus of Ohio State University, is a keyaccount executive with the Puritan Fashion Corporation. The couple will be married Jan. 6.

title: Marriage Announcement 11 -- No Title
description: Marriages

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: The curious thing about John Metz's harpsichord recital Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was that the most interesting moments came at the end. This was curious because the piece in question, William Penn's Fantasy for Solo Harpsichord, was composed in 1975. Mr. Metz is a specialist in the Baroque repertory, is studying for his D.M.A. at the Juilliard School with work on the French Baroque, and devoted all the rest of his program to such older music.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH the fallwinter weather has been fairly mild so far this year, there is little doubt that in the near future the usual deep freeze will set in, with temperatures dropping below freezing and staying there. And, if the last two or three winters are any indication, long stretches of belowfreezing weather will mean that some homeowners will be caught by surprise when unprotected pipes that pass through unheated areas or cold outside walls freeze UD.

title: DINING OUT ardens and Woods Set the Mood
description: WOODLANDS is perhaps the most handsome restaurant in Westchester. The principal dining facility in the Stouffer's Inn complex at White Plains, this plush restaurant  more typical of the West Coast than of Westchester  affords a superb view, particularly in the evening, of informally planted gardens and illuminated woods retreating to the pale green of the inn's tennis bubble and to the buildings of White Plains beyond.

title: A CeaseFire for Rhodesia; War Plans for South Africa
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  They come in many guises, the South Africans who have been helping Rhodesia fight its war a police officer manning a roadblock near an ambush site, warning motorists in Afrikaner accents to turn back, helicopter pilot doing a crossword on his knee as he scoots his chopper down a driedup riverbed, carrying troops to fireforce engagement with guerrillas. Or it can be an army colonel turning up to rent a suburban Salisbury home, telling the landlord only that he expects to be around for number of months.

title: Music: Jaime Laredo, Violin
description: The best came last: a playful, heartwarming rendition of SaintSaens's Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso. Here, Mr. Laredo's tenderness was always to the point, and so captivating that the virtuosity with which he dispatched the pyrotechnics was hardly noticeable. In fact, the work's double stops and scampering 16th notes were carried off to perfection, and the tunes were inflected with a degree of style and imagination that only a strong, agile bow arm makes possible.

title: Superstar Treatments Of Familiar Operas
description: Last week this column discussed new recordings of several intriguing operas seldom encountered in live performances. The companies have not neglected the standard repertory either, and arriving just in time for Christmas are a number of favorite works, all of them lavishly cast with many of today's reigning superstars.

title: Diane Kilmartin Is Betrothed To Michael Joseph Tierney
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Kilmartin of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Kilmartin, to Michael Joseph Tierney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Tierney of Holliston, Mass. A wedding is planned in March.

title: Including Comeon Quotations
description: N the England in which I was reared, books just about grew on the trees. They were everywhere, and they were everything. They were father, mother, nurse, preceptor and friend. They defined England and the English better than anything else, and In a world that boded no good we counted on them to keep us one jump ahead of trouble.

title: Dr. Calvin Roberts And Andrea Colvin Set March 16 Bridal
description: Andrea Janet Colvin, an associate in Citibank's public finance department, and Dr. Calvin Warshaysky Roberts, a resident in ophthalmology at the Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute at Presbyterian Hospital, plan to be married March 16.

title: The Region; In Summary
description: Goldin is Cleared In Case Involving Water Contract Suit

title: Christmas Ghosts
description: THE tradition in England of ghost stories at Christmas is much older than Dickens. It is evident enough that no one who writes now can use the Pagan deities and mythology, Dr. Johnson said in 1780. The only machinery, therefore, seems that of ministering spirits, the ghosts of the departed, witches and fairies. Although Dickens is the most celebrated exponent of the machinery of ministering spirits at Christmas, of ghostly epiphany, there was no better practitioner of the English ghost story than Montague Rhodes James. His stories are more eerie than Dickens's, dustier than L. P. Hartley's, less harshly suburban than Elizabeth Bowen's, and though lacking the narrative gracility of his namesake Hen- ry's, are much scarier for their persuasive antiquar- ian detail.

title: Time Isn't of the Essence, Assembly President Finds
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  Salim Ahmed Salim, the affable, chunky, young Tanzanian career diplomat who presides over the General Assembly, likes to make trains run on time  and in his direction. Last week, he was derailed.

title: What's Doing in BUCHAREST
description: ANOMALY IN THE BALKANSThe English novelist Olivia Manning, who set her Balkan Trilogy in Bucharest during World War H, once described this quintessentially Balkan city as the edge of Europe, a region in which [one] already smelt the Orient. Even today, Rumania is an anomaly among the gray conformity of Eastern European nations, a country of ex- traordinary contrasts, where, in the midst of aggressive modernization, the sights, sounds and smells of an earlier age remain unchanged.

title: The Auto Plant That Could
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y.Throughout the country auto plants have been idled, putting thousands of people out of work as manufacturers desperately try to cut inventories in the face of falling sales. The General

title: The Aid Package Put Together Last Week Raises New Policy Questions; How Can Congress Help Prevent Other Chryslers?
description: Though the junior Democrat from Massachusetts, Senator Paul E. Tsongas, helped draft the Senate version of the bill, he admitted nonetheless that lobbying on the Chrysler package reminded him of a previous Congressional encounter with the auto companies: passage of the 1975 Fuel Efficiency Act, requiring them to manufacture cars with better gas mileage by 1985. A Representative then, Mr. Tsongas supported an amendment that would have toughened the bill. The auto companies went to the Republican side of the aisle; the unions went to the Democratic side, and the country got squeezed in between, he recalled.

title: Curbs on Development of Barrier Islands Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  The Carter Administration is moving toward protecting the barrier islands along the Atlantic Coast and the Gulf of Mexico by inhibitMg their development and discouraging redevelopment after storms and flooding.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: In late 1976, basking in the success of his Blood and Money, Thomas Thompson spurned a great number of offers to do another truecrime book. For instance, he says, I was asked to write about Patty Hearst. But I've never been interested in frontpage stories, because the media will have given all the information. I like surprises.

title: U.S. Voices Concern Repeatedly to Moscow Over Afghan Buildup
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  The Carter Administration has expressed its concern to the Soviet Union several times in recent days over its military buildup in Afghanistan, a State Department official said today.

title: North Carolina Defeats Indiana
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 22 (AP)  James Worthy, a freshman, scored 18 points and Mike O'Koren and Al Wood added 16 apiece Saturday as North Carolina upset injuryplagued Indiana, 6157, in a college basketball game.

title: For Some, Sunlight Raises Hues and Cries
description: THERE are only two types of houses in suburbia. Never mind all you've heard about modular, ranchstylP, Colonial and all the other architectural shorthand. When you come right down to it, there are only two sorts of homes to be found: light houses and dark houses.

title: 2 Hunts Pursue Tradition
description: IT was an unseasonably hot Sunday afternoon in late fall, perhaps too hot for the horses, certainly too hot for the heavily clad fox hunters. In Upper Brookville, on an open field adjacent to the C. W. Post campus, Fred Getty and his horse leaped a fence along the second run of the Smithtown Hunt Club's weekly drag hunt. At approximately that same mo- ment, John Sondericker  field master for the Long Island Hounds Hunt Club  guided his mount along a sandy path, gingerly skirting a scrub oak on the property of the Suffolk County Airport in Westhampton.

title: BRIDGE
description: ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Bill to tax the socalled windfall profits of oil companies, which is expected to raise $178 billion over the next 10 years, passed, 74 to 24, Dec. 17.

title: A Sunday in Chapultepec Park Evokes All Mexico
description: On Sundays, the soul of Mexico past and present flees the museums of Chapultepec Park and takes over its paths, lakes and fields. The museums, impressive during the week, pall next to the colors, sounds and smells of Sunday outdoors in the park.

title: Papa Bear Halas Is Going on 85
description: Sports of The Times

title: A Dream of Being Santa Claus That Became Real
description: After a 15minute walk through the cold and bustle of Seventh Avenue, Robert fforek enters Macy's, at Herald Square, and, riding to the 15th floor, reports to a small, plywoodsided dressing room to prepare for work.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: There is something distinctly unsplendid about the ex-majesties of Europe, in spite of Charles Fenyvesi's fervent attempts to puff up the romantic pasts and dreamridden futures that attend them. Mr. Fenyvesi seems to adhere to a somewhat mushy form of monarchism, ex- pressed in sentences like, It is a time to remember a waltz, a quatrain of long ago, and to re- call a lost kingdom. He trades relentlessly on one's vaguely nostalgic feelings about toppled monarchs, and memories of Shakespeare's Richard II sit- ting upon the ground and telling sad stories of the death of kings. But the fact remains that he cannot make these 13 exkings remarkable, and confirms the view that monarchy is a risky institution at the best of times.

title: Islanders Outplayed But Top Capitals, 21
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. Dec.22  The New York Islanders beat the Washington Capitals, 21, tonight in the Nassau Coliseum in the first meeting between the teams this season. The score, however, was misleading. It was the Capitals who played the better hockey and it was only the superb work of Chico Resch in the New York goal that saved the victory for the Islanders..

title: ROCK CONCERTS LIFT BROWN'S 1980 FUNDS
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 22  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. stood quiet and smiling behind a tower of sound equipment last night as Linda Ronstadt and a pair of rock bands staged the first of two weekend concerts that will swell the Presidential candidate's strained campaign coffers by some $400,000, a third of that in publicly donated Federal matching funds.

title: Tis the Season To Defend Santa
description: OUR friend The College Student settles into my kitchen on Sunday afternoons, smashing Brazil nuts and trying to save me from myself. Although he feels it is all right for me to occupy space on this planet, my head is stuffed with garbage. He is against capitalism, Hollywood, Detroit, the Japanese fishing fleet and eating cows. He approves of girl named Mary Helen, my cooking, The Grateful Dead, woodburning stoves and bicycles.

title: Feiffer Play: Frightening and Funny
description: LINDENHURST JULES FEIFFER'S Little Murders may be the contemporary theater's last word on urban paranoia. An odd coupiing of fantasy and naturalism, by turns frightening and funny, this is a problematical play to pull off. It shifts gears, sometimes in midscene, from surreal to startlingly real.

title: Why Nassau Needs a Real Legislature
description: THERE is no doubt in the minds of some people that the New York State Court of Appeals went out of its way to reach its tortured conclusion that declared the weighted vote system of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors was constitutional and not in violation of the oneman, onevote rule as set forth by the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: Where Have All the Whippoorwills Gone?
description: Where were the whippoorwills this year? It seems they didn't like our Northeastern weather any better than the rest of us did. A few of these intriguing birds appeared in early June, tested the balmy summer nights, found them rare, and apparently moved back south. Few of them were reported in New England this summer. Too bad, because eastern whippoorwills are welcome visitors.

title: Alison H. Browning Plans Spring Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Owens Browning of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Harper Browning, to Theodore David Sands of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore Sands of Normal, Ill.

title: Guide Sets Out Rights Of Disabled on Work, Travel and Education
description: The rights of the handicapped to transportation, education, employment and access to public facilities are detailed in the most recent addition to the American Civil Liberties Union's series of civil rights handbooks.

title: Helping the Elderly Live at Home
description: SYOSSET ANA CHLETSOS came here after an absence of two weeks, despite the lingering pain in her back from a fall she took. She was sitting now, with a small pillow tucked behind her and her black cane propped nearby, watching as some of her contemporaries danced a few steps around the room in time with the song being played on the piano.

title: The World
description: Jimmy Carter certainly doesn't need another crisis in foreign affairs, but one is building up in the Senate over ratification of the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union. And in contrast to the moratorium on debate over Iran, the SALT II critics are relentless, numerous and vocal.

description: ADANA, Turkey, Dec. 20  Three Americans spending their eighth Christ. mas in a Turkish prison hope and almost believe that it will be their last.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: MAN'S HOPE, by Andre Malraux. (Grove, $6.95.) An account of the first eight months of the Spanish Civil War, in which the French writer Andre Malraux (190176) served as an officer in the Loyalist forces. Originally published in 1938, the book has lately been out of print. Critics have debated whether it is a novel or reportage; in either case, it is a vivid mosaic of men and politics in our age.

title: Robbers Escape With Diamonds
description: WINONA, Minn., Dec. 22 (AP)  Two armed robbers wearing Santa Claus suits escaped yesterday with two packets of diamonds from Morgan's jewelry store here, the police said. They said the diamonds were valued at about $20,000.

title: 2 Face Several Charges After Hostage Incident
description: Two gunmen who released six hostages unharmed and surrendered four hours after a thwarted holdup on the Lower East Side were booked on a variety of charges yesterday, the police said. Neighborhood residents expressed concern over the incident and satisfaction with the outcome.

description: Peter Diaz likes to celebrate Christmas as much as anyone else, but this year he almost did not have any halls to deck or a roof for his Christmas tree.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Lively youngster. The trade paperback is a kind of book that defies definition. The dubious offspring of the hardcover and the massmarket book, a Radcliffe student described it not long ago, an evolving field moving faster than our comments can capture its identity. Said another student: Some are like Big Macs.. Some are like gourmet food  a reprint of Paradise Lost or poems by Dylan Thomas.

description: DENVER, Dec. 22 (AP)  The Hare Krishna Temple has won a temporary restraining order against a truth squad that has been interfering with Krishnas soliciting donations at Stapleton International Airport.

title: Bold Gamble in OPEC: Yamani's Supply Weapon
description: CARACAS  It had all the trappings of a disastrous encounter. Expected to run the normal two days, the 55th ministerial meeting on oil prices dragged on for an unprecedented four, and still no accord was reached. Instead, for the first time in its history, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries wound up with no price structure at all.

description: Joyce Trisler died last October. But her legacy of welltrained young dancers and pieces for them to perform is on view at the EmanuEl Midtown Y.M.Y.W.H.A., where the Joyce Trisler Danscompany is performing Saturday and Sunday nights through this week.

description: They may only have been making gestures. But in their own way, the President in Washington and the Ayatollah in Qum showed their responsiveness last week to the cumulative pressures of world and domestic opinion on the hostage stalemate of 50 days.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH the fallwinter weather has been fairly mild so far this year, there is little doubt that in the near future the usual deep freeze will set in, with temperatures dropping below freezing and staying there. And, if the last two or three winters are any indication, long stretches of belowfreezing weather will mean that some homeowners will be caught by surprise when unprotected pipes that pass through unheated areas or cold outside walls freeze up.

Where else, she asked, can you find so many grayhaired people having a ball?

description: They work out of a small room in the cellar the Central Presbyterian Church in the hub of officeAmerica, among the skyscrapers of Park Avenue. Neither draws salary, but their intended audience made up of some of the highestpaid people in the world  leading American executives. Their message is that sexual harassment on the job is a pervasive problem and must be dealt with.

title: Article 11 -- No Title
description: Metropolis redivivus. A few years ago it was fashionable to wonder whether New York, N. Y., had a future. The answer is obvious if you've lately tried to find a hotel room, an apartment or even a place to park on the Isle that is Manhattan. During recent weeks, authors and publishers have been submitting their answer  a shelffull of books about the city's treasures, pleasures and possibilities.

title: CARTER SAID TO EASE STAND ON STATE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  President Carter, under pressure from governors and mayors who are supporting him politically, is now considered likely to modify his longstanding position on revenue sharing and propose that some direct aid to state governments be continued, according to knowledgeable officials.

title: Housing Renovation Reverses Racial Mix
description: RIVERHEAD ONLY recently, the slum conditions of an almost exclusively black apartment complex here, known locally as 821 East Main Street, rivaled those of any innercity tenement. When the complex of townhouse apartments was built some 15 years ago, it was said to be the the best housing in the area, but over the years it degenerated into a playground for petty criminals, drug peddlers and arsonists.

title: Test Finds Jersey College Students Lacking in Verbal and Math Skills
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22  A third or more of the students entering New Jersey colleges have not acquired the verbal and mathematical skills they need to do col legelevel work, according to a report received yesterday by the State Board of Higher Education.

description: MOST people are familiar with Murphy's Law  If something can go wrong, it will  but a growing number of suburban women now also subscribe to Mrs. Murphy's Corollary, which adds, ... especially when your husband is out of town.

title: Nuclear Risks: How Remote?
description: Nuclear power is praised as a blessing that will save an energystarved world from darkness  and vilified as a demonic technology that threatens the survival of humanity. Its advocates are denounced as arrogant, greedy, powermad  and its opponents paranoid flower children seeking a target, any target, to march against. Is there no way out of this bitter dispute, no middle ground that would enable the nation have nuclear power plants and safety, too?

title: STALIN MAKES A COMEBACK
description: As the bus rambled through the sunny Georgian countryside Soviet Georgia, that is again and again, the eyes of the passengers were drawn away from the mountain landscape, me vineyards and the palm trees to a picture which the bus driver had taped to his dashboard  a portrait of Josef Stalin. It was a rather handsome picture of the late dictator, in full vigor; a picture that long ago had etched itself in my mind's eye, for it had been Governmentissue in the last years of Stalin's life, when I was a foreign correspondent in Moscow (194954). In those days, it was this likeness of Stalin that had stared down from the walls of every Soviet office, store, theater

description: DETROIT, Dec. 22  The J. L. Hudson department store here had a Thanksgiving Day parade for two years before Macy's stole the idea. It is the tallest department store in the country. Why, for a while there was even a Hudson automobile that attracted as much ferocious devotion as the store did.

title: INVESTING In Stones, It's Now Color That Counts
description: At auction and in the international jewelry market in recent months, it's all been colored stones  record prices and high demand outshining the traditional diamond. In emeralds, rubies and sapphires, all the price rules were rewritten last month at sales in Switzerland and the feeling was that the investing eye would be increasingly upon them.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 22 (AP)  Eric Heiden won two races and his sister Beth one today as trials for the United States Olympic speedskating team continued on the 400meter Olympic rink in suburban West Allis.

title: U.S. Asks Recalculation of Quake Stress at Reactors
description: SEABROOK, N.H., Dec. 22 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has requested a review of earthquake stress calculations at all the nation's nuclear power plants, top officials of the commission confirmed today. The action followed discovery of an error in calculations for the proposed plant at Seabrook.

description: The Vatican's censure last week of the Rev. title: Chinese Publications on Rise
description: PEKING, Dec. 22 (Reuters)  China publishes 1,200 newspapers, magazines and journals, an increase of 450 since 1976, the New China News Agency said today. It said The People's Daily, the Communist Party paper, and the Foreign News Bulletin, a digest of foreign news, had the largest daily circulations, six million and nine million.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: This is a book that works. It works as good reading because Anne Rockwell has selected 11 tine, satisfying folk tales and told them with care and clarity. Other aspects of the literary scene may flicker fitfully, but in the clear light of the folk tale, vanity, envy, weakmindedness and overconfidence still get their comeuppance (in The Fox and the Crow, The Tortoise and the Hare, The Frog and the Ox, The Three Sillies and The Milkmaid and Her Bucket of Milk). Here, too, are visible the triumphs of the weak but clever (or lucky) over the strong and hungry (in The Travels of a Fox, The Bremen Town Musicians and The Lad Who Went to the North Wind), and of the simple but wise over the powerful (in The Shepherd Boy). Even mere silliness has its place, as in the title story. So let it be, now and forever.

title: A Secret Christmas Ritual, Gone Forever
description: MY BROTHERS thought it strange that I, who had so many material things, asked for my mother's wedding ring when she died. But it was important to me.

title: GARDENING; Deck the Halls and Dream
description: TO the druids, holly was a symbol of the return of spring, and its evergreen boughs laden with red berries were used in their winter solstice celebrations. Christians first considered it to be un- holy because of its association with such pagan rites, but they eventually adopted it as a part of their own religious festivities. One legend arose that described Christ's crown of thorns as having been made from twigs of prickly holly.

title: 72 Rivalero Captures Roamer
description: Some racetrack followers call Rivalero the meanest horse in the world, but he brought nothing but smiles yesterday to those who backed him to win. The reward: $9.20 for each $2 bet.

title: DINING OUT Classic Spanish, the Latest Thing
description: AWOMAN at an adjoining table at El Meson, a new Spanish restaurant in Westbury, remarked that on the Island, Spanish food is the latest thing. She might be right, because in the last year at least three Spanish restaurants have opened in Nassau County.

title: Indian Voter Group Seeks to Keep Mrs. Gandhi Out
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 22  A group of prominent citizens has started a movement in India designed to protect democracy and avoid any repetition of emergency rule of the type carried out by Indira Gandhi in the last 20 months of her tenure as Prime Minister.

title: Susan Cari Smahl Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Susan Cari Smahl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Smahl of Brooklyn and Palm Beach, Fla., to David John Plummer, son of George Plummer of Oradell, N.J., and the late Betty Plummer, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Miss Smahl, an account executive with Albert Frank / FCB, advertising agency, and her fianc, the traffic director at the Philip Stogel Company, also Manthattan advertising agency, will be married May 26. The future bride's parents are founding partners in the Mill Harbour School and directors of the Neighborhood Playhouse for Children, both in Brooklyn. Mr. Plummer's father is a technical supervisor with New York.

title: Parole Hearing Postponed
description: FOLSOM, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP)  A parole hearing for Joseph Remiro of the Symbionese Liberation Army has been postponed for two months. The hearing was delayed on Wednesday until Feb. 27 because Mr. Remiro's attorney, Stuart Hanlon, was suffering from a pulled neck muscle. Mr. Remiro, 33 years old, is serving a life sentence for his 1975 conviction of taking part in the murder of the Oakland school superintendent, Marcus Foster.
