title: Sheila Jaffee Fiance of Dentist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Jaffee of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Jaffee, to Dr. Alan B. Spector of Edgewater, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Spector of Clitfside Park, N.J. The bride-to-be is a registered nurse at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. Her fiance is a graduate of the University of Maryland and the Tufts Dental School. A wedding is planned in the spring.

title: Ken Howard

title: Music: Premiere Troupe
description: Arnold Schoenberg's First Chamber Symphony, written in 1906, is a transitional work, poised between the fullblown Romanticism of GurreLieder and the tortured Expressionism of his atonal period. But there is nothing transitory about its appeal. The writing bristles with ingenious structural and polyphonic machinations. For all its fin de siecle echoes of Brahms and Mahler, it retains its freshness even as the idiom grows recognizably older.

title: CAP Laws Can Work, but Only if . . .
description: I BELIEVE that government has been traditionally less effective and efficient than the private sector in delivering services. This is a key reason for rapidly escalating tax burdens in the past.

title: Washington Loans Help Renovation Projects
description: A little more than a year ago, the fivestory brick tenement at 523 East Fifth Street on Manhattan's Lower East Side was a shambles, its 12 railroad flats burned out, its shattered windows boarded, its copper plumbing long since stolen by vandals.

title: Judith Nahas Is Married To Richard D. Popper
description: Judith Nahas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy Nahas of Middletown, Va., was married at the Community Church of New York yesterday to Richard D. Popper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Popper of New York. The Rev. Bruce Southworth performed the ceremony in the Chapel of Peace.

description: EL PASO, Dec. 22 (AP)  A clutch goalline tackle by Greg Grimes and two fumble recoveries, including one by Grimes, sparked the University of Washington to a 147 upset today over Texas in the Sun Bowl.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review last week did not make clear John B. Connally's position on two issues, Mr. 17onnally favors the Equal Rights Amendment, but did not favor exten- sion of the time allowed for rubrica- tion unless slates were assured the right to rescind earlier votes. Mr. Con- natty considers abortion a moral issue, not a constitutional One, spokesman said; he does not favor encouragement of abortion on demon( through Federal funds.

title: Olivia Wilson Will Be Wed; Bridal in May
description: The engagement of Olivia Laneres Wilson to Edward Hambleton Welbourn 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Welbourn Jr. of Garrison, Md., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. M. Wilson of Garrison and Shelter Island. N.Y.

title: Car Fumes Kill Chicagoan
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (UPI)  A Southwest Side man who took refuge in his garage to listen to taped Christmas music in his car died of carbon monoxide poisoning, the police said. Allen Boatner, 46 years old, was tound tnis morning, by Ms wife, slumped over the wheel of his car, the motor running and the garage door and windows shut, the police said.

title: Beaths
description: BERNHEIMTheodore. On December 22, 1979. Beloved husband of Gwen. Father of Michael, Mari lane and Lisa. Fatherinlaw of Paul Bell. Private services Sunday 1 PM at Beth Israel Cemetery. Cedar Knolls. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to HaveaHeart Foondatka, N.Y.C.

title: Congress Broadens Its Influence on Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Congress voted in October to restrict United States aid to Afghanistan until the Government formally apologized for the killing there last year of the United States Ambassador. Afghanistan thus became the 26th nation to have its American aid restricted by Congress.

title: New York Times/Joyce Dopkeen
description: Families, dogwalkers and others strolled on dock Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn yesterday, waiting for fishermen to come in with their daily catches. The fishing was meager, and nearby, Assemblyman Charles E. Schumer said that fishermen's future was even more in doubt because of plan to auction their dock space to highest bidders. He said neighborhood won't be able to stay afloat if the cost of mooring a boat is greatly increased.

title: Tackling Inflation, Unemployment and the Oil Problem
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Rising energy prices fuel inflation. To combat inflation, we seek to slow down the economy. But forecasters project little resulting restraint on price rises while they expect unemployment to soar.

title: Knicks Set Back Trail Blazers
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 23 (AP) Michael Ray Richardson converted 3point play with 4 minutes 21 seconds remaining in the game to put the New York Knicks ahead, and they went on to gain a 111103 triumph over the Portland Trail Blazers tonight at Memorial Coliseum. The victory broke the Knicks fourgame losing streak.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION There is a scramble under the backboard in a National Basketball Association game, and a player on Team A finds himself with both feet out of bounds as he catches a ball on the fly that was sent out of bounds by a player on Team B. Whose ball is it?:

title: U.S. Steel Ends Price Rise Plan
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (Reuters) The United States Steel Corporation, bowing to competitive pressures, said Friday that it had decided not to increase prices of sheet steel as scheduled on Jan. 1.

title: Advertising
description: THE Mother of Invention visited Betsy Eagles, long associated with the fashion field, when she was doing a film for the Avon cosmetics folks about five years ago and had difficulty in lining up hair and fashion stylists and makeup artists.

title: StrayAnimal Hunt Pressed In Houston Rabies Outbreak
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 23  At intervals all day, every day last week, yellow pickup trucks with cages in back have been pulling up near the low brick building on Houston's North Side with Rabies Control Center on its front. Inside, where the telephones are ringing off the hook, there is always a line of people waiting to obtain vaccinations for dogs and cats of every description.

title: The New York Times/David Handschuh
description: MENORAHS DESTROYED AT TEMPLE IN THE BRONX: Rabbi Avranam Weiss, right, and Stanley Langer of the Hebrew Institute at Riverdale, background, examine one of two 10foot high menorahs that were torn from their bases Saturday night. A second menorah, weighing 300 pounds and constructed of metal pipe, was thrown onto the Henry Hudson Parkway.

title: Old Dominion Is Upset in Final, 5957
description: Nancy Lieberman sat with her legs crossed on the cold wooden floor, watching the championship trophy of the Manufacturers Hanover Christmas Classic women's basketball tournament awarded to Louisiana Tech. It took several minutes for the chill from the hockey ice below the Madison Square Garden basketball court to creep upward and force her hands into the pockets of her hooded Old Dominion sweatshirt. Finally, the cold reality of yesterday's 5957 defeat sank in.

title: Music: Pro Arte Offers Bach Christmas Oratorio
description: BACH'S Christmas Oratorio is a grand and festive piece, but it isn't heard as often as other major Christmas pieces Handel's Messiah, of course, but probably also Berlioz's L'Enfance du Christ  or as often as Bach's own other major choral works. The reasons seem to be two. First, as reworkings of secular cantatas and as six smaller cantatas that were meant to stand alone on separate festival days, the Christmas Oratorio was long looked down upon as inferior Bach. And second, its length might seem to make casual performances difficult.

title: Dallas Film Classification Board Disturbs the Industry
description: DALLAS (AP)  This city has an unusual movierating system that local critics say is getting the city widely criticized in Hollywood.

title: DONALD S. GILMORE OF UPJOHN COMPANY
description: Donald S. Gilmore, retired chairman of the board of the Upjohn Company, the pharmaceutical concern, died Friday at his home in Kalamazoo, Mich., after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

description: While students and faculty members of Hunter College were signing petitions and raising their voices during the bitter 10month search for a president that ended last Friday with the selection of Dr. Donna E. Shalala, some of the most powerful people in New York State politics were engaged in a more subtle form of electioneering offcampus.

title: Associated Press
description: STREAK STAYS ALIVE: Bobby Clarke of Flyers battling with Greg Carroll of Hartford for loose puck in first period last night in Philadelphia. Flyers kept alive their record streak of consecutive games without a defeat by beating Whalers, 42.

title: Fromm and Rosello Lead Net Advance
description: Eric Fromm of Glen Head, L.I., Bobby Rosello of Mineola, L.I., Jon Molin of Yonkers and Cary Leeds of New York City led the field into the third round of the Ellesse Winter open tennis tournament yesterday at the National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens.

title: On the Rails, Joyful Noise
description: For a handful of Saturday cornmuters in the last car of a Long Island Rail Road train, it began like just another nosebehindthenewspaper trip into the city. Wheels clacked drowsily. The flat, drab landscape rolled peaceably past.

title: Sketches of Three Clerics Who Are Going to Iran
description: Senior minister of Riverside Church in New York City since 1977 . .. Served 17 years as chaplain of Yale University ... Civil rights and antiVietnam War activist ... In 1967 was tried with Dr. Benjamin Spock for allegedly counseling young men to evade the draft ; their conviction was overturned on appeal . Born in New York City 55 years ago ... Graduated from Yale and studied  at Union Theological Seminary before spending three years with C.I.A. . . Graduated from Yale Divinity School and was ordained in the Presbyterian ministry ... Left the Yale post in 1976 to write autobiography ... Was overwhelmingly elected senior minister of Riverside Church despite opposition to his politics and the fact that both his marriages have failed.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23 (AP)  Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit and Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, have reached an agreement that calls for the city to pay for a $28.5 million addition at a Chrysler factory, city officials said.

title: Soviet Nuclear Test Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) The Soviet Union apparently conducted its 15th underground nuclear weapons test of the year at 11:57 last night at the Semipalatinsk nuclear test site in Siberia, the Energy Department announced today.

title: Feel Eke running away from home?
description: To Waikiki, Montmartre. Acapulco, the Greek Islands, Miami, Las Vegas or wherever your quick little feet may want to take you?

title: AvantGarde: Niblock. In SevenHour Program
description: Phil! Niblock has always been something of a Wagnerian. But with a sevenhour program Friday night at his Experimental Intermedia Foundation loft on Centre Street  of which this writer saw the first 90 minutes  he has become a (Robert) Wilsonian, as well.

title: Sumaya ElTawil Bride Of Dr. Magdi M. Khalifa
description: At the Manor Club of Pelham, N.Y., yesterday afternoon; Sumaya Bahgat ElTawil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bahgat ElTawil of Pelham and Cairo, became the bride of Dr. Magdi M. Khalifa, son of Fatma Khalifa of Cairo and the late Mohamed Khalifa. Dr. Hosny M. Gaber, imam and director of the Islamic Cultural Center of New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Darryl F. Zanuck, Flamboyant Film Producer, Dead
description: Darryl F. Zanuck, the last of tne flam boyant movie moguls, died of pneumonia late Saturday in Palm Springs (Calif.) Hospital. He was 77 years old. A Hollywood wonder boy at 25, Mr. Zanuck went on to become one of the pacesetters of the film industry, with a career as dramatic as any of the stories he brought to the screen.

title: Arlene Shrut Wed
description: The marriage of Arlene Shrut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Shrut of Pittsburgh, to Mark Rosenman took place yesterday. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the New York apartment of Mervin Rosenman, father of the bridegroom.

title: Dollar Climbs Against Yen
description: TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 24 (AP) The dollar opened two yen higher on the Tokyo foreignexchange market today and continued to rise in thin early trading. It opened at 241 yen, compared with Friday's closing of 239.00, and soon jumped another yen to trade at around 242 to 242.50.

title: Vranes of Utah Ineligible
description: The college athletic eligibility scandal that has engulfed New Mexico, Oregon and Oregon State touched the Utah basketball team and Danny Vranes, one of the nation's outstanding forwards, on Saturday.

title: 5 Killed in Plane Crash in Storm In Mountain Region of California
description: LANCASTER, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI) Five persons, including a 10monthold baby, were found dead today in the wreckage of a light plane that crashed in stormy weather in mountains north of Los Angeles.

title: Canadiens 8, Maple Leafs 4
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 23 (UPI)  Guy Lafleur scored his 27th goal to highlight a fivegoal outburst in the first period as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 84, tonight.

title: Associated Press
description: Four men were given summonses by police for disorderly conduct following a brawl in which several Boston players climbed into the stands and fought with fans after the Bruins 43 victory over the Rangers last night at Madison Sauare Garden.

title: Stockpiling Cited In Gas Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) A major factor in the nation's gasoline shortage last spring was a decision by United States oil companies to build inventories rather than sell their products, the Brookings Institution said in a report issued today.

title: The Region
description: NEW CITY, N.Y. (UPI)  The Hudson Valley Regional Red Cross blood bank received blood from some unexpected sources yesterday. The donors were participants in a Rockland County alternative rehabilitation program for firsttime youthful offenders.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: PARIS  Prince Sihanouk, who has been seeking an international political solution for Cambodia, now says that only a guerrilla war will persuade the Vietnamese to leave his country. And he says China is ready to help any Cambodian forces, regardless of ideology, that will fight such a war.

title: ExPolice Chief Speaks in Pride Of Coast Career
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23  Police Chief Charles Gain walked out of his slickedrlann nffirc. Fridny night, rinsing the door on a career of law enforcement that stretched over 30 years of change and controversy.

title: Letter: On Helping Older Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Tells Overseas Operators To End Their ThreeDay Walkout
description: Six hundred striking telephone operators in Manhattan went back to work last night in the overseas section of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Long Lines Division hours after the company won a temporary injunction in Federal District Court against the strike.

title: An Unjust War in East Timor
description: Americans have only gradually become aware the unjust war Indonesia has been waging in remote East Timor. The former Portuguese colony has suffered a ruthless military occupation since Indonesia invaded it in 1975 and proclaimed its annexation a year later. The fighting, disease and starvation may have claimed a third of East Timor's 600,000 inhabitants no one can say for sure, because Indonesia has restricted access by the international relief agencies.

title: Oilers Statistics
description: INDIVIDUAL LEADERS

title: Italian Business Returns to Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Almost a decade after being unceremoniously ousted from Libya, the Italians are back some 18,000 of them, almost as many as were thrown out of Libya in September 1970, when Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, nationalized all properties owned by Italians.

title: Christina Maria Montero Bride
description: At the Marble Collegiate Church yesterday, Christina Maria Montero, an account representative for the Associated Merchandising Corporation, was married to Kim Anthony Bradford, a sales manager with Western International Hotels. The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Julio Montero of Irvington, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Guy Bradford of Ridgewood, N.J. The bride is an alumna of Skidmore College. Mr. Bradford graduated from Utica College of Syracuse University.

title: Roberta Newmark Married to Dr. Robert Taylor Effren
description: Roberta Newmark of Orangeburg, N.Y., and Dr. Robert Taylor Effren of Englewood, N.J., were married yesterday morning at the Palm Aire Country Club in Pompano Beach, Fla., by Rabbi Israel Zimmerman.

title: ExC.I.A. Agent's Passport Blocked After He Makes a Proposal to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has revoked the passport of a former Central Intelligence Agency employee who has proposed resolving the Iranian crisis by exchanging C.I.A. files on Iran for the release of the 50 hostages being held at the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: The Hardy Wall St. Bonus
description: The yearend bonus is widely believed to be a thing of the past among Wall Street brokerage firms, and for many of them, it is. But by whatever name, bonuses persist today through much of the industry, and some are bigger than ever.

title: Islanders Trounced By Black Hawks, 80
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP)  Grant Mulvey had his second threegoal game in the National Hockey League, drew 26 minutes in penalties, and knocked the New York goalie, Billy Smith, out of the net during a secondperiod fight tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks routed the Islanders, 80.

title: Dave Anderson
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: BearsEagles Scoring
PHYLLIS GORDON SOLOMON
description: Phyllis Gordon Solomon, a lawyer, died of cancer Saturday at Wellesley Hospital in Toronto. Mrs. Solomon, who lived in Toronto, was 29 years old.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Nephew Is Due To Be Freed From Jail
description: VACAVILLE, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI)  A nephew of President Carter, Willie Carter Spann, will be released Christmas Eve from a prison where he is serving a sevenyear term for robbery, the authorities said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When George Platt, who has been in the oil business some 30 years, discovered recently that his Texas International Company was being sought by another corporation, it did not take him long to refuse the offer.

title: Hawaii's Tourist Industry Afflicted By Economic and Political Worries
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 23  The Hawaiian tourist industry, which had hoped for a record 4 million visitors this year, seems likely to fall short of its goal because of pyramiding economic and political woes. Some officials fear that there may be 10 percent to 19 percent fewer tourists this winter than last year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: U. S. Clergyman, Leaving for Iran, Attacks Carter's Call for Sanctions
description: The Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin Jr., one of three American clergymen invited to celebrate Christmas services at the American Embassy in Teheran, sharply criticized President Carter's call for economic sanctions against Iran yesterday, saying that it was highly reminiscent of Lyndon Johnson's bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Sports Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 23 (AP) Phil Dent of Australia captured the men's singles title in the New South Wales open tennis tournament today with a 64, 64, 75 victory over Hank Pfister of the United States.

title: Sports Today
description: Rolex international junior tournament, at Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy, 9 A.M.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ACCORDING to the jacket of his new novel, Don Carpenter spent 12 years in and out of Hollywood writing for movies and television, and he will probably spend the next 12 years writing about it. Hollywood to me is a civilization easily as complex, fascinating and mysterious as ancient Egypt. The heart sinks and the feet itch and the mind wanders. The last novel by Don

title: BroncosOilers Scoring
Dance: Meg. Harper In 3 Solos
description: FORTUNATELY, Meg Harper is choreographically inventive. Otherwise, she could not have gotten away with calling a dance Bad Moves. Titles like that invite wisecracks.

title: Guerrilla Officer Killed in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23 (Reuters)  A member of the Palestinian , guerrilla group known as Saiqa, Capt. Isam Hawawi, was shot to death in West Beirut last night when he challenged five gunmen who were trying to rob a supermarket, witnesses said today. The gunmen escaped.

title: Music: Harmonic Choir
description: DVID HYKES'S Harmonic Choir has been with us for several years, now, exploring the variety of religious chanting styles throughout the world and synthesizing them into something presumably meaningful for a contemnorary American audience. Saturday evening the group capped a series of local performances with a concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where it has been in residence.

title: Chess:
description: It is fascinating to watch the progress of a speculative positional pawn sacrifice, for it usually gives the game an ethereal character. At first, there are no threats in such a gambit at least not serious, unparryable ones  and yet it is not easy for the defender to maneuver his pieces to acceptable squares.

title: In Seoul Cautious Changes
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 23  In one of his first moves as President of South Korea, Choi Kyu Hah announced on Friday that the Government planned to revise the 1972 Constitution under which

title: Emhart's Talks With VSI End
description: The Emhart Corporation announced yesterday that it was terminating merger negotiations with the VSI Corporation by mutual agreement. John F. Budd Jr., vice president of Emhart, said in a telephone interview that his company had also dropped. its offer to buy roughly 34 percent of VSI's shares that are controlled by a trust. He dedined to discuss reasons for the moves agreed.

title: Outdoors: Peace For All Earth's Living Things
description: ALMOST always, when the earlyafternoon Christmas feast is done and the house is filled with talk and people, I am moved to walk alone to better comprehend the meaning of the day, to settle my heart and mind as well as my stomach.

title: New Seville Bucks LuxuryCar Slump
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23  When Valerie Garrett went shopping for a new car, she looked at the 1980 Cadillac Seville, with its bustle trunk. The unusual styling left her cold. And the $20,000 price tag also bothered her

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets are ending the year held in check by a rough balance between the forces pushing rates higher and those pulling them down. Last week, it seemed that the equilibrium would last at least through the holiday season.

title: Sydney Hovland Is Married To Roger Wittlin in Arizona
description: Sydney Hovland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Hovland of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married there yesterday to Roger Wittlin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Marc S. Wittlin of Stamford, Conn. City Magistrate David L. Phares of Chandler, Ariz., performed the ceremony at the Conference Resort Hotel.

title: Consumers Oil Cartel Proposed
description: PARIS, Dec. 23  An oil consumers cartel, dedicated to evening out the rise in energy prices, may now offer Western industrialized nations their best hope of becoming prosperous again, in the view of senior economists at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Brooklyn 74, Hunter 69
description: Aronia Parker, a sophmore guard, and Alex Lloyd, a junior forward, each sank two foul shots in oneandone situations in the final 67 seconds to give Brooklyn College a 7469 victory over Hunter College in a City University Conference game in Brooklyn last night

title: Holiday in the Bayous: 16Mile Stretch of Fire
description: LA PLACE, La., Dec. 23 (AP)  The log structures stand along the levee strung out like primitive watchtowers. All is calm. All will soon be bright.

title: Have Yourself a Marsupial Little Crispness
description: Walt Kelly's first rendition of Deck the Halls by the Pogo characters appeared in the Dec. 22, 1998 New York Star, a newspaper that only lasted about six months. Pogo wasn't famous yet, but he'd been around for a few years in a book called Animal Comics that was mostly about a little boy named Bumbazine.

title: Notes on People
description: Not long ago, Leonard Bernstein was reported to be planning not one, but two performances in two cities in one night, being chauffeured, jetted and helicoptered so that he could perform in New York after appearing in Washington.

title: Coal Lode Idle in Western States As Concerns Prospect for Buyers
description: DENVER  Under the frigid plains and the skiers mountains lies perhaps 100 years worth of Western surface coal, the rhetorical answer of the last three American Presidents to Arab oil embargoes. The nearly untouched reserves of the Rocky Mountain and Great Plains coal states used to inspire mining men to call the region America's own Saudi Arabia.

title: June Helene Price Is Married To Robert Brieff at Columbia
description: June Helene Price, daughter of Helen Price of Williamsville, N.Y., and William Price of Buffalo, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Louis Brieff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Brieff of New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Baptist minister and director of chapel activities at the Church Center for the United Nations, and Rabbi Julius Rosenthal officiated at the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: Storm Hits West Coast With Rain and Winds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (UPI) Rain and snow accompanied by winds up to 60 miles per hour struck northern California today, shutting highways and impeding Christmas travelers.

title: Supplementary OTC Listings
description: Week Ended Dec. 21, 1979

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Federal Tower Looms Over Everyday Life
description: You're not likely to fight it, as you might City Hall. And you probably won't write to it, at least as you would your Congressman. But at some point, it has almost certainly affected you, paid you, regulated you  and perhaps even irritated you.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Learning how to ski or improving your ability can be accomplished in the home by utilizing a onehour cassette designed for use in video recorders. Instruction by leading experts is available for beginning or advanced skiers in slalom, freestyle, powder and crosscountry. The film uses slowmotion and stopaction techniques, while repeating vital sections to provide consistent learning situations. The cassette sells for $60 from Liberty Productions, 1331 South Dixie Highway, Pompano Beach, Fla. 33060, (305) 9925720.

title: Suns 106, Bucks 103
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 23 (UPI) Paul Westphal scored the last 9 points for the Phoenix Suns tonight as they rallied for a 106103 triumph over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Fire Chief's Auto Burns In Missouri Firebombing
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 23 (AP)  A city car used by Kansas City Fire Chief John Waas was burned tonight a few hours after he dismissed 10 firefighters who had participated in a job action a2ainst the city.

title: Martha's Vineyard Ferry Service Threatened in Dispute Over Slip
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Dec. 23 Martha's Vineyard is threatened with curtailment of ferry service next spring because of a dispute with the Wood's Hole, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket Steamship Authority over construction of a second ferry slip here. Officials said a reduction of ferry service could mean economic disaster for the island's tourist trade.

title: Chamber: Elysian Trio
description: BALDWINWALLACE College must be counting its blessings to have such an excellent chamber ensemble as the Elysian Trio in residence. The group played in Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night and its performances had the sort of musical integration, intelligence, care for detail and pulsating vitality that is rarely encountered, even among musicians who may have worked as a team much longer than these young artists.

title: R. H. McAllister, Vice President Of Worldwide Tugboat Concern
description: Roderick H. McAllister, vice president of McAllister Brothers Inc., one of the largest tugboat companies in the world, died Thursday at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. Mr. McAllister, a resident of Glen Cove, L.I., was 59 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: A new name is likely to make an impact on the national scene in the coming year, causing some to ask the question: Who is Barbara Haberman? The name is new, but not the player, for Barbara Haberman is one of the world's top women players. Among her many tournament victories two are unusual: she has won two consecutive national life master pair championships, and three consecutive Goldman Pair titles in New York.

title: Campbell Hurt
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 23  The Houston Oilers survived the loss of Earl Campbell, pro football's premiere running back; Dan Pastorini, the quarterback who directs the team's offense; and Ken Burrough, the club's leading pass receiver, in their 137 National Football League playoff victory over the Denver Broncos today.

title: Eagles Statistics
description: INDIVIDUAL LEADERS

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  At Christmas time, the news in Christendom was the decision approved by the Pope that Hans Ming, the outspoken German religious thinker, can no longer be considered a Catholic theologian. When protest mounted among Catholic theologians around the world, the Pope agreed to review the order with the German Catholic hierarchy, which is now trying to work out a compromise.

title: Excerpts From Coffin's Sermon at Riverside Church on Trip to Iran
description: Following are excerpts from the sermon of the Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin Jr. yesterday morning at Riverside Church as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Moon's Church in Dispute on Westchester Property
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Dec. 20  The Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church is about to spend its first Christmas as a property owner in the Town of New Castle, and that has led many a local resident to look again at what religious freedom means.

title: Mixed Media: New Program By Hayman
description: RICHARD HAYMAN gave a concert of dream music at the Kitchen a few years ago. He asked people to bring their sleeping bags and spend the night with his sounds, and many did. His program at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation last Monday evening was much shorter than the Kitchen presentation, under 90 minutes in fact, but it was strikingly evocative. Its themes were disembodiment, dispersion and death.

title: And HoHoHo to You
description: ( With abject apologies to Erato, the muse of poetry, and all eight of her sisters.)

title: De Gustibus
description: One hundred years ago, on Dec. 31, 1879, Gilbert and Sullivan's The Pirates of Penzance had its world premiere in New York. To celebrate the occasion, there will be a Hundredth Anniversary exhibition of memorabilia at the Pierpont Morgan Library, opening Thursday.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Unger's N.H.L. Streak Ends While Simmer's Reaches 12
description: Charlie Simmer extended his modern National Hockey League record last night by scoring a goal in his 12th consecutive game as the Kings rolled to an 93 victory over the Edmonton Oilers in Los Angeles. Another record ended in St.Louis as Garry Unger of the Flames, who had the longest consecutivegame string, sat out Atlanta's 73 victory over the Blues. Unger had played in 914 straight games.

title: Wisconsin 94, Hawaii 42
description: MADISON, Wis., Dec. 23 (AP) Wisconsin, led by 22 points by Wesley Matthews, warmed up for the Rainbow Basketball Classic in Hawaii with a 9442 victory over Morgan State today.

title: Denise Gosliner Is Wed To Harry C. Orenstein
description: Denise Gosliner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bertram J. Gosliner, was married at her parents New York home yesterday to Harry Coleman Orenstein, son of Aaron Orenstein of Ocean City, Md., and the late Mrs. Orenstein. State Supreme Court Justice Martin B. Stecher performed the ceremony.

title: Canadiens Snap Losing Streak
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 23 (UPI)  Montreal snapped its longest losing streak in 40 years, six games, as Serge Savard and Mark Napier broke a 22 tie with thirdperiod goals that gave the Canadiens a 42 victory Saturday night over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: BUS SYSTEM IN CITY TERMED THE WORST OF ALL M.T.A. UNITS
description: Riders of the buses, subways and commuter railroads run by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have long known of their problems in maintenance and scheduling. But a new, Governmentfinanced study provides details of these problems that go far beyond any previous examination of the metropolitan area's transit systems.

title: Seoul Detains General in Sedition Plot
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 24  The Defense Ministry today announced that Gen. Chung Seung Hwa, former army chief of staff, has been detained for suspected involvement in attempted sedition at the time of the assassination of President Park Chung Hee on Oct. 26.

title: World News Briefs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 23  A Turk , ish Airlines plane crashed into a hill in dense fog this afternoon on the approach to Ankara's Esenboga Airport, 20 miles north of here. The authorities announced I tonight that there were four survivors and that the other 39 people aboard were presumed dead. All the passengers were Turkish, officials said.

title: The Spirit of Sharing
description: Americans find their personal Christmas cheer muted as they remember the hostages still captive the embassy in Teheran. It cannot detract from that concern to remember at the same time that there are also victims of a different kind  of illness, poverty, old age, loneliness  here at home. They, too, need he remembered, and helped. Our own holiday would diminished if we forgot the needy.

title: Associated Press
description: EYE LEVEL: Kathy Horvath lining up shot during her victory yesterday over Patrizia Murgo in final of world junior tennis championships in Miami Beach.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Until this month, the last time Temple University had appeared in a postseason game was on Jan. 1, 1935, when the Owls lost the first Sugar Bowl, 2014, to Tulane. So 45 football seasons later after defeating the University of California. 2817, in the Garden State Bowl at Giants Stadium, it didn't matter all that much when the Governor of New Jersey, Brendan Byrne, presented the winning trophy to the University of Temple.

title: Crossing the Channel for Christmas Bargains
description: DIEPPE, France  The blue and white channel ferry Valencay, her decks empty in the driving rain, eased gently against the dock. A gangway was run out and, minyees later, the passengers, heads bent against the wind and rain, hurried ashore.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Helps Unwed Adolescent Parents
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund helps people in a variety of ways. One program started this year focuses on single parents between the ages of 16 and 21. It is the Community Service Society's Adolescent Parent Project in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

title: Train Crash Kills 18 in India
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 23 (AP)  An express train hit the back of a standing passenger train today near Sarupeta in Assam State in northeast India, killing 18 people and injuring 25, the United News of India reported.

title: St. John's Trounces Centenary by 9272
description: Did you ever get up in the morning and put on two left shoes? asked Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's basketball coach, last night. That was us against Centenary.

title: Article 1  No Title
Rhodesian Peace Force Begins Taking Up Its Positions
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 23 British and other Commonwealth military personnel began deploying to Rhodesian military bases today in the first phase of a ceasefire monitoring exercise that was acknowledged by its British commander to be fraught with dangers for the men involved.

title: Holiday Closings
description: The stock exchanges, banks and most governmental offices are expected to be open for business as usual today. Some, however, may close early. Some bank branches will close in midafternoon. The American Commodities Exchange will be open, but other commodities exchanges will be closed.

title: Bears Ousted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23  The last time the Philadelphia Eagles tried the play, Ron Jaworski's pass bounced off Billy Campfield's shoulder for an interception that set up the Cowboys first touchdown two weeks ago in a Dallas victory that virtually eliminated the Eagles from the division title.

title: Maritime Fleet Aid Stirs New Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) When the American freighter Atlantic Bear slid down the ways in 1976, she was backed by $40.4 million of taxpayers money. In the following three years, the Bear's owner, Pacific Far East Lines of San Francisco, received $70.3 million of tax funds in subsidies. Today, however, the Bear awaits bankruptcy sale in Virginia's James River.

title: Is There A Diesel In Your Future?
description: Diesel cars get terrific mileage, almost never catch fire in collisions, and emit less in the way of dangerous hydrocarbon fumes and carbon monoxide than gasolinepowered cars. Alas, there's a catch: diesels emit far greater amounts of tiny soot particles suspected of causing cancer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amstar Corporation, a manufacturer of sweeteners and supplier of industrial tools and equipment, has elected Randolph R. Williams and Charles W. Bradbury Jr. vice presidents.

title: A Preventive Approach to Child Abuse
description: They are children who have known more tears than laughter. They have known the fist, the belt, the burning cigarette. But the other day they giggled and clamored for Santa Claus, sang Jingle Bells with all their might and opened their presents with a world of expectation in their eves. The oldest was 12. The youngest was seeing her first Christmas at 3 months of age.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON

title: Scene in Brooklyn Court Recalls 3 Slayings and a Previous Trial
description: Mounted next to the jury box are stark photographs of the scene  the Brooklyn street where two police officers and a former convict were killed and a second former convict was wounded in the brief but furious shootout.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 3, 18, 8, 25, 7 and 35. The supplementary number was 33.

title: Kelly Piper Married to Kenneth A. Locker
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Kelly Piper, an actress known as Kelly Piper, to Kenneth Andrew Locker, an independent film director and producer based in Los Angeles, took place in New York yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice William Zeck performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Hyde.

title: Soviet Denies Charge on Afghans
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 23  A staff commentator of the Soviet Communist Party paper Pravda described as pure invention today reports by the United States Government that the Soviet Union had moved combat troops into Afghanistan.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI Widespread cloudiness covers most of the East with heavy cloudiness stretching from the lake region to the lower Misslsslppl Valley and from Arkansas to Texas. Snow clouds are visible In the central Rockies while a heavy band of frontal clouds covers the coastal regions of the Pacific Northwest and the Central and Southern Pacific States.

title: Certificates as Housing Spur
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)  New savings attracted to the nation's thrift institutions in the first year that moneymarket certificates were available stimulated the construction of nearly 300,000 new homes, says a report issued today by the Brookings Institution.

title: 2Car Motorcade Gives Baker a Relaxed Swing Through New Hampshire
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Dec. 21  Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., convinced that he faces a makeorbreak challenge in the earliest Presidential primaries, has just spent four days in New Hampshire, shaking hands on chilly street corners and imploring clutches of wouldbe voters to trust his experience.

title: Commodities
description: GIVEN the widening news coverage of the soaring prices of precious metals, one might expect the brokerage houses to be busy signing up new futures trading accounts. Most are, but many are far from happy over the public's eagerness to participate in the paper gold rush, for two major reasons.

title: California Assembly Speaker Challenged by ExAlly
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23  Speaker Leo McCarthy of the California Assembly, whose intention to support Senator Edward M. Kennedy for the Democratic Presidential nomination is an open secret, is being challenged for his leader, ship post by the Assembly's majority leader, Howard Berman.

title: Cambodians Finding Security in a Remote Hilltop Village
description: SOK SANN, Cambodia, Dec. 21  To get to this village perched atop a steep hill facing the Thai border first requires a 90minute tractor ride through tapioca fields and jungle. From the foot of the hill it takes another 90 minutes to climb up a trail that crosses five unbridged streams.

title: U.S. Forecasts Wheat Crop
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)  In its first major forecast of crop production next year, the Agriculture Department announced that the 1980 winter wheat crop could yield 1.57 billion bushels, only 3 percent less than the bumper 1979 harvest.

title: Beaths
description: MILLERHarold C., on Dec 22, 1979, beloved husband of Shirley, devoted fattier of Bryce and Barbara, latherinlaw of Etta, loving grandfather of Ira Zevi, dear brother of Alice Rothkowitz and Ann Goodman. Services Monday, Dec 24, 11:30AM, The Rlierside", 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: NO EARLY RELEASE SEEN FOR HOSTAGES
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 23  The 50 American hostages entered their eighth week of captivity today with no indication that their militant captors intended to release them in the foreseeable future.

title: Music: Dessoff Choirs
description: BIG, festive choral pieces suit the holiday season, and the Dessoff Choirs offered two of them Dec. 15 at Alice Tully Hall. The performances were spirited and generally did the music justice, the only major complaint being that the second and bigger of the two wasn't big enough.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ALL ABOUT EVE There is something reassuring about that traditional, holiday tree set in the middle of one of the city's bestknown pastoral clearings  venerable Washington Square. Again the public is invited to join in carol singing around the decorated branches starting tonight at 5:30. This year the informal singing will be led by the fourmember Waldo Park Brass Ensemble, and the children will receive candy canes.

title: Revised Pay Curb Demanded
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  In what amounts to an ultimatum, John T. Dunlop, chairman of the Administration's Pay Advisory Committee, has told the White House it must agree to recast the voluntary payrestraint standard, now 7 percent, as a numerical range instead of a single number.

title: Iona 54, Belmont Abbey 46
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y Dec. 23 (UPI)  Glenn Vickers scored 15 points to lead Iona College to a 5446 victory over Belmont Abbey today. The triumph raised the Gaels wonlost record to 52.

title: Mayor Byrne Taking Firm Grip on Chicago Democratic Machine
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 23  One morning last week, Mayor Jane M. Byrne, embroiled as she was in a crippling transit strike and an unyielding school financial crisis, summoned to breakfast the members of the Cook County Democratic Central Committee, the tough ward bosses of the venerable Chicago machine.

title: Air Florida's Push for Routes
description: MIAMI, Dec. 21  Air Florida, the darling of deregulation and a pioneer in cutrate unrestricted air fares, is making its move for the big time.

title: Art of Theodore Gericault Is Shown
description: PARIS

title: Primer on the City's New Tenant Fees
description: Last week, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board approved two kinds of temporary rent increases: a sixmonth fuel surcharge for the tenants of 300,000 rentstabilized apartments, and higher starting rents for new tenants moving into rentstabilized apartments during a fivemonth period next year.

title: Market Place
description: THE McDonald's Corporation is by all accounts one of the great concerns of the era, capitalizing as no other company has on the eatingout trend. The company's revenues will reach nearly $2 billion in 1979, which puts it high on the list of big companies. But it leads some to the conclusion that its era of super growth is over.

title: Jazz: Bob James 6 Times
description: LAST week, Bob James, a pianist, composer, arranger, record producer and president of his own record company, Tappan Zee Records, who has been one of the most successful crossover artists in recent years, gave a series of six concerts in four days in three different halls that showed three different aspects of his work.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1979
description: BUSINESS Digest

title: 2 Seized in City In Sale to Agents Of 10,000 Guns
description: Briefcase bombs, letter bombs, grenades, poison darts, dozens of firearms and scores of documents were seized over the weekend in simultaneous raids in New York City, Nutley, N.J., and Crewe, England, and criminal charges were filed against two men described by the Manhattan District Attorney as major international gunrunners.

title: Captive Deer Kills Keeper in Ohio
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 23 (AP) One of the deer kept on the grounds of the. Ohio Masonic Home apparently gored the home's administrator to death today, the authorities said. The victim was identified as Keith Bruster, 57 years old. A sheriff's spokesman said that he was apparently attacked by a large buck while feedings the animals.

title: Nordiques 3, Sabres 1
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 23 (UPI)  Jamie Hislop's shorthanded goal 1 minutes 10 seconds into the second period tonight helped carry the Quebec Nordiques to a 31 victory over the Buffalo Sabres. The Nordiques, winners of six of their last eight games, ended the Sabres threegame winning streak.

title: Brazil, Its Economy Sputtering, Is Hoping Tuneup Helps
description: BRASILIA  In a recent cartoon Brazil's head of state and his chief Cabinet officer are pictured from the rear as they address a political rally spread out beyond their pillared balcony.

title: 120 in Arizona to Be Evacuated While Asbestos Waste Is Cleared
description: GLOBE, Ariz., Dec. 23 (AP)  Gov. Bruce E. Babbitt asked all 120 residents of a mobile home subdivision today to evacuate their homes while the area is cleared of cancercausing asbestos waste.

title: Consumer Unit Asks U.S. to Act On CholesterolLowering Drug
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)  A consumer group asked the Food and Drug Administration today to prosecute a drug company for allegedly using false and misleading advertising on behalf of a potentially dangerous cholesterollowering compound.

title: FirstPlace Stars Go Second Class
description: THE 15seat bus rolled to a stop in the middle of an intersection, sputtered and died. The driver pointed down the dark, wintry street in Chicago. Three blocks ahead was a railroad trestle; two blocks to the left was the De Paul University gym. Without a word of complaint, the New York Stars and their coach, Dean Meminger, filed out and began walking.

description: LAKE PLACID

title: The City
description: Fifteen firefighters were treated at Jacobi Hospital after a fire in a Bronx store generated high levels of carbon monoxide early yesterday. One was admitted for several days of oxygen treatment.

title: Lakers 102, Sonics 97
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (AP)  Ka. reern AbdulJabbar scored 32 points and grabbed 14 rebounds tonight, leading the Los Angeles Lakers to a, 10297 victory over Seattle and into a virtual tie with the SuperSonics for first place in the NBA's Pacific Division.

title: Flyers Win, 42, and Extend String to 30
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) Brian Propp, a rookie forward, scored two goals and led Philadelphia to a 42 victory over the Hartford Whalers tonight, extending the Flyers record unbeaten streak in the National Hockey League to 30 games.

title: Beaths
description: GOTrLIEBDr. Moses L., formerly President of the Medical Board of Bronx Medical Hospital, a World War I I veteran, and resided at 4280 North Ocean Blvd., Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Beloved husband of Rose. Private services Menorah Chapels, Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Campbell Injury Appears Minor
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 23 The Houston Oilers next game will be against the Chargers at San Diego on Saturday,in the second round of the National Football League's postseason playoffs, and Earl Campbell, the invaluable Houston halfback, is expected to play.

title: Music: Christmas Capers
description: CHRISTMAS CAPERS is the name given to the Christmas program presented by the Ensemble for Early Music at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, and repeated on Friday and Saturday nights, and the program ends with what are called revels. Because capers and revels suggest merrymaking of a very lighthearted variety, these nouns do not really suggest the true nature of the Ensemble for Early Music's offerings.

title: 2 Disco FM Stations Top Ratings
description: Two FM disco stations  WBLS and WKTU  have been listed by the Arbitron rating service as the mostlistenedto stations in the New York metropolitan area. Figures from the service cover the OctoberNovember rating period and are estimates of how many people, 12 years or older, were listening to any of 42 area stations during any average quarter hour of a week.

title: Philadelphia's Taxi Service Is Slack as the City Revives
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24  Of the halfdozen people huddled against a piercing wind in front of the Reading Terminal, only one, the man from the Salvation Army, wanted to be there. After 10 minutes, an empty taxicab drove slowly by. The crowd waved as if the scene had been choreographed. The driver waved back and kept driving down Market Street.

title: Science Watch
description: A new technique for determining the age of fossils has been applied by the University of Rochester to the remains of a baby mammoth found in the Soviet Union two years ago.

title: West Germany Acts to Bar Agee
description: BONN, Dec. 24  West German authorities initiated efforts today to revoke the residency permit of a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, Philip Agee, following the United States State Department's cancellation of his passport.

title: OBSERVER
description: Instructions for assembling MOMMY AND DADDY, translated from the Japanese:

title: Market Place
description: HAS Santa left a promising stock market under the investor's tree this year? Four analysts think not. Of the three technical analysts and one economist reached yesterday, all noted that the market would be starting 1980 from a relatively high base  unless there is a serious setback for shares generally in the week ahead.

title: Nancy Berkule Married To R.C. Kuhn in Florida
description: The marriage of Nancy Berkule, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Liegh Abrams of Lauderhill, Fla., to Robert C. Kuhn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas G. Kuhn of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., took place in Miami Beach yesterday. Rabbi Sheldon Harr performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Bellock.

title: Few Poisons on Canadian Island
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP)  The Ontario Ministry of the Environment has found little evidence of poisonous chemical wastes on Fighting Island, an island in the Detroit River that Michigan officials fear could be contaminated, The Detroit News reported today. Companies have piped wastes from a plant in Wyandotte to the island in Canadian waters for more than 50 years, the newspaper said.

title: Sheathing the Sword in Rhodesia
description: One holiday blessing calls out to be counted. For the first Christmas in seven years, the guns are silent in Rhodesia; peace  or its reasonable facsimile prevails as a result of the accord signed Friday in London. But the next day, there was a terrorist shootup in Salisbury in which two were wounded. More scoresettling violence is likely before Rhodesia emerges as a legally independent country under a majorityrule constitution. If peace proves to be so fragile, then some may well ask: What, if anything, has the agreement achieved?

title: Entertainment Events
description: Films

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: International

title: What's in a Book Name? A Miffed Author
description: ST. PETER, Jersey  Harry Patterson, author of the bestselling The Eagle Has Landed and more than 40 other books, is used to a certain amount of confusion over his name. For Mr. Patterson  the given name on his birth certificate is actually Henry wrote Eagle and most of the other action novels that have made him worldfamous as Jack Higgins. He has also used such pseudonyms as James Graham, Martin Fallon and Hugh Marlowe.

title: At a Viennese Pawnshop, The Auction Is the Thing
description: VIENNA  Bad times are good times for pawnbrokers, although not normally good times for auction houses. But being both a thriving pawnshop and Central Europe's largest auction house has allowed the Dorotheum to weather Austria's bad times.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COUNTRY SIDE Few New Yorkers are more knowledgeable about Central Park than Marshall Wershaw, a former walkingtour guide for the Museum of the City of New York who now conducts park treks independently. The tours are popular safaris, with Mr. Wershaw imparting a commentary on new park sites and developments and background statistics going back to the park's origin in .1876, as designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux. Last Christmas, the Wershaw tour drew 120 walkers, and today's trek is expected to attract another enthusiastic crowd.

title: Chairman of State G.O.P. Dismisses Financial Chief
description: New York State's Republican Party, once supported by Nelson A. Rockefeller and his friends, is having such severe money problems that the party's finance chairman, Albert F. Gordon, was quietly dismissed last week by the Republican state chairman, Dr. Bernard Kilbourn.

title: St. Mark's Benefit Is Canceled
description: The annual St. Mark's Poetry Project benefit scheduled for next Tuesday has been canceled. It was to have been in the Entermedia Theater, but that theater's plans changed and it was impossible to find a new location on short notice and to advertise it properly. Sponsors held out hope that another St. Mark's benefit could be held on Valentine's Day or some later date.

title: Books of The Times
description: A HISTORY OF THE MACHINE. By Sigyard Strandh. 240 pages. Illustrated. A. & W. $35.

title: Volunteers in Chicao Fight Holiday Season Depression
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 24  More than 300 Chicagoans are spending Christmas week helping people whose holidays are full of loneliness or poverty or are struggling against alcohol, drugs or suicide.

title: Pilot License Suspension Is Sought in NearCrash
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (UPI) The Federal Aviation Administration announced today that it would seek to suspend for two months the license of the pilot of a small airplane that allegedly took off from Burbank Airport without clearance, barely avoiding a jetliner carrying 63 persons.

title: Irving M. Saunders, Hotel Owner Who Took Over Hilton in Boston
description: BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP)  Irving M. Saunders, a longtime hotel owner whose company recently took over the former Boston Statler Hilton and renamed it the Park Plaza, is dead at the age of 76.

title: Silver Surge Lures Stock Buyers, Too
description: WALLACE, Idaho, Dec. 19  Surging silver prices, pointing to record earnings for investors, have led to a shiny outlook for the silver mines of northern Idaho next year, and the glitter is drawing both stock buyers and corporate investors.

title: Bonn Curbing Utility Oil Use
description: BONN, Dec. 24 (AP)  West Germany hopes to eliminate the use of oil to generate electricity by the mid1980's, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today.

title: Astrodome Surface Faulted by Center
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 29  The synthetic turf of the Astrodome, the rug cursed by so many football players, was at fault for the injury suffered by Dan Pastorini, the Houston Oilers quarterback, in the 137 playoff victory over the Denver Broncos here yesterday, according to Carl Mauck, the Oilers outspoken center.

title: Zanuck Services Are Scheduled For Thursday on the West Coast
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif, Dec. 24 (UPI)  Funeral services will be held Thursday for Darryl F. Zanuck, cofounder of 20th CenturyFox.

title: Dorothy M. Kunhardt Dies at 78
description: Dorothy Meserve Kunhardt, an author of bestselling children's books who was also an acclaimed Lincoln scholar, died Sunday at the home of her daughter, Nancy Lodge, in Beverly, Mass. She was 78 years old and was a longtime resident of New York City and Morristown. N.J.

title: Soviet Gets a Hiroshima Protest
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  The Mayor of Hiroshima, Takeshi Araki, sent a note today to the Soviet Ambassador in Tokyo, Dmitri S. Polyansky, protesting a reported underground nuclear test yesterday in the Soviet Union. Mayor Araki has sent 37 similar protest notes so far this year  23 to the Soviet Union, 12 to the United States and one each to France and Britain.

title: Screen: 'Scavenger Hunt' Is a Comedy About Greed
description: The cast of "Scavenger Hunt" spends a lot of time searching for good gags, in vain. Sent out, in several greedy teams, to compete for the estate of a mean old moneybags (Vincent Price), they bring back five ostriches, a toilet, a beehive, a stuffed fish, and nothing funnier. Some of the film's more likable actors  Cleavon Little, James Coco, Robert Morley, Tony Randall, Scatman Crothers  behave as if the material were cleverer than it is, and their composure amounts to the movie's only real peculiarity. Otherwise, it's just a broad, low comedy full of speech defects and pratfalls. Here's pie in your eye.Cloris Leachman and Richard Benjamin, with Richard Masur as their idiot protege, play the villains; in this case, that just means they holler louder than the others. Roddy MacDowall, Cleavon Little and James Coco, as the dead tycoon's butler, chauffeur and cook, bring a little class to a movie that doesn't need any. Stephanie Faracy, who gave such a convincing performance as a plain, overweight waitress in "When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?" is transformed into a svelte Fifi the French Maid character, although in this case the name is Babbette. There are also a lot of brief cameo appearances, by Meat Loaf, Ruth Gordon and Arnold Schwarzenegger, among others, that could have been briefer."Scavenger Hunt," which opens today at the Embassy I and other theaters, was directed by Michael Schultz, whose talents don't seem entirely suited to the material. Mr. Schultz, also responsible for "Cooley High," "Car Wash" and "Greased Lightning," has previously been capable of more sharply honed work than the present material allows for. When a movie's jokes are so noticeably without punch lines, only a mood of uproarious confusion can save the day. Mr. Schultz takes an orderly approach that only makes the movie more of a mess."Scavenger Hunt" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains occasional harsh language.

title: Stealth, Quickness, Reflection, Life
description: It was once an American custom to go out on Christmas Day and shoot as many birds and beasts as possible. A hunt could get pretty bloody. A party might bring down a hundred geese, quail, pheasant  and a bear along the way. But around 1900, Frank Chapman, later chief ornithologist at the American Museum of Natural History, decided that these hunts had become excessive and, instead, he proposed a Christmas Day bird count. The idea caught on. In recent years, under Audubon Society auspices, phalanxes of amateurs have gone forth each Christmas and counted, by number and species, every bird they could find within a 15mile radius. And there are lots  of them, as Alfred Hitchcock had that old lady explain in The Birds.

title: Oranges: Brazil's Boom Crop
description: MATAO, Brazil  King Coffee has moved south, the cattle barons have ridden off into the West and the staple sugar cane that used to hug the hilly contours of this part of Brazil has been plowed under to make way for, of all humble things, the orange. Booming worldwide consumption has suddenly made Brazil the world's leading exporter of orange juice.

title: Climbers Report Finding Tracks That Could Be of the Snowman
description: LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP)  Members of a British mountainclimbing expedition said today that they had found footprints of what could be the Abominable Snowman and heard it scream during their climb up a Himalayan mountain.

title: New Musical to Open At the Hudson Guild
description: A new musical will open at the Hudson Guild Theater on Jan. 9 with the presentation by David Kerry Heefner, the group's producing director, of Snapshot, with music by Herb Kaplan and lyrics by Mitchell Bernard.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TransAtlantic

title: The New York Tunes/Edward Hausner
description: RUSSIANS PRACTICE FOR MEETING WITH THE RANGERS: Viadislav Tretiak, goalie for the Central Red Army hockey team, staving off attackers yesterday during practice at ice skating rink in Totowa, N.J. The Soviet team is preparing for game on Thursday with the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

title: After Delay, Shuttle Simulation Succeeds
description: Engineers and technicians working on the space shuttle at Cape Canaveral, Fla., took a brief holiday break this week. Once, they had had hopes that this would be a time to celebrate the first orbital test flight of their new and technologically challenging space ship, but that remains months away. They have had to settle for some more modest milestones of progress in a year otherwise marked by one frustrating

title: The Region
description: An administrative law judge of the National Labor Relations Board has ruled in a Long Island case that employees of a company and nonemployees have the right to solicit on company premises and in surrounding mall areas other employees to ioin a union

title: About New York
description: The feeling of an old New York Christmas breathes in Chelsea Square, the block occupied by the General Theological Seminary on Manhattan's West Side, between Ninth and 10th Avenues and 20th and 21st Streets.

title: N.B.A.'s Big Guns Unhappy and Unwanted
description: Bob Lanier wants to leave the Detroit Pistons. So does Bob McAdoo. Maurice Lucas is unhappy with the Portland Trail Blazers. Spencer Haywood sulked after Paul Westhead, the Los Angeles Lakers interim coach, had cut his playing time. Pete Maravich sits in Utah and waits for the Jazz to find a new place for him to play.

title: IRAN SEES SANCTIONS AS POSSIBLE BENEFIT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 24  On Iran's border with the Soviet Union, as many as 2,500 heavily loaded railway cars have been sidetracked, awaiting clearance to complete their journey from Europe to destinations in Iran.

title: Elevator Checks Found Wanting By Goldin Audit
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday that the Department of Buildings had failed to inspect elevators in New York City four times a year as mandated by law and that this had created a potential safety hazard in elevators throughout the city.

title: N.H.L. Launches Inquiry on Brawl
description: The National Hockey League began investigating yesterday the circumstances surrounding the postgame brawl between the Boston Bruins and fans at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night.

title: The City
description: The Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn, which expects to be unable to meet its payroll next week, asked the Federal Government yesterday for an immediate cash infusion, the hospital's executive director said.

title: Bidding Battle for Reinsurer
description: A bidding war for control of the ERC Corporation, one of the nation's biggest reinsurance companies, developed yesterday.

title: Frederick A. Travalena, Olympic Running Coach
description: Frederick A. Travalena Sr., a noted distance runner in the 1920's and coach of the United States runners and walkers at the 1948 Olympic Games, died yesterday of a heart attack in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: Road Record Buoys Them Against Bucs
description: Even for the Eagles, leaving Philadelphia is no hardship. The team that is beginning to think it is destiny's darlings must play the rest of the National Football League playoff season on the road, but that's all right.

title: Watkins Glen Grand Prix Hopes to Weather a Change in Dates
description: Will they love the Glen in April as they did in October?

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Dec. 24 (AP)  A Chinese court sentenced a Chinese activist today to two years in prison on a charge of violating public order.

title: GROUP USING TITHES TO FINANCE ITS WORK
description: Tithing. which reached its height in the Middle Ages, worked quite well for the Christian church for centuries. Now the Equal Justice Foundation has turned to the system for its support. It is the first national legal organization to do so.

title: Notes on People
description: Its followers say Zen is the way and it indeed appeared to be the way that Olga Bloom, the former concert violinist who runs the music barge under the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn Bridge, and the late Libby Holman, the 1930's torch singer who became a Reynolds Tobacco heiress after the death of her husband, have been connected. Bargemusic Ltd. has just received $10,000 from the Libby Holman Foundation  well above Mrs. Bloom's previous major grants of $4,000 from the city and $2,000 from the State Council on the Arts.

title: West German Bonuses Are Built In
description: BONN, Dec. 24  Last month, in the midst of frenzied negotiations to rescue AEGTelefunken, the lossridden West German electronics company, Telefunken's 125,000 employees received a Christmas bonus in their paychecks. It totaled between 10 and 50 percent of one month's wa2es.

title: Pop: Rosemary Clooney Gives Her First New York Solo in 20 Years
description: Rosemary Clooney made her first solo appearance in New York in 20 years on Sunday when she gave three performances at Ted Hook's OnStage, a new restaurant and cabaret at 349 West 46th Street.

title: Britons Begin Rhodesia Truce Duty Apprehensively
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 24 Capt. Richard Hodson sat in a rainsoaked tent at the airport here today reading The Times of London and reflecting on the hazardous task that lies before him and hundreds of other Commonwealth soldiers who will monitor the Rhodesian ceasefire.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5103, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10240, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Car Production to Fall Further
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP)  United States auto makers have cut production schedules for the first three months of next year by another 11 percent to the lowest point in five years, a trade publication reported today.

title: Revue: Singers Carry This Song
description: Richard Burke has written almost a dozen songs for a musical revue called I've Got This Song that is playing on Sunday evenings at the Duplex, 55 Grove Street. But it is more important to his revue that he also got a couple of performers, Julie Kurnitz and Ira Siff, who can fulfill his better material and give a lift to his lesser songs.

title: Michael J. O'Neill Is Dead at 83; Executive in Ford Tractor Sales
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24 (UPI)  Michael J. O'Neill, a longtime executive in the tractor operations of the Ford Motor Company, died Friday at a suburban Grosse Pointe hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Seeks FullTime Court Coach
description: TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 24 (AP)  Athletic Director Stan Wright of Fairleigh Dickinson University says he will seek a fulltime basketball coach for the 198081 season. Al LoBalbo, who teaches in the Belleville school system, has coached Fairleigh on a parttime basis since 1969.

title: Texas Experiments Indicate Sulfur Is Useful in RoadSurfacing Mixes
description: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 24  Unwanted sulfur from a variety of chemical processes may soon be in great demand as a roadbuilding ingredient.

title: RADAR POST TO AID AIR TRAFFIC SAFETY
description: With near collisions in the skies around New York showing an unnerving increase, officials are awaiting with special urgency the first use next month of a $25 million automated radar control facility in Garden City, L.I.

title: Couple, 77, Must Live In Two Nursing Homes
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP)  After 57 years of marriage, Imogene and Aubrey Cash are separated. They did not want it that way; they just could not find space in the same nursing home.

title: In Bethlehem, Faiths Play Out Ancient Story
description: BETHLEHEM, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Dec. 24  In the shady, sundappled cloister of the Franciscan monastery adjoining the grotto where Jesus is believed to have been born 1,979 years ago, three Americanmade M16 automatic rifles were stacked like a tripod.

title: Jury Investigates Activities of Two Held in Gun Sale
description: A Federal grand jury in Washington is investigating the activities of two men arrested in New York City last Saturday and charged with attempting to sell 10,000 machine guns to city detectives posing as Latin American revolutionaries.

title: Oregon State Confirms Rule Violation
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Dec. 24 (AP) Oregon State University confirmed today that its football team used an ineligible player in all 11 games during the 1979 season.

title: Carter to Seek $615 Billion Budget With $15 Billion Deficit, Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 24  President Carter has decided on a budget of at least $615 billion with a deficit of $15 billion for the next fiscal year, somewhat higher than the Administration had been hoping for, Government officials disclosed today.

title: Soviet Hints Disapproval Of Sanctions on Iranians
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 23  The Soviet Government today indicated its disapproval of the American effort to have the United Nations Security Council impose economic sanctions against Iran.

title: JUDGE ORDERS HALT TO FIRE JOB ACTION
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 24 (AP)  A judge ordered an immediate end today to a firefighters job action that has resulted in one of every nine firefighters being discharged or given a delayed suspension.

title: World Gold
Gregg Eyes N.F.L. Post, Asks Toronto for Release
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 (AP)  Forrest Gregg says he does not know whether he will be released from his contract with the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League to return to the National Football League.

title: Fighter in Coma After Knockout
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C., Dec. 24 (AP)  Tony Thomas, a 20yearold Spartanburg middleweight who incurred head injuries during a fourround bout here Saturday night, was in critical condition today.

title: Europe's Booster Rocket Is Fired After 3 Failures
description: PARIS, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  Western Europe's Ariane booster rocket lifted off successfully today from the Kourou space center in French Guiana.

title: At Ngong Hills, Africa's Heart Beats Strongly
description: AT THE TOP OF THE NGONG HILLS, Kenya, Dec. 24 I had a farm in Africa, at the foot of the Ngong Hills.

title: EDUCATION
description: A panel of distinguished professors has conducted an unusual departmentbydepartment analysis of the arts and sciences at Columbia University, pinpointing weaknesses that threaten the institution's excellence and raising searching questions about the future.

title: Man Wanted in Deaths Returned
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 24 (AP)  A man wanted in the fatal shooting of three elderly Philadelphians was taken back to Pennsylvania today to face murder charges. The authorities said that Alfonso Faulkner, 31 years old, was taken by Philadelphia detectives after waiving extradition proceedings in Clinton County Court. He had been arrested Saturday at the Champlain, N.Y., border post trying to enter the country from Canada. A murder warrant was issued for him Nov. 28 after three persons were killed and a fourth wounded by gunfire outside a North Philadelphia church.

title: 4 CLERGYMEN HOLD CHRISTMAS SERVICES FOR IRAN HOSTAGES
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Tuesday, Dec. 25 Three American clergymen and the Frenchborn Roman Catholic Archbishop of Algiers held Christmas services and spent nearly five hours with American hostages in the United States Embassy in Teheran last night and early today.

title: Imports Pass Ford In Sales
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24  This was the year that imports pushed their way into the No. 2 spot in the American automobile sales rankings, surpassing the Ford Motor Company and trailing only the General Motors Corporation in a market that was once dominated by domestic producers.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Some Chicago Democrats Shift To Uncommitted Delegate Roles
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP)  Several Cook County Democratic leaders have switched gears and say they plan to run as uncommitted delegates to the party's national convention next year despite the Democratic organization's endorsement of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: SUDDENLY John Reed became drowsy and forgetful. At age 84, he had been alert, read the newspapers, and was able to care for himself and walk around his nursing home. Now that he had become confused, attendants put him to bed. The next day he became even less communicative. A nurse stuck a thermometer in his mouth. He had no fever. His physician examined hini and found no change in Mr. Reed's heart condition or the arteriosclerotic damage to his legs. Blood tests showed that his diabetes was not out of control.

title: Neediest Cases Aided by Family Of L.I. Child Who Had Surgery
description: The family of a West Hempstead, L.I., girl who underwent thyroid surgery this year has sent $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: A Noble Uncertainty
description: Our journalistic problem with Christmas is that it commemorates a colossal triumph of history over news. When Christ was born almost two millenniums ago in a small Jewish town in the Middle East, hardly anyone noticed that something stupendous had happened. Decades passed before the significance of the event was absorbed into human experience. The Bethlehem bureau really missed the story, and the editors of the day never even knew it.

title: Iran Reports Execution Of a Military Governor
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 24 (AP)  The Teheran radio announced that retired Maj. Gen. Esmail Estahrom was executed tonight in Ivin Prison after the Teheran Islamic revolutionary court had confirmed his death sentence.

title: For Now, the Baluchis Hold Their Fire
description: ZAHIDAN, Iran, Dec. 24  Suddenly, in a movement that was both theatrical and startling, Mohammed Mirza rose to his full six feet, raised his rifle above his turbaned head, and said: Unless they get out of here fast, I promise you there will be more bloodshed. They have no business being here. This is the homeland of the Baluchis and they have suppressed us long enough.

title: Girl, 16, Jailed On Traffic Fines, Commits Suicide
description: A 16yearold girl who was serving a 55day jail sentence because she could not raise the money to pay $170 in traffic. fines hanged herself last Friday in the Albany County jail. An inquest is expected to be held this week.

title: Chattanooga Names Oliver New Head Football Coach
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 24 (UPI)  Bill Oliver, an assistant coach the last nine years under Paul (Bear) Bryant at Alabama, was named head football coach today at the University of Tennessee, Chattanooga.

title: COMPANY NEWS

title: Three School Days, Two Work Days

To anyone aware of the 45 percent dropout rate in New York City's high schools, that observation in a recent report by the Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education is hardly a surprise. What's more, inferior education knows no rigid racial bounds. The dropout rate for lowincome white students exceeds that of poor blacks, and their unemployment rates are roughly the same.

title: Inquiry on Recruit's Death Ends
description: FORT DIX, N.J. Dec. 24 (AP)  The Army has concluded that it was not responsible for the death of a recruit who collapsed during a 10mile training march last summer. A Fort Dix spokesman said that the 18yearold soldier, Pvt. Lawson D. Hileman of Clarksburg, w. va., apparently died because he had myocarditis, a mild inflammation of the heart and lungs, which was aggravated by heat and physical activity. In a report obtained by The Philadelphia Inquirer, some other recruits had said that Private Hileman had been kicked by a drill sergeant, but the spokesman denied that, while acknowledging that the sergeant had used his knee as a getalong.
