title: Movie: 3 Widowers Try 'Going in Style'
description: Joe (George Burns), Al (Art Carney) and Willie (Lee Strasberg), three elderly widowers, share an apartment in Queens and an existence in which the arrival of a Consolidated Edison bill becomes an occasion  it's something to argue about. Each day is like every other. They sit around and stare at the walls or, if the weather is nice, they amble to the park.Surprisingly, because he is a retired taxicab driver, Willie is the most passive one of the group. He's also infinitely polite. Whatever anyone says is all right by Willie. Al is the occasional joker and Joe has the brains. One day when Joe suggests they stick up a bank, Willie and Al agree. As Joe points out, they can't lose. If they succeed, they'll be rich. If they're caught, they'll receive, at most, three years in jail, during which time they'll live off the Government while their Social Security checks accumulate."Going in Style," a first commercial feature written and directed by Martin Brest, means to be both moving and comic, but though the cast is headed by three fine actors, two of whom, Mr. Burns and Mr. Carney, are also extremely funny men, it never elicits any emotional response more profound than curiosity. There are isolated moments that are amusing  the bank holdup, a brief spree at the Las Vegas gaming tables, some lines delivered by Mr. Burns ("If that kid eats any more jelly doughnuts, they'll have to take him to kindergarten in a moving van"). The lower-middle-class milieu is nicely observed through Billy Williams's photography.Mostly, "Going in Style," which opens today at the Sutton and other theaters, is as uneventful as the lives it records. Death stalks these characters not like the Grim Reaper, but like a bored meter reader.Here is a movie that might well have been helped had its three stars refused to act so legitimately. Their material isn't good enough for them, which is particularly apparent when Mr. Brest reaches for pathos. At one point, Mr. Strasberg throws everything he knows about acting into a monologue about a dead son, but our interest is less emotional than clinical."Going in Style" is so humdrum I suspect it could only interest people whose outlooks are even more so. Perhaps the recently departed."Going in Style," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes some vulgar language.

title: Japanese Stage Shopping Spree For Christmas
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24 They deck the aisles with boughs of holly, and in the central area of the department store, where it can hardly be missed by customers entering from the street, a papiermitche Santa Claus beams from a limb of a huge plastic tree. Signs say Merry Christmas in English.

title: Hawaiian Birds Endangered
description: KAUAI, Hawaii  Although the birds of Hawaii are said to be among those hardest hit by extinction, this island has until recently remained an avian paradise. Now, however, the battle for survival is on, and 18 species are classed as endangered.

title: Kidney Transplant 25 Years Ago Opened Era
description: Twentyfive years ago, a young Massachusetts man who was near death received from his twin brother one of the strangest but most welcome Christmas presents ever given. It was the gift of a living kidney, accomplished through the first successful transplantation of a vital organ from one human to another. To Richard Herrick, the person who received the kidney from his brother, Ronald, it was the gift of seven more years of life. For the world at large it proved to be an even greater gift, leading to the saving of many thousands of lives and the opening of important new vistas for medical science.

title: Surgery Is Looming For Simms
description: Phil Simms, the Giants quarterback, will be examined early next month to determine if he needs an operation to repair sprained ligaments in the thumb of his throwing hand. He hit his right thumb on the helmet of an Atlanta Falcon player during a game on Nov. 11 and struggled through the final weeks of the season.

We shall long remember his kindness and concern for his fellow man. Sincerest condolences are extended to his beloved wife Celia and family.

title: Financing Education

While school enrollments and the number of teachers have fallen sharply, the number of school administrators has risen distinctly. As a result, more money, in real terms, than ever before is being spent on public education but with a questionable positive impact; the results in almost all standardized test and other achievement indicators are lower for the average pupil than they were 10 years ago.

title: A Glossary of Herring; Schmaltz (fat) herring

Sometimes used for pickling, frying or baking, though it is classically eaten taken from the brine and soaked in water for one to three hours, then filleted and served with sliced or chopped onions, boiled potatoes and perhaps black bread. Schmaltz herring is generally softcured in salt and sugar.

I'm sure she would want to contribute to such a worthy cause.

description: BOSTON, Dec. 25 (AP)  The Old Corner Bookstore, which served as a meeting place for Hawthorne, Emerson, Thoreau and other 19thcentury authors, is out of business after 151 years as a Boston landmark.

title: Deatha

title: TURKISH CITY CENTER OF TERRORIST ACTION

We're not hysterical, but we have to be careful, says Cetin Remzi Yuregir, owner of the local newspaper. Violence has become almost a way of life.

title: 29 Dead in Peruvian Air Crash
description: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 25 (Reuters) All 29 people on a Peruvian Air Force plane were killed when it crashed Saturday in a jungle east of here, aviation authorities said today. The propellor craft was on a special flight to a point near the Brazilian border. The wreckage was spotted Sunday and the bodies were recovered yesterday.

title: Brown Assails Neglect In Relief for Cambodia
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 (AP)  At Christmas morning sendoff of an airlift of emergency supplies to Cambodia, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California criticized the State Department for quietly standing by while tens of thousands of people are starving to death in Cambodia.

title: Economic Scene
description: Dim Oil Hopes, Vivid Dangers

title: Associated Press
description: WINTER STORM RAVAGES PACIFIC COAST: Three men worked to free truck from floodwaters on the California coast at Pillar Point after storm passed over the area, washing trimaran on shore and flooding highways. The storm, carrying snow, rain and high winds, was blamed for at least two deaths, road closings and power outages.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia and Indonesia look at each other across the narrow gap of the Timor Sea in almost perfect misunderstanding, which at times can have serious implications. Neither country has ever really understood what the other is about.

title: Year's 1,700 Homicides Break a Record
description: Grim and heartless as it sounds, it was ust another murder.

title: Overregulating the Regulators
description: Congress is attacking the regulatory agencies with a vengeance. The heaviest fire during the session just ended was directed at the Federal Trade Commission, which has moved too vigorously to suit some industries and their Congressional allies. But the antiregulatory spirit spread even further. Congress, for example, passed legislation to exempt many planes from noise regulations, the House voted to give Congress veto power over pesticide controls, and the Senate acted to weaken enforcement of strong stripmining rules. Before this cascade turns into a rampage, Congress had better consider the damage it may do and the problems that it could bring upon itself.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IT is inevitably true that any food column will inherently reflect the taste and cravings of the author. It is certainly true in this column. I have often noted that some of the foods presented here are those directly related to my childhood in Burgundy, or dishes that impressed me mightily when I was only a practicing chef many years ago.

title: Idahoans Have Faith in Judge on Rights Amendment
description: BOISE, Idaho  The fact that a highranking official of the Mormon Church is also the Federal judge hearing a major challenge to the proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution has caused a considerable upset among feminists around the country. But in this small, southwestern Idaho city, where people know Federal District Judge Marion J. Callister, there is little alarm or indignation.

title: China Says Its Rising Juvenile Crime Stems From Cultural Revolution
description: PEKING, Dec. 25  The Ministry of Public Security has disclosed that China has 10 times more juvenile delinquency now than in the early 1960's.

title: Queen Hails Rhodesia Accord
description: LONDON, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  Queen Elizabeth II, in her annual Christmas message, paid tribute today to Commonwealth leaders for their achievement last week in laying the basis for a Rhodesia settlement.

title: Smiley Quick, 70
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) Smiley Quick, who tied for first place in the 1958 Bing Crosby proamateur golf tournament, died at his home last Sunday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: A Village of World Athletes And of Local Controversy
description: RAY BROOK, N.Y., Dec. 25  There will be a touch of snowy surrealism about life in Olympic Village, the madetoorder town where more than 1,900 athletes will spend one month in the middle of nowhere in the middle of winter.

title: Marcos Moving to Ease Detention of Key Critic
description: MANILA, Dec. 25  President Ferdinand E. Marcos was reported today by official and opposition sources to have ordered house arrest for his chief rival, former Senator Benigno S. Aquino, at his home in a Manila suburb.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: ONE of the truths the nouvelle cuisine has hammered home with its dogmatic use of colors is that the appearance of food can be as significant as its taste. We all knew that, of course. But it's important to be reminded of It every now and then so that a dish on the verge of being ordinary can  with a decorative touch that manages not to be precious  be rescued and carried across the line into loveliness.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Rock Tape Becomes a Pioneer Opera
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25A dozen performers from some of the Bay Area's better known rock bands came together recently in a rare collaboration of musical talent. The result, a rock opera called Rock Justice, has captivated local critics.

title: Rep. Hansen Embarks On Second Trip to Iran
description: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Representative George Hansen, Republican of Idaho, criticized by the Carter Administration last month for his personal attempt to gain release of the 50 hostages at the American Embassy in Iran, is embarking on a similar effort again.

title: A Gift for Any Christmas
description: Sports of The Times

title: The City
description: 7,000 V. A. Workers Don't Get Paychecks

title: Abrams Acts to Deter Gouging on Heating Oil Cost
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams announced measures yesterday to implement recent New York State laws designed to protect users of home heating oil from price gouging and other unfair practices.

title: Boy, 3, and Mother Die in Fire
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 25 (AP) Cindy Davis, 24 years old, and her 3year old son, Strisand, died here in an accidental fire on Christmas morning. Their bodies were found in their beds in their apartment at 501 West Third Street when firefighters arrived at 4:16 A.M., said Fire Chief Edward Ingraham.

title: Humble Herring: A Plump Delicacy With a Rich Past
description: ALTHOUGH herring lacks the aura of elegance that surrounds deepsea luxuries such as salmon, sturgeon and caviar, in many countries that humble fish shares top honors with the costlier delicacies on New Year's Eve party tables. Fat and juicy silverblue herrings, made satiny in salt or sugar cures, then marinated to firm and spicy succulence inspire the most serious connoisseurship in Scandinavia, Holland, Northern Germany, Russia and parts of Central Europe, and are also much appreciated in Ireland, Scotland and England.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I am in a quandary when it comes to homemade bread. My kitchen during the winter months is always cool or cold and not warm enough, Im afraid, for letting the dough rise. Do you have any suggestions?

title: Athletes in Action Lose To Soviet Five, 10487
description: MADRID, Dec. 25 (AP)  An allstar Soviet squad defeated Athletes in Action, 10487, tonight in a Christmas basketball tournament.

title: Books: A View of Asia
description: FOR a young correspondent arriving in Asia in 1968, a call on Bob Shaplen at his base in Hong Kong was as mandatory as clearing customs or applying for press credentials. He had already been there, in one capacity or another, for 24 years, and his reporting in The New Yorker was incomparably the best coming out of a troubled and turbulent corner of the world. Once at a dinner on the broad veranda of the Repulse Bay Hotel, with the lights of the yachts and junks twinkling on the water below, the intensity of his absorption with Asia came through in every sentence.

title: Troubles m Iran Kindle Demand for Fallout Shelters Made by Texan
description: DALLAS, Dec. 25 Business had gone downhill for Jerry Poarch since the Cuban missile crisis and the height of the cold war.

title: Gas in City Rises to $1.20, New Increases Predicted
description: Another round of gasoline price increases was predicted yesterday by representatives of the petroleum industry, gasoline retailers and consumer advocates, just as motorists began paying prices increased last week to an average of $1.20 a gallon at New York City pumps.

title: In South Korea, Brighter Looks Over Christmas
description: SEOUL, Dec. 25  Truth Muoi, a Vietnamese mother of four small girls by her Korean husband, whom she met when he worked in Vietnam during the war, lives in a shack, a kind of cement blister, on the hills outside Seoul. The place is to be torn down in three months and once the dry but bitter winter is over, she will have to move again.

title: The Lone Survivor of Paris's Soup Kitchens
description: PARIS

title: Deaths
description: AUGENHarry, beloved husband of the late Jennie, loving father of Mrs. Nina Solinger. Dear brother of Eddie. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Service Wednesday 12:30 PM at the Westchester Riverside, 21 West Broad St, Mt. Vernon NY

title: The Danger of Dumping the Mentally I11
description: Many New Yorkers and others are saying that the Berwid case, in which a mental patient free on a pass reportedly killed his wife, is further proof that the program to treat the mentally ill in local communities is a bad one. We think they are wrong. What the Berwid case illustrates is that some hospital officials aren't taking good care of their patients. They are being careless, andso is the state that employs them. Careless is also the word for the way state hospitals have been dumping even their most peaceful charges. As a result, the entire program of deinstitutionalization  a sound and humane idea  is in danger of being discredited.

title: U.S. Plan Aids Computer Use
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)  The Commerce Department has established a new program intended to help the Federal, state and local governments to compare notes on computer technologies.

title: Bratlys
description: KAPLANHoward. On December 24, 1979. Beloved husband of Iris (Broverman). Devoted father of Anthony E. and James F. Dear brother of Justin of Cambridge, Mass. Service Wednesday, 1PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Please omit flowers. A contribution to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Close to a Jogger's Heart

title: 6 Lost as Greek Ship Sinks
description: ATHENS, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  Six crewmen of the Greek cargo ship Soula G were feared drowned when the ship sank in heavy seas off the east coast of Greece, a spokesman for the Greek Merchant Marine Ministry said today. One member of the crew of seven was picked up by a rescue helicopter.

title: Comdie Franaise Rustling Dusty Bustle
description: PARIS. Dec. 25  The Comdie Franaise, now on the eve of its 300th anniversary, raised some eyebrows here last week when it unveiled the latest play by the controversial Spanish playwright, Fernando Arrabal. The company's first outing with Mr. Arrabal, entitled The Tower of Babel, gave the startled audience a scabrous, scatalogical analogy to modern Spain, peopled by a sadomasochist amputee, a donkey from Mars, a whipbrandishing nun and a transvestite count.

title: Finding the Best Herring in New York
description: RESEARCH for this article was done at the processing plants of three of the leading herring wholesalers in the city : Nova Scotia Food Products Inc. and the Marshall Smoked Fish Company in Brooklyn, as well as in the Philadelphia plant of the Montrose Smoked Fish Company, whose executive offices are also in Brooklyn. All of the processing in these plants was similar, the biggest differences being in the sauces and brines used. These companies sell herring all ways  cured and barreled, pickled in various sauces, in institutional pails for appetizer stores, delicatessens and restaurants and in jars with their own or private labels. All companies preferred the bestquality herring such as the Icelandic and Norwegian but admitted to using the best they could get at any given time. This means that quality varies. To counteract that as much as possible, I bought several samples from each retail source over a fourweek period and the evaluations here represent a synthesis of my findings.

title: Opera: The Met Stages Dual Hansel and Gretel
description: HUMPERDINCK'S Hansel and Gretel is as much an operatic tradition at Christmas time as Parsifal is at Easter. The Metropolitan rarely lets a year go by without presenting each opera during the appropriate season, and, sure enough, Hansel returned to the repertory for a Christmas doubleheader on Monday and last nights, each performance with a different cast of principals.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TALE OF TWO CITIES Word is enthusiastic about the family holiday entertainment now concluding at the 92d Street Y, near Lexington Avenue. Titled The Lost Fairy Tale, the 75minute program of song, dance, magic specialties, films and slide projections is a stage fantasy of reported appeal for all ages, as performed by members of the Young People's Theater of Toronto. Curtain times are 1 and 7 P.M. at the concluding performances today and tomorrow, and admission at the door is $5.

title: Letters
description: Wrong Way to Spur Cambodian Relief Efforts

title: Bridge:
description: When bidding screens were introduced on occasions of high importance five years ago, players had mixed feelings. To have no visual contact with one's partner during the bidding, and very little during the play, seemed strange. For some it seemed too high a price to pay to assure that a tiny minority would be prevented from cheating.

title: State Plans Study on Power Line
description: ALBANY, Dec. 25 (AP)  Two state agencies have agreed in principle to conduct a detailed study of the hazards that a 765kilovolt power line, which runs through northern New York, might present to persons and animals near it.

title: Joan Blondell, Actress, Dies at 70; Often Played Wisecracking Blonde
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) Joan Blondell, the movie and television actress, died of leukemia today. She was 70 years old and had been hospitalized for several weeks. At her bedside were her son, Norman Powell, a television producer; her daughter, Ellen Powell ; and her sister, Gloria.

title: Deaths
description: BOULARDGrace M. Survived by her loving cousins Alfred Boulard, Jr. and Elizabeth DrIng. Services Thursday at Woodworth Chapel, Woodlawn Cemetery 3PM.

title: Hostage's Christmas Wish: No Sad Faces
description: KRAKOW, Mo., Dec. 25  Toni Sickmann sat reading and rereading the letter from her son Rocky, temporarily oblivious to the exclamations of her four other children and three childreninlaw and the squeals of her six grandchildren as Santa Claus handed them presents last night.

title: PRONUCLEAR GROUPS SEEK CITIZEN ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  Utilities, reactor manufacturers and engineering companies committed to expanding the use of nuclear energy following the accident at the Three Mile Island power plant have started an ambitious information program aimed at convincing Americans of the comparative safety of nuclear power.

title: Asher Penn, ExForward Editor And Author of Book on U.S. Jews
description: Asher Penn, a former feature writer and city editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, and the author of Judaism in America, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hopital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and had lived at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan.

title: A New Holtzman Push
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  When Elizabeth Holtzman presides over her House of Representatives subcommittee, she does so with Emanuel Celler looking out from a portrait and over her shoulder.

title: Private Lives
description: THE columnist came back from jury duty, as if from military school or a monastic retreat, to find that the old year was almost used up. The year didnt bother him so much; there is always another year.

title: News of the Theater
description: CIRCLE in the Square, which almost went out of business last spring because of severe financial problems, is finally making plans for a new season that will start in February. Instead of opening the new season in the fall, as usual, the management of the 29yearold theater has extended the run of Loose Ends, which has been playing since the close of last season, to save money on new productions and to concentrate on straightening out the theater's fisnances. Loose Ends will close at the end of next month.

title: Portland, Ore., Asks Court to Bar Data on Alleged Police Brutality
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 25 (AP)  The city of Portland and the Portland Police Association have asked a circuit court to block the release of reports on allegations of police brutality.

title: Personal Health
description: AS cold weather descends upon much of the country and the humidity drops indoors and out  sometimes to the level of the Sahara Desert  skin gets dry and itchy, lips chap and mouths and throats become parched. Many blame their propensity for wintertime colas ana coughs on the discomforting dryness of winter air. And in the wake of the energy crunch, humidifying indoor air has been promoted as a means of increasing comfort at lower room temperatures.

title: 2 Railroad Workers Hurt in Crash
description: FIRTH, Neb., Dec. 25 (AP)  Two Burlington Northern railroad employees were injured today in the collision of two empty coal trains. W.A. Smith, 56 years old, of Lincoln, a conductor on the lead train, which was struck from the rear, was listed as in critical condition. Pat Linder, 28, of St. Joseph, Mo., a brakeman, was listed as in fair condition.

title: Bolivia Appears Normal Again but Threats of a Takeover Linger
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 22  Trucks laden with food are once again groaning up the steep cobblestoned streets that were recently emptied by a military coup and a subsquent general strike.

title: Disks: Slabtown's Jazz
description: TWENTY years ago Wilbur de Paris led a jazz band, which he called his New New Orleans Jazz Band. It had a rugged,

title: Will Easing of Mortgages Spur Loans in New York?
description: News Analysis

title: The New York Times/Edward Hausner
description: It was their first Christmas in the city. Three months ago when Sharon and David Lewis had come up to New York from Atlanta they had it all figured out: They would find a loft, fix up and then David would paint brillantly while he waited to be discovered.

title: Notes on People
description: For some of them, it will probably be the first time they've crossed the East River, said an employee of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. She was one of those preparing materials  including maps of the Brooklyn's main business area and lists of recommended restaurants  to assist the members of the academy's new theater company who will assemble there today, for the first time, for orientation and rehearsal.

title: Australian Coal Exports Due to Expand
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 25  As the price of oil keeps spiraling, Australian coal exports, currently No. 3 worldwide behind the United States and Poland, are poised for a major expansion.

title: Risk of Fatal Cancer Is Assessed As Tiny in Smoke Detector Study
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has issued a report that assesses as small the risk of fatal cancer from radioactive material in smoke detectors.

title: Stop That Song
description: New Jersey has no official state song. So last week the State Assembly approved a bill directing the State Council on the Arts to hold a contest to choose one. The reason for a contest, we suspect, may be the Assembly's desire to block a proposed song that they fear already has too much support. It is called I'm From

title: TEXAN PLANS SEARCH OF WRECKED TITANIC
description: ABILENE, Tex., Dec. 25 (AP)  A Texas oilman who tracked the sasquatch, an immense apelike creature, in Canada and sought the Loch Ness monster in Scotland has charted a course for the icy depths of the Atlantic Ocean and the wreck of the Titanic.

title: BusDriving Santa Suspended
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 25 (UPI) Gary Van Ryswyk, a bus driver, has been suspended indefinitely for wearing a Santa Claus suit at work despite orders not to do so. An official of the Metropolitan Transit Commission, Gary Abel, said that the driver had violated the commission's dress code by wearing a red hat and fake white whiskers on his job. He said that there might be dire consequences, if an exception were made. What might happen at Halloween? he asked.

title: Yemen Deal for Mitsubishi
description: TOKYO, Dec. 25 (Reuters) Japan's Mitsubishi Corporation And the Rinkai Construction Company have won a joint $31 million contract to build a port facility at the Yemen Arab Republic's town of Hodeidah, on the Red Sea coast, Mitsubishi said here today. The Japanese companies will start construction in January and the project is to be completed in October 1981.

title: Boxer Still on Critical List
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C., Dec. 25 (UPI)  Tony Thomas, a middleweight boxer, remained in critical condition today with a head injury resulting from a fourthround knockout Saturday night.

title: Market Place
description: Effect of Finds On Oil Shares

title: Higher Output Of Coal Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)  The National Coal Association has predicted that the nation's coal production will reach a record 776 million tons in 1980, a 2.6 percent increase over this year's level. The increase will come mainly west of the Mississippi River, it said.

title: BLACKS NOT RUSHING TO SUPPORT KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  When Senator Edward M. Kennedy challenged President Carter for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination, it was widely believed that American blacks, once considered one of the most monolithic voting groups, would rush to his support.

title: Text of Statement by U. S. Clergymen
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 25 (UPI) Following is the text of the statement issued by three American clergymen after their visit with the hostages at the United States Embassy here:

title: U.S. Networks Won't Air Hostage Film
description: The Iranians holding the United States Embassy in Teheran yesterday offered the three American television networks an hourlong film of the meetings between four clergymen and the 43 hostages, but all three networks refused to carry it.

title: On New Year's Eve, The Chefs Feast
description: IAM passionately fond of New Year's Eve. I love that night like a warm blanket, a roaring log fire and an extra dry martini. It is the only festival at the year's end about which I am sentimental. It is a time of abandon and forgetfulness, good will, good wine and good food. In times past, when I have been bearably poor, I have on that one night felt colossally rich, the grandest of pashas, the epicure's epicure.

title: Deaths
description: PARETRutus Story of Larchmont, beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Howard), devoted father of Ursula Marlorie Cunningham and Marguerite Frances Paret, fond grandfather of Cobv Sue, Lauren Mary, Devin Druce Cunningham and Russell Rathbun Paret. The family will receive friends 10AM11AM in the Chapter Room, St. Johns Episcopal Church on Thursday where services will be held at 11AM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: Egyptians Undertake Major Restoration of Sphinx
description: CAIRO, Dec. 25  The Great Sphinx of Giza, guardian of the Pyramids, is being shored up with limestone blocks in the most extensive repairs since the Romans worked on it more than 2,000 years ago.

title: EQUATORIAL GUINEA WARMS UP TO SPAIN
description: MADRID, Dec. 25  A bold and risky visit by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia to the former Spanish colony of Equatorial Guinea appears to have given Madrid a major role in shaping the future of the African nation, which until last summer had been largely under Soviet influence.

title: Single Phone Network Is Proposed For 14'0 U.S. Agencies in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  The General Services Administration, the central purchasing agent for the Federal Government, is trying to link the 240,000 telephones of 140 separate agencies into one huge new system, but critics in Congress, in other agencies and in the procurement system itself say that the multimilliondollar project is unnecessary and violates Federal procurement rules.

title: Dollar Dips in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26 (AP)  The dollar was down slightly against the yen today after rising almost one yen yes. terday to close at 239.50, up from Monday's 238.55. Today's opening rate was 239.30 yen, and the dollar dipped in light early trading to 238.80. Dealers said trading was quiet on Christmas Day, not a national holiday in Japan.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: In keeping with the spirit of the Christmas season, the National Audubon Society, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and other agencies earlier this month initiated a program designed to save America's largest soaring bird, the California condor, from extinction.

title: For Mrs. Gandhi, Test in Nehru Country
description: BALEMAU, India, Dec. 23 The candidate, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, was late, but no one in this onestreet hamlet seemed to mind. It was a festive Sunday morning and there was really no where else to go.

title: Man With a Rifle and a Message Is Seized in Siege of Mason Hall
description: MANCHESTER, Mass., Dec. 25 (AP) A 33yearold unemployed physical therapist who said he wanted to tell the world that Masons kill people was grabbed by the police today after he took over a Mason hall at gunpoint.

title: European Allies Are Getting Major New Weapons
description: Eleven European members of the Atlantic alliance will add 11,270 weapons to their armaments in 1980, including two types of fighter planes.

title: Private Investigator, the Shamus Revisited
description: IT was in midtown Manhattan, one of those new highrises where the lobby rug is so thick you trip over it and the walls are so thin you can hear the plumbing rusting. The office was on the 21st floor, at the end of a long corridor. I knocked on a door. The man who opened it looked like a private investigator. That was O.K. by me. I was there to write about private investigators.

title: 2 Debates Help Iowa Caucuses Get Top Billing
description: DES MOINES  Never mind Jimm and Teddy. The national personality wit whom Iowans are on a firstname basi these days is Walter.

title: Korean Death Sentences Upheld; Defense Lawyers Plan to Appeal
description: SEOUL, South Korea. Wednesday, Dec. 26 (AP)  The martial law commander has confirmed the death sentences of the former chief of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, Kim Jae Kyu, and six other men in the assassination of President Park Chung Hee, a command spokesman said today. Defense lawyers said they would appeal.

title: Deaths
description: CROWLEYAmos H. December 21, 1979, of Forest Hills. NY. Commander USNR. retired. Beloved husband of Esther, toying father of Angale Uztin and Amos H. Jr. Also survived by three grandchildren. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave corner Metropolitan Ave, Forest Hills. Religious and American Legion services Friday 11AM. Interment Caiverton National Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 2 to SPM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Heart Fund.de NIKANOVLeone Revillon. On December 12, 1979 Beloved wife of Feodor. Memorial Service Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90115 Street 12 Noon Friday, December 28th.DOTYMonsignor William L., Sunday December 23,1979. Pastor of St. John's Church, Pawling, NY. Beloved brother of George E. Doty. Mrs. Josephine Jaburg, Mrs. Lillian Cortese and Mrs. Joan Werthman. Masses of Christion Burial at St. John's Church Wednesday. December 26th at 8PM and Thursday, December 27th at 11AM. Interment St John's Cemetery. Pawling.EMERSONMichael. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted lather of David, Donald, Jonathan and Steven. Fatherinlaw of Laurie. Most loving grandfather of Dov, brother of Sam, Joe, Goldie, Gabe, Harry, Bunny and Hynda. Services were held December 24th at Congregation Shaarey Tefila Far Rockaway. Shiva will be observed at the Emerson Home in Lawrence.FELLPhilip S.P. Of Boca Grande, Florida on December 22, 1979. Survived by his wife Elisabeth W. Fell, his daughters Elisabeth F. Allen, Dorothy F. Fameily, his sons Philip S.P. Fell, Jr. and Ogden Mills Fell and 7 grandchildren. Services at St. Johns Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Thursday December 27, at 11am. Interment St. Johns Cemetery. In lieu of flowers family will appreciate contributions to St. Andrews Church, Boca Grande, Florida.GERRYRobert L., of Dallas, Texas, on December 21, 1979, in N.Y. Husband of Harriet Wells Gerry, father of Nancy G. Bedford of Middleburg. Va., and Robert L. Gerry III of Houston, Texas. Grandfather of Cynthia and Bryan Benttz, Jr. and Robert L. Gerry IV and Lloyd H. Gerry. Also survived by 3 brothers, Henry, Edward and Eibridge and a steph4Jaughter, Penn Gardner. Funeral service at St. James Church, Lake Delaware, Delhi, NY at 1pm on Thursday, December 27th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Lake Delaware Boys Camp, Delhi, N.Y. 13753.HORNCharlesOf Greeniawn, NY. On December 24, 1979. Beloved husband of Louise. Devoted father of Dorothy Horn. Funeral Service Wednesday 8PM at the A. L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Ave, Huntington Station. Leave Thursday 10AM for cremelion at Fresh Pond Crematory, Middle Village. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Memorial Fund of Greenlawn Presbyterian Church, Greenlawn NY 11740 appreciated.

title: U.S. Is Troubled by a Discrepancy On Number of Hostages in Teheran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25  Carter Administration officials expressed concern today over the apparent discrepancy between the 43 Americans allowed to meet with four clergymen in the American Embassy in Teheran and the total of 50 the United States believes to be held hostage.

title: In Germany, the Sugarplums Are Marzipan
description: LUBECK. WEST GERMANY

title: Chess:
description: Grandmaster Florin Gheorghiu of Rumania captured the 1979 United States Open championship at the Palmer House in Chicago with a score of 101/21%.

title: 100 Flee Vessel That Hit a Reef In the Antarctic
description: More than 100 passengers and crew members were evacuated in lifeboats yesterday from the Lindblad Explorer, luxury cruise ship that ran aground in Antarctica, the ship's radio operator reported last night.

title: Boise Seeks Lost Shareholders
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 25  The Boise Cascade Corporation, which owns a controlling interest in the defunct Shanghai Power Company, has begun a complex search to find other shareholders in the company, most of whose last known addresses were in Shanghai in 1949.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Quebec Alters Tax Rules
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 25 The government of Quebec has just scored its first success in three years of attempts to improve relations with business.

title: TV: Shining Season, Tale of Courage
description: ASHINING SEASON, on CBSTV tonight at 9 o'clock, is one of those television movies that deserve to be better solely on the basis of good intentions. It is based on the true story of John Baker, a track star who died of cancer in 1970 at the age of 26. It's being sponsored by General Motors on behalf of the company's Cancer Research Foundation. The only commercial will showcase three scientists working in cancer research.

title: Books of The Times
description: MOST people laugh too easily, it seems to me. Perhaps they laugh on principle, to make sure they are in on the joke and not the butt of it. It may even be true to say that our laughter is increasingly existential, a hollow attempt to comprehend the incomprehensible or assimilate the unassimilable.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: IN the end, Lionel felt he had to take on Stella. It was, he knew, the only thing that a man could do. Every morning, Lionel stopped at the deli on Second Avenue. He inched forward in the long, silent line with all the others who were late for work. He ordered black coffee with no sugar black, no  and a bagel with cream cheese bagel, smear. And every morning, Stella, at the cash register, took his money, gave him change and didn't ring it up.

title: The Region
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. (AP)  Gabrielle, the Niagara Falls Aquarium's 22yearold dolphin, gave birth yesterday to a 31/2foot female tentatively named Christmas by cheering onlookers.

title: Chinese Airline Seeks Attractive Flight Attendants
description: PEKING, Dec. 25  The stateowned Chinese airline is now choosing female flight attendants partly on the basis of their good looks.

title: Chinese Oil Find
description: PEKING, Dec. 25 (Reuters) Geologists have reported a new oil discovery north of the Yangtze River in the northern part of China's eastern Jiangsu province, the New China News Agency said today. The agency said that large oil and gas flows had been found in the vicinity of the new well at Zhentong since 1970 and that prospecting was still going on. The oil flow from the new well indicated good production prospects, the agency added.

title: 4 CLERGYMEN MEET 43 HOSTAGES IN IRAN; NEW DOUBT ON TOTAL
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 25  It was a bittersweet Christmas morning for the American Embassy hostages here as groups of four or so, sometimes weeping, sometimes eating Christmas cookies, shared holiday services and what was for some their first glimpse of the outside world in 53 days, clergymen who visited them said today.

title: Dr. Gerd Muehsam, Art Authority On the Faculty of Queens College
description: Dr. Gerd Muehsam, an author and art bibliographer at Queens College, died Dec. 14 after a heart attack. She was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Real Estate Agents Are Depresssed, Along With Market
description: Real estate agents are as depressed these days as the housing market, which has been greatly slowed in most parts of the nation by sharply rising interest rates and a dearth of mortgage money.

title: Letter On Savings Bonds
description: Safe, Convenient and Good for the Country

title: Connecticut Area Hit By Blackout Affecting About 8,500 Families
description: COLCHESTER, Conn., Dec. 25 (AP) Thousands of residents in eastern Connecticut spent Christmas morning without electricity, opening presents by candlelight and cooking on wood stoves and in fireplaces.

title: TV: The Presidency So Many Seek
description: OUR country's biggest competition, the election of a President. will take place in less than a year, and tonight at 9:30 an NBC White Paper special will present one of the first of the pregame programs dealing with the office and what it does to those who hold it.

title: United Press International
description: Kansas City, Mo., police officers on duty at one of seven fire stations they began staffing on Monday

title: Engine Maker Works on Image
description: HARTFORD  The finest fighter engine ever developed is the way one newspaper advertisement rates Pratt & Whitney's troubled F100 engine. Sweet dreams reads the inscription above a magazine photograph of a blond toddler dozing restfully in a commercial airliner powered by another Pratt & Whitney engine.

title: Reds Sign Draft Choice
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Jeff Russell, an 18yearold righthanded pitcher who was the Cincinnati Reds fifthround choice in last June's draft, has signed with the National League club.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Decision Is Due On Williamson
description: John Williamson, the New Jersey Nets most prolific scorer last season, sat out his ninth game in a row as the Nets lost by 131102 loss to the Knicks last night. But his future may soon become clearer.

title: New Path For Solar Institute
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  Last summer, the Carter Administration abruptly dismissed the director of the Solar Energy Research Institute, the Government's national laboratory for solar development, and replaced him with Denis Hayes, an outsider who had long been critical of Washington's energy policies. The reaction both inside and outside the institute was mixed.

title: North Victor By 2213
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 25 (AP)  The coaches in the BlueGray college allstar football game today said the Gray's failure early in the fourth quarter to convert a fourthdown play deep in Blue territory had been the turning point in the Blue's 2213 victory.

title: Play: AMDA Studio Revives Eiliom
description: THE inspiration for the musical Carousel, Ferenc Molnar's Liliom tells a strange story, beginning with a bright, bawdy prologue at a carnival and ending with a haunting, haunted epilogue in heaven. It is an elusive play, Liliom, but with the current revival at the AMDA studio, it becomes evident that even a flawed production cannot impair its intrinsic, lyrical charm.

title: Reserves Help 76ers Top Bullets
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 25 (AP) Bobby Jones, a reserve, sparked a fourthquarter surge that carried the Philadelphia 76ers to a 9592 victory over the Washington Bullets today in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Real Estate
description: NO greater friend hath the American turkey than Eli Bartzvi. He is the founder and president of the New York Turkey Corporation, a man who thinks turkey and talks turkey from 6 A.M. until nightfall. He believes that processed turkey foods will some day challenge the mighty hamburger and hot dog for popularity in the fastfood market.

title: Two Men Found Bound and Slain In a Burning Building in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Firemen who broke into a burning building that housed a tavern found the bodies of two men bound with electric cord, their heads wrapped in gauze.

title: Recovery In Foreign Loans Cited
description: LONDON, Dec. 25  A longawaited recovery in the market for loans by international banking groups appears to be taking shape, according to senior bankers in London.

title: American in Istanbul Prison Gets Holiday Gift: She's Freed on Bail
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 25 (AP) Loretta J. Dooley, an I8yearold American exchange student charged with drug smuggling, was ordered released on bail today in an unexpected Christmas present. But she returned to the gray and cold Sagmalcilar prison until the $1,500 bail could be posted and was expected to spend another day or two in jail.

title: Holiday Spoiled Again For Miami Homeowner
description: MIAMI, Dec. 25 (AP)  For the second consecutive year, fire spoiled Christmas for Police Sgt. Juan Santos and his family.

title: Owner of New Casino Fights HonkyTonk Surroundings
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 25  Officials1 of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, which spent $300 million on its elegant Park Place casinohotel, are fuming because visitors entering this city's newest , gambling emporium will be confronted with a 200foot strip of Boardwalk honkytonk.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Reactor Closings Asked if Utilities Lack Evacuation Plans for Locales
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  A report drafted for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has tentatively recommended that serious consideration be given to closing any reactor whose operator is unable to develop plans to evacuate everybody living within a 30mile radius of the reactor.

title: Becton After Sun Co.'s Siege
description: At the headquarters of Becton Dickinson & Company in Paramus, N.J., the ritual Christmas celebrations were particularly joyous this year. As far as Becton's executives were concerned,

title: Books: The Warrior Architect of Pearl Harbor
description: HE was short, plump, superstitious, a womanizer and a passionate gambler He came from an obscure exsamurai family. Yet, in his time, he shook the world. He was Yamamoto lsoroku, the architect of the Japanese triumph at Pearl Harbor and the beaten admiral in the Battle of Midway.

title: ESSAY A Cure for Androlepsy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  One of the Carter spokesmen, asked about a few suggestions made in this space recently to put effective economic pressure on the Iranian terrorists, responded with evident relish that military bluster might make the likes of this columnist feel good but would free no hostages.

title: Snake Cuts Power in Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Dec. 26 (Reuters)  A snake wrapped itself around two highvoltage electricity conductors, causing a short circuit that cut the power suppiy for four days in the Ivory Coast's Abengourou region, the newspaper Frateniite Matin reported today.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the commonest of all bidding confusions leads to a postmortem lament: I meant it as Blackwood or, perhaps, I thought you meant it as Blackwood.

title: Rhodesia Rebels Get Tumultuous Welcome Home
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 26 After seven years of being among Rhodesia's most wanted men, the top military officers of the Patriotic Front guerrillas returned here today to a tumultuous welcome from tens of thousands of jubilant blacks.

title: City's ComqiercialLoft Dwellers Win a Key Tenant Rights Ruling
description: Tens of thousands of New Yorkers who have been living in commercial lofts without protection against eviction or arbitrary rent increases will now be covered by the city's rent stabilization laws as a result of a state appellate court decision.

title: Dividends
description: x Company revised to 5 for 4 amount of stock solit, perviously announced

title: Petroleum Data Delayed
description: The American Petroleum Institute said yesterday that because of the Christmas holiday its weekly report on the nation's petroleum situation might not be available until tomorrow.

title: Conservatives in Idaho Pressing
description: BOISE, Idaho  Word has been out in political circles for months now that Senator Frank Church, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, is in big political trouble back home. He is high on the hit list of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, and the campaign against him went into high gear in midsummer, making it longer than the Presidential campaign.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: THE popularity of animals as home decorating motifs has waned in recent times and fantasy in general has been relegated to the children's room. But one place that animals are holding their own, decoratively speaking, is in the bathroom.

title: City Preparing New Tactics on Towing
description: Two cars, one from New York, another from Ontario, sat empty at the curb on Fifth Avenue in front of Saks shortly before 3 P.M. yesterday, the heavy postChristmas Day traffic flowing around them.

title: Hi1de Somer,49,Dead; A Noted Concert Pianist
description: Hilde Somer, a pianist who championed contemporary composers and gave several world premieres, died on Tuesday while vacationing in the Bahamas. She was 49 years old. The Austrianborn musician came to the United States in 1938 as a refugee with her family, which was Jewish. While aboard the French liner Normandie the 8yearold pianist was heard by Eddie Cantor, who was arranging a shipboard concert. The comedian, who had discovered such popular child singers as Deanna Durbin and Bobby Breen, became the Viennese pianist's sponsor, arranging for radio appearances and tours.

title: Pipe Bomb Blast in Brooklyn
description: A small pipe bomb exploded early yesterday outside a twofamily home at 915 Avenue T in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn. The police said the blast, which caused little damage, appeared to be the work of pranksters.

title: Two Counties to Forgo Inquest in the Suicide Of Girl in Albany Jail
description: Officials of two upstate New York counties decided separately yesterday not to conduct a coroner's inquest into the suicide of a 16yearold girl who had hanged herself while being held in the Albany County Jail for failure to pay $170 in traffic fines.

title: Restoring the Finish of a Saarinen Table
description: WE are inclined to think of contemporary wood furniture as having indestructible finishes, easy to maintain and needing little or no attention the opposite of antique furniture. It's true that these finishes are extremely durable and handsome, capitalizing on the beauty and figuring of the wood's natural grain. Yet a piece of contemporary furniture can be ruined, sometimes by marks from a plant pot or a burn from a cigarette.

title: Notes on People
description: ExOpera Star Rescued

title: Emergency for WCBS Copter
description: The WCBS radio traffic watch helicopter had to make an emergency landing on a Queens golf course yesterday morning because of a rotor problem. The pilot, Tom Salat, was uninjured.

title: Suits Are Filed On UV Debts
description: A legal battle involving the Sharon Steel Corporation's takeover of UV Industries surfaced yesterday in suits by New York banks asserting that some UV debt payments were in default and in countercharges filed by Sharon.

title: At Vermont House Raising, Old Yankee Tradition Is Revived
description: WESTMINSTER. VT

title: Japan Finds Need For Nuclear Growth
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26 (AP)  Japan's atomic energy commission says nuclear power is indispensable to the nation's economic future and predicts that Japan will double its nuclear power generating capacity by 1985.

title: Stocks Show Only Token Gains
description: Preciousmetal stocks and recently depressed gambling issues shared honors as Wall Street's bestperforming groups yesterday. Stock prices in general showed token gains in light trading on the day following Christmas.

title: U.S. REPORTS SOVIET FLYING MANY TROOPS TO AFGHAN CONFLICT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  The United States said today that in the last 24 hours the Soviet Union had begun a roundtheclock airlift to Afghanistan, raising Soviet military involvement in that country to a new threshold.

title: Albania's Future
description: LONDON  Albania, the most isolated country in Eastern Europe, has been totally friendless since 1978, when China, its only ally and friend, stopped the huge flow of economic and military aid it had provided during the previous 17 years. When this happened, Albania was soon faced with grave economic difficulties. It is now making desperate efforts to overcome them by increasing the volume of trade with countries with which it already had commercial links and by a frantic search for new markets for its exports.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Commission on Imports Gets Caretaker Chief

title: Nation's No. 2 Cable TV Company Joins Battle for Franchise in Queens
description: The operator of Nassau County's cable television system  second largest in the nation  joined the muddled Queens franchise fight with a $170 million proposal yesterday, and the city's Director of Franchises suggested that the disputed threeyearold process might have to be started all over.

title: Correction
description: In Wednesday's Living Section, an incorrect address was given for The Red Herring. The correct address for that shop is 384 Bleecker Street.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Fuqua Industries announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its three television stations to separate buyers for a total of $61 million.

title: Roosevelt Statue Blown Up
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 26 (Reuters)  A statue of President Franklin D. Roosevelt in Montevideo was destroyed by explosives planted by terrorists today, the Uruguayan Interior Ministry announced.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ROOM WITH A VIEW The threesided window panorama is so stimulating at the new Plaza Cafe (8677179), which overlooks Third Avenue at 37th Street, that you wish more restaurants were perched on terraces under highrise structures. The new spot is easy to bypass in the avenue's bustle. Look up one level at the blueandwhite awnings; the entrance is around the corner and across the terrace.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Home Improvement
description: SNOWTHROWERS, once considered a comparative luxury, are now selling in greater numbers than ever before Much of this growth is undoubtedly due to the unusually heavy snowfalls in many parts of the country in recent years. But the rising popularity of snowthrowers can also be traced to improved models, including a new generation of lower priced, lightweight machines that are compact enough to eliminate storage problems for many homeowners (some models can even be hung up on a wall when not in use).

title: Great Performers Series Will Open on Jan. 18
description: A violinist, a flutist, a chamber ensemble and the Philadelphia Orchestra are the artists who will appear next month in Lincoln Center's Great Performers series at Avery Fisher Hall. Vladimir Spivakov, the Soviet violinist, will open the series on Jan. 18 assisted by Boris Bechterev, pianist. This will be Mr. Spivakov's only New York recital this season.

title: Ban Is Affirmed; On Homosexuals; Entering Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 Justice Department lawyers have concluded that the Immigration and Naturalization Service must enforce a statutory ban on the admission of homosexual foreigners to the United States even though the head of the Public Health Service says homosexuality is no longer considered a mental disease or defect.

title: Indian Election: A Slate of 4,663 After 528 Seats
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 26 Princes and peasants, lawyers and journalists, businessmen and movie stars, a staggering number and variety of candidates are running for Parliament in elections scheduled for Jan. 3 and 6.

title: Philippines Growth Rate
description: MANILA, Dec. 26 (UPI)  The Philippines has scaled down its target for economic growth in 1980 after slumping to a 5.8 percent growth rate this year from last year's 6.8 percent. it was announced today. A report by the policymaking National Economic Development Authority said it was readjusting the country's original 7.5 percent growth target for 1980 to 6 percent in light of unfavorable developments, such as the new oil price increases.

title: Hockey: Europe's Game, Too
description: For the next act in the hockey circus at Madison Square Garden this season, the Soviet Central Red Army, perhaps the world's best team, will skate onto the ice tonight near where most of the Boston Bruins and some Ranger fans brawled after Sunday night's game. Coincidentally, there is a connection between the Sports of The Times Soviet team's esthetic arrival and the Bruins ugly departure. The link is the swift skills of European hockey players. Put the Soviet Central Red Army team in the National Hockey League and it probably would win the Stanley Cup, to the chagrin of N.H.L. chauvinists. And the European imports, notably Ulf Nilsson and Anders Hedberg of the Rangers, should be considered ornaments for the N.H.L., but too many N.H.L. players, and maybe even too many N.H.L referees, sneer at the imports as a threat to what they consider to be Canada's game, their game. But hockey is no longer only Canada's game. It also is Europe's game now. Most Importantly, hockey is a better game in Europe than it is in the

title: Union Leader Softens Threat of a Bus Strike For Jan. 1 in Nassau
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 26The president of the union representing the drivers and maintenance employees of Nassau County's publicly run bus line apparently has softened the union's threat to strike if a contract is not agreed upon by Monday, when the current contract expires.

title: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY HE TELEPHONED TO 354 3900 UNTII 5: 30 PM FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS UNTIL 7: 30 PM ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN RFGIONAL OFFICES 9: 00 A II TO 4: 30 P M MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY, NEW JERSEY (70I) MARKET 33900, WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300, NASSAU CO (516) 7470500 SUFFOI K CO (5I13) 669 MOO, CONNECTICUT (703) 3413 7767
Former Korea President Will Face Court Martial
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Dec. 27 (AP)  Former President Po Sun Yun and 17 other dissidents have been referred to a court martial in connection with an antigovernment rally disguised as a wedding ceremony on Nov. 24, the martial law command announced today.

title: More Kansas City Firemen Sick
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 26 (AP) Police officers ran 13 of Kansas City's 33 fire stations today after 114 of the city's 900 firefighters called in sick in their sixdayold work slowdown.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  Railroad officials and environmentalists are joining in a new court effort to stop a Federal lockanddam project on the Mississippi River.

title: Congress Gets D Minus;In Rating by Proxmire
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, today gave the first session of the 96th Congress a grade of D minus and said that its worst failure was not balancing the budget.

title: U.S. Says Freeze Bans Loans to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) The Treasury Department said today that its order freezing Iran's assets under United States jurisdiction also prevented American banks from granting any loans or otherwise extending credit to Iran.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Ghosts
description: BOSTON, Dec. 26 At this season, seven years ago, the United States was carrying out the most intensive bombing campaign the world had ever known: the Christmas bombing of North Vietnam. Over eleven days, B52's and other planes made 2,000 strikes on Hanoi and Haiphong.

title: Union Oil to Cut Petroleum Prices
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (AP) The Union Oil Company, the nanon's 13thlargest oil company, announced today that it was cutting wholesale gasoline, heating oil and diesel fuel prices by a penny a gallon.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American E xchange and (0) overthecounter

title: DR. SHIRLEY C. FISK, FORMER DEAN, DEAD
description: Dr. Shirley Carter Fisk, a former associate dean at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and deputy assistant secretary of defense from 1963 to 1967, died Tuesday at the Co. lumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a long illness related to muscular dystrophy. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan and Arden, Westchester County.

title: 3 Clergymen Find Misconception In Teheran on U.S. Unity in Crisis
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Thursday, Dec. 27 Physically exhausted, emotionally drained, yet seemingly exhilarated, the three American clergymen who visited the hostages at the United States Embassy on Christmas morning flew home today persuaded, they said, that Iranians were under a misconception about the attitudes of the American people toward the holding of hostages at the embassy.

title: NONEMERGENCY RUNS DIVERT AMBULANCES
description: Nonemergency patients calling for an ambulance to take them to the hospital  are creating lifethreatening delays in New York City's emergency medical services, according to a state legislative study issued yesterday.

title: Vietnam Issues a Gloomy Report on Economy in 1979
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 26  Vietnam depicted 1979 in grim economic terms today, attributing serious but largely unspecified shortcomings to wars and natural disasters.

title: U.S. Election Panel Sues For DraftKennedy Data
description: MIAMI, Dec. 26 (AP)  The Federal Election Commission filed suit today against the Florida for Kennedy Committee, demanding that it be allowed to inspect the records of the movement to draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy as a Presidential candidate.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: Foreignexchange quotations were not available for publication in this edition of The New York Times from the Associated Press, which normally transmits closing New York prices. Some European markets were closed for Boxing Day.

title: The City
description: The Consumer Affairs Department said yesterday that it had referred 23 cases of alleged gasoline overcharging by service stations to the Federal Department of Energy for prosecution.

title: Keeping Up to Date On Theft Insurance
description: FOR most people, the holidays are a favorite time for visiting with fnends and relatives. Unfortunately, some will find on their return that it has also been a favorite time for burglars to ransack their homes and apartments.

title: By George, a Girl Crosses the Delaware
description: WASHINGTON'S CROSSING, Pa., Dec. 26 (AP)  The original was 203 years ago and a painting of the incident indicates an allmale crew. But this year, when George Washington crossed the Delaware River, a 17yearold girl was on board.

title: Franklin Five Wins, Defaults
description: Benjamin Franklin High School of Manhattan overcame early trouble with the zone defense employed by Evander Childs and posted a 5548 triumph last night in the semifinals of the Harlem Holiday Classic at City College.

title: Sanitation Department Cites 16 For Violating City Dumping Laws
description: The Department of Sanitation yesterday released the names of 16 violators of the city's laws against illegal dumping. The names of five violators whose vehicles were impounded are included in the list.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Kodak to Increase Film Prices 630%
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 26 (Reuters)  The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it would increase prices on most sensitized products marketed by the consumer/professional and finishing and graphics markets divisions by 6 to 30 percent, effective after the close of business on Jan. 25.

title: The Editorial NoteboOk England's Own Racial Tensions
description: An American visiting England today is quickly tempted to see parallels between the conditions of racial minorities in the two countries. Like blacks in America, blacks and Asians in England complain about racial discrimination in employment and housing, in schooling and police protection. Somewhat like Hispanic Americans, England's Asians are intensely troubled by the Government's proposal, recently approved by the House of Commons, to limit further immigration from thirdworld countries but not from Europe. It does not take long, though, to discover that there are more differences than similarities in the racial situations of Britain and the United States.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Grants Help Owners To Repair Facades
description: Around the corner from the birthplace of Winston Churchill's mother and just up the alley from where Thomas Wolfe wrote You Can't Go Home Again is the home where Edward and Anna McCann have lived for 33 years. He, a retired shipyard administrative assistant, and she, a former fabric designer, raised their daughter here and have watched the alley go up and down with the neighborhood's fortunes.

title: Design Notebook
description: AS a research freak, I am certain that dazzling discoveries as well as elementary accuracy reward those who dig in dusty archives, or at least consult the standard references. I am secretly convinced that the revelations of genius come not from a celestial thunderbolt, but from a combination of sitzfleisch and an intensely curious mind. Unfortunately, newspaper research time, unlike doctoral dissertation time, consists of a few days rather than a few years, and I must rely on the efforts of those who prepare exhibitions and write books for adequate and accurate information. This research is my profit and pleasure; one of the perks, so to speak, of the Job

title: Carters Exchange Gifts On Relaxed Holiday
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI)President Carter, an avid fisherman, received a fly reel from his wife, Rosalynn, as a Christmas gift, and he gave her a small desk calculator, a White House aide said today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Price of Gold Tops $500 for First Time
description: The price of gold in New York shot past $500 an ounce for the first time ever yesterday as worried traders headed for cover after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said Iran's current conflict with the United States could worsen.

title: Books of The Times
description: AS Leon Harris makes clear in Merchant Princes: An Intimate History of Jewish Families Who Built Great Department Stores, the pattern tended to repeat Itself. True, you got an occasional sport, such as Moms Rich of Atlanta, who came from Hungary instead of Germany, or Julius Rosenwald, who bought into his business  Sears, Roebuck  instead of starting from scratch.

title: Panel in Jersey Assails Conduct Of a Prosecutor
description: TRENTON, Dec. 26  A threejudge panel of the Appellate Division of Superior Court suggested today that the New Jersey Supreme Court consider disciplinary proceedings against prosecutors guilty of improper courtroom conduct.

title: Home Beat
description: CATHY and David Comins first met when they were in seventh grade. Now they are married and he teaches wood shop at the Brooklyn Friends School and she is a music textbook editor. The Cominses began making a few wood items for the kitchen. David started with the napkin holder. I added the salt and pepper shakers, said Mrs. Comins. They rented a workshop and experimented with inlaying routed lines in the wood with colored epoxy.

title: CarterKennedy Debate Rated Potential TV Hit
description: Seventyeight percent of the American public would be likely to watch one or more of a series of televised debates between President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: How to Gain Control Of Your Radiator
description: WHILE many New York tenants complain of the cold when the heating season arrives, others start opening their windows.

title: 16 New Homes Planned By Nixon Estate's Buyer
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Dec. 26 (UPI)  Former President Richard M. Nixon's seaside estate will be subdivided into 16 singlefamily homes, one of them the Spanishstyle structure that served as the Western White House, according to preliminary tract map filed by the company that purchased the property.

title: Christmas Retail Sales
description: Gains in Christmasseason retail sales this year were substantially short of the 13 percent nationwide increase of the 1978 season, and when price increases stemming from inflation are taken into account, the real gains are expected to average only 2 to 3 percent.

title: Spanish Communists Find Star Is Waning
description: MADRID, Dec. 26The Spanish Communist Party of Santiago Carrillo, who once grabbed headlines with his barbed attacks on the Soviet Union, has fallen on hard times. Mr. Carrillo is no longer a frequent and privileged visitor to the offices of Prime Minister Adolfo Surez. And the Socialists have been accusing the standardbearer of independentminded Eurocommunism of being on the take from Moscow.

title: Spinks Will Face Spaniard Jan. 12
description: Leon Spinks, former heavyweight champion, will fight Alfredo Evangelista on Saturday, Jan, 12, in Atlantic City.

title: Kerkorian Stock Bid Is Planned
description: Kirk Kerkorian, who tried without success last month to sell his 25 percent stake in Columbia Pictures, disclosed a complex plan yesterday to purchase a million shares of Columbia stock. The purchase would not take place for at least two years however, and then only under conditions that he did not specify.

title: Kennedy, on Vacation, Meets Campaign Aides
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 (UPI)  Senator Edward M. Kennedy interrupted his Florida vacation today to meet with aides for more than three hours to review the themes of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday. Dec 26.1979

title: Warm Spell Costly To Area Ski Resorts
description: With an estimated $10 million in sales of lift tickets already lost this season, skiarea operators in the Northeast were hoping that a predicted return to subfreezing weather would help make up some of the loss.

title: G.A.O. SEEKS ACTION ON RENTAL HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26The General Accounting Office says that the shortage of affordable rental housing is so acute that immediate Congressional action is required.

title: Woman, 92, Donates to Neediest; Another Hails Work by the Fund
description: I'm still here, although 92 years and much diminished, wrote Germaine Schnitzer of Manhattan in a clear, firm hand, enclosing a check for $100 for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: BL to Build A New Honda Car
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 27 BL Ltd. has signed an agreement with the Honda Motor Company to build a new car to be developed by the Japanese company. BL's chairman, Sir Michael Edwardes, told reporters that technical collaboration on the new car was the first stage in what could be closer links between the two companies.

title: Career Test Gives Way to Attack, Opening U.S. Jobs for Minorities;
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26  The Government's PACE examination, designed as the first step to meaningful Federal careers for junior level executives and professionals, appears to be on the way out or at least slated for substantial modification.

title: Where to Write for Drawings
description: For more information about the Library of Congress's collection of historichouse plans, write to the Prints and Photographs Division, Thomas Jefferson Building, Room 1051, Washington, D.C. 20540, or call Mary Ison, reference librarian, at (202) 4266399.

title: Boston College, St. John's Gain in Festival
description: St. John's and Georgetown, both nationally ranked, had trouble handling zone defenses last night in the opening round of the fourteam Holiday Festival tournament before a crowd of 10,466 at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  Justice Howard E. Levitt of State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the decision by the Muttontown Zoning Board of Appeals denying a special use permit to the Independent Church for the Realization of the Word of God Inc. Since 1977 the church has been using a 40room mansion in Muttontown as its headquarters, and housing 50 members there.

title: Money WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1979
description: Money rates 3.15p m

title: Nets Conquer Bullets As Newlin Scores 37
description: PISCATAWAY,N.J.,Dec. 26  The man struggled down the hallway toward the New Jersey Nets locker room under the weight of a large cardboard box. As he put it down outside the entrance, a writer standing nearby noticed that it bore the label of a wine company.

title: Auto Exports Gain in Japan
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26 (AP)  Japan's motor vehicle exports totaled 417,969 units in November, up 1.9 percent from October and up 37.5 percent from 303,996 units in November 1978, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: F.C.C. Is Sued on Radio Deregulation
description: The Office of Communication of the United Church of Christ filed suit yesterday in an effort to prevent the Federal Communications Commission from deregulating the radio industry without disclosing to the public the basis for its decision.

title: Swiss Refuse to Permit Saudi to Purchase Home
description: SAANEN, Switzerland, Dec. 26 (AP) Citizens in this Swiss resort refused today to let a Saudi official buy a luxurious holiday chalet although he offered to give $250,000 to the municipal treasury in return for the permit.

title: CLERICS AT EMBASSY NEARLY WALKED OUT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 26  Three American clergymen nearly walked out of the United States Embassy here on Christmas Eve without seeing the hostages when the captors refused to allow a combined religious service for all

title: White House to Give Jan. 3 Reception for Nation's Leading Poets
description: To make up for what some believe has been a neglect by the Presidency of one segment of the arts  poets and poetry the White House is planning a reception on Jan. 3 for a large group of well known and established poets. Five hundred people are expected to attend, about 75 of them poets. The gathering is intended to honor poetry and American poets, a White House representative said.

title: 3 Skiers Missing in Italy
description: AOSTA, Italy, Dec. 26 (Reuters) Mountain rescue teams were working by torchlight tonight to try to save three skiers feared buried under an avalanche, the police said. The skiers were directly in the path of the avalanche, which was brought on by a sudden change in temperature.

title: Oil Slick
description: UNIVERSITY, Ala.  Recently in San Francisco I realized why some of us not in the oil business have such difficulty believing fully in the oil crisis.

title: Dpaths
description: BINESDavid, beloved husband of Ruth Menorial Mass, Chapel of Saints Faith, Hope & Charity, 128 East 58 Street, 11 A M , Saturday. December 29,1979

title: World News Briefs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 26 (UPI) Leftists killed four persons today who had rightwing political connections, and also killed a policeman and wounded two in an attack on a patrol car in the northeast, the police reported. And a bomb was detonated at an office of the rightwing National Movement Party.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Companies

title: Dpaths
description: ARTHURJack R Of 802 Plympton Street, New Milford, N J Beloved husband of Pearl (nee Fotnick),devoted father of Rosanne A Kuba and Paul, loving brother of Gladys Weinberg Services will be held at GuttermanMusicantKreitzman corner of Passaic and Park Streets, Hackensack, N J on Thursday Dec 27 at 1 30 P M The memorial period will be observed at the residence through Sunday evening Should friends desire, contributions may be made to the Jack Arthur Camp Scholar of Camp Neleda, 153 Roseville Avenue, Newark, N J

title: Abrams Raising Campaign Fund For a 1982 Race
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams, in office less than a year, has started an ambitious fundraising effort for his next campaign, although he has not yet said just what job he may be seeking.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Increase in Electric Rate Opposed by P.S.C. Staff
description: ALBANY, Dec. 26 (UPI)  The Public Service Commission staff recommended today that the commission reject a request by the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation for an $8.4 million temporary electric rate increase. The staff said there was no legal basis for the increase.

title: Oilers List Campbell, Pastorini as Doubtful
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 26 (UPI)  Bum Phillips, coach of the Houston Oilers, reported to the National Football League office today that three of his key offensive players  Earl Campbell, Dan Pastonni and Ken Burrough  had doubtful statuses for Saturday's playoff game against the Chargers at San Diego.

title: Dealers and Police Note a Marijuana Shortage in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 26  Storms in Colombia, Federal agents in Florida and Soviet troops in Cuba combined to produce an apparent shortage of marijuana in the United States last fall.

title: Deaths
description: AVNET  Charles The Officers, Board of Governors and Staff of the Greater New York Committee for Israel Bonds note with profound Sorrow the passing of a distinguished colleague and friend, a great humanitarian and supporter of Israel, who for over two decades served as honorary chairman of its campaign in Congregation Beth Sholom of Long Beach Our heartfelt condolen ces to his wife, Celia, and the entire family

title: 1979 Is Reported a Record Year For Tourism in New York City
description: More tourists and businessmen visited New York this year and they spent more money than in any year in the city's history, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau reported yesterday.

title: United Technologies Names Haig President
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's chief of staff and more recently supreme commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, was appointed yesterday as president and chief operating officer of the United Technologies Corporation, which is among the nation's 20 largest industrial enterprises.

title: Is It About Headlines or People?
description: THERE are special hazards in presenting the first Broadway revival of Lillian Hellman's antiNazi drama Watch on the Rhine, Arvin Brown, the director of the production, was saying the other day. Currently playing previews at the Golden Theater, the play is scheduled to open on Jan. 3.

title: Senate Panel Fears Arson Cases Are Nearing an Epidemic Stage
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)  Arson is virtually out of control, killing 1,000 Americans annually and costing insurance companies $1.6 billion, according to a Senate subcommittee. Failure of Federal, state and local agencies to work together to limit arson for profit has helped to nurture an arson epidemic, the panel said.

title: TV Networks, at Midpoint of Season, Look Again
description: It is as though the television season that started in September has been canceled.

title: There's No Hurry on Nuclear Waste
description: It has been more than three decades since the nuclear age began and there is still no agreement on how to dispose of highlevel radioactive wastes. Unlike the siting of nuclear plants, some critics believe the waste problem is insoluble. They say the wastes will remain, fiendishly toxic, for millions of years, posing an unconscionable threat to future generations. But most nuclear advocates believe the technical solutions are already known and could be promptly applied  if only the critics conquered their hysteria and the Federal Government pressed ahead with the job after years of shocking neglect.

title: New Mexico President Denies a CoverUp
