title: The Revolution Seems to Miss One Iran Town
description: KARAJ, Iran, Dec. 27  There are few revolutionary posters on the aging buildings of this small bustling town on the sides of a range of the Elburz Mountains.

title: Soviet Display Of Flexibility
description: The primary military lesson for the United States and its allies in the Soviet Union's swift airborne movement into Afghanistan is that the Russians have the ability to move significant numbers of

title: Innis Is Accused Of Flouting Ban In Drive for Aid
description: Officers of the Congress of Racial Equality have been charged by the State Attorney General with disregarding a court order barring them from soliciting public contributions.

title: Lee Bowman, Actor; Was a Star in Movies And TV Ellery Queen
description: Lee Bowman, the veteran actor who starred with Jean Arthur in The Impatient Years and Rita Hayworth in Cover Girl, died of a heart attack at his home in Brentwood, Calif., on Christmas Day. He was 64 years old.

title: Corporate Democracy
description: WASHINGTON  If the Founding Fathers were now drafting a document to cope with arbitrary official power, this time they would have to include the corporation in the Constitution.

title: Bail Denied to Slaying Suspect
description: BURLEY, Idaho, Dec. 27 (UPI) Hafiz Nasser, a suspected member of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was ordered held without bond today in the slaying of two Palestinian refugees. Mr. Nasser, one of three suspects in the Dec. 8 shooting deaths here, was returned to Idaho from Albuquerque last weekend. The two other suspects were held in New Mexico pending extradition hearings.

title: TV Weekend
description: CREDIT or blame Muhammad All and the film Rocky, but boxing has been making a popular comeback. Although the remake of The Champ had only a moderate boxoffice success, despite a superb performance by Jon Voight, the fight scene is being promoted heavily in television, that most massive of entertainment distributors.

title: Afghanistan AT A GLANCE
description: Afghanistan is a landlocked country about the size of Texas bordered by the Soviet Union, Iran, Pakistan and China. Its 15 million people earn their living mainly by raising crops or herding animals. Outside of the deceptively modern capital of Kabul the people live, as they have for centuries, In mud villages often surrounded by 20foot walls to keep out bandits.

title: 50 S.R.O. Tenants Charge Harassment
description: A group of residents in a single room occupancy hotel on the Upper West Side have charged, with the support of several community advocate groups and local legislators, that they are being illegally harassed into vacating rooms in which some of them have lived for more than a decade.

title: The Pop Life
description: MILLIE JACKSON, who'll be at the Beacon Theater tomorrow and Sunday, has developed a reputation for talking dirty and influencing people. It started in 1974, with an album called Caught Up, the first of her recordings on which she was coproducer and the first to include the sort of uninhibited banter she habitually inserts between songs in her shows. The album went gold, one thing led to another, and Miss Jackson found herself becoming better known for her recorded raps than for her singing. Her latest album, Live and Uncensored, on the SpringPolydor label, exploits this image to the hilt. A warning sticker asserts that the album, a twodisk set recorded live at the Roxy Theater in Los Angeles, contains explicit language which may be considered objectionable by some listeners  for mature audiences only. While the band finds a rhythmic groove and vamps away on it, Miss Jackson raps at length, and often quite winningly.

title: Iranian Cleric Murdered By Gunman in Kerman
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 27 (Reuters) A Moslem religious leader was shot to death today in Kerman, a city in the southeast, the official Pars press agency reported.

title: Radio
description: 7 A.M.Noon, WNYCFM. Toccata in D. C.P.E. Bach; Polonaises, Bach; Canzon 26, Lappi; Sonata for Violin and Continuo in C, Duc; Mistress Anne Grene Her Leaves be Greene, Danyel. The Walk to Paradise Garden, Delius; Excerpt from Tannhauser. Wagner; Ballet Suite. Bliss.

title: APPROVAL IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW. Dec. 27  The Soviet Government expressed its approval today of the changeover in Afghanistan by distributing a speech by the proclaimed new leader denouncing his predecessor as the head of a bloody dynasty and an agent of United States imperialism.

title: Georgian Widow Fights for Work of Artist Soviet Curbed
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R.  In a walkup apartment amid the narrow streets and low balconies of the old section of Tbilisi, a woman works and schemes to make the world rediscover her late husband. the Georgian modernist painter David Kakabadze, whose promising career was blighted in the Stalinist artistic freeze of the 1930's.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I.  Scott Davis of Santa Monica, Calif., the United States junior champion, won twice today and reached the boys 18year division quarterfinals of the Rolex international junior tennis tournament at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Trade Unit Nominees Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27  A fresh Congressional conflict over trade policy has broken out over two White House nominations to the agency that processes domestic industry's complaints about imports. The two men are generally acknowledged to be liberal in trade philosophy.

title: Conrail Expense Bills Questioned
description: At least 13 Conrail employees, including a railroad police inspector, submitted $3,400 in questionable expense vouchers during a 13month period from 1976 through 1977, the New York State Comptroller disclosed yesterday.

title: Auctions
description: VIRTUALLY everyone is faced with the responsibility at some point of emptying a home and converting its contents swiftly, if possible  into cash. Usually the reason is a death in the family, but whatever the cause, the process is far from pleasant for everyone. Those who experience it are invariably frustrated when they attempt to evaluate what is involved financially, unless they know where to turn for professional assistance. Indeed, most people under stress may choose the easiest way out, and thereby overlook the possibility of getting the expertise to evaluate fairly what they have. Because that could mean financial loss, it is wise to investigate all avenues before making a decision about how and through whom to sell an estate.

title: In Sri Lanka, the People Cluster and Cluster And Cluster and Cluster and Cluster and . . .
description: AMPITIYA VILLAGE, Sri Lanka I have lived in Sri Lanka one year, and. if there is one most distinguishing quality of the people I would emphasize. it is their extraordinary closeness. Perhaps the best word for it is inseparability.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1979

title: Five Worthy Men for Cooperstown
description: Voting, says a rule governing election to the Baseball Hall of Fame, shall be based upon the player's record, playing ability, integrity, sportsmanship, character, contribution to the team(s) on which the player played and not on what he may have done otherwise in baseball. Translated, this means that all

title: Metals Stocks Up; Market Stays Firm
description: Soaring prices for gold and silver bullion kept the Wall Street spotlight riveted on precious metal stocks yesterday. Elsewhere, selected natural-resource stocks and a number of specialsituation issues in other industries also performed handsomely.

title: Art People
description: THE first underground magazine of current Russian art to be published in the West has surfaced in the United States, and it's a lively surprise. Called A:Z (meaning A to Z), the 60page journal reports on the unofficial art scene in Moscow and the doings of expatriate artists in Paris and New York. Declaring itself open to all independent thoughts and new ideas, the magazine has as the keynote of its first issue a photograph showing the Soviet police breakup of a dissident art exhibition in Moscow in 1974. From there it goes on to essays and interviews that examine the work of contempory unofficial artists of every stripe, including the conceptualist team of Rimma and Valery Gerlovin, and Erik Bulatov, a realist painter who satirizes the deadly officialdom of Soviet life. It also presents, in line with the magazine's aim of publicizing unknown documents of the early Russian avantgarde, a 1920 excerpt from the diary of Kasimir Malevich, the Constructivist artist whose work is now banned from public view in the Soviet Union. And it interviews Russian artists on their impressions of the New York art scene (New York impressed me the most when I saw it from above, says one, Genrich Khudyakov); includes a review of last year's Jasper Johns retrospective at the Whitney Museum by Aleksandr Kosolapov, a sculptor who now lives in New York, and winds up with some scathing comments on the recent ParisMoscow show at the Pompidou Center in Paris. One quote, from the dissident Soviet writer Andrei Sinyaysky: Now the Soviet power promotes this Russian avantgarde, that it itself has crushed, in a Parisian exhibition. What led it to do so? Business has to prosper. One needs prestige, foreign currencies. Then one goes on bargaining over the corpses of murdered artists.

title: Bridge
description: An old argument, never likely to be resolved to anyone's satisfaction, is between groups of users of the weak twobid. Some insist on disciplined use of the bid: the opener is expected to have a strong suit, preferably including two of the top three honors.

title: A Rebel General and 3 Britons Die, Complicating Rhodesia Peace Bid
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 27  The deaths of a Patriotic Front army commander and of three British airmen today complicated Britain's settlement initiative in Rhodesia as troops from the Commonwealth monitoring force prepared to observe the ceasefire scheduled to take effect at midnight tomorrow.

title: Prof. John K. Norton Dead at 86; Active in Education Since 1920's
description: Dr. John K. Norton, professor emeritus of education at Teachers College of Columbia University, died early today at his home on Riverside Drive after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Boynes Helps Nets Beat Pacers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 28 When the New Jersey Nets are on the road and their entire lineup is introduced before a game, Winford Boynes is the first name announced. Then, as the arena announcer moves in alphabetical order down the team's roster, the scenario is inevitably the same.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON A HUSBANDANDWIFE TEAM of chemists at the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., got a patent this week for compounds with many structural applications, such as spoilers, or devices to control the Ditch and roll of aircraft.

title: RamsCowboys
description: Even though the Cowboys beat the Rams by 270 last January and by 306 last October, Dallas can expect no easy afternoon in Texas Stadium. The Los Angeles defense, which enlists extraordinary athletes like Jack Youngblood and Dave Elmendorf, is intact again, with Rod Perry and Pat Thomas available at cornerback. This defense is certain to give Roger Staubach, pro football's top quarterback this season. some problems.

title: Amtrak Tells of Averting a Crash Of 2 Passenger Trains on Dec. 10
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28 (AP)  A faulty relay switch caused two trains traveling on the same track and carrying more than 450 passengers to come within 500 feet of one another in the evening rush hour on Dec. 10, Amtrak officials said today.

title: EaglesBuccaneers
description: A turnover  a fumble recovery by the defense or an intercepted pass  may be the crucial play in this game, because little scoring is likely.

title: Byrne Will Ask For New Taxes To Meet Deficit
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28  Governor Byrne said today that he would ask the Legislature to enact a package of new and expanded taxes within the next two weeks to close an anticipated $280 million deficit in the 198081 state budget.

title: Scientists Are Studying A Catfish Kill in Florida
description: MIAMI, Dec. 28 (AP)  Scientists are tyring to determine what killed thousands of fish from a species called walking catfish. The catfish, which floated to the surface of a Dade County canal yesterday, may have been victims of disease, scientists said.

title: An Eviction Warrant Is Pursued Against Tenants of Hotel Above Zabar's
description: Although Stanley Zabar vowed Thursday afternoon to provide relocation assistance to tenants in the singleroomoccupancy hotel above his food emporium, his lawyers said yesterday they would continue their efforts to get a warrant of eviction against them. Such a warrant would make the tenants subject to immediate dispossession.

title: Students and the Young Leading Moslem Fundamentalist Revival
description: CAIRO  At Cairo University recently, a group of students decided to organize a concert and reserved the auditorium. It was to be a decorous event, classical and Islamic music. But a Moslem fundamentalist group heard about it and moved into the auditorium beforehand to hold a boisterous meeting.

title: Changes in Milk Dating I Bring an Inquiry by City
description: New York City is looking into allegations that tampering with a Health Department regulation may have resulted in an improper extension of the time after pasteurization that milk can be legally sold in the city.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week Answers appear on page 22.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RISE AND SHINE Francine Mancini comes into her own tonight, stepping into the spotlight for two weeks as star of the entertainment at Once Upon a Stove, Third Avenue at 23d Street. Although continuing her duties as hostess at the restaurant's Valentine Room, the singer will also head the show bill presented by members of the dining room staff and kitchen crew. The roster of musicians and comedians includes Michael Crouch, Rick Dolan, Cyndi Mitchell, Pamela Rowe, Kim Wagner, Donna Bullock, Ciro Barbero and Suzi Vaughn.

title: Special Stamp to Honor W.C. Fields Centenary
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) The Postal Service will issue a special stamp honoring the entertainer W.C. Fields on Jan. 29, 1980, the 100th anniversary of his birth.

title: St. John's Wins Festival for 4th Time
description: A year ago David Russell won the most valuable player award at Christmas high school basketball tournament on Long Island. It was an award he had expected. His team, Bellport, had won the tournament as Russell scored a total of 50 points in two games.

title: Worker's Neck Is Sprained as Machine Snags Apron
description: A 37yearold postal worker suffered bruised head and a bruised and sprained neck when his apron became tangled in conveyor belt yesterday at the United States Postal Service's New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center in Jersey City. That is the building where another postal worker was killed in a conveyorbelt accident two weeks ago.

title: Television
description: Noon (5)  1979 Human Rights Day Concert A musical celebration of the International Year of the Child; Peter Ustinov is the host (1 hr.)

title: Bengals Hire Gregg as Coach
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 28 (UPI)  The Cincinnati Bengals today hired Forrest Gregg, a disciplinarian, as head coach, and Gregg immediately announced that he did not care whether the players disliked him, because I'm in this business to win football games.

title: Stocks of Crude Fell Last Week
description: Crude oil inventories fell 4.9 million barrels last week, to 345.8 million barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reoorted yesterday.

title: Connecticut Bottle Law Set to Take Effect
description: Connecticut consumers will pay at least a nickel deposit on each bottle or can of soda, beer or other beverage starting New Year's Day.

title: Takeover Stocks Up As Market Is Firm
description: Takeover situations, silver stocks and small oil exploration issues provided the main fireworks yesterday in an evenkeel stock market.

title: Couple Marks 51st Anniversary With Gift to Fund for Neediest
description: The first year Elsa and Simon Daniel were married, they made a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. That was in 1928. The couple, both native New Yorkers, met at a surprise party at the Ambassador Hotel, then at 51st Street and Park Avenue.

title: Marian C. Randall, 82; Headed Visiting Nurses
description: Marian G. Randall, executive director of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York from 1944 to 1958, died Wednesday the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. She was 82 years old.

title: France's Coalition Wins a Vote but Faces New Strains
description: PARIS, Dec. 28  France's brittle coalition Government won a limited tactical victory last night in the political crisis that erupted Christmas Eve when the country's watchdog Constitutional Council declared next year's budget void because it was not correctly approved by Parliament.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1979

title: Bridge:
description: Should a player, in any sport or recreation, be stripped of titles retroactively because of some irregularity that was not known to the authorities at the time? The most famous case is that of Jim Thorpe, who lost his Olympic medals because of a rigid interpretation of regulations barring professionals.

title: Rhodesian Vote Set for February
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  Lord Soames, the British Governor of Rhodesia, today set the end of February for general elections that will pave the way for legal independence for the British colony after 14 years of rebellion.

title: The Region
description: WESTBURY, L.I. (AP)  The threat of a New Year's Day bus strike on a publicly run line that serves Long Island and Queens increased late yesterday as the Transport Workers Union broke off negotiations with the Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority.

title: Kennedy Supporters Sue Carter Aides on Fund Use
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  A group of supporters of Senator Edward M. Kennedy filed suit today accusing seven Cabinet members and seven Presidential assistants of improperly using their Government positions and public funds to promote President Carter's election campaign.

title: Firefighters and Mayor Are at Standoff in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 28  The city's firefighters continued their work slowdown today as their union and the city administration remained at loggerheads in a dispute over wages and the work week.

title: Around the Nation
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 28 (AP) Federal district judge today denied motions to delay the courtordered sale of quartershare in The Manchester Union Leader, and ordered that the transaction be completed by Monday's deadline.

title: Notes on People
description: Earlier this year, a passage in a review of Enrique Hank Lopez's book The Harvard Mystique attracted the attention of Joseph C. GouIdea. The passage said some of the material in the book seemed to have been drawn from such best sellers as The Superlawyers. Mr. Goulden, who wrote The Superlawyers, a book about famous lawyers that was published in 1972, went out and got a copy of Mr. Lopez's book.

title: Where Kidnapping Is Business
description: LONDON, Dec. 28  Not a cloak or a dagger, not even a pinstudded map or a rogue's gallery grace the offices of Control Risks Ltd., a few blocks from the Tower of London.

title: Sax be Says Nixon Applied Pressure To Intervene in Watergate Matters
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI)  In the final months of his Presidency, Richard M. Nixon repeatedly put pressure on the Justice Department to intervene in Watergaterelated matters, former Attorney General William B. Saxbe and his deputy said today.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Steve Cady
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 28  On the way to the airport today, a middleaged cabdriver named Marc had all figured out.

title: Deaths
description: REINHARDT  Mildred L., on December 27, 1979 of Hicksville (formerly at Manhasset) devoted wife of the late Walter, mother of Janice White of Hicksville and Betty Smith of Illinois. Sister of Helen Scott. Six grandchildren also survive. Reposing at The Vernon C. Wagner Funeral Home, Inc. 125 Old Country Rd, Hicksville. Mass Monday 10:30 am in Our Lady of Mercy R.C. Church. Intombment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx.

title: Deaths
description: ADLEREdward M. Beloved son of Betty and Sidney. Loving brother of Joseph, Devid, Nathan, Caroline Goldwyn and Susan. Services Sunday 9:45AM Boulevard Park West 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Steel Strike Set in Britain
description: LONDON, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  Leaders of Britain's 150,000 steelworkers ordered a strike tonight after national pay negotiations broke down.

title: The U.N. Today
Carter Pulls Out of Forum in Iowa, Saying the Iran Crisis Gets Priority
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  President Carter, saying he could not participate in a political event because of the hostage crisis in Iran, withdrew today from forum with his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.

title: Jazz: Smithsonian Ensemble
description: The Smithsonian Jazz Repertory Ensemble, an eightpiece group under the direction of Bob Wilber, made its New York debut Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall with a program that stretched from Jelly Roll Morton to Charlie Parker. It also included sam- plings of the repertories of Bix Beiderbecke, James P. Johnson, Fats Waller, the Duke Ellington small groups and Thelonious Monk.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Theater: In Nutcracker, Tavel Is Again Prankish
description: In the 1960's, as one of the creators of the Ridiculous Theater movement and as the author of Gorilla Queen, Ronald Tavel revealed a prankish sense of comedy, which derived its primary source from old movies, comic books and popular myths. In the early 70's, in his best work, plays such as Bigfoot and Queen of Greece, he began to explore society, science and history. With his linguistic agility, he seemed to be a kind of highcamp American equivalent of Tom Stoppard. However, his more recent works  a children's show and a travesty of Anita Bryant  have been chaotic rather than comic.

title: 45 Debutantes Bow In at International Ball
description: Fortyfive young women representing 12 countries and 9 states made their formal bows to society at the 25th annual International Debutante Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria last night.

title: Clerics Say Hostages Were Eager for News
description: The Americans being held hostage in the United States Embassy in Teheran have been cut off since Nov. 4 from I knowledge of the outside world, the clergymen who visited them at Christmas said yesterday. The hostages were unaware, for example, that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi had left the United States for Panama.

title: Advisory Arbitrator Is Ordered In Strike by Cleveland Teachers
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (AP)  Judge Frederick M. Coleman ordered the school board and striking Cleveland teachers tonight to present details of their pay dispute to an advisory arbitrator.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WNCN. Hirt auf dem Felsen, Schubert; Flute Concerto, Woodcock; Symphony in C, J.A. Benda; Adagio for Strings, Barber; Trumpet Works, Fantini.

title: On a Clear and Windy Day, a Compressed View Across the Harbor Blends a Skyline's Symmetry
description: As brisk winds cleared the air yesterday of smoke and smog, the view of Manhattan's skyline, as seen through a telephoto lens from the shore of New Jersey, had the Statue of Liberty merged into the geometry of the lower Man- hattan skyline. Temperatures under sunny skies were seasonally mild yesterday, with a high of 48 degrees recorded in Central Park at 2 P.M. Much of the same is expected today, with temperatures ranging from 33 to 48 degrees.

title: Carter's Statement on Iran and Afghan Situations
description: Thank you. Secretary of State Vance will proceed to the United Nations tomorrow to press the world's case against Iran, in order to obtain the speediest possible release of American hostages in accordance with demands which have already been made earlier by the United Nations Security Council and the International Court of Justice.

title: Geniality (and Bargains) Luring Philadelphians to Italian Market
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28  If it wasn't family, this would never work family you can pay cheap and tell them they'll inherit, said Paul Giordano Jr. as he stood behind the cash register of his family shop here in the bustling Italian Market.

description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5 30 PM FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS UNTIL 2 30 PM ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9 00 A.M TO 4.30 PM MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY, NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900, WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300, NASSAU CO (516) 7470500, SUFFOLK CO (516) 6691800, CONNECTICUT (203) 3467767

title: Steel Exports Up in Japan
description: TOKYO, Dec. 28 (AP)  Japan exported 2.5 million metric tons of steel products in November, up 4.6 percent from October and up 1.2 percent from the yearearlier month, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said in a preliminary report today.

title: State Initiates Audits Of All Commissaries For Mental Hospitals
description: The state's Office of Mental Health began a sweeping audit and policy review yesterday of commissaries in all 33 state mental hospitals.

title: Colts Show Interest in Idzik
description: The Baltimore Colts, looking for a new head coach after Thursday's dismissal of Ted Marchibroda, yesterday approached John Idzik, the ousted offensive coordinator of the New York Jets. Idzik was an assistant at Baltimore in the early 1970's.

title: London and Bonn Criticize Soviet Role in Afghanistan
description: BONN, Dec. 28  West Germany, expressing grave concern, and Britain, accusing the Soviet Union of open intervention, reacted with striking firmness today to Soviet military involvement in the coup in Afghanistan.

title: For Bottega Veneta, Wider Horizons
description: When Vittorio Moltedo came to New York in the summer of 1972 to open the first Bottega Veneta shop, he knew nothing about retailing. He had been selling the Italian manufacturer's leather handbags to stores here and thought a boutique was a good idea.

title: MortgageRate Ceilings Suspended Till March 31
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  President Carter signed legislation today suspending the ceilings on home mortgage interest rates imposed by various states until March 31. He predicted the step would immediately help Americans obtain mortgage loans that would not otherwise have been available.

title: BL's Fight for Survival
description: LONDON, Dec. 28  The arrangement under which BL Ltd. will produce a new Hondadesigned car here was initiated by the troubled British company to fend off disaster while it desperately goes about replacing its aging line of small and mediumsized cars.

title: U.S. Imports Of Steel Rise
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (AP)  Foreign countries shipped 1.65 million tons of steel to the United States in November, a smaller increase than expected over October's steel imports of 1.6 million tons, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Dec. 28, 1979

title: Rock Island Files Plan to Reorganize
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP)  The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad filed a reorganization plan in Federal bankruptcy court today, saying it needed to eliminate nearly threequarters of its trackage to stay financially afloat.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, Dec. 28, 1979

title: A U.S. Judge Upholds City's Ban on Opening Of New Massage Sites
description: A zoning regulation to prevent any new massage parlors from opening in New York City was upheld yesterday by a Federal judge, but he said a trial would be needed to determine if the city could use the regulation to close existing massage parlors.

title: Bill Rates Up Slightly In U.S. Sale
description: The Treasury reported yesterday that rates rose slightly in its sale of threemonth and sixmonth bills, a financing moved ahead because Government offices will be closed on Monday. It also announced plans to sell 15-year bonds next Thursday.

title: New Zealand Troops in Rhodesia Trek Into the Unknown
description: LUPANE, Rhodesia, Dec. 28  At first light today, Maj. Patrick McDonald and 16 other New Zealanders set off from this besieged community in western Rhodesia on a mission into neighboring tribal lands. The mission is expected to give an early indication of the prospects for peace under the Britishsupervised ceasefire.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Most Editors in Survey Believe Carter Will Be Party's Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)  Most editors of major newspapers across the country believe President Carter will be the Democratic standardbearer in 1980, with inflation as the major issue, according to a survey made public today.

title: 'Manhattan' Wins Best Picture Award
description: Woody Allen's Manhattan was named best picture of 1979 by the National Board of Review yesterday, as that group chose the winners of its 1979 David Wait Griffith Awards. Sally Field was named best actress for her

title: Mary Hays Weik, 81, A Writer, Was Active In Antinuclear Cause
description: Mary Hays Weik, a writer and antinuclear activist, died at her Manhattan home on Christmas Day. She was 81 years old.

title: Maximum Base Rent Up In Controlled Apartments
description: In a move that raised the ceiling on rents in rentcontrolled apartments, the city increased the level of maximum base rents by 10 percent yesterday.

title: Soviet Said to Act in Afghanistan To Protect Political-Strategic Stake
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  Administration officials said today that they believed the Soviet Union mounted its military effort in Afghanistan to try to preserve a large politicalstrategic stake there that was menaced by the disintegration of the Afghan Government and Army.

title: A Terrorist, Freed by Hijackers, Is Facing Extradition to Sweden
description: Federal officials began proceedings to extradite a Croatian terrorist to Sweden, where he was freed from prison in 1972 at the demand of airline hijackers. The man, Miro Baresic, 29 years old, had been serving a life sentence after being convicted in 1971 of murdering Vladimir Rodovich, the Yugoslav Ambassador to Sweden.

title: L.I.R.R. Police Officer Wounded
description: An offduty Long Island Rail Road police officer apparently shot himself in the head in a suicide attempt in an L.I.R.R. station at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues in Brooklyn at about 10:50 P.M., the city police said. The officer, identified as Anthony Politano, 38 years old, was taken to Long Island College Hospital. His condition was listed as fair.

title: Ozawa Leads Chinese in a First Beethoven Ninth
description: PEKING, Dec. 28  Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, says Seiji Ozawa, is a big, tough piece. And tonight, after he had finished conducting the Peking Central Philharmonic Orchestra in the first of three performances of it, Mr. Ozawa said kindly, I thought they were really trying

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Your Money
description: MARGE and Walt had been married for 30 years and had just packed their youngest child off to college when they were divorced. Walt had agreed to pay Marge $1,000 a month in alimony, but he fell behind soon after retiring on a generous pension from the company be had worked for all his career.

title: Duran to Fight Ugandan
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 28 (UPI) Roberto Duran, seeking a title bout against either Sugar Ray Leonard or Jos (Pipino) Cuevas, will fight Josef Nsubuga of Uganda at Caesars Palace Jan. 13.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: THOMAS F. B. HAGAN

title: The Struggle to Improve Welfare
description: The legislative path to welfare reform has been tortuous. Every ambitious Presidential scheme overhaul the unsuccessful system  notably Richard Nixon's Family Assistance Plan and Jimmy Carter's Program for Better Jobs and Income  has failed in Congress. The Carter Administration has long since lowered its sights and, as a result, the House has handed it  and the poor  a modest victory by approving a bill that improves benefits in several areas. It sets a national minimum for welfare benefits, requires assistance to twoparent families, and pays bigger share of local welfare costs. So far, so good.

title: AvantGarde: By Ashley
description: Robert Ashley calls his Perfect Lives (Private Parts), which has been receiving its most complete performances thus far at the Dance Theater Workshop this week, an opera. Literalists will quibble, as they did when Robert Wilson and Philip Glass called their Einstein on the Beach an opera, but at least Mr. Ashley is announcing his intentions early on. If the word opera can be most broadly defined as a work, then in the context of the contemporary avantgarde it can safely be taken to mean a major work. And on the basis of the four halfhour segments (out of a projected total of seven) that were performed on Thursday, the second evening of a run that ends with performances tonight at 7.30 and tomorrow afternoon at 2:30, Perfect Lives (Private Parts) is major work, comparable to Einstein in its confidence, originality and richness, if not in its considerably more intimate physical scope.

title: Ralph B. Johnson Is Dead at 84; ExPartner With Investment Firm
description: Ralph B. Johnson, a retired partner of the investment banking firm of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, died Thursday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Preview of N.F.C. Playoff Games: Cowboys and Eagles Favored
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers, who managed to lose 26 straight times in 1976 and 1977, find themselves the host team today in the first of the National Football League's four division playoff games to be contested this weekend.

title: Letter: On Domestic Crude Oil Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Long December Shadows
description: pie walking south and facing into the lambent December light seemed to move more slowly than those going north? Was towing their trailing shadows such a heavy burden? How much, I wondered, does a shadow weigh? Is it easier to push it ahead

title: TV: Kennedy Center Honors Celebrates the Performing Arts
description: Yet another award show? Take heart. The Kennedy Center Honors: A Celebration of the Performing Arts, to be seen on CBSTV tonight at 8 o'clock is a winner, despite any misgivings you might have about sitting through two hours of the usual award mlange of great talents, small talk and heavy emotion.

title: Building New York City, and NonBuilding
description: The state of public building in New York City  or, rather, the current state of nonbuilding in the public sector  mirrors political attitudes toward that overabused and occasionally overpraised institution, the New York public authority.

title: German Brewers Looking to U.S. Market
description: BONN, Dec. 28 (AP)  West German breweries are seeking a bigger share of the United States import market, now dominated by the Netherlands.

title: Skipper of Cargo Schooner Vows To Raise Her And Pursue Profit
description: The skipper of the cargo schooner that foundered in a storm off Long Island vowed yesterday to raise the 97foot ship and turn her into a commercial venture despite the accident that ended her maiden voyage, He spoke on shore as a Coast Guard cutter reporteo no sign of the twomasted wooden sailing vessel, the first of its type to be built in the United States in nearly half a century.

title: Sakharov Retracts His Report Of Suicide Attempt by Dissident
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident leader, said today that a report he distributed Wednesday that a jailed human rights activist had tried to commit suicide in his cell had proved to be false.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times on Thursday about Arvin Brown, director of Watch on the Rhine, the list of plays he has directed for Broadway was incomplete. They also include The National Health and a revival Of Ah, Wilderness!  both at Circle in the Square.

title: Four Miami Police Officers Charged in Fatal Beating
description: MIAMI, Dec. 28 (AP)  Four police officers were charged with manslaughter today in the death by beating of a 33yearold Miami businessman.

title: Flyer Streak Reaches 32
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 28 (UPI)  Reggie Leach's 25th goal of the season, at 12 minutes 34 seconds of the final period, lifted Philadelphia to a 53 victory tonight over the Winnipeg Jets, extending the Flyers' National Hockey League unbeaten streak to a record 32 games.

title: ARTHUR SYLVESTER, EXU.S. AIDE, IS DEAD
description: Arthur Sylvester, a former newspaper editor and correspondent who became the Defense Department's spokesman for six years in the 1960's, died yesterday, after a short illness, at Butterfield Hospital Cold Spring. N.Y., where he recently served a term as Mayor. He was 78 years old.

title: Parisian Night Life In Unlikely Settings
description: PARIS  Where to go for excitement if you're weary of spots like Maxim's and Rgine's? Parisians are turning to nightclubs and restaurants in untraditional settings  a public bath, for instance, or a wrestling arena. or a Gothic chapel.

title: Prisoner Rejoices at Spirit of the Law
description: Just before he left his brother's wedding reception in Small's Paradise in Harlem last Saturday night, Darryl Harris jumped onto a chair near the bandstand and grabbed a microphone. He waited for the 200 people in the hall to become quiet, and as he waited he began crying. Then he spoke, haltingly.

title: Move Against Synanon Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI)  Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court refused today to block California's attempt to place the Synanon Foundation in financial receivership. Justice Rehnquist turned down a request by the nonprofit corporation to bar George Deukmejian, the California Attorney General, from beginning proceedings in state court. Earlier, a Federal district judge in California refused the group's request for a preliminary injunction.

title: Tighter Air Traffic Rules Urged in San Diego Area
description: The National Transportation Safety Board urged Federal officials yesterday to take emergency action to tighten airtraffic rules around San Diego in the aftermath of two nearcollisions involving airliners last month.

title: SOVIET SAYS AFGHANS ASKED FOR ITS HELP
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28  The Soviet Union 'today portrayed its military intervention in Afghanistan as a response to a request for military assistance against the provocations of external enemies.

title: About New York
description: It has not been the best of years for Ida Kaminska, shining light of the Yiddish theater. She spent it turning 80, mourning her husband, who died just about a year ago, and reflecting on her . past as director of the Jewish State Theater in Warsaw for 21 years before she went into selfexile during an upsurge of official antiSemitism in 1968. For all that, Miss Kaminska is not reedy to retire to a life that looks only back. She has plans, is at liberty, will travel. She remains the complete professional.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel met with President Carter today and asked for more American assistance to help Israel deal with its economic problems.

title: Margaret Clary Married To Tobias M. Bisharat
description: Margaret Mary Clary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Andrew Clary of Yarmouthport, Mass., was married at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Hyannis, Mass., yesterday to Tobias Maurice Bisharat. son of clarita Uhlmann Bisharat of London and Victor Hanna Bisharat of Greenwich. Conn. Msgr. Charles H. Sewall, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Robert J. Casey and the Rev. Raymond F. X. Cahill.

title: 37,000 Gave Up Farms In 1979, U.S. Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) About 37,000 farmers in the United States went out of business this year, continuing a 44year trend to fewer and larger farms, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: OBSERVER
description: I intended to summarize the decade today, as a dull journalist should at this turn of the Earth, but fell instead to thinking about my grandfather, who was born 125 years ago. That was in 1854, and though he is dead now and beyond the tedium of yearend and decadeend press summations, I wonder what, if anything, that happened from 1970 through 1979 would have struck him as worth reading about.

title: Satellite Photograph
Dumping Protection on Ourselves
description: Everyone wants economic security, but insecurity is what free enterprise is all about. Whenever someone invents a new product or a cheaper way to make an old one, someone else gets driven out of business. But when people are faced with this harsh reality, they forget the speeches they may have made about the virtues of competition and run to the Government for protection. That just happened at Chrysler; that's what is about happen in a new wave of protection for American industries.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
HondaBL Pact May Set Pattern
description: TOKYO, Dec. 28  The new agreement under which BL Ltd., formerly British Leyland, will produce compact Honda cars in Britain is expected in industrial circles here to set a pattern for efforts by other major Japanese auto makers to stave off a rising tide of antiJapanese protectionism overseas.

title: China Opens a New Airport
description: PEKING, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  A new airport, the largest in northeast China, went into operation yesterday at Harbin, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: I.M.F. Said to Bar Iran Bid on Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Iran has last a bid to have the International Monetary Fund condemn the United States decision to freeze Iranian assets totaling more than billion within American Jurisdiction. an I.M.F. source said today.

title: 2 Queens Burdens: Budget, Recruiting
description: Lucille Kyvallos considered the fact that for the first time in its fouryear history the Queens College Women's Holiday Basketball Tournament was without a top10 ranked team.

title: Hair Shapes Up in Braids and Bobs
description: After several years of comparative quiet, hair's beginning to fly again in the beauty salons. Women are getting bored with long, loose hair that looks just like everybody else's and the men behind the scissors and blowers are creating again, after a period of doing nothing more interesting than winding model's hair into whimsical topknots.

title: Higher Traffic Fines for Czechs
description: PRAGUE, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  Onthespot fines for traffic offenders will be doubled next year, Rude Pravo, the Czechoslovak Communist Party daily, said today. The maximum fine for speeding will go up from $50 to $100. Fines for other offenses will be increased to $20.

title: Deaths
description: GRUMBACH  Edna R. Congregation EmanuEl of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Edna R. Grumbach, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of her passing. It Is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life, may all who loved her be comforted.

title: For Want of a Key, 10 Inmates Die In South Carolina County Jail Fire
description: LANCASTER, S.C., Dec. 28  A few more weeks for a new jail, a few more dollars to go bail, the right key to a padlock  these were all that the jailers and those locked up at the Lancaster County jail needed to escape last night's fire. But they did not have them, and 10 of the 11 inmates died.

title: City Receives Federal Funds to Assist Commercial Construction Projects
description: New York City received five Federal grants yesterday to aid commercial construction. They included an expected $10.35 million award to supplement state and private funds needed to build the new headquarters for the American Stock Exchange at Battery Park City.

title: New Clash Erupts in Tabriz and Hostages Are Seized
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 28  A dozen Iranians were being held hostage late tonight in Tabriz by critics of Ayatollah RuhoBah Khomeini after new fighting between Teheran's forces and backers of Ayatollah Kazem ShariatMadari.

title: New Afghan Regime Says Moscow Agrees to Send in Additional Aid
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 28  Afghanistan's new Government, which came to power yesterday in a coup apparently planned and carried out by the Soviet Union, announced today That the Russians had agreed to a new program of urgent political, moral and economic aid, including military aid.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Opponents Step Up Attacks on Her Son
description: BOMBAY, India, Dec. 28  As India's election campaign enters its final week, with former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi poised to make a comeback, her opponents are stepping up their attacks on what they regard as her greatest weakness  her son Sanjay.

title: Iran Notifies Panama That It Intends to Ask For the Shah's Return
description: PANAMA, Dec. 28 (AP)  Iran has told Panama that it will request extradition of the deposed Shah, President Aristides Royo said today, but he added it was unlikely that Iran would be able to fulfill Panama's legal requirements.

title: Knicks Top Bulls, 120102
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP)  Michael Ray Richardson scored 26 points and Bill Cartwright added 19 tonight as the New York Knicks defeated the Chicago Bulls, 120102.

title: New Tomato Hurts Small Growers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A thickskinned, highyielding variety of tomato, sometimes called the square tomato, is causing problems for small California growers and canners even as it helps assure a steady supply of tomato products for the rest of the country.

title: COMPANY NEWS National Gypsum To Sell Cement Unit
description: DALLAS, Dec. 28 (AP)  The National Gypsum Company announced today that it had agreed to sell its cement division to the General Dynamics Corporation for about $100 million.

title: I.B.M. Sets Wide Rises In Its Prices
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday what amounted to acrosstheboard price increases on its products.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Narrows
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)  The United States trade deficit narrowed to $1.4 billion in November as the volume of oil imports fell to the lowest level in almost two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Music: The Hidden Talent of R D.Q. Bach
description: Musical humor is like clerical humor in that both are based on the faintly sacrilegious pleasure to be had from kidding sacrosanct subjects. They are also similar in another significant way: rarely is the joke good enough to justify the laughter it elicits. The musical joker, like the jocular pastor, usually needs only to announce his intention to be humorous, and almost any material he chooses will do the job.

title: Teamsters Drivers Walk Out At Eight Major Movie Studios
description: HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 28 (AP) walkout today by more than 2,000 Teamsters Union drivers stopped virtually all transportation at Southern California's eight major movie studios.

title: U.S. REPORTED READY TO DEFER U.N. PLEA FOR IRAN SANCTIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 28 The United States has decided to defer its call for sanctions against Iran and instead will ask the Security Council to send Secretary General Kurt Waldheim to Teheran to seek the release of the American hostages.

title: Options and Problems for Russian Forces in Afghanistan
description: After establishing control of Kabul, the Soviet Union's ground and air forces must now cope with serious and in some cases unorthodox military problems. And if unsolved, the problems could undermine the impression of Russian military

title: PayFreeze Vote Saves Steel Plant
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28Steelworkers at the Ambridge, Pa., plant of the United States Steel Corporation voted today to accept a threeyear wage freeze and the company immediately announced that the plant, employing some 1,200 workers, would be kept open.

title: FOUR OIL EXPORTERS RAISE PRICES 1015% ABOVE LATEST RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  In what appeared to signal a new round of international oil price increases, several major exporting countries today announced price rises of 10 to 15 percent.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Some Testimony From the Taping
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  Following are excerpts from the testimony of Pearl Reeves in the robbery trial of Rich- ard L. Goodson as taken down by a newspaper reporter in the court- room:

title: Appellate Judges in Jersey Back All Convictions Against Kallinger
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28 (AP)  A state appeals court today upheld all convictions in New Jersey against Joseph Kallinger, a former Phildelphia shoemaker found guilty of sexoriented attacks on two worn en while accompanied by his 12yearold son.

title: The City
description: A smoky twoalarm fire broke out yesterday on the 37th floor of the American Brands Building, at Park Avenue and 97th Street, forcing the evacuation of the building's upper floors and snarling midtown traffic. Two firefighters suffered minor cuts and were treated at Bellevue Hospital and released.

title: More Youth Jobs Reported Sought In Carter Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  Despite the Carter Administration's emphasis on fiscal restraint, the President's forthcoming budget will include substantially more money for youth employment programs, while public service employment levels will remain unchanged, according to Government officials.

title: North Carolina Wins Gator Bowl by 1715
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP)  Matt Kupec engineered a 97yard, thirdquarter scoring drive tonight, to help North Carolina post a 1715 upset victory over 14thranked Michigan in the Gator Bowl. It was the seventh consecutive postseason setback for the Wolverines.

title: U.S. Orders Inspections Of 747 Engine Mounts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)  The Federal Aviation Administration ordered United States airlines tonight to inspect engine mounts on most of their Boeing 747 aircraft as the result of damage to one of the jumbo jets in a rough landing in London. None of the three crewmen on that plane was hurt, in the landing but the forward part of one engine dropped, leaving the engine attached at the rear.

title: Videotape at Court Trial: The Replay Is in Dispute
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 28  The first videotaping of a trial witness in Long Island's history did not go smoothly last week.

title: Jack Kofoed Is Dead at 85
description: Jack Kofoed, for 44 years a columnist for The Miami Herald and in the 1920's and 30's a New York newspaperman, died Thursday at the North Miami General Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: CARTER CALLS SOVIET ACTIONS A THREAT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  President Carter said today that the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan was a grave threat to the peace and blatantly violated international rules of behavior.

title: Reviewing NationalSecurity Policy Before Approving SALT
description: The debate on the SALT II treaty has left the people of the United States confused and, even worse, indifferent. This is due largely to the absence from public discussion of a current definition of foreignpolicy and nationalse

title: Filling the Planning Chairs
description: Mayor Koch finally looked in his backyard to fill the chairmanship of the City Planning Commission. He chose Herbert Sturz, who has been serving ably as Deputy Mayor, and then Coordinator, for Criminal Justice. Having pursued a distinguished career in the justice field, Mr. Sturz lacks specific training in urban planning and capital budgeting, zoning, or community affairs  the major commission responsibilities. But his administrative talents and the pleasant, firm manner with which he manages to advance programs doubtless attracted the Mayor.

title: A.M.C. Raises '80 Prices 1.6%
description: DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP)  The American Motors Corporation today joined the second round of industry price increases this model year with an average rise of $134, or 1.6 percent, in sticker prices of its cars and Jeeps.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA. Lincoln Center. Humperdinck's Hansel and Gretel, 2; Strauss's Der Rosenkavaller, 8.

title: Carol Deitch Schein Is Bride Of Arthur Gill, an Executive
description: At the Village Temple in New York yesterday. Carol Deitch Schein of Irvington, N.Y., head of the social science department and director of college guidance at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married to Ar- thur Gill of New York, president of Argil Electronics Ltd. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony.

title: Hunt Brothers Buy 3% Equity in Bache
description: N. Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt, two Texas brothers who are reputedly among the richest individuals in the United States, recently purchased a major interest in the Bathe Group Inc., the securities firm holding company.

title: What About The Fish?
description: I feel a patriotic responsibility in writing this, because enough is enough and soon I won't have any fingernails left to bite and what about the fish, Mr. Editor?

title: Books of The Times
description: It is not uncommon to see people in public places moving their lips, silently talking to themselves, and the essayist is the exception who writes down and publishes this incessant internal monotome. He throws words and ideas back

title: 2 Escapees Seized in Idaho
description: BLACKFOOT, Idaho, Dec. 28 (AP) Two prison escapees from New Mexico were arrested here last night, leaving only one of the 11 inmates who broke out of the prison Dec. 9 at large. The police said William Norush and Richard Chapman were arrested, unarmed and without incident, when they left a motel. The two were taken to the Bannock County Jail at Pocatello to await extadition.

title: Jersey Approves Operation of Controversial Meadowlands Garbage Baler
description: NEWARK, Dec. 28  The Board of Public Utility Commissioners today removed the final governmental obstacle blocking the operation of a controversial $6.9 million solidwaste baler in the Hack- ensack Meadowlands by approving a certificate of need for the facility and a rate structure that could more than double the costs of disposal of solid wastes by municipalities and private carters.

title: Coalition Presents Ballot Initiative To Raise California Oil Profits Tax
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28  A coalition of consumers and organized labor delivered more than enough signatures today to qualify a statewide initiative to more than double the state tax on the profits of major oil companies.

title: 3 ExHouston Policemen Begin Terms for Civil Rights Violations
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 28 (UPI)  Three dismissed Houston policemen began sentences of one year and one day in a minimumsecurity Federal prison today for their role in the death of a MexicanAmerican.

title: $2 Million Award by Jury Is Cut to 6 Cents by Judge
description: An acting New York State Supreme Court justice has reduced a $2 million damage award to 6 cents for a woman who accused her landlord of harassment and his agent of sexual assault.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1979

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Friday, Dec. 28, 1979

title: U.S. Banks Use Frozen Iran Assets To Pay Off Debts of Shah's Regime
description: American banks lent hundreds of millions of dollars to the Shah of Iran and entities linked to him in the last few years, according to bank documents in Iran and the United States.

title: Music Notes: A Violin Prodigy
description: If the name of AnneSophie Mutter is unknown to the general music public in this country, it's a safe bet that it will not remain so from now on. The violinist, who is a mere 16, will make her United States debut next Thursday with the New York Philharmonic, playing the Mendelssohn E minor Concerto. She comes here as protegee of Herbert von Karajan, who auditioned her when she was 13 and immediately engaged her for appearances with him at the Salzburg Festival and with the Berlin Philharmonic.

title: MUSIC
description: THE distinction of sponsoring the first major concert event on the 1980 Connecticut calendar goes to an organization that spearheaded the cultural revival in the area, and has long served as a model for similar musical societies all around the state. It's the Friends of Music, based in Westport, and its 23d anniversary season will highlight chamber performances by a number of outstanding ensembles, plus an assortment of lectures and private musicales.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Rare coins are basking in an unaccustomed spotlight as the final curtain falls on the 1970's. Interest and prices stand at an alltime high, and there is every indication that the pattern will continue as the old decade gives way to the new.

title: British and Rhodesians Split Over Ceasefire Response
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 29  British and Rhodesian officials painted radically different pictures today of the state of the ceasefire as guerrillas who fought the Salisbury Government for seven years began linking up with the Commonwealth Monitoring Force.

title: POLITICS
description: LIKE the ghost of Jacob Marley in Dickens's A Christmas Carol, the Oyster BayRye bridge across Long Island Sound is rising from the grave to haunt Nassau Republican politicians again.

title: America: the Seventies and Beyond
Let him twist slowly, slowly in the wind
description: WASHINGTON  One of the ironies of history is that some of the most fundamental changes occur in periods that on the surface seem stagnant or dominated by conservatism. So it was in the 1970's, when quiet fmled over the cities and John D Ehrlichman, or L Patrick Gray 3d, March 6, 1973 campuses, when much of the population seemed disillusioned with government and politically cautious, when Keynesian economics fell into disfavor as the nation embraced the goal of a balanced budget.

title: Excerpts of the Discussion
description: Following are excerpts from the roundtable discussion earlier this month of Connecticut in the 1980's:

title: STAMPS
description: The United States is continuing four series in 1980, in addition to concluding one series and honoring five women of achievement and three men on single commemoratives. Other issues are promised for the American past, for various aspects of nature, and forAmerica's achievements in space.

title: Washington Irving and
description: THE biographical mode has been expanding in several directions of late. It is not only that individual lives can run to a thousand pages and up to five volumes. Nothing new about that: Philip McFar land, in Sojourners, n minds us that Washington Irving's life of his namesake George Washington also filled five volumes and that the oldfashioned Life and Letters regularly required two tomes. It is, rather, that the biographical subject itself has been multiplying. Michael Holroyd's Lytton Strachey might be called a group biography, taking as it does long biographical looks at those other personages who formed Strachey's human and intellectual surroundings. Family biography seems now to be on the rise  we have recently had sagas of the Rockefeller and the Sitwell clans, among others  somewhat unsteady efforts, to my mind; this genre needs clarifying. With Sojourners we encounter yet another and larger species that I am tempted to call epochal biography.

title: Small Shifts in U.S. Population Of 243 Million
description: WASHINGTON  If the Census Bureau's projections are right, there will be about 243 million Americans by the end of the 1980's. How will they be distributed? Will the suburbs still stand as the most prominent feature of Ameri can urban life? Or will the older central cities revive? Will the shift of population and jobs toward the socalled sunbelt persist?

title: WHERE'S FATHER?
description: Passing, fumbling tackling, blocking

title: DINING OUT Philosophy vs. Practical Application
description: LA MONET opened 18 months ago in the premises formerly occupied by a popular Morristown restaurant called L'Affaire. The new establishment is under the guidance of three seasoned professionals: George Demos, who has Philosophy vs. Practical Application been a restaurateur for 25 years; his partner, George Meyer, who was the maitre d'hotel at the Canoe Brook Country Club in Summit, and Ralph Cutes, the chef, who received his culinary training in Europe.

title: Martha Swope
description: SHOUT ACROSS THE RIVERBarbar edaYoung and Ellen Barken in the Phoenix production of Stephen Poliakoff's drama, opening Wednesday at Marymount Manhattan.

title: Search for Satellite Focuses on Sussex
description: WASHINGTON ATINY $50 million satellite that the RCA Corporation launched earlier this month is still lost in space. And technicians at the company's tracking station in the Sussex County community of Vernon Valley are still pouring over complex formulas and feeding data into their computers in a desperate search to find it.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Take time out to learn from experiences of the Old Year and look forward to making better efforts in the New.

title: Seton Hall Defeats Wagner Five, 7365
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 29  Seton Hall defeated Wagner, 7365, tonight, dropping the Seahawks from the unbeaten ranks and breaking their regularseason winning streak at 23 games. Wagner had won seven games this season.

title: First in Sports, First to Admit It
description: If any single individual dominated the sporting scene in the 1970's, it was Muhammad Ali. As a garrulous 18yearold named Cassius Clay, he achieved prominence in 1960 when he won the Olympic light heavyweight championship. He succeeded to the professional heavyweight championship of the world in 1964, joined the sect called Black Muslims and changed his name, and in the late 60's his defiance of the draft made him a hero to youth protesting United States involvement in Vietnam.

title: CHESS
description: Siegbert Tarrasch, writing about the Tarrasch Defense in his 1931 book The Game of Chess, was greeted with snickers when he declared, The future will decide who has erred in estimating this defense  I or the chess world. But the derision is currently fading into embarrassment in the face of an epidemic of successful Tarrasch Defenses.

title: CONCLUSION
description: Well, no one expected consensus. But what a melange of contradictory specifics: oil auctions, a Federal Energy Corporation, excises on gaspline, elimination of payroll taxes, wage and price controls, 4 percent monetary growth, centralized collective bargaining, and more. Nor is there unity on whether the Government's role in repairing the economy should expand or contract.

title: Vines on the Skyscrapers
description: When a sciencefiction novel is published with no reference to the fact that it is s.f., the presumption is that the book has transcended the usual limitations of genre writing  pulpy prose, stock characters and followthedots plotting. As often, however, the label is left off the package because the imaginative component of the tale is too inconsiderable to pass muster with an audience of any sciencefictional sophistication. It is the special task of such intellectually sanitized si. to purvey familiar ideas at a pace slow enough and in a style bald enough that even a rudimentary consciousness can assimilate them. Such a book  such a safe, dull book  is A Secret History of Time to Come.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff spent some 13 hours on Dec. 18 at an open meeting near Ossining, N.Y., debating with an audience of several hundred who angrily rejected the concept that it is reasonable or possible to evolve a realistic plan of evacuation for people threatened by a disaster at the Indian Point nuclear power plants.

title: Karen Springhorn Is Affianced to John Gage
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Springhorn of Blue Point, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Karen Elizabeth Springhorn, to John Zeller Gage, son of Mrs. Harold S. Berry of Llewellyn Park, N.J., and Singer Island, Fla., and the late John Hunter Gage.

title: Khomeini Bids America Ring Bells for Oppressed
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Ira. nian Islamic leader, has urged Ameri. cans and others to rise up against oppression and to ring church bells in support of oppressed nations rather than  as President Carter suggested at Christmas  for the Americans held hostage.

title: Harold Pinter: I Started With Two People in a Pub
description: Harold Pinter, who began his career in the theater as an actor, has been writing plays for 22 years, from the oneact The Room to Betrayal, which is now in previews and will open at the Trafalgar Theater on Saturday. He has worked as a playwright, director and screenwriter, and is an associate director of Britain's National Theater. He is an extremely private individual and seldom gives interviews or makes public speeches, although he has occasionally participated in poetry readings  of his own work and that of others. Recently, we met late in the afternoon in his New York hotel suite. He spoke with his usual precision, rephrasing his words if he felt that they were not accurate, and pausing frequently.

title: Williams, Bradley Call 79 a Good Year
description: WASHINGTON NEW JERSEY'S two United States Senators found their past year's efforts a plus for the state and the country. And, they insisted at a yearend news conference, reports of a rivalry between them were greatly exaggerated.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Some movie years are like visits to the doctor  they seem endless at the time, but, in retrospect, they turn out to have been not bad at all. The past year has been such a year. It certainly wasn't all fun and games but, when you think about it, it wasn't really so terrible. Contributing to these mixed feelings were two colossal disappointments (Bernardo Bertolucci's Luna and Steven Spielberg's 1941), one movie so overreviewed while it was in production (Apocalypse Now) that its release had to be an anticlimax, plus a couple of arid patches when, as during the fall, there was very little to shout about. Then, too, there was an extraordinar, amount of junk. In spite of what most people think, it is not much fun to write about pictures like Sidney Sheldon's Bloodline, Hurricane, The Champ and the spectacle of Mae West losing her formidable race with the clock in Sextette. Nice people were involved in all of them.

title: Edna's Feeling Achy
description: BUFFALO  Edna's 71yearold eyes look gloomily out at the storm clouds gathering outside the window of her small apartment. The temperature has dropped 20 degrees. Yet no steam hisses out of the radiator. She feels a pain creep from her neck down through her shoulders and into the joints of her armpits. Winter is coming, and with it the struggle to keep warm.

title: For 1980: Pay More, Get Less
description: When you begin to think about your 1980 vacation plans, steel yourself for some disappointments. Here is what travel experts predict:

title: WILLIAM W. BABB
description: William W. Babb, a former treasurer and business manager of the Children's Book Council of New York City, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital after brief illness. Mr. Babb, who lived in Manhattan, was 78 years old.

title: Caracas Meeting Confirmed New Trend in World Distribution
description: PARIS  Pity the Seven Sisters. A decade ago, 70 percent of the world's oil trade passed through these imperious multinationals with names like Exxon, Texaco and Shell. Today, the percentage is below 50 and dropping. Stateowned companies, favored increasingly by both exporting and importing countries in a turbulent, expensive and increasingly politicized market, are crumpling the Sisters crinolines, with mixed results.

title: Fashion View
description: Clothes, as despicable as we think them, are unspeakably significant, wrote Thomas Carlyle in the 19th century. Clothes, from the king's mantle downward, are emblematic. In recent decades, the symbolism of fashion and the accouterments of appearance have intensified in their import. Take the antiestablishment 60's, for instance: the untamed manes of the flower children, the faded jeans of the affluencerejecting hippies, the discarded bras of the women's liberation movement, the kneefreeing skirts of Courreges, and the streetimitating gear of the radical chic. At first glance, the sartorial symbols of the 60's  wacky, vinylbright miniskirts and tattered hippy garb  may seem to have little in common. What they share, however, is a rejection of classical high fashion  an antifashion attitude that became, in the end, the most powerful and pervasive fashion of all.

title: TV VIEW
description: Probably the most prominent, certainly the most controversial television development of the year has been the major networks news coverage of the Iranian crisis. Additional money, personnel and air time have been expended on the story, and in many instances the results have been impressive. At the same time, however, certain aspects of the coverage have triggered criticism in various quarters, including the White House. Is television being manipulated by the Iranian revolutionaries? Should television newsmen agree to conduct interviews bound by restrictive conditions? Would the absence of television lower the intensity of the crisis? On very general level, the questions are not new, but they undoubtedly will be debated with renewed vigor for years come.

title: Author's Query
description: CARL HEINTZE

title: A Case of Ilychitis
description: N The Death of Ivan Ilych, set in the feudal Russia of 1882, Leo Tolstoy tells  with a commanding irony that finally turns into religious compassion  a bleak tale of the folly of earthly things. Ilych, a typical functionary, lawyer and prosecutor, has a successful public and private life, and is able not to mix the two.

title: Golden Hoard
description: Mark Spitz won seven gold medals at the 1972 Olympics, the most ever.

title: La Vern Pyles Jr. Weds Audrey RindeThorsen
description: Audrey RindeThorsen of Syosset, L.I., widow of Percy RindeThorsen, was married yesterday to LaVern Pyles Jr. of Dresher, Pa., a widower and Pennsylvania State Representative.

title: North Carolina Gives Its Conference a Lift
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29 (UPI)  North Carolina's Gator Bowl upset of Michigan last night added credence to the claim that football is coming into its own in the Atlantic Coast Conference, which has long been dominated by basketball.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Brigid C. Williams Is Affianced
description: Brigid Cunningham Williams and Patrick Calhoun Hickox, who received master's degrees in architecture from Yale University and are partners in Hickox Williams Associates, an architectural firm in New Haven, plan to be married next April 12.

title: Kimball S. Davis Is Wed in Stamford To Kevin P. Heelan
description: Kimball Sherman Davis of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin C. Davis Jr. of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Kevin Patrick Heelan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Heelan of Baltimore.

title: Illinois Sues Army Engineers
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UPI)  William J. Scott, the Illinois Attorney General, has filed suit against the Army Corps of Engineers, charging that it is allowing work on the Kankakee River in Indiana that could cause flooding in Illinois. The suit was filed Wednesday in Federal District Court. No hearing date has been set.

title: Smart Chips Off New Blocks
description: A new industrial revolution is being powered by such microcircuitry as the silicon chip, about the size of a match tip, that can contain the equivalent of 68,000 of the transistor switches that enable computers to think. These devices will make possible in the 1980's a host of new and better consumer products  both new versions of existing devices at affordable prices, and things that are still beyond the imagining.

title: Dish With a Dash of Luck
description: GIVEN the current economic and international situations, champagne and caviar, the usual luxury splurge to ring in the New Year, seem inappropriate. It's time to consider simpler fare that just might help things along in 1980.

title: Other National Events
description: It may prove an election year embarrassment, but Justice Department officials last week read the letter of the law on the admission of homosexual foreigners to the United States, and concluded that the Immigration and Naturalization Service must enforce the standing statutory ban. They concede, however, that there might be practical difficulties. After a suit last summer from a London antique restorer turned away from San Francisco because, when asked, he had said he was a homosexual, the Public Health Service, to which immigration inspectors refer questionable persons, cited generally accepted canons of medical practice and announced that it would no longer consider homosexuality a mental disease or defect.

title: In the Matter of Bobby Knight: The View From Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. IT would not surprise me if Bobby Knight soon claims that prior to the Pan American Games last July that at least two million Puerto Ricans decided to gang up on him for no reason at all. From the words he used in The New York Times of Dec. 2. it would seem like it  especially when he claims the only crime he committed in Puerto Rico was beating the Puerto Rican basketball team. This happened on the 13th day of the games.

title: BRIDGE
description: In one area of international bridge, the United States has been outstandingly unsuccessful. In two decades of quadrennial team olympiads the Americans have won neither the open title nor the women's title. Powerful squads have been dispatched with high hopes, but none of them have done better than finish second, and many of them have done much worse.

title: Cocaine May Be Chic, Booze Is the Big Worry
description: Consider, from the 1960's, Timothy Leary's muchquoted aphorism about drug use: Turn on, tune in, drop out.

title: POP MUSIC VIEW
description: In the wake of rockandroll's new wave, it's become more fashionable than ever to complain about how boring the 1970's were. As it happens, this decade, for all its flaws, seemed full of interest to this writer. But there can be no question that 1979 was a most eventful year, one that can be conceived almost in terms of classical drama. It saw a battle between disco and rock, and a struggle between the rock fathers and the rock sons, all against a backdrop of upheavals in the record business itself.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterdays Weather at 1 P M National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration /UPI

title: Our Saudi Friends
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  A funny thing happened on the way to the OPEC meeting in Venezuela.

title: I have wanted to meet you for a long time.
description: PARIS  At the end of World War II, Henry Luce proclaimed the advent of the American century, and many people agreed. It lasted little more than a generation. Now, America's role has changed. diminished in a way.

title: Two HalfCenturies Back to Back
description: THERE is much to be said for the occasional shifting of the chronological milestones that have traditionally marked the intellectual and cultural history of the past 300 years. It has not been decreed from on high that a break must be made around the time of the French Revolution, restricting the Enlightenment to the 18th century, an age dialectically followed in the next century by Romanticism, or the Romantic reaction.

title: 5 Exam Groups Ease Opposition To Law on Tests
description: In a sharp departure from their earlier position, the leaders of the Educational Testing Service and four of the major college and graduate school admissions testing programs have endorsed the principles of New York State's new truth in testing law, which takes effect Jan. 1.

title: ONLY SOVIET TROOPS SAID TO GUARD KABUL
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 29  Afghan troops patrolling the streets of Kabul were apparently replaced today by Soviet soldiers following the Soviet backed coup d'etat there Thursday.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Columbia University will not remain a gem in academe's crown unless it recognizes the decline of interest in the liberal arts, the falling numbers of humanities Ph.D.'s, and the danger of maintaining too many academic programs. Nineteen faculty members raised this specter in an unusually candid analysis of the university's arts and sciences departments, recently completed for and presented to Columbia's president, William J. McGill.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH the task of repairing small holes and cracks in plaster walls and ceilings, or in walls and ceilings of gypsum board (dry wall), is not an especially difficult one, many doityourselfers still seem to have trouble making a repair that will not crack, and one that will not require a great amount of sanding and smoothing when dry.

title: Hey, hey, my, my! Rockandroll will never die
description: Once upon a time, people knew what culture was. It had to do with what Matthew Arnold had lately called the best that had been known and thought in the world, and it was something that you worked at on your own.

title: EaglesBucs Scoring
description: INDIVIDUAL STATISTICS

title: New Staten Island Houses Show Inflation's Impact on Construction
description: On Staten Island, land with sewers was selling for $2.50 a square foot in 1969. Today that same land sells for $6.50 a square foot. And prices will continue to rise in 1980. Add to this a square foot cost of frame construction that has risen from $14 in 1969 to $35 in 1979 and you have buyer resistance, because the prices are too high, says Morton Meltzer of Avon Green Inc., now building on Staten Island.

title: The War America Lost
description: As 1970 began, American troop strength in Indochina stood at 475,000 and the Paris peace talks were stalemated. At home, antiwar protests intensified when National Guardsmen killed four student demonstrators at Kent State University after President Nixon ordered the invasion of Cambodia. The invasion led the Senate to repeal the Tonkin Resolution and to bar military operations in Cambodia. In 1971 fighting worsened throughout South Vietnam and President Nixon ordered North Vietnamese ports mined to put pressure on the still dragging Paris talks and to block war supplies.
