In 1973, a peace treaty was signed in Paris. North Vietnam began releasing United States prisoners. Finally, in 1975 the North Vietnamese overran Saigon. Altogether, 57,507 Americans were killed and 300,000 wounded; 44 are still unaccounted for.

title: Shifts Found in Student Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)  An increasing number of college students chose to set up their own households in the 1970's rather than live in dormitories or with their parents, according to a Census Bureau study.

title: GARDENING
description: AS the holiday season wanes, so often do the fortunes of holiday plants. The busy season may have left little time to provide them with adequate care, or the location in which they were used for decoration may have been unsuitable. Many plants may be beyond saving and would best be discarded as they fade. Others may still survive if given a bit of attention and care.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: STATE environmental officials want the state's owners of forest lands to do more reporting and housekeeping in order to maintain tax benefits they accrue by keeping land free from development.

title: Liberia Ship Collision Inquiry Set
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Dec. 29 (AP)  The Liberian Government will conduct an investigation into last month's collision of two Liberian ships in the Gulf of Mexico that killed 32 sailors, according to the Coast Guard. The Liberian Bureau of Maritime Affairs will convene an investigation board in New York March 17, the Coast Guard said.

title: Bonnie Ann Lewis Is Betrothed to John Michael Rodney
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Bonnie Ann Lewis, daughter of Leon Lewis of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Elaine Lewis, to John Michael Rodney, son of Mrs. John Carnevali of Elmsford, N.Y., and the late John Rodney.

title: 2 Youths Wounded in Chinatown; Police Suspect Link to Gang War
description: Two 16yearold youths, described by the police as Chinese, were wounded by gunfire early yesterday while sleeping in a parked car in Chinatown, and detectives said they were checking the possibility that the incident was linked to continuing gang war.

title: Barbara Ann Hyer Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Fredrich C. Hyer of Roseland, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Hyer, to John Robert Huber Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Huber of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Miss Hyer expects to receive a B.S. degree in nursing in May from Bloomfield College. Her fiance, a graduate of Hobart. College, is with Salomon Brothers as a senior profit analyst. The wedding is planned for June 14.

title: Residents Lose LifeCare Suit
description: MEADOW LAKES, in the Mercer County town of Hightstown, is a lifecare community, a relatively new concept in housing for people 60 years and older that provides something between total independence and nursinghome care.

title: AIDE IN AZERBAIJAN IS TO SEE KHOMEINI
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 29  Dissident followers of Ayatollah Kazem ShariatMadari continued to hold a dozen loyalist revolutionary guards hostage in Tabriz today in renewed ethnic unrest in the Azerbaijan region.

title: June Wedding Set By Eileen Grieve
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Grieve of Kennebunk, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Margaret Grieve, to Robert Michael Stokes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Stokes of Metuchen, N.J.

title: Thousands of Refugees Have Been Uprooted
description: HARGEISA, Somalia  One bright morning a few weeks ago, seven Ethiopian MIG fighters flew low and slow along the Somali borderline that runs south of this town, dropping leaflets demanding the release of three Ethiopian officers captured by the Western Somalia Liberation Front. Expecting fire, certainly not paper, nomads ran for bush cover and crouched until the sky had cleared of everything but vapor trails. Then, those few who could read picked up the leaflets and divulged the demands to companions, the demands ending with WE WILL TAKE OUR REVENGE!

title: Deaths
description: TOMPROS  James, on Dec 28, 1979, General Manager, Glen Oaks Golf Club, Old Westbury. Dear husband of Beatrice. cherished father of Kathleen and Patricia. Funeral Monday, 11.30AM from the Fairchild Funeral Home, Franklin Ave at 12 St, Garden City, NY. Funeral liturgy 12 noon, St. Paul's G.O. Church, 110 Cathedral Ave, Hempstead. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery. Visiting hours 25 and 79PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the St. Paul Church Mosaic Fund.

title: THIS WEEK INSPORTS
description: The Knicks are at Madison Square Garden to play the San Antonio Spurs Tuesday and the San Diego Clippers Thursday In 7:30 P.M. games. On Saturday, the Knicks meet the Chicago Bulls at 8 P.M.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH the task of repairing small holes and cracks in plaster walls and ceilings, or in walls and ceilings of gypsum board (dry wall), is not an especially difficult one, many doityourselfers still seem to have trouble making a repair that will not crack, and one that will not require a great amount of sanding and smoothing when dry.

title: Inflation and the Central Bankers: Five New Faces
description: PARIS  The men who have held the purse strings of the industrialized world for much of the 1970's are bowing out. The governors of central banks in five major countries have yielded their places this year, while two others may be approaching the end of their careers. It is the most complete power shift in more than a generation and comes at a time when the world of central banking itself is in flux.

title: EDITORS CHOICE
description: For the 12th time, the Book Review picks what it takes be the best books of the preceding year. The 17 titles below did not strike us as of equal merit; we could, with some debate, probably rank them in excellence. What caused no debate, however, was that three books stood apart from the others; they were immediately and unanimously chosen. Two are the creations of editors: Flannery O'Connor's letters The Habit of Being, and the NabokovWilson letters; the third is A Bend in the River by perhaps the most talented novelist alive, V. S. Naipaul.

title: SPORTS
description: BUILD a better mousetrap, they say, and the world will beat a path to your door. Since mice have become fairly well subdued these days, inventors have been turning to more sophisticated ventures in order to attract the attention of the public and, they hope, pave their way in gold smack up to their doorsteps.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Japan today is a mixture of much modern and some classic. It is hard to imagine a Tokyo without colorful neon and overcrowded streets. JAPAN: Photographs 18541905 (Edited by Clark Worswick, with an introduction by Jan Morris; Penwick/ Knopf, $25) is a fascinating compilation of photographs by various Kago (forerunner of the rickshaw] with Passenger and Bearers in Studio,1880's. Western and Japanese photographers of an untouched Japan. Pictures of the Samurai warrior, Geisha girl and religious itinerants open a new door to the wonders of Japan. Of particular interest are the beautiful handcolored photos that replaced the dying woodblock art.

title: Article 12 -- No Title
description: Beverly Sills, the redhaired Brooklyn soprano who became a star of the New York City Opera, has begun a new career as the opera's general director.

title: Coping With the Young Old and the Old Old
description: WASHINGTON  The fact that Americans are living longer has had an enormous effect on, among other things, the size of the Federal budget and the way tax dollars are spent. In the 80's, the demographic tilt toward an older America will become even more pronounced and, in the process, many areas of life will be affected.

title: HOME CLINIC Smoothing a Path Over Cracks
description: ALTHOUGH the task of repairing small holes and cracks in plaster walls and ceilings, or in walls and ceilings of gypsum board (dry wall), is not an especially difficult one, many doityourselfers still seem to have trouble making a repair that will not crack, and one that will not require a great amount of sanding and smoothing when dry.

title: Megan McDonnell Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. Murray McDonnell of Peapack, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Megan McDonnell. to G. Clayton Kyle Jr.. son of Dr. and Mrs. Kyle of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia. The wedding is planned for next May.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Two contemporary history books clash as 1979 closes. (They are included in the Editors Choice list on page 1 today.) Both have made headlines around the world, both have caused retorts by their respective authors, and both might well be read together. They are: Henry A. Kissinger's White House Years, published by Little, Brown, and William Shawcross's Sideshow: Kissinger, Nixon and the Destruction of Cambodia, published by Simon & Schuster and Pocket Books.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: OHMSDavid Birney plays a teacher who organizes a farming community's battle against a utility company in the madeforTV film to be shown Wednesday at 9 P.M. on CBS.

title: Commuting Age Dawns In Space
description: The exploration and use of space, after a time in partial eclipse, should expand in the 1980's when American astronauts return to orbit aboard a revolutionary new spaceplane, Soviet astronauts further test human endurance in space and the Western Europeans begin regular launchings with their Ariane rockets.

title: Connecticut This Week
description: BETHEL   Works by area artists and artisans. Bethel Gallery. 186 Greenwood Ave Through Jan 19 Wednesday through Sunday noon to 5 30 Phone 7436644

title: Laurie A. Rummel Married to Doctor
description: Laurie Ann Rummel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Thomas Rummel Jr. of Haddam, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Stephen Memhard Brittain, son of Alfred Brittain 3d, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company, and Mrs. Brittain of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Mark R. Pawlowski of the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich performed the ceremony at the Brittain home.

title: Republicans See Carter as Weak on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  What the President's pollster, Pat Caddell, calls a baffling experience in Presidential popularity may be coming to an end, many politicians and public opinion experts believe. But although they are nearly unanimous in predicting that President Carter cannot much longer count on the striking surge in public esteem that his handling of the Iran hostage situation has evoked  especially if nothing continues to happen  they cite little more than instinct for this belief.

title: Jersey Permits 3d Casino to Open
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 29 (AP) The Bally Manufacturing Corporation opened its $300 million Park Place casinohotel today after the state said that it met minimum standards. The state had delayed the opening for two days.

title: THEATER
description: BRIDGEPORT ONLY writers reading the credits for the current show at the Downtown Cabaret Theater will be upset. It carries the subtitle A New Musical From the Old Story, and the information that it was adapted by Claude McNeal. But as to what the old story was and what Mr. McNeal has made his adaptation from there is not a clue.

title: A Pilot Program in Union County Could Provide a Model
description: TRENTON  Fifty years ago, welfare or social services was the province mainly of private, charitable agencies or individuals and was organized on a smallscale, persontoperson basis. Even after governments accepted the basic maintenance of citizens as their responsibility, there was for years simply a local welfare department where a needy individual or family went to seek help.

title: The Plaza Hotel: A Moneymaking Fairyland
description: It was perhaps the most celebrated bath of the flapper era. F. Scott Fitzgerald, newly famous as a writer, and his wife, Zelda, went for a romp in the Pulitzer Fountain just outside the Plaza Hotel. The hotel still recalls the episode, 50 years later, in the brochures it puts in its rooms. The Plaza, they read, is New York  the way it was.

title: She Has a Firm Grip
description: The New York Times Joseph Kugielsky

title: Waldheim Ready to Go to Teheran But Says He Is Unsure of Reception
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim gave qualified approval today to a new American proposal that would send him to Teheran to seek the release of the hostages in the United States Embassy.

title: DINING OUT
description: IN the last few months, a number of new restaurants have opened in Westchester, among them, and always welcome, several establishments specializing in seafood. Laughing Seahorse in Armonk, guileless in both ambiance and culinary art, offers fresh seafood simply prepared.

title: Rating the Hotel Rating Systems
description: Think for a moment: How would you define a firstclass hotel? What criteria would you apply to judge the facilities and service? And how certain are you that others would agree?

title: Shows and Events
description: Friday through Sunday  Antiques show at Birchwood Manor, 111 Jefferson Road, Whippany. 85 exhibitors. Admission: $2.50. Hours: Friday and Saturday, noon to 10 P.M.; Sunday, noon to 8 P.M. For Information, call (201) 8279271.

title: Suzanne L. Clark Is Engaged To Steven Robert Hageman
description: Mrs. Clarence Stuart Clark of Bryn Mawr, Pa., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Suzanne Lauretta Clark, to Steven Robert Hageman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gilmore Hageman of Asheville. N.C. A May wedding is planned.

title: Realty News
description: Bolton's, the women's apparel chain, has leased retail space at 2729 West 57th Street for its ninth outlet in the metropolitan region. It has taken 3,500 square feet for 20 years at an aggregate rent of approximately $4 million.

title: Engagrntrnts
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Ward of New Rochelle, N.Y. announce the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Teresa Ward to Joseph A. Cullen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Cullen of Stamford, Conn. Ms. Ward Is a graduate of The Ursuline School and St. Bonaventure University. She Is currently enrolled in a Master's Program at Montclair State College. Mr. Cullen is a graduate of Stamford Catholic High School and St. Bonaventure University. He is an Account Executive with John Mc Namara Advertising of New York City. A June Wedding is planned.

title: Where Did All The People Go? To Running, Mostly
description: IN the 1970's, virtually every participant sport attracted new followers. Tennis bubbles and racquet clubs sprouted in empty lots, and major newspapers introduced special sports sections for doers instead of watchers. Subway cars were full of people with gym bags, poking one another with the handles of squash racquets; women in tennis dresses pushed grocery carts in the supermarket, and the police department in Nassau County said it could no longer determine how many joggers were killed by motorists because so many nonrunners wore running shoes.

title: Blacks Made Gains but Expect Hard Times Ahead
description: ATLANTA  I know where we are, I know where we have come from, I know where we have yet to go, proclaimed Richard Arrington, the first black Mayor of Birmingham, Ala., at his recent inauguration. It was a ceremony that told a great deal about the uneven progress of black Americans in the 1970's, not only in the South but in the entire nation.

title: 2 Modern Houses Pass the Test of Time
description: FORTY years ago, two newly built Westchester houses were the talk of their towns. With huge windows, terraces, open floor plans and simple lines, they stood out among Westchester's Colonials, Cape Cods and English Tudors.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The 1970's could have been worse. Nobody was killed when hit by a falling politician. Science didn't mate a gorilla and an elephant; as a result, we don't have to wear fur coats made out of elephant trunks.

title: Mailbox: No Honor On Frazier's Night
description: To The Sports Editor: Being an avid Walt Frazier fan,I was excited in anticipation of attending a memorable night honoring Clyde. After witnessing the event, I was both disappointed and annoyed at the way Madison Square Garden handled the whole affair.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The 10 most memorable photography shows of 1979 all brought something new or unfamiliar to the New York museum and gallery scene, or opened up new perspectives on something familiar. This made them stand out even in a season that featured firstrate work by Robert Frank, Eugene Atget, and the masters of early 20thcentury American photography. Here they are, in order of their appearance during the year.

title: Susan Wyman Fiance of Steven Blackburn
description: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Henry Gregory Wyman of Patchogue, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Wyman, to Steven Peter Blackburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Frederick Blackburn Jr. of Alexandria, Va.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: The International Year of the Child is drawing to a close, and its conclusion will be marked by a program of songs, In Celebration of Childhood, that will be presented today in the Vogt Theater at the Bloomfield Public Library.

title: Beaths
description: FOGEL  Irving A., beloved husband of Jean, loving father of Murray and the late Harvey. Dear brother and adored grandfather. Services Sunday 10AM Kirschenbaums Coney Island Ave at Ave H, Bklvn

title: Design View
description: Remember furniture? 11's what fashionable folk had before platforms made it obsolete. A sofa was something one sat more or less upright On, and a ned mid 0 space underneath where the dog could hide during thunderstorms. Now, all that is passe. An no courant room is no longer furnished; it is sculptured into a hasrelief of carpeted hills and dales across which one sprawls seductively, if youth and agility permit. Surfaces that once were handy dropping spots for life's more presentable effluvia are immaculate now, thanks to custom builtins designed to accommodate the precise number and shape of the owners errant possessions.

title: Smoothing a Path Over Cracks
description: ALTHOUGH the task of repairing small holes and cracks in plaster walls and ceilings, or in walls and ceilings of gypsum board (dry wall), is not an especially difficult one, many doityourselfers still seem to have trouble making a repair that will not crack, and one that will not require a great amount of sanding and smoothing when dry.

title: Eiffel Tower Is Going Public
description: PARIS, Dec. 29  The tourist buses that swarm like ants around the base of the Eiffel Tower disappeared with the last leaves of autumn. But day after day the tourists still come. The Louvre may he empty and the pickpockets around Notre Dame may have trouble making ends meet, but there are still lines at the Eiffel Tower.

title: Steelers and Dolphins Renew Old Rivalry
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29  The football teams that dominated the American Conference in the 1970's, the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Miami Dolphins, meet tomorrow to decide who will play in the last conference championship of the decade Both coaches, as if irresistibly drawn together, expected the matchup. Each club has been off for two weeks, but until last weekend neither Chuck Noll of the Steelers nor Don Shula of Miami knew who his opponent would be.

title: I'll set women's tennis back 20 years
description: In sports, they will be remembered as the symbols of the 70's  Muhammad Ali for his travels as a true world heavyweight boxing champion, O.J. Simpson for representing the primetime popularity of pro football, Jim (Catfish) Hunter for establishing the market value of baseball's instant millionaires, Billie Jean King for propelling the women's movement as well as a tennis ball and the neighborhood jogger for inspiring fitness.

title: Fledgling Models Get Their Cues From the Professionals
description: How does a model improve her style?

title: Some Donors Prefer Anonymity As They Assist Neediest Cases
description: Each year, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund receives hundreds of anonymous contributions. One for $100 was received recently with a letter that went a step further than most, but may be symptomatic of the world in which we live.

title: Even Tree Frogs Inspire the Work Of Theater Troupe
description: WEST CORNWALL LOTTE GOSLAR harvests dance and theater pieces from her farm here. The stonefenced hilly terrain provides both seed and soil for the performers creative crops. Country quiet and country sounds, the visual vitality of the rural landscape all form a working environnects to something I might have thought years ago, or wished years ago or experienced years ago  or yesterday.

title: Gandhi Family Is Trying for A Comeback In Indian Voting
description: NEW DELHI  This week, when more than two hundred million largely illiterate voters cast their ballots in parliamentary elections, their immediate choices will have more to do with the principles of dramaturgy than with alternatives of national policies.

title: THEATER
description: BRIDGEPORT, CONN. PERHAPS only writers reading the credits for the current show at the Downtown Cabaret Theater will be upset. It carries the subtitle a new musical from the old story, and the information that it was adapted by Claude Mc Neal. But as to the name of the original story and to what Mr. Mc Neal has made his adaptation from there is not a clue. Granted a child of 5 could read the new title, A Tale of Scrooge, and probably tell you the source, but Dickens and A Christmas Carol don't get an inch of type space. Such are the horrors of having your work fall into the public domain.

title: The Revolution: Conventional Attitudes
description: ALTHOUGH more than six decades separate us from the Russian Revolution, the historical literature on that grand event is still more the domain of politics than of scholarship. There exist wellestablished, politically determined canons regarding.

title: HOW TO SNOW THE VOTERS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: The New Hampshire primary is a highrisk venture for Presidential candidates. More lose there, in fact, than win. But the important thing, in the first primary of the campaign season, is to beat the polls, not the opponents. A candidate can win the New Hampshire primary and not be nominated by his party  as was the case with Estes Kefauver in 1952 and in 1956, and with Henry Cabot Lodge in 1964; or lose the primary and be nominated by his party as Barry Goldwater was in 1964.

title: CAMERA
description: Years ago, taking pictures was a snap. The old box camera was hauled out of the closet, dusted off, and then pointed at various members of the family. After clicking off eight exposures the film was taken to the local drug store for processing and In about a week the prints were picked up. Everyone exclaimed over the barely recognizable, squinting images that were reasonable likenesses of mom and pop, and the kids.

title: DINING OUT
description: ONE of the most popular restaurants to open in recent months on the South Shore of eastern Nassau County is the Brown Osprey in Seaford. It considers itself a Manhattan style restaurant, a highly questionable characterization. Although there is a sedateness about the soothing beige color scheme that denotes a certain elegance (dominated by an attractive tapestry of an osprey), the menu and the preparation and service of the food do not suggest urban sophistication. Nor does the crooner occasionally on duty.

title: More Deer Hunters Using Bow and Arrow
description: WHEN the Island's deer hunting season for bow users ends tomorrow and the season for using firearms begins next week, fewer hunters will be exchanging their arrows for bullets. A greater appreciation for nature and a marked increase in hunting success are responsible for the growing preference for bows, say several gunners turned bowmen.

title: 4 Air Force Bobsledders Hurt on Lake Placid Run
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 (AP)  Four riders on a United States Air Force bobsled were injured today when their sled crashed while making a practice run at nearby Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: Joan Marilyn Balfe Bride of Executive
description: Joan Marilyn Balfe, senior representative for corporate services with the New York Stock Exchange, was married yesterday to James Pearson Northrup, manager of personnel policies and systems with W. R. Grace & Company in New York. The Rev. Dr. David Waltermulder performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Leader in State Senate To Appoint Gotbaum To Conventions Body
description: The Republican majority leader of the State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, yesterday named Victor Gotbaum, the labor union leader, and Sheldon H. Solow, a builder, to be his representatives on the board of directors of the New York Convention Center Operating Corporation.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THREE PLAYS OPENING

title: Politics Was Force That Had to Be Reckoned With
description: THERE was yelling and screaming during the evening meeting. Differences existed over the method of protest, but there was unity of purpose. Something had to be done.

title: New York City Region Ends Year With 10% Inflation
description: Spurred by sharp increases in energy, food and transportation costs, inflation in New Yorknortheastern New Jersey rose to an annual rate of 10 percent at the end of 1979, compared with 7 percent at the beginning of the year, the Federal Government reported yesterday.

title: ANTIQUES
description: I wanted the whole history of light, said Preston R. Bassett, inventor and collector extraordinaire, explaining why he had acquired close to 900 18th and 19thcentury American lighting devices over a 50year period.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE spacious chamber on the eighth floor of the County Office Building that was built in 1932 for the Westchester Board of Supervisors has been completely renovated for its decadeold successor, the Board of Legislators. The $200,000 job will be completed this week for the first session of the new year, on Jan. 7.

title: 5 German Prelates Meet With Pope on the Kung Case
description: ROME, Dec. 29  Leaders of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in West Germany returned home today after meeting with Pope John Paul II to discuss the case of the Rev. Hans Kiing, the liberal theologian who was censured by the Vatican 12 days ago.

title: William L. Smith
description: WATCH ON THE RHINEJan Miner appears in a revival of Lillian Hellman's play about an American family's awakening to the Nazi menace. Thursday at the Golden.

title: A Daughter's Death, A Mother's Faith
description: IT was a very hot but beautiful late afternoon in June of 1964. Elizabeth Watson, her husband, George, her mother, Grace, and her three daughters were returning from a wedding in Philadelphia to their home in Chicago, when suddenly a tire blew and the car went out of control. Everyone in the car was injured, and her 23yearold daughter, Sarah, died.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: It is barely more than a week since major oil producers embarked on their latest round of price rises, but already the economic effects are washing up on American shores like so much flotsam.

title: Study Urges L.I.R.R. Cleanup Campaign
description: THERE'S a lot the Long Island Rail Road commuter can do to improve his railroad. and if a team of management consultants who spent nearly four years studying the line have anything to say about it, the rider will be asked to do his share very soon.

title: The Man Who Published DeLorean
description: Thomas Aquinas's warning to Beware the man of one book is probably a good rule of thumb, so perhaps one should be watchful of Jameson G. Campaigne Jr. Mr. Campaigne is editor and president of Caroline House Publishers, and he is bask  ing in the glory of his first blockbuster On a Clear Day You Can See General Motors.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE  Minimum Wage: Up Again
description: WAS HNGTON  Unlike past years, when it generated controversy as predictable as the singing of Auld Lang Syne on New Year's Eve, the increase in the minimum wage is creating minimal uproar this time around. Inflation and the overall increase in wages in the United States have made the 20cent rise seem almost insignificant.

title: Finger Tips' Regrowth Encourages Study of Nerve and Limb Renewal
description: Several years ago at Children's Hospital in Sheffield, England, a child appeared with the tip of one finger cut off. Doctors dressed the wound, intending to refer the child to a plastic surgeon for further treatment.

title: Too Much Off the Top
description: LAST month, the Northstage TheaterRestaurant scheduled four Saturday night showings of the musical Hair at 11:45 (dinner at 10). These followed the regular evening performances of The Sound of Music. Has any theater ever presented such musical extremes back to back?

title: Long Island This Week
description: ALBERTSON  Retrospective of works by Stan Kaplan; Wednesday through Jan. 31; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. For hours, CH 87303.

title: Serious Crimes Reported Up 9% In the First Nine Months of 1979
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)  The number of serious crimes reported in the United States in the first nine months of this year increased by 9 percent over the like period a year ago, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: I'm having trouble managing the mansion. What I need is a wife
description: For better or for worse the 70's have heen a time or change in relation between men anti women. In the way the:, work, together, In how they think cthout each other. in the way they play together arid the war the I raise their Tam:lies. Candice Bergen. an actress and photoiournahst. Willard Goyim, a psychiatrist and president of the Institute of tiociety, Ethics and the Life Sciences at the Hastings Center. Janet Guthrie, a race dr: ver and former aerospace engineer. and Erica Jong. a novelist, talked with Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Week in Review of The New York Times. Mitchel Levitas. editor of The Week in Review, and Le Anne Schreiber, sports editor of The Times, about some of the changes. and their implications for the so's. Excerpts from their discussion follow.

title: Rock: A Night of Oldies
description: Oldies shows can be dreary affairs, but at their best they're a rock version of that recent phenomenon, the jazz repertory concert. Recreations of early jazz usually draw on a mixture of older players who were there and younger players who learned from records, and most of the vocal groups now touring the oldies circuit are similarly constituted  if they're not new groups put together to cash in on an old name.

title: CALENDARS
description: Wednesday  Rockland Auto Competition Club meeting; at The Blauvelt Inn, Erie Street off Route 303, Blauvelt, N.Y., at 8:30 P.M. All interested welcome. Information: (914) 3530017 nights.

title: Add to your collectibles: Gameboards. Page 8
description: NEWTOWN THE social games people play can pique the curiosity of Scudder Smith in his job as editor of The Newtown Bee, the weekly newspaper. As an antique collector for the last 20 years, his interest has been captured by the tangible paraphernalia used to play games.

title: Steven Harris Will Marry Karen Skinder; Trudi Skinder Engaged to Jerry Krivitzky
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Skinder of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagements of their daughters; Karen and Trudi Skinder, to Steven Harris and Jerry Krivitzky, respectively.

title: Seeking Not 1, But 100 Cancer Cures
description: The war on cancer is not lost  just unfinished. Despite the public perception of failure, statistics indicate that death rates for most cancers have been steadily decreasing since President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act in 1971. Funding for cancer research has increased, from $5.7 billion spent from 1971 through 1979, to $1 billion already appropriated and being spent for fiscal 1980. And, according to researchers, their efforts have not abated.

title: Associated Press
description: WELLSPENT HOLIDAY: Ginger, a nineyearold horse, being lifted by crane Friday from a well in Madera, Calif. The horse had fallen through boards covering the well on Christmas Day and was not located until Friday.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: In architecture, this has been a year of consolidation, as they say in business and politics. The heroes have familiar faces, and the manifestos have a familiar ring. No bright new stars have suddenly shot across the horizon; no worldshaking events have upset the established order. This year there has been as much interest in where we have been as in where we are going; the perspective is through the rearview mirror.

title: I have nothing against a community trying to maintain ethnic purity
description: LOS ANGELES  In this city's school system, the nation's second largest, children of Hispanic origin now outnumber either whites or blacks. Broadway. once Los Angeles most fashionable downtown thoroughfare, has Lecome a thriving Latino shopping center, throbbing with the sights and sounds of Mexico. Spanish has become the primary language in large parts of East Los Angeles.

title: 2 Actresses, 2 Plays, a Single Purpose
description: TWO current shows, both Yiddish in derivation but in form and content as different as day is from night, epitomize the rebirth of Yiddish theater, and the infinite variety of it.

title: A Play for Resource Stocks
description: The stock market last week gave investors a telescoped performance of the entire year. The theme was clear: In a period of galloping inflation and great uncertainty, companies with resources in the ground were a good place to turn a profit.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: HAPPY TEARS: Dan Pastorini (7) embracing Gifford Nielsen after Oiler victory over Chargers yesterday in San Diego. Oilers won despite injuries to Pastorini and Earl Campbell.

title: TelevisionThisWeek
description: Today

title: Earl Campbell, Pastorini Out
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 29  The Houston Oilers accomplished today what seemed at the start of the game to be an impossibility. They defeated the San Diego Chargers without the league's best running back, Earl Campbell; the team's starting quarterback, Dan Pastorini, and its top receiver, Ken Burrough.

title: Get a Bonus This Year? It Might Be the Last
description: It usually works something like this: Late in December, the head of the company calls in each of his top managers, one by one, for a chat. Let's see, Felix, begins the Chief, looking up from a ledger. Your salary is now $50,000. We're going to raise that by $5,000. The Chief would pause and then hand over a long, machinewritten check for $50,000. And here's your bonus. Happy New Year.

title: A Handson Guy Meets The Welfare Mess Headon
description: It was less than a year ago that Stanley Brezenoff sat in his office and answered questions about the title that had become his almost overnight, City Human Resources Administrator. Mr. Brezenoff, a tall, bespectacled man with an easy grin, was surrounded by the symbols of the city's welfare system  papers and more papers. Atop the pile, however, was a document a bit different from the rest. It was a memo to Mayor Koch, explaining that come what may, he would be out of town the following week because of a previous commitment to take his young son to Disney World.

title: Albert Lee Lesser, 62, President Of New York Advertising Agency
description: Albert Lee Lesser, who had been president of the BlaineThompson Advertising Agency for 35 years until his recent retirement, died Friday of a heart attack at his home in Lenox, Mass. He was 62 years old.

title: Article 10 -- No Title
description: Article 10 -- No Title

title: WASHINGTON Moscow Uses Its Muscle
description: WASHINGTON  Soviet foreign policy may seem reckless these days but at least it is consistent and almost predictable. When in doubt, the Russians protect their borders and defend the turf beyond their borders.

title: It's not the time for great gestures
description: Three huge towers are rising to greet the new decade in midtown Manhattan, and they are as different from one another as they are from the skyscrapers of the past. One, designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes for the IBM Corporation, is a sixsided shaft of dark green granite with a glassenclosed park at its base. Another, designed by Poor, Swanke, Hayden & Connell for developer Donald Trump, is a multifaceted tower of reflecting glass. The last, designed by Johnson /Burgee for the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, is a granite box with classically inspired arches at the bottom and a flamboyant broken pediment at the top.

title: The Cities of America Are Getting More Aid
description: WASHINGTON  Two weeks ago, the Carter Administration let it be known that the new Federal budget would contain a significant boost in funds to help small and rural communities handle their growth. Last week, it was disclosed that despite growing Congressional opposition to funds for state governments as part of the general revenue sharing program, that $2.3 billion expenditure will remain intact in Mr. Carter's request to Congress  although it will probably have tacked on to it a stipulation that the Federal dollars be passed through the state to local governments. Both actions are sure signs that the Presidential election is heating up.

title: Philosophical Group's Dominant View Is Criticized
description: Charging that the American Philosophical Association has become a monolith and intolerant, that its programs neglect basic philosophic issues and that its leadership has lost contact with other philosophers, the Committee for Pluralism in Philosophy of the A.P.A. spent two hours Friday night severely criticizing the leaders of the philosophical group and said it planned to try to replace them.

title: As Jolly as an Ingrown Nail
description: PLAINFIELD SEE HOW THEY RUN is a 1940's English farce about a group of vicars whose conduct suggests that they're 9 years old and going on 8. Why is the New Jersey Theater Forum, a progressive organization, airing it?

title: Six Steelworkers Die From Fumes In Indiana Plant
description: EAST CHICAGO, Ind., Dec. 29 (AP) Carbon monoxide leaked into an area around a blast furnace last night when fan quit turning and six steelworkers were killed, officials of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Company said today.

title: World News Briefs
description: Sprcial to The New 1ork Ttmes

title: Keeping Up With the Joneses Cuisinart
description: In 1978, a big year in the athletic footwear business, Americans bought 13 million pairs of running shoes and 42 million pairs of lookalikes  shoes resembling the real article closely enough that some people might be unable to tell the difference.

title: A Number of House Plants Thrive on Benign Neglect
description: Those who like the look of indoor greenery but think they are too busy or too disorganized to care for plants can take heart. A number of attractive foliage plants will grow well, if not actually flourish, under what can best be described as benign neglect.

title: Deadlock Over U.N. Seat Persists
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29 The General Assembly remained deadlocked today over a struggle between Cuba and Colombia for a seat on the Security Council.

title: Beaths
description: ADLER  Edward M. Beloved son of Betty and Sidney. Loving brother of Joseph, David, Nathan, Caroline Goldwyn and Susan. Services Sunday 9:45AM Boulevard Park West 1150 Broadway, Hewlett. L.I.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: The onagain offagain electric news sign circumambulating the former Allied Chemical Tower at 1 Times Square has been off again since a year and a half ago, the last time the building's owner renewed his protest against the state of Times Square and the high cost of electricity.

title: Bucs Built on Trio of FirstRound Choices
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 29  Lee Roy Selmon, Ricky Bell and Doug Williams of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers today justified the National Football League's first commandment that firstround draft choices should form the nucleus of an emerging team.

title: Letter to America You Have 12 Kinds of Toothpaste. . . Why?
description: NEW DELHI  Among the hazards and joys of a halfdecade's travel in Africa and the Subcontinent, an American's vision of home is regularly tested against the perceptions of those who live in what is called, somewhat vaguely, the Third World.

title: Rev. John Joseph Cavanaugh, 80, Former President of Notre Dame
description: The Rev. John Joseph Cavanaugh, president of Notre Dame University during its postwar expansion and a close friend of the Kennedy family, died Friday at a home for retired priests on the campus in South Bend, Ind. He was 80 years old.

title: What's Doing in the ADIRONDACKS
description: OVERVIEW  The typically ruddy complexion of the Adirondack region in winter takes on an extra, international tinge this year with the staging of the 13th Winter Olympic Games in Lake Placid, Feb. 13 through 24. That small village, charged with preOlympic energy, will be host to the spectacle and attendant fanfare that only an event of such magnitude can produce.

title: When He Plays, The Vibes Are Good
description: SEAFORD IT T may seen a natural shift from drums to vibes, said Ray Alexander, referring to a transition he himself made nearly a quarter of a century ago at the age of 24, but it doesn't always work. Drumming gives you some of the technique for playing vibes, but there's more to it than that. It takes a special ear. and not all drummers have it.

title: WSNLTV Returns to Air On L.I. After 41/2 Years
description: WSNLTV, a UHF station licensed in Smithtown, L. I., has resumed broadcasting on Channel 67 after a hiau's of four and a half years.

title: Panelists Say Connecticut Faces A Test on Refusal to Tax Income
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 29  Connecticut's reluctance to enact a state income tax and its tradition of local autonomy for its 169 towns face difficult tests in the 1980's.

title: Cheryl Frenzel Is Betrothed
description: Violet Frenzel of Upper Saddle River, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Cheryl Frenzel, to V. James Galgano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Galgano of West Orange, N.J. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Herman Frenzel. A wedding is planned for next August.

title: Bottle Law Ending Era Of No return
description: THE bottle bill, which kept state legislators squabbling for several years, will become the bottle law on Tuesday and it will mark the end of the era of no deposit, no return in Connecticut.

title: Headliners
description: Jack Lewin is a retired businessman who for a $15 fee will trace the history of old financial paper. Last week, it was revealed that he had found a Texas Pacific Land Trust bond purchased for $3,000 in 1888, but missing since 1904 and now worth a tidy $4 million. Half of the money may go to three medical schools, half to the original owner's daughter, Alice DeLamar, 82, an already welloff resident of Palm Beach. Miss DeLamar said news of the windfall was  very nice.

title: Dr. Herbert Wendelken, ExMedical Aide in City
description: Dr. Herbert F. Wendelken, a former deputy medical examiner for New York City, died Friday at his Staten Island home. He was 72 years old.

title: Carter Crisis Team Gets Its Act Together
description: WASHINGTON  Carter Administration conduct of foreign policy has sometimes tended to be disorderly, as in the case of former Ambassador Andrew Young's unauthorized meetings at the United Nations with Palestine Liberation Organization officials. By contrast, in dealing with Iran, the President's advisers have displayed an unusual degree of unity. There have been almost no signs of internal discord, and secrecy has been tightly maintained on sensitive actions such as unannounced messages to the Teheran authorities and undisclosed military moves bolstering the announced buildup.

title: Kentucky Deals Irish First Loss
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 29 (AP) Kyle Macy's 3point play with minutes 6 seconds remaining scuttled a Notre Dame comeback and helped propel secondranked Kentucky to an 8680 college basketball victory tonight over the thirdranked Fighting Irish.

title: Austin Street Beset by the Troubles of Success
description: Austin Street in Forest Hills has become a showcase for what many local retailers and residents consider to be the best highcaliber shopping, square foot for square foot, in the borough of Queens. And the retail vitality of the shopping area, traditionally along the four blocks from Ascan Avenue to 70th Avenue, has extended west toward Yellowstone Boulevard and into the side streets. It also has become a magnet for shoppers from Long Island, store owners say.

title: The Nation
description: In Summary

title: KOCH TO WITHDRAW SOME POLICE AIDING SUBWAY CRIME FIGHT
description: New York City police officers who have been helping the transit police fight subway crime in a program introduced with fanfare by Mayor Koch last March will be quietly withdrawn tomorrow.

title: 3 New Books Depict Colonial New Jersey
description: MORRISTOWN THREE new books by state authors focus on the people behind the battles, documents and dates of New Jersey's past.

title: Importation of Mexican Natural Gas Is Given Final Approval by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 29  The Govern i meat gave final approval today to the longawaited importing of natural gas from Mexico and also approved a large price rise for gas from Algeria that is consumed on the East Coast.

title: Westchester ThisWeek
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Pinoch!, new rock musical based on tale of Pinocchio, by Jan Miles and Robert Saunderson Sim, starring Laurie Coppa, Bill Wheeler and Leigh Ross. Today 3 and 8. S5, children $3.50. Reservations, Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Route 6281169.

title: Congress on Free Press Is Slated for Jan. 1617
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP)  A First Amendment Congress scheduled for next month and featuring Walter Cronkite, the CBS anchorman, as keynote speaker, will focus on the importance of a free press.

title: Plankton and Heavenly Ade Win
description: Plankton and Heavenly Ade won the split divisions of the Beaugay Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday before a crowd of 22,650.

title: The Music Craze Was All Disco
description: Popular music in the 1970's often has been condemned as a conservative reaction in the wake of the innovations of the previous decade. In a sense, this is true, particularly for the first half of the 70's. In music and lifestyles, the decade saw a consolidation and dissemination of the creativity of the years just before. As the music became the anthem of millions, it lost the vanguard communitarian fervor it had enjoyed as the secret song of the hippie underground.

title: Nathaniel Prentice Weds Anita Rhett
description: Anita Morgan Rhett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. G. Rhett Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Nathaniel Sartell Prentice, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra P. Prentice of Cold Spring, N.Y. The Rev. Bradford Hastings performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: The industrial world's progress based on cheap oil is finished
description: A bit less than 50 years ago, about when the Great Depression began to bite, the historian Charles Beard summed up the scientific, social and technological achievements of the United States in a book called A Century of Progress. In his preface, Mr. Beard dealt with the idea of progress in such terms as: Everywhere it makes its way. dissolving the feudal institutions of Europe. disturbing the slumbers of the Orient, arousing lethargic Russia and finding a naked avowal in the United States of America: The earth may be subdued to the security, welfare and delight of them that dwell therein. It is not the notion of Japan sleeping that makes Professor Beard's paragraph seem so quaint, nor that of a Soviet Union in need arousing. History naturally ages, but it is the unalloyed confidence in progress that marks the distance between the threshold of the 1930's and that of the 1980's.

title: Brown and Kennedy Aide Assail Carter for Pulling Out of Forum
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and a campaign coordinator for Senator Ed I ward M. Kennedy accused President Carter today of using the hostage situation in Iran to help himself politically. It was charged that his decision yesterday to withdraw from a Jan. 7 candidates forum in Iowa was a move to keep attention on them and away from economic issues.

title: Television: The Big Daddy Of Nearly All Sports
description: OLGA. The youthful smile, pigtails, acrobatic grace. She cried, and viewers saw their children in her tears. She scrambled back, gold medals around her neck, and melted the Cold War. And television showed everything.

title: Sahara Guerrillas Report Gains
description: LISBON, Dec. 29 (UPI)  Algerianbacked guerrillas fighting for control of the former Spanish Sahara said today that they had inflicted important losses on Moroccan troops in a recent offensive. In a statement released in Lisbon, the Polisario Front said it had attacked the town of Smara and the villages of Lem Seid, GueltaZemour and BirEnzaran between Dec. 20 and 26.

title: ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON DRAWINGS have traditionally been the testing grounds for artists ideas  steps toward the creation of more important paintings or sculpture. However, a drawing may also be an independent and fully realized work of art that can be admired for its own special qualities. There has long been a small cotene of collectors who specialize in this medium, attracted by its immediacy, intimacy and the particular rendering of line and form that can be achieved only by graphic means.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The usual activity for musical 1979: busy concert halls, artists from everywhere coming to display their talents, the city's opera houses on full schedule (with the Metropolitan Opera proudly waving a balanced budget), national and international orchestras coming in with their usual programs, each conductor determined to show that his Mahler Seventh or Brahms First or Verdi Requiem is the only Mahler Seventh, Brahms First or Verdi Requiem. New York is still the musical hub of the United States.

title: Article 11 -- No Title
Trenton's Policy On Sexuality Is LaissezFaire
description: NEW JERSEY has been hung up lately on the subject of sex. Within the last year, the Legislature has grappled with issues such as:

title: Bruce Howard Golboro Marries Susan B. Barsky
description: Susan Beth Barsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Harris Barsky of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married last evening to Bruce Howard Golboro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Golboro of Glencoe, Ill. Rabbi Irwin Maurice Blank, national director of B'nai B'rith's adult Jewish education department in Washington, performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: WHITECOLLAR JOBS SEEN LIKELY TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)  The Labor Department predicts that the nation's economy will create nearly 16 million new jobs in the next decade, with more than half of them in whitecollar occupations.

title: Gemma Jones- As Independent as the Duchess of Duke Street
description: The less you know about actors, the better  that's half the game. British actress Gemma Jones was talking over lunch the other day at a midtown French restaurant. Ironically, her defense of anonymity was made during a trip to thiscountry to help promote the 16 new episodes of The Duchess of Duke Street, currently being telecast Sunday evenings at 9 on WNET/Channel 13. Like the independentminded character she plays, Louisa Trotter, who kept her cockney accent even after she hobnobbed with the upper class, Miss Jones clearly is who she is  and doesn't like to risk being defined by anyone else.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: FOOTBALL

title: DANCE VIEW
description: No use being coy about it. The headlines in the dance world in 1979 were made offstage. For starters, there were the defections from the Bolshoi Ballet of Aleksandr Godunov, and Leonid and Valentina Kozlov. There was the surprise announcement that Lucia Chase would relinquish her post as American Ballet Theater's artistic director next September and the even more startling announcement that Mikhail Baryshnikov would then step into that position. To top it off, Mr. Baryshnikov suddenly resigned from the New York City Ballet after 15 months, although he had been scheduled to spend a second year with that company. A sad piece of news was Ballet Theater's lockout of its own dancers in a labor dispute.

title: Magazines Put Troubles Behind
description: The New York Times/Joyce Dopkeen

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Dec. 29 (UPI)  Time is running out on a campaign to raise $5 million to prevent the sale of worldfamous Gilbert Stuart portraits of George and Martha Washington, and with two days to go only $1 million has been raised.

title: The Hayseed Celebrity
description: Talk about actors basking in the limelight! Will Rogers once said. Say, an old senator can make an actor look like he is hid under a barrel. Rogers was in a position to know. He spent 20 years in the limelight without ever giving the impression that he was basking, and more time with senators than one might expect of a popular hero. Today, film stars, sports stars, popmusic stars move comfortably with political figures in a presumably glamorous world quite distinct from the one in which most of us live, and a great many Americans, who view them with envy, fascination and contempt, spend a deal of money and time reading about them.

title: BirdMagic Meeting Fails to Ignite Match
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29  The green suitcase, the one with the Boston Celtics' logo on it, was at his feet. The white nameplate for his warmup suit, the one that says BIRD in green letters, was in his hands, ready for packing and a trip to another city. Larry Bird tried to say that this was just another night, another one in 82 in the first season of his life in the National Basketball Association. Hello, I must be going.

title: Of Words and Their Masters
description: It was a decade during which Vladimir Nabokov (born in Russia) managed to die before the Nobel Prize for Literature deserved him; Saul Bellow (born in Canada) and Isaac Bashevis Singer (born in Poa Halberstam and much much more. That is, we weren't necessarily watching television. The big people were buying good books, the little people were publishing underground newspapers, and the Word  subtle, promiscuous, guilty of association with rational comment and abstract ideas, haunting  was alive and wellput.

title: Higher Costs, Slower Growth Will Compel, Finally, Tough Choices
description: In the last decade, the United States was hit with a series of shocks: oil shortages and soaring energy prices; accelerating inflation and higher unemployment; declining productivity and sluggish growth; trade deficits and a weakening dollar  and a growing anxiety, reflected in the securities, gold and money markets all over the world, that worse is to come.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: In the Festival of Russian Dance at the Beacon Theater last spring, The Times's Anna Kisselgoff singled out the Krasnayarsk Dance Company as one of outstanding virtuosity, in which every number is like a finale in a musical. Now on its second full North American tour (the first was in 197374), the 80member company specializing in the folk dances of Siberia will open at Carnegie Hall on Saturday for an engagement of 10 performances. (See Dance).

title: Sailors Put a Bit of Frostbite in Their Sails
description: TO some, frostbite sailing might seem an eccentric sport that stands a little to the windward side of the Polar Bear Club, but not to Barbara Gillman, a psychiatrist and a member of the Mamaroneck Frostbite Association for 19 years. It's like skiing, she said. It's cold and the same thrills and elements of fear and excitement are involved, but there are more injuries in skiing. In frostbiting, the icy waters down there add another dimension to the competition and the camaraderie.

title: The New York Times/John Sotomayor
description: AIDS BLOOD PROGRAM: Mayor Koch contributing to the Greater New York Blood Program, 310 East 67th Street. The center is down to a day's supply and, as a resuit, city hospitals are not performing any nonemergency surgery. A spokesman called the situation serious and urged donors to phone 212 5703158 for an appointment.

title: Ronald Winston, Harry's Son
description: In the 19 years that Harry Winston Inc.'s travertine mansion has been gracing the corner of 56th Street and Fifth Avenue, little has changed. An architectural jewel in a sea of glass skyscrapers, the sixstory, Louis XIV building still announces  on a golden plaque  that rare jewels of the world are sold here. Two small windows shimmer with some of those wares.

title: Authors Queries
description: For a book on Huila Rebay and the founding of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, formely the Museum of Nonobjective Painting, I would appreciate hearing from anyone who knew her during the 1920's and 1930's or earlier.

title: Melanie G. Dorsey And M. R. Berger Planning to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Henry Dorsey of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melanie Graham Dorsey, to Mitchell Rand Berger, son of Lila Berger of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Stanley Berger.

title: Farmland Plan: Future in Doubt
description: WITH the departure from office this week of Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein, farmers and environmentalists on the East End of the Island are expressing concern for the future of the uncompleted Farmlands Preservation Program, which Mr. Klein largely developed and nurtured during his eightyear tenure in office.

title: America's Little Switzerland
description: Garrett County, a tight little triangle of mountains, lakes and valleys wedged between the MasonDixon Line and the sidewinder coils of the north fork of the Potomac River, is the westernmost link in the articulated chain making up the geographic oddity that is the state of Maryland. For centuries the area was only a welltrod corridor  first for Indians pounding a trail through this break in the Alleghenies, then for British troops seeking the French (Capt. George Washington slept there; his commander, Gen. Edward Braddock, died and is buried there) and then for waves of pioneers seeking new lands in the West.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Rock hit. This week the tradepaperback list above includes an unusual kind of best seller  a book about a popular rock star. The rollercoaster career of Bruce Springsteen and rock music's journey from its 80's innocence to its 70's cynicism is told in fanzine style by Dave Marsh in Born to Run (Doubleday/Dolphin, 7.95). Only once before, when Elvis Presley's death occasioned several instant memoirs, has any book about rock achieved best sellerdom.

title: Beaths
description: GRUENWALD  Ernst, With profound sorrow we note the passing of an esteemed friend who so generously contributed his leadership and guidance from our founding days. His continuous service as an officer and member of the board of directors contributed immeasurably to the successful attainment of our goals & to the position of respect which our organization holds in the industry 8. community. Our sincerest sympathy to his wife Edith and toall histamilv.

title: Brown to Be a Bit More Cautious After Ruling on Lieut. Gov. Curb
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s Presidential campaign manager conceded today that he and Mr. Brown would be looking over their shoulders when the Governor began campaigning again out of state.

title: Uniform Pay Scales Urged for New York's Judges
description: In a report citing unreasonable disparities in the salaries of countylevel judges of equal rank, New York State's chief administrative judge has recommended a number of legislative actions to establish uniform pay scales.

title: Miss MacDonald Becomes the Bride Of J.T. Kiernan Jr.
description: Elizabeth Estelle MacDonald, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William James MacDonald of Rumford, R.I., was married yesterday afternoon in Providence. R.I.. to James Thomas Kiernan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kiernan of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Kehew, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Manning Chapel of Brown University, from which the couple were graduated in 1974.

title: Daisy Spalten Becomes Bride Of Norman Alexander Hirsch
description: Susan Daisy Spalten, daughter of Elinor Spalten and Dr. Robert Spalten, both of New York, was married yesterday to Norman Alexander Hirsch, son of Wilma Keturi Hirsch of Sunnyvale, Calif., and the late Harry Hirsch. Osel Tendzin performed the ceremony in Dorje Dzong, a Buddhist shrine in Boulder, Colo., where the couple reside.

title: The Bedsheets Are Flapping Again
description: THE community of West Hoboken no longer exists. But it did 50 years ago, when I was born there and it was the state headquarters of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: DINING OUT
description: NEW MILFORD THE chef at Joey's. a newcomer to the New Milford restaurant scene, knows how to prepare fresh sea food with a fine Italian hand. The results are fairly simple dishes often embellished with subtle sauces, distant cousins to the heavyhanded, tomatoev sauces one encounters all too often at many Italian restaurants in the area.

title: HOW MANY IRANIANS LEFT U.S. IS UNKNOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29  More than two weeks after ordering a sharp reduction of Iranian diplomatic and consular personnel in the United States, the Carter Administration still does not know exactly how many have actually left.

title: Checks and Balances Resumed
description: THE United States became a world power under the leadership of President Woodrow Wilson during World War I. Congress played little part in the process, except to vote for war and appropriate the necessary funds. But in 1919 and 1920 the Senate took negative control of American foreign policy by repudiating Wilson and the League of Nations.

title: 40% in U.S. Worship Regularly; Number Steady, Gallup Poll Says
description: Forty percent of the adult population of the United States regularly attended churches or synagogues in 1979, continuing a pattern of attendance that has held steady since the beginning of the decade, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Margaret Tillman Gilson Wed to Henry Thompson
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington last evening Margaret Tillman Gilson, daughter of Col. Leslie Arthur Gilson, U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Gilson of Washington, became the bride of Henry Alexander Thompson, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John Alexander Thompson of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. William Sharp performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Bus Line Is Success in Huntington
description: HUNTINGTON'S HART buses are going places. Despite dire predictions that the town's municipally owned bus service would ruin the suburban ambiance, the bus system has far surpassed the town's highest expectations of ridership and is about to expand further.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Before bidding a gentlemanly farewell to 1979, and even as I am riffling through old notes and old Playbills trying to identify the 10 best theatrical events of the year, I have a mistake to confess to, a terrible error to acknowledge. I got it all wrong about the lollipop man.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: Hilton Kramer's The Blunt Case [Dec. 2] confuses the character of art history, charge that cannot be leveled against the Briton's distinguished scholarship. The history of art is not a moral study. It is devoted to the examination of changing style and meaning in the visual arts through time. By definition this field is not devoted to ideal beauty or absolute truth, leaving such esthetic and moral considerations to the philosopher.

title: San Francisco Taps The Same Source
description: The bright lights of San Francisco and other Bay Area communities are largely powered by geothermal energy. It seems unlikely, however, that this energy source will contribute significantly to total American needs. Nevertheless, energy unquestionably lies beneath the ground, ready to be tapped; its environmental drawbacks, manageable.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Iran Shows a Less Hostile Side
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 29  An American who arrived in this cold, snowswept city the other evening from New York asked to be driven directly from Mehrabad airport to the United States Embassy on TaleRhani Street.

title: The Best and Worst of Times
description: It was the best of times for the players; it was the worst of times for the owners, if their piteous cries could be taken seriously.

title: Deirdre Cooke Wed To D. J. Schroeder
description: Deirdre Elizabeth Cooke was married in New York yesterday to Donald J. Schroeder of Princeton, N.J., where he is a financial analyst with RCA. Msgr. George Murphy performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Revs. William Carton and Stephan Findlay.

title: Aarriages
description: Of Mr. and Mrs. Warner F. Hirsh of New York City, on December 29 at the Wilbraham and Monson Academy Chapel in Wilbraham, Ma. The bride received her B.S. in nursing from the University of Massachusetts where she was president of her sorority, Kappa Kappa Gamma, and her Master Degree in Nursing at Boston University. The groom graduated from Columia Ulversity Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa and received his medical degree from Heryard University Medical School. The couple will reside In New York City where Dr. Hirsh is completing his surgical residency at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center.

title: Time to Take 10   Or More
description: TYPICALLY, as a decade winds down, the press and television recount for us the highlights and horrors of the justending 10 years. For the 70's, we're being reminded, of course, of Richard Nixon, the campuses, Jonestown, Henry Kissinger, Bowie Kuhn, Saul Bellow, Bing Crosby, SadatBegin, Walt Frazier and all the rest.

title: Looking For Zora
description: THIS collection of writings by the leading lady of black American letters between 1920 and 1950 includes several short stories and essays ; excerpts from her autobiography, reportage, collections of folklore; and selections from three of her novels  thus making available for the first time a representative sample of And Then Again When I Am Looking Mean and Impressive. A Zora Neale Hurston Reader. Edited by Alice Walker.

title: List of Deaths of Outstanding Figures in Sports During 1979
description: Allyn, John, 61, White Sox owner and president (196975).

title: Elizabeth Summers Wed to John Lubar
description: Elizabeth Ann Summers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Summers of Portugal Cove, Newfoundland, was married yesterday to John Victor Lubar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lubar of New York. The Rev. Eric O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in St. John's. Newfoundland.

title: CRIME
description: Like Shakespeare and the Bible, Rex Stout mysteries are always in print. For decades they have all been available in paperback, from one imprint or another. Rex Stout is a most profitable property, as well he should be. He created Nero Wolfe, and there are those buffs who consider the fat detective one of the most significant minds of the century, entitled to sit at the same table with the likes of Sherlock Holmes, Lord Peter Wirnsey and Sam Spade. There are those, indeed, who are prepared to document the fact that Nero Wolfe was the illegitimate son of Mycroft Holmes.

title: Food
description: Edna Lewis's chocolate souffle

title: 11 Die in Two Chicago Fires
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP)  Fires struck two apartment buildings 11 blocks apart on Chicago's North Side today, killing 11 persons and injuring more than 60 others, the authorities said.

title: Kathleen Agnes O'Shea Becomes Bride
description: At St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Rome, N.Y., yesterday, Kathleen Agnes O'Shea, daughter of James C. O'Shea of Rome and the late Kathleen Corroon O'Shea. was married to Timothy Joachim MCGillicuddy, son or Mr. and Mrs. John McGillicuddy of East Dennis, Mass. The Rev. Patrick K. McGillicuddy, brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. William M. Kelly and the Rev. James F. Quinn.

title: Engagements
description: Lucille and Mike Jacobs take great pleasure In announcing the engagement of their daughter, Aimee Robin, to Marvin Schwartz. son of Edna Schwartz and the late Hyman Schwartz.

title: INVESTING Buying a Piece of the Bullion Boom
description: With gold, the ageold pet rock of insecure investors overseas, soaring past $500 an ounce last week, the companies that mine it are also taking off. Some South African shares have soared 50 percent since the beginning of November.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith F. Hole Married To Samuel Tate Suratt
description: Judith Forester Hole, a producer for CBS News, was married yesterday to Samuel Tate Suratt, the CBS News archivist. The Rev. Norman Catir performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Tranifiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), where the parents of both the bride and bridegroom had been married.

title: Miss Bendo Wed to Editor
description: Katherine Theona Bendo, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George J. Bendo of Neponsit, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Eldridge Hitchings, son of Dr. and Mrs. George H. Hitchings of Durham, N.C. Walter T. Lawton, a member of the National Council of Leaders of the American Ethical Union, performed the ceremony in the West Penthouse of the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: CARTER TELLS SOVIET OUT OF AFGHANISTAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29  President Carter, in the toughest diplomatic exchange of his Presidency, has warned the Soviet Union in a special message to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan or face serious consequences in its relations with the United States.

title: Staubach Snub Irks Landry
description: DALLAS, Dec. 29  The National Football League's statistical formula ranking quarterbacks established Roger Staubach of the Dallas Cowboys as the No. 1 passer this season. Staubach, the focal player in the division playoff game at Texas Stadium tomorrow between the Cowboys and the Los Angeles Rams, was also ranked first last season.

title: Brenda Theresa Dunbar Is Bride of Conrad Govine Jr.
description: Brenda Theresa Dunbar, a manager in the businessmarketing education division of American Telephone and Telegraph in Piscataway, N.J., was married yesterday to Conrad M. Govine Jr., a senior accountant for the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains. The Rev. George Knight performed the ceremony in Brooklyn's Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: THE EYE YOU SAYE MAY BE YOUR OWN
description: On the first day of each year, the number of treatments of eye injuries in hospital emergency rooms increases dramatically. The reason: flying Champagne corks on New Year's Eve. People opening Champagne bottles tend to forget that the corks are under strong pressure from the carbondioxide gas in the wine, and stare directly at the corks as they work them out.

title: Miss Randall Has Nuptials
description: At Trinity United Methodist Church in Richmond yesterday, Nancy Kay Randall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Alfred Randall of New Canaan, Conn., was married to James David Mackey, son of Mrs. George Wilmer Mackey of Richmond and the late Mr. Mackey. The Rev. Dr. Harold Fink performed the ceremony, in which Dr. Dean G. Wilson, president of the Pittsburgh Stake of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, participated.

title: Major News
description: The long arm of the Soviet Union last week reached into one national victim of armed intervention to consolidate its grip on another. Moscow plucked Babrak Karmal out of exile in Czechoslovakia and installed him as President of Afghanistan in a bloody coup d'etat. But Moslem guerrillas have been battling Mr. Karmal's Marxist predecessors for more than a year and analysts are divided over whether Afghanistan can quickly be beaten into satellite submission.

title: Bell Gains 142, Scores Twice
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 29  Don't laugh, but the Tampa Bay Buccaneers are one victory away from the Super Bowl.

title: Language a Key to the Spirit of an Islamic Revival
description: TUNIS  At airports throughout the Middle East, there are always several passengers who arrive carrying tape recorders, often very large, the way they used to carry radios. Cassettes are the new weapon of the twentieth century, says an Egyptian magazine.

title: A Family Lights the Sky For 1980
description: Felix Grucci Sr. with his sons, James Felix, left, and Felix Jr., loading shells in Bellport for the finale at Central Park tomorrow night BELLINRT FELIX GRUCCI SR. is a man of few words. But what he lacks in verbosity he makes up for with fiery bursts of color that ignite the sky in resounding salutes that shake whole buildings. I let my fireworks do the talking, Mr. Grucci said And talk they will tomorrow night, when thousands of people will gather for the annual New Year's Eve sky show at Central Park and the heavens will erupt for In minutes in starlike glitter in white, blue and gold.

title: New Year: A RedLetter Day for Resolve
description: Igenerally shy away from written New Year's resolutions. Most years, I promise myself to make a few changes and get fired up for a few days. Then, in the busyness of daily life, the resolutions disappear into that misty realm of unreclaimed and unfulfilled good intentions.

title: Wine
description: In the cellars of Moe! et Chandon in the village of Epernay, a solidly built, leathery faced man in blue work clothes and a white apron reaches for a bottle of Dom Perignon after its cork has been removed. He sniffs at the opening to assure himself that the wine is in good condition, then he puts the bottle back on the production line to be recorked. He repeats the process thousands of times each day. His highly skilled nose is an important qualitycontrol device at Moet, the largest Champagne firm.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: It is frequently said that economists, or at least the more benighted ones, believe that we should generate a recession to fight inflation. While this may seem heartless, a strong case can actually be made for such a policy.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: An Inflation Index That Inflates
description: Everyone wants protection from the continuing economic storm. Given a decade of rapid inflation, gloomy forecasts for the early 80's and uncertainty as to whether it can even be stopped by the 90's, some people think the only ready shelter is indexing  that is, adding a costofliving escalator clause to everything.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: GOOD AS GOLD, by Joseph Heller. (Pocket, $2.95.) Dr. Bruce Gold, a scheming professor of literature and New York intellectual of a sort, grooms himself for high office in a Nixonian Administration. This third novel by the author of Catch22 and Something Happened is a broad farce about Jewish families and Washington politics that contains much truth as well as gross slapstick lunacy.

title: F. EDWARD HEBERT, EXLAWMAKER, DIES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (UPI)  F. Edward Hebert, the Democratic Congressman who served Louisiana's First District from 1941 until his retirement in 1977, died at 5 P.M. today of massive heart failure, hospital officials said. He was 78 years old.

title: IN THE NATION Boldly Into The 80's
description: The Wall Street Journal observed unhappily the other day that its editors had begun to fear that the control of this inflation exceeds not only our will but our intellect.

title: Terror: Almost a Commonplace
description: BONN  It is all a dim memory now, buried by an avalanche of barbarism and criminal inventiveness, but the first big international terrorist act of the 70's was a handsdown victory for the law of the gun against the temple.

title: Ruth Kroll Married To E. R. Tolles Jr.
description: The Lutheran Church in Silver Spring, Md., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Ruth Dorothea Kroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Kroll of Silver Spring, to Edward Robert Tolles Jr., son of Mr. Tolles of Palm Coast, Fla., and Elizabeth B. Tolles of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David Shaheen performed the ceremony..

title: Footnotes, Signposts, Etc.
description: An estimated 466 million people died during the 1970's, but only Howard Hughes had to do it to prove he was alive. Mr. Hughes's previous efforts to demonstrate his existence  his remotecontrol battle over Clifford Irving's phony biography, his meeting in 1972 with the President of Nicaragua and the United States Ambassador, were unconvincing. But his death in 1976 of kidney failure, drugs and selfneglect was persuasive, as was his failure to leave a will.

title: On Language
description: A nomenclator, in ancient Rome, was the slave who called out the names of arriving guests; today, it is the person who dreams up the scientificsounding labels for automobiles, stereo sets, cameras and airplanes.

title: Deaths
description: LUSTIG  Rose. Beloved mother of Harriet Lun and the late Nora Capus and Eugene Goldsmith. Dear sister of Ida Green. Loving grandmother of Debra, Marc, Mitchell, Charles and Marcia. Services today, fpm, Parkside Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue opposite Kings Plaza.

title: The World
description: Neither steel fences nor police lines backed by German shepherd attack dogs deterred thousands of black Rhodesians from rushing the tarmac at Salisbury airport last week to welcome home returning senior officers of the Patriotic Front guerrillas.

title: Ten Years of Best Sellers
description: Tbegan with the invasion of Cambodia and the bloodshed at Kent State. It is ending with an anguishing drama in Iran. In between there have been half a dozen other traumas, including the evacuation of Vietnam that concluded the longest and most futile war in United States history and the Watergate affair that led to the first resignation from office of an American President.

title: Further Revisions Were Suggested Last Week; Where Lies The Future of Nuclear Power?  A Dialogue
description: WASHINGTON  Last spring's accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant near Harrisburg, Pa., set in motion a chain reaction of concerned fact and faultfinding that hasn't ended yet. Already, a Presidential commission has presented its findings, many of them critical of the Federal Government's procedures for licensing and regulating the generating plants and of the utilities that operate the facilities. President Carter has outlined reforms he wants Congress to take up in 1980. And last week, The New York Times reported that the N.
