R.C. s own inquiry, in a preliminary version, said serious consideration should be given to halting work on new reactors until the commission has been abolished and replaced by a new agency. The inquiry's report also tentatively recommended shutting down any reactor operating in an area where provisions haven't been made for evacuating the population within a 30mile radius.

title: The Celebration of Self Themes and Variations
description: HALFWAY through the 1970's. even the man who would be President could not resist the confessional pressures of popular culture and the need to talk of his true self. And so Jimmy Carter confessed lust in his heart to Playboy magazine in much the littleboy way George Washington is said to have confessed felling the cherry tree.

title: Samuel Robins Jr. Weds Ruth McCollester
description: At the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Ruth R. McCollester was married to Samuel Davis Robins Jr. in a Protestant ceremony performed by the Rev. James J. Wisecup.

title: Theology and Scarcity
description: WASHINGTON  The world is moving from an age of growth to an age of scarcity. At the same time, America is experiencing a largescale evangelical religious revival. At the center of this revival are two competing doctrines, each battling the other to define the direction that this religious movement will take.

title: More Power To the Sun   And From
description: After the boisterous observance of Earth Day, April 22, 1970, and the 1971 inauguration of an annual Earth Week, the next logical step might have been Earth Month and Decade. In fact, it was Sun Day, May 3, 1978, a celebration designed to lead the United States into the solar era. Earth Day brought 2,000 colleges, 2,000 community groups and 10,000 schools to demonstrate for the environment; nationwide some 20 million people celebrated. Earth Week, offering lowerkey, primarily local observances, signalled the environmental movement's comingofage.

title: The Unfolding Drama of House Ads
description: ANY observer of society, to analyze our dreams of the good suburban life, should peruse the advertisments for houses. Many families have dreamed of Westchester's beauties and comforts, only to find that inflation has deflated their dreams. But while the dreams get harder to realize, the ads get louder and fancier.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: There seems to be a need at The New York Times to bring to the attention of its readers each year the misguided holiday habits of certain Christians and Jews who have personal identity problems.

title: G.M. Recalling Small Trucks
description: DETROIT, Dec. 29 (UPI)  The General Motors Corporation is recalling about 16,000 1979 Chevrolet LUV trucks because a bolt in the steering mechanism could work loose, possibly causing a loss of steering or damage to brake lines. Only fourwheeldrive models of the small, Japanesemade truck are affected by the recall, G.M. said in its announcement yesterday.

title: Kennedy Partisans Last Week Filed Suit Charging Misuse of Office
description: WASHINGTON  Since he became Secretary of Transportation last summer, Neil E. Goldschmidt has made big news only once, and he did not mean to do it that time.

title: Buccaneers and Oilers Win
description: Tampa Bay beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 2417, and Houston upset the San Diego Chargers, 1714, in pro football playoff games. Section 5.

title: Vital Statistics of the Planet
description: Biggest Cities; (Populanon in milhons)

title: Wilder's World
description: THE narrator in Thornton Wilder's last novel, Theophilus North, confesses to eight ambitions: to be a saint, anthropologist, archeologist, actor, magician, lover, rogue and free man. Vicariously, in fiction and plays, essays and addresses (and sometimes in real life), Wilder approximated the goals of his selfdeHis World.

title: Hospice Program to Start
description: WHITE PLAINS WESTCHESTER'S only statecertified hospice  a facility designed specifically to care for the terminally ill  opens Tuesday at United Hospital in Port Chester.

title: Times are changing, time is short
description: Until the mid1960's, forecasting religious trends was simple: Churches would grow, since they had always grown and churchgoing was a mark of the solid citizen.

title: Exhibitions in Fair Lawn and Summit Send the Old Year Out on a High Note
description: THE end of the year also marks the end of most art exhibitions. The majority of museums, galleries and university showcases want to start the New Year with something fresh, turning their backs on the old year.

title: Eileen Sinon Is Married To Edwin Halsch on L.I.
description: St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L.I., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Eileen Sinon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Sinon of East Williston, L.I., to Edwin Thomas Halsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. Halsch of Paramus, N.J. The Rev. Patrick J. Whitney performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: GARDENING
description: AS the holiday season wanes, so often do the fortunes of holiday plants. The busy season may have left little time to provide them with adequate care, or the location in which they were used for decoration may have been unsuitable.

title: Egyptian Sees U.S. Strike at Iran If Hostages in Embassy Are Slain
description: CAIRO, Dec. 29 (UPI)  The Defense Minister of Egypt, Lieut. Gen. Kamal Hassan Ali, believes the United States will undertake military action against Iran if the Americans held hostage in Teheran are killed, and he added that this might lead to a confrontation with the Soviet Union. Al Abram asked the Defense Minister and other Cabinet members and wellknown figures for their 1980 forecasts.

title: In Europe, it would be in a guidebook. Page 17
description: IT ALWAYS takes you by surprise. On the last curve of Spring Valley Road between Squires Corner and Blairstown, there is a dip and then a rise; suddenly, surrounded by tall, dark cedars in a tumbledown cemetery, stands the ruin.

title: There's no free lunch
description: The tocsin that sounded for the environment a decade ago is a bell that cannot be unrung. In the 1970's it pealed and the nation awoke to environmental problems, and those concerns emerged as a novel element in politics, and a locus for legislation and litigation. By the end of the decade the bell had tolled and events proved that environmental purity is not an absolute. It is relative, an ideal state to which one can only aspire.

title: The Ramapo Ramapoughs: A Thirst for KnowHow
description: MAHWAH THE chief of the Ramapough Mountain Indian tribal organization pointed toward a wooded 34acre tract on Stag Hill.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: According to an article by Harold M. Schmeck Jr. (The New York Times, July 4), the smallpox virus has probably been eliminated from nature everywhere on earth, but fear of the disease is still causing death through unnecessary use of smallpox vaccine.

title: LETTER TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The two articles on Long Island's history of hate [Bigotry on L.I. Then and Now and This Terrible Undercurrent in Our Society, Opinion Page, Dec. 2], provide important insights into the most recent manifestations of visible hatred. The continuing epidemic of symbolic terrorism in the form of burning swastikas and crosses on Long Island should be recognized as an acute attack of a chronic condition. As resident director of the AntiDefamation League on Long Island, I routinely receive scores of reports of incidents every year.

title: Taxes and Farms: What Is a Farm?
description: HALL GIBSON of Ryder Farm in Brewster fights a constant battle to maintain the land he works. At harvest time, with assistance from some highschool students and one fulltime helper, a 21yearold agricultural student, he picks squash, beans, tomatoes and corn for market in New York City.

title: Skillful Soviet Hockey Team Triumphs Over Islanders by 32
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 29  Although the coaching staff expressed dissatisfaction with the squad's play, the Soviet Central Red Army team still demonstrated enough speed, agility and concentration today to beat the New York Islanders, 32, in an exhibition hockey game before 10,123 fans at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE were a few commuters, at least, who were unaffected by the recent unpleasantness on the Long Island Rail Road. They got into their cars, drove to the parking lot, climbed aboard and were at their desks by 9 A.M.

title: The Melting Pot Didn't
description: Many Americans began to pull themselves out of the melting pot in the 70's. The urge to preserve an ethnic identity, or, as often as not, simply to find one, touched many ethnic groups.

title: A Soldier's Private War
description: BROOKFIELD THE evening two years ago after Ronald Mutchko helped defuse BZ bombs  tiny canisters containing a hallucinogen said to be 10 to 100 times as potent as LSD  he was flown by Army helicopter to a medical center, suffering from severe hallucinations.

title: Court Delays Attempt By Protestant Couple To Adopt Jewish Boy
description: The adoption of a handicapped Jewish baby by a Protestant minister and his wife has been temporarily blocked as result of a lawsuit brought by a young Hasidic couple who hope to adopt the child instead.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: IN less than 48 hours we will be in the 80's  the dawn of a new decade for housing as well as for everything else. What alterations are in store in our list of priorities for choosing a home?

title: 6 Countries to Discuss Soviet Afghan Moves
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (Reuters)  A highlevel delegation of American officials will hold urgent consultations Monday in London with five other nations on the Soviet military moves in Afghanistan, the State Department said today.

title: Deborah Deffaa Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Deborah Anne Deffaa to Bruce F: Lee of Arlington, Va., and Chevy Chase, Md., son of Ralph Lee of Chevy Chase and the late Millicent Lee, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis P. Deffaa 3d of Glen Rock, N.J.

title: They're Tapping Today in Brooklyn
description: Many tap dancers blame Oklahoma!  which opened on Broadway in 1993 with Agnes de Mine's thennovel balletic choreography  for instigating tap dancing's seemingly moribund postwar quarter century. Ballet was in; tap was out. And it was not until Ruby Keeler came back in No, No, Nanette in 1971 that the clatter of busy feet began to regain popularity. Other taphappy musicals followed, including Eubie!, Bubbling Brown Sugar, Irene and Whoopee revivals, and most recently Sugar Babies, in which the indomitable Ann Miller taps up a storm.

title: Women Athletes Gained Recognition And Also Respect
description: ON the first chilly day presaging winter in Norfolk, Va., the home of Old Dominion University, Nancy Lieberman decided to do some holiday shopping. Entering a shop not far from the college campus, the frecklefaced 21yearold milled around the store until she spotted a small container on the cashier's counter that held a number of cards detailing the schedule for the women's basketball team at Old Dominion. From under the brim of her Panama hat, she studied her picture on the flip side, and with mischievous grin asked a saleswoman, Who is this girl?

title: Bear Hug
description: WASHINGTON  The Soviet Union's traditional interest in Afghanistan, Iran and other states to its south was stated bluntly by Vyacheslav M. Molotov in negotiations with the Nazis during their honeymoon prior to Hitler's invasion of Russia. Agreement on a NaziSoviet protocol was possible, Mr. Molotov said, provided that the area south of Batum and Baku in the general direction of the Persian Gulf is recognized as the focal point of the aspirations of the Soviet Union.

title: Snow Geese Imperiling Brigantine
description: OCEANVILLE THE snow goose, which until 10 years ago was considered merely an occasional visitor to New Jersey, has increased in the state so much that it has disturbed the ecological balance of the 20,000acre Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge here. As a result, Federal officials have been discussing the possibility of allowing substantially more hunting within the refuge.

title: How'm I doing? New York ABC's Angst, Broadway, Cosmopolitanism
description: It's not in very good shape, this city of ours. It must count every penny or again face bankruptcy. Its streets are dirty and full of potholes. Its services are down to a minimum. It is full of tensions that could explode during the 1980's.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: CHAPPAQUA THE guest of honor was Cleveland Amory, but the author had to share the spotlight. Specifically, he had to share it with four dogs, three cats, one quail, one rabbit and one skunk.

title: Radical Change In the Schools: Two Views on Voucher Plan
description: Depending on what happens this week, California may face a decision on a voucher system that would radically change the structure of public education. Under the plan, public and private schools would both continue to operate as they now do. But in addition, parents would have the choice of spending vouchers at two other kinds of schools, both supported by public funds. Independent Public Schools (IPS's) would be established by local school boards as selfgoverning public corporations, while Family Choice Schools ( FCS's) would be set up by groups of parents or teachers or others as nonprofit, private corporations. Both would be financed by vouchers set at 90 percent of the perpupil cost of the public schools.

title: Generations of Women
description: RIGHT MORRIS'S novel is a very good book, easily the best we have had from him since Ceremony in Lone Tree. He now has 30 books to his credit, and most of the best of them For Female Voices.

title: Mary Catherine Burke Is Bride
description: Mary Catherine Burke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Burke of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to Mark Royal Lybeck, son of Royal C. Lybeck of Edison, N.J., and the late Jane Pemberton Lvbeck.

title: The Region
description: New York City's crowded skies are no stranger to midair collisions back in 1960, 127 persons were killed as two airliners collided over Staten Island and one of them crashed in Brooklyn. Since then, New York City has experienced numerous nearcollisions. This year alone, two F15 fighters came within 15 feet of a Concorde airliner, two Boeing 707's nearly collided over Long Island, and a Boeing 727 and a commuter plane came close to crashing near LaGuardia. Those incidents have contributed to the fear of too much air traffic in too many directions over the metropolitan area, and not enough technological control.

title: Lois Nacht Becomes the Bride Of Philip B. Rosen, a Lawyer
description: Lois Nacht and Philip Bruce Rosen, graduates of the New York University School of Law, were married last evening in Lawrence. L.I., where Rabbi Morris Friedman, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony in Temple Israel.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Desmond Morris, the popularizer of animal ethology (The Naked Ape), and various helpers at 40 locations from Glasgow to Istanbul have mapped 20 key gestures. They contend that by tracing the geographical range and the antiquity of these actions we can begin to see them more clearly as an understandable pattern of human behavior. Well, for such an investigation to be worth the trouble (and it took many hours of interviews as well as a grant of undisclosed dimensions from the Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation), there ought to have been some initial mystery to solve.

title: GARDENING Holiday Plants Needn't Fade With Season
description: AS the holiday season wanes, so often do the fortunes of holiday plants. The busy season may have left little time to provide them with adequate care, or the location in which they were used for GARDENING Holiday Plants Needn't Fade With Season decoration may have been unsuitable. Many plants may be beyond saving and would best be discarded as they fade. Others may still survive if given a bit of attention and care.

title: Martha Page Bride Of Per Lorentzen Jr. In New Hampshire
description: Martha Hellyer Page, an assistant to the director of production at Harry N. Abrams Inc., New York publishers, and Per Arne Lorentzen Jr., a liquified petroleum gas specialist with Poten & Partners Inc., ship and LPG brokers and consultants, were married yesterday afternoon at the Community Church in Sugar Hill, N.H., by Canon T. Chester Baxter, an Episcopal clergyman.

title: New Census Has Some Changes
description: Adecade ago, the last time the Census Bureau conducted its decennial head count, muncipalities like Mount Vernon had very little to do about it except check the results  and then complain, sometimes years later, about the hundreds or even thousands of residents who were not counted.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ONE of the major legislative battles shaping up even before the new State Legislature is sworn in on Jan. 8 will pit apartment landlord and tenant groups against each other over the question of passing along higher fuel costs.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Dance: Nikolais Scenario and Tent
description: Alwin Nikolais opened his box of magic tricks again on Friday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater when the Nikolais Dance Theater offered a program of spectacular works from its repertory choreographed, designed and composed by Mr. Nikolais, the wizard of modern dance. Yet the presentation also suggested that Mr. Nikolais is best as a magician when he regards magic as a serious business.

title: Jordan Willits Wed To Pennsylvanian
description: Jordan Howard Willits, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Cooper Willits of Paoli, Pa., was married at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa., yesterday to Stephen Dittmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Carton Dittmann Jr. of Wynnewood, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James A. Trimble, assisted by the Rev. Richard W. Hess.

title: Champagne  GoGo: The Many Brands of MoetHennessy
description: PARIS  Dom Perignon, the monk who is said to have invented champagne, is also said to have described it as stars in a bottle. At 30 Avenue Hoche here just a few yards down from the Arch of Triumph, champagne means something else  big money.

title: SOVIET BACKS OFFER TO AFGHAN REBELS
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 29  The Soviet Government indicated today that it would favor a move by the new Afghan regime of President Babrak Karmal aimed at a political settlement of the Moslem tribal insurgency.

title: China Assails Soviet Afghan Role
description: China has condemned the heightened Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, which it said would spread the flames of armed rebellion and burn Moscow's fingers.

title: Infectious Diseases: I.N.I.T.I.A.L.I.S.M.
description: A recent radio commercial advertising a popular business publication depicts a couple on a cruise to the Galapagos islands. The husband is having a miserable time. He says he feels lost without the familiar ambience of his office. What I really miss, he confesses to his wife, are JF, RW and CM.

title: 10 Held in Marijuana Seizure
description: CAMERON, La., Dec. 29 (AP)  Federal agents arrested 10 Colombians and seized 5 to 10 tons of marijuana yesterday from a utility boat that apparently halted because of rudder problems.

title: Mantras, Meditation and Murder
description: When the news flashed out of the jungle in Jonestown, Guyana, of the mass suicide of 918 people in November 1978, the horrifying images seemed to justify the warnings of the 70's on the dangers of cults. They were proliferating and they were capturing the hearts and minds of young people. That did not apply only to religioustype organizations but to groups like Synanon, Scientology and est that sought to raise consciousness.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IF you've always wanted to own a piece of art with a distinctive history but have been scared off by high prices, the Little Studio, a print gallery at 1007 Port Washington Boulevard, is worth a visit.

title: South Fork: It's Not Too Late for a Choice
description: HISTORY, geography and the concern of its residents have preserved the quality of life and the integrity of the natural resources on the South Fork for three centuries. Both are now threatened by rapid growth and sprawling development.

title: Miss Hendrie Has Nuptials
description: Margaret Brooks Hendrie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fowler Hendrie of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to James Landauer Widdoes of Los Angeles, a film and television actor, whose parents are Mr. and Mrs. William Peirce Widdoes of Pittsburgh.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Cover: Illustration by Robert Grossman

title: Krasnayarsk Dances Put Off
description: The Krasnayarsk Dance Ensemble, a folk company from the Soviet Union that has performed here several times in the past, will not arrive in the United States to begin a national tour as scheduled. The company was to have opened next Saturday at Carnegie Hall. Columbia Artists Management, which was presenting the tour, said yesterday that the engagement had been postponed. Refunds may be obtained at the Carnegie Hall box office or at the Columbia Artists box office at 165 West 57th Street.

title: Patience Is Strength in Iran
description: As the year, and the 70's, near their end, not a taper yet gleams in the tunnel called Iran. A Christmas visit by three American clergymen to the Teheran hostages has deepened, not diminished, the murk. They found no answers as to who controls the fate of the captives, or even how many there really are. It is understandable, after two months of national frustration, tnat some Americans wonder if a charge of dynamite would unblock the tunnel, redeem honor and bring the Teheran hostages safely home.

title: For Boston Drivers It's Turn Right on Red and Full Speed Ahead
description: BOSTON, Dec. 29  Driving in Boston, a legendary madcap freeforall affair known nationwide for its resemblance to a drunken gocart race, will take on new dimensions Tuesday when Massachusetts bows to Federal pressure and becomes the last of the 50 states to allow motorists to make right turns on a red light.

title: Beaths
description: DALLOORFGilbert. The Board of Directors and Officers of Research Corporation express their sorrow at the death on December 21st of a dis tinguished scientist, teacher and ad ministrator. During his long career Dr. Daildorf contributed to the health of mankind through his discoveries In pathology and viral disease, and as founder of the Westchester County Division of Laboratories and Research and later DIrector of the Division of Laboratories and Research of the New York State Department of Health in Albany. His concern for the further advancement of medical science was demonstrated by his many years of service to Research Corporation In directing a program of grantsinaid to support biomedical research by academic Investigators.

title: Topics Dry, Dusty, Crisp
description: Even Palm Beach  a place of delicate tints dedicated to the most splendid and conspicuous consumption  has encountered its hardships. This year it is a shortage of Dom Perignon champagne, an item that may mean as much to the Florida resort as the opalescent sea. (Iranian caviar has also disappeared, but that's said to be a voluntary austerity.)

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Viewed from a distance, classical records have had a good year. The volume of releases did not diminish perceptibly, there have been a wealth of distinguished performances, especially in the operatic field, and, despite rising prices, collectors still seem willing to pay a premium to hear their favorite artists and explore new repertory. Most record stores even report an increase in classical sales, in marked contrast to the present slump in the pop market.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: The original version of William Faulkner's Sanctuary had already been set in galleys by his publishers, Jonathan Cape and Harrison Smith. when Faulkner wrote As I Lay Dying in an astonishing six weeks in the fall of 1929. Sanctuary was put aside in favor of the new novel. After the critical success of As I Lay Dying, Faulkner was reluctant to let it be followed by the horrific tale he had written as a calculated assault on the commercial market, but Cape and Smith had invested money in the book and could not afford to scrap it. Faulkner agreed to publication only after extensive revision. He himself paid half the expenses for resetting the text.

title: Florence T. Childs Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Childs of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Florence Twombly Childs, to Donald A. Macdonald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Macdonald of Rumson, N.J. Plans have been made for a June 19 wedding in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan.

title: Art: How Companies Get Burned
description: Pierre Apraxine, art curator at the Gilman Paper Company, sat in his small office in his employer's lavishly appointed midtown headquarters and pointed to a Eugene Atget photograph. Bought in January 1976 for $1,400, Versailles, he said, should probably now be worth $6.000.

title: Centralizing The County's Support Units
description: WHITE PLAINS PEOPLE whose marriage is falling apart. People who are depressed after the birth of a child. People who are divorced or widowed. People who have cancer. People who are alcoholics. People who are just plain lonely.

title: Flyers Unbeaten Streak Hits 32
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 29 (AP)  The Philadelphia Flyers left Winnipeg last night with their National Hockey League unbeaten streak at 32 games after defeating the Jets. 53.

title: Ann S. Miller Is Married to Knight Kiplinger
description: Ann Sheldon Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lambert Henry Miller of Falls Church, Va., was married in the Falls Church Presbyterian Church yesterday to Knight Austin Kiplinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Huntington Kiplinger of Poolesville, Md. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen Smith, assisted by the Rev. John Pierpont Cobb, uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Births
description: Susan and Ethan LevinEpstein (nee Helper) Joyfully announce the birth of their daughters Lauren Sade and Amy Helper on December 23, 1979.

title: Copeland Paces Knicks Victory
description: Hollis Copeland, the New York Knicks rookie, sits and waits for his chance to contribute and prove he belongs in the National Basketball Association. The opportunity came last night, with 2 minutes 27 seconds remaining in the third quarter.

title: Vilas Gains Easily In Australian Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 29 (UPI)  Guillermo Vilas of Argentina took another step today toward becoming the first man in seven years to win two consecutive Australian opens with a 63.6.4, 64 victory over Peter MacNamara of Australia.

title: Winner of Individual and Team Chapionships During 1979
description: World Champions

title: Behind the Headlines: Remembering Subtle Scenes of 79
description: THE headlines fade into history, but behind the headlines are the subtle scenes. And in 1979, as in every year, those are the memories that remain.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:30 A.M. (2) For Our Times: Events that made religious news during 1979.

title: A Look Toward the 80's
description: Barbara Maslen

title: It Gets Wearing
description: During the winter of 1970, women wore shorts  hot pants, protesting a hemline drop from midthigh to midcalf. The shorts soon vanished, women sported pants suits, and for years everyone ignored fashion. Yves Saint Laurent signaled a new sumptuousness in 1976 with his midcalf, peasant look. Women began wearing longer skirts as designers tried bringing back kneelengths, where skirts end today.

title: Cohalan Puts New Faces in County Posts
description: THE new administration being fashioned by Peter F. Cohalan, the Republican who will be sworn in as Suffolk County Executive on Tuesday, promises to be as different from that of the outgoing John V. N. Klein, also a Republican, as if another party had won control.

title: A World
description: AS the 1970's began, Nolan Ryan had his baseball salary doubled, from $12,000 to $24,000. As the 70's end, he has become the first $1millionayear player in team sports history.

title: Sailor Defends Boat After Atlantic Storm
description: John Tuttle is back at his office in North Andover, Mass., buying and selling real estate. Land is something he has learned to appreciate lately.

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: John Connally frightens me. In an era when image particularly television image  counts for all, and substance for very little, the article by Stephen Brill (Connally: Coming on Tough, Nov. 25) describes a John Connally who has a most dangerous combination of attributes  an image of tall, whitehaired sincerity and a stentorian speaking voice, coupled with an almost childlike impatience and a hollow unconcern for the realities of today's world.

title: L.I.R.R. Increases Patrols
description: Long Island Rail Road officials said they were adding extra railroad police officers to battle an increase in violence aboard trains. The officials said this marks the first time the L.I.R.R. has assigned officers to ride trains for eighthour shifts.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: YOUTH SERVED: David Russell of St. John's hanging on rim after dunking ball Friday against Boston College. Russell, a freshman, was penalized play but was named M.V. P. of Holiday Festival as St. John's won final, 7870.

title: If You Go
description: to the Little Switzerland area of Maryland, you may obtain travel information from the Deep Creek LakeGarrett County Promotion Council, Room 300, Court House, Oakland, Md. 21550 (3013343888). Also helpful on park and forest material is the state's Department of Natural Resources, Tawes State Office Building, Annapolis, Md. 21401. Maps of two of the state parks are available from the New Germany superintendent at 3018955453 or the Herrington superintendent at 3013349180. Information on snow may be obtained by calling 3017680895.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: John Rayburn, head of the music department at Mercy College, has arranged a onemonth Arts as Adventure course for January that will include 12 trips into New York City to attend dress rehearsals of Lohengrin and Fidelio, followed by backstage tours at the Metropolitan Opera House, performances of Sweeney Todd and A Chorus Line on Broadway, trips to the Guggenheim Museum, the Metropolitan and Whitney Museums, architectural tours of the great churches and Greenwich Village, a New York City Ballet performance and trips to notable libraries and galleries.

title: Owning an Island Holds Its Appeal Despite Problems
description: In 1969 Bob Douglas was sitting in his real estate office in Moncton, New Brunswick, Canada, when his secretary announced that two drunken men were in the waiting room and that they wanted to buy islands. Should she show them in or throw them out?

title: THE THREATENING ECONOMY
description: The United States of America produced an astounding total of more than $15 trillion in goods and services during the decade of the 70's. Its gross national product for the year that ends 1 tomorrow is more than 50 percent greater than that of the Soviet Union and more than double that of Japan, its nearest rivals; its consumers were able to buy $1.5 trillion worth of products, by far the highest figure for any nation. As America enters the 80's. it is still outproducing and outconsuming all other industrial economies. But at some juncture during the past decade precisely when is difficult to pinpoint  signs of deep and continuing trouble began to appear. The country's rate of production began to decline; it slipped from being No. 1 in the world to No. 7 in per capita G.N.P.  that is in the amount it produced per person; the value of the dollar plunged on world markets, and inflation began to erode severely the abilities of Americans to support themselves and their families. With doubts growing day by day, some believe we could well be entering a dangerous world crisis whose roots are essentially economic. For this reason, a continued failure to solve our economic problems may herald far more than downward adjustments in living standards. No one needs to be reminded that economic chaos gave rise to Hitler and ultimately World War II.

title: A THANK YOU NOTE FOR NATURE'S WAYS
description: To oysters, whose indecisive sex does not impair Their edibility; to bluegreen algae endowing the air With oxygen; to black ducks winnowing the dusk with wild Wings, and to the channeling worm whose flair For excavation makes our gardens grow, my best. To the Black bear in his blowdown den, a good winter's sleep. I do, at times, consider joining him, but cannot keep My hands warm at hibernation's tiny fire.

title: Football's Clockwork Makes Fan See Red
description: TERRY Bradshaw, one of the most successful of modern quarterbacks, stands 6 feet 3 inches tall and weighs 215 pounds, considerably larger than your avarage embryo. Yet, on many occasions during the course of a season, you will find Terry doing a remarkable imitation of a fetus, curled up on a gridiron, trying to conceal a football in his navel, as thousands of spectators watch from the stands, and millions more view from their homes.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books 4bld at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: An Eye on a Hastings Artist of Old
description: EARLIER this year, the village of HastingsonHudson marked its association with Jasper Francis Cropsey (and its own 100th anniversary) with a small show of his oils and drawings of landscape. The artist, who lived from 1823 to 1900, now appears again but in greater depth and at the Hudson River Museum. Entitled An unprejudiced Eye and organized by Kenneth Maddox, the guest curator, the show contains more than 100 drawings lent by institutions such as Boston's Museum of Fine Arts, the Metropolitan Museum and the Newington Cropsey Foundation, as well as private collectors.

title: Beyond Jogging, Real Health Concern
description: Whose speaks on Health is sure of a large audience. Save for the grammar, this statement could be made today as well as in 1864 when, as Bruce Haley puts it in his book. The Healthy Body and Victorian Culture, healthconscious Victorians flocked to the seaside, tramped about the Alps or Cotswolds, dieted, took pills, sweated themselves in Turkish baths, adopted this system of medicine or that [and] invented, revived or imported from abroad a multitude of athletic recreations.

title: Molecular Biolozy Takes Over Where Evolution Left Off
description: If the decades could be given signatures, the 1950's might be called the age of the atom; the 60's, the dawn of manned space flight and the 70's the comine of age of electronics.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Just in case the climate really settles down into winter, those who cater to coldweather sports are keeping their facilities at the ready. For example, through February, Nassau County's crosscountry trails at Bay Park, East Rockaway; Morley Park, Roslyn; Eisenhower Park, East Meadow; the Garvies Point Preserve, Glen Cove; Grant Park, Hewlett; North Woodmere Park and the Tackapausha Preserve, Seaford, will be open free of charge for novice skiers.

title: More Must Share the Research Pie
description: WASHINGTON  The outcries of American scientists suggest that support for scientific research has decreased over the oast decade and that this country's considerable scientific powers are disintegrating. In fact, America's commitment to research and development has more than doubled in 10 years, growing by 7 percent.

title: 1,625 Spills in Year
description: Karl Birns is chief of the Department of Environmental Protection's Office of Hazardous Substances Control, which directs the cleanup of accidental chemical spills and operates a prevention program.

title: The Unraveling of the Watergate Affair: Shock by Shock
description: June 17, 1972   Five men are arrested in Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate. One, James W. McCord Jr., is security director of the Committee to Reelect the President. Shortly, two other men with White House and Nixon campaign ties, E. Howard Hunt Jr. and G. Gordon Liddy, are linked to the burglars.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOkS
description: Children recapitulate the history of the race: their toys are imbued with life, as the totems of primitive people are. Every child has a toy rabbit, doll or bear that seems to have a living personality, that can see with button eyes and hear with stitchedon ears.

To settle the quarrel : Any 10 years make a decade. The 10 years beginning with 1970 conveniently make a decade called the 1970's. It ends tomorrow. However (because Jesus was born in the Year 1, there being no Year 0), the 198th decade of the Christian calendar ends Dec. 31, 1980. So it s 20 years to the 21st century. Or 21

title: Backgammon:
description: Upon reaching a highly favorable position many players tend to relax and let the position play itself. This is the best time, however, to bear down and take advantage of your opponent's weakness. By exploiting the defects in his game, you can reduce his chances of winning and possibly gammon him.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING Some Alternate Forms of Financing
description: MORTGAGE money having become tight this year, many realestate brokers in New Jersey have turned to alternate forms of financing.

title: New Jersey/ This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College. Franklin and Fremont Streets)  A Christmas Carol. in an Actor's CafeTheater production. Today, 7:30 P.M. Also, Waiting for Godot. Opens Friday (through Feb. 2). Thursday through Saturday. 8:30 P.M. 53.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50.$4.50; group rates. (201)4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Chicago Schools Nearing Shutdown in Fiscal Crisis
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 29  Vendors who serve schools and officials of unions representing the Chicago Board of Education's 50,000 employees have told school officials they will not provide services after next Friday if they are not paid. The assertions increased the likelihood that the nation's third largest school system might have to shut down as a result of its fiscal crisis.

title: Editors Choice
description: DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Golding. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A magic fable that explores the darkness of human nature through the fortunes of Malty, brushed by fire as a boy during a World War II blitz, and of numerous people he later encounters in 13ritain and Australia.

title: Trying to Lower the Price Tag Will Be an Early Task for Education Secretary
description: WASHINGTON  Though it has been overshadowed by energy, Iran and other issues, a higher education measure passed by the House last month could be one of the more significant bills to come out of the 96th Congress. It promises greater financial relief not only for parents and students, keenly aware during this holiday recess that tuition payments are due or past due, but also for colleges and universities pinched by inflation and declining enrollments.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: THE State Senate has buried an ethics bill so deep that even an archeologist would have trouble finding it. This assessment by a state official pertains to a measure that would have required members of the Legislature and local officials to disclose their sources of income and their major debts.

title: Zabar Vows a 3Month Delay in Tenant Evictions
description: Stanley Zabar, .speaking to protesters crowded in front of his delicatessen on Broadway, pledged yesterday to restore essential services to the 50 people who live in a singleroomoccupancy hotel situated over his food emporium and not to evict the tenants for at least three months.

title: With a Fortune Over $20 Million, Kennedy Is Wealthiest in '80 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who has never fully disclosed his net worth, owns or benefits from a personal fortune valued at more than $20 million, according to a review of the Massachusetts Democrat's finances. That makes him the wealthiest candidate in the race for President.

title: Redefining Individual Rights
description: In any given term, year after year, the same core issues are somewhere on the United States Supreme Court's docket.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1979

title: When Bob Fosse's Art Imitates Life, It's Just All That Jazz
description: Bob Fosse has choreographed his own death. In a splashy, hallucinatory extravaganza, lying on a hospital bed surrounded by gorgeous dancing girls in sequins, satin and ostrich plumes, he goes out to the tune of Bye Bye Life. It's ironic, black, funny and devastating. A real Fosse show.

title: Maki Returns, Wins SkiJumping Contest
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29  Jim Maki, a 29yearold sporting goods salesman in Grand Rapids, Minn., who has ended a oneyear retirement, won the opening event today in the first of four qualifying tournaments to determine the remaining places on the United States Olympic ski jumping team.

title: FALSE TEETH LPHOLO RIGHIS OF NEGRO
description: Just as, more than any other novel of the 20's, The Sun Also Rises came to be regarded as the testament of the Lost Generation, so it seems certain that On The Road will come to be known as that of the Beat Generation.

title: ART VIEW
description: No doubt about it: The outstanding art event of the year was the mammoth ParisMoscow exhibition at the Pompidou Center in Paris. To mount a definitive exhibition of the Russian modernists had long been the dream of many a curator on both sides of the Atlantic. But the obstacles looked all but insurmountable, and foremost among them was the necessity of securing the cooperation of the Soviet Government.

title: Iceland Is Boiling Over With Geothermal Energy to Spare
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  This is the cold, dark season here in the world's most northerly capital city, but no one worries much about heat or hot water. You just turn it on, and there it is, always, Hella Jonsdottir, a typical Icelandic housewife, explained over a cup of coffee in her toasty warm kitchen, as the winter wind howled outside.

title: Europe Still Possible for $25 a Night
description: The Hotel Esmeralda in Paris, just across the Seine from Notre Dame Cathedral, dates from the 17th century. It opens onto the garden of the 12thcentury church of St. JulienlePauvre, which is said to contain the city's second oldest tree, a North American acacia planted about 1680. Most of the hotel's 16 rooms have exposed beam ceilings and some of the furnishings are antiques. All the rooms have private showers and toilets.

title: Ann V. Folliss, W. J. Jeffery Plan Nuptials
description: Ann Vivien Folliss, a market representative with Frederick Atkins Inc.. marketing and merchandising concern, and William Jeremy Jeffery. who is with the corporate bond department of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., investment bankers, will be married Feb. 9 in New York.

title: GARDENING
description: AS the holiday season wanes, so often do the fortunes of holiday plants. The busy season may have left little time to provide them with adequate care, or the location in which they were used for decoration may have been unsuitable. Many plants may be beyond saving and would best be discarded as they fade. Others may still survive if given a bit of attention and care.

title: Monitors of Waste Seek a Shift in Tactics
description: TRENTON WE WANT to shift from a reactive mode to one of aggressive prevention, said Dr. Ron Buchanan, chief of the Office of HazardousWaste Management of the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Light Is Right And So Are Veggies
description: Spinach is fashion as we ap proach the 80's. So are carrots, broccoli, cauliflower and beansproutsofallsorts. The vegetables our mothers had to bribe and admonish us to eat because they were good for us (what less appetizing reason could there be?) have become high style, served in bouquet abundance and usually merely blanched to nearraw crispness.

title: Torrijos's Power in Panama Shows Signs of Steady Erosion
description: Protest Over Shah's Arrival Was a Symptom

title: Chess:
description: Two grandmasters  Arthur Bisguier of Rock Hill, N.Y., and Lev Album of New York City  and Leonid Balmazi, a national master from New York City, tied for first place with 41 scores in the 30player Swisssystem Greater Boston Open Tournament. First

title: A Viewer's Guide to Tomorrow's College Bowl Games
description: Alabama: Offense  QB, Steadman Shealy (10); HB, Major Ogilvie (42); T, Jim Bunch (63); FB, Steve Whitman (45); PK, Alan McElroy (6). Defense  E, E.J. Junior (39); CB, Don McNeal (28); LB, Tom Boyd (90); SS, Tommy Wilcox (15); T, Byron Braggs (47). Ish Ordonez

title: Commodities
description: GOLD is not a cause; it is an effect. Gold makes little happen; everything makes gold happen.

title: DENCHU HIRAGUSHI
description: TOKYO, Dec. 30 (Reuters)  Denchu Hiragushi, a Japanese wood sculptor, died of pneumonia here today. He was 107 years old.

title: Fortune Changes for Sampson
description: Ralph Sampson and Sam Bowie got to know each other last spring as they traveled and played against each other on the scholastic allstar circuit. They were wined and dined and underwent similar recruiting pressures before the 7foot4inch Sampson chose to attend Virginia and the 72 Bowie decided on Kentucky. Both began the season as starters, but Saturday night their basketball lives took different turns. While Bowie sat in the stands because of a onegame disciplinary suspension, Kentucky played and defeated Notre Dame, one of its biggest rivals for national attention, 8680, in Louisville, Ky.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alpha Industries Inc., a Woburn, Mass.based maker of microwave components and devices, has elected to its board Alfred M. Bertocchi, vice president, finance and administration, at the Digital Equipment Corporation.

title: Summary of Findings in Public Schools Reading Achievement Tests
description: The following tables summarize some of the findings of the reading tests given in June 1979 as reported by New York City's Board of Education.

title: Csonka, Little and Staubach Consider Retirement
description: After suffering frustrating season finales, two distinguished Miami Dolphins, Larry Csonka and Larry Little, and one noted Dallas Cowboy, Roger Staubach, said yesterday that they were considering retirement.

title: Steelers Rout Dolphins
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30  In a collegiate atmosphere, with fans singing fight songs and waving the team's colors, the old pros, the Pittsburgh Steelers, moved today to still another American Football Conference championship game by trouncing the Miami Dolphins, 3414. Special to The New York Times

title: New Fear Is Isolated: Freeway Phobia
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 30  As she drove along the freeway on her way to work, the panic started to build. The trembling and sweating began. She grew dizzy. So she pulled off to the side and stopped. Then she blacked out. Special to The New York Times

title: Davis, Miss Casale Win in Junior Event
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 30  Scott Davis of Santa Monica, Calif., the United States junior tennis champion, and Pamela Casale of Fairfield, N.J., were among the winners In the Rolex international junior tournament finals today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy. Special to The New York Times

title: Dance: Tap Festival With Copasetics
description: NO grander tribute to the oncedying art of tap dancing seemed possible than Saturday's wildly exciting evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, entitled Steps in Time  A Tap Dance Festival. Any fears that this would be a reverent exercise in nostalgia were marvelously shattered when this program's exuberantly spirited veteran hoofers simply walked onstage. No historical context. No allusions to the past were necessary. They gave us the here and now  great dancing on its own terms.

title: Purchasing Agents Turn Pessimistic
description: Many of the nation's purchasing agents  those who buy such industrial building blocks as fuel, steel and plastic  suggest that the economy's current malaise may be spreading. The latest report of the Business Survey Committee of the National Association of Purchasing Management, released over the weekend, showed that the nation's economy slumped sharply in December. Production and new orders fell and order backlogs were reduced.

title: New Year, Old Need
description: A letter from a couple in Manhattan says that their donation represents the beginning of their second quarter century of annual gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. We hope we will be able to continue our tradition  for so long as the need exists. Another contributor recalls that her late father started giving to the Fund 42 years ago  a tradition she and her husband are now carrying on even while supporting three sons in college. Again and again, supporters of the neediest stress the continuity of need. Now, on the threshold of 1980, for the poor, the sick and the lonely, anxiety must be sharper than hope. That is why the work of the Fund goes on from one year to the next. And the appeal for contributions, which began in early December, continues through January and February.

title: New Year's Is Coming, and Philadelphia Is Donning Plumes and Practicing Its Strut
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29  With stern demeanor, John Riecky, the captain of the Satin Slippers, stood watching a chorus line of stevedores, policemen, firemen, and operators of forklifts and tugboats as they tapped and turned to the strains of The Sidewalks of New York.

title: The New York Times Paul Hosefrm
description: Zipping through Central Park on roller skates at midday yesterday, wearing purple leg warmers, a purple shirt and corduroy cutoffs, Vicky Wesley looked like the sort of person who would know where stylish people would be celebrating New Year's Eve tonight. It so happened that Miss Wesley, a secretary, still hadn't settled on her plans. Last year, when everyone was going to discos, she spent her New Year's Eve at New York, New York. This year, she said, everyone is into roller skating, and that's what she plans to do tonight. The only question is where.

title: Outdors in the 80s: Acceleration but a Shift in Direction
description: WHILE outdoor recreation has emerged as a phenomena with mass appeal in the 1960's and 1970's, the decade ahead is expected to see it becoming an increasingly significant factor in the lifestyle of Americans, absorbing a greater chunk of their time and income. Sonya BullatyAngelo Lomeo and The New York Tunes

title: Coffin and His Liberal Pulpit Renew Legacy of Controversy
description: When Riverside Church went looking for a new senior pastor three years ago, the search committee considered 250 candidates and unanimously settled on the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr. We were looking for somebody to stand in the line of prophetic preachers, said the Rev. Eugene Laubach, the church's top administrator, to continue the tradition of an open, liberal pulpit, and TO stimulate some controversy.

title: New York's Hospitals Will Gain by Filling Fewer Beds
description: Hospitals in New York State are about to receive stateestablished subsidies for keeping some of their beds empty. The subsidies, embodied in state hospital financing regulations that take effect at midnight tonight, represent a radical new approach by the Carey administration toward containing hospital costs.

title: Deaths
description: NADLERPhilip S. Suddenly. Be loved husband of Bernice, lovInt brother of Rose, Irving, and Jeanne Funeral services today 1:45 P.M. a the I.J. Morris Inc Funeral Home 1895 F I atbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Governor Orders Rhodesians to Curb Rebel Infiltration
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 30  The British Governor, foi the first time, has ordered Rhodesian troops into action along the country's eastern border to curb infiltration by guerrillas in violation of the ceasefire agreement, a British spokesman said here today.

title: 4 Concerns in Atlantic City Plan Major Casino Complex
description: ATLANTIC CITY  On an undeveloped wasteland 17 blocks from the Atlantic Ocean, four major hotel companies are moving ahead with plans to open a casino strip here that they hope will outshine the Boardwalk strip. Special to The New York Times

title: Bees Hindering Cleanup After Mauritius Cyclone
description: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, Dec. 30 (Reuters)  Huge swarms of bees are adding to problems of rescue workers cleaning up after a cyclone struck this Indian Ocean island last weekend.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Tough Tests For Iacocca's Skill and Savvy

title: Sports World Specials
description: Sparky Anderson has learned fear, and the whitehaired manager of the Detroit Tigers thinks he will be better at handling his men because of it.

title: Pay Deductions For Child Support Urged in Study
description: A fiveyear study of child support in Michigan, published this month, has proposed the establishment of a nationwide system of direct childsupport deductions from wages as the best remedy to a problem that last year cost the American taxpayer $8 billion in welfare payments and enforcement costs. David L. Chambers, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School and author of the study, says, If a Federal system were established under which withholding occurred from the first moment of a court order and traveled with a person wherever he took work within the country, the need for much of the current enforcement would largely disappear. His findings were published earlier this month in Making Fathers Pay  The Enforcement of Child Support (University of Chicago Press).

title: Richard Rodgers Is Dead at Age 77; Broadway's Renowned Composer
description: Richard Rodgers, the world renowned composer and lyricist, died at his East Side home in Manhattan at 10:28 P.M. last night after a long illness. He was 77 years old. A spokesman for the family said funeral services would be private. The Garrick Gaieties, A Connecticut Yankee, Babes in Arms, The Boys From Syracuse, Pal Joey, Oklahoma! Carousel, South Pacific, Flower Drum Song, The King and I, The Sound of Music. What binds together these disparate musical comedies is a single phrase spanning 55 years of Broadway: Music by Richard Rodgers.

title: Nova Scotia Bill Criticized
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 30 (AP) The Nova Scotia legislature, by a 26to16 vote, passed a bill on Friday that union leaders claim was intended to sabotage their efforts at organizing the 3,500 Michelin tire workers in the eastern Canadian province. The bill was a 500word amendment to the province's Trade Union Act, and took effect after its passage.

title: 100th Annual Statistical Abstract Bulges With Thousands of Facts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  While won't tell you how many angels can dance on the head of a pin, the centennial edition of the Statistical Abstract of the United States has enough data about Americans to stagger even the most voracious collector of facts. Special to The New York Times

title: Sporting Gear
description: Slalom skiers need not worry about shattering and possibly being cut by bamboo gates with the introduction of the flexible hinged pole called RapidGate. The safety poles feature a 360degree automatic spring reset action that makes them virtually shatterproof. When struck, the pole, built of a thermoplastic resin, folds down until the skier is past, and then springs back to its original position without the assistance of a gatekeeper. RapidGate is also useful for trail markers or for identifying danger areas. Each RapidGate costs $20, plus shipping charges, and can be purchased from Athalon, 333 East 52d Avenue, Denver, Colo. 80216, (303) 6234721.

title: Flyers Win and Streak Reaches 33
description: DENVER, Dec. 30 (AP)  Brian Propp, a rookie, scored the Flyers first goal Saturday night and added a secondperiod assist as Philadelphia withstood a late Colorado Rockies rally and hung on for a 32 National Hockey League victory that extended the team's record streak without a loss to 33 games. A capacity crowd of 16,452, the largest ever for a Rockies home game, watched as the Flyers improved their wonlosttied record for the season to 24110. The Flyers only loss this season came in their second game, a 92 setback to the Atlanta Flames on Oct. 13. They started the streak the following night, with a 43 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs at the Spectrum in Philadelphia.

title: Afghan Events Affect BonnMoscow Links
description: BONN, Dec. 30  The events in Afghanistan appear to be quickening a cooling in relations between West Germany and the Soviet Union, a development underscored yesterday by rare Soviet criticism of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday a Weather at 1 P M National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Around the Nation
description: KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Dec. 30 (AP) A salvage diver swam through the hull of the capsized ore ship Lee Wang Zin yesterday and reported no signs of life. The Coast Guard began operations to scuttle the 714foot Taiwanese freighter, giving up the search for 28 missing crewmen. Two bodies were recovered last week.

title: Building Materials Sales Slump With Tight Credit
description: LOS ANGELESThe LouisianaPacific Corporation, in Portland, Ore., issued a terse announcement recently: Rather than prostitute a valuable timher inventory by converting it into finfished goods inventory either to be sold at depressed prices this winter or possibly to remain unsold until business picks up next spring, 1..P has scheduled holiday closures, shift curtailments and three mill closures.

title: Notes on People
description: The setting will be Buckingham Palace, a leading role will be played by Queen Elizabeth, and the famous profile of Alfred Hitchcock will be displayed to great advantage when the master of the mystery and suspense film is invested in ceremonies early in 1950 as a Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire.

title: The Region
description: Talks resumed yesterday afternoon in an effort to head off a New Year's Day strike against a publicly run bus line serving Long Island and Queens. Contract negotiations went on from Saturday morning until 7:30 A.M. yesterday with substantial progress reported on noneconomic issues. The contract of Local 252 of the Transport Workers Union expires at midnight tonight. George Arnold Jr., president of the local, has warned that the members would not report for work tomorrow if there was no settlement.

title: Canadian Monetary Goal
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 30 (Reuters)  The Bank of Canada has announced a new target range for annual growth of the basic money supply of 5 to 9 percent from the average level of the second quarter 1979. The previous range was from 6 to 10 percent from a June 1978 base, and the actual growth from that date to the second quarter 1979 was 8.1 percent a year. The basic money supply consists of cash in circulation and money in checking accounts.

title: St. Mark's Poetry Project Off
description: The St. Mark's Poetry Project benefit scheduled for New Year's Day at the Entermedia Theater, 12th Street and Second Avenue, has been canceled. No substitute date has been set.

title: 100 Retired Subway Cars Will Rejoin Fleet
description: Extensive defects in a fleet of 759 subway cars purchased by the city from Pullman Inc. have led the Transit Authority to retrieve from storage 100 older cars that had been retired several years ago because of costly maintenance problems. Fiftythree of the cars have already been placed in service and 47 more will follow, after cleaning and temporary repair that will cost $200,000, according to officials who insisted on anonymity. In addition, a consultant has been retained to examine ways to modernize the older cars and to eliminate the problems that originally led to their removal.

title: Stephanie J. Stokes, Editor, Married to Reginald Oliver
description: Stephanie J. Stokes, a senior editor at Essence magazine in New York, was married in Seattle yesterday to Reginald A. Oliver, manager of the Castro Convertibles branch store in Jamaica, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Samuel Berry McKinney performed the ceremony at the Mount Zion Baptist Church.

title: Accrediting Associations Are at Center Of Debate Over Evaluation of Colleges
description: The accrediting of colleges and universities. an almost sacrosanct activity shrouded in confidentiality, is facing challenges from critics in both education and government who believe that the process has failed to keep pace with changing conditions. An emerging view of students as consumers, entitled to protection from such abusive practices as inadequate teaching time or overcrowded classes, is leading to questions about the effectiveness of accreditation in assuring educational quality. At the same time, colleges and universities themselves are arousing concern with aggressive recruiting practices and controversial academic policies that, some critics say, are overlooked by accrediting agencies.

title: Vilas Topples Dent In 5Set Quarterfinal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 30 (AP)  Topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina battled five sets today before ousting 13thseeded Phil Dent of Australia in a raininterrupted, fourhour match to gain the semifinals in the $400,000 Australian open tennis tournament. Vilas, the defending champion, downed Dent, 62, 36, 76, 46, 62. He will next meet thirdseeded Victor Amaya of the United States, who beat countryman, Peter Rennert, by 76, 64, 64 today.

title: JOHANNA BERGMANN
description: Johanna Bergmann, a philanthropist who was active in the United Jewish Appeal and the Parkinson's Foundation in Golden Beach, Fla., died Saturday at Memorial Hospital in Miami after a long illness. She was 84 years old. She was the widow of Augustus H. Bergmann, who was a director of the American Home Products Corporation. They were former residents of Great Neck, LI., and had retired for Florida about 22 years ago.

title: HELEN CARYL BRATTRUD
description: Helen Caryl Brattrud, who retired 10 years ago as a publicity woman for CBSTV, died Saturday in Presbyterian Hospital in San Fransisco. She was 77 years old and had been living in the Bay Area since her retirement. Miss Brattrud joined CBS during the 1930's, after attending the University of Wisconsin and graduating from Hunter College in New York City.

title: Bridge:
description: The new generation of bridge players had a field day in the recent Fall Nationals in Cincinnati  especially three players in their early 20's: Jeff Meckstroth of Reynoldsburg, Ohio, Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., and Bobby Levin of Miami, who each won two major titles. Levin, as winner of the Blue Ribbon Pairs and the Reisinger Teams, the two prestige events of the 10day tournament, won the Herman Trophy for the best overall performance.

title: Economists See Mild '80 Recession
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 30  The business outlook for 1980 is for a moderate recession ending late in the year, a recession less severe than that of 197475, according to leading economists attending the annual meeting of the Allied Social Sciences Associations that ended here today.

title: Egypt and A.I.D. Sign Phone Pacts
description: CAIRO, Dec 30, (Reuters)  The United States Agency for International Development and Egypt signed agreements today worth $332.5 million for improvements in the telephone system and development planning studies in the Sinai peninsula, officials of the agency said.

title: For Mike Newlin of Nets, Discipline Is Rule of Life
description: IT is nearly three hours before gametime when Mike Newlin's black Mercury Cougar pulls into the nearly empty parking lot at the Rutgers Athletic Center in Piscataway, N.J., the current home of the New Jersey Nets. in a rew moments, he is out on tne silent basketball court, his white athletic socks pulled up to the bend in his knee, his unusual blacksoled basketball shoes making solitary squeaks on the polished floor. He practices jump shots, layups, turnarounds and hooks. Then he moves to the freethrow line. Looking down at his feet to make sure they are placed an exact distance from the line, he holds the ball as if it were his offspring  purposefully yet quietly, with obvious tactile enjoyment and a curious care. The pattern begins: glance down, bounce the ball, hesitate, look upward, release. Through the hoop. He continues the routine until he reaches the limit of consecutive free throws he has set for himself on this day.

title: Kathryn M. Mesney Is Bride of Louis Hetler
description: Kathryn Muriel Mesney and Louis Hetler, who are on the theater faculty of the Cornish Institute of Allied Arts in Seattle, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: An End to Social Promotions
description: For years, teachers have routinely advanced pupils at the end of the school year even if they hadn't learned to read, write, multiply and do all the other things that they were supposed to have been taught. The motive for such social promotions has often been a mixture of kindness and defeatism : slow learners should stick with their peers  especially when their teachers feel unable to bring them up to par. New York City's Chancellor Frank Macchiarola, convinced of the wrongness of letting students graduate with meaningless diplomas, has come up with a practical way to end these automatic advancements. His proposal will have to be approved by the Board of Education before taking effect, and it is encountering mixed reactions in public hearings around the city. So the idea is a courageous one. It also responds to the increasingly desperate needs of New York City's school children.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TO DAY

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: REFLECTIONS Recently, toward dusk, the pool by Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater mirrored abstract images of passersby. Watching the bustle and resting under the poolside trees, two strangers began casual conversation. No names were exchanged, New Yorkstyle. Talk was pleasant and effortless. Yes, goingout prices would be up, up, up this new year; everything else was. Still, the city offered so much free.

title: Drive to Encourage Vasectomies Urged at Peking Birth Curb Talks
description: PEKING, Dec. 30 (Reuters)  A birth control symposium in Peking has resulted in a call for a campaign to make vasectomies and male contraceptives more acceptable to Chinese men, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: A BROA D AT HOME When Man Does Not Matter
description: BOSTON, Dec. 30  It was the decade of Pol Pot and Pinochet, of Idi Amin and the Shah, of Brezhnev and Kissinger. Even in this terrible century, as Hannah Arendt called it, the 1970's were notable for their inhumanity. If there was a link among the brutal politicians who flourished in these last years, it was their ability to treat human beings as abstractions, to brush them aside. People had to yield to the imperatives of ideology, megalomania or national power.

title: Iran Indicates Waldheim Won't Get Warm Welcome
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 30  Iranians indicated tonight that Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations would not receive a warm welcome when he arrives here later this week.

title: The 70's Or, Show And Tell
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  In the 1970's, my mother asked me if I wanted to be popular or make a lot of money. I was robbed by two blacks in pink fedoras. We communicated via handguns. A .22caliber pistol spoke of dirt streets, ruptured plumbing. A .357magnum made demands: sex, money, power.

title: Withdrawal of City Police From Subways Assailed
description: The head of an Assembly panel on transit safety yesterday criticized Mayor Koch's decision to withdraw New York City police officers who have been assisting transit policemen in the fight against subway crime. A spokesman for the Policemen's Benevolent Association, meanwhile, said that more policemen were needed throughout the city.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Allison Sue Donenfeld Wed to Malcolm Nichols
description: At the Woodbury (L.I.) Country Club yesterday afternoon, Allison Sue Donenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Paul Donenfeld of Oceanside, L.1., became the bride of Malcolm Swift Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Nichols of Carlisle and Long Pond, Mass. Rabbi Nathaniel H. Schwartz performed the ceremony.

title: Advertising
description: SINCE Kenneth Roman became president on Sept. 15 of Ogilvy & Mather U.S.A., responsible for the New York office with its $350 million or so in billings, there have been quite a few changes  new creative and media heads, assignment changes and additions in account management and 29 names trimmed from a payroll of 900.

title: ESSAY Rejected Counsel's Return
description: WASHINGTON  Remember the Rejected Counsel? He's the White House staffer whose job it is to go into the Oval Office in times of crisis and say Mr. President  do the popular thing! Take the easy way! The President can then say: Some of my advisers have suggested that I do what is politically popular. I have rejected such counsel He is apparently alive and well in the Carter White House. For the past two days, Press Secretary Joseph L. Powell has been buttonholing reporters to press upon them the details of a political memorandum he wrote to the President. Since Mr. Powell does not usually leak to all and sundry such confidential advice to his boss, the information is necessarily suspect  indeed, those cushionshot press releases are usually the opposite of the truth.

title: Red Wings Beat Islanders
description: DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP)  Danny Labraaten scored after only 1 minute 47 seconds of play to ignite a fourgoal Detroit surge in the first period as the Red Wings jumped off to a quick lead and defeated the New York Islanders, 42, tonight. The victory was only Detroit's second in its last 10 games. The Islanders have now lost 15, equal to the number of losses they suffered during the entire 197879 season, when they compiled the best wonlost record in the National Hockey League.

title: 7 Jersey City Men Arrested After Rampage in Village
description: A band of seven young men from Jersey City went on a threehour rampage in the West Village yesterday evening, indiscriminately beating and robbing pedestrians and attacking patrons in one restaurant, the police said. The rampage began at 4:50 P.M. in a PATH station at West Ninth Street and ;the Avenue of the Americas where two people were beaten and then robbed of a jacket and an undetermined amount of money, the police said.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1979

title: Reunion Recalls Those Gone With the Wind
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30  Forty years after the premiere of Gone With the Wind, more than two dozen of the people who helped make it gathered here Friday night for a reunion and love fest honoring perhaps the most popular motion picture ever made. Special to The New York Times

title: Connecticut Drivers Must Carry Insurance Identification as of 80
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 30 (AP)  Connecticut drivers will be required to carry nofault car insurance identification cards in their motor vehicles beginning Jan. 1. Under a new state law, insurance companies were required to mail identification cards to all Connecticut vehicle owners. Drivers are to keep one copy of the card at home and the other in their vehicle.

title: The Editorial Notebook Enough of Economic Fits and Starts
description: The much heralded recession is starting fitfully, and the Carter Administration is still waiting to see how severe it will be before recommending a tax cut or other stimulus. Quarters of growth have been following quarters of decline. Sharp drops in auto production may be masking a healthier general economy. But by the time the recession's severity has become clear, it will be too late for Government to respond. It takes many months for tax cuts and easier money to turn economic decline into advance. if next summer's economy is too limp for political comfort, there will be nothing constructive to be done about it.

title: Reading Level Of City's Pupils Shows Decline
description: In a dip from 1978 levels, 60 percent of the students in New York City's public elementary and junior high schools read at or below the national average, according to last spring's annual citywide reading tests. The announcement of the scores yesterday by School Chancellor Frank J.Macchiarola came when some other big cities were finding a slight upturn in reading scores. The results for New York City showed that while 43 percent of the pupils in Grades 2 to 9 read at or above their grade level in 1978, only 40.3 percent did in the tests last June.

title: November Tool Orders In Slump
description: Orders for machine tools, which have been at a high for most of the year, dropped 23 percent in November compared with October and were 1 percent below the order rate for the similar month last year. But Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst 01 the machine tool industry for Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc., said in an interview that even with the downturn, the level of orders for November, which totaled $435.75 million, was still high.

title: The City
description: The wife of Imamu Amiri Baraka, the playwright, charged that her husband, who was convicted of resisting arrest, was being held as a political prisoner at the Rikers Island jail.

title: MAYOR AT MIDTERM: A NEW CONFIDENCE
description: After two years in office, Mayor Koch says that despite some disappointments, his onthejob experience has made him a more confident and a less anxious Mayor. Relaxing in shirt sleeves at a large conference table in the Blue Room of City Hall. Mr. Koch made his comments in a 90minute traditional yearend interview with City Hall reporters last week. With characteristic ebullience, he recalled some of his administration's accomplishments and sketched his expectations for the coming year.

title: Deaths
description: ADLEREdward M., who gave his life in rescuing the life of another from the attack of a violent assailant. Beloved nephew of our Board members, Dr. Simeon and Bette Guterman. We extend deepest condolences and highest admiration to his family.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The situation in Iran is impossible to solve on a facetoface basis. The Iranians refuse to yield. And the United States has no options. It cannot surrender the Shah at present, and even if he were within our territory as a guest, as he was in New York, we could not. No honorable country could surrender him. And military action is impossible. We could bomb Iran, or blockade its ports. But what would the effect be on the whole Arab world? What would happen to the oil supply of half the world? What would Russia do? And what would happen to our hostages? Austria decided to teach the Serbs a lesson in 1919. We know the result.

title: BUSINESS. Digest
description: A moderate recession ending late in 1980 is expected by leading economists. But it would be much shallower than the 197475 downturn, said the economists, who were attending a meeting of the Allied Social Sciences Associations in Atlanta. They also expect nonstimulative tax trimming and continued high inflation. [D1.] MONDAY. DECEMBER 31. 1979

title: Jennifer Ann Berger, a Nurse, Wed to Neal Harrison Penny
description: Jennifer Ann Berger, a nurse at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, was married yesterday to Neil Harrison Penny of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Penny of Bedford, England. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Berger of Pomona, N Y., at whose home the ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Arnold Edelstein.

title: Time Names Khomeini Man of Year for 1979
description: Time magazine has named Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's revolutionary leader, as its Man of the Year for 1979. The magazine's editors said they sought to identify the individual who has done the most to change the news, for better or for worse.

title: Pope Upholds Censure of Liberal Swiss Theologian
description: ROME, Dec. 30  The Vatican announced today that the Pope and Roman Catholic Church leaders from West Germany had decided that the decision barring a liberal theologian from teaching must stand. But the statement expressed the hope that the theologian, the Rev. Hans Kiing, a professor at the University of Tubingen in West Germany, would after deeper reflection take a position enabling him to be reinstated.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Tip Leads to Actual Killer, Freedom for Innocent Man
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  There was nighttime robbery, three gunshots, a man dead on the sidewalk. An eyewitness said: I am sure of this guy's face. I will never forget his face. Bradford Brown was convicted and sentenced to prison, 18 years to life. After nearly five years, Mr. Brown has been set free because the real killer pleaded guilty. Those who have reviewed the case see no glaring mistakes, and no obvious way to prevent a recurrence.

title: JapanRolls Jet Pact
description: TOKYO, Dec. 30 (AP)  The Japanese Government has decided to allocate about $7.5 million for the joint development of a jet engine for commercial aircraft by Japanese companies and RollsRoyce (1971) Ltd., officials said on Friday. Three Japanese companies and RollsRoyce, the stateowned British jetengine maker, signed a 30year contract earlier this month for the $584 million project to develop a mediumsize engine with high fuel efficiency and low noise and pollution. The Japanese companies are IshikawajimaHarima Heavy Industries, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Kawasaki Heavy Industries.

title: Denver to Open Complex Of Repertory Theaters
description: DENVER, Dec. 30  Denver is preparing to join the theatrical big leagues tomorrow night with the opening of a repertory theater complex planned to rival, if not outshine, the Guthrie in Minneapolis and Lincoln Center in New York. There are three theaters in the complex; they will open on Special to The New York Times three successive nights starting New Year's Eve. The third night will culminate in a special American National Theater and Academy presentation to honor Henry Fonda for his many years of distinguished acting.

title: Water Cut Off in Caracas
