description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 30 Reuters)  The four million inhabitants of Caracas were without water today after a mysterious explosion at a purification plant 10 the south of the Venezuelan capital last night. The president of the National Institute of Sanitary Works, Alexis Carstens, said the break would last at least five days.

title: Road to Kabul: Tanks Rolling
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 30  Fifteen years ago, when the Soviet Union, as a foreign aid project, built an impressive highway from its border down to Kabul, through the forbidding and legendary mountain range known as the Hindu Kush, some Afghans made nervous little jokes about the fact that the road seemed strong enough for tanks and troops carriers.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Verdi's Rlgoletto, 8. LUCIANO PAVAROTTI, tenor, Avery Fisher Hall,

title: Books of TheTimes
description: PERHAPS it was to ward off the evil eye. Or maybe we wanted to set a standard against which anything at all would seem an improvement. Whatever the reason, it somehow seemed appropriate to send out the old decade and ring in the new on a note of aereat. so we took up Stephen Pile's The Incomplete Book of Failures and Stan Lee's The Best of the Worst and settled down to read in a purple funk.

title: Valentine's Day Candy Found Safe After F.D.A. Tests Boxes for PCB's
description: There was heartening word from the Food and Drug Administration yesterday  it's safe to eat chocolates that come in heartshaped boxes this coming Valentine's Day, as an investigation has discounted possible container contamination. Valentine's Day Candy Found Safe After F.D.A. Tests Boxes for PCB's

title: Weizman Hopes Pact Becomes Buffer Against Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  Israel's Defense Minister, Ezer Weizman, expressed the hope today that the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty could be extended, with United States participation, into a multination buffer against Soviet penetration of the Middle East.

title: Simmer Streak Ends
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 (UPI)  Charlie Simmer's record goalscoring streak of 13 games was snapped Saturday night in a 43 victory by his team, the Los Angeles Kings, over the Minnesota North Stars. The Minnesota checking line of KentErik Andersson, Mike Polich and Tom Younghans shadowed Simmer the entire game and limited the left wing to just one shot in his quest to equal Harry (Punch) Broadbent's alltime N.H.L. streak of scoring in 16 straight games, set in 192122.

title: All Liquor in Metric Bottles
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)  The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms says that as of Jan. 1, all imported and domestic distilled spirits must be bottled in metricsized containers. The agency has approved six metricsized containers: 50 milliters 0.7 liquied ounces); 200 milliliters (6.8 ounces); 500 milliliters (16.9 ounces); 750 milliliters (25.4 ounces); 1 liter (33.8 ounces), and 1.75 liters (59.2 Ounces). The bureau noted that nonmetric containers may continue to be marketed provided they were bottled before Jan. 1.

title: Brooks Potter, Lawyer in Boston, Dies After Automobile Accident
description: Brooks Potter, a senior partner in the Boston law firm of Choate, Hall & Stewart, died Saturday after an automobile accident near his home in North Andover, Mass. He was 77 years old. Mr. Potter was a 1924 graduate of Harvard College and joined the firm soon after. He was a specialist in domestic relations and fiduciary matters.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 30 (AP)  Missouri turned a fumble recovery, in the second quarter, and an interception, in the fourth quarter, into touchdown drives of 30 and 28 yards en route to a 2414 victory over South Carolina Saturday night in the Hall of Fame Bowl before a crowd of 62,785 at Legion Field. Phil Bradley, the Missouri quarterback, lofted a 28yard touchdown pass to David Newman on the first play after South Carolina fumbled a kickoff to give the Tigers a 106 lead they never surrendered. Bradley also scored on 1yard keeper as Missouri erupted for 17 points in a 5:09 stretch of the second quarter to erase a 60 South Carolina lead.

title: Brzezinski Increases U.S. Estimate Of Soviet Soldiers in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  President Carter's national security adviser said today that the number of Soviet troops in Afghanistan had grown beyond the 25,000 to 30,000 estimated yesterday and he urged Iran to settle the hostage crisis with the United States because Teheran could be next to face a Soviet threat.

title: WALDHEIM TO LEAVE FOR TEHERAN TODAY TO DISCUSS HOSTAGES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 30 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim will leave for Teheran tomorrow in an effort to negotiate the release of the Americans held hostage there. Mr. Waldheim announced that the Iranian Government had today accepted his proposal that he make the trip. But when asked if he would be received by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Secretary General pointedly declined to comment. Diplomats in all camps here believe that the Ayatollah holds the key to the hostages fate.

title: Brazil May Seek Loans
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 30 (Reuters)  Brazil's Finance Minister, Karlos Rischbieter, said on Friday that Brazil might have to raise between $14 billion and $16 billion in foreign loans next year to finance its balanceofp,-ments deficit. He did not disclose how much Brazil borrowed in 1979, but economists said the foreign debt was approaching $50 billion at the end of this year.

title: The City Will Pinpoint Arson Prone Buildings By a Computer Search
description: New York City plans to use a computer to pinpoint arsonprone buildings and identify landlords who may be contemplating burning their buildings for profit. Using statistics from city agencies, an arson strike force has isolated many characteristics of arsonprone buildings in hopes of supplying the addresses of such buildings to authorities by April.

title: China Reports Record Harvest
description: PEKING, Dec. 30, (Reuters) China's grain harvest set another record this year with production estimated at more than 315 million metric tons, an increase of over 10 million tons from last year, the New China News Agency said today. (A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds.) The agency, reporting generally increased farm production, said the biggest single reason was new rural policies under which peasants were now being paid for the amount of work they do. In addition, private plots have been reintroduced, encouraging workers to increase output and earn more.

title: Methodists Differ on Films on Sex Made by Pastors
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 30 (AP)  Explicit sex movies produced and filmed by ministers are causing an uproar within the United Methodist Church. Screenings of the 10 films, intended for sex counseling, are proper if the viewers are carefully selected, according to the Nashvillebased Board of Discipleship. But some church leaders and members want the screenings discontinued.

title: New Jazz: Leroy Jenkins
description: THE Public Theater's new jazz series concluded its fall season on Friday and Saturday nights with an unusual presentation by the violinist and composer Leroy Jenkins. One uses the word presentation advisedly, for Mr. Jenkins choreographed some 22 episodes involving various permutations of his eightpiece group and used the multitiered stage set up in the Public Theater Cabaret and a variety of lighting cues to enhance the changes in personnel and mood.

title: Rafael Bonnelly at 75; ExDominican President
description: Rafael Filiberto Bonnelly, a former provisional President of the Dominican Republic, died of cancer Friday in Santo Domingo. He was 75 years old. From 1962 until 1963 Mr. Bonnelly presided over a transitional Government that was credited with helping to pave the way for democratic elections after a coup that toppled the long entrenched dictatorship of Rafael Trujillo, and a brief period of rule by Joaquin Balaguer.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 25, 3, 13, 4, 6 and 5. The supplementary number was 33.

title: Tabriz Rebels Adamant on Their Hostages
description: TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 30  As the captivity of the American hostages in Teheran continued into a ninth week, the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has found itself unable to force the release of nine of its own Revolutionary Guardsmen held hostage here by the followers of a rival political Party.

title: Savings
description: KINGS PARK, N.Y.  The United States has one of the lowest rates of personal savings of all of the industrialized nations. The level of the savings rate must be raised. To be very attractive, savings must be reasonably competitive with other types of investments, as well as be able to counter the effects of inflation. The solution is to exempt completely personal savings account interest from taxation. There are a number of advantages to this approach.

title: New Soviet Motives Emerge
description: The movement of two Soviet motor rifle divisions into Afghanistan appears to change the character of the intervenHon from an effort to support the Russiansponsored regime in Kabul to the first phase of a serious and potentially costly operation to eliminate rebellion.

title: Space Shuttle Problems Cut Support for Other Missions
description: Three planned scientific missions, one for rendezvous with comets, another to study the sun and a third to orbit and probe Jupiter, have run into political trouble as a result of the space shuttle's continuing development problems. Budget cuts necessitated by the shuttle's increased financial needs have imperiled the comet mission, according to sources at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The plan had been to send a spacecraft past Halley's Comet in 1985 and fire an instrumented probe into the comet's head, then proceed to longduration rendezvous with the comet Tempel 2 in 1988.

title: National Science Medals. Awarded to 20 Specialists
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  President Carter has awarded 20 National Medal of Science decorations, which are the highest honors accorded United States scientists and engineers by the Federal Government. Special to The New York Times

title: Deaths
description: SHAPIROPauline. Beloved sister of Fay Sherb, devoted aunt of Martin, Alan, and Michael Herbert, Ben Sherb and Susan Sternfeld, and cherished greataunt. Services BoulevardPerk West, 115 West 79th Street, Monday 1 P.M.

title: California Campaign For Voucher System Of Education Dropped
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30  Advocates of a radically different voucher system of education have abandoned their camipaign to get it on the June ballot. Special to The New York Times

title: De Gustibus Please Don't Squeeze the Coconuts
description: On three separate occasions I have been asked how to select various fruits and vegetables. One lady who grabbed my arm and ear was in a great state of perplexity about the choice of eggplants. How do you select an eggplant with small seeds? Another wanted to know the best way to select a juicy grapefruit. A third wanted to know if I would buy tomatoes during the winter months.

title: Opera: Miss Scotto Is Gioconda at Met
description: THE Metropolitan Opera performance of La Gioconda on Friday night featured four principal singers new to their assignments with the company. Chief among them was Renata Scotto as Gioconda, a role she sang for the first time in her career last fall in the San Francisco Opera's openingnight international telecast. Miss Scotto's familiar virtues were amply in evidence, her sensitivity for the style, her shrewd husbanding of vocal resources and her care for giving the words a very specific dramatic character. When all is said and done, though, Gioconda cannot be numbered among Miss Scotto's most congenial parts or as one of her more impressive Met achievements.

title: Kansas State Tops Arkansas, 6657
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark., Dec. 30 (UPI)  Rolando Blackman scored 22 points to lead Kansas State to a 6657 basketball victory over Arkansas today. Arkansas dropped its third straight game after six victories with a frustrating series of missed shots in a final surge against the Wildcats.

title: Rangers Conquer Capitals by 52
description: At one end of the ice Rick Green, Washington defenseman, had just thrown his body in front of an empty net to deny Ron Duguay of an apparently easy goal. At the other end of the ice Steve Baker had given up a goal on a long slapshot by Antero Lehtonen. On the bench, Mike Nykoluk, the Rangers assistant coach, was thinking, Oh no, not again. Nykoluk was strangely nervous, he admitted, for a coach with a 42 lead in the third period and en route to a 52 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: Arson Suspected in Fatal Chicago Fire
description: The Chicago Sun times / Jerry Tomaselh and United Press International

title: World News Briefs
description: CAIRO, Dec. 30 (Reuters)  Egypt has frozen about $2 billion of Arab deposits here in retaliation for economic sanctions imposed against it by other Arab countries, Economy Minister Hamed Abdel. Latif elSayeh was quoted as saying in an interview published today. Dr. Sayeh told the weekly magazine Rose el Youssef that a military order had been issued banning the withdrawal of  Arab deposits in Egypt for national security considerations.

title: Soviet Says It Sent a Limited Force To Help Afghans Repel Aggression
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 30  The Soviet Union, in its first public acknowledgment of its intervention in Afghanistan, said today that it had sent a limited military contingent to that country to help repel aggression from abroad. The statement, which is to appear in tomorrow's issue of the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda, was read on the main Soviet television evening news program. It said the Soviet troops would be withdrawn from Afghanistan when they were no longer needed.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A long forward pass In National Football League game is intercepted by the opposing safety, who runs the ball back and is tackled after he crosses the original line of scrimmage. He fumbles the ball, and it is recovered by the quarterback who first threw the ball. Can the quarterback, since he is still behind his line of scrimmage, throw another pass to the original receiver, who is still down the field? No. He can run with the fumble, but an offensive team may make only one forward pass during each play from scrimmage.

title: For a Rhodesian Rebel Leader, It's Time for Peace
description: ST. PAUL'S MISSION, Rhodesia, Dec. 30  After 30 months of guerrilla warfare Sithunywa Zithe and his men came in peace last night to this burnedout mission hospital in western Rhodesia. When the 41yearold commander in Joshua Nkomo's Zimbabwe People's Revolutionary Army saluted a New Zealand Army major outside the mission gates at 7:35 P.M., he formally accepted the ceasefire agreed to in London on Dec. 22. With him were 55 other men, the largest single group to report so far among the several hundred black nationalist guerrillas who have renounced the war under the truce that went into effect at midnight Friday.

title: Kin of Korea Assassin Are Said to Have Been Tortured
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  The wife and brother of Kim Jae Kyu, the convicted assassin of President Park Chung Hee of South Korea, have been arrested, tortured and compelled to sign false statements against him, according to a cousin of Mr. Kim in the United States. The cousin, Doug K. Kim, recently visited Seoul where he said he learned of the torture and the forced signatures from Mr. Kim's wife and other members of Mr. Kim's family.

title: At U.S.C., the Rose Bowl Means Hollers, Dollars and Scholars
description: LOS ANGELES THE president of the University of Southern California was not seated where university presidents are supwsed to be seated at football games, in a private box between the 49yard lines, where they can hobnob with politicians, put the arm on corporate bigshot donors and avoid the students. On that day in Hawaii, almost 13 months ago, John Hubbard was not seated at all. He was standing with his football team, roaming the sidelines, ready to fight on for U.S.C. He was getting madder with each penalty.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Three Fashion Individualists
description: Just call her Jane. It's her professional name and the only plain thing about Jane Spielberg, a young new designer with long lashes, brown eyes and lots of curly dark hair who chatters and giggles as she shows her collection of clothing, belts, hats, bags and furs. Princess Donatella Missikoff doesn't mind being called Princess. A tawny blonde whose father was a Russian Prince and whose husband is a Swiss jewel dealer, she's produced a collection of jewelry that combines classic designs with the currently fashionable look of semiprecious stones in subtle colors.

title: Kuwait Oil Rises 19% To $25.50
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 30  Kuwait, one of the few countries that did not raise its oil prices before the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting 10 days ago, announced today that it is raising crude oil prices by 19 percent to $25.50 a barrel.

title: KANSAS CITY STRIKE LIMITS FIRE WATCH
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 30 (UPI) Only six union firefighters came to work today, leaving fire protection for the city almost entirely in the hands of police officers, National Guardsmen and nonunion supervisors. The combined work slowdown and sickout left only two of the 32 fire stations in the city manned by union firefighters. Eight of the fire stations were closed, and fire officials said 33 pieces of firefighting equipment were in service, compared with 53 during normal operations.

title: Rhode Island Railroad Up for Sale at $100,000
description: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I., Dec. 30 (UPI)  It is a little late to buy as Christmas gift, but for $100,000 John P. Miller is selling what he describes as a beautiful little piece of an America that's disappearing. Dr. Miller, a dentist from Newtown, Conn., says he is putting the Narragansett Pie??? Railroad on the block because he is ? ?d of making the long drive to Rh??? Island to operate his colossal hobby.

title: Rams Unload the Shotgun
description: IRVING, TEX. FOR five seasons now, the Dallas Cowboys had used their shotgun offense without much rebuttal from opposing coaches. In obvious passing situations, the Cowboys quarterback, Roger Staubach, would stand back about 7 yards from the line of scrimmage, take a direct snap from center, survey his receivers and then dissect the defensive coverage with his precise passes. In his career, Roger Staubach has guided the Cowboys to 16 victories in the last two minutes or in overtime, including four this season. those comebacks, he often was operating out of the shotgun offense that Tom Landry, the Cowboys coach, revived in 1975, after it had fallen into disrepute when abandoned the San Francisco 49ers nearly two decades ago.

title: Moan Over Miami
description: WHEN the Steelers whipped the Houston Oilers last winter for the American Conference championship in the National Football League, weather closed the Pittsburgh Airport and nobody could get out of town. When they mangled the Miami Dolphins for half of the same title yesterday, fog socked it in and nobody could get into town. At least, that's what U.S. Air said. U.S. Air used to be Alleghany Airlines. Only the name has chaneed. Flight 201 was scheduled to leave La Guardia at 9:45 A.M., but by 8:20 a notice on the departures schedule announced that takeoff would be delayed until 10:05. Then another halfhour delay was announced. Then another. About 10:45 the public address system brought word that the fog was lifting and passengers could go aboard. They did, sat down, and waival. Along toward 11:15 a stewardess said over the horn that the Pittsburgh airport was now open but the plane was experiencing a slight mechanical. She promised to keep passengers advised.

title: Bars Atmosphere Found Driving People to Drink
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 30 (AP)  The country twang of Willie Nelson, Kenny Rogers and WayIon Jennings as they sing of lost loves, lost lives and too much liquor may cause bar patrons to drink too much, according to Dr. James Schaefer, head of the drug and alcohol abuse program at the University of Minnesota. Dr. Schaefer studied saloons in western Montana in 1977 and 1978 when he was on the staff of the University of Montana in Missoula. But he said that bar atmosphere affected drinking habits everywhere, and that some atmospheres were risky for those who might indulge too much.

title: Brezhnev Is Told by Mrs. Thatcher She Is Disturbed by Afghan Coup
description: LONDON, Dec. 30  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has written to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader, to say that she is profoundly disturbed by Russian intervention in Afghanistan, her office announced today.

title: W. G. MALCOLM DIES; EXCYANAMID CHIEF
description: Dr. Wilbur G. Malcolm, former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the American Cyanamid Company, died Saturday at his home in Grand ViewonHudson, N.Y. He was 77 years old. Born in Moscow Mills, Md., and raised on a farm, he studied at the University of Maryland, where he earned his bachelor's and master's degrees and a doctorate in bacteriology.

title: Israel Defers Closing of Settlement
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 30  The Israeli Government today voted to extend for five weeks next Thrusday's deadline for the evacuation of militant Jewish settlers from Elon Moreh on the occupied West Bank.

title: Market Place
description: SHARES of the Franklin Mint Corporation have been decidedly out of favor since the company was mentioned unfavorably a year ago on the 60 Minutes television program.

title: Blazing a New Trail in Yosemite Park
description: Yosemite Valley, near the southwesterly entrance to the National Park, is known to all Americans for the magnificent rocky surge of El Capitan, and for the superb lacy drop of Yosemite Falls in spring and early summer. But too many holiday tourists know it also as the scene of frustrating traffic and overcrowding, more like sale time at a shopping center than summer at a national park. Now the National Park Service plans to reduce the congestion. It proposes to use $100 million in private, rather than Federal, funds. The idea is ingenious; it merits serious attention by Congress; it might be worth extending.

title: Flight Delayed by Bomb Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) raps World Airlines 727 jet was delayed at Washington's National Airport today after the airline received a telephoned threat concerning the plane, according to an airport spokesman. The plane, flight 321 hound from Columbus, Ohio, to Orlando, Fla., via Washington, resumed its journey after a search.

title: Rams Upset Cowboys
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 30  The Los Angeles Rams, who have never gone to the Super Bowl, upset the Dallas Cowboys, who have almost made it an annual habit of attending, by 2119 today on three touchdown passes by a neophyte quarterback. Special to The New York Times

title: Grahek Triumphs In 70Meter Ski Jump
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30 James Grahek, a 22year old college senior, has been ski jumping since he was 5 years old. Today, all that practice paid off. Special to The New York Times

title: The U.N. Today
Canada Budget Is Election Issue
description: TORONTO, Dec. 30  Canada's 15 million voters, who must brave the biting winds of a winter election on Feb. 18, are being presented with one of the most clearcut choices in their modern history in a campaign waged chiefly on economic grounds.

title: Blood Program Tries to Reduce Seasonal Deficit
description: With reserves of blood still at one day's supply, the Greater New York Blood Program was delivering blood only on an emergency basis yesterday. It continued its call for donors to alleviate a customary yearend shortage. The program, which supplies all 262 hospitals in the metropolitan area, was down to 2,000 units, according to a spokesman, who said types 0 negative and B negative were in particularly short supply.

title: Essex Gets Republican Sheriff
description: NEWARK, Dec. 30 (AP)  Charles Cummings, a retired Montclair police captain, was sworn in yesterday as the first Republican sheriff of Essex County. Mr. Cummings defeated the incumbent, John F. Cryan, in an election held two 1 months after Mr. Cryan was indicted on Federal racketeering, bribery and extortion charges involving bargaining for county jobs in return for political contributions. Mr. Cryan has pleaded innocent and will goon trial in January.

title: OutofTown Check for Neediest Includes Thanks to New Yorkers
description: The following letter was sent by a lawyer from Montreal, who asked to remain anonymous. Enclosing a check for $140 made out to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, he wrote: It's my privilege to send this contribution once again at this season. This is my way of saying thank you to New York City (and The Times  be it not forgotten) for all the many pleasures I have enjoyed in The Big Apple.

title: Home Permanents Spring Back
description: The years from 1965 to 1977 were bad enough to make homepermanent manufacturers tear out their hair.

title: Water From Third Main Break in a Month Cascades Down Fifth Avenue
description: A jogger stepping through a swirling stream created yesterday on Fifth Avenue at 17th Street after a water main burst. Streets in the area were closed to traffic as The New York Times/ Paul Hosefros repair crews sought to locate the break and the source of an accompanying odor of gas. Twelveinch mains ruptured recently at Varick Street and on lower Broadway.

title: Steinbach's Closing in Plainfield
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 30 (UPI)  Steinbach's department store will close in midJanuary, ending 25 years of busi1 ness, the company has announced. Store officials say the move was caused by financial reasons, including inadequate sales. The closing leaves Bamberger's the sole department store in this city of 45,000.

title: A Calendar for Every Taste
description: From years past, as far as calendars are concerned, we best remember the pinup and the winter landscape. But for 1980, instead of the timeless and often innocuous images of the past, calendars are appealing to people with the special interests of the present. For the muscleconscious, there is the Arnold Schwarzenegger calendar, with exercises, which is $4.95 at Waldenbooks. For francophiles, a review of the year's fashion shows, en franca's, in Les Jours et La Mode, $30 in vinyl, $35 leather covered, at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue.

title: Winn's Approves Merger
description: Shareholders of Winn's Stores Inc. approved the previously announced merger of the variety store chain into Heinrich Bauer Verlag, a West German publishing concern, for about $50 million, at a meeting on Friday in San Antonio. Winn's operates 153 variety stores in Texas.

title: Mexican Tells of Torture in Secret Prison
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30  On April 9 this year. Berta Lopez de Zazueta and five other reputed guerrillas were arrested by the police in the northern city of TorreOn. Neighbors witnessed her detention and the incident was reported in detail the next day by a newspaper in nearby Monterrey. She then disappeared and the authorities repeatedly denied knoveledee of her whereabouts. On July 5, after almost three months of imprisonment at an unknown location, Mrs. Zazueta was to testify later, she and three other women from the group were blindfolded, taken from their cells, driven to a bus terminal in Mexico City and put on buses going north. Before being freed, they were warned not to talk of their experience.

title: Marsh &
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies, already the world's largest insurance broker, has close corporate ties in every major insurance market except the biggest, London. And now, it appears, Marsh & McLennan is making its move for that one.

title: Inspectors Ready to Check Homes on Their Energy Use
description: Energy officials are gearing up the vast machinery needed to evaluate the energy use of every homeowner in the nanon.

title: Charles Grossman, 84, Organizer For Socialist and Labor Groups
description: Charles Grossman, a veteran political organizer for the Socialist and Labor movements in New York City, died Friday at Mount Vernon Hospital. He was 84 years old. Mr. Grossman came here from Budapest, Hungary, as a 7yearold and made his living in later years in the printing trade. For more than a half century he was coowner of the Atlanta Printing Company in lower Manhattan.

title: Moslem Leaders Watching Revival Warily
description: TUNIS  The elites that lead and articulate the world of Islam are scarcely less perplexed and apprehensive at the surge of Moslem fundamentalism through their countries, and especially their youth, than is the West  but in a different way.

title: Wendy Schlessel Bride Of Dr. Edward Harpham
description: Wendy Jean Schlessel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Schlessel of Great Neck, L.I., and Rocky Mount, N.C., was married at noon yesterday to Dr. Edward J. Harpham, son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Harpham of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Michael Rosen performed the ceremony in the Garden Suite of the TerraceonthePark in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.

title: Julie Agronsky, Nurse, Is Married
description: Julie Agronsky, an oncology nurse at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, and Dr. Stephen Romansky, chief resident in psychiatry there, were married yesterday afternoon in Washington at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Agronsky. Rabbi Joseph Weinberg performed the ceremony. The bride's father, a journalist, is host of the CBSTV program Agronsky & Company, which is also carried by the Public Broadcasting Service..

title: NUMBER PUT AT 30,000
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 30  The Soviet combat troops sent south across the border into Afghanistan in recent days are being deployed into scattered parts of the countryside, according to reports reaching Islamabad today. Large numbers are thought to have taken up positions in the north of the country, where some of the fiercest fighting of the last few months in the spreading rebellion by Moslem tribesmen has taken place.

title: Earthquake Recorded In Area of Greenwich; No Damage Reported
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 30 (UPI) A slight earthquake rumbled through the tip of southwestern Connecticut and the New York State border today, startling residents but causing no damage or injuries. Dr. Edward Chiburis, assistant director of the Weston (Mass.) Observatory, which records seismic events in the Northeast, said the quake measured a magnitude of 2 or 2.1 on the Richter scale.

title: Battles on Revenue Sharing Set Stage for 80 Showdown
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 30  The disclosure that President Carter had recommended that the states continue to receive a third of general revenuesharing funds. reversing his previous stand, aroused little attention compared with the size of the power struggle that preceded it. Special to The New York Time

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON A PROSPECTIVE change in American tax laws, which has the strong backing of Treasury Secretary G. William Miller and now the support of the Senate Finance Committee, would make it easier for American enterprises to borrow overseas and use the funds domestically. The problem now is the 30 percent general withholding tax on the interest received by the foreign lenders or bondholders. The foreigners dislike paying taxes to Uncle Sam. Perhaps even more important, they object to having their names recorded for fear of drawing attention to themselves in the revenue collection centers of their own countries.

title: U.S. Opposes Bank Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)  The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit on Friday to block the merger of two major banks in Utah. The merger of the Zions First National Bank and the First National Bank of Utah would eliminate potential banking competition in Cache County, Utah, John H. Shenefield, Assistant Attorney General, said. Zions First National has 47 offices in the state.
